text: This is my favorite camera of all time. Purely manual, needing a battery only for the meter, and with bullet-proof construction, classic good looks, and very manageable weight. I've tried Leica, and Zeiss, and a vast array of digital cameras, but this is the one I would never part with. It has aperture priority mode, fully manual mode, and shutter speeds from B to 1/4000. Metering is center-weighted, with no "spot" option (the only thing I would change). The meter can account for film from ISO 12 through ISO 6400. It allows for multiple exposures and exposure compensation. If has extremely capable TTL flash and fill flash capabilities. It will use almost any Nikon lens ever made (just not the modern "G" ones, and there is an almost limitless supply of used lenses to check out.If you are interested in film photography and want to get away from digital, but don't want to risk a lot of your pictures "not turning out", this is an excellent first choice camera. If you already shoot film, already use Nikon digital, or just want the best film camera you can buy, this is also an excellent choice.

You can't beat the price (free at the time of this review). But like so many free Kindle books, this is difficult to read for two reasons. One, there is no table on contents. This is an over 600 page compendium of several old books, but there is no way to jump from one book to the next. Two, there are tables of genealogies which are exceedingly difficult to navigate in this format.Perhaps worthwhile if you just want to read straight through, but probably not worth your time if you need to skim or use it for a class.

I love this. A lens cap is mostly useful when your camera goes into the bag, where it needs to stay on to avoid scratching the lens with the cap itself. And that's exactly where many lens caps fail (in my experience), by popping off on the edge of the bag. This cap can't do that. It is slightly slower to take off, but when I'm shooting, I walk around with the cap off anyway, so that isn't a detriment for me. I use it with the Zeiss 50mm f2.0 ZM Planar and it stays put far, far better than the weak cap that comes with the lens.This is cheap, it fits, and it works quite well for my style of shooting. Highly recommended.

These are the best double edge blades I've found. They are sharp, cut well, and last me about 4-5 shaves, which means this box will last me about 18 months. Since it cost about the same as a 4 pack of Mach3 Refill cartridges, I'm definitely saving money, and getting a better shave while I'm at it. Plus it's fun. What's not to love? Try them.Highly recommended.

I'm just getting into medium format photography, and this is amazing. I'm enjoying this film so much I'm considering selling my digital camera. Some day, perhaps, film will no longer be made, but until then, I'll be shooting this and Tri-X . The colors are wonderful and accurate, the grain is superfine, and it scans well.Highly recommended.
Like the rear lens cap from the same company, this fits well, is sturdy, stays on in my bag, and protects the lens. Can't ask for more.Highly recommended.
It's a lens cap. It is sturdy, it fits well, and stays on in my bag. No complaints.Highly recommended.

Does Tri-X even need a review? This is absolutely the classic black and white film. I develop it myself, and have pushed it two and three stops without difficulty. Developed as ISO 400 it is also fantastic. If Tri-X has a fault, it's that it is too easy to use. The exposure latitude can make you lazy, because chances are if your lens cap was off and you pressed the shutter, you got the shot.So much fun, highly recommended.

I love this. It stays out of the way of all important buttons, improves my grip, and makes shooting easier. The grip itself matches perfectly with the camera finish, and indeed I forget that it didn't come with my x100s. I had tried another product for this purpose, the Fotodiox Pro Thumb Grip for Mirrorless Digital Cameras  and while it worked out, I was bothered by the fact that it requires a small screw applying pressure to the hot shoe to stay in place. It also didn't fit as snugly as this Lensmate version. The higher cost of this accessory was worth it.Highly recommended.

The best thing about this is the cost. It fits my Fuji X100s fairly well, but the part that fits into the hot shoe is just slightly too narrow, and so arm rocks forward a hair while in use. Additionally, it is fixed to the hot shoe by a tiny hex screw which presses into the shoe when tightened. It probably won't damage the camera, but I spent too much on the camera to let a couple of dollar accessory damage the hot shoe. I upgraded to the Lensmate version http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E259GQI and am quite happy with the change.

These are cheap, well sized, they hold tightly and protect your lens. Can't ask for more. I'm not a fan of the lens keeper bit, but that holds true for all lenses, since the dangling cap is just plain annoying. The good new is the keeper comes separate, and you don't have to attach it.Highly recommended.
It's just a great classic sounding country song. Clearly channeling her father and grandfather here, but with a style all her own.Highly recommended.

Just heard these guys in the gym, and I had to stop my workout to figure out who they were. The music is great, simple and upbeat. Certainly not a lot of lyrical depth, but that may come with time. The misuse of an apostrophe in their name is a bit silly and though some argue it's no worse than the mis-used umlauts in Mötley Crüe's, at least there you know the band was in on the joke. Here I just have to wonder if the band and their label know the difference between a plural and a possessive.All of which has little bearing on the music of course. If you like the clips of "San Francisco" and "The Great Divide", you'll likely enjoy the whole album.Highly recommended.

I came to this book knowing almost nothing about beekeeping, and picked this as an introduction. I finished it with a great appreciation of the art, and even more for the wonderful insect we all depend upon. The authors cover (apparently) all that is needed to start an apiary, and cover everything from an organic perspective.Chapter one is a discussion of the pros and cons of this specific hive type. Though all the examples in the book are based on the top-bar hive, a lot of the information translates to other hive styles as well. Chapter two is an overview of honeybee biology, and discusses organization, bee types, and the concept of the "superorganism", the idea that a hive can be conceived of as a single organism. He then proceeds in chapters 3-5 to discuss beekeeping basics and hive management.This section was enormously impressive to me, as he lays out the system by which the beekeeper decides how to rearrange combs to encourage or discourage swarming, to maximize honey production, and keep the hive healthy. Chapter six discusses the particulars of extraction of honey from this hive style, and details how he cleans combs and harvests the wax, using mostly solar power. He then discusses evaluating queen health, treating and managing disease, and raising queens. The book closes with a discussion of planting to attract and feed bees.I am not yet a beekeeper, so my evaluation is not one from experience, but I feel the information in this book is sufficient to give me a start at it. It is quite well written, well organized, and has clear, pertinent pictures illustrating concepts. I loved reading it and am anxious to put these concepts into practice.Highly recommended.

It is apparent to any thinking person that we can't run from pollution forever. Eventually, every "over there" becomes here, and our culture regarding manure (both animal and human) has failed to embrace this fact.Mr. Logsdon seeks to address this deficit. He covers practical aspects of animal manure handling, discusses how these considerations are different and similar to human manure handling, before moving on to the basics of microbe science and how we actually reduce soil fertility by depriving it of these natural fertilizers. He closes with a discussion of how this relates to large scale municipal waste and its use as biosolid fertilizer for commercial farming.While much of the information here is found in other references as well, no one else can write it with Logsdon's wonderful style.Highly recommended.

There are good aspects to this film. A lot of the science is well presented, the interview subjects are well chosen, and the message is clear. However, the multiple video-game like interludes and reenacted scenes from the life of the presenter add a bit of "late night infomercial" atmosphere that is tough to watch.The weakest aspect though, is that it doesn't really address the fact that the meats and vegetables eaten by paleolithic people were nothing like the meats and vegetables available to us today. It doesn't address the problems inherent in grain-fed meats. It also glosses over the fact that our grain-eating ancestors were able to wipe out or replace their non-grain eating competitors. These are common criticisms of the Paleo diet, and they must occur to anyone watching the film, so it was tough to see an otherwise strong effort to support this diet fail to answer the most common critiques.Probably worth watching, but I'm glad I didn't pay for it.

I wanted to like this film. As other reviewers have stated, the filmmakers rent an acre of land in Iowa and use it to grow corn. During the process they interview farmers, ranchers, and agribusiness executives about the way corn figures into the food system in America. They make high-fructose corn syrup in their kitchen. They interview random people in parking lots who make authoritative but unsupported shocking claims about the effects of corn.Most of what they cover is touched on in other films more extensively, and this isn't the best made or most informative work on the subject. But it does provide a thought-provoking look at how ubiquitous corn is in our diet, and asks some good questions about the way we've constructed our food system.Recommended with reservations.

This is an immensely hopeful genre of film, if only because the subject is so important. And while the amateurish cinematography and 16mm vintage look interludes were initially distracting, I grew to appreciate both over the course of the film. Overall, an engaging set of profiles of small farmers, similar to "To Make a Farm", but here only showing American farms. The other work is better shot, but with a similar feel.Recommended.

I love this genre of film. As an armchair farmer, who dreams of expanding his large-ish garden into a moneymaking enterprise, I've watched quite a few films like this. So I am familiar with the message and style. This is very similar to The Greenhorns, except from a Canadian perspective. Quite enjoyable, but if you're debating spending money on this vs. watching something for free (assuming you have Amazon prime), the biggest advantage this has over other choices is slightly better cinematography and cool Canadian accents.Recommended.

Improbable violence, with a small team of retired operatives taking down the security apparatus of an entire government. With Bruce Willis on your side, anything is possible, right?Quite enjoyable, and highly recommended.

I have an LED battery operated Ottlite that I really like for travel---it's very light and bright.  However, the batteries do run down; I decided to look for an AC adapter and found this one.  It works perfectly.  I had concerns about whether some of the others would fit the adapter port on the light; this one fits perfectly.

I've been enjoying this series so much. It just keeps getting better and better.  The main characters are fun and funny and have been developing through the series.  But my favorite is Aunt Tillie; we learn more and more about her as the series goes on.  This episode has a high school reunion as its backdrop, and who hasn't wanted to cast a spell or two on a few people in their high school class?  A very satisfying addition to the series; possibly my favorite so far.

This is a repeat, from April 2013.  It's well reviewed, though, and a good game, so if you didn't get it before, here's your chance.  I actually got it then, but hadn't played it (it was one of those 3AM ET gets; I went back to sleep and then forgot about it. :D)  At that point, it had only had a few reviews.I've played it now, and it is very much a keeper.  It's a platform game with a unique twist--that draws from those sliding tile number games from when I was a kid.  Once you get into the game a bit (level 1-3), you have to rearrange the tiles to finish the course.  Tap out to see the entire game board, slide a tile to allow a clear path for the next bit, and doubletap to resume play.  Doubletap again as needed to go out and rearrange tiles again.  A great original twist! You can play on without beating the time.  Graphics are simple and fun.  Tested this on my 8.9" Kindle Fire HDX, but I think it would work as well on smaller devices.Love this game...

This series is as much about self acceptance as it is a fun series of kinda-cozy mysteries.  Three young women who happen to be cousins and who happen to be witches are coming to terms with their witch-ness....and solving mysteries while they do so.As always, Aunt Tillie is keeping them on their toes, this time while they're dealing with love, family and a new supernatural threat!

This series gets better every book.  As we get to know the main characters--Bay, Clove and Thistle--and their family better, the mysteries that they solve get more and more interesting.  And the love interests are hot!

This is the third in this series by Amanda Lee.  Each one has an exciting mystery to solve and a little bit more of the family history and relationships is revealed.  I love the three main characters--Bay, Clove and Thistle--their mothers and their Aunt Tillie.  Each book in the series has had a little more magic in it, too, which is great.  The town the stories take place in is a character of its own.  If you like cozy mysteries, and you like witch tales, you'll like these!

This is the second in the series and I liked it better than the first.  There was a bit more magic--I do expect witches to cast spells--and the relationships are getting better established.  Looking forward to the third in the series!

I was drawn in immediately by the story.  The idea of software embedded in one's brain that allows telepathy is compelling.  The descriptions of the intimatcy of that connection were beautiful.  I enjoyed the characters--the cerebral Kade Lane and the awesome agent Samantha Catarnes are both characters I could root for.  I can't wait to see what happens next.

I picked up this as part of today's multi app free promotion as I'm a Apple AND Amazon kind of girl:This is an app you add to your Fire TV or Fire TV Stick  (or, I guess, you could have it on a Fire tablet--it's compatible with my Fire HDX) which then, with the addition of a free app on your iPad/iPhone, allows you to mirror the iOS device to your Fire device.I have a Fire TV Stick.  I installed the above app on my Stick and then downloaded the iOS Mirror assistant to my iPad.  Connection was pretty straightforward. And the Mirror Assistant from the iTunes App Store will walk you through it.Open the app on your Fire TV and select Mirroring Assist from the pink bar.  The QR code thingy will become active.  Underneath it will have the device number for your Fire TV (Android-AFTM-xxxxx) and a nine digit Mirroring ID.  When prompted on your iDevice, either scan the QR code or enter the nine digit Mirroring Id (without hyphens) to connect the device.  On your iDevice, swipe up to access the Control Center and select Air Play and turn on Mirroring.I found that there's a bit of a lag with the Fire TV Stick. Video didn't work well, and even switching screens and photos sometimes lagged. This may be one instance where a Fire TV's extra processing power helps.  But still, I can see me using it occasionally (and this may give me the excuse I need to upgrade to a Fire TV).I would pick this up now as it's free and hope the developer makes it better for video.  But still, if you want to share your photos from your trip and don't have an Apple TV, this might be the thing for you now.

This is a standard mahjong solitare game where the tiles that you match are coffee themed.  Other than the different tiles, the twist is that you play against a countdown timer to try to get through ten layouts in a level.  I got through seven.  This may be frustrating for some.  I'd give this game three and a half stars.  I'd give it four if there were an option to play untimed.

I enjoyed this book--I think the character of Katerina is getting fleshed out and developing into the kind of strong, feisty female character I love.  In the first book of the series, I felt she let things happen to her, in this one she starts to take control of her own destiny.  The nascent love affair between her and the Greek cop Melas is being developed tantalizingly slowly.

[url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00HA8WNZ0/?tag=kb8-20][img]http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/21HnPp9zGLL._SL160_.png[/img][/url]This is a most beautiful and unique variation on a "path" puzzle.  You try to guess the correct path between pairs of shapes. You cannot cross a drawn path. The difficulty builds gradually, in lieu of a tutorial.  You start with the most basic set and work on, adding multiple paths as you go.  The shapes that have to be joined have a white shape within the shape; empty shapes are intermediate waypoints that must be crossed.  For example, starting points might be triangles with a small white triangle inside.  When you get to multiple paths, you can only cross a path at a designated intersection  (designated with two interior shapes) that both paths must pass through.  For example a stop-sign shape with two little diamonds inside.When you've connected two shapes, the entire path is outlined in white. An illegal move will show with a red outline. When you've completed the puzzle correctly, the entire drawing turns solid white and the next game appears automatically.As you connect shapes, you hear little electronic boops.  I like that you can turn the sound on and off easily in mid game by tapping on the little triangle at the top of the page; a drop down that allows you to end the current game, resume or mute/unmute the sound appears.  Tap on the little triangle now at the bottom to go back to the game

I'm charmed by the star of this cozy series, a young Greek-American woman who finds out that her family history is not what she thinks it is.  I did think that there was a brief stretch in the middle where not quite enough happened but the beginning and ending more than make up for it.  Great characters and lots of Greek ambiance.

I really enjoyed this cozy murder mystery set in the midst of a dysfunctional family of witches.  It's told from the perspective of one of three cousins, Bay.  The cousins, their mothers/aunts and Aunt Tillie are always squabbling with each other, but stick together when it counts--like when they're trying to solve a series of murders in their home town.It left me wanting to see what happens next to the cousins, not to mention Aunt Tillie!Great fun.

It's an arcade-style puzzle game.  Each level, you get an increasingly complex obstacle course of dots, bars and arrows which may or may not be moving and which sometimes have special attribues.  The goal is to flick your playing piece, a small circle, through the obstacle course, bouncing off or passing through the course to the target, where it will be sucked in if it gets close enough.  You have to get there within a set number of bounces.I found this quite enjoyable--I'm up to level 45 now.  Some of the levels are quite challenging--it's often just the matter of a degree or so in the angle you choose to flick your playing piece.  There doesn't seem to be anywhere spyware installed, it plays in either portrait mode and plays in airplane mode on my 8.9" Fire HDX

This is a quite intriguing and quirky puzzle game.  You are exploring a world, one level at a time, one puzzle piece at a time.From the main menu, you can play, set options for sound, look at the credits, or click on a link that takes you to web pages about the game including a YouTube video.Clicking on Play, you'lll see the  main levels.  I recommend tapping on the two Demo modes and playing them, as they demonstrate two different kinds of game play.  In one of them, you have to drag the playing piece and match it up to the starting piece.  You can select the pieces given in any order.The other mode, you only have to tap the piece you want to play, but the game determines which piece has to be placed next.  I found this more difficult.  In both modes, you earn points for solving quickly and can earn up to three stars per level, so there is a replay value.From the main level screen, you can tap on any available level (some will be locked initially) and select an available sublevel to play.In the games where you fill the designated spot next, too many wrong moves/and or time will cause you to lose the game.  You can replay.  Levels that have been won can be replayed in either mode (pick the piece of fill the spot).There is a little chiming noise that is heard when you play a piece in some modes.  That is an audible cue to how many stars you've earned for that piece--1,2 or 3 stars based on time.  If it annoys you, you can turn it off from the main menu.Playable in either landscape orientation.  Exits cleanly using the exit button (door) and plays in airplane mode.I give this game four and a half stars, though I can see I'm going to have a challenge earning all three stars on all levels.  The stars give it replay value.  The only negative is it's a bit dark and the pieces can be tiny even on my 8.9" Kindle Fire HDX.  Recommended for larger tablets.

I found this book to be boring and disjointed with utterly unlikable characters.  I just couldn't get interested in what happened to them.  I've liked other things the author has written, so I was disappointed to not like this one.  As the reviews are largely positive, it probably just didn't resonate with me--your mileage may vary.

This brain "training" game was the FAOTD back in January 2014.It's a good game, though I think the instructions for the games could be a bit more clear and include an example--a couple of games it took me a couple rounds to figure out exactly what I was supposed to be doing.  Or perhaps that's part of the test. :D  You can play as a guest, or create a user so that your scores can be tracked.To see how you've done on various games, tap on "Games" on the main menu.  You'll get a grid with your best score and you're most recent score for each game you've played.  You can also choose the game you're going to play or play next.  Games that are in similar categories are color coded.You can schedule a reminder to play a game.The game quits cleaning using Quit on the main menu.  It plays in airplane mode and can be played in any orientation.

This is a physics based game built around golf. I'm not usually interested in golf games, but this is more like Angry Birds with a golf club than like a real golfing game. I liked this game.There is a tutorial, I recommend it. You can also play a practice course, which I also recommend. You earn golf bux by completing achievements and can then use the golf bux to unlock power ups or purchase additional shots. You can buy additional golf bux, but you earn a lot by playing the game and earning the achievements. You can pinch to zoom in and out.Use the controls on screen to aim your ball and then the Go meter to change the strength of your swing. I didn't like the popup ad that appeared the instant I opened the game, but haven't had another popup. Hopefully they won't be too intrusive--they shouldn't be in a paid game. The game plays in airplane mode and in either landscape mode.I give it three and a half stars--would have given it four but docked half a star for the popup ad in a supposedly ad-free game.

This is a quirky but intriguing addition to a hiking app repertoire.  It shows you the view from the top of various peaks and labels the mountains you can see.  You can also pinch or spread to zoom in and out.It needs some work.  The controls and menu system aren't all intuitive. The initial mountain peak database isn't complete, which isn't made clear.  You need to tap on the "i" icon to go to Info and then tap on "coverage" to go to the world map.  Pinch or spread to change the part of the world you are viewing. You can tap on the map to select a tile of coverage to install.The first tile installed automatically was my local area.  The tile installed includes the map and elevation data and the peaks that can be searched in the database, so if you want peaks from a different area--say, Everest in Nepal--you'll have to download that tile separately.  I'm going to be traveling to San Diego soon, so I downloaded that tile and was then able to search for Mt Laguna and Mt Soledad, two mountains I know I'll be visiting (driving).I like that from the info page for a viewpoint, you can change your perspective (altitude) which allows me here in flat Alexandria to see more peaks.I recommend that users check out the user's manual at www.peakfinder.org/mobile/manual/This is definitely better than the reviews indicate, even with the flaws.  I recommend downloading it and fiddling with it a bit.  I'm going to use it when we go hiking in San Diego to try to figure out the view from the top of Mt Laguna.  I had no problems with crashes on my Fire HDX.it's worth having as part of your collection with hopes it improves.
Justified is one of the very best series I have watched in a very long time.  The cast and the writing are exceptional.  I highly recommend this series about a modern day cowboy.

I have found this show to be strangely compelling due to the cast.  The storylines are mostly ridiculous.  Apparently there is only one agent capable of doing anything in all of the CIA and she doesn't have to show respect for the agency or her bosses as long as she gets the job done.  But it's very attractive.  And I really like Augie.

This is an arcade/physics game where you guide your rocket ship along a path to collect objects and make it to a portal.  You guide the ship by holding and dragging your finger ahead of the ship.  I like the fact that inertia is factored in--the ship will try to follow the last path drawn and there's a slight lag in changing direction.  Other reviews complain about the lack of responsiveness--but I thought it was part of the "physics" aspect of the game.You can earn one of three achievement levels for a stage--the size of the star you earn changes based on the number of objects you scoop up and the time you take to do it.The graphics are kind of old style comic book, which I like.It plays in only one landscape mode, and is playable in airplane mode.  There's no exit button, but it exits cleanly using the device's back button. That's the good news.  The bad news is that you lose all of your levels and have to start over. :(  I like this game--I'd get it and hope they fix this.I'd give this game two stars--I think it's much better than the average stars, but the fact that it's not saving the progress in my game when I completely exit the game on my Kindle Fire HDX8.9 is a major flaw.

OK, it's about a Scot with a tentacle.  So I sort feel like I shouldn't rate it four stars--that's a pretty high ranking for me.  But it was so much fun to read.... Kit has a light deft touch to her writing.  I'm definitely going to seek out more by this author.

I enjoyed this book from start to finish.while it doesn't deal with the end of the world, it does explore the lives of a community that has been cut off from the rest of the world.  Loved the characters, especially the main character.

The books in this series start out with really strong scenes.  Though I don't think they quite live up to the promise of the opening scenes, I really like the main character, Jennifer.  She's both a real girl with the hopes and fears of her age and a kick-butt heroine.

This is a very nice tower defense game--I enjoyed it immensely.  You have to prevent "heroes" from rescuing a princess in a castle safe using various traps--spikes from floor, spears, acid dripping from ceiling, overactive air conditioning. The evil overlord is at the top directing the waves of heroes. You earn currency by accumulating "screams" from the princess (there is also a scream generator) and coins and screams that the heroes drop when you kill them (no blood).  There's also a flying monkey I haven't quite figured out.  Like Plants v Zombies, there's a meter at the top that tells you how you are doing with the waves of heroes.  Also like Plants v Zombies, you pick the traps that you are going to use for each stage.I didn't encounter any of the problems playing it with my HDX that some report in the reviews--unless I tried to play in airplane mode. Then the game would not advance past the splash screen. If played with WiFi on, the game played fine--I'm currently up to stage 7.The game does offer in-app purchases, but so far none are needed to make purchases in the shop; you are able to accumulate enough "stuff" to do upgrades, etc.One of the other top reviewers reports embedded spyware. This, combined with the inability to play in airplane mode, is a big red flag for those with security concerns. It's a shame, because it is a really good game.... I give it five stars for game play, but will probably bring that down to three for the inability to play in airplane mode with the spyware that's reported. You may want to pick it up and keep it in the cloud in case the security concerns are addressed, as it is a really good game.

This is your typical Mahjong tile matching game with the ability to choose tile sets (designs), the background and whether the tiles are animated or not.There is a Tutorial and also a Training Mode under options.You can access the options or Tutorial within a game by tapping on the top bar (where it has the clock and number of moves) and then tapping on the menu bar at the top.  At the bottom of the screen are two options to change the orientation of the tiles--this may help you see the board differently enough to recognize matches--a shuffle key that looks like a die (dice), an undo button, a pause button and a hint button (the "advance" button on the far right).  The hint button lights up a match--you have to look closely to see it.  The shuffle button adds 10 seconds to your time.  When you tap on the menu button at the top, you'll see a "play" button in the upper right which will solve the game for you.The game works well, graphics are attractive.  Nothing really unique but a good solid mahjong matching game.The two one-star reviews have nothing to do with game play or the purchase experience, so this is really three out of three that are four stars or above.I'd call it a solid four star Mahjong game bordering on five stars.  OK, I'll round up to five stars considering there are two bogus low reviews.

This is a cute physics based game.  You drop blocks of ice containing fish onboard your boat.  Each level you have a primary goal--total number of blocks, weight of blocks or height of blocks for example, a time goal and an additional goal of not knocking the dog off the boat (not sure if this is consistent on all levels).  You can earn up to three stars on each level.  Only the primary goal is mandatory to clear the level with at least one star.If a block falls off the boat, your level ends.  If you don't make the time goal or other goal, you clear the level but lose stars.My only issue is that there is no way to pause the game or start a replay within the level.  If you want to start over, you need to drop a block into the water to get the replay option.  If you clear the level but want to play it again, you have to go to "select level" and reselect the level.It's playable only in one portrait orientation, but is playable in airplane mode.I had no issues playing the game on my Fire HDX7

This is a kind of endless runner, er, faller game which is better than the average star rating would indicate.  Apparently back in 2012, when first released, it had some issues.You have a little gremlin who is very, very hungry and goes into free fall.  Using the tilt mechanism, you have to help the gremlin eat all the doughnuts, pies and cakes he goes by while falling and avoid the enemies. There is a health meter--if your health goes down to zero, you lose a life. Occasionally there is a new life powerup that he can consume to gain a life.  The game is over when all the lives are exhausted.  There are various levels with different enemies on different levels.You earn various trophies.  Unfortunately, once you earn a trophy, you can't tell what you earned it for. :D  Check out the trophy screen from the main page and tap on the trophy silhouette to see what you're aiming for.There is a calibration screen when you first start playing.  There is also a help screen on the Main Menu which basically tells you what you can probably figure out for yourself as you play--the game doesn't need much instruction.  Options include turning sound on and off, replaying the story or resetting the game.I liked the game as endless runners go.  It's more relaxed than some of them but gets progressively more challenging.  The controls work very well and the game is very intuitive--you'll figure it out very quickly.I'd give this four stars.

*This book was gifted to me in exchange for an honest review*As promised here is the review for Ghost Files Volume 2…Be ready for Ghost Files Volume 3.Apryl Baker does it again…she just keeps me on the edge of my seat with Ghost Files Volume 2. Her writing is so suspenseful its hard to quit! The book draws you in so quickly with Mattie having to deal with another foster home, and not a very nice one! I just want Mattie to be happy and free from all the hurt she has had to deal with. Thankfully Officer Dan comes to the rescue…or does he? I loved all the new characters that are introduced in this new book, the living and the dead ones. She meets some scary characters. My favorite scene in the book is when she meets the painter. I found this scene intriguing, scary, and confusing, but thankfully Miss Baker explains all the confusion away. Mattie and Dan also get to find out a bit about their pasts. Will this new information strain their relationship or will it make it stronger? With all that happens in this book, Ghost Files has me on an emotional roller coaster with heart break, stress, loss, and physical pain. I rate this book 5 creepy stars!

I went into this book blind. All that I knew was the tagline - "Things are not always what they seem" - and THAT is the best way to describe this book.Ice, is the President of the Regulators MC. He's a widower trying to raise a teenage daughter. Morgan is a prim and proper banker. Their worlds collide when Ice's daughter, Brooke, becomes best friends with Morgan's sister, Madyson - and when I say collide, I mean BOOM! Personalities clash. But when Madyson disappears, and Morgan begins her own investigation, Ice steps in hell bent on finding Madyson and taking Morgan as his own.I expected the same type of MC book. It wasn't. I can't give too much away, except to say when, WHEN is book two coming out! I'm giving this book 5 stars!!

I have read several MC books and I have to say I enjoyed the depth this series went in to.  These men all had more to them than just the MC, lots of things going on.  Definitely a different lifestyle, but a brotherhood just the same.  Family isn't always blood.

Whoa!! Kick is dark, violent, discomposing, and bloody. I'm still in shock - and I freaking LOVED every single bit of it. I could not put it down. Where do I even start? Kick is so broken, lost, and numb. Indie is totally shattered.Raised in a MC by a sadistic father, Daniel "Kick" Johnson is taught that brotherhood is everything. But when they take it too far, Kick betrays them. Now in another MC, Kick is fearful everyday that they will learn of the betrayal to his first MC. When Kick finds a kidnapped victim, he defies his orders to kill her, and decided to take her for his own, giving her a new name - Indie.Kick is far from the typical hero - he is NOT the good guy. You want to strangle him one minute and in the next, you are rooting for him to take vengeance. Carmen Jenner did an amazing job on this book. It scares me how she made me feel empathy for such a disturbing character, but she did.. I'm giving KICK a bloody 5-stars!!

Do you believe in fate?Skylar was a good time girl that barely got to know a guy’s name before she left him in his bed. Until one night she hits rock bottom, determined to change her life she chooses to do something selfless. After deciding to give up men and booze she decides to be a surrogate. Since she has never had a child of her own she has to go about the whole surrogate thing unconventionally. What she never expected was to find a new best friend and fall in love with her husband too.Griffin and Erin were high school sweethearts. Erin is not able to have her own baby and is not considered a good candidature for adoption so they never though they would have a child at all, until Skylar.Skylar meets Erin and Griffin and agrees to be their surrogate. She instantly bonds with Erin and she is instantly attracted to Griffin.“You know I love you, right, Erin? You know I’d do anything for you and I want to do this. I really do. I just need to know I’m doing it for the right reasons.”Skylar really evolves in this story but not so much that it is a complete surprise. You just know that she is a good person deep down and she just had to figure it out for herself. She does this with the love and support of her best friend Erin. Even though Skylar is in love with Griffin she would never betray Erin by acting on these feeling. Skylar experiences loss and learns to love in more ways than one. She finally gets to her true self only to lose her other half.After tragedy strikes everyone is left to clean up the pieces and figure out what is the truth and what has been planted by someone they love. Can they find a way to get to happy again?“Why do you always have such an issue with me saying f***? What’s your problem?” He blows out a long breath, “My problem is that it makes me want you, okay? When you talk like that, all I want to do is throw you down and scr*w the h*** out of you.”The heartfelt and unconventional relationship between these three people is beautiful. The author writes the story beautifully and makes you feel every emotion that Erin, Griffin and Skylar are going through. I laughed, cried, and swore at the unfairness in it all.The epilogue will leave you feeling good about it all and makes you realize that sometimes Fate has its own agenda.I know I haven’t given much away on my review and that was by design, it would ruin the story to give too many details.Have the tissues ready and be prepared to fall in love with all three of these remarkable characters. One last thing…READ THIS BOOK!Fate-Faith-Family

***Just a little note***Hold On is the EPIC (Yes I said EPIC) finale to the ‘Burg Series.  Each of the ‘Burg series installments can be read as a standalone BUT I am a huge believer in reading an entire series, because quite frankly I feel  you do not have a FULL picture of the world the author is trying to build if you only read a random book in the series.  Even when the author does a masterful job of recapping some of the secondary character history it still does not tell the whole story.  So if you haven’t read the series to completion and have no plan to I would skip the epilogue in this book because it is really a series epilogue as much as it is a book epilogue.  But who knows you may get intrigued by some of the other characters in the epilogue and decide to read the series in full so I take that back.On to the review…As I was saying Hold On is the FINAL ‘Burg series book and I could not be having a harder time letting go of these characters.  From page one of the series (For You) Kristen Ashley brilliantly brings to life the small town of Brownsburg and its crazy, loyal, loveable and sometimes completely broken citizens.  The series has angst, betrayal, love triangles, suspense and a LOT of lovin’.  So it is not a surprise to this reviewer that she chose to go out, coming full circle with this book giving us the story of Cheryl who was the bamboozled stripper girlfriend of Denny Lowe, the serial killer who was obsessed with Feb and Colt.  After finally pulling her life back together with a little help of Feb and Colt, the single mother and former stripper turned bartender, Cheryl and her son Ethan become part of the ‘Burg family.  This story is also about Garrett “Merry” Merrick the final single hot cop, who has been in the background for 5 books.Two lost souls that are friends but become so much more.Merry has been in love with his ex Mia since he left her and now she is moving on and he is miserable.Cher has been secretly in love with Merry for years but knows it cannot be anything more, well because he us hung up on Mia.Merry decides to drown his sorrows and everyone knows that you should never leave a friend to wallow in misery alone so Cher decides join in the shots and to enlighten poor Merry on a few things…“That’s bulls***, Merry, straight up.  You got good, you don’t let it go.  It lets you go, you hold on.  It slips through your fingers; you pull out all the stops to get it back.  You got something’ worth fighting for, you fight for it.  You do not sit on your ass waitin’ for it to come back to you.  You show whoever that is they mean something and you go all out on that, and the only way you go down is doin’ that s*** swinging.”Merry has some deep emotional baggage that he must overcome and Cher being a single mom and survivor needs to learn to finally trust others to help live instead of just exist.  Cher’s son Ethan is amazingly bright and charming and he steals the show many times in the book.  (He makes me want to go all gooey on him).Merry and Cheryl are great together, they have witthy banter, and can read each other's mood better than anyone else. The chemistry is there and it does not take long for that pull to start is magic.This installment of the ‘Burg is the no less dramatic, suspenseful, exciting and romantic than any of the other books in this series.  There is a healthy dose of all of them in the form of drama queen exes, certifiable stepmothers, dangerous neighbors, Ryker’s mysterious dealing and of course Merry and Cher themselves.  We touch base with familiar faces from the previous 5 books and we see how everyone is doing.The epilogue is what makes this book EPIC; I mean it is amazing and could not have brought me more joy if it tried.  I loved getting to see the future for some of my favorite book friends and love the slip in of one of my favorites of the hot bunch.Honestly I could wax poetic all day about this book because there is so much to love but since I have to get back to the real world I will wrap it up.Thank you Kristen Ashley for taking care of my ‘Burg friends.  Thankfully I own the series so I can always visit when I feel the need, which will probably be in a couple of weeks.5 stars does not come close to the amount of love I would want to give this book but alas that is not the way of the rating scale. So to show more of my love I am giving it 5 HEARTS!

Sometimes it seems so unreal that someone famous would end up with an average Joe.  This was a great story about what one person sees and what the person really is like.  I like this series so much I am starting the next book now!

I absolutely fell in love with Moxie!  With Moxie, you know exactly where you stand.  If you need an escape from reality, then you have to read this series!  I laughed so much at some of the things Moxie thought and said.

*I was gifted this book in exchange for an honest review.*Girls is a very intriguing book! First off this is Savannah Avery’s first novel, and I have to say it was a great book. This is a short book of only 144 pages, but that doesn’t mean it wasn’t a great read. There are four main characters in this book and each one is a mystery to me except for Coco because she is the narrator. I found it interesting that when Savannah wrote the book she waited until the end to explain how her and Kitty came to be. Her writing leaves an air of mystery around the entire story…it keeps you wondering. I wondered throughout the entire book..where were the parents, why didn't they care ect. But Miss Avery does a great job of answering all of your questions at the end of the book..so just hold out. Each girl was missing something in their life and I believe that is why the excepted M so quickly. Although it is scary how easily young girls can be influenced by someone so quickly. I found that M had some good advise about boys…don’t let them take your power. I did feel that Coco was a bit too dramatic about her and Mark in the beginning but it was a good flaw and made her a better character. This book was unlike anything I have ever read. It didn't have much suspense but I also couldn't stop reading it. The story just flowed for me and never became dull. I think that is because I wanted to see how M came to be who she was….was she a madam, was she abused as a child, was she planted in the school to get recruits? This was a book I will remember for a long time…I rate it 5 stars for originality, and content.

Great oil with a strong odor and flavor. I'm using it for toothpicks and I think it will be great for that application. Everything arrived perfectly but the packaging was a little flimsy so I'm glad it wasn't handled too roughly because it would have probably broke. Overall great product.

Very well built item with an o ring seal for the top. It was longer than I was expecting but still fits in the pocket well. It was an expensive item for it's purpose but you pay for anything titanium.
The bottle was wrapped well for shipping and the cinnamon oil has a strong cinnamony odor and flavor. I'm using it for toothpicks and it appears to be just what I was looking for.

I couldn't wait to dive into Tyler and Meredith's story. Laramie introduced Tyler Blackfoot in the first book of her Heaven Hill MC series, and something about the silent-but-deadly larger than life man made me want to know more. And Meredith - I had to know what happened! In Meant To Be, we witness the horrible attack against the "too nosy for her own good" reporter and Tyler finding her in the aftermath. Without a second thought, he became her protector and her shield.Where do I begin - I love the way Laramie writes. Her style allows you to see both sides; what they think, how they feel, and I enjoy reading stories like that. This is an MC book, but she gives us a glimpse into the harden shells that these men have had to erect around their hearts.One of the best things I enjoyed in this book, was the way Laramie treated Meredith's rape. It wasn't down played. The most tender moment for me was when Tyler tells Meredith about his tattoo - swoon worthy.This was a wonderful book, and with the introduction of Jagger (and Tyler's skull cup) I had to dive right into the next book in this series. I know I gave the first book a 4.5, but that was because it was the beginning of a series. The intermingling of new and older characters is a talent, and I wanted to see how her followup book would fare. I'm happy to say, I'm hooked and I love this author - 5-stars!

Meant To Be is the beginning of a new series by Laramie Briscoe. Denise is a single mother with two teenage children. No father, no child support, and losing her job when the factory closes, has her financially in a bind and she's getting ready to lose her house. When Denise picks up an extra waitress shift for Roni, her coworker, little does she know that she's now came under the radar of the local MC, Heaven Hill - especially Roni's brother Liam, the chapter's Vice President. When a deal goes bad and Denise and her children are caught in the middle, Liam puts her under his protection as his "old lady".Let me say, I read a lot of the MC genre books. Starting a new series is never easy. The first book is the introduction. It takes a lot to keep them fresh and new. Laramie Briscoe has taken both sweet and rough and created a believable MC world in the hills of Kentucky. At first, I wasn't sure I would like Liam, because of William, his father. But Liam showed that when he claims you as family, he protects his own.I loved the secondary characters. They are blended in with humor and a sense of honor.  Laramie Briscoe did an amazing job introducing and including the members of the club and extended characters from the small town.

I want to tell you how I came to read this book. I was at Books and Bourbon, which was a book signing that I attended in Kentucky. That’s where I met Apryl Baker’s and stopped by her table because of her book “The Ghost Files”. The cover drew me right in!  Also the fact that it will be turned into a Major Motion Picture says a lot about the book.  Not only does the cover pull you in…but the first page does as well. I couldn’t put it down, and I can't wait to read the second and third book as well. Apryl is a great suspense writer, and she is good at plot twists….(can’t give too much away). I would have to say this is more of a suspense book rather than a horror book. It just keeps you guessing.  Baker’s take on ghosts is pretty normal…its hard stray from what everybody knows. Her ghosts are typical, but they are creepy. Her take on the Reaper legend is pretty creative. I like that she also talked about wraiths in the story! It isn’t just about the ghosties.  Mattie is such a great character! She is tough, caring, courageous and daring. I also like that Mattie knows who she is as a person, and I feel like I can relate to her character (we have a lot of the same qualities). I found that I enjoyed the fact that Mattie handles her problems in a very teenage way. She just does, and worries about the consequence later. Although I am still kind of unsure of Officer Dan’s intentions, I like him as well. I love the banter between the two characters and the loyalty that Officer Dan offers Mattie. He really completes the story; I enjoyed the fact that he was so young and its easier for Mattie to trust him and his boyish good looks. Overall this books was a great read, and I can’t wait to review the next two for you!

This book is a fun little witchy book! Carlie is such a fun character, and she is somebody I would love to know and be friends with. I love how she is in touch with everything around her and how she cares for her little town. She is insightful, caring, smart, small but tough. I found that I enjoyed how much her craft keeps her in touch with nature, especially the moon.  I enjoy how Terry writes…he adds in little bits of life advise that just make sense. For instance this quote was my favorite, “take care of things that take care of you.” The book has many more of these fun, little insightful tidbits. I also like how Terry describes his supernatural characters..some of them are so unique. He also does a good job of describing the classic creatures as well….the mummy was my favorite!  I would have liked to have known more about what happened with Major he is only mentioned briefly in the story…I kind of expected him to be more of a protagonist. I would also like to see a book written about the grandmother, because Carlie mentions her powers so often.  Overall I enjoyed the book and have passed it on for others to enjoy…I rate this book a 3.5 stars!

*I was given a copy of this book for a honest review.MERK! I have been "Team Merk" since Debra Kayn introduced us to him in For Life. Oh, I love Cam, but Merk stole my heart. We all knew he'd been in prison for murdering a man, but when we learn the whole reason of who and why - well, that completely does me in.Merk has been haunted by the crime, because of a young girl's plea to help her. Being the only witness to the crime, she unwittingly helps to convict Merk for the murder. The young girl, Desi, is now a grown woman, who is one of the best pool hustlers around; and when Merk is hired, by Desi grandfather, to keep her safe, he sees his chance to make her pay for putting him behind bars.I love Debra's books. It's that simple. She has a way of showing a gritty, ugly side to the Moroad MC, and yet, somehow, she is able to endure these hardened criminals to our hearts. Merk is a haunted soul, and drink is his choice of addiction. Even when Merk was with Christine in For Life, the alcohol is what controlled his actions. Desi has a way of both infuriating him and calming him; and although the alcohol is always a temptation, Merk is finally finding peace with a woman who owes him.I'm giving this highly anticipated continuation to her Moroad MC series 5 stars! More, Debra! We need More!

To be quite honest I did not want to read this book, before you bite my head off let me explain. I am a HUGE KA fan.  ABSOLUTELY LOVE HER but I felt very little connection to these characters as they did not live in the 'Burg.  I know, I know I should have read the book before I made any judgments but like many people I loved my 'Burg characters.  I am protective of the people there and was worried I would not get to see them if this book took place in Chicago.  Gladly the book takes place in Chicago and the "Burg and we get to see A LOT of our favorite characters and the birth of Cal and Vi's baby Angela AND their wedding!!!  I LOVE CAL AND VI to the extreme so that was a super BONUS.So after re-reading the first 4 books in the series I decided that I should read this one because a) I owned it (I one clicked the entire series a while ago) and b) the newest and final book in this series is coming out Sept 1.  Let me tell you I was thankful I did.  I love these characters.  Benny and Frankie are complex and hilarious.  Frankie is broken and lost and she is living a half-life because she lost her boyfriend 7 years ago and in doing so she lost his family, who she loved very much.  Benny and the rest of the Bianchi's blame Frankie for the death of his brother and they have been holding a grudge for 7 years.Fast forward to book 2 in the 'Burg series (I highly recommend you read at least "At Peace' in the series if not the entire series before you read this one} Frankie helps save Benny's cousin Cal's woman Violet and is severely injured in doing so.  Benny realizes that she is the 'one', always has been and he is determined to get her.  Frankie does not agree and has a hard time getting over the guilt that is associated with being in love with her late boyfriend’s brother.“You were mine, even when you were his.”-BennyThis story is complex.  There are nasty family members, there is lots of healing and forgiveness and there is a lot of self-discovery.  This book is like the biggest onion you will ever peel and with every layer you cry a little more, No Joke.  Not to say that it is not witty, funny and sometimes downright hilarious.The Bianchi's are quite funny and endearing not to mention overbearing and a pain in the behind.  We see a lot of Theresa, Vinnie and Sal in this book and we see and finally understand the whole family dynamic a bit more clearly than in book 2.KA easily integrated our Chicago couple into the 'Burg and it did not feel forced or contrived, Seeing as Frankie made acquaintances in the 'Burg most noticably with Vi and Cheryl I hope we can look forward to her in the next book. Did I mention that there are a few of our Rock Chick friends in this one? I just about squealed like a school girl when it happened. EEPP!All in all I am very happy that KA did not disappoint and I am able to move on to the final *sniff* book in the series knowing all is well not only in the 'Burg but the Windy City as well.

This book was about more than the love story between two characters, it was about four character, two that have decades to make up for and two that have their whole lives ahead of them.Couple #1 Mike and DustyFirst Mike Haines who we met in “At Peace” when he was fighting a losing battle to win Violet’s heart event though we all knew, even Mike, that she was always going to be Cal’s.  He is a divorced dad of two teenagers that has been unlucky in Games of the Heart. He has not given up but he will not go into another relationship easily after being burned twice.Dusty Holliday moved away from the ‘Burg right after high school. She left everything, her family farm, her family and of course Mike, who was at the time her sister’s ex boyfriend  (whom she secretly loved)The death of Dusty’s brother brings her back to the ‘Burg and Mike.  What starts off as Mike going to give Dusty a wakeup call about her “bad behavior” ends up with them in bed and starting a relationship. Of course things don’t go smoothly for our couple, so when they hit a road block, in come Reesee, Mike’s teenaged daughter and Finn, Dusty’s nephew, to knock down that barrier.  It is nice to see that when Mike and Dusty do FINALLY get on the same page and they stay there.  They have many obstacles the biggest one being Dusty’s sister and Mike’s ex high school girlfriend, Debbie.  Not to mention exes that will not go away and the fact that Dusty has a home, business and life in Texas.Couple #2 Finn and ReeseeThey are in the background but as the relationship with Dusty and Mike hits a roadblock they scheme to get Dusty in town to stay. In doing so Finn and Reesee embark on a sweet journey of young love that has its own obstacles, the biggest one being Mike, who does not want his baby girl dating but especially not by a guy who is experienced like Finn. With a little help from Dusty these two find a way.Poor Finn has had the resposibility of becoming the "man of the house" dumped on his shoulders at the young age of 17. With Reesee he feels his age and that weight is not as heavy.Reesee is a child of divorce and ishaving trouble finding herself. Finn makes her feel good about herself and with little boost the her self esteem she seems to find her way.This storyline is simply adorable and I cannot tell you how much I enjoyed it.KA really brought this story full circle.  The relationship with Finn and Reesee lets us see what the relationship between Mike and Dusty could have been if Mike had not been with Debbie first. I am so happy Mike and Dusty as well as Finn and Reesee get their HEA.

Each of the books in The 'Burg series is meant to be read as a standalone but I highly recommend you read all the books in order, it makes them more enjoyable and also make the story flow better (even though KA does a masterful job of recapping with out repeating).Layne Tanner and Rocky Garrett have a past, Rocky left Tanner one day and never explained why. 18 years later Rocky's brother is investigating a dirty cop in the department, a case that Tanner was working as well until he was almost shot to death and now Rocky is determined to help, by trying to seduce the dirty cop. Tanner is not having it even if he is still pissed at Rocky and decides they should have a pretend relationship as a way to keep her safe and a way for her to find excuses to be at the station. She can get near the guy but not so near she will get hurt. Rocky reluctantly agrees.Rocky and Tanner butt heads at first then find a way to call a truce but when pretending feels real. emotions start to surface and feeling get hurt, can you still call it pretending?I liked Rocky, she is sad and it shows all the time, even when she tries to hide it. Tanner who knows her better than anyone else in the world can feel it like a heavy blanket and he is determined to find out what it is and help her fight it.“It’s not fake is it?” Jasper asked softly and Layne studied his son thinking he had vastly underestimated Jasper too.“It was, Jas, it isn’t anymore.” Jasper nodded. Layne continued. “She doesn’t know that yet, though.”Jasper stared at him then his mouth twitched before, very slowly, it spread into a smile.”Who knew a small 'burg could be so full of crime, especially crime as evil as the one being perputrated in Brownsburg, Indiana?The secondary cast of characters play a huge role in this book. There is Gabby the awful ex wife, Jarrod the cheating ex husband, Ryker the crazy yet likable sideckick, not to mention Dev the nutty ex CIA agent that is Tanners mentor and Tanners mother who hates Rocky with a firey passion. Tanner teenage sons play a huge role in this story because the crimes being commited are against children.With much going on in this book its a wonder that Rocky and Tanner actually get together. Sit back, buckle up and hang on tight because this book is crazy from the prologue to the end.
Lots of sexy scenes between Dylan and Gemma!  But there is so much depth to both characters.  This was a well written set of books with more to the story than just sex.  Loved both books!
Of course the hot motocross guy doesn't hurt, with all his manliness!  This was a great story line to match all the hot sex scenes!  I can't wait for the next book!

I'm using this as an autograph book of sorts. I'm an aspiring author and when I got to book signings I ask authors to give me one piece of advice.  This is the perfect size for that and fits in my purse.

Jay Crownover never lets me down, she is one of my go to authors. I love this point series, it's full of suspense and romance. You can't go wrong with any Crownover book, but I really think this series is crowning glory.
Lying Out Loud was an okay book. I enjoyed the first book, Duff much more. Predicable.
I get many compliments when I'm in this dress and it great for a petite frame. I'm 5'1 and it's about an inch above my knees.
I'm so addicted to this game!

I loved the first book, Love In English! I didn't want the story to end, this squeal was from the male POV. I love getting into the men's heads but this one was a little slow. Still a great read over all.
This is more of a self help book than a tool for writers. Not what I expected at all.

This works great in brown hair! It covers  the grey also between coloring. I can go an extra couple of weeks before getting my hair done using this. My only complaint is I can't find it anywhere local and I have to order it.
This was such a great series.  I especially loved the conclusion...or rather the beginning!  A beautiful story.  What a precious gift given to Grace, in Cain.
I cried for most of the book.  What a heart wrenching story.  A story about love and forgiveness.  Christina redeems herself in the end!

I was gifted a copy in exchange for an honest review.  I haven't met a Winter Renshaw book that I haven't fallen in love with. She has quickly become one of my go to authors.  Arrogant Bastard is a bit of a departure from her other books and I think that is a sign of what a truly talented writer Winter Renshaw is.  Jensen has to leave his father's house after he is caught in a compromising situation. He goes to live with his mother who he hasn't seen in years. She is married to Mark and he has two other wives in addition to her. They have a little community of sorts with the children from the three different sister wives.  They live a very private and religious existence. There are rules that have to be followed for just about anything you can imagine. When Jensen meets his mother's new family he is introduced to his stepsister Waverly. They are not related by blood, only through marriage and they become good friends. Jensen begins to loosen up Waverly's uptight ways and show her how to enjoy life and in the process they end up falling for each other but it's unacceptable for them to be together.  I really enjoyed this book and I can't wait for the next one in the series. I'm giving Arrogant Bastard five stars!

I've read all of D. Kelly's books and her Acceptance Series is one of my all time favorites. #TeamDanielforever! D. is one of those authors that I just one-click without even reading the free sample chapters, because her writing is so consistently great.  Cassidy is a woman that has had a very troubled childhood and as a result, she has a hard time accepting love and trusting people. She is full of insecurities and feels unworthy of her fiancé Zack's love. Zack is a total sweetheart and has been in love with Cassidy since they met when they were just kids.  On the day they were supposed to be married, Cassidy panics and runs out on Zack. There is some drama with a family member that plays a part in all this and it's the last thing an already insecure, Cassidy needs. Zack immediately goes after her. He has to somehow make her realize how much he loves her and always will.  This book is a sweet love story, but the steam factor is still there. In spite of the drama of her running out on their wedding, this book is fairly low angst. It's a nice departure from the typical bad boy books, to read about a genuinely nice guy that loves his woman and isn't afraid to show it.  Chasing Cassidy is a great summer read and I really enjoyed it. I'm looking forward to whatever D. Kelly has in the works. I'm giving Chasing Cassidy five stars!

*I was gifted this book for an honest review*Dying to Live is a sweet story that captures you immediately. Melissa has such intriguing dreams, and that is really what drew me into the story, along with who she meets in real life. I know that it was a short story but it still had such great content and I really loved how well Isobelle writes conversation between her characters....it flows nicely and is natural. This book also has such a great little twist at the end...I rate this book 4.5 stars! I can’t wait to read more by Isobelle Cate!

WOW!  The old quote about you can't go home rings true for Scout! From everything I've read, this book was written before to Kill A Mockingbird, but was rejected by the publisher.  I think I know why.This book finds Jean Louise a.k.a  Scout, all grown up and returning home from New York. Things in Maycomb, Alabama have changed. Jean Louise no longer see things through the eyes of Scout. She's finally able to see injustice's that were going on around her.Jean Louise narrates this book in her present tense, and as memories as Scout.  This is very witty and it is like a walk through old Alabama.  I found it to be a delightful and sort of disturbing.  Disturbing?  I think we are all fortunate to live in this era, where people are treated equally.  The sins of our past really bothers me, all of our prejudices and down right hate.This book was written in the 1950's, I think one of the reasons it was rejected, is because at that time it would have been very controversial. Harper Lee was very insightful and I feel she was well before her time.I think it's time to read to Kill A Mockingbird again.Harper Lee receives 5 stars in my book.

Broken Juliet by Leisa Rayven is squeal to Bad Romeo.  I enjoyed this book but it was so close to rehash of Bad Romeo, it was hard to tell a distinct difference.  Rayven set the bar so high with Bad Romeo, and Broken Juliet was a really good book. I hate to say this and I know it's not the popular opinion, but I was a little disappointed.Broken Juliet is from Cassie POV again. Since Bad Romeo ended in a cliffhanger, we all really wanted to know wht was going to happen. What did we get?  We really didn't get anything new, a few mind blowing scenes of whoopie. This book was really slow but so witty that it still kept my pages turning.I give Broken Juliet 3 stars.

River Savage writes another gripping story, this time it is of a real affliction that affects many military veterans, PTSD. I don't know much on the subject but what was written in the pages of Desertion has made me feel that is time I learned a bit more.Jesse meets innocent nurse Bell in Incandescent and again she has an encounter with him in Affliction. She becomes an object of fascination (because she does not fall for his charming ways) He tries to win her over with his lame pickup lines but Bell is not interested in a player like Jesse, no matter how hot she may think he is. She has not time for him or men in general.Jesse hides behind his easy going facade because he doesn’t want people to see the real him. He lets people see what he wants them to see, no more no less.Bell is stuck in situation that suffocating her even if she does not see it because she is busy taking care of those around her that she fails to see her life for what it is, existing.Bell decides to ask Jesse for help with a situation she has she goes to a club party and seeks him out. When a drunken Jesse takes a woman back to his room for a little fun he is completely thrown that it turns out to be his very own object of desire.I cannot say much more without giving away the good stuff but these two both have demons that they must overcome. In true River Savage form she takes you on this journey as Bell and Jesse fight these demons and try to survive and come out the other side together.I'm not going to lie at first I did not really like Bell, she was too innocent and bit of a woman child. But thankfully she starts to take control and she grows up and I grew to actually like her until I didn't, again. She is not Kadence. But she has her moments and in the end she was somewhat likable.Jesse on the other hand, I loved until I wanted to slap him silly, shake him, or possibly punch him in the face. Then I wanted to hug him and kiss him and soothe all his pain away.I would have given this story five stars and usually a River book does that for me BUT there were a few drawbacks to this one. But thanks to Ms. Savages ability to make you feel right along with her characters I only deducted half a star despite its flaws. My reasons for my hald star deduction are:1)Bell's friends, I mean really, these girls are a bunch of enablers. Cowing to Bell's situation and never really pushing her to be herself and not someone she thought she should be. The only SANE female that Bell knows before the club is her sister, AVA. She tells it like it is.2)Then there is the whole Jesse hooking up with another girl after hitting on Bell. I mean seriously, come on.3) Jesse and Bell's first time (I will say NO MORE)So to sum it up:This installment of the Knights Rebels is an emotional roller coaster that makes you want to put your hands in the air, screaming but at the same time hold on for dear life (still screaming of course). So grab your tissues, your alcoholic beverage of choice and hang on for another thrilling ride with The Knights Rebels.****ARC RECIEVED IN RETURN FOR HONEST REVIEW*****

Who knew getting  a flat tire could change your life? When the Joker pulls off the road to help a woman and her baby with a flat tire he did not realize it was none other than the object of his high school affection Carissa Teodoro.  Carissa finds something vaguely familiar about her motorcycle riding knight in shining armor but with the long hair, sunglasses and facial hair she cannot be sure. With an offer to help her out further with her automobile needs and without telling Carissa his true identity,  Carson “Joker” Steele gives her his  business card with his numbers.Although Carissa makes a snap judgement about all bikers she finds she is immediately wrong about this one especially. Taking up the offer of fixing her tire she takes her car to the Ride and decides to take Joker a thank you as well.  Carissa does not take charity.  She does not want to owe anyone, anything. So begins a battle of wills when she gets the royal treatment on her junker car.The attraction between Joker and Carissa is instant but it also stems back to high school. Even if Carissa does not know it yet. What will she think and do when she finds out the enigmatic Joker is her high school crush Carson Steele. Will Joker be able to hold on to the girl he has loved since he was a teenager?Ride Steady is the best in the Chaos series so far. The writing and character dialogue was realistic and entertaining.  There were moments in the book that had me laughing and also others that made me cry (the prologue was tear jerker). Kristen Ashley has outdone herself and proven she can write pretty much any genre with ease. The story is told from many points of view including Tack the Prez of The Chaos MC and Carissa’s ex-husband (yeah we endure that jerks mind for a spell).Ride Steady is an entertaining and enjoyable ride that I would highly recommend to romance readers and MC lovers alike.

Carried Away was an interesting read! It's about the suffrage of women in England.  This is not a subject I would normally read, but I think I have found a new interest. Tressa is a maid and that made the story a bit more interesting. Sir Smythe is who Tressa works for and he is such a great evil character! You hate him right away! I found Carried Away interesting because Lady Smythe supports the cause in her own secret way! I rate this book a 3.5.

I received an ARC in exchange for an honest review.Since this was the first Sierra Simone book I've read, I wasn't sure what this book was going to be like going in to it. The cover is very appealing and sexy so that made me hopeful, that the writing would be also. As soon as I began reading,  I was immediately drawn in to the storyline by Father Bell and Poppy's attraction to each other. Talk about some serious steam factor. Sierra was able to create such amazing sexual tension between them. It really kept me on the edge of my seat. Sierra's writing is really good so even if you find the subject matter a bit distasteful, it's still worth reading. For me, the fact that he was a priest didn't bother me at all. Maybe it's that I'm not catholic, but Father Bell made me give some careful consideration to converting!I'm giving Priest 5 stars! I can't wait to read the rest of Sierra's books!

I'm always excited when I find out about an author that is new to me. In this case Jax Newman is also ,new to the self publishing world, with Fade to Black being her debut novel. This book doesn't read as if a new author wrote it though. The story is interesting and well thought out. She has created interesting, likeable characters that I want to know more about. I loved Tristan and Freya and how they met was nice and original. Jax infused this story with lots of humor. The clever banter between Tristan and Freya had me laughing out loud. I'm looking forward to the next book in this series and getting to know these characters even more!I'm giving Fade to Black 4 stars and looking forward to more from Jax!

I have been a fan of Robyn Roze's since I first read Chain of Title last year. I enjoyed it so much I immediately followed it up by reading The Keeper Series which was also amazing. When I found out about the release of HELLKAT, I was ecstatic and I have to say it definitely lived up to my high expectations for it.Kat James comes from a wealthy family, but she has distanced herself from most of them. She enjoys life on her terms until she meets cowboy, Tucker Williams in a hotel bar and that's when things get start to get really interesting. The two of them have some serious chemistry and at times, I thought they were going to burn my tablet up! At first there's a lot of banter between the two of them, which I really enjoyed and Kat does her best to stay away from Tucker but to no avail. Robyn even included some mystery in the storyline and it makes for a lot of excitement and tension.I can't wait to see what Robyn comes up with next. I love reading her books but I'm always a little sad when I finish one because her writing is so good I want it to go on and on.....Robyn writes intelligently and seamlessly. Her words have a beautiful flow to them. I often find myself re-reading sentences just to savor the way she strings the words together. She has a true talent for writing and in my humble opinion it's only a matter of time before she becomes a household name in the book world.

I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.Something's Gotta Give by Maggie Adams is the perfect mix quick whit and steam. It is the third installment in the Tempered Steel Series. I love this series and this book was a great installment.Chance is a charmer, and he charmed his way into my heart in Leather and Lace. He continued to make me swoon in Something's Gotta Give.You can't but root for Chance, he is so sweet, and there is defiantly great chemistry between him and Georgia. The Coalson family's saga continued and I think we are getting closer to culprit to their problems.Georgia thinks she can resist Chance but who is she kidding? Who can resist any of these men? Where can we all find one? They are great to their ladies in more ways than one!Adams has a knack to keep you turning her pagers and you wanting more of the Coalson men. I give Something's Gotta Give 5 stars.

Sometimes the hardest thing to do is to forgive yourself. Serenity is a mysterious young woman, who is trying to outrun ghosts from her past. She's trying to find not only peace, but the acceptance of being the person she wants to be.Matt is on assignment, undercover for the DEA. Unfortunately, Serenity is in the room he needs to use to complete his mission. But the beautiful Brit wants to have nothing to do with him.I loved this story. There is an undeniable bond between these two. Matt carries as many demons as Serenity does. While he slowly discovers the secrets Serenity holds close, he learns that together they can fight anything. This is a short, but very loving story. I give this beautiful tale 4 stars!

I thought that Cassia Brightmore‘s debut novel Malevolent was twisted but with the release of Evanesce, I can see she has delved even further into the darkness this time around.  I cannot believe the stuff that comes out of her head.Evanesce centers around the small town in Texas that has seen a rash of disappearing women and infants.  No women or infants are safe. The local PD is stumped.There are two stories that run parallel, one being told of goings on in the house of horrors and the other being the second chance love story between Nora and Gabe.Evanesce tells you the story from a third person POV so that you get a good idea what is going through the mind of every player on this warped chess board. Even more frightening is that you want to know what they are thinking, even the villain's head is a place you want to poke around in. The reader is taken through every emotion of these characters. They hurt, you hurt. They cry, you cry. And hurt and cry you will.Cassia serves up a mixture of dark and twisted with a bit of sexy.Be prepared for your mind to be blown!*** I was gifted this ARC in exchange for a honest review****

Fire inside is an emotional journey that required lots of tissue and wine.Lanie has had it rough since she was eleven years old and the world as she knew it was shattered. Then when her last relationship left her alone and broken she begins to question her life choices and decides that being alone is better than having something to lose.Hop has been burned by his ex, a burn that leaves permanent scars. He likes women but he is loyal to only his Chaos brothers and his kids Molly and Cody.Hop and Lanie find themselves in a "non relationship" that lasts past the "one night" that Lanie originally proposed.
