But he had been working his head off taking on more and more responsibilities but Savvas had never rewarded him with a change of title to show his present scope of responsibilities, nor had he given him any increase in salary...When he was given the responsibility of acting as host to hostess Aphroditi, was he totally out to take advantage of her or did he really begin to care for her as a beloved woman and friend? For we will see what happens to Aphroditi after she has fallen deeply in love with Markos and faces an unexpected pregnancy...And while that was all happening, Markos had stayed with his family, the last Greek Cypriots to stay in Famagusta...ultimately joining with the last Turkish family to try to survive as the Soldiers invaded each home, stealing, killing...and more...Don't expect a good ending to the novel. Can it be anything other than the truth of the lives of those individuals who are affected by the devastation of war? The novel is provocative, intriguing, and epic in the breadth of the story itself. I was impressed by the author's obvious knowledge of the history and the setting as well as her ability to establish the tension and fear of characters as they are forced to hide or run for their lives, reacting to a totally unexpected attack, while trying to deal with the thousands of tourists who were visiting there and now caught in a place where no place and no people could really be totally trusted...An amazing story for your consideration, featuring both a historical tale of an important coup in 1974, as well as deep family drama! Do check it out!GABixlerReviewsBook Provided by Publisher

Back when Blue Moses first appeared on the scene, it was one of the must-have albums for young people turning on to jazz. I hadn't listened in a coon's age, but decided to add it to my CD collection when I saw that not only had it been remastered, but the price was right. Well, after a couple of listens, I still like it but it doesn't sound as great as I remember it. Maybe it's because I've evolved musically, but it doesn't pack that same stirring punch of yore.I notice that several people have knocked Creed Taylor and/or arranger Don Sebesky and they are much the same criticisms I have seen directed at some of their other work by both fans and artists. Like them or not, you have to give them credit for assembling a stable of some of the best musicians in jazz and making their work accessible to the general public. CTI was the "gateway drug" for a generation of jazz fans who are still listening and buying music today while hopefully expanding their musical horizons.On Blue Moses, I particularly enjoy the soaring musical explorations of Freddie Hubbard and Grover Washington, Jr. The CD is not long, just around 40 minutes of listening and it's already over, but there is a lot to enjoy. I particularly like Marrakesh Blues.The CD is housed in digipak form and comes with no extras. But the original artwork is attractive and every time you examine it, you will be reminded of the days when album art drew you to the mysteries within.

I only first heard of Pendragon four or five years ago, but the more I hear the more I am impressed. Not of This World is a remarkable piece of work both lyrically and musically. Had this come out in the seventies, you would never be hearing the end of it on the so-called classic rock radio stations and it would have been hailed as one of the musical hallmarks of a generation. But it didn't, and so it (and the band) are left to be discovered by word of mouth.Much has already been said so I won't give it a song by song blow by blow. Suffice to say I like the album from start to finish. I have not yet found it possible to tire of listening to it on a fairly regular basis.This import version of the CD comes cased in a standard plastic jewel box and is accompanied by a very attractive booklet packed with pictures, artwork, album info, and the lyrics. Do be sure to read those as you listen for the first time. It will enhance your enjoyment immeasurably.Note on the import version: When I read the back of the case, I noted that it was meant for sale in Russia, the CIS, and the Baltics only. There are a couple of woofer "pops" in several places early in the CD, so I am going to buy the remastered version on the Madfish label to see if the same happens and if there are any other qualitative differences. Happy listening!Note: Bought and listened to the Madfish reissue. MUCH better quality...

The Banks of Eden has been fairly uniformly praised and rightly so. It is the Flower Kings' most consistent album from start to finish in a long time. Even the bonus CD, though less proggy than the main disc, is quite enjoyable.What does the listener get? LOTS of tasty prog including a 25 minute opus to get things rolling. First-rate musicians, first-rate songwriting, you just couldn't ask for more. Though I like the entire album, my favorites are that epic Numbers, For Those About to Drown, Rising the Imperial, Fireghosts, and the beautiful instrumental Illuminati.The CDs are housed in a six-panel gatefold digipak and are accompanied by an attractive booklet containing artwork, pictures, pertinent album info, and the lyrics. Banks of Eden is a winner, make sure you own the special edition.Note: The order of the tracks on the bonus disc as listed on amazon is not their actual order.

Some years ago when I was replacing cassettes with CDs, Afro-Classic for some reason had not been remastered and was unavailable. Something made me think of Hubert Laws recently, so I looked this up to see if it had yet been remastered and, voila, here it was!OK, I don't like James Taylor's whiny delivery of Fire and Rain, but here Hubert Laws makes the music itself at least palatable. The real meat is in the dreamy renderings of two Bach pieces, one from Mozart, and a surprisingly astounding interpretation of The Theme From Love Story. This is so relaxing I could put it in the CD player and let it run through it's ever too brief 40 minutes over and over.With the CD comes a somewhat flimsy insert featuring basic album info and updated commentary on Laws' career. If you were allowed to own only one Hubert Laws recording, Afro-Classic should be your choice. It is truly a first-rate piece of work right in there with his work on Jim Hall's album Studio Trieste.

I have most if not all Glass Hammer recordings since Lex Rex and it surprises me that after all of the albums they've recorded most music store clerks give you a look like a cow pondering a new gate when you ask about them. I champion their music to friends and am in hearty agreement with those who consider them one of the best US prog bands. But I am not entirely delighted by Perilous, something seems to be missing, and that something is continuity. Now I know prog can take the listener all over the musical map so to speak, but I like a return to theme at the end of the musical journey. This album just does not offer that.There is lots of tasty organ and some medieval ambiance to go with the storyline and the artwork, my favorite portion of the CD is the interior section. But somehow overall, Perilous just doesn't satisfy the way many other Glass Hammer albums do.The CD is housed in a standard plastic jewel box and comes with an attractive insert containing album info, artwork and pictures, and those all-important lyrics. Three stars doesn't say this is a bad CD, it just says it doesn't measure up to what has preceded it.

Having missed the last collaboration between Ray Manzarek and Roy Rogers, I am pleasantly surprised to hear how good this one is. Reviews are all over the board, but if you give this an honest listen and are not expecting some blues revival, you should find a lot to enjoy too.Is there are touch of the Doors? Well, yes there are a couple pieces that wouldn't have sounded out of place on Morrison Hotel or LA Woman. But no way is Translucent Blues a Doors redux. The recording starts out enjoyably enough, maybe even a little commercial in places, until it starts to gain traction on Kick. From there on to the finish, it's mostly great stuff. My favorites are Kick, Tension, New Dodge City Blues, Greenhouse Blues, and a pair of instrumentals: the suave, jazzy As You Leave and the rollicking An Organ, A Guitar, and a Chicken Wing. The duo's sidemen put in some great performances, particularly George Brooks on tenor saxophone.The CD comes packaged in a standard plastic jewel case and is accompanied by an attractive insert containing all pertinent album info, a few pics, and the lyrics. If you haven't heard anything from Manzarek for a while, check this out. Though in his 70s, he shows he still has the mojo!

I had unfortunately never heard of Jan Lundgren until I recently heard him on a Richard Galliano recording. Needless to say, I was impressed so I sought out other works and decided to start with Together Again...at the Jazz Bakery because of one passionate and well-written review.If you hadn't noticed when looking at the track listing, every piece recorded here is a jazz standard. Some have been recorded commercially hundreds of times. Lundgren's trio handles them with skill and aplomb. For a live recording, the sound is great and without any perceivable flaws. Then why not five stars? Because nothing really stands out to grab the listener. You know you love the music, but you just can't pick out any particular moments that are memorable. For the most part, this is the kind of jazz you'd want to hear and expect to hear at a swank dinner concert.Together Again...features an astounding 70 minutes of supremely enjoyable music and an interesting, value-adding booklet that is more than engrossing, with producer Dick Bank's sometimes wisecracking introductions to each musician, his discography, and a rundown of the history of each song, along with pictures. If you like jazz piano as I do, be sure not to miss this!

It seems from reading the reviews that many people came to the music of Jim Hall organically as his career developed. I came to his music via his later work on the CTI label. I recently acquired a CTI remaster of Studio Trieste that had been long out of print and was so impressed with Hall's work that I sought out some of his back catalogue, choosing to start with Trio: The Complete Jazz Guitar because of uniformly high praise for it.The reason I haven't given this five stars is that though it swings flawlessly throughout, there is nothing that stands out. What are covered here are tunes considered standards and as such are de rigueur for any accomplished jazz trio. Picture yourself in an intimate setting, perhaps in a swank hotel at a dinner concert (up front, of course!), perhaps a quiet romantic evening at home, and that is where you might find music such as this most enjoyable.This release is said to be truest to the original, along with bonus tracks. You get a lot of music for the money, nearly an hour and twenty minutes worth. Plus, the CD comes with an informative booklet with the original liner notes, comments on this edition, a short biography of Jim Hall, and pertinent album info. If you like good mellow fifties-style jazz, you'll not be disappointed with this!

When I see that an album has been released on ECM, I know to expect a certain level of quality in both the recording and in the packaging. So even though I had only heard one other Paolo Fresu recording and am only marginally familiar with Ralph Towner, I felt comfortable ordering Chiaroscuro without first hearing a single cut.How did that work out? Well, I find the music to be highly introspective and perfect for when the lights are low and you just want to relax. For those unfamiliar with Fresu, well he's not Herb Alpert. Think more along the lines of Tomasz Stanko or Miles Davis. And as for Towner, his play here reminds me somewhat of the post-shredder work of Al DiMeola when he made his own meditative musical excursions into the land of his ancestors.To me, Chiaroscuro has an even flow with no cut really standing out. Rather it ends much as it begins and leaves you wanting to hit replay over and over when the mood is right. It is accompanied by a protective sleeve like many other ECM recordings and a minimalist insert featuring pictures and bare bones album info. I like both musicians well enough to seek out other recordings of theirs and find out what I missed.

I have long been a fan of Richard Galliano, but for some reason had never heard neither of Paolo Fresu nor of Jan Lundgren. And were it not for YouTube, I may never have come across Mare Nostrum. I was recently posting a Richard Galliano cut to facebook from YouTube and noticed on the sidebar that someone had posted this to YouTube in it's entirety. So I listened, liked, and bought.Mare Nostrum is a very pleasant album that draws it's vibe from the musical heritages of the three musicians, two from the Mediterranean area and one from Scandinavia. It mostly works very well as no one dominates and all are able to demonstrate their virtuosity and their compatibility. My favorites are the title cut, Principessa, the Seagull, Chat Pitre, Valzer del Ritorno, and Para Jobim. There is a pleasing mix of moods and styles, so the listener should never be bored.The CD comes with an attractive booklet that explains the project and introduces the listener to each of the musicians, gives minimal but sufficient information on the music, and offers a few photos of the musicians. I like Mare Nostrum well enough to make me want to hear more of Lundgren and Fresu. It may be a journey to a new musical realm. Let's see how that works out!

OK, well Lonely Planet's Discover Canada is not the kind of detailed guide you might have been hoping for, but it is a grand overview that highlights the various provinces and regions about as well as you might expect a guide this size to do for a country as large and diverse as Canada.No matter where in Canada you are traveling, you can refer to Discover Canada for tips on where to eat, where to stay, what to see, local specialties and peculiarities, and what to do indoors or out. Nine writers contributed their expertise on the parts of Canada they know best so that you are not overburdened with one person's take on the country.I have been to Canada several times, but I do not know it nearly as well as I know my own country. I plan on using Discover Canada on my next trip there, and if I find a more detailed guide for an area I really like necessary, I'll buy it. In the meantime, this book suits me just fine.

While reading Negropedia, it was often hard to tell whether author Patrice Evans' stories and insights are serious, tongue-in-cheek or merely outrageously over the top. Smirks and snickers abound throughout, especially when Evans is dealing with stereotypical subjects.Those who live the urban life are probably acquainted with the humor and the thrust of much of what Evans talks about. White suburbanites like myself may find most useful discussions of Louis Farrakhan and Evans' classification of black entertainers.While Negropedia is not great literature, overall I was amused. If the opportunity presents itself, give it a read and have a few good laughs.

In the liner notes of the six panel gatefold digipak that houses Savoy Brown's newest album Voodoo Moon, songwriter and guitarist Kim Simmonds is quoted as saying that he thinks the songs on this album are the best he's written since the early 70s. In that, he is absolutely right. I would go out on a limb and say that the collection of songs on Voodoo Moon are his best overall since Looking In, the fine album that marked a radically new direction for the band after the departure of Chris Youlden.On this new album are nine mostly hard charging rock tunes strongly tinged with a taste of the blues. The gritty voice of singer Joe Whiting adds a new dimension and the masterful guitar of Simmonds grabs your attention from start to finish. It's hard to pick what I like best after the blazing one, two, three punch that opens the album. Guess I'll go with the Trower-like Look at the Sun, the instrumental 24/7 and the rousing title cut.If you were ever a fan of the Savoy Brown of old and kind of fell away after the release of a series of weaker albums, it's time to listen again. The CD comes with no booklet and pictures unfortunately, but the packaging format allows space for the lyrics and all pertinent album info. Voodoo Moon is yet one more album that puts the lie to any claim that there is no good music being made today. Get it and hear what I mean.

There is nothing subtle about the approach of Black Bone Child to rock music. It's one speed, and that is full speed ahead! With the release of Alligator, the band follows the path they blazed on their debut album.There's nothing here I don't like, and there are a few songs I like quite a bit. My favorites are Be Your Man, Baby Baby, What I Know Ain't Right, This Disease, and Devil's Teeth. It clear that Donny James and Kenneth M have decent songwriting skills and the musicianship gets better as they mature.If you like hard charging, high energy rock and roll then Black Bone Child's Alligator fits the bill. The quality of the music here shows they avoided the dreaded sophomore slump. Unfortunately, the packaging is bare-bones and so the CD case provides only minimal information about the band and none at all about the music except for the song titles. Nevertheless, I am looking forward to buying and hopefully enjoying their third album.

Since Lee Hazlewood's death several years ago, there have been a number of reissues and compilations of various quality that have appeared on the market. I eagerly look for something I haven't yet heard and most eagerly await the remastering and reissue to CD of all of the Nancy and Lee albums. LHI Years: Singles Nudes & Backsides 1968-71 is a pleasant surprise for me because it contains quite a few very listenable pieces I haven't heard before as well as some I have heard and enjoyed many times.Of the ones I hadn't heard (or don't remember), my favorites are The Bed, the exquisite Bye Babe, the thought-provoking Trouble Maker, and the previously unreleased I Just Learned To Run. Of those I know, I like The Night Before (with Nicky Hopkins' swirling organ)and the moody What's More I Don't Need Her most. But I also enjoy the duet Leather and Lace, the gritty If It's Monday Morning, the jaunty Hey Cowboy, and the relentless Come On Home To Me. If I had to pick a cut I don't particularly like, I'd pick Nobody Like You. Otherwise, it's all good!The CD is very attractively packaged, from it's "bound to be a cult classic" cover to the fat booklet that features pictures, album info, and a very informative and touching tribute to Hazlewood by his Manager for Europe, Wyndham Wallace. If you are a Hazlewood fan who has been stung by a few reissues and unauthorized compilations, don't be afraid of this one. It's well worth owning.

Thank heaven for sites like amazon and hard-working evangelists of progressive rock such as Greg Walker without whom finding albums this obscure but this good would be well-nigh impossible. I had never heard of No Name until a friend in Escondido urged me by phone to get this CD while I was in Utah browsing the deep prog rock inventory of Mr Walker. I took his suggestion, bought the CD, and was floored when I listened for the first time. Here is a band that is clearly on a level with Camel, IQ, and other similar progressive rock bands yet is undeservedly obscure. They are so far under the radar I couldn't find a single posting of their music on YouTube!Apparently, 20 Candles is a compilation of some of their best work, re-recorded for the occasion of the band's 20th anniversary. The music of these Luxembourgers is soaring, melodic, and ever so addicting.The best songs by far are the stunning First Night, the evocative Orient Express, and the rousing Battlefield. But the others are very listenable as well and grow on you as you play 20 Candles over and over.On this CD, No Name offers its listeners well over an hour of brilliantly crafted progressive rock. It is accompanied by a handsome booklet containing pictures, lyrics and album information. If they are this good, it's time to pick up some of their earlier albums as well!

It is a given that youths are in need of a positive role model to help launch them into successful adulthood. In popular culture however, role models are often negative and destructive. Miles Dean's quest to ride a horse across the United States, visiting places along the way that are important to African Americans, was a personal journey. But in the end, it also serves as an inspiration for a generation of youths whose most visible "heroes" are sports stars and rap musicians. Digressions throughout the book touch on the stories of ordinary black men who overcame obstacles and followed their own bliss to the greatest extent possible through hard work and perseverance. That is important not just for black kids to read, but also for kids of other races who may harbor negative stereotypes of blacks.A Black Cowboy's Ride Across America is an easy read, essentially written to the level of a middle school student. Less print is devoted to the actual trip than to the sideshows along the way. I would like to have read more about Dean's thoughts and reflections as he faced everyday situations. Instead, we read about them only when there is some sort of emergency. In places, the story seems conflated with locations and distances confused. One instance is where the author says Dean passed the split of Interstates 10 and 20 after leaving the ancient store (now closed)in the West Texas hamlet of Kent. At Kent, he was more than 10 miles past that spot. Another is where he was crossing the Chocolate Mountains 81 miles from Los Angeles. I assure you, they are much farther from Los Angeles than that and the route along I-10 is not half as rough as author Lisa Winkler makes it out to be.Sometimes, the author seems to exaggerate the difficulties. While February and March temperatures in Southern New Mexico, Southern Arizona, and Southeastern California might reach the mid-90s, it is extremely unlikely to do so for days on end as the October through March period in that area is generally very pleasant and the coolest time of year.So while the story is inspirational, it is too weakly and haphazardly told to capture adult imaginations. I would recommend this book to a sixth or seventh grade class, particularly one comprised of inner-city youth who could see by reading this that there is another world out there to be seen and that they can be part of it if only they apply themselves.

Until a couple of years ago, I had never heard of Snowy White in the context of solo artist. When a friend in Escondido introduced me to this several years ago, I was blown away and surely sorry for all the years I'd spent unaware of his huge talent.If you are new to the music of Snowy White, you may instantly be stricken by how his music is infused with the spirit of Peter Green. Many of White's songs are so evocative that you will think that you are hearing Green himself. Listen to Blues is the Road, No Faith Required, I Loved Another Woman (composed by Green), and Sweet Bluesmaker then you will hear what I mean. White recalls other artists too. In Love, Pain and Sorrow I hear echoes of Bob Welch. What I'm Searching For is something you might expect from Santana. Both Bob Welch and Chris Rea come to mind on Too Far Away.Besides those songs, all of which I enjoy, I like most of the rest of the album especially Long Distance Loving, Silence In the Valley, The Journey, Old Number 7, Angel Inside, and Loving Man.With Best of Snowy White, you get well over an hour and a half of great British blues. The CD set comes handsomely packaged and is accompanied by a fat booklet containing commentary by White about his career and notes about each song as well as the usual pertinent album information. If you are a blues/rock fan, you will enjoy this album as the gateway to the sounds of one of the finest blues musicians around.

A frequent lament I hear from friends my age is that there is no good music being made today, as if somehow the heyday of everything worth listening to was recorded during the ten years roughly spanning the tumultuous years 1966-1975. My answer is always that there is more good music being made today than you have time to hear if you just know how to find it. Appointment With Mr Yeats is a perfect illustration of that. Here is an album that deserves to be heard at least once by everyone but it will likely fade as so many great albums do, heard only by the cognoscenti.Despite my rather wide musical interests, I had never heard of the Waterboys until a friend introduced me to this several months ago. I picked it up on his recommendation and after a few listens, was hooked for life. Most people of a certain level of education have at least heard of Yeats as one of the high priests of Irish letters, even if they have never read any of his work. This ambitious project adapts his poetry to music, often very powerful music, and what a thrilling combination that makes!My favorites are: The grand, spirited Hosting of the Shee; the majestic, theatrical News For the Delphic Oracle; the evocative White Birds; the mystical Before The World Was Made (previously touched upon by Van Morrison); and the political songs September 1913, An Irish Airman Foresees His Death, and Politics.The CD is packaged in a six-panel digipak and comes with a useful booklet containing the all-important lyrics and all pertinent album info. If hearing this doesn't cause you to make your own appointment with Mr Yeats, it will at least make you a confirmed fan of the Waterboys. Check it out and hear what I am talking about!

Over the past several years, O.S.I. has established itself as one of the most innovative American groups on the progressive metal music scene. Fire Make Thunder solidifies that position. What sets them apart? Well, not only have they developed a "trademark" musical style, the distinctive vocals make an O.S.I. recording instantly recognizable to the musical cognoscenti.Here's what I like best: The steady, relentless Cold Call; the uncharacteristically mellow and dreamy Indian Curse; the pounding, driving Enemy Prayer; and the sweeping Invisible Men.The CD comes very attractively packaged and is accompanied by a useful insert containing the lyrics, standard album info, and a picture of the group's two principals, Jim Matheos and Kevin Moore. If you haven't yet come to enjoy O.S.I., Fire Make Thunder is a great place to start!

Those accustomed to hearing Klaus Doldinger as a jazz-fusion pioneer are in for a big surprise when they put Shakin' the Blues on for the first time. For not only is this not jazz-fusion, it's not even really the blues promised in the title! If Shakin' the Blues sounds like a rip-roaring throwback to the best style of 60s jazz, that's because it is. It swings and smokes as Klaus just cooks. Think labels like Verve and Blue Note and you'll know what to expect here.I like the entire album, and like it more and more every time I listen to it. You just have to hear it to believe how hot this is. My favorite cut hand down is the stunning Delilah; but I also am stoked by Blues Toosy, which sets the pace for the album; the extended jam of Careless Love; the swinging Waltz of the Jive Cats; and another swinger, That Bluesy Sound. Most impressive to me is that Doldinger's compositional skills make the more traditional standards covered, with the exception of Delilah, seem weaker by comparison.Shakin' the Blues is a digitally remastered compilation assembled from from several albums Doldinger recorded with his jazz band in Germany in the mid-sixties. The players are all first-rate, especially evocative of the period is the Hammond organ of Ingfried Hoffman. Album info is scant, but the insert at least gives all the necessary information about who played what on which song and when the song was originally recorded. If you like the type of 60s jazz exemplified by the Verve and Blue Note labels, you are going to love Shakin' the Blues. Don't miss it!

Ever since the demise of the Third Reich, people around the world but especially in the West have searched for answers as to what made Hitler tick. Now I don't profess to know as I did not know him personally, but this documentary Understanding Hitler comes closest of any I have seen to the view that I have developed over my years of fascination with the subject: that is that people didn't follow Hitler because of his antipathy toward Jews and foreign (i.e. non-Western) minorities such as the Gypsies, but rather despite that aspect of his personality. They followed him because he offered them hope when everything seemed hopeless and because he best articulated a bright and heroic future for the nation.This two DVD set covers many areas: The development of Hitler's worldview in the context of the times; one of the best explanations of Mein Kampf that I have heard; a sample reading from the modern English translation of Mein Kampf; an assortment of propaganda films both light-hearted and very serious, plus a film on the Secret Life of Adolf Hitler that revolves mostly around social gatherings at the Eagle's Nest and his relationship with women, particularly Eva Braun.I give it only four stars because the main documentary makes a couple of very serious errors and glides over how Hitler came to discover the small political party which he subsequently dominated. Understanding Hitler does not make clear that it was the Bavarian Army he joined and not the Austrian Army. It fails to mention that he fled to Bavaria to avoid military service in his native Austria because he despised the multi-cultural and shambolic nature of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. And as for joining the German Worker's Party, he wasn't particularly searching for a place to fit in but working as an army spy supposed to be keeping tabs on extremist groups that sprung up after the First World War when he stumbled upon a meeting of their's and was drawn to the party's philosophy. There are other errors, put it down to sloppy editing.Viewers might find interesting the section on Mein Kampf where it is explained how poorly translated earlier English editions  of Mein Kampf led to the generally held view that it is a poorly written and rambling book. Actually it isn't "written" at all, but taken as dictation from a series of soliloquies Hitler gave while pacing his prison cell and later at his home.Of the propaganda videos, my favorite is the one that shows a happy, ordered, and carefree lifestyle in Berlin under the Nazis. The best and rather chilling film, however, is the one that shows people with all sorts of disabilities and which makes a case for euthanasia chiefly because of the cost to the state of caring for them.The Secret Life of Hitler is interesting mainly because of insights given by associates of Hitler who survived the war and it's portrayal of Eva Braun as kind of a self-absorbed airhead.Overall, this set is well worth the small price paid and those interested in the subject should find it quite illuminating. No booklet is included, just two discs and the minimal information provided on the clamshell.

Like the first reviewer, I vacillated between awarding A Mediterranean Odyssey four or five stars, but unlike that reviewer I decided on four because there is absolutely nothing new here. Yes, there is the virtuoso instrumentation, the enchanting vocals, and the expert manner is which Loreena McKennitt is always able to set the scene for the listener. But as a long-time fan, I just feel a sense of having been here before every time I listen. However, if you just need a go-to album for a road trip or just want to introduce someone to McKennitt's music, this box set is a perfect choice.Disc one, the Olive and the Cedar, is a compilation of songs from other albums that relate to the Mediterranean theme of the album. The entire side is good, but my favorites are: The Mystic's Dream, with it's quasi-religious vibe; the hypnotic Tango to Evora; the percussive Caravanserai; and the beautiful instrumental Sacred Shabbat.Disc two, From Istanbul to Athens, is comprised of recordings made from various concerts on her 2009 tour of the Eastern Mediterranean. My favorites are the evocative The Gates of Istanbul; Marco Polo; the percussive Caravanserai once again; the soaring Santiago; the enchanting Beneath A Phrygian Sky, and another superb rendition of Tango to Evora.A Mediterranean Odyssey is a great value as well, available at this time from an amazon partner for under ten dollars. The accompanying attractive booklet containing album information and lots of pictures from the tour only adds to the value. If you already have everything McKennitt issued previous to this you may consider passing this by but I think the addition of the live CD makes this an album worth owning.

Had a friend's daughter not used a tune by Bitter:Sweet as bumper music for her website, I might never have heard of them. The song she used was so intoxicating, I contacted her to find out the title. And as I find downloading lame and ephemeral, I looked the group up and took a chance on the entire album. And so? Well, not only is the voice of Shana Halligan alluring but the music is both interesting and quite different from the styles that usually attract me. She reminds me vaguely of Ambrosia Parsley, the delightful vocalist for Shivaree.Here's what I like best: the sultry Come Along With Me, the energetic The Bomb with it's interesting vocal changes, that incredibly intoxicating A Moment, the evocative Trouble, and the dreamy Everything. Two I don't care for are Waking Up and Love Revolution, mostly because of what a friend refers to as cheesy "R2D2" noises that randomly intrude. Some of the other songs are beset by such noises to a lesser degree. Might that be the Monte Nido Frog Choir listed in the credits or is it mere electronica?The couple who comprise Bitter:Sweet are backed by a shambolic orchestra that help make Drama at least a fun album. And no one can say that Halligan and Kiran Shahani are not talented songwriters and arrangers. This was released in 2008, I hope it's not the last we are going to hear of them.Drama is issued in digipak form and is accompanied by a flimsy booklet bearing all pertinent album info and the lyrics. If you like hearing female vocalists who are out of the mainstream and enjoy new music that is both different and interesting then just maybe Bitter:Sweet is for you!

Like the previous reviewer, I was hesitant to buy Lifelike at first because of the lack of album information. Now that I own it, I have found that it is just a potluck album, with no overarching theme or any kind of continuity. That being said, there are at least a few tunes to like here.On Disc one, I most enjoyed the funky Shirokko and the melodic, well-defined Guna Guna. The rest of the side I found rather weak, particularly Ostinato, which is too drawn out and pseudo-psychedelic. Disc two starts out well with Jadoo, a spirited mix of funk and big band elements. Sambukada is an exciting piece with a Latin touch Doldiger-style. Then Stormy Monday moves along just fine until Etta James kind of ruins it with repeated "Lawd have mussy" shouts. After that, the rest of the side is just OK.Jazz fans might be excited by guest appearances of Richard Tee and Herbie Mann, but I was unimpressed with the participation of Etta James and the Average White Band. Overall, Lifelike is not a bad album but its not one I would recommend. There are far too many good Passport albums available to have to settle for this mediocrity. Take my word for it and get a different live Passport album instead.

Those who are familiar with the biblical Revelations, the warnings of the coming of the Anti-Christ, and Armageddon to come will surely recognize a secular version of those prophesies in Pallas' powerful and electrifying XXV. This is a theme album on which Pallas and its new lead singer Paul Mackie thrusts the band to the forefront of the world of prog-metal along with bands like Pendragon, Opeth, and Pain of Salvation.I like the entire album immensely, but here's what I enjoy most: the stirring Falling Down, in which man's hubris has us heading for the fall; the driving, pounding Crash and Burn; the foreboding and memorable Monster; the bombastic Alien Messiah (as Anti-Christ) with his promises of glory if only we follow him; the dark final warning of Twenty Five Good Honest Men; the eerie, mesmerizing Violet Sky; and the haunting finality of The Unmakers Awake. An enjoyable DVD that features live excerpts from the album and a slide show is also provided. Very nice, but I wish that the entire album live could have been shown.XXV is packaged in a standard jewel case with the discs stacked, though easily removed. The accompanying booklet features lyrics, album info, and inspired artwork that fits the mood of the music. Pallas doesn't release many albums and this one is said to be the sequel of another theme album released twenty five years ago. If you like intelligent, hard-driving music then you are almost sure to like this endtimes extravaganza.

Even though Pendragon have been around a long time, they haven't been on my horizon for long so I don't have that deep well of listening experience I can draw on to compare and contrast with previous work. But if their other work is anything like Passion, all I can say is that I have really been missing out on some great music. Simply said, Passion is a powerhouse, a real piece of work that should thrill all fans of great progressive music.Here's what I like best: The hard-driving, exciting title cut; the relentless, enticing Empathy which is sometimes evocative of Pain of Salvation; the chaotic Feeding Frenzy, and the spectacular Skara Brae. There is also an enjoyable "progumentary" DVD that is added as a bonus, but as is usual with these sort of things you will likely watch just once then go back to enjoying the great music you bought the CD to hear.The packaging is first-class and the booklet that accompanies the discs is filled with with all the information you'd expect including the lyrics which are interspersed with artwork that will surely add to pride of ownership. If you are passionate about quality progressive rock, then Pendragon's Passion is surely an album to be excited about. It may take some a few listens, but this is the real deal.

Paatos will never be accused of flooding the market with new material, in the twelve-something years they have been recording they have released only four full-length albums, an EP, and a live album. Breathing is their fourth, and it has been a long time coming.Those already familiar with Paatos' other work will be delighted to hear that singer Petronella Nettermalm sounds sexy as ever. My favorites are the simmering In That Room, the excellent title cut, the wistfully beautiful Precious, and the fast-paced Over and Out that harks back to their earlier work.The CD is simply but elegantly packaged in a six-panel gatefold digipak and comes with a equally elegant booklet that contains just a picture of the band and the lyrics. Other information is presented on the panels. Paatos is one of the finest Swedish bands on the scene today and you should find their music to be ultimately satisfying. If you aren't yet into Paatos, Breathing is a great place to start a musical journey with them!

It is generally a good idea to see a film before obtaining the soundtrack if only to understand the sequencing of the music. Most soundtracks are mere snippets of music and dialogue and Delusion is no different. I have yet been unable to see the film but bought the soundtrack anyway on the strength of its association with Barry Adamson.Here's what I like: the title track, with it's Spanish guitar licks; the eerie quasi-spiritual feel of Il Solitario; the Latin ambience of Fish Face; Go Johnny, a tense exciting piece that is pure Adamson; the humorous rendition of La Cucaracha; and Anita Lane's gutty, slatternly rendition of Lee Hazlewood's classic These Boots Are Made For Walking which is the soundtrack's only complete song.The Delusion soundtrack is not for everyone, but the mere fact that you are reading this shows some interest. I would think that it would appeal most to fans of Barry Adamson's musical vision. If you buy, I recommend that you listen when there are no distractions for maximum enjoyment, otherwise it will amount to disjointed background noise. It is cheaply packaged in a standard jewel case and comes with an insert bearing minimal but crucial information.

So it seems there are at least three versions of this floating around. Mine is the Japanese import that includes Cinema Show, but lacks some of what is on the others. So even though amazon lumps all reviews together, mine will refer to the Japanese version.Scanning the Greenhouse is an excellent introduction to the music of the Flower Kings for newbies who don't know where to start with the band's daunting catalogue. It is even a great go-to recording for the experienced listener having a hard time deciding whick FK CD to bring on a road trip.Every song is well chosen and delightful, but I particularly enjoy In the Eyes of the World, the re-recorded version of The Flower King, the re-recorded Stardust We Are, and the dynamic cover of Genesis' Cinema Show.This version is accompanied by an attractive booklet containing lots of pictures, pertinent album information, and the lyrics as well as an informational insert in Japanese. If you can't obtain this version, you'll miss out on Cinema Show but in return you'll get to hear something I didn't. But do obtain one of the versions however you can and you will be rewarded with some fine music.
I have been using this program for a number of years. so far, I have no complaints. Service is prompt, files arrive cleanly and well-organized, and integrate into my PC smoothly without problems.

This author has many crime novels in print. They are all competently written with interesting characters in sometimes unusual locations. The Jake Hines series is particularly interesting in that it follows a lone Mexican with a checkered past who ends up in a small city on the eastern border between Minnesota and Wisconsin. Over a period of years Jake Hines gets his life together, becomes a cop, a detective and now head of the investigations squad in Rutherford, Minnesota.Noontime Follies is a title with someone’s tongue firmly and cheekily implanted. And even though revealing the inner meaning of the title wouldn’t ruin the plot of the crimes herein, I think it’s more fun and more intriguing to suggest that readers who want an incisive crime novel about human relations and corporate maneuvering ought to read this one.This novel is, in part, about the corporate development of new genetically engineered food crops which may or may not provide substantial benefits to mankind in the form of better nutrition. The issues are several and do indeed address questions of ethics and morality. After all, mankind, since the beginning, so far as we know, has been trying to improve crop yields, both to enrich the tribe and provide adequate food beyond immediate needs.Some find that questionable, particularly as to motive, and may be provoked to unusual actions. Noontime Follies, raises some interesting questions along those lines as well as its more intimate plot lines. A worthwhile experience with a satisfactory conclusion.

More than one mystery intersect in another adventure from Kate Charles. She’s an experienced expat author living in England exploring the mysteries of faith, love, family and violence in her books. In this fourth Callie Anson novel, it is her circle of acquaintances who are involved in a variety of actions and decisions, old and new, that drive the story and its sometimes complicated relationships.Callie travels from London to Cambridge to attend a reunion of her classmates, graduates from theological seminary. She will have to confront both the scenes and at least one man with whom she was deeply emotionally involved during her time there: a man who unceremoniously dumped her in a shameful and hurtful way. Around her are arrayed classmates and older theologians who help Callie’s travel to emotional understanding. Meanwhile, the new love of her life, a London policeman who functions as a Family Liaison officer, becomes involved in the murder of a young man in Paddington Square. As intriguing as the convoluted relationships among the religious that are examined in this story are, the murder of a school boy with only a single tenuous link to the other plot, leads to examinations of working and absent parents, stresses in modern society and pressures of various kinds on law enforcement. Together, the development of these separate plot lines present a realistic picture of modern life.These ideas and more are nicely embodied in the characters brought to the page by the author. The messages are many perhaps too many, but the author’s delicate touch leaves them to the reader to accept or pass over. None is presented in such a way that one feels manipulated or into forced acceptance.Charles nicely places the action in several consummately English locations. No generics here. She’s been called a most English of writers and compared favorably to Agatha Christie in these aspects. All in all an excellent, calm and deliberate story that can leave a reader with considerable food for thought.

Author John Talton hails from a multi-generational line of Arizonians. As such he is privy to the historical development of the state. In 1915 the US Census registered fewer than 7,000 residents. In 2015, more than seven million. Lots of changes in that time. Most of them make Talton unhappy. His unhappiness occasionally gets in the way of a powerful, nuanced and complicated tale of murder and mystery.Talton is a fine writer and you’ll realize it from the beginning. His sensitivity and understanding of more subtle pressure points in the relationship between Maricopa County Deputy Sheriff, David Mapstone and his wife, Lindsey, provide both complications and additional rhythm to this story.Yes, Mapstone is still in Phoenix, first as a private investigator after his friend and former boss, Sheriff Mike Peralta, is defeated in the most recent election. Almost nobody likes the new sheriff in town and Mapstone is suspicious when the man coerces Mapstone into regaining his job as a deputy. This is particularly odd because Peralta is on the run, hotly pursued by an assortment of law enforcement types for stealing a large consignment of unset diamonds he was supposed to be guarding. It’s also an interesting development because it has unforeseen consequences for the new sheriff.Nevertheless, and against his better judgement, Mapstone takes the badge and starts an investigation into a suspicious thirty-year-old death. Meanwhile, Peralta is still missing, Peralta’s wife is agitating Mapstone and vague accusations against Mapstone’s wife are clouding the picture.The writing is clean, the characters are well delineated and separate and the pace relentless. Talton has a fine sense of when to insert emotional scenes that are important to readers’ understanding of character motivations and to readers’ invitation to bond with the attitudes of the protagonist, not just in relation to the crimes involved, but to the ongoing changes in the landscape of Arizona. And these are changes that the author resignedly accepts but not willingly. In some ways the novel is a plea for a return to older, simpler values.Like others in the Mapstone series, the story winds up to a thrilling and tense solution. Its well worth the ride and as a bonus, offers a look at some troubling aspects of modern Arizona.

You know you are in the grasp of a master story-teller when the ground becomes unstable underfoot in the first four pages. Given her longevity and varied output in the crime fiction genre, this is not surprising. Nor is it unusual that you have to read the entire novel to learn the neat resolution of that first chapter.By turns clever, thoughtful, gut-wrenching and uplifting, this novel is very contemporary in its themes. The author’s long-time protagonist, Jane Lawless, now a licensed private investigator in Minneapolis, in addition to carefully overseeing the operation of her restaurant, faces complications at every hand, some of which are reflected in her sexual orientation. Yes, there are more and deeper examinations of gay and lesbian themes in this than readers will have encountered in earlier Lawless adventures. However, as always, Hart is tasteful and circumspect in her writing.Long-time buddy, the ever flamboyant Cordelia Thorn has purchased and is restoring an ancient, historic theater building in downtown Minneapolis. As is the case with many building that suffer several alterations, there are oddities in this building, as well as several tales relating to more turbulent and law-skirting times. Seeking to create yet another restoration of the old building leads Cordelia and Jane down dusty narrow stairways and through ancient locked doors.What crimes lie beyond those doors relate in surprising ways to a current case of murder that involves Jane and her father, Criminal Defense Attorney, Raymond Lawless, together with the family of a nationally known Country-Western singer and his inner circle and family.With prudent care and thoughtful reveals, Hart entices readers to keep reading and turning pages. Her ability to parcel out important facts, bit by bit, is of a high order. The entire story is brought together in a complete and eminently satisfactory manner after Jane and Cordelia sort out several mis-directions. A most enjoyable experience.

Leopold Blake is a bright, wealthy, ego-centric and occasionally oddly behaving entrepreneur. Among many enterprises he owns a security consulting firm. In this story, Blake is hired by the Director of the Louvre to examine their various security routines. Yes, the one in Paris. Blake discovers an important daVinci (no, not That one) has been stolen and a rather bad fake put in its place. Blake’s response is to rip the offending painting off the wall and get himself detained and handcuffed by the museum’s security forces.The plot now focuses on finding who stole the daVinci, why, and retrieving it. Complicating the plot are an assassin after Blake, a New York cop who may be Blake’s girlfriend, and a French restorer who works at the Louvre and is in love with the director. Somewhere offshore is a ship named Thanatos which apparently is tasked with hacking and maintaining surveillance over the world’s financial markets. And there is also a wealthy holding which is at risk of being sold to the wrong people.If all of this seems a bit unclear, that appears to be the purpose of the author. The pell-mell plot has a lot of loose ends or, blind alleys, if you prefer and the writing is riddled with clichés and sloppy writing. But the pace is so relentlessly swift, one tends to overlook some of the deficiencies. Found this to be both fun and teeth-grindingly frustrating.

Cover copy calls this a work of intricacy, precision and psychological complexity. I cannot agree more emphatically. Yes, it's another in what one hopes is an endless line of Dalziel and Pascoe mysteries. And yes, it contains powerful, evocative writing."Here four men labored with shovels, their faces wrapped with scarves, not for disguise but as barrier against the stench of the decaying bat droppings they disturbed, while high above them a sea of leathery bodies rippled and whispered uneasily as the sound of digging and the glow of bull-lamps drifted up to the natural vault."Peter Pascoe's wife, Ellie, is hard at work on her book. Yes, she's hoping to be a published author one day. And then, abruptly, inexplicably, there is an abduction attempt on her. Though the attempt is thwarted by Ellie's nimble-mindedness, the act sets in motion a vast, complex investigation and a plot that ranges over wide spaces of the English coastal area and pits D&P against some very nasty characters. Adding to the complications are difficulties over jurisdictional questions affecting the National Interest.This is a complex story with a large cast of interesting characters and a strong sub-plot. It is an excellent novel by an excellent writer. Hill handles his characters, his plot and his setting with consummate skill. .More than ten years old now, its well worth seeking out.

Jack Higgins still has the touch. This is an absorbing, fast-paced thriller in the best sense of the word. The plot is current, and quite believable. Once again, ex-IRA terrorist Sean Dillon is teamed with Scotland Yard DCI Hannah Bernstein and her boss, Brigadier Charles Ferguson. He runs an elite intelligence unit responsible only to the Prime Minister of England. Apolitical, the unit has, inevitably, become an action unit as well.Ferguson enlists Dillon in an attempt to run down a mysterious group known as “January 30.” This is a group that has murdered a variety of people operating in the shadow world of international espionage and terrorism. January 30 appears to play no favorites, having been identified as killing former KGB agents, American diplomats and even Israelis. Now they plot to destroy the tenuous peace process taking hold in Northern Ireland. ANGEL OF DEATH, told in flashbacks and present-day action, carries the reader pell-mell from Ireland to England, to America, Beirut, and back. Along the way the reader is treated to imaginative convoluted twists and accommodations of the diplomatic games nations play, set against brutal and abrupt physical action. You’ll see Dillon the charmer with a gift of gab, Dillon the stone killer and Dillon the experienced, intelligent agent, provocateur.As always, Higgins characters are sharply drawn and always consistent. As always Higgins sense of place is thoughtfully and evocatively laid out so we are with him in the mean streets of Belfast and the elegant rooms of Ardmore House.,

Irony, conspiracy, anger, abuse and police corruption, judiciously blended with persistent bad weather. What more can regular readers of British crime fiction expect or desire? Author Cutler is an experienced successful author with many solid novels to her credit so readers will expect and receive everything a well-conceived examination of a water-soaked community, West Mercia, in Northern England will entail.Two former cops with sterling records, Fran Harman and her husband, Mark Turner, now retired from the active police service are called north to help a newly conjoined police force in clearing out their old unsolved cases. In this instance, it’s the disappearance of a popular member of the community, married to an even better known footballer. Ten years earlier, Natalie Foreman, mother of two boys, and wife of star striker Phillip Foreman, disappeared, leaving behind in her sedan beside the roadway, one dead son. Her body and that of her other son, Hadrian, are never found. Foul weather hampered the search. Hence the case is still open.Fran and Mark are disconcerted to discover, upon arrival, per their contract, that there are forces arrayed against them, some blatant, others more subtle and thus more dangerous. They have to sort through a lot of stuff including personal attacks to solve the mystery.The writing is excellent, smooth and consistently logical. The opening prologue is like a sock in the gut. Character development is also excellent with some interesting and unusual characters, scenes are well-tended and the narrative is tightly secured.The novel moves well, although there are instances toward the end which seem a bit convenient and somewhat hurried. Still, a reader is left to contemplate a nicely presented turn of moral complication at the end. And a reader would ponder long over whether to move to reside in such a green and unpleasant land.

Fascinating. Funny. Clever, and, at the end, rife with tension-filled risk. Today, most of us have some sense of the shorthand of text messaging. In the mid-1980’s that was a skill yet to be mastered. Digital technology and communication thereby gained was still only on the horizon for many people.But, as is true of so many inventions of the clever human intellect, there is almost always a potential for evil, as well as for good. Here we have a young man, Peter Talbot, by name, who has built upon a rock of a computer, a modest information service. Forces of both good and evil immediately discover ways to use Peter and his service for their own ends. The resulting expansion is making Peter a wealthy man, but it is also making him vulnerable to forces that first would use him and then destroy him. Will he win out in the end?Like many English crime novels, the story is heavily populated with quirky, unusual, and odd characters and ordinary folks who act in quirky and odd ways. Consider George, an old ex-paratrooper who is at odds with the world. When he saves Peter from undesirable attention, Peter offers him a job. A shadowy figure we are expected to accept at face value, apparently some sort of government spook, enjoins Peter to provide client information, some of whom are obviously on the wrong side of the law, prostitution and espionage appear in the mix. Young hackers or computer game developers wander in and out and then the American Mob show up.Readers will have already caught on to the odd style, often cheeky observations of the characters, the unusual and often abrupt short—hand style that cuts off potentially tedious descriptive passages. The author employs a sometimes wild narrative style that fits well with the story and the characters.There are some aspects of the book that may put readers off. Logical progression sometimes is let go by the boards in favor of a faster pace. Foregone conclusions and almost-obvious results crop up from time to time. Still, the characters are charming if mis-identified. Talbot, for example, is not a computer hacker, he’s a smart, up-coming young businessman. He’s also wise beyond his years, careful around murderers, fit enough to get out of tight scrapes and has a way with certain female characters.High tension, screaming car chases, a brief air-borne chase, guns and bombs all make this a delightful cyber-crime reading experience.

I was a fan of Cat DeLuca from the beginning of the series. Her private investigations business, concentrating as she does on errant (mostly male) spouses, is aptly named Pants On Fire. She has two partners (Cleo) and a dog (Inga). The novel starts out with a routine case and looks intriguing enough, but then Cat is distracted when her running partner (Inga) finds a dead body in a neighborhood park.Things get messy from there on and in spite of often being surrounded by large men competent in the darker arts who have to protect her from numerous stumbles, wrong turns and the occasional homicidal maniac, she manages to once again survive and solve the riddle at the core of this story.I really liked earlier stories in this series but this seems to have descended into chaos. There are serious lapses in logical sequences. Fact checking and editing took the occasional day off. There are sections in which the story line wanders and I got the feeling the authors (the series is a collaboration of three Chicago-land sisters) had insisted on including every joke and snarky aside a sharp editor had cleaned out of earlier stories.The best part of the narrative, for me, are the two chapters detailing the long-delayed formal church wedding of Cat’s mother and father, attended, naturally, by several generations of DeLuca relatives.Still and all, most of the characters shambling through the pages have sufficient endearing qualities, or nasty proclivities to satisfy many mystery readers. Not quite four stars.

Novel carries an unusual style of narration that is deep, thick and thoughtful. To achieve the psychological depth of the novel, the author has resorted to a slow-moving, textually impressive, and imprisoning sort of narrative. There is mystery here, almost from the first page. There is danger here lurking in the convoluted relationships that develop between a character “Alva” who may or may not be real, and a young and hedonistic girl.Alva apparently works in a gallery where he allows himself to be immersed, almost drowned, in the art on display. He is, we are led to believe, the product of the mind of an author. The author, female, sees her characters as a line of figures, waiting at her front door and across her yard. She will, she believes, bring them in, these insubstantial figures, give them depth, life, problems and solutions. She sees herself as a God-figure.But, Alva jumps the line. In the middle of the night he forces his ethereal presence into the narrator’s mind. It is just about the only human substantive act he successfully completes. The conflict this character initiates roils the water of the author/narrator’s existence which leads to this stylistically difficult, yet compelling novel.

Bai Jaing is an interesting protagonist with an unusual background and a high potential. Unfortunately, she doesn’t get there in this novel. Unmarried, she believes herself to be a Buddhist but with tendencies toward violence as a solution. She hangs out in the near vicinity of extremely vicious people in San Francisco. Her family consists of two young girls, a Chinatown warlord lover whose mother watches over the kids when Bai is captured or off throwing knives at suitors, and a gay partner. Together, Bai and Lee run a sort of investigatory operation.Bai styles herself as a finder of missing people, apparently people who mostly don’t want to be found and resent it when they are located. Bai is a fetching, rapacious sexy and morally flexible woman who has the talent and street awareness to avoid being killed and yet manages to require being saved from death or great bodily harm a number of times by the men she associates with.The plot begins with a drug sting mounted by the San Francisco Police that goes wrong and a cop is killed. Even more important, it appears nearly a quarter million in cash and the equivalent in heroin goes missing. All of that fades inexplicably into the background as Bai and Lee are asked by a drunk cop to find a man for them. Whether the missing man has anything to do with the heist is unclear until the very end.In between episodes of violent escapes, Bai has to fend off marriage proposals from people she doesn’t care for, while keeping her peace with her mother. If some of this seems confusing, well, it is. The ability of a writer to inject some level of humor into scenes in a violent turbulent novel is tricky and requires exquisite timing. In this case not so much in evidence. Additionally, the author appears to believe that all Caucasian cops are drunks, slovenly or lazy.There are some very nicely done scenes and some well-laid out dialogue, but the narrative drags in many places and has the feeling at the end that the author felt a sudden need to wrap things up.

A delightfully thoughtful and intimate treatise on the art and techniques of human kissing. One of the problems with most pornography is its common theme of aggression. Even when the participants are acting passionate toward each other, the only objective appears to be penetration and climax.Here is a delightfully written antidote. Kissing with one’s lover can be a delicate, subtle and intimately varied experience as the author illustrates. Here, the object is intimacy, emotional connection, joy and satisfaction not necessarily of the mind-blowing variety.There are a couple of clever links to relevant television sitcoms which I enjoyed. The short, well-organized pamphlet is discreetly illustrated with one anomaly (the dressed officer kissing the fully dressed lady’s fingers), and a few lapses. Drinking Champagne from your lover’s rounded belly if graced with an outie simply doesn’t work well. Minor caveats.Here is a well-considered piece of directional writing that will benefit most couples of any age. This book reminded me of the art of sensual massage, something I have practiced as an amateur for many years. I recommend it.

Another powerful and excellent offering from a superb writer and publisher. I won’t reveal the basis of this excellent political suspense novel because that would spoil the surprise. It’s a stunner and a real stick in the eye.Sean Duffy is an older, nearly burned-out, detective and something of an anomaly. He’s a Catholic copper in the Royal Ulster Constabulary of Northern Ireland. The RUC is an intensely protestant law enforcement agency and in the time this novel is set, the mid-eighties when Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan ruled the western world, Duffy had his internal problems in addition to solving the murders and other crimes. Crimes of all sorts, large and small proliferated in Northern Ireland during this period.Duffy seconds a younger, less experienced, detective in their Belfast unit when a prominent couple is discovered executed in their loungers before the large television. Their son is missing. As the case develops, Duffy struggles with near despair over the level of violence and economic downturn in the country. He struggles as well with an attractive offer to move to England and join MI5, the British equivalent of the FBI. The job would entail far less action and more desk work.  Duffy is torn, not least because the offer comes from an attractive woman, the Gun Street Girl of the title.McKinty is a powerful writer in complete control of his medium. The novel thunders along amid rocks, bullets and political and emotionally fraught maneuvering by Duffy’s superiors. It is by turns, thoughtful, moody, precisely on target and exploding with action. The darkness is expertly leavened with humor of a conscious sort that only enlarges and enhances the fine characters and setting. It is amazing that McKinty hasn’t been swept up by one of the large publishers. A rare and outstanding effort.

It began on June 6, 1994. A significant anniversary date in American history. Fifty years earlier a generation of America’s youth was storming a beach at Omaha and Utah in the invasion of Fortress Europe. Normandy.In 1994, however, things were different. Louis Solomon, principal narrator of this James Gang adventure, picks up a pink telephone message slip. Solomon is a graduate of the Barrett college class of ’74. He has three close buddies, and the narrative of the novel pretty well synopsizes their lives. These lives, disparate as they are, are nicely handled in narrative chunks that relate to the main adventure and don’t slow it down. Contrarily, the lives and resulting talents of the quartet serve to enhance the results of the adventure.For many years a hefty statue of a woman of uncertain heritage graces the campus of Barrett College. Sirena of the title is removed from her pedestal, retrieved, decorated and redecorated as is the wont of rampaging underclassmen and women. Eventually, in 1959, she disappears for good. Years pass and in 1994 a wealthy graduate offers millions for her return, including a healthy reward for whoever shows up at that year’s reunion celebration with Sirena in tow.The four former roommates come together and decide to try to retrieve Sirena—the first hurdle, then get her to the college in New England in time—the second hurdle, and protect her from other alums who want the reward, and the glory.The writing is excellent, the characterizations are first rate and the situations range from understandable to off-the-wall zany. The timeline works, the dialogue is funny, trenchant, and the developments for all four make total sense. If things are just a tad slow at the very beginning, a little patience will result in a very enjoyable experience.

Sounds. They’re stuck in your head. A muzzle blast from a .38. Garfield’s rasp. Bogart’s lispy rhythm and Cagney’s high-pitched rants. The sea, restless, running past Key Largo punctuated by blasts of tommy guns echoing off the greasy walls of that Chicago garage on St. Valentine’s Day, so long ago. And of course you remember the looks, the swaying hips, the invitation to whistle from the women who graced and sometimes motivated the greed, the sex and the violence in the hard-boiled crime story.Well, here they all are, reborn in slinky, sly and quippy dialogue and crashing plot, pulsed by dangerous swinging saps, out of control thugs, cops and robbers. From the slimy Mr. Jupitor to the gunman with the roscoe in the dark doorway behind Jimmy Shin, the action never lets up and the dialogue races on.Here they are, eleven tales of the hard-boiled, urban warrior, stalking his targets down the soft summer ribbons of asphalt, and always with a smart retort, even as the pistol fires. Ben Solomon has got it just right.Richard Prather would be pleased, I think.

Murder, fraud and greed on a grand scale, clashes of culture and intriguing misunderstandings litter the well-trodden ground in this novel. The strong and vibrant writing helps draw the reader in to a world long hidden from western understanding. And even with the recent deluge of news focused on the wars in Iraq Afghanistan, and Pakistan, western knowledge is rooted as much in lack of understanding of Muslim and tribal mores. Dissecting the motives and the perpetrators of these crimes and the application of justices is extremely problematical.All of that requires a carefully constructed, well-written narrative with characters that speak to us even through the veil of poorly understood history and culture. And here it is. Add the setting, that mysterious –to Western sensibilities—culture of the Middle East, and one has the makings of an enthralling novel. And here it is!The writing is superb, the tension almost unrelenting and the incisive eye of this author is everywhere available. This is a fine novel and deserves every rave it will acquire.

The author is a lawyer from Portsmouth, England. The novel is rooted in the legal arcana of the British legal system. In point of fact, the novel is a lengthy, detailed critique of that system and an examination of the sometimes extensive damage the system does to innocent, wrongly accused, citizens.Robert Abramsky is a very successful small town attorney who is faced with a client who started a specialized security firm. The security firm is absorbed into a much larger conglomerate and then unethically destroyed. Abramsky out-maneuvers the big firm and in turn destroys the vindictive man responsible. Readers will recognize that the tale will not end there.Lawyer Abramsky’s main opponent is a nasty, vindictive man with a long memory. Years later, he still seethes over the memory of his destruction, conveniently overlooking the fact that he was, in fact, the guilty party. He determines to destroy Robert Abramsky in a most hurtful way, by ruining his honest reputation as a lawyer and member of the community. Corruption takes many forms and this intriguing novel examines several.Although the pace of this overlong novel is almost as glacial as the legal system it addresses, the writing is strong enough and the plot is complicated enough to keep many readers engaged. In addition, the characterizations of many of the cast of dozens, is intriguing. Retribution fits its title nicely and the world-wide scope of the story plus the curiously intricate cyber security the author lays out all tends to keep one attention. Definitely not a soft summer beach read. Rather, a thoughtful careful examination of important elements of today’s society.

This is another intense, convoluted and complicated case for Moirah Dru and Richard Lake out of Atlanta, Georgia. Dru, a former cop, is the head of a PI firm that specializes in finding and protecting lost, damaged and at-risk children. Her lover and frequent partner is a lieutenant in the Atlanta PD.A three-year-old cold case, the murder of a sixteen-year-old girl engages Lake who in turn engages Dru to help him solve the murder of this wild teen-ager. The more they probe beneath the surface, the odder and more troubling facts suppositions and cross-currents bubble to the surface. The duo’s task is complicated by the association of some principals in the case with local motorcycle clubs and gangs. Soon, the coiling tentacles of the case engaged the FBI and other police agencies in other states.The novel is an intense and thoughtful look at motorcycle clubs and gangs, their motivations and rivalries. Locations range across multiple state and city jurisdictions and the author has made an effort to illuminate some of the restraints and difficulties encountered when law enforcement pursues cases across state and municipal boundaries. The contrasts between an upper-class private school with all its social niceties and the rough and tumble world of the biker are interesting.There are several incidents of violence and incipient head-breaking. They are well-handled on the page and will, I suggest, keep readers engaged. The pace of the novel is by no means pell-mell, but the tension is palpable, the characters genuine, the dialogue both pert and realistic. A very satisfying experience.

Second adventure novel by this author. Let’s say you are approaching the beginning of your middle years, and you have a reasonable if not very exciting job and you really aren’t thinking about adventure, certainly not with a capital A. I mean, you tend to go to Disneyland on your vacations. But you are single with no real attachments, certainly no romantic entanglements.You have a neighbor in the Corning, New York, apartment, a younger couple with almost unpronounceable names, who have moved to Corning from India. Sriram and Vidya are a lot of fun to socialize with and Jason Talley, our earnest protagonist, enjoys being with them, particularly since it appears that Srirham, an electronics designer, is on the verge of some big-time breakthrough in the computer field. One day, Srirham, in a oddly conspiratorial manner, importunes Jason to hold for him a package, a package Srirham plans to personally deliver to his mother soon, back home in India. Jason, of course, agrees. Wham! The very next day, Srirham and his lovely wife are found dead in what is considered to be a murder/suicide circumstance. So what does Jason do? Of course, he decides to deliver the package to Srirham’s mother, as a last gesture to his dead friend.And so the adventure begins. In no time at all, Jason is off on a package tour to India. There, he meets a girl and soon, the tour is somewhere back in the dust. Now, if you begin to suspect this is a pretty over-the-top novel, you would not be mistaken. Reality and realism are not strong suits for this author. But if you say, oh, well, I’m along for the ride, then you’ll be in good hands. Benoit is a pretty good writer and he infuses the book with a high level of energy, great pace, enough twists and misdirection to keep the reader guessing, and if you just suspend every trace of disbelief you’ll have a good time with this novel.

An outstanding debut novel. Rosenfelt’s writing is brisk, honest and takes the reader directly into the lives of these very real characters. Defense lawyer Andy Carpenter endures the sudden death of his father, a retired prosecutor in New Jersey. Prowling through the records of his dad’s estate shock follows shock when Carpenter discovers an estate worth 22 million dollars. Where the money came from is a mystery that Andy sets out to solve.Meanwhile, to honor his father’s memory, Andy pursues appeals and wins a retrial for a death row inmate his father had prosecuted years earlier. And then dangerous and mysterious events begin to wrap themselves around Andy Carpenter, events that seem to bring him ever closer to the ultimate resolution, his own demise. In spite of his sometimes misplaced wit, Carpenter struggles through his moral and real dilemmas to a logical and satisfying solution.There are one or two places where clichés intrude but they are minor. The tale is convoluted, full of puzzling contradictions and masterfully told. A real winner in the crime fiction genre.

One of the perks of reading in the Crime Fiction genre, is that most of the good authors one reads are producing at a fairly steady pace. It is possible, therefore, in one’s lifetime, to follow the development of an author. Assuming they do develop.Such an author is Harlan Coben. And “One False Move” is arguably his best book to date. It is certainly an excellent, engaging novel. Sports agent Myron Bolitar is hired to look after a star player in a women’s basketball league that is just getting under way. Initially it appears to be a fairly simple task. Then Myron discovers Brenda, the player, has been getting threats, and than an old nemesis of Myron’s is trying to acquire the star’s contract. After that, things get complicated. The more involved Myron gets, the more involved and complicated the situation becomes.The complexities include political aspirations, Myron’s family, Brenda’s family, Myron’s former basketball coach, and other significant relationships. The author’s sure hand with this complex tapestry attests to his maturity in a book filled with tension, energy and enthralling characters. Author Harlan Coben has plenty to say in his thoughtful, powerful way. An excellent novel.

As with many collections of short stories by Crime authors, this one is a mixed bag, quality wise. It contains several really nice, taut, economic stories which are entertaining, surprising and a pleasure to read. There are others which don’t quite measure up, although all of them are readable. The anthology was conceived as a way to provide some financial support for the popular co-owner of one of the best mystery books stores in the nation. Once Upon A Crime, the store for which the anthology is named, has been voted by readers of CrimeSpree magazine, the best independent mystery bookstore in the entire country. It is also a recipient of the Raven Award.I wish this anthology achieved that distinction. It comes close. The stories are widely varied by a motley collection of new and experienced crime writers. It is, as I have said, entertaining, but its greatest value may be in that it introduces readers to a range of writers and the quality of their work. Among the writers are several award winners of note, including William Kent Krueger, Reed Farrell Coleman, Max Allen Collins, Gary Phillips and David Housewright. It’s a good value.

M. D. Lake is a retired college professor who writes tidy campus-based mysteries for his own and others' amusement. Lake's series protagonist is a campus cop, Peggy O'Neil, who works at a major Midwestern university that is described in these books in a way that seems suspiciously like the University of Minnesota. One can imagine some of Lake's potential targets.Peggy O'Neil is a street-smart cop who's wicked sense of humor is tempered by her Minnesota nice. Her character is engaging, she acts as one would expect such a cop to act who is also burdened with a strong sense of justice. She and her friends are a lot of fun to read about and the book is intelligent and competently written.Once upon a Crime tells the interesting tale of a prominent Danish scholar, named Jens Aage Lindemann, who comes to campus to conduct a conference on a storyteller we've all heard of, named Hans Christian Andersen.
