Both of them end up in grave danger.Though teenagers like dystopian works, this one, like Atwood’s THE HANDMAID’S TALE, is absolutely for adults or very sophisticated older teens.  Though it is very well-written and engaging, saying it is harsh is putting it mildly.  There are very harsh themes and incidents, even in the seemingly perfect Consilience world, and Stan’s language, especially, is peppered with the “f-bomb.”  I must hold at four stars simply as a warning about the extreme harshness.

I chose this product because we recently adopted a dog (Australian shepherd/Border collie mix, age estimated at 1.5 years) that tends to dig under the edge of the porch.  This digging is dangerous because she could be injured if she got underneath, and we hoped that this product would stop her.I’m sorry to say that this repellent does not seem to stop her.  She still digs, even where the repellent was applied.  I was concerned that this might happen even when the product arrived because she was curious about the scent rather than put off by it.This repellent may work to help train some pets, but it didn’t work for us.

This is a full set of fifteen pairs of straight bamboo knitting needles; sizes range from 0 (very fine, for knitted lacework) to 15 (very chunky).  There are no size 12’s but that size isn’t in frequent use.I already owned a similar full set of bamboo double pointed needles (five to the set) and really like them.  When I was working on a sweater with metal straight size 4 needles, I was almost fussing and ripping more than I was progressing with the sweater because metal is slippery and the sweater pattern has a lacy panel down the front. So my husband asked where I might get some better (less slippery) needles, weren’t my bamboo DPNs less slippery.  I ordered these and immediately transferred the work to the appropriate size of bamboo needles when the set arrived.  Things went much better after that – less slippage, more comfortable grip, much happier me.I have one concern and one technical complaint about these needles:  If you are working an intricate pattern with slip, slip, knit, or knit 2 (or 3) together with finer sizes of these needles, the bamboo needles will bend.  Try to be as gentle as possible; bamboo is a grass and might break.  Also, for straight needles, the size number would be much better on the bead at the end of the needle than on the shaft of the needle where it could fade.  (Mine now have the size marked on the bead.)Overall, though, I give these bamboo needles a very high 4 star rating. These are smooth but not slippery and have a good feel/grip.  Try them; your work will probably be a lot easier and more pleasant to do.

We recently adopted an Australian Shepherd-Border Collie mix said to be about 1.5 years old.  Anyone who knows these breeds at all knows that they are intelligent and physical, and absolutely must have plenty of physical and mental stimulation.  We remembered how much our very old dog (a Border Collie mix going on 14 years old) loved her Jolly Ball when she was younger, so I looked for one for the new dog.Similar balls for dogs at the local farm store had floss instead of a molded handle.  Dogs that play hard can fray the floss and harm themselves with the frayed thread.  This one with a molded handle is just the thing.Did the younger dog like her new ball?  Absolutely yes!  I tossed the ball once, and she knew exactly what to do; she shook it, ran with it, cuffed it with her paws, rolled around with it, the works!If you have a dog like ours – young, with a low boredom threshold, buy one of these for him/her.  The dog will love it!

Francis, perhaps about ten to twelve years old, has few friends at school, partially because his interests are different from those of other boys his age.  Francis likes fashion.  He sews and designs clothing and owns dolls that he uses as models.Andi, the same age as Francis, is a short, stocky red-headed girl, the youngest in a houseful of brothers.  She is no girly-girl, doesn’t hesitate to stand up for herself or others, and has been in serious trouble at previous schools for doing so.  She feels that she has few friends because she isn’t tall and pretty.Roland, also a tween, is a chubby, non-athletic boy.  His mother offers him too much unhealthful food.  He, too, feels like an outcast.Tying this unlikely trio together is Jessica.  Only these three youngsters can see or hear Jessica because she is a ghost; she was about the same age as the other three youngsters when she died.  Readers are surprised to learn how Jessica died and why she remains as a ghost (a mission to complete before moving on).This book is for about ages nine through twelve, and it is very well-written and very sensitively written. I can definitely recommend it. However, because of the themes (bullying, depression, and other serious matters), young readers will probably benefit from an adult presence when reading this book.  This gives the opportunity for discussion this type of book requires.

This bath towel for pets is the same size as bath towels for people.  The microfiber is absorbent and produces less lint (thus less mess) than cotton terry.  It feels softer than cotton terry, which may be a bonus for some dogs’ sensitive skin.  The embroidery (purchaser's choice of a paw print or a bone) adds a bit of fun and flair.I am holding at a good, solid 4 stars for two major reasons:  First, time will tell about the durability of this towel.  Second, I’m uncertain about washing it with chlorine bleach to sanitize it, something I have been taught to do with bed, bath, and kitchen linens.Overall, though, this towel is actually better -- the feel, the apparent durability so far, and the appearance -- than I expected.

Sloane has a good husband and a charming nine-year-old daughter.  Sloane’s husband earns enough for her to be a stay-at-home mom.  However, something is troubling Sloane, so she plans a three-week getaway at an aunt’s shoreline home for herself and her friend Hillary.  Then another friend, Georgina, who doesn’t seem to settle down anywhere, invites herself to join them.Hillary is a counselor. Just like Sloane, Hillary seems to have it all together, too – except for an apparent inability to conceive.  Readers soon learn the reason for this.Georgina has been globetrotting and living off her wealthy family’s trust fund.  She seems to be a fair-weather friend – someone who is present when things are good, but seems to disappear off the face of the earth when a friend needs her. She, too, has a secret that this novel reveals.I found this to be a good summer novel – reasonably engaging, but not at all deep.  I wanted to find out who would learn whose secrets, when, and how, and what would happen when the secrets were revealed.Though there is some strong language, drinking, and some veiled sexuality, if you’re looking for something to pop into your book bag to read in a summer afternoon or two, this book might be just the thing.

In Sweden, apparently near Stockholm, Elsa, almost eight years old, lives with her mother and her mother’s new partner in a multi-family building.  Her parents have divorced, but her father lives nearby.  Her mother and her mother’s new partner are expecting a child, whom the family refers to as Halfie.Elsa’s 77-year-old grandmother lives in the same building.  Elsa sees her granny as her one and only friend because other children don’t like her.  Elsa likes Harry Potter, Spiderman, and her granny’s stories about the Land of Almost Awake, and the other children bully her about this.  Elsa is an outcast because in some ways she is brilliant, and in other ways she is a fairly typical seven-year-old, even confusing “therapist” and “terrorist.”  Granny is – well – eccentric; she shoots paintballs at passersby from her balcony.Elsa does have one non-human friend – a large, black dog.  The dog, which Elsa calls a “wurse,” does, on occasion, show its affection toward Elsa, and, yes, defend her.Some of the other people in the building seem just as eccentric, in their own ways.  Britt-Marie wants to start a residents’ organization, similar to an HOA in the U.S., and has her own ideas about rules and the benefit of all.  Britt-Marie’s partner Kurt is constantly on the phone to someone in Germany about supposed business matters.  All the characters impress me as exactly how a seven-year-old might see such people.Elsa’s granny is diagnosed with terminal cancer.  Granny, upon her death, sends Elsa with a mission – to deliver letters of apology to many different people.  I’ll let readers be surprised about the very last letter among these, but I will say that the letters are just as eccentric as Granny.Backman does an excellent job with the setting.  He has an excellent way of reminding readers about the short daylight hours Sweden has during the winter, and people who have never been to Sweden can imagine the place and time.Some passages and quirks are a little confusing to readers, but if adult readers imagine how they must have felt and what they must have thought at Elsa’s age, they would remember that they were puzzled about the world around them, too.This is an enjoyable novel that helps adults remember what the world is like through a child’s eyes.

Allen Paul’s HONEY THE DIXIE DINGO DOG is a first-person (first-dog?) narrative from the viewpoint of Honey, a rescued Dixie Dingo dog.  This is a breed that is also called the Carolina dog or Old Yeller dog and is prevalent in the Carolinas and Georgia.Honey not only tells us her story – her survival in the wild, her rescue, and something else very important – but also the story of her ancestors.  These dogs worked with the Native Americans of this area until the Trail of Tears, when the Native Americans had to cross the Mississippi River to Oklahoma and the dogs could not go with them.  Those dogs had their own trail of tears back to the Carolinas and Georgia.This work is fiction based on fact and thorough research.  There is artwork and photography interspersed through this short work.This book is for all ages, but young, very sensitive readers may be disturbed by some violence, animal cruelty, and mild language.  For these readers, an adult may want to stand by, but I still rate it Highly Recommended and can assure readers that there isn’t anything any stronger here than in the novel or film OLD YELLER and that readers will learn about an exceptional dog.

The 4 inch Bora drill press vise works well. It clamps well due to the two (2) guide rods that keep the clamp jaws straight.  The jaws of the drill press vise do not jam when they are closed tight; the jaws of the vise will release when reasonable force is used.  The material of the drill press vise jaws is such that it does not mar whatever is being held in it.  The drill press vise has a handle that will pivot 90 degrees in both directions; this allows more force to be applied with the jaws of the vise. The drill press vise has two (2) long slots in the base, one on each side.  The slots can be used to secure the drill press vise to the drill press table; this is a very useful feature. On the top of the drill press vise at the rear there is a button that when pushed and held it releases the threaded rod; which is used to apply tension to the vise jaws, so the jaw of the vise can be moved in or out quickly.  When the button is released the threaded rod engages and it functions as it is designed to and it controls the tension of the vise jaws. The Bora 4 inch drill press vise is very useful for small to medium work, however the vise to small and light for large work.  Using the Bora 4 inch drill press vise for large work would be unsafe and potentially dangerous, but for small or medium work it is great.

First, let me begin by saying that this is the first wireless router my household has ever dealt with; we are NOT experts with such things.  However, I chose this product because I thought it would be good to be able to use the Internet away from the big desktop computer when necessary.  Also, I must add that our internet service provider is a satellite system, and we live in rural (and I do mean rural!) Texas.Installation did not seem difficult.  My husband handled that; I heard few complaints of problems, and it didn’t take him long to do this.My trial usage was with a Surface notebook computer approximately fifteen feet from the main desktop computer.  I spent a few minutes visiting sites I frequent; it took slightly longer for sites to load than it would from the main desktop, but still not bad at all, and I suppose a slight bit slower can be expected.I do like that this router requires two security passwords:  one for the network itself and another for security.  I don’t know whether this is commonplace, but it probably is a good idea.I do believe that this router will serve us well during times when we cannot or do not wish to work from the desktop.  The apparent ease of installation and good performance make it a good choice for those like us who aren’t experts and want a reasonably priced router to free us from the desktop when necessary.

THE GOLDEN THRONE is Katia Fox’s third installment in a series set in the High Middle Ages.  Readers who have read THE COPPER SIGN and THE SILVER FALCON know the story of the sword smith Ellen and her son William.  THE GOLDEN THRONE tells the story of Guillaume Marechal, William’s father.As readers see in the earlier installments (and apparent by William’s birth), Guillaume and Ellen were lovers but, for many reasons, ended up loving and marrying other people.  Ellen wanted to make her life as a sword smith, a breaking of barriers especially for the time in which this series is set. Young William wishes to become a falconer. Guillaume wants only to become a knight and serve his king.  When he saves the queen’s life, he does get a position in the as a sword-fighting instructor for the prince.To that end, Guillaume endures intense training, goes to battle, earns the favor (and disfavor at times) of three different kings (Richard, Henry II, and John).  Yes, Guillaume seems vain and obnoxious at times, but sometimes the kings he serves were, too.  He still has feelings for Ellen but must marry Isabelle of Kilkenny.  He truly loves her, too, and they bear ten children together.  So Guillaume must deal with keeping his king and his family happy.This novel begins during Guillaume’s training in 1162 and closes with his death in May 1219.  Fox clearly shows Guillaume feeling his age as he grows older; he can’t ride horseback as long or as well as he did as a young man, and joints and muscles are more troublesome.  Fox bases this novel on historical fact, but does note that she takes some liberties with her own imagination.Though this novel can stand alone, readers will find it helpful to have read the first two.  Though ends are tied up (Guillaume’s death), there is still more to go on if Fox should choose to write more about the people of this time and place. The translation by Aubrey Botsford seems smooth and accurate.  Like the other two novels in the series, THE GOLDEN THRONE is rather long and dense, but I did not feel bogged down; in fact, I would like more.

THE MOON SISTERS is a novel by Therese Walsh.  It tells the story of two sisters in small-town West Virginia.  Jazz Moon is the older sister and the practical one; she has just been hired for a new job in her town, something different from the family bakery.  Olivia Moon is a dreamy, imaginative one.  She has synesthesia; she hears colors, sees sounds, and tastes words.  Olivia does not see very well at all; her eyes are damaged from looking directly at the sun for too long.Both must face their mother’s death.  Practical Jazz is almost certain that the mother’s death was a suicide, but Olivia has many doubts about that.  Both want closure.  Olivia’s means of seeking closure is to take their mother’s ashes to a bog, the setting of their mother’s unfinished novel.  She is determined to go, but this is days before Jazz is to start her new job – and Olivia cannot go by herself.On this mission, they meet several train hoppers who could mean them help or harm.  Tensions between the two sisters mount.The structure of the segments of this novel follow the pattern of grief, from denial to acceptance; this structure helps readers better understand each segment.I would recommend this book for anyone who has lost a loved one and also has siblings, especially siblings who have such opposite personalities as Jazz and Olivia.

POSITIVE is a memoir written by Paige Rawl with Ali Benjamin.  Rawl has been HIV positive from birth; medication in some form to control (but not cure) her HIV status has always been a part of her life, just as it would be for someone with any chronic condition.  Things turn when Rawl begins junior high school.  At a school party, she tells a so-called friend of her status in confidence, but within an hour the news is all over the school.The other students bully and ostracize Rawl and even call her “PAIDS.”  The principal says she can do nothing to protect Rawl, and the school counselor tells Rawl to stop the “drama.”  Rawl is on the soccer team; the coach is glad to have her because her status may evoke fear in the opposing team.But this is not typical junior high school “drama,” and Rawl does deserve some sympathy and protection because of her status.  Things become so bad that Rawl has pseudo-seizures brought on by stress and even attempts to take her own life.Now, Rawl is a student at Ball State University studying molecular biology, with the hope of one day finding help for those like her.  She also gives presentation about bullying and HIV/AIDS.This memoir is well-written; I can easily imagine this young woman sitting down and talking with her audience.  I was engaged throughout and still want to know how she’s doing.  She gives some good facts about bullying and HIV/AIDS.  However, I wish she’d stated her resources for this information more clearly; indeed those who know about HIV/AIDS know that these facts are common knowledge with no citations necessary, but those who still fear those of this status would want to know where these facts came from and whether these resources would be trustworthy to that fearful audience.  With those thoughts in consideration, this would be a good resource for an anti-bullying or HIV/AIDS program in junior high school or high school health classes with many good talking points.Note about me:  I’m trained as a teacher/librarian.

THE ABYSS BEYOND DREAMS: CHRONICLE OF THE FALLERS by Peter F. Hamilton is set in the 3300’s in what seems like a very different – but very realistic, considering the time setting – story world.  Beings can be easily rejuvenated, giving them near-immortality.  They also have “tee-kay” (telekinesis) and can “fuzz” (become invisible to others.But this is not a perfect world.  These beings are dealing with Fallers, beings that can “eggsume” them – consume their bodies, and, apparently, their souls.  Technology presented in this novel impresses me as mixed; there is interplanetary travel, but there is also low-tech travel – horses and buggies.  The government in the main world readers visit in this novel is extremely corrupt.Slvasta, a captain in this world’s armed forces, sees this corruption and excessive bureaucracy and decides he must do something about it.  He also knows that something must be done about the Fallers; he was rescued just in time from a Faller “eggsumation” but lost an arm to this Faller. He and an unlikely group – including a seventeen-year-old girl who is escaping to avoid an arranged marriage – start creating cells to foment a revolution.This novel is long – 600+ pages – is arranged in several books, and is very dense.  There is some front matter in my advance copy that explains some of the story world’s history, but, as dense as this work is, more front matter introducing the characters and telling more about the story world, would have been very helpful.  Hardcore science fiction readers about age 16 and older will probably enjoy reading THE ABYSS BEYOND DREAMS.

THE GUARDIAN HERD: STARFIRE is a middle grades (about ages 8-12) novel that tells the story of a young pegasus foal names Starfire.  He is growing up in the Sun Herd, one of the five herds of Anok, under the care of a foster mare.  He knows he has a great destiny; he could be a healer, or he could be a destroyer.  Neither he nor the other pegasi of the Five Herds knows which way his fate will go.  Because of fear among the other pegasi, Starfire might not even live beyond his first birthday.This novel is Jennifer Lynn Alvarez’s first novel, and even adult readers will be drawn into the storyline and the characters (mostly pegasi, but a few other animals).  An extensive list of characters in the front matter describes members, young and old, of each herd. The one caution I offer for very sensitive young readers:  there are violent fights among the animals, and some animals that readers do care about die.Overall verdict:  Five stars.  Highly recommended.Who I am:  I am trained as a teacher/librarian.

My Oceanique bath rug has just arrived, and I must admit to mixed opinions about it.The good points?  The cream color and the simple horizontal pattern in the loft suit almost any bath décor.  It is washable cotton and does feel soft against bare feet.The bad points?  This rug is 17” by 24” – a little small, but that may be fine for smaller bathrooms.  Instructions indicate that it should be dried flat, not in the dryer.  Perhaps the worst bad point of all is that I felt little to no slip-resistant backing when I felt this rug and walked on it; that is a potential fall hazard.  For that reason, I would not recommend this bath rug for use in a home with elderly, disabled, or small children.Overall verdict:  A very low three stars; I would not have chosen this bath rug if I had seen it in a brick-and-mortar store rather than as a Vine selection.

In a dystopian U.K. in the not too distant future, readers meet Kyla.  She is about sixteen years old, and she has been slated; all her memories have been erased.  She is just released from a long stay in a hospital, even learning to walk, talk, and feed herself again.  She has a different identity and has been placed with a new family.  This is punishment for a crime she has no memory of committing. Supposedly to keep unwanted emotions such as anger in check, the Slated must wear a bracelet that can cause them to have seizures or even die.  “Happy juice” is liberally administered. Slated youth are required to attend counseling sessions.Kyla resumes school and finds that she excels in the visual arts.  She can draw better with what she believes to be her non-dominant hand; people, including teachers, are openly taken away by the Lorders (police) and disappear. She learns things that don’t add up about the Slated; they may or may not have actually committed crimes.Because of violence and themes, I recommend this book for readers about age fourteen and older who are interested in dystopian fiction.

Stacy Jay's PRINCESS OF THORNS takes the Grimm Brothers' SLEEPING BEAUTY a step farther and is intended for about age fourteen and up because of violence and very veiled sexuality.  (The sexuality is there, but it's veiled like fade-outs in older movies.)Aurora is the daughter of the awakened Sleeping Beauty.  When Aurora is seven years old, her mother dies in her arms. Aurora is gifted with her mother's fairy magic but is cursed never to love anyone except perhaps as one would love a sibling.  Aurora's brother Jor is captured by troops of the Ogre Queen, and Aurora must raise an army to rescue him.  When the main part of the story opens, she is a small but slightly round seventeen-year-old but with fairy powers and warrior training.Meanwhile, Prince Niklaas, also seventeen, must overcome his own curse.  He is the eleventh of his brothers, and, on his eighteenth birthday, faces the same fate his ten older brothers did - transformation to a swan.Aurora, disguised as Ror, a boy of about fourteen, seeks Niklaas's help to raise an army and rescue Jor.  Niklaas is persuaded to help this odd "boy," and plot twists ensue.This story is told from three different viewpoints:  Aurora's (watch out, readers, she does call herself "Ror" to other characters for most of the story), Niklaas's, and, in a few chapters, the Ogre Queen's (watch out here, too; she tells her tale in the royal plural "we.").  The voice of each viewpoint is distinctive and there are headings to alert readers who is telling his or her tale.Maps in the front matter introduce readers to the story world.I found this an enjoyable fantasy novel for teens and up taken from a well-known tale.

It is 1962 in Denver. Katharyn (usually known as Kitty) Miller, a single woman in her late 30’s, runs a bookstore called Sisters’ with her best friend Frieda.  Her life is not the norm for women her age in that time, but she happily lives in a duplex with her cat Aslan.  She was once in a serious relationship with a young doctor named Kevin, but things didn’t work out.  She tried running a personals ad years ago and arranged to meet a gentleman, but the gentleman, Lars Andersson, didn’t appear.  Later she finds out why.It is 1963 in Denver.  Katharyn Andersson has married Lars, whom she contacted eight years before in a personals ad.  They have a nice home and are the parents of triplets, two boys and a girl. One son is diagnosed as autistic.This novel goes back and forth between Kitty’s and Katharyn’s world, from one reality to another.  Kitty/Katharyn, as well as readers, wonder what she is doing in the other woman’s world and how the other manages.  Kitty, of course, struggles with the children, in particular the autistic son.Swanson gives a good backdrop of the times.  She adds details about the Cuban missile crisis and Kennedy, as well as the growth of Denver during that time.  This backdrop is important to the storyline because Kitty and Frieda must consider choices about their business as Denver changes.I found myself truly pulled into this novel and wondered throughout which world was a dream world and which was reality – and found the theme of life paths and choices intriguing.

NEST tells the story of Naomi Orenstein of Cape Cod, in about 1972. Naomi is eleven years old and lives there with her dad, a psychiatrist; her mom, a dancer; and her sister Rachel, about two years older than Naomi.Naomi is an average eleven-year-old.  She has the typical love-hate relationship with school – sometimes a little more hate than love because of an uncertain-of-herself first-year teacher.  She quarrels with her sister and her friends at times.  She becomes friends with Joey, the boy across the street, whose family isn’t the best – and the youngsters do find mischief together.  One thing Naomi loves and understands is bird watching; she knows the birds of her area very well, to the point of having the nickname “Chirp.”Then Naomi’s mom becomes ill, and everything seems to fall apart for the whole Orenstein family. Responsibilities within the family change.This novel is very well-written, and I can recommend it for the appropriate age group with one provision:  Because of some of the thematic elements readers encounter, I would recommend that the intended readership (about ages nine through twelve) read it with an adult available to discuss these themes and how things have changed since the time this novel is set.Five stars, but adult presence advised.Who I am:  I hold degrees in English and library science.

This bread knife is very good, but it takes a bit of a learning curve if one has become accustomed to using a non-serrated knife to slice bread.  The first time I used this knife on my own homemade bread I felt as if it hacked the bread rather than sliced it, and the slice was much larger than I wanted.  Apparently, I was dealing with the lean to the left that other reviewers mentioned.  However, I obviously needed to accustom myself to a serrated knife, and a little practice remedied these problems.The grip is good – soft but not too soft.  A good grip is important to me because my hands are smallish and not very strong.Prospective buyers need to remember that, like most knives, this one really should be washed by hand, not in the dishwasher.Overall, with some practice, users will find this to be a good knife but not one that merits an excellent rating.

In this collection of essays, Mikita Brottman endeavors to highlight twenty-six dogs from the arts, literature, and philosophy.  She does this in alphabetical order, starting with an introduction, then the story of a standard poodle named Atma, owned by Arthur Schopenhauer, and ending with a greyhound named Zemire, owned by Catherine the Great of Russia. Brottman intertwines information about these dogs with her own experiences with her French bulldog Grisby.There are citations in back matter for the resources Brottman uses in each chapter.This would impress readers as being very organized, and, in some ways, it is.  However, many of the individual essays seem to wander.  Brottman begins each essay with information about the dog she is highlighting, but then she meanders to information about another dog, then to information or an anecdote about Grisby, then perhaps to information about yet another dog, then back to the dog she intends to highlight.  Is she perhaps trying to emulate the way dogs meander when they're out for a walk, and how their interest goes from one thing to another?  Perhaps, but this doesn't work for me in writing.I also note one apparent error in fact.  When Brottman mentions the dog Bobby, a dog that legend says never left his owner's grave after his owner died, she incorrectly identifies Bobby as a Scottie, or Scottish terrier.  The legend gives Bobby's breeding as a Skye terrier.With all this in mind, I must say that overall I found this book to be interesting reading, but this advance copy shows a need for some stylistic and factual cleanup.  If Brottman will check her facts and reduce her meandering within the essays, dog lovers will find this an excellent read.

This lubricant works very well as a spray lubricant and/or penetrating oil.The dispensing spray nozzle is large and easy to control and direct.  The spray straw is easy to install in the spray nozzle and stays in place until removed, which is a very good feature.This product compares very favorably to other well-known similar products.Even though this is a good product, the manufacturer’s suggested retail price seems high.Quality and usability: 5 starsPrice: 4 stars

Is college, particularly a four-year university, the best answer for every young person after high school, or are some young people better off making a different choice?  Why is post-secondary education so expensive?  Is it worthwhile for young people to graduate from a four-year university drowning in debt? What are the best colleges and majors for return-on-investment?These are the questions that Bennett and Wilezol attempt to answer in this book.  The authors impress me as very frank, but they seem to emphasize the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) or perhaps health care mindset over education (and, excuse me, I was appalled at one mention in the main text wondering why teachers needed a college education!), liberal arts, and humanities.  But there are people who simply don't have the mindset for STEM coursework - neither the talents nor the temperament -- and the authors offer very little to help these people.Though I think the content is very biased toward the STEM students, I did like the twelve hypothetical scenarios and the honest suggestions the authors made for each case.  The style throughout this book, but particularly in the "verdicts" for these scenarios, seems straightforward and honest, as if the authors were indeed sitting down with the person in each particular scenario.So, yes, this book is slanted toward the authors' viewpoints - political and otherwise.  Yes, they sometimes cite their own earlier works and works that show their slant.  However, in spite of the apparent imbalances, Bennett and Wilezol offer food for thought for young people and their families.

Jeremiah Conway’s THE ALCHEMY OF TEACHING is a collection of six anecdotes of incidents during his teaching career at the University of Southern Maine.  Educators, especially those who have taught at the college level (two-year or four-year) can smile as they relive similar “aha moments” with Conway: the lesson apparently gone so wrong, the seemingly-difficult student, the seriously ill student, and more.This book’s back matter consists of a readers’ guide with discussion questions for each chapter that truly do give pause about what Conway has to say.This is not so much a book about HOW to teach, but it helps teachers consider WHY they teach.  Conway is a master storyteller and obviously, and excellent teacher who truly encourages his students to think.  Were I attending his university, I would certainly try to enroll in one of his classes.

Samantha (Sam) McKenna is sixteen years old, the youngest of four siblings in a military family, and, on a dare from her older brother, has just enrolled in Denmark Military Academy.  She is about a year older than the typical beginning student at the Academy, and among the first of five girls to be admitted.Since Sam is a military brat herself, she knows that life at the Academy is hard, especially the first year.  Another older brother of Sam's is Cadet Colonel and cannot be seen as showing favoritism toward her.  A group of the other cadets don't want girls at DMA, so she and the other girls are treated especially harshly to try to wash them out - send them packing.  "Smoke shows" - extreme periods of push-ups, jumping jacks, high-knees and more, for hours, at all hours - are meant to break Sam and the other girls.  In addition, Sam uncovers information about a secret society involving past and current cadets that could have serious implications.  She also gets involved with forbidden romance and fraternization - in her own case and other students'.I am impressed by the military jargon and style in this novel.  The jargon is a combination of what ground and air forces (Army, Marines, Air Force) and sea forces (Navy and Coast Guard) use.  This style works, because the students may well be going into different branches of the military after graduation from DMA.I am also impressed with Sam's determination to survive not only Hell Week and her first semester, but also her determination to graduate as one of the first young women from DMA, in spite of the "Old School" attitude of past and present cadets and a family situation.I would recommend this novel for about tenth grade and older because there is some profanity, violence, and underage drinking that the adults in charge overlook.  However, the tension and apparent accuracy are such that I truly wanted to see Sam make it through

This set of bath towels consists of a face cloth, a fingertip towel, a hand towel, and a large bath towel.  The main color is off- white, which is indeed suitable for most décor, and the seashell and starfish embellishments also suit most baths.However, these towels are far from practical!  The care tag even suggests dry cleaning (Dry cleaning?  Bath towels?!), probably because of the embellishments (small shells) on the bath towel trim. I also have concerns about how the shell trim would feel – or hold up – during use. The velour from which these are made is not as absorbent as plain looped terry.  Nor is bleaching these towels recommended, and there are times when bath and bed linens must be bleached.Beauty = five stars.  Practicality = low one star.  Anticipated durability =  one to two stars.  Apparent absorbency: 2 . Average = 2.25

THE RIVER AND ENOCH O’REILLY is a dark, perplexing novel setting a river’s flooding of a small village in Ireland with a young man named Enoch O’Reilly.  The author weaves scenes of the 1980’s flood with the story of a young man named Enoch O’Reilly.  O’Reilly was fascinated by his Da’s ham radio equipment when he was a boy; as a young man he becomes an Elvis impersonator and a televangelist over the radio.  Yet when O’Reilly starts seminary, he is removed because he openly states doubts about his belief in God.  But he starts his radio televangelism anyway, and it ends with a big surprise for the audience.This novel is not in linear time; readers must pay attention to the chapter headings or they won’t know when and where they are.  Don’t try to take this one too quickly, or you’ll be lost, and hang on for quite a ride.

NO BOOK BUT THE WORLD is a novel about two siblings, Ava and Fred.  They grew up together on a “free school” without any formal lessons; they learned through play in the woods at their so-called free school, named Batter Hollow, and by teachable moments.Ava and Fred become close with another family who live on the free school grounds; Kitty is about Ava’s age; Dennis is older, but he eventually becomes Ava’s husband. Fred has some developmental differences that his parents refuse to have diagnosed; they simply see him as unique.Ava and Fred grow up and go their separate ways, and their parents die.  One day Ava gets word that Fred has been incarcerated; he’s accused of molesting and killing a twelve-year-old boy.  But did he do it?  Do his differences have anything to do with what he’s accused of doing? Would they be a defense, once properly diagnosed, or would they hurt his case?  How far should one sibling go to help another? There seem to be more questions than answers as Fred’s court appointed attorney studies the case and tries to build a defense.The story thread does go back and forth from the days that Ava, Kitty, and Fred played together all day at Batter Hollow  -- including arguments between Ava’s parents about how Ava and Fred should be educated --  to the present day in Perdu, where Fred is incarcerated, so readers need to pay attention. The pace of the “childhood” scenes in particular seems slow, but just consider that pace to be similar to long summer days that carry through year round at Batter Hollow.Readers expect the several sections of this novel to be in different literary points of view, but there is a surprise about that at the end – and this isn’t the only twist, either.

This is a mystery story with a twist.  We have a pastor who is in a bank when robbers enter.  Our pastor is probably different than any other that you know.  He is also a marriage counselor.  As he goes about his parish work he manages to get himself in trouble.  He is given an opportunity to rent a yacht for his work.  The well developed and well rounded characters in this story will gain your interest and hold it until the last page.  The story has suspense as well as mystery.

A great study in what happens when you are raised by a cold hard father.  Two little girls whose fun loving mother dies after a fire on their homestead.  The children are sent by the father to live with elderly uncles where they experience a normal home life.  The girls grow up with very serious problems.  They solve them in various ways.  This is a very good story well written to keep your interest.  The characters are drawn so that they live on the page for you.  This is not a quick read because of the depth of the story woven around them. They all harbor secrets that affect them all.

Bullying in schools is rampant and it seems like no one really knows how to solve this problem.  This story is about a very loving young lady trying her best to just survive.  Some girls in her school decide they don't like her and daily pick on her.  As she tries to escape the torment she is struck by a school bus and killed. Death whisks her away to a Better Place.  Her expectations are high after she tries to accept she is no long living.  The rest of the story is a tale from a good story teller.  We follow her for a few days and discover some unsettling truths.  Our young lady is so well portrayed she becomes real to you and you want to change things for the better for her.  A short and very good story. Would even recommend this to older young people.

A pleasure to read about truckers in a positive note. It proves to be a hard job running your deceased Father's trucking company.  Especially when you only knew part of the business.  The clerical part of it.  Trying to deal with the sudden unexpected death of your father makes the job that much harder.  You cannot rest.  You ask a friend, a retired R.C.M.P. and a trucker to look into the death and find out why he died.  The surprise ending was not expected.  The characters in this story are so well developed you feel that you know them or people who they remind you of. A book worth your time in the reading.  Not your typical mystery.

An excellent book with a cunningly developed main character.  With the droughts that are occurring right now this was a timely subject for a good story. It depicts an engineering feat worthy of renown,  politically stealing water from a valley in Northern Nevada and piping it to Los Vegas where the large population has depleted it water resources.  It describes the sometimes insurmountable problems that can happen.  The story has diverse characters whose lives are interwoven making them very memorable.  The end is an unexpected surprise.  Great read.

When I have no inkling of the actual murderer until the end of the book, that is a very good story teller at work.  Mr. McDonald has written a story different than most mystery in that the main character is a Human Relations Manager in a Corporation.  As such he uses the skills he has developed over the years to size up people.  He has an employee that is doing some things against the company policies and has to call him in on the carpet.  He disappears that day and his family asks for his help to find out why. Someone not involved in law enforcement is suddenly involved in city politices, the world of real estate and dirty police.  A very good read with well developed characters..

The very first page of this  gentle Sci fi story about another dimension grabbed my attention and held it to the end.  I would recommend this book highly even to older young people.  It has enough suspense to keep you turning pages.  The characters have depth and are nicely rounded out.  The romance involved is gentle with no sex.  I did find the language trite at times but kept reminding myself that is was a period piece.  Sci Fi that is believable.

Keeley was a successful lawyer until a condition causing syncope caused her to leave the profession.  She moves to Danger Cove for a less stressful life.  She has studied to become a quilt appraiser feeling that it is not a stressful job.  She wants to be hired by the local museum as their appraiser giving her a fairly steady income.  She takes other jobs on the side waiting for the board to make up their minds.  The world of quilting has many thief's stealing high price quilts.  Others make and sell for outrageous prices what they pass off for old valuable quilts.  Danger for Keeley as she tries to solve a murder involving passing off fakes.  A beautifully written story with much suspense.  Small town of Danger Cove where much goes on. Characters are so well depicted that you feel you know them as friends by the end of the book.  So much fun reading this book. Difficult to detect the murderer until the last few pages.
As promised the book does have some hacks that even old time campers can use.  I managed to find a few that I did not know.  Anything to improve your camping experience is helpful.

Women's agony at reaching the age when they have to give up the hope of having a child.  No matter how educated you become when the urge to have a child comes upon you and you have used up every possible means to conceive you run the gauntlet of  emotions.  Ms. Alden successfully takes you through her agony and eventually to how she was able to accept her fate.  Beautifully written.

I'm very disturbed by the number of products for sale on this site offering super high doses of vitamin D. The US Institute of Medicine (IOM) sets a safe upper limit for vitamin D of 4000 IU per day. Even a single capsule of this supplement exceeds that.Note that the IOM is a division of the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine. It operates under congressional charter.On an empirical level it's also important to be aware that the research tells us that there's a "reverse J shaped" relationship between blood levels of vitamin D and all cause mortality (i.e. death). In other words, as your vitamin D levels go up, your chance of dying goes down... up to a point. Beyond that point it starts to rise again. Just because some is good, that doesn't necessarily mean that more is better. The most recent research also links high vitamin D levels specifically to cardiovascular deaths.Because Amazon doesn't like external links in product reviews, I'm going to include some in the comments immediately below this review should you wish to verify this or do further investigation for yourself.Theo.

Even a single capsule of this supplement exceeds that.Note that the IOM is a division of the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine. In other words, as your vitamin D levels go up, your chance of dying goes down... up to a point. Beyond that point it starts to rise again. Just because some is good, that doesn't necessarily mean that more is better. The most recent research also links high vitamin D levels specifically to cardiovascular deaths.Because Amazon doesn't like external links in product reviews, I'm going to include some in the comments immediately below this review should you wish to verify my claims or do further investigation for yourself.Theo.

This is one of those cases where the book's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness. Why? Well, as you may have guessed from my title, it's... yes, full of inside jokes.In many ways this makes for a fascinating read. The view from the trenches of the animation industry is often a surprising one. Sometimes it's _exactly_ what you'd expect: the take on Michael Eisner, for example. Other times it's completely different. The view that emerges of Uncle Walt himself is unlike anything I've heard before - from either his detractors or his admirers. And in still other cases  the author makes jokes about things that would never even have occurred to an outsider, not in a million years. Like the "dress code" at Pixar.But for this selfsame reason, I found it very hard to actually laugh at these jokes. They're just not of my world. My primary reaction to almost all of the cartoons in this book was more along the lines of "Oh, that's interesting". And then, often, I would smile to myself. But not laugh. Not even once.None of which is to say that I think the author is a bad cartoonist. I'm quite sure that many of his cartoons would not only have been a scream, but also very daring - for the audience for which they were originally intended. Which is to say, his fellow insiders.But for us, the outsiders?For us, it's more along the lines of an academic exercise. Or at least, it was for me.So should you buy this book? That depends on what you hope to get out of it. If you're motivated primarily by curiosity, if you're looking for that insider's view, then read no further: this book is for you. Buy it now.But if you're looking for something to actually make you laugh..?In my humble opinion, no.I received a free copy in exchange for an honest review.Theo.

If you're a grown-up looking for something you can watch with the kids and maybe even enjoy yourself, you've definitely hit the mark. The only qualifier I'd insert here is that if you are considering this film as a parent, there are a few scenes towards the end that might be a little scary for some younger children. No blood or guts, you understand. Just... perhaps a little scary.Similarly, if you're a grown-up hard core animation fan like me who's followed the work of both Tim Burton and Neil Gaiman with great interest for decades, then again, this is a film you're going to want to see.But...While by no means a bad film, this doesn't quite catch either Burton or Gaiman at their absolute best. My main reservation here is that I feel the story gives itself away a little too easily, a little too early on. In previous reviews I've observed that if it's true that there are only a finite number of stories - stories that are told and retold again and yet again across the generations - then the real job of the storyteller is to disguise this fact. To somehow make us forget that we've heard it all before. Even if we ourselves must needs be - to varying degrees - complicit in that forgetfulness.For the adult viewer, this film doesn't quite pull that trick off. We're just a little too aware, almost from the very beginning, exactly which story this is, where our heroine is going to wind up, and exactly how she's going to get there.Provided you can live with that flaw, this is an amazing thing just to look at and to listen to. On a visual level it has the playfully Gothic charm of so much of Tim Burton's work. The sheer craftsmanship that's gone into creating the visual side of this film is incredible. Coraline was apparently created almost entirely using traditional stop motion techniques.Of course, especially when employing the more technically demanding forms of animation, one major risk that directors need to be aware of is the temptation to include shots that exist only to show off the animator's virtuosity. There are a few instances of this near the beginning of the film, although it gets better in that regard as it goes along. By the end, the animator's art is employed entirely in the service of the greater whole.The actors do a similarly superb job. Although I must admit that I feel that Keith David and John Hodgman both got shortchanged in the credits: French & Saunders bumped them down a notch out of deservedly higher billing - apparently by sheer weight of star power. I mean, I _like_ French & Saunders, but still...The titular character of Coraline herself is an especially impressive creation - the work of both the animators and an enormously talented (and still very young) Dakota Fanning. You can't help but wonder at the body of work that lies ahead of her in adulthood. Somehow she strikes me as someone with a little more going for her than just cuteness - someone who's likely to beat the child star curse and do amazing things as an adult actor.Finally, this is one of those films where the title and incidental music most definitely deserve special mention. Kudos to composer Bruno Coulais. Tim Burton has obviously long known the importance of this element of filmmaking; witness his 1989 version of Batman, which, courtesy of Danny Elfman, gave us one of film's most memorable and enduring riffs.In the end, I see this work as a kind of flawed masterpiece. I do wish that it didn't give itself away quite so easily. But there's still an enormous amount here that's worth seeing.Theo.
Bad.

This animated series from the mid nineties still stands as one of Nickelodeon's better efforts. It's not on the same level as the first season of Ren & Stimpy, but it's got nothing to be embarrassed about either.The basic premise of the show is that there's an entire secret underground of monsters who live to scare humans. The show is centred around a group of three young monsters at a live-in academy where they've been sent to learn this skill. If that sounds like a rather prosy premise (and let's face it - it is), this is a show that nevertheless manages to make it work: mainly by virtue of its own densely grunge aesthetic. It may not be Ren & Stimpy, but it ain't Harry Potter neither.For serious film and animation buffs, there's a lot to take in. For example, in a recurring role as Simon The Monster Hunter, Jim Belushi reveals himself to be an extremely talented voice actor. Tim Curry does the same in his role as the bug-like monster Zimbo. For those more specifically interested in animation, Charlie Adler, arguably the pre-eminent voice actor of the era, appears in what is essentially the show's starring role as Ickis.Perhaps most interestingly, serious animation enthusiasts will notice a definite similarity in the music used in this series, and that of the adult animated series Aeon Flux. Not surprisingly, that's because the two share a common composer: Tim Blake. The unique sound he provides - a kind of absurdly operatic cacophony - contributes much to this show's twisted aesthetic.Like any cartoon from days gone by, Aaahh!!! Real Monsters will doubtless pick up a certain number of sales from pure nostalgia. Fair enough. But even from a strictly grown up perspective, it does have more going for it than that.It is a show you can watch for the first time as an adult, and still grow to love.Theo.

Okay, I couldn't resist the Star Wars reference. And truthfully, there is a little Star Wars here. But what I love most about this film is that it reminded me what I love most about Marvel: that sense of a true Universe that comes along as part of the Marvel package. A rich and storied cosmos with history and depth and an ongoing continuity all of its own. A fantastic, larger than life realm where big personalities abound, and around any corner we might find people or things filled with electrifying energy; events pregnant with cosmic portent. A place where godlings walk among us, and every flame burns just that much brighter.Yes, I love the Marvel Universe. And we are deep, deep inside it in this film.The Star Wars thing... can be overstated. It's there, but the people who dwell too long upon it have not, I think, seen very much in the way of science fantasy. For example, one scene in this film reminded me of nothing so much as an old episode of Invader Zim. Specifically "The Fry Cook What Came from All That Space". And trust me: that's a good thing. As you might then guess, this is not a film that takes itself too seriously. That's another good thing. It is, quite simply, an enormous delight to watch. It's laugh out loud funny, but at the same time, a long long way from mere spoof or self-parody. It's more of a rollicking swashbuckler, but with spaceships and blaster pistols instead of tall ships and rapiers - and get down funkiness in place of rococo.Through most of this film I really thought I was going to give it five stars. However, I found the ending just a little weak. For that and that alone, I'm knocking it down to four.Nevertheless, if you're looking for a movie that's just plain fun, you'd be hard pressed to do better than this one.Theo.

If there's one thing Couteney Cox brings to her character, it's an immense likeability. Seriously, you just instantly like this woman. I'm sure Sally Field would be proud. In fact, you like all of the characters. They're all soft and cuddly, likeable people. No sharp edges anywhere. Except perhaps in the aptly named "Barb", who's brought in for a few seconds here and there as comic relief. It's like dwelling in a universe of stuffed toys: every plushie's fantasy.But I ask you: is that enough? Because this show is SO gosh-darned likeable, you really want it to be smart too. And edgy. Unfortunately it isn't even remotely either one of those things. In fact, despite the "adult themes", it's got to be the farthest thing from a truly grown up show I've seen in a long time.Take Grayson, our heroine's across-the-cul-de-sac neighbor. Within literally three seconds of meeting him, we know he's her real series-spanning love interest: Dylan to her Brenda; Sam to her Dianne. And unless this is the first TV show we've ever seen (and I do mean EVER) we also instantly know that it's going to take as many seasons as the writers can manage to string this thing out for for these two people to really get together properly and make it work. At the same time, we also just as instantly know that there'll be many near misses and a few ill-fated false starts along the way. And of course, once they do get properly together the writers will have to break them up again, because a stable, mature relationship doesn't make for good television. Seriously, all this is instantly obvious within three seconds.My Little Pony is edgier than this. WAY edgier in fact. Come to think of it, the latest incarnation of that particular franchise actually is kinda edgy in its own sweet way. But... you get my point. For edginess, go to My Little Pony. Not Cougar Town.PROS: If your ultimate fantasy is to live in a universe of cuddly stuffed toys, then you've just come home.CONS: You may already have seen the Care Bears.(Seriously, if they gave those fuzzy little guys functioning genitalia and allowed them to do their thinking with them just occasionally, well, that's Cougar Town.)Theo.

For anyone with an interest in the paranormal, visionary experiences, or just pop culture, I'd definitely rate this one as a must read. It tells - in some detail - the story of a life I was hitherto unaware of. Before learning of this book, to me the "dero" were just monsters in an old edition of Dungeons & Dragons. And "Ray Palmer" was just the secret identity of the silver-age Atom: a DC superhero who I now know was named in homage to this real life Ray Palmer.Palmer's professional life began in the science fiction pulps of the 1930's and 40's, and ended with him editing no-less pulpy publications dealing with UFO's and general paranormal phenomena. To be completely honest, in some ways I find this journey a little sad. It seems to me that he started out in a rather fun place, and ended up devoting much of his life to the purely and simply crackpot. While I do believe that paranormal phenomena can be the subject of legitimate and serious inquiry, it is very hard to buy into the idea that Ray Palmer was ever engaged in such.To what extent Palmer himself believed in what he was publishing is forever an open question.Nevertheless, this is a genuinely interesting book. I would especially recommend it to anyone with an interest in the current crop of fringe conspiracy theories - David Icke's reptilians in particular. Reading this book and comparing Shaver's dero with Icke's reptilians will, I think, afford the reader a deeper appreciation of the nature of the current phenomena. One can't help but wonder who will succeed Icke in another twenty years or so, and what shape the next generation of monsters will take.This book is also rather interesting for the questions it raises, and perhaps implicitly answers, about the nature of the visionary experience. It has been said that tribal cultures turn their schizophrenics into functioning members of society by making them into shamans. Palmer, I think, performed this service for one such individual.To be clear, I am not suggesting this as a universal theory of shamanism, psychic phenomena, or paranormal experiences. Many people engaged in such pursuits or reporting such experiences are quite obviously not schizophrenic. Nevertheless, this biography may perhaps serve double-duty as fable, warning us all of the dangers of excessive literalism in our interpretation of these experiences. Of being too quick to take things at face value.Interestingly, the author suggests that Palmer himself could have been prone to this kind of overly literal thinking. By way of evidence he offers up the following quote from Palmer: "Even Rod Sterling must suspect there is a Twilight Zone, or he would not write of it". Though perhaps, in this particularly telling line, there are deeper clues as to the true nature of Ray Palmer's world view, and how he regarded his own literary career.Perhaps to him, flying saucers, the Hollow Earth, and the shining world of tomorrow depicted in the earliest of the pulps were all part of the same continuum: a transmundane domain of both wonder and horror, seances and superscience, beckoning us all to come explore. A world that, for the likes of Shaver and Icke, may indeed be accessible, even if only to the bravest and most intrepid pioneers.But for better and for worse, for most of us that world must beckon forever.Like the dog-headed men of medieval geography, it lies always just beyond the next horizon.Theo.
