She became his secretary, and is now his fiancé, and when married will become his partner in his Private Investigator business. There is great chemistry between Tobe and Samantha, not to mention humor as they deal with the aspect of no sex until they are married. The characters in the book are believable, they are real, and they are, as all of us are, somewhat flawed in various ways.If you liked fairy tales as you grew up (and who of us didn't?), I think you will enjoy the retelling of them, in a modern and supernatural setting, as retold and explored by Ms. Keley's characters. A great read. Enjoy ;-)

The book is exactly as advertised. It is a novel of Intrigue, Seduction, and Redemption. There were a few places where I had difficulty suspending my disbelief, and I shan't mention them, because you may not have that problem.The book is emotionally captivating, I liked the characters, and I enjoyed the history woven into the story. I now know more about the Spanish Civil War than I knew before. The Awakening takes place over time, and to a degree over geography; mostly in Spain, a bit in Paris, and a tad in East Harlem.This book was a good read, wonderful for my bedtime read, in other words, the story moved well, but was not an adrenaline gusher. Much food for thought and cogitation, and it belies the old saw that you can't teach an old dog new tricks. Read the book. Write a review.I hope the next book is available soon.

After all the hype, I wasn't sure I wanted to read it. I've read, and enjoyed at various levels her other books, save one which I just can't get into, so I decided to read this one. I still like The Last Runaway best, but maybe because it was the first of her books I read?If you want a nitty gritty history of Vermeer, or life in his place and time, this probably isn't for you. I'm not sure how historically accurate this book is, but it's a fun read, and I do believe she has done some homework.My classification of this book is Brain Candy, and every so often, I enjoy brain candy, especially when fairly well written.I can understand why the wife would not like Griet. Griet is young, innocent, beautiful, and a servant. The other servant is old, ugly, and no competition or threat. I can understand why the wife would never want to wear the earrings again, and why her husband gave them away when he died (via a will). Why did Vermeer not paint his family? Perhaps as he says in the book, because they could not sit still. Perhaps no one would want to buy them. It is my understanding that many artists ground their own pigments to get them the way they wanted, that it was not usually something entrusted to a lowly servant. I may be wrong on that, but if so, then it was a sign of respect that Griet was allowed to do it. And, again, possibly his family had wanted to, and for whatever reason didn't do it right?Though these characters are not deep, they are satisfying, especially if read for what it is, a novel. A made-up story. If you want adrenalin, read someone else's books. If you want a satisfying read that isn't racing hither and yon, read Tracy Chevalier.

When the Soviet Union collapsed, Elena went from being an astrophysicist at Baikonur to being a janitor in her hometown of Almaty, who makes extra money buying and selling clothes on the black market. On her last trip, she picks up a small spherical object that is heavy, and oddly warm. As a scientist, she becomes curious and keeps it to study.Ilya is 800 years old, a warrior of myth and legend, not quite human, but not sure of what he really is, who has one goal in life — to be able to die. Every time he is close to death, the rusalka come and heal him, against his will.Ilya is hired to find the small, round object, and not only does he find it, he finds Elena, and together they discover the object can open gateways into an alternate Soviet Union, on another planet. Together, they must decide who gets the "key" and where they will live. Elena, the scientist does not know all the players. Ilya, the legend, does, and has spent 800 years hating and fearing some of them. But, are they who and what he has believed all this time?I had a hard time putting this book down. I loved the characters, and the travel down the Silk Road in both universes. The ending came at just the right time, and was both satisfactory and conclusive. There are a few loose ends flying in the breeze here and there, but nothing serious, and perhaps, eventually, there will be a sequel?I look forward to reading more books by Liz Williams.

I have a soft spot in my heart for Crocs n Gators. Don't ask me why, perhaps it's their constant smile? At any rate, I was delighted when notified that Ms. Child has written another one of her marvelous books, and this time on Crocodiles.If you haven't read her other books, you're in for a treat. She has a relaxed way of writing that will appeal to any child, regardless of their age. She researches her subjects, and uses professional photographs.As in all of her books, there is a section of fun facts to learn and wow your friends with. Like their 80 teeth are replaceable, and scientists think they can be replaced up to at least 50 times in a lifetime. That crocs can live up to 75 years of age (wow! something older than me) and that saltwater crocs are bigger than alligators, and can grow up to 23 feet or so.One question I have that was not answered—is crocodile meat as good to eat as alligator meat?This is a great book for children to read on their own, and also one that the adults can read to them, as often as asked for. If you're giving a Kindle to a kinder, load it up with the books by Ms. Child!

Being a short book, I knew none of the stories would be in depth; however, because they were about women I knew nothing about, they were mildly interesting. The writing is good, the subject matter terrific, but due to the shortness of the stories, not overly informative; more gravy, less meat.I think this would be a good introduction to anyone not at all familiar with this part of our history, and would hopefully pique their interest to go on and read more in depth accounts, including the actual diaries of the women.There was nothing here about how they coped with emergencies, or daily lives on a personal level, except as a high level gloss. Personal things, such as how they dealt with babies and diapers would probably not have been mentioned in their actual diaries and or letters home. That would have been considered women's work, and of no importance to record, as all the women would have known. And the men wouldn't have cared what they thought, let alone read the diaries.I really wish the author had written longer stories with more usable information, given the women 50-60 pages each, and used more quotes from their diaries and letters. Unfortunately, the lack of information in this book make me hesitate to buy any of her other books, though I see she has several out about the same era and subject.

First off, I love stories of Ancient China, especially about Qin Shi Huandi, the first emperor. I love the histories I've read, and the fiction I've read, and the fantasies of Ancient China whether or not it ever was. So it was with great excitement I began this book. I was not as excited by the end of the book as I was at the beginning.The writing is consistent, and while I enjoyed some of the characters, I really didn't bond with any of them. I never saw them as anything but paper cut outs. And there were a few times when I was thrown completely out of the story.The story has its amusing moments, as Li Kao and Lu Yu (aka Number Ten Ox) go about their adventures finding the treasured ginseng root to save the children of Lu's village from a mysterious illness. However, I thought it a tad too long. By the time we were on the third, and final, adventure, I found myself wondering if I cared enough to finish the book. I was, at best, only mildly curious at the whole outcome (saving of the children was a foregone conclusion).I believe this is Mr. Hughart's debut novel, and long as it was (psychologically, not literally) I will give his next book a read. He has a good story, I think, just too much fluff and not enough busting (editing). I want to care about his characters. I want to identify with at least one of them.

I haven't reviewed True Cat Toons because Roberta wrote about my cat, and I didn't think it would be kosher for me to brag about the book. But, I'm going to. These stories are delightful, and if you love cats, or know people who love cats, I heartily recommend making this book a part of your library and or theirs! The stories are fun, and the artwork is marvelous.

My new gloves just arrived, and I love them! They are long, they are warm, and I can easily type while they are on. They come as one size fits most, and they could have been a smidge smaller, but I'm not complaining. I love them and may have to order a few more.

This is my introduction to Mrs. Pollifax, so I have no idea how it compares to the rest of the series. I found it moderately entertaining, enough that I finished it. Mysteries are not my normal reading genre, and when I read them, I try not to figure out who the bad guy is so the ending won't be ruined when I get there.This is a book I would be delighted to find on the hospital book cart, should I find myself confined to such a place. Mrs. P and the Lion Killer is easy to read, easy to put down, and easy to pick up again later.The title is somewhat misleading; it is not about a person who goes to Africa to kill lions, but about the man who kills others like a lion might.If you are a fan of the Miss Jane Marple books by Agatha Christie, I think you will enjoy the Mrs. Pollifax books.  While there is violence, it is neither gratuitous, nor graphic, and there is a great deal of humor. And, true to the "cozy" format, it ends well for everyone but the antagonist.

One of the problems I've had with the GoPro is that the location of the camera is almost never where the mic. should be. The MXL lavalier mic. is a good start to freeing the camera from live sound. I have tried mounting the camera in my car behind my seat (center console) to catch live driving. Attempts at narration are futile, buried in road and wind noise. Using this mic, I can clip the microphone to my shirt and the voice over is clean and crisp. This is a very good unit.Also packed with the MM-165GP is a second wind screen to go over the first. This one looks like fake fur. It is meant to handle outdoor conditions with real wind. I never had to use it, but this type of screen is almost always used on mics that professional cinematographers use outdoors. I tried it and it does cut down on wind sounds without noticeable degradation of the sound quality. There is a nice pleather case and a cleaning cloth (not sure why that was included).Just as the GoPro is a serious hi-def camera in a small package, this mic is an equally serious accessory for hi-def sound.

This speaker offers a chance to extend music listening without running wires. I like that a lot. The sound is quite good for a speaker this size. I think it's a bit ironic that I am using a single, monaural speaker in the 21st century. The thing is that I find I am fine with it. The first problem I have with this unit is that it requires an IOS or Android device to control it. I have a Windows phone. Ok, not the end of the world. I also have an old iPad and a small Android tablet. But still, even though there aren't very many of us, it would be nice for Yamaha to remember the Windows folks.Setup using the app is a snap. I connected via WiFi. As it turns out, the room where I located the speaker is the same one where my WiFi router is located, so signal strength is not an issue. What is an issue, and the reason I only gave this product 3 stars is that it drops WiFi randomly. Each time it does, I have to dig out the tablet and redo the setup. That's inconvenient to say the least. I also have a Bose Wave radio that connects via WiFi for Pandora and my music library. It never looses the signal and it is considerably further away from the router.There is no question that this unit is versatile. It can receive music from a wide range of sources including the Apple system. In my case I have to use the app to select music from my server. That's fine. I have to do the same thing with the Bose. Since I don't have a Yamaha receiver or other MusiCast devices, my options are limited. But that doesn't matter. I can listen to what I like. The only problem is that this unit keeps dropping the network. Fix that and I will give this unit five stars.

This is another diesel fuel additive. The manufacturer makes significant claims that I can't verify. In fact, as far as I can tell there is only one claim that there is any chance for a driver to test: reduced gelling. Diesel fuel will gel in low temperatures (well below 20 deg F). It just doesn't get that cold around here. However, I don't doubt that claim. So why use this stuff?Diesel fuel, unlike gasoline, doesn't have an "octane" rating at the pump. Actually, diesel uses a Cetane value that roughly equates to available energy for the engine.A lot of truck owners believe that a cetane additive will improve performance and mileage. What it all boils down to is how much you trust your fuel supply. Good quality diesel fuel should have the necessary cetane rating and contain the additives to protect your engine. Pow-R 365 diesel fuel treatment has those additives in its formula. So, for a price, you can have both belt and suspenders for your diesel fuel.This product won't harm your engine. It just may not really help. We tried it in our Ford F350 Powerstroke engine truck. We observed no improved fuel economy. The engine ran fine before using and stayed fine with the additive in our fuel. Without dismantling our engine, we have no idea if this product cleaned the injectors or not.I had hoped for increased fuel mileage. I didn't get it. As for the other benefits, all I can do is take the manufacturer's word for it. We'll finish up the free bottle we got, but we won't be buying this product.

I've had eczema for most of my life. Sometimes it gets going on my scalp. Tar-based shampoos do nothing for me. Last week I was suffering with that itchy scalp and started thinking back to earlier years> I remembered that I used Sebulex then and it worked. So, I did a search and discovered that Sebulex is no longer made but that Sebex is available. It is an accurate copy of Sebulex. It even smells just the same. Best of all, it works. I have been able to discontinue steroid lotion and just shampoo with Sebex. This is the real deal!

I've seen shop towels around for a while, but I never imagined that it would make sense for my home use. However, I've been very unhappy with paper towels for cleaning our vehicles' windows and other around-the-garage and RV chores. I like these shop cloths a lot! They are very strong and I can use one or two for weeks for window cleaning. I can rinse them and they dry as good as new. I used them for some clean up around the RV. This is probably where they will end up. We have a lot of greasy clean up jobs around hydraulics and our fifth wheel hitch.What's particularly nice is that these cloths feel like the kind you launder, but they are disposable. Moreover, they are made of a renewable substance with little impact on the environment. I am tempted to reuse these more than I should. They are that good.

Vornado (does it rhyme with tornado?) products have an excellent reputation for long-lasting quality. My grandparents owned at least one Vornado heater. This heater (Model TAVH10) is definitely a twenty-first century product. The first thing I noticed was that there are no physical controls. When unplugged, all you see is a dark, smoked plastic panel on top. No obvious on/off switch. No indication of the promised features. It's not bad looking for a heater. The design is quite retro in my opinion.Back to the controls. The first time I plugged it in, nothing at all happened. I couldn't turn it on or make it do anything. Then I noticed that one of the feet was resting on part of the power cord. Ah ha! That caused the safety tilt switch to cut off power. Not bad, but annoying when first trying to test the product. Once the cord was moved out of the way, a tiny power symbol appeared behind the smoked plastic. Very cool. Touch the spot on the plastic started the heater and turned on the LCD display showing status, set temperature, etc. By touching  various symbols you can set the heater to 750 watts or 1,500 watts, target room temperature, etc. Easy peasy.Once in operation, the unit is very quiet; much quieter than other heaters we own. The air being emitted was warm, but not burning hot; another great feature, especially around pets or kids. Most important, it did a good job of warming the room. The fan is powerful enough to get good air circulation going. We have a rather large basement play room that is always cold. I put the heater there and let it go. We have been using another electric heater down there. It does an effective job of heating and takes about an hour to warm the room. The Vornado was about equal in time to heat the room. That makes sense since both units are 1,500 watts. The big difference is that the Vornado stopped heating when the room hit 73 degrees (the set temperature). The other heater just keeps heating until it is turned off. Once warmed up, the room was maintained that the set temperature.This model comes with some added features you may find helpful. One that I like is the twelve-hour timer. You can set the heater to run for a set period of time and then shut off. This period can be up to twelve hours. This is a big money saver for people like me who forget to turn the heater off after leaving the room for the night. The unit also has a remote control that will allow you to manage most of the functions. This is less useful for me. The remote is very small and has to be aimed carefully at the heater to work. Since there is no display on the remote, you need to be close enough to the heater to read the settings. I suppose if you have everything preset and you have the heater on a high shelf, you can use the remote to turn it on or off. Or, if you use it in the bedroom, you can shut it off or turn it on from bed. The remote comes with the battery packed separately. You need a small Phillips head screwdriver to put it in the remote. Inconvenient, but not the worst thing in the world.There are several Vornado Vortex heater models at lower prices. This is the top-of-the-line model and the only one with the remote control. There is a comparison chart on this page that might help you decide which model is right for you.Vornado heaters are among the best available and the TAVH10 is no exception. It comes with a five year satisfaction guarantee. That is something I like since the controls are all electronic and this guarantee shows Vernado's confidence they will be as reliable as the old-fashioned mechanical controls that have lasted decades. There is a very big difference between the way this unit "feels" and the less expensive heaters. Most noticeable for me is that the temperature of the air coming out is pleasantly warm, not burning hot like our less-expensive units. I am confident this heater will be keeping us warm for decades to come.

We have a golden retriever and two parrots. I am allergic to the parrot dust and dog dander. We own several vacuum cleaners, each one top rated by Consumer Reports when we bought them. One is a Kenmore canister vac, the other a Panasonic upright. Both do a good job, or at least we thought they did. Each of our older vacuums cost more than twice as much as the Black and Decker AirSwivel.The surest test for a vacuum is to clean an area with the old vac and then go over the same area with the new one. As it was, my wife had vacuumed the bedroom floor last night before we went to sleep. This morning we unpacked the Black and Decker. Assembly was easy. You do need a Phillip’s head screwdriver for the single screw you need to put on. Everything else snapped into place.We started off by vacuuming the parquet wood floor in our hallway. The Black and Decker picked up all dirt and none was scattered or left on the floor (both of our old vacuums struggle on bare wood). We moved to the carpeted area where the birds live. The Black and Decker did a great job on that carpet. However, it could not pick up larger nut shells. The head is too close to the ground to allow them in.Next, we moved to the freshly-vacuumed bedroom. We were both amazed at the results. The dust container quickly filled with dog hair that the Panasonic missed! This will be great to help keep away my allergies. As a bonus, the head didn’t clog with hair.  This is a frequent problem with the other vacs. Until now we thought that the Panasonic did the best job. It has an indicator that goes from red to green when the carpet is clean. It lied! After vacuuming an area until the indicator said it was clean, the Black and Decker pulled a large amount of dog hair out. Clean indeed! The Black and Decker is truly powerful.The dust container removes easily. Dumping was a bit messy since the dog hair needed a helping hand to get it out of the container. This is normal for this type of machine. Our other vacuums use disposable bags. While it is a bit messier, the reusable dust container will be a big money saver for us.This unit is advertised as “Air Swivel” meaning it is easier to maneuver the head. The swivel works beautifully. We were able to get the head into every corner, under the bed, and below the bird cages. The machine is quiet as well. The other two vacs we own make much more noise.Frequently, products I review don’t make it into our day-to-day lives. Often, the products we already have do a better job. Not this time! The Black and Decker AirSwivel is now our main vacuum. The other two will be in the garbage next week.Let me emphasize that this is the best vacuum cleaner we have ever used to pick up pet hair. Our real-life testing proved to us that compared with high-priced, heavier, noisier vacuums we used until now, the AirSwivel out performs both of them. If you have pet hair to clean up, this is amazing! We love it.

I know that in this age of giant monitors it may seem, well, old fashioned to want a 21-inch monitor. But actually this smaller size is perfect for some important applications. HP clearly intended this monitor for TV viewing. It has a HDMI input and can be connected easily to a cable box or, in my case, a DirecTV DVR. It also has a VGA analog computer input. My first use was as a larger monitor for my laptop. Since this monitor is very thin and it's base lets you put it right up against a wall, the monitor with my laptop in front of it, fit perfectly on my home desk.This is a mid-range resolution monitor for a computer. It's 1920 X 1080 pixels is about average for popularly priced monitors.But that's not the whole story. I wondered why HP would develop a monitor this small. It's price point isn't the lowest for similarly-sized monitors. Once I connected it to my DVR I found out. Resolution isn't the entire story when it comes to monitors. If you want to watch hi-def TV, the monitor needs to be very fast. That means it can track motion without blurring caused by pixels taking too long to extinguish and light up. This is a very fast monitor. Hi-def TV looks great. The other feature that is important for TV watching is how far off axis the picture remains bright and sharp. The 22cwa has a remarkably wide viewing angle. Another key feature is the contrast ratio. The larger the number, the richer the blacks and dark colors will be. HP claims an impossibly large  8,000,000 to 1 ratio. I can't measure this feature, but that is a very big number for a monitor at this price. However, the proof is in the watching. My viewing experience was nothing short of great.I was skeptical about this monitor when I received it. I am very fussy when it comes to monitors. I have a 55-inch plasma for our main TV watching. I figured that the 22cwa might be a good monitor for my laptop. I never imagined that I would want to use it for TV. I don't think you can do better for $100.

Our luck with doggy puzzles hasn't been very good. Our golden retriever chews the doors off of a couple we tried. Yes, she solves the puzzle but has her own way of solving some that destroys them in the process. Knowing that, we are understandably cautious about investing in expensive "educational" toys. The Foobler looked like it could provide some lasting fun.When the toy arrived, it was a bit of a human challenge to work out preparing it for our dog. The markings on the body and lid that indicate where to put things together are not easy to read. If they were larger or engraved deeper in the mold, it would be much easier to open the power compartment and the all-important food bins.It takes a lot of unscrewing to get the battery cover off. I have  never had to deal with so many turns of the screwdriver to get in. Since the battery compartment is inside the toy and away from prying teeth, I don't see why a simpler lock for the battery couldn't have been provided. Be sure to use alkaline batteries only. Once we got the batteries in and the food loaded, we pressed the button to start the fun. A green light blinked for a little while and then it turned into a rapidly flashing red light. We tried this several times with the same result. We rechecked the batteries to be sure they were correctly oriented; they were. Finally, we concluded that the unit was defective. I went on the Foobler web site and confirmed that we did things correctly. I wrote an email to Foobler customer service (this was Friday evening). At the same time I asked Amazon to replace the defective toy. The reply to my email and the Amazon replacement arrived at about the same time. Good work for Amazon and a disappointing wait for Foobler.The replacement unit works correctly. Now the hard part. We filled the toy and put it on the floor. The dog wasn't very interested. So, we rolled the ball around and when a treat fell out, we showed her. That inspired her to push the ball around a little. When no treat emerged, she gave up. We repeated our demonstration and fed her the results. My wife got very good at extracting treats. Too bad, this isn't her toy. The dog got the idea and found some treats on her own. Clearly we need more tempting goodies to motivate her. Fifteen minutes later the bell rang. She ignored it. My wife got on the floor and showed her that treats are available again. We did this a couple of more times. Our dog is smart, but she hasn't figured out what the bell means.We plan to try again tonight. The toy has real potential, but it isn't something our dog just understood without help. So far she hasn't tried to chew it. The construction doesn't seem to lend itself to that sort of attack. We are following the instructions that were packed with the Foobler to train her to enjoy it. I am sure that eventually she will learn. It will take time and work, but she should eventually love it.I gave this product only three stars because of the low initial quality that required a replacement, and more importantly the slow response from customer service. If you buy the Foobler, prepare to spend some time helping your dog figure it out, especially the timed release of treats. We both enjoy this opportunity to interact with the dog, so the extra work for training is a plus for us. If you don't have the time or interest to train your dog to use this toy, save your money and get something else.

This is a large, rugged, and heavy watch. Everything about it shouts that this watch can take it. There are a lot of cheap watches that look similar to the Invicta, but they are all show and no go. This is the real deal! The price is reasonable for a watch of this quality. Here's what I like about this watch:• It’s rugged. The case is high quality stainless steel.• The dial window is synthetic sapphire. This is much more scratch resistant than glass. Only the finest watches have a sapphire dial window.• The band is a perfect width for this watch. It is heavy, stainless steel.• This watch is waterproof to 330 feet. That means it can be used as a dive watch. Watches that claim to be waterproof to 30 feet are generally unable to handle long immersion in water of any depth. The 330 foot certification means the watch will keep running on a scuba dive.• It has analog day, date, and 24 hour time dials. I prefer this to the numeric kind.• The hands are wide, easy-to-read, and glow in the dark The minutes are engraved in large, black digits on the bezel.• It has a stop watch function (something I don’t really use)The watch is made in China. The quality appears to be very good. I don't have very thick wrists. Large watches like this often look like I have an alarm clock strapped to my wrist. Even though this is a very large watch, somehow it looks like it belongs on my wrist. The only thing I am not too happy about is the weight. This is a thick, heavy watch. I would have liked it to be a bit thinner and lighter. However, because of its thickness, all the controls seem meant for big fingers. Adjusting settings and accessing features is easy even for a big guy.It comes packed with an excellent, illustrated guide on how to use it. Like the watch, the guide is large enough to read without a magnifying glass. I'm very happy with this model. The price is right and the quality makes it an excellent value.

This Trager rub is a good, mild, very-standard rub. It absolutely makes chicken delicious on a smoker. Due to the nature of the spices in this rub, it may impart a burnt taste if you use it on a standard grill. The rub also works very well if you roast your chicken in the oven. The secret to getting a perfect, wonderfully browned chicken is to first wash and pat dry with paper towels. Then, rub oil (I use canola oil) all over the skin. Next, sprinkle a liberal amount on the chicken and PAT (not rub!) the rub into the chicken.I tie the legs together. It makes a much neater presentation. I also have a stand so I can smoke/roast the chicken vertically (they have them here for less than $5). Preheat the smoker (or oven) to $450 and roast the chicken until the internal temperature is 165 degrees. That's it! You'll love it.

I have a cellular internet hub (AT&T). I wanted to use it to reach various Internet-connected devices in my RV. I had a combination of wired and WiFi devices (laptops, DirecTV receivers, etc). I purchased a wireless router that would handle everything. The problem was finding a way to get the cellular hub connected to the router. The router needs an ethernet cable to get the Internet. This is the standard way your home system works. So the problem was to make a WiFi connection to the cellular hub and convert it into a wired ethernet connection. The Linksys WES610N-4 is the device that does the job.Setting it up is really simple. Just connect the WES610N to your wireless router. Then power up the device and your cellular hub. You will find a way to connect to a WiFi device to your hub, generally a button to touch. Press the button on the Linksys and do the same on your hub. The devices will connect. Voila! You are done! You can connect wired devices to the 4 ports on the WES610N.This works perfectly. I have been using it for months with no problems at all. It's worth every penny if you need a way to connect wired ethernet devices to a WiFi network.

This is my second set of replacement batteries for my UPS (they should be replaced every three years or less). I bought this kind the first time, 3 years ago. The original batteries that came with the UPS had swollen and needed to be pried out. The replacements came out after three years in the same condition they went in. This particular seller offers the best price I could find. The kit includes everything you need to replace the OEM batteries. Excellent seller!

I use eye wash when putting on my contacts. I have Synergeyes, hybrid soft/hard contacts. It is necessary to put a pool of sterile saline in the center of a lens before inserting it. This prevents painful dry eye inside the hard contact portion of the lens. I had been using Baush and Lomb eye wash for this purpose, but this brand is much less expensive. It works every bit as well as the high-priced brand name product. Whatever your use for eye wash, save a lot by getting this brand.

These batteries perform as well as any other brand I have tried. Energizers are very unlikely to leak. They cost a bit more than the Chinese batteries, but the quality is much better and if you get one that leaks, you can complain to a company that cares.

This shampoo does a good job at cleaning without stripping my hair. It is hypoallergenic, but it has a scent. I tend to be allergic to scents, but the Finesse scent didn't trigger an allergy attack. That said, I really prefer and unscented product. There are very few hypoallergenic shampoos and conditioners out there. This one isn't bad at all. I would have given it five stars if it was hypoallergenic. I still recommend it for people like me with sensitive skin.

This battery is fairly unusual. It's required in the remotes for our keyless lock on our fifth wheel. After a season of use, the remotes become too weak to use. Amazon (as always) has several brands of this particular battery. We selected the Duracell because the unbranded, Chinese batteries are prone to leakage. Duracell stands behind their product and if a leak develops, you can contact them and they may replace the damaged item. I don't know if they actually will for a very good reason: Their batteries have never leaked in any application I have!

We bought an ultrasonic cleaner for glasses and some personal stainless-steel products. At first we tried cleaning with just warm water. It worked to a degree, but we didn't get the squeaky-clean finish we wanted. After taking a lot of time on Amazon looking for a cleaner to add to the water, we found this one. Only one capfull of this concentrate is enough to get the level we want. Glasses come out like new. The stainless steel items are dirt and grease free. We are delighted with this product.

This product is known and loved in the mechanic world. In fact, a former mechanic suggested I buy this to lubricate the slides on my fifth wheel. It is very easy to use and not messy. Unlike lithium grease, this lubricant is light and so far, very effective. I have also used it to lubricate my garage door; those rollers and pulleys need regular attention. This product makes that maintenance as simple as spraying each roller. Lubing a door takes me less than five minutes. It works wonderfully!

I've been using the Naturelle Hype-Allergenic shampoo and conditioner for over a year. I have very sensitive skin and this fragrance-free, hypo-allergenic shampoo gives me no trouble at all. I would say its cleaning power is average. My hair isn't as clean as it would be when I use Nutragena shampoo. That performs best but also is fairly tough on hair. I don't want to nit pick, but I wish this formula were a bit stronger.However, for everyday use, this is an excellent shampoo and for me, at least, doesn't bother my very sensitive skin.

I'm not one for cosmetic products. I also have very allergic, sensitive skin. My face tends to dry out in warmer weather, so when I came across this product, I had to give it a try. First and foremost, it is completely unscented. I love that. I put some on and it felt light, not oily. For a while after applying I feel it on my face. It isn't unpleasant, but I know it is there. I can't attest to the SPF 15 sun protection, but I'm sure it is there and works. Cetaphil is a great brand. I have used their skin cleaner for years.This is the first face lotion I have seen that is designed for men. I like the way it feels and my skin is definitely less itchy. That means it's working. Now the challenge will be to remember to put it on each morning.

We have a heavy fifth wheel. The plastic chocks are easy to run over and crack under the weight. We had metal chocks that wedge between the two tires on each side. Just hitching up had us run over these. The Roadblock chocks are expensive, but they are worth the price. These chocks are designed for 18-wheelers. They aren't pretty and have a slight rubbery smell. Each one weighs 8 lbs.! The work. If you have a heavy trailer, these chocks are going to hold you in place. We bought four of these and love them.One small issue: The eyebolts that come on each chock are not tightened at all. Be sure to hand tighten them so they don't fall off with use.

I needed these as a replacement for some worn plates in my Vermont Castings grill. The price for three of these is less than the factory price for one. When I got these, I was very pleasantly surprised to discover that there is nothing "cheap" about these parts. They are heavy stainless steel. They fit perfectly. It's great to find such a fantastic value.

This is the first concentrate I have used. It took me a few glasses of tea to get the strength I like. Now all I have to do is squirt enough in to get to the "right" color and the tea tastes great. Surprisingly, it is pretty easy to make it too strong, at least for my taste. It's refreshing with no bother. Normally I make my iced tea using my Keurig. But there are a lot of times when I just want a quick, refreshing drink.There are two things I suggest you consider about this product: First, there is a significant amount of caffeine in each glass. If you react to caffeine, be careful when you drink this and how much you consume. Second, I fount a "chemical" aftertaste. The product does use an artificial sweetener (sucralose), but I don't remember that aftertaste with other beverages using it. This taste isn't very strong and won't stop me from continuing to enjoy this convenient product.This slight aftertaste reduced my rating from five to four stars. There is a lot to like about this concentrate. It's definitely worth a try.

I've been using the Norelco Body Shaver for years, so I have an excellent basis for comparison. The writeup claims that the Mangroomer  pulls less and is less likely to pinch than other body shavers. I found the opposite to be true. To be fair, I did a trial comparing the Norelco body shave with this product. Here's what I found:1. Close shave: Both products were equal in terms of cutting down to the skin.2. Catches hair: In this case, the Mangroomer lost badly. It took four or five passes with the Mangroomer to get the same amount of hair that the Norelco removed in one pass.3. Pinch and cut: In this case, the Mangroomer was horrible. Even when stretching loose skin, the Mangroomer nicked me repeatedly. The Norelco isn't perfect here, but it is way better than the Mangroomer.4. Combs: Both razors come with combs for trimming. The Mangroomer's combs are closer to what I want than the Norelco's. The shortest comb is 3mm, which is about perfect for me.5. Charger: Both razors are equal in terms of charging time. The Mangrromer's charger is flimsy and difficult to hold firm contact with the charging base. The Norelco is much more secure in its base.6. Price: The Mangroomer is the same price as the least expensive Norelco, and considerably less than the better models.SUMMARYIn my opinion the Mangroomer is not the best choice for male grooming. It was rough on my skin. Since I have been grooming for many years, it isn't because I am not used to an electric shaver. It's due to the quality of the Mangroomer's cutting head. The Norelco Bodygroomer is my shaver of choice. I think it is worth the money to avoid the nicks and poor shaving coverage of the Mangroomer.

I've used various plastic blocks to put under my 5th wheel's 6 leveling jacks. The rig weighs 15,000 lbs. We were most recently using Camco's large jack stabilizer pads. These pads are advertised as very heavy duty and are more expensive than these. They did work, but clearly showed signs of strain. They didn't remain flat on an uneven surface. These Fas Ten Leveling Blocks are considerably thicker and do a better job under our pads. Of course, their open design makes them unsuitable to be used alone under the jacks. We put 2 - 4 X 6 X 12 in. wood blocks on top of the plastic blocks. This works out perfectly for us. The plastic protects the wood from ground moisture and also provides a slip-free landing for the wood.Since we have a six-point leveling system, we don't need blocks under the trailer wheels, so we can't comment on how well these work for that purpose. Side-to-side leveling is critical with any RV. These blocks look like they will be a big help for rigs without jack systems. For those of us who have these systems, the blocks make an inexpensive, handy way to protect our jacks.
Great fit. Exactly what I wanted. Great quality and perfect fit.

This is a very interesting read. Since it's written by a current Google employee, it gives insight into the Google analytics platform in the context of Google's intentions. I use Google analytics in addition to a tool that I host on my servers, Piwik. The numbers from Piwik and Google never agree. Google always shows more users. This is interesting since the Javascript for both are located one after the other in my footer. However, exact numbers is much less important than trends and page popularity, entry, and exit pages.This book explained exactly how Analytics integrations, the combination of pre- and post-visit activities can help improve site performance. There is much in this book that goes way past my interest in site analytics, but if you have a site that produces revenue, this book and the very robust Google platform provide help in building traffic and revenue.The book itself is well organized and it is easy to go directly to the topic of interest. While it's true that the Google help pages provide the same information, just having it in convenient form organized for easy use is well worth the price. If you use Google analytics, even casually, you will get value from this book.

I've had the glass version of this feeder for several months. This model is identical except that it has a plastic nectar container. I hung this one at a different location and it proves just as effective as the glass model. That's no surprise, of course. I also have a hummingbird feeder that uses the "IV" bottle. It will only feed one hovering bird at a time. After I hung the Perky-Pet glass feeder, "business" dropped off dramatically at the IV type. The hummingbirds clearly prefer this style of perch and feeder openings.There hasn't been a bee or ant problem with this feeder either. If ants do come around, just fill the moat (it's the depression in the cap that you hang the feeder from). That will prevent ant access. I don't use the commercial nectar. It contains coloring. Contrary to what some say, hummingbirds are just as happy with clear nectar as with red. The red color of the bottle is not necessary either.You can make your own hummingbird nectar easily. Just put 1 cup of sugar and 32 Oz. of water in a pot. Stir and bring to a boil. Let it cool and fill the feeder. This model holds 32 oz. In the winter if the temperature is going down below 25 degrees F, you can mix the nectar with two cups of sugar per 32 Oz. of water. This will keep it liquid down to about 20 degrees.  Be sure to change the nectar weekly during warmer months. Bacteria, harmful to the birds, can grow in old nectar.I like the glass model better. It is more rugged. But both work perfectly, so it is a matter of preference. This is the best feeder I have used.

This product has a mildly-salty, menthol taste. It is much milder than other mouthwashes. It usually hurts to swirl other mouthwashes in my mouth. This one is pleasant and easy to keep in for a full minute per the instructions. It leaves me with a menthol taste in my mouth not unlike after a cough drop. It's pleasant.Most important, it did sooth a sore spot in my gum. This is the first product that has actually done that for me. This stuff does what it claims. On the negative side, it is incredibly expensive.It may be worth a shot if you have sore gums. If it works for you, it's worth the money. The reason I gave it four stars is that it was a real pain to open the bottle. There is a seal under the cap with a "pull tab". No matter how hard I pulled it wouldn't come off. Finally, I stabbed it with scissors and pried it off. That is what cost it one star.

I don't know what it is about humidifying type diffusers, but I had a hard time finding an attractive one which also had a good average customer rating. (I mean, what's up with all the weird, asymmetrical shapes?) This Allay Aromatherapy EO diffuser was the best I could do in the looks department, although it's only moderately attractive. However, the functionality and end results of this diffuser are much better than the old-fashioned heat-warmed diffusers I've always had previously.Basically you fill the water reservoir with distilled water, if you don't want hard water deposits to eventually build up inside your diffuser. It takes maybe a third cup at most I think. Then you drop in 3-4 drops of essential oil, replace the reservoir lid and the decorative outer funnel thingy, and turn it on. It works very well to scent the room while adding a touch of extra humidity -- a very helpful bonus in dry, overheated winter rooms. The built-in shutoff occurs when it runs out of water; perhaps 3 to 4 hours altogether. I really like that I don't have to monitor this myself.Just one cautionary tip: I have read in many customers' reviews of humidifying diffusers that it is not advisable to diffuse any citrus EOs in these diffusers, on the grounds that contact with citrus oils will eventually degrade the plastic they are made of, and impair the unit.  On some product pages you will see customers' comments about other types of EOs (such as Eucalyptus and Pine) also being destructive to plastic diffusers. I have no idea if this is true, or just a rumor. The Allay diffuser had no such warnings printed about avoiding any specific EOs, but I have been hesitant to test citrus, pine, and eucalyptus EOs in mine all the same. This is a real shame, because these oils are among the most aromatherapeutic  for people with breathing difficulties. If there is a problem with specific EOs, Allay should have notified me, so I am not sure what to think about this. Having to avoid grapefruit, bergamot, and orange EOs certainly impairs my enjoyment of this product! I *have* tried lavender, sandalwood and lemongrass in this diffuser, with no problems so far.I do like this product overall. I can recommend this diffuser as a pretty good, low-maintenance aromatherapy tool that is especially appropriate for winter use.

You pop these between your teeth and a burst of peppermint essential oil floods your mouth -- but it's actually quite small. I got these to have on hand in case a friend forgot her inhaler and needed a little help opening her airways in a pinch (on the suggestion of other people who use peppermint essential oil for their breathing difficulties).Be warned, there is NO sweetness to these beadlets. Kids would probably hate them, but as an adult I don't mind the sharp taste.

Ordered this pack of screen protectors before I even bought the Nintendo 2ds for my kids; I suppose I must have learned a thing or two from experiences with other electronic devices. ;)The installation is about the easiest I've ever experienced, and you can quickly line the protectors up and lay them down. Before you do that however, be absolutely certain that there are no little specks on the screen. That's what the little black microfiber cloth is supposedly for, but the instructions failed to mention that part.The best technique I have found for screen protectors of all types is to line up one edge perfectly, then bend it back a bit so that it sort of rolls down into place, as opposed to just laying it down flat all at once. This helps you eliminate any air pockets as you go with the plastic card. In the case of this screen protector however, there were literally no air pockets to push out.The screens of our 2ds are well protected now.

This was sent to me as a Christmas gift last week. I have used it several times in the past few days. I love this diffuser!My observations:ASSEMBLY: Simply two parts, and couldn't be easier; just the base and the flower-shaped glass top part that rests on top of it.GETTING STARTED: I scoured the package for instructions, as I had never operated this type of diffuser before. The only instructions included were printed on a little address label-sized sticker which said the following: "Caution: Do not use alcohol based fragrance or perfume in any 'aroma burners'. Heating of fragrant oil without use of hot water is not recommended. Use no more than 10 drops of fragrant oil for every 1/4 cup of hot water. As water runs low from evaporation, add only hot water to dish. Avoid the build up of old  oil base by periodically washing this dish with soap and water." Well it isn't rocket science, so despite the dubious "manual", I was able to boot up two of my brain cells to figure out that I was supposed to put water in the glass dish, then drop a few drops of essential oils on top of that before turning on the base. Still, the writers of the instruction sticker need to brush up on their skills a bit.To turn on the diffuser, simply plug it in and touch anywhere on the base unit. To my delight, I discovered there are three light intensity settings, which you also change by touching the base unit area. Ingenious!QUALITY: so far, so good. It operates well and appears to be well constructed. Admittedly, I have only used it for less than a week, so time will tell. Taking the low price into consideration, the quality of this diffuser can't be beat.APPEARANCE: Simply lovely to look at this softly glowing, rosy light thorugh the pierced metal pattern of the base. It is a bit more impressive in a dark room, but it is also pretty to look at in daylight. No complaints!EFFECTIVENESS: works very well to disperse the aromas of the essential oils into a smallish room area. I have used it in our dining room which is about 20 feet by 25 feet. I haven't yet tried it in a larger room.Cautions: Becaues the way this type of diffuser works is by heating the water and oil in the glass dish, eventually the water and oil will evaporate. I found that on the medium intensity setting, after having been filled to maximum capacity before turning it on, this took about 3 and a half hours. After that, whatever oil residue left in the bottom will dry and then..I don't know for certain, but I imagine it might start to burn if left indefinitely. I really don't want to find out. It is obviously not advisable to let that happen. There is no built in time setting for this diffuser, so for safety reasons, I would not leave it turned on unattended, nor indefintely. The instructions do not mention this at all, and it is irresponsible of the company to not include more "idiot-proofing" somewhere on the packaging to ensure that hapless customers don't have easily avoidable accidents in their homes while using this product. We all know those people who would simply assume that if the instructions don't tell you *not* to dry the family pet in the microwave, then it must be okay.CONCLUSION: A great little diffuser for the money, but I would not let it fall into the hands of people who rate Jersey Shore higher than Breaking Bad.

One star for the nice snowflake molds, one star for the tasty chocolate candy. Zero stars for Wilton's peppermint "bark" scheme.On the front package picture, this project looks awesome: you mold chocolate peppermint "bark" into snowflake molds and package them in unique gift bags. The picture makes it appear as though the peppermint portion of the bark is smooth and pretty. Nothing could be farther from the truth.You heat the chocolate and the peppermint separately in the microwave, taking them out at intervals and kneeding them, until they are sufficiently melted to squeeze nicely into the snowflake-shaped cookie cutter molds. (alternate directions suggest you can use a double boiler, but I didn't have one on hand so I microwaved the two bags of candy). The chocolate candy bag melted quickly and smoothly; I had no trouble squeezing it into the molds. You let the chocolate portion harden first for 10 minutes, then squeeze the peppermint bark candy bag on top of this. The problem is, the peppermint candy (which as far as I can tell is white chocolate mixed in with little pieces of candy cane) doesn't want to A, melt completely, nor B, melt at a temperature in which the human hand can comfortably handle the bag in which you are melting it. I must have had that darn thing in and out of the microwave, burning my hands as I attempted to kneed it into something smooth and workable, at least 10 times. It would not melt past the consistency of cookie dough, and finally I realized it was pointless to continue. I squeezed the peppermint candy into the molds on top of the chocolate, and it would not settle in nicely. I was forced to use my fingers to push it  into the corners. After about 10 seconds, the stuff stiffens up in the plastic squeeze bag and I had to scoop it out with a spatula. The end result is that after fussing with this for far too long, my peppermint bark had a lumpy and unattractive appearance. No way was I going to give these as gifts.Later, these snowflake barks do not unmold well, meaning there's no way they are coming out in one piece. No, you have to chisel them out with flatware or something. Double fail.Do yourself a favor and forget this kit. If you like the snowflake molds, I believe they are sold separately.

Carrot seed EO by Nature's Kiss is a wonderful deal. When I bought it, I had no idea that it had a natural SPF -- still haven't had an opportunity to test that out for myself, and now that it's November. ..well, wait until June for an update on that. What I did notice right away is that it does live up to its reputation for being a natural skin smoother. In a facial mask recipe and an anti-wrinkle blend (diluted in a base of jojoba oil and other EOs), carrot seed oil gave me a nearly instant result of smoother-feeling skin. I've been using this blend for about one week now. It could be the placebo effect, but I also notice fewer tiny lines around the mouth and corners of my eyes. Gotta love that!As for the smell, you will have to experience it for yourself. My kid likes it because it smells like pumpkin seeds to him, my man..not so much. Carrot seed EO definitely emits a warm, earthy odor. If you decide it's not to your taste, maybe blend with Lavendar to disguise ithe smell a bit, and be sure to dilute heavily in a base of carrier oil regardless: put "neat" onto my skin, it provokes that that faintly tingling feeling that warns me it could irritate more sensitive skin areas.I've also seen recipes for carrot seed EO in massage oil blends with names like "PMS oil" and "Fat Attack" (to be massaged onto cellulite problem areas). Supposedly, the vitamin A-rich carrot seed oil helps with weight loss. Now THAT sounds like an overblown claim to me but it couldn't hurt me give it a try some time :). One little 10 ml. bottle of this stuff goes a long way.

At first I was taken aback by the seeming lack of pungency of this Cinnamon essential oil, but then I remembered: this is REAL cinnamon bark (cinnamomum verum), not the cassia (cinnamomum aromaticum cassia) that's commonly labelled as cinnamon in the USA. Just like a stick of real cinnamon bark, this essential oil has that light, clean, almost floral scent with just a touch of sweetness.Cassia oil is definitely a heavier and sharper scent, which many actually prefer; however if you want the aromatherapeutic benefits of real cinnamon bark oil, this EO is what you'll need.I have used my cinnamon EO in a recipe to imitate doTerra's On Guard blend. It's nice to dilute the blend with distilled water in a spray mister, which I then use as a sanitizing spray on tables and counter tops -- it smells like Christmas cheer in a bottle. Here is the basic blend:20 drops clove essential oil18 drops orange or lemon essential oil10 drops cinnamon bark essential oil8 drops eucalyptus essential oil5 drops rosemary essential oil.Simply combine into a small, dark glass bottle and swirl to blend. Dilute with water or carrier oil when ready to use. If using as a spray, put approx one teaspoon of the blend into a 4 oz glass bottle with a mister pump and fill to the top with distilled water: shake before each use to disperse oils.There are a lot of uses for cinnamon bark oil due to its antimicrobial, antibacterial, antifungal, etc. properties. It is a very potent medicinal oil, and I have also heard of people using cinnamon EO to flavor their cooking and baking in place of powdered cinnamon. Keep in mind that a very little goes a long way, and that you should never apply this particular oil directly to skin -- predilute at no more than 3% in a carrier oil to avoid "burning" skin reactions!

I bought Blue Tansy because it kept popping up in recipes for tissue-healing blends and for its reported soothing effects on the psyche. I have been pleased with the results of this oil, which has come to our rescue in my personal blend inspired by doTerra's Deep Blue; combined with Wintergreen, carrier oils,  and a few other EOs, Blue Tansy was effective as an anti-inflammatory, healing topical on two separate muscle injuries this month.Although I have no other experience with which to compare Nature's Kiss' Blue Tansy EO, it does seem to be a pure oil with powerful therapeutic benefits. The unique tansy scent is a sweet and slightly musky floral -- not unpleasant. One drop is all you need per application. This bottle will last our household for a few years at this rate, unless I find futher uses for it; but even so, it was more than worth the price.

When you read those product descriptions that claim that the aroma of roses is historically considered an aphrodisiac, you may wonder: an aphrodisiac for whom? Surely many people like sniffing it from flowers or using it to disguise worse odors, but when I think about it, I can't say I've ever personally known a *man* to be turned on by the smell of roses. I also can't say that I have, either :). Ah well, but on to the review...I have always enjoyed the scent of roses, sandalwood, and jasmine; and to find a blend that featured all three was like a dream come true. My expectations were for something warm and sensual, being that sandalwood and jasmine have those properties, brightened nicely with sweetness from the rose. What the Sexxy Blend from Miracle Botanicals gives you is a strong hit of rose. While you're reeling from that, you might also detect the sandalwood and jasmine dancing timidly around the perimiter of the ring while Rose Up The Nose charges in for the knockout punch.It's okay. I have come to terms with the fact that this was never going to be the aphrodisiac scent that I was looking for. Plenty of skin care and body lotion recipes call for rose essential oil, and Sexxy Blend will substitute nicely. This blend would also be good to refresh a rose potpourri or a sachet. Unfortuantely, after my husband got his first whiff of Sexxy Blend, all possibility of using it in a massage oil recipe was wiped out by that "I am horrified but resigned to ignore this" expression that crossed his face. Never mind hon, I get it: Sexxy Blend is retired from the bedroom.One more of life's imponderable mysteries: how can such a hugely expensive oil such as rose, jasmine, or sandalwood be sold for a mere forty-ish dollars per 5ml if in fact it is "100% Pure Essential oil blend"? Absolutely incrdible. Meaning, methinks there is something literally too good to be true in that claim... we continue to live and learn.

This was a Christmas present to my son last year: he loved it.The T-shirt itself is of good quality material and construction. Of course it shrinks, that's been the nature of T-shirts ever since the dawn of the Age of Comfortable Clothing. It didn't shrink much, however, nor did it fade in the last 10 months of wash-n-wear.The coolest thing is the glow-in-the-dark circuit graphics, which have also held up pretty well. The lack of specific Tron trademarkings will leave 'em guesing. I'd recommend this T-shirt on the basis of general nerd-approval.

Our smart phones are much-abused, when you think about it: rattling around in purses amongst the tiny bits of debris, sand that somehow worked its way into the bottom of handbags from that late-summer trip to the beach (even though it's now November..I don't clean often, and my handbag is no exception!), and left exposed in various ways which invite all kinds of Bits and Pieces to randomly wind up in those little cracks and crevices which *should* be kept pristine for optimal functioning of the device. Headphone jacks are particularly vulnerable to Bits and Pieces invasions, as most of the time they are left unplugged. That's why I love this little stylus/plug accessory.Note that while I like the *idea* of a smart phone stylus, I rarely use this mini-stylus /plug for that purpose. My fingers, as clumsy as they can be, are still handier for navigating the screen. Perhaps if I had bull-in-a-china-shop man-fingers I would be all about the stylus; but then, if I had beefy man-fingers, I'd probably want a larger stylus anyway.It comes in 8 cute colors, so you'll probably give the puke-colored ones away to your hipster friends. It's a pretty good value for your dollar, all said and done.

Stories of miraculous healings abound around Helichrysum essential oils; disappearing cysts, bruises, dark circles, and muscle injuries healed overnight. Some claim that Helichrysum EO has cured their back injuries, stiff joints, sciatica, and neck pain. How can a newbie such as myself resist what seems like such a bargain price for this reputed "miracle oil"?I bought this Helichrysum essential oil a few months ago before I'd done much research into using EOs for therapeutic purposes: it turns out that this type of Helichrysum, Gymnocephalum, is not considered the best not the most potent strain of Helichrysum which you find in the higher-end essential oil companies -- that would be Helichrysum Italicum. H. Italicum is the strain with consistently high levels of anti-inflammatory curcumenes and regenerative di-ketones. H. Gymnocephalum has lower levels of these molecular components, though I couldn't tell you how much lower. But now that I know this, it's no wonder this was so inexpensive compared to DoTerra's and Young Living's (both Helichrysum I.) EOs!Having established all that, I do think this oil has some good beneficial properties, based on my limited use of it. At first, I used a couple drops of Nature's Kiss Helichrysum Gymnocephalum EO in a homemade facial mask; it had a cool, slightly tingling effect on my skin. I do believe it did its job there in terms of improving my skin's texture and smoothness, but of course that kind of thing is highly subjective. One month later, my son sported a deep muscle injury from training for wrestling on his upper arm; he could barely lift the arm and was in constant pain. The coach had applied an ice pack to the arm right away, but when we got home that afternoon (about two hours after the injury occurred), I made a concoction of Helichrysium, Wintergreen, Blue Tansy, and Peppermint EOs -- loosely interpreting a recipe from a very pricey EO blend used for soothing injuries and aches. I diluted it in extra virgin coconut oil and rubbed lightly over the injured area. This mixture dulled the pain somewhat, but I admit he also took an Advil before bed The next morning the pain did not return and the injury had lessened up somewhat, so I applied more of the mixture to the area before he went to school. By the end of the day, his injury had nearly disappeared, my son could lift his arm again and we still haven't seen a bruise or any visible sign of injury on his arm since. Who's to say if that's due to the Helichrysum or something else?So there's my personal testimony for this product. I am now a believing skeptic for Helichrysum G. Essential Oil by Nature's Kiss. As with their other EOs, my opinion of this product is that it is a good quality EO for a very reasonable price: a budget alternative to the more premium EO brands out there, if perhaps not the absolute top medicinal variety. When this bottle is finally used up, I plan on investing in a bottle of H. Italicum essential oil, which can be had from a few other companies on Amazon, and other external Web sites. It pays to do one's research before buying expensive aromatherapeutic products -- I know that now. Hopefully you can benefit from reading of my experiences, to then make the right purchase for yourself. Happy shopping!

My reasons for ordering this unscented, organic shampoo and conditioner are that 1., I am attempting to incorporate more natural body care products into my life as I cut out synthetic and toxic substances, and 2., so that I can scent the products myself with essential oils that I enjoy and use for aromatherapy purposes. This conditioner accomplishes both of these objectives admirably. One to two drops of EO mixed in with a single application of the shampoo and conditioner (in separate bowls, obviously!) is enough to put a lingering aroma on my hair after everything is rinsed away. It's like perfume for the hair without the chemicals; subtle, not overpowering.If you've read my review of Desert Essence Organics Unscented Shampoo, then pretty much the same points apply here: like the shampoo, it's good on "normal" and/or greasy hair, but it is not especially moisturizing. I found on my "normal" hair it moisturized/conditioned adequately, and when my hair had dried, it was in good condition, but on the drier side (if that makes any sense). Therefore, I would not recommend it for people with hair that requires extra moisturizing.I like Desert Essence and will continue to buy their products as needed.

I ordered this unscented, organic shampoo so that I could scent it myself with aromas that aren't often found in shampoo (at least, not in the more reasonably-priced product lines that I can afford): good-quality essential oils of sandalwood, jasmine, ginger, etc. That has worked out really well: I squirt one "serving" sized amount into a bown and drop my EOs in, mix, and take to the shower. I wish I could have mixed my EOs in the squeeze tube itself in order to save time, but there really is no way to do that (no removable cap/ dispensing tip). Oh well, not a dealbreaker -- but note to the manufacturers, a removable cap would improve my satisfaction with your product!As far as the shampoo itself, it does the job. This Desert Essence shampoo is a decent quality shampoo and I appreciate that it's organic and all-natural. I have "normal" hair, meaning neither greasy nor especially dry, and I find that this shampoo does tend to leave my hair in good condition -- but perhaps just a tad on the drier side. The shampoo does leave the faint scent of the EOs on my hair, which is great for my puposes of a subtle aromatherapy effect in place of wearing actual perfume :).I don't use this shampoo every day due to the bother of having to scent each application of both shampoo and conditioner every time I use it...I tend to forget to get my EOs and bowls before I'm in the bathroom and ready to start. But that's my problem, and it did not influence my rating of the product itself.A good shampoo: I would recommend it generally.

Being that citrus essential oils are expeller pressed and not distilled, they do have a limited shelf life..the relatively faint scent led me to wonder if this bottle of grapefruit EO was perhaps older stock. In my opinion, situations like this merit expiration dates on bottles of certain, more volatile essential oils such as this.I thought it was a nice grapefruit-y smell, but too weak. Still, I will use it until it is gone, and then not order citrus oils from Plant Therapy again. To be fair, their other oils (ginger, petigrain, lemongrass) did make a good impression on me, so I would be open to ordering other types of EOs from this company in the future.

As someone who is more familiar with the scent of German chamomile (been drinking the tea for 2 decades), I was interested to see what a Roman chamomile essential oil would smell like by comparison. If this is any example, then the "apple" scent is fainter and the "herbal" scent is stronger; but it is recognizably chamomile all the same.This is a good, solid chamomile oil, although I just don't get the sense that it is the absolute highest grade/potency available. Nonetheless, Nature's Kiss has it at a great price and the value per dollar is very good. I have used it in skin care recipes and diffused a sleep aid -- it does the job!As usual for this company, it was shipped within 24 hours of my order and arrived in 3 business days' time, standard delivery. I have no complaints at all about the packaging. Nature's Kiss has been proving to me for two months now that they are a highly professional company that delivers a quality product -- my trust as a customer is well-earned.

I bought this as a solution to access my many little (5 ml to 15 ml) essential oil jars in my so-called "apothecary cabinet" -- which is deep, and thus it is often hard to find small items set toward the back. I like the non-skid surface and the lip at the edge. It does the job very well for my purposes.

As soon as the cap comes off you will smell this powerful hybrid lavendar as a potent and slightly more camphorous scent than you may be used to with "French" lavender. I put that  word in quotes because I have a variety of lavender that the nursery sold to my as French lavender, which looks nothing like Lavandula Angustifolia. But I digress..Nature's Kiss has a great, high-quality lavandin oil here, you can't help but be pleased with it.For this past 2 months I have been using this essential oil in a homemade lotion recipe, and it adds a very rich and lasting fragrance to my nighttime routine. I generally do not have trouble falling asleep so I can't comment on its sedative properties, but it is very psychologically soothing. I do believe that it may have repelled more than a few mosquitos, as evidenced by the fact that since I started applying my lavendar lotion before bedtime, I only woke up twice with a new mosquito bite whereas my dh (who of course would never wear "girly-smelling" lotion at any time of day!) would awake with with several. I wasn't looking to use it as an insect repellent, but there you go.All that being said, I enjoy the fragrance from this lavandin oil very much and would use it in all kinds of body care products, but it is not as sweet as true lavender. However, lavandin's higher camphorous content ( cineole, camphor, and borneol) is powerfully antibacterial/antimicrobial, making it ideally suited to applications in cleaning and personal hygiene products. I will share my "all-purpose" cleaning spray recipe with you:1/2 cup white distilled vinegar1/2 cup distilled water12-24 drops of "cleaning" essential oil of your choice*.Put ingredients into a spray bottle, seal, and shake well, to evenly disperse essential oils before each use.*I love using citrus essential oils for their uplifting scent combined with tea tree oils for antiseptic properties in this recipe, but Lavandin Grosso essential oil is also excellent here.Is there any purpose which Lavandin Grosso EO is ill-suited for? Reportedly, the high camphor content is not beneficial to the treatment of minor burns, which is something regular old lavender oil *is* recommended for. And yes, I am aware that I just ended two sentences with prepositions -- please don't tell my jr. high school English teacher ;).

This is a very herbacious and "green" smelling essential oil, which is appropriate because it is derived from leaves and twigs. I would rate its scent potency at about medium strength.I  tried it on the soles of my feet for its reputed calming/sleep inducing properties. I could discern very little effect. It was pleasant enough, but not particularly calming. When I diluted in a toner recipe to control oily skin/acne, once again; little help there. But my face smelled nice!I suppose that since Plant Therapy has it at such a good price, that it would be fine for general aroma uses, but this product did not make a believer out of me in terms of its therapeutic properties.

I don't get the product description's claim that this isn't "true" lavendar: it may not be the exact scent that some people have become used to from French Lavender (Lavandula Angustifolia), but it IS the true, original lavender cultivated by monks and medics going back to Roman times, Lavandula Officinalis. I happen to think that this lavender scent is the nicest and purest form of Lavender.Nature's Kiss has done it once again with a top-drawer essential oil, their "Wild" Lavender. It has a strong, rich top note that is intensely floral. rub a drop on your inner wrist and note, it has staying power! I like to use this EO in body lotion recipes as well as a drop in my baths, facial steams, difusers, and any recipe calling for a sweetly-scented lavendar; it is an excellent, all-purpose aroma. I have not needed to use but the minimal amount called for because it is well concentrated.Thanks, Nature's Kiss! I will surely be back for more.

So "what if" the South had won the War of Secession?Readers already familiar with Harry Turtledove's previous work, Guns of the South, can look forward to another novel set in a similar -- although not exactly the same -- alternate history timeline. How Few Remain picks up after a new country was born of a split between the USA and the Confederacy: the CSA. Now, as adolescent countries are wont to do, these bitter rivals have a new quarrel to occupy them as the CSA aims to purchase a hefty chunk of Mexico that will enable the young nation to realize its own version of Manifest Destiny, extending its territory to the Pacific. Egads, this will not set well with the arrogant and power-hungry USA, now will it, my fellow history students?HFR is written in what has become the typical Turtledove format of splitting the point of view between several characters -- some of which are real historical figures, although others are just the author's own figments. This makes for a good plot device to balance the narrative between "the noble and the common", giving us insights into slice-of-life history as well as the larger arc of the war's progression. Readers will instantly be able to tell which historical characters are the author's pets and which he considers to be buffoons (*cough* Custer *cough*). A major highlight of this story format is the author's delightful take on Samuel Clemens, which showcases a brilliant wit that's uncharacteristic of this author...as if he'd really channelled Clemens to write that portion of the book. The downside of course is that it is often confusing (to me personally, anyway)to switch POV's so frequently; I often thought that a glossary of characters would have been useful. But you could chalk that up to early onset senility if it's convenient..One unmistakable theme in this book (that's hammered to the point of tedium) is that the USA is a proud and overreaching nation --basically, bullies on the world stage. In the space of the first half of the book, we (Northerners) already managed to display the worst sort of racism, condescension, and fascist attitudes that have (in our present-day reality) traditionally been attributed to the South. And is there any truth to that? Well, possibly. When you re-write history you can make any "truth" you want, but there's an undeniable authenticity to the racist tones of speech and thought uncovered in all the characters. It's perhaps a hallmark of their era, but highlighted and underscored more on the USA's side of things here. There are numerous hints throughout that the author apparently believes that, given the right circumstances, our country would have become an oppressive and genocidal tyrant to rival Nazi Germany; and he makes the case with logic and...glee, I do believe. Yes, there is a distinct element of revenge fantasy playing out in the narrative. Turtledove certainly enjoys subverting our established underdogs and winners, that much is certain.The narrative in HFR is looser and more fragmented than in the superior previous work Guns of the South, which is an outstanding example of the best of alternate historical fiction. Sidebars nowithstanding though, HFR is a solid piece of speculative history, written by somebody who obviously knows his subject well. In that sense, Turtledove proves himself to be a master of this era of American history: he plays with the possibilities and remixes them as a master chef might remix a favorite recipe to bring something new and delightful out of an old standby. It was a pleasure to observe how the nations collided, reacted, and mingled in this tale. This was what, in the end, elevated this book from three-star mediocrity to a four-star fandom. Well done.

Well, this is a letdown.The Big Grid Family Organizer turns out to be an ordinary calendar, after all. No, strike that -- ordinary calendars usually have pictures or interesting graphics. This is just a large plain paper calendar, period.What makes this an "organizer" is the fact that there are seven faint lines printed on each calendar day square. I suppose the sheet of little stickers is cute, but for the purposes of planning, I find it faster to just write the activity than hunt up a sticker to put on the day square.Realistically, those paper desk blotter calendars are bigger and have more space to write in than this Big Grid family organizer. I wish I had one of those right about now...There was no "look inside this" on the product page. In order to know what the organizer looked like inside, I had to remove the shrink wrapping from the product...which pretty much makes it unreturnable.Thanks a lot, Amazon.

About 3 days after I started taking this product, I began to notice a gurgly sensation in my belly that came and went. It was akin to the feeling of a baby moving around during the 7th month of pregnancy. I *knew* I wasn't pregnant. It was not painful however, so I blamed vegetables and didn't think much about it.About 4 days after I started taking this product, my dear husband began to make references to my "landfill swill" breath. At first I assumed he was joking. Never having had such a problem before, I dismissed it for the next ten days until the complaints grew so frequent that they couldn't be ignored. Even my kids began to comment on the stench.I couldn't think of one thing I'd been doing differently for two weeks, except...selenium. But selenium is a trace mineral, how could it..? Ah, the label on the bottle said "yeast" which I hadn't noticed when I was ordering it because it was in small type. There ya go.Now that it has been ten days since I ceased with the yeasty selenium, my gut has not been gurgling and my breath has returned to its pre-landfill state. Peace is restored in our household. I'm sure the planets are free to align as well.Now to find a non-yeast source of selenium...
