Last summer when my grandmother moved to a retirement facility, my family and I discovered hundreds of priceless family photographs being stored loose in one of the drawers at her old house. She had no album to take with her to her new home. The solution of course was for me to create a scrapbook for Oma so that she could enjoy her memories as well as share them with visitors.This K & Company album kit was the perfect answer to Oma's preference for pink and the retro look needed for an album that had most of its photos from the mid-20th Century. The papers are sweet, charming, and actually very simple in pattern, many with a '50s style. You do not have to use them for baby pages (although of course you can)! The front of the album cover was customized with letter stickers included in the kit to read "Dot's Family" and a b&w picture of Oma with her young family inserted into the photo frame. It was perfect, and the way the album went together did not look "babyish" at all but rather something straight out of the 1950s. The leftover baby-themed stickers and embellishments included in the kit were saved for an actual baby album.Everybody agreed that this scrapbook album was a great present for Oma's 89th birthday.Thank you K and Company for these great scrapbook album kits. If I had one complaint it's that I could have used more of the papers  -- you only included like 10 sheets in the kit-- I looked for them separately but they were nowhere to be found unless I wanted to buy another kit! I had to extend the album with papers matched as best I could with the kit papers, and it wasn't easy to find matches but in the end it worked out alright. Really, the coordinating papers should be available to buy separately.

I have many K and Company albums and products already, and have been completely satisfied with them. So satisfied, that when I searched for a scrapbook album with a turquoise blue color accent and came up with this one, I put it in my cart without a second thought. I intended to purchase it the next day after I'd had more time to shop for a few other items to add to the order.So imagine my dismay when I logged in the next morning and the price had more than doubled overnight! Yes, it was an amazing coincidence that when I initially added the album to my shopping cart, it was 10 dollars and change, but in less than 24 hours the price had gone up to 20.60. I moved it into the Save for Later hoping this was a mistake that would be corrected.I have yet to move this item out of the Save for Later back into the cart. It has been sitting there for approximately 2 months as I wait for the powers that be to realize that they messed up and lower the price back. That has not happened. Meanwhile, I still would like to purchase this album but it is not available locally. So, I am in deadlock. I am certain now that this was a deliberate price increase triggered when I put the item into my cart -- somebody noticed that it was mistakenly priced and "fixed" it to the tune of double what it had been. This "fix" is all in the favor of the seller and against the customer, and it makes for lousy service policy. In a real-life retail situation, would K and Company want a customer to find an item with sale price, bring it to the register and be told "sorry, that's not the real price, let's fix that and charge you double what you thought you'd be paying." Of course the customer would not stand for it. In protest, I am refusing to move it into my cart for purchase until the situation is corrected with the price back down to ten dollars. Then and only then will I buy this album and update my review.

The Big Book of Scrapbook Pages has one main thing going for it: lots of pictures of scrapbook pages done in the latest styles. This could be very inspirational if all you're looking for is trendy ideas for your next layout.However, very little other information is included next to each picture, aside from the manufacturer of the products. This can be daunting, especially for somebody without advanced scrapbooking skills; most of the layouts are done in very "busy" styles which include lots of elements, bits, and pieces and maybe only one or a few photos. Because of this, it is hard for me to decipher what elements are on each page and "translate" it to the order and techniques I'd need to duplicate the look. I am an intermediate scrapper who's been away from scrapbooking for a few years, and it isn't automatically obvious to me how to recreate these pages.So as a point of inspiration, TBBOSP is right on target, but I was hoping for more help from this book.

I picked this up at my supermarket thinking the kids and I were in for a real treat; they'd had peppermint hot cocoa from a restaurant recently and were begging for more.You mix this stuff with one cup of hot milk and have to stir like mad for a long time to get it mixed in properly. No matter, it still tastes like sharp, unpleasantly watery dark chocolate and not the creamy rich cocoa we were hoping for. A nasty brew -- the kids hated it instantly and so did I. Other than this stuff I am a dark chocolate fan, but come on..! Starbucks has some nerve calling this stuff "velvety".A waste of money. Now I have to find some unsuspecting sap to pass this on to. And yes, I just ended that sentence with a preposition! RAWR!!

Following the recipe on the package to a "t", I still managed to overbake this cake by about 15 minutes. Surprise--still moist and dense!Of course no gluten free recipe will ever ever taste *exactly* like the wheat version, But I have to say this chocolate cake came remarkably close. I like that it has a nice dark chocolate flavor that's not overly sweet. To make it even richer chocolate-y, add in a tablespoon of chocolate extract along with the vanilla extract.

I am well known in my family for my home made breads and baked goods (sorry I had to toot my own horn there). I used to think from-scratch was ALWAYS best. But even I can't top how delicious the pumpkin bread comes out when made with this kit. I took the sliced loaves of pumpkin bread to a school picnic and people were going back for seconds and thirds.Your kit basically has the can of pumpkin, the dry mix and the icing packet. Add your own (4)eggs, oil and water to the pumpkin, blend, then add in the dry mix and stir just until moistened. Pour in tins and bake. Easier and faster than measuring the dry mix ingredients out one by one in a scratch recipe.Hint1: use olive oil. It mades for a moist and dense bread and definitely smells better than anything made with corn oil.Hint2: butter the loaf tins generously. I think butter does the job better than nonstick spray...just a personal preference.Hint3: stir in the dry mix JUST until moistened. Overstirring toughens anything made with wheat flour. Do not try to "work the lumps out". They work out on their own in the baking process.This recipe made one 8X4 loaf plus three "mini" 5X3 loaves. You can get a bundt cake out of this or make other sized loaf combinations if you like. Probably even makes great muffins ( I don't have the back of the box to check on this right now).

Cake's style is the definition of quirky, and it hasn't changed at all from their first album: monotone-ish lead singer vox, acoustic and electric guitar, a small brass section and an enthusiastic drumbeat underpinning it all. There's a supplement of background chorus shouts every now and then, putting me in mind of a Punk influence. The lyrics are smart, more coffehouse-style poetry than anything else, and each track covers a wide variety of subjects from romantic musings to Austrian noblemen. The ironic served up with the sincere -- yep, that's Cake all right.Comfort Eagle has a few standout tracks and a lot of milder ones which grew on me. Short Skirt/Long Jacket is the big hit that first grabbed me, an upbeat tribute to the modern dream girl who is "touring the facility and picking up slack" while her nails "shine like justice" and she "uses a machete to cut through red tape". The title track Comfort Eagle is a strange compare/contrast mashup of religious cults, the music business, and television shopping channels--but it was absolutely useless to resist that beat, and I was chorusing along with it and stomping my heels in time on the second listen. I would have clapped my hands, too, if I hadn't been driving. Love You Madly is a bold declaration of love exactly as the title suggests, my third favorite track for its fast pace and tuneful sincerity. Subtler tracks such as Meanwhile, Rick James..., Shadow Stabbing, Arco Arena and Long Line of Cars took a few more listens as they were slower and more thoughtful, but still quite well-crafted. In a more mellow mood, those are my tracks of choice. Commissioning a Symphony in C is an unusual track about the patrons of the arts way back in the days of Mozart, nice enough but I never go out of my way to seek it out. The only track I can honestly report as an "avoid" is the first one, Opera Singer. Please don't let its bad placement in the lineup discourage you from the rest of this fun and intelligently made album!Consistency of style and great musicianship: if you have enjoyed any of Cake's radio hits in the past (Never There, Going the Distance), you will know exactly what you're in for when buying Comfort Eagle. This album is IMO their overall best effort to date, showcasing the band's personality and independant flavor to perfection. Do try!

I'm sorry, I couldn't help myself; we're only on March 25, and already I have to review this book. It was just impossible to wait until we'd finished out the entire yearJ.Being a christian is hard even before you even consider God's command that we must also raise our children in the ways of the Lord and teach them the scriptures. It would be easy to just put that job off on the Sunday school teachers (and much of the time, that's exactly what I did), but is that really *their* job? Traditionally, my family not only went to church on Sundays but also Wednesday nights and we read from the bible, although not every night. That was how I grew up learning about the bible, but I confess, it seemed like a dry and dull way. My grandmother also had a set of vinyl records with bible stories and picture books to accompany them (I don't remember the titles) -- now that was more interesting, and stuck with me more as I grew and remembered the beautiful illustrations.  So now as a parent, that seems more intuitively the ideal way to bring the bible alive for my own boys.The One Year Bible for Children is nicely geared toward children of about elementary school age as a daily "devotional" style read-aloud.  It begins on January 1 with the Genesis creation story and follows approximately along the time line through the Old and New Testaments until the end of the year. Flipping through, I would say that about half of the daily selections have illustrations -- but they're truly top quality illustrations, nothing cartoon-y or "babyish" about them (please excuse me, those are pet peeves of mine..I believe children's books should be every bit as well-illustrated and lovely as anything an adult would read that has illustrations). The text is a simplified version of the more familiar bible stories, which seem to be selected for being interesting and action-oriented from a kids point of view, and they are told in a language that paraphrases to a child's level of understanding, but never patronizes them. Each "day" ranges in length from one quarter page to a full page of text. At the bottom of each selection, there are questions that parents can use to help the children recall details of the story and encourage them to analyze and apply the morals and principles to their own lives. My 6- and 10-year-olds never stall or complain when "story time" comes every night.To give you a taste of this book: As of this day in March 25 the book has progressed to Joshua 1-2, "Spies Visit Jericho", with a small box illustration in the bottom corner page. Tomorrow's has "Crossing the Jordan River" with a two-page spread and a colorful, panoramic picture taking up the entire bottom half. An excerpt reads: "Joshua gave orders, too. "Each of you must make yourself clean on the outside to show that your heart is pure and clean on the inside," he said. "Tomorrow you will see a miracle". The next morning Joshua gave orders to the priests. "Take the Ark and lead us across the river", he said.  So the procession started."  Skipping ahead to the New Testament, September 2nd, Jesus Stops a Storm, the entire two page spread is the picture of the disciples and Jesus in the boat with the text printed over it: "Jesus spoke to the wind and the waves. "Be quiet!" he said. The wind and waves died down quickly. Suddenly everything was calm and still. "Why were you so afraid?" he asked the disciples. "Don't you believe in me?"Fabulous!Yes of course attending Sunday school and memorizing verses is indispensable in our children's education. Why not also make it seem real and alive to them?  I will be giving this book to many other children as birthday and Christmas gifts -- what a great way for them to see bible history!Andrea, aka Merribelle

This is a ghost story, but not a horror story.  You may get chills reading it, but not always from "the creeps". On the other hand, you may finish it wondering just what the heck you just read. I submit to you All Hallows' Eve-- definitely not for everybody.All Hallows' Eve is Charles Williams' last novel, written and set in WW2 England. It starts shortly after the tragic deaths of two women friends, Evalyn and Lester, in a bizarre collision, and neither is aware at first that they have died. They wander a weirdly deserted London separately for a brief time before meeting up, which gives the author an opportunity to focus on Lester's inner spiritual journey as she slowly confronts some unattractive truths about herself and her important relationships with her husband and her friends. In a separate but intersecting storyarc, Lester's surviving husband and his artist friend cross paths with a popular cult leader, Simon Le Clerc. This disturbing figure has a hidden past that is revealed only to us, the readers, as the plot unfolds.  He is shaping up to be something not unlike an antichrist of sorts who is conducting covert, occultic experiments on the artist's love interest, Betty Wallingford, who is the daughter of one of Le Clerc's most devoted followers.Williams makes use of Betty's nighttime passages to scratch the surface of an alternate universe which Evelyn, Lester and (presumably) other newly-deceased inhabit. It is simply described as the City, and although it bears a surface resemblance to London, it is more of an infrastructure to London, or perhaps the Platonic Ideal of London...possibly something more. Many things in this realm tantalize us with glimpses of hidden spiritual truths, and time itself seems to have no linear requirement; past, present and future flashbacks occur without regard to conventional order.  I was left with the sense that I would have liked to discover more about this City, and as this is my first Williams novel, who knows..he may indeed refer to it in his other stories.I'm not sure what sort of person would be best prepared to read this final Charles Williams novel. The author (an Anglican, or so I've read) clearly gives his audience much credit, as he allows us to draw our own conclusions about either the allegorical or the literal truths he dallies with along the storyline; he never force-feeds or "preaches". Somebody moderately educated in various religious history and/or theology would recognize a lot of the hints and references Williams makes along the way to telling his story. I wouldn't say that you must be a Christian to appreciate it, but it might help. On the other hand, I would only recommend this book to a mature Christian who has some direct study of the bible under his belt and yet a non-legalistic attitude toward their christian fiction. Certainly the reader would benefit from an ability to appreciate mysticism.All Hallows' Eve was recommended to me by A Reader's Delight, which appeals to readers who crave rare literary treasures from various genres. Williams' writing style is rich and many-layered, so that I may have to read All Hallows' Eve several times to extract everything I should from it in time. Take that under advisement, and if the shoe fits, do try.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

1. This book is definitely intermediate level or above. Having learned some stumpwork and ribbon embroidery myself, I think of my skills as intermediate and I would never give this to a beginner as a learning tool. Although the author does explain the stitches and techniques, it is done in a very condensed way that could be confusing for first-timers. There are few how-to illustrations here compared to beginner's books.2. In order to complete the embroidery sampler as pictured (the whole book is a panel-by-panel sampler project, by the way), you need to go on the author's Web site and order her pre-printed cotton fabric to embroider and stump on top of. In theory one could trace the design in the book, but that would leave out the subtle colors and shading that give this piece its extraordinary colorful, dimensional quality. Apparently, all of Di van Niekerk's books need their accompanying printed fabrics, and this one is about 16 American dollars. Why this is never mentioned either on the online page or on the book's cover is a mystery to me.3. The threads and silk ribbons that you will need for Di's projects are brand names that can not easily be found outside of South Africa (the author lives in Cape Town). You can order these from her Web site as well. Of course you could use YLI or other brands more available in America, but you'd have to guess to match the colors.  I'd feel more comfortable using the author's recommended brands and colors.A Perfect World in Ribbon Embroidery and Stumpwork is simply exquisite. It features high-quality, lovely, original designs. The finished effect of combining ribbon embroidery and stumpwork takes my breath away, and Di van Niekerk deserves credit as a pioneer of sorts in the world of embroidery. She does indeed show a few techniques that I have never seen before.Be prepared to do some online shopping first, and you will be able to make a sampler project that will be the envy of all your embroidering friends.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

If the Harry Potter books are the most popular books of this generation, then the Nancy Drew books were the hits of the 1930s. Remarkably, how every decade since then, both girls and boys have rediscovered Nancy Drew and made her adventures their own. This is how you can tell the true classics apart from the pretenders.Like most of the `80s kids, I had never realized that the escapades of my favorite childhood heroine had ever been made into movies. It took a badly done remake in 2007 for somebody to realize that money could be made from the generations of fans who have adored the real Nancy Drew; and so these four films were released on DVD as part of a cross-promotional marketing tactic. Well lucky for us, anyhow!Starting with Nancy Drew, Detective and progressing to the Hidden Staircase, we get four fun mysteries.  Detective introduces Nancy and shows how she got started sleuthing when a wealthy elderly woman disappears mysteriously.  Reporter is about Nancy and Ted's investigation into a murder, which kicks off when Nancy is convinced that the accused woman is innocent. Troubleshooter follows Nancy and her dad to a vacation at Sylvan Lake where they uncover clues to exonerate a family friend who has been charged with the murder of a local businessman. Hidden Staircase is the most exciting mystery, in which Nancy and Ted find an underground tunnel in the basement of a "haunted" mansion. I regret that I no longer have a sharp memory for the specifics of the books' plots, so I cannot compare them to these movies with any accuracy, but their spirit is well kept as I remember them.*This* is the Nancy Drew I remembered from those books read so long ago: feisty, charismatic, energetic and unstoppable. Bonita Granville's Nancy is also impossibly cute, which is very much in keeping with the style of those times. The actor who played Ted Nickerson is the perfect sidekick, reluctant with just a touch of teenage dorkiness. I enjoyed their performance, if it was a bit over-the-top acting by today's standards.In my opinion, this Nancy Drew DVD would be enjoyed most by people who have read the books and who like nostalgic black and white films. It's certainly a wholesome and perhaps somewhat corny look back at the 1930s ideal of an independent, intelligent young lady.-Andrea, aka merribelle

This is almost two books in one: the first half is a superb, thorough instructional manual of stumpwork embroidery techniques; the second half, a detailed collection of stumpwork projects from designers which have been featured in Inspirations magazine, arguably the most prestigious embroidery publication in the world. You really get the A to Z!Despite the carefully photographed, step-by-step technique section, I would rate A-Z of Stumpwork as a book for the intermediate stumper. True, it is published in a spiral-bound format, which in my opinion is invaluable for a working reference guide of any kind. But even experienced stitchers do forget stitches from time to time. And let us not overlook the elegant, gorgeous designs that are laid out for us to duplicate, designs from the likes of Anna Scott, Jan Kerton, Wendy Innes and Janet Luce. Their elaborate embroideries are given complete materials' lists and instructions, but not illustrated step by step.Everything in the A-Z series is so beautifully photographed, so carefully organized and detailed, and so charmingly illustrated with whimsical prints and retro-Victorian artwork, that of course I have to award A-Z of Stumpwork five stars. I recommend that a beginner get a copy of Kay Dennis' Beginner's Guide to Stumpwork to get started and this lovely A-Z reference to use and keep for a lifetime of usefulness and inspiration.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

As I have stated elsewhere, there are three things I look for in an instructional embroidery book:1. The book must not be so thick that it is intimidating to beginners.2. Embroidery instructions are best if they are illustrated each step of the way; the higher the quality of the illustrations, the better a beginner will be able to learn.3. Projects must be simple and quick to complete.Needlelace and Stumpwork by Loretta Holzberger certainly starts off well.  The book is a nice modest size for students to get into (pass on point #1). The basics are explained logically and in a simple enough manner. However, my impression of its quality was marred early on when I noticed that except for a few color plates in the center of the book, it was entirely printed in black and white and on relatively cheap stock. The illustrations were relatively sparse, simply hand drawn, and slightly amateurish compared to the standards I've come to expect from other embroidering books printed in the last 15 years or so. Several of the photographed samples were fuzzy and unclear. In short, corners were cut, and for the price I expected better. My second point was not successfully honored.On the positive side, the projects are indeed simple and beginner appropriate (pass on point #3).  I thought the butterflies pictured on the cover (the reason I bought this book to begin with) were fun and quick. With careful attention, it is possible for students to learn beginning level needlelace and stumpwork methods from this book; it does its job in the end.-Andrea, aka merribelle

I have not even scratched the surface of this new stumpwork hobby, but I have tried learning a lot of new embroidery techniques over the last 10 years. If I have come away with anything from the experience it's how to spot a good beginner's book:).Students want to feel encouraged to try. Three things are important:1. The book must not be so thick that it's overwhelming.2. Embroidery instructions are better if there are photos and/or illustrations for every step of the process. The higher their quality, the better a newbie will be able to follow and duplicate techniques (hint: look for full color!).3. Projects should be basic and quick to complete.Kay Dennis has hit the nail on the head with all of these points. The Beginner's Guide to Stumpwork covers just enough technique to give the reader a feel for the craft, really showing just a few of the most common stitches and their variations to get somebody started stumping and needlelacing. The sample projects are quite simple, even a bit primitive in my opinion, but they are presented perfectly for learning and building confidence.Once you gain some basic practice from this book, I would recommend moving on to the Complete Book of  Stumpwork Embroidery by Jane Nicholas for elegant, inspirational designs and a nice bit of background on the history of stumping.-Andrea, aka merribelle

Bottom line, you buy one of these mainly to make pancakes.  The Anolon Double Burner Griddle is better than a traditional frying pan for pancakes because you can fit more on it at one time, which means less time in the kitchen and more time eating those tasty little crumpets while they're still hot. The kids also get less whiny when you can serve them all at once instead of doling out a few pancakes here and there or worse, serving them all at once when they've gone cold.Turns out, it's also good at French toast, eggs, bacon, quesadillas and grilled cheese sandwiches. Added bonus: you only have to add butter or oil if you like the flavor, because after owning and using this thing for two months, I have to admit, it truly deserves to be called nonstick (unlike so many "nonsticks" that have disappointed me after the first few uses).Some might point out that at 10 inches wide, this griddle is too narrow to fit all their breakfast items at once. Well get two, they're a slim profile and lightweight and at about fifteen bucks less than the Circulon, you can probably afford it.My 22-year-old recipe for Frickin' Fantastic Pancakes:1 cup Buttermilk, 1 cup flour, 1 egg, 2 Tablespoons oil, 1 Tablespoon sugar, 1 tsp. baking powder,  tsp. baking soda, ½ tsp. salt.Heat your griddle to med-low. Mix ingredients in a large bowl with a balloon whisk until just a few lumps remain (no overworking allowed). Pour on the griddle (you know what size you like) and watch for the bubbles in the center of your pancakes to signal it's time to turn. Flip, cook a few more minutes, serve, and notice how much better this is than that mix stuff.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

I feel a connection with David Masumoto. Not that I've met him or anything - in fact, there's a good chance I never will (although I keep hoping that one summer day I can make it over to his farm to pick peaches). No, this feeling is based on an impression that we have both fought the same fight over different things, for the same reasons. It is also because he writes so poignantly about a landscape I grew up in.  Mr. Masumoto is an organic farmer in the valley of California, and his story is becoming more and more familiar to me as I see this way of life disappearing across the country.A third generation Japanese American peach and grape farmer, David Masumoto inherited the family orchard from his father. He also had the heritage of his childhood memories of how that particular peach variety, Sun Crest, tasted and ran with juice unlike the pretty red baseballs that have passed for today's supermarket peach varieties.  Mr. M wanted to show the world how delightful an old-fashioned peach could be. When he took over his father's farm, he resolved to not only continue growing his Sun Crests, but to do it organically. This would prove challenging in our day and age of cheap, quick fixes; moreover, it would test his strongly felt ideals.  The land needed to heal and replenish itself after years of chemical fertilizers and toxic pest control methods. Masumoto had to take his example from research on other organic farming practices, planting wildflowers to encourage beneficial insect life and sowing "green manure" crops to act as natural mulch and compost. All this took time, patience, and faith that his hard work would eventually pay off.Epitaph for a Peach is rich in sensory descriptions, philosophy, and nostalgic flashbacks. It is a picture of the way a farmer's life is connected to the seasons, capricious weather patterns, and changing market conditions. Not incidentally, Masumoto also teaches about the obscure history of Japanese farmers in the Valley - something that even I, native to Fresno, had little idea of. Reading this book was a slow, thoughtful experience much in the same manner that one slows down to savor a rich fruit. Recommended to anybody interested in history, growing food, or the vanishing California landscape.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

At some point after you've sealed your umpteenth jar of strawberry preserves and peach jam, you find yourself asking, Is this as exciting as it gets? Really, your sister and office mates are probably (secretly of course) just as bored with your yearly batches of apple jelly as you are. To keep motivated every harvest time, you repeat to yourself over and over, like a mantra: Made with real sugar, not high fructose corn syrup...Well imagine their eyes popping out of their heads when you triumphantly hand them your Pear and Ginger Marmalade, Green Tomato Relish, and Plum and Raisin Chutney!When the title of a cookbook claims the status of Art, expect that it contains inventive, quirky and elegant combinations in addition to the more pedestrian basics.  Also, assume that it was not meant for rank beginners any more than it was written by a rank beginner. Jan Berry, the author of Art of  Preserving has decades of experience with preserving a wide range of fruits and vegetables, and while she discusses the basic methods in a short preface chapter, it's barely sketched. But more on that in a moment.In the ten years that I have owned my copy of Art of Preserving, I have tried perhaps a dozen of the 300 or so recipes in this book.  It's all I have the nerve, resources or the gourmet gumption, to have tried. From this book I have produced Blood Orange Pommander Brandy, Orange Wine, Lemon Oil, Candied Citrus peel, Blueberry Jam, Apple and Geranium Jelly, Figs in Brandy, Red Bell Pepper Jelly, herb-infused vinegars and sugars, Preserved Ginger, and Banana Jam. I am eager to try several more as time and ingredient availability permit, such as Pumpkin and Rosemary Jam  and Melon Jelly. Ah, for an acre of garden space to grow the stuff and a few months every year to harvest and preserve it all! That would definitely be somewhere in my heaven.In a way, the Art of Preserving is like a look back to pre-industrial times. The author apparently grew up in the Outback under poor circumstances.  She had to learn to make do and be very careful with her resources, so I believe that is why none of her recipes here list commercial pectin. Instead, the jams and jellies are set with the natural pectins in apples, quinces, citrus seeds, etc. Some of them require elaborate preparations of more than one day's time to draw the juices out through jelly bags, or marinate ingredients to perfection. In a nutshell, Jan Berry's preserving style is not for those looking for instant gratification.As to Jan Berry's recommended methods for sealing up jars: waxed paper and a lid. If you want to be decorative, she suggests additionally covering the tops with paper and twine or ribbon. I'm the first to admire the simple rustic charm in this style, but I can rarely use it as I like to ship my jams and jellies as gifts and enter them in fair contests now and then; the official rules prohibit anything but hot water-bath canning methods, sealing lid and screw-rings only. In order to translate her sealing instructions for modern times, it might take a bit of know-how from a more intermediate canner. See what I mean about this book not catering to complete amateurs?Finally, the photographs are works of art in themselves.  Truthfully, TAOP is one of the best-photographed cookbooks I have ever seen, and thankfully, a little more than half of the recipes are displayed in these artfully arranged shots. I have never seen such a complete and extensive collection of offbeat jam, jelly, chutney and etc. recipes in one place, as in The Art of Preserving. It is certainly a must for preservers who love to gift their jars.This book, sadly out of print for several years now, is well worth the time and effort to search out if you enjoy preserving above and beyond its original, practical purpose.-Andrea, aka Merribelle

On the one hand, I loved this book. It was light and frothy and you could buzz right through it in one sitting. However, there is the rub. One of the best selling Bible study aids of all time is the meaty "Imitation of Christ"--in which almost every sentence should be reflected on and digested; in comparison, you finish this book filling joyous and uplifted, but then stop to think--"what did I really learn that will change me going forward"--this book pales in comparison. Yes, it has the obligatory end-of-chapter Q&A's and discussion group prompts, but somehow, it still winds up more on the "cotton candy" pile than "meat and potatoes" pile..Would I rec it? Absolutely! Loved it. Learned from it. Laughed out loud.Would I buy it? $10 is pushing the envelope for such a short read, but definitely for $4.99 or less.Would I reread it? Yes. It is a great little "feel good" book that reminds you over and over that God loves us.

I just want to take a sec to let potentially interested readers know that this is an "R" rated comedy that the protagonist drops "F"-bombs throughout. If you don't find that off-putting, fine. Just thought you should know. If I were reading them I wouldn't care so much, since I'd just skim over them. However, I listen to most of my books on Kindle, so that won't work for me. I returned for refund. Just an FYI.

To be fair, the first half of the book is absolutely excellent: riveting, well-paced, lots of twists and turns. Couldn't believe it was on the Kindle free list. The two main characters (Vince and Laura) are well drawn, three-D characters, and the reader will deeply care what happens to them. The author does a fine job of fleshing out supporting characters and not simply making them "plot devices." At least three of them have weaved a fairly tangled web of their life, and the author knits all of these pieces together seamlessly. There are enough unexpected plot changes (like good key changes in music) that keep the reader riveted to the page and at the edge of their proverbial seat..But then comes the second half, where we get "more is better." There can only be so many people who get their head's bashed in, or then it becomes just another "basher" book. Almost everyone who dies in this book gets their head bashed: poker, walking stick, pick ax, etc. Since it's not always the same character doing the bashing (and since this is such a messy way to kill someone), it's unclear why this gratuitous choice is made over and over again--it begins to be salacious. However, far worse than this is the implausible ending.  It is one thing to have a "dark horse" candidate be revealed as the murderer/murderess at the end of a mystery. It's another thing to have that person be completely out of character with anything that has gone before in their story arc. Imagine "Casablanca" if Elsa had decided to turn in Rick and her husband to the Nazis before she got on the plane--sure, it's an unexpected plot twist, but it doesn't fit. If you twist just for the sake of twisting, something will break, and that's what happens here..Would I rec it? YesWould I buy it? YesWould I read other books by this author? Yes

That should be the title of Ms. Fluke's next book. Can someone please tell me why we are still reading these? Thank God my library no has OneClick, so I can now just check them out electronically for free and listen to them on my laptop. I am not spending another penny on this fodder. I agree, at the point, Ms. Fluke is just "phoning in" these books, so to speak. Who can really churn out a book every other month if they are trying to write something worthwhile. She's got a great franchise, but she's killing it with "overexposure." At this point, it's like looking at a train wreck that you just can't look away from. I haven't read every book in the series like some loyal readers, but even I've had enough of Hannah's "stuck in the doldrums" life. I agree with many of the reviewers who have begged Ms. Fluke to wrap up the series. All good things have to come to an end--even Seinfeld pulled the plug after nine years, and it still had a lot of gas left in the tank, but he wanted to go out on top. Let Hannah pick one or the other suitor, and let us all (characters included) live happily ever after.

I wanted to like this book; I really did. I love Christ on many levels, but especially as an entity that walked the face of the Earth and did it with such grace, control, and boundless love. I love the succinctness of Christ. How in the world can someone come up with such amazing guiding principles: "Love your neighbor as yourself." Five words! Phenomenal! The efficiency and effectiveness of the gospel parables are mind boggling. We (and by this I mean 20th and 21st century humans) get so gummed up in splitting biblical, spiritual, moral, and societal hairs, that we forget (often) the profoundness of many of the quotes that are attributed to Christ. Does it matter if he uttered them all or not? Does it matter if the Bible came down to us with 100% fidelity or a little less? Just as Shakespeare transcended his milieu as did Bach to emerge out of almost nowhere to write words and music that were so far advanced for their time that all one can do is shake one's head and drop one's jaw in wonder. Of course, Christ is the ultimate jaw-dropper because he was like a meteor striking the Earth with amazing spiritual clarity that is seen once a millennium or so. Having said the above, the author challenges this paradigm to say that Christ's missing years (from ages twelve to thirty) were spent in India and Asia learning teachings of the Buddha. Great story line for a book if developed properly; however, there are issues:.(Too Preachy) First, THIS BOOK IS TOO PREACHY (not evangelical preachy, but preachy just the same). Buddhists and "spiritual people" are good, but fundamentalists are dogmatic and bad. Yawn. Whether or not we always like or respect their position, there certainly are wonderful people who are evangelicals. The type of people who don't abort a child with Down's Syndrome or other disease and actually take wonderful care of them all their lives. (Don't see many secularists pulling that trick). OK, they can be annoying too with their positioning on "gays," and other narrow-minded stances, but they are not all bad. So, having every evangelical in the book being either a hypocrite or an opportunist is annoying..(Derivative) Second, the evangelical "villain" who is trying to keep the Issa Codex from becoming public knowledge because it would undermine Christianity is a virtual clone of the nut case from DaVinci code: same "pervert who hates himself because he can't control his sexual desires," same "brainwashed by religion when he was young and now he wants to be a martyr." It's annoying..(Lecturing) Third, there is WAY too much lecturing on Buddhism especially, and in glowing terms that seem to imply that the author feels this way is the best choice to enlightenment. That's fine, but don't pretend to be ecumenical if the real agenda is to promote one philosophy over another. Because the author spends so much of the book (40%) "teaching" us about different religions, it distracts from the plot. If the reader has what they feel is enough familiarity with these different religions, the lecturing is just annoying. If I wanted to read a non-fiction book about "What is Islam?" that's what I would be doing..(Phony Romance) Forth, the "romance" between Grant and Kristen is pretty lame. There is a scene after he has a "debate" with an evangelical who accuses him of academic plagiarism. He is embarrassed by this, and apparently "the media" pounce on the story and further run him down. Somehow, in the midst of all this scandal, where his whole career could be ruined, he finds the energy and interest to go to his girlfriend's apt. and have a "make out" session, which we are told lasts for thirty minutes (I guess that's so we know that Mr. Sensitive Post-doc Man knows how to give foreplay.) Anyway, after this scene, where we are told "pelvises were grinding" (yikes!), but she decides that she doesn't want to "do it." Mr. Sensitive Post-Doc tells her, "That's OK. We don't need to go there." Really? Isn't that a little forced? You mean to tell me that Mr. Post-Doc doesn't need the release that would come with sex after such a horrendous day? He's just going to be Mr. Understanding and not even walk out in a huff? Serves no purpose and doesn't seem realistic. For that matter, the whole "romance" seems forced and not at all interesting..(Poorly Paced) Fifth, some of the most "revelatory" parts of the book take place over Indian food. This totally deflates their importance. In the DaVinci Code, Robert Langdon was revealing things to his side-kick during tense situations, where the insights really mattered. In many of the scenes in this book, the facts just "spill out," but there is no "weight" attached to them..OK, having said all the above, here are the good parts: (1) Book is highly readable. I'm not saying it's at the level of "I can't put it down," however, the reader does want to know what happens next. (2) The "on location" scenes are good, and the author clearly has a good knowledge of the areas and locales in which he sets parts of the book. (3) The basic premise that Christ might have gone to Asia and India is intriguing, and although it could have been developed with more suspense and intrigue, it is--a priori--interesting..Would I recommend it? YesWould I read it while it's discounted to $1.99? YesIs it a MUST READ? NoIs it logical with good grammar? YesHope this helps.

I really think if the artwork hadn't been so wonderful on the cover, the book wouldn't seem half so good. The very best part of the book, and the only think that salvages it from absolute chic-lit fotter, is that every chapter starts out with an excerpt of the protagonist's (Sophy's) great-great-etc-relative, Alys, who may or may not be a witch. These diary tidbits are easily the most interesting part of the book. We slowly find out more about Alys, but never really enough--pity, since she's the most interesting character in the book. She has recipes for various cures, recipes, and details about various plants and flowers..As for the actual story--yawn (sorry). It doesn't have an interesting POV, nor does it have any interesting history (which is a wasted opportunity since Alys lives in the 1500s. The author could have fleshed out something about the world that Alys lived in if she didn't want to build a full character and plot around her. Sophy inherits a fabulous, decaying house, and "bonds" with it when she goes there to investigate. That's fine, but not terribly novel, since many of us have a "love at first sight" feeling for the home we buy. There is an obligatory fake suitor (who can be spotted a mile away--very one dimensional character...bad, bad, bad). There is the friendly assortment of loyal "servants" who want nothing more than to restore the house to its former glory. There is the feminist "women can do anything" theme that also rings cliche and improbably. There is the dark horse suitor that hooks up with Sophy at the end so they can live "happily ever after," all with the blessings of Alys, who Sophy just knows is pleased by all that has transpired..As many other reviewers have already mentioned, the book is well-written on a sentence by sentence basis, so it flows well. This is true even if neither the characters nor the plot is particularly engaging. Now that I've finished the book, I have to say that the plot really goes down the drain at the end. Everything is so predictable that it's almost unbearable. On the other hand, if you can buy it for a few dollars and are looking for a modestly anglophile read, you could give this a try.

I enjoyed this book. It is a nice, old-fashioned, "Root for the Good Guy, Hiss at his Evil Wife" story. I don't want to give too much away, but the husband is a Scot who comes to America seeking a little adventure and to expand his fortune. His wife thinks Americans are uncouth (well, ain't we :) and wants nothing but to convince him to return to Europe. He has firmly planted his stake in the ground here, and won't be moved. She is conniving, which makes the story enjoyable (few thinks better than seeing a wicked wealth spoiled diva get her comeuppance!) Lots of nice details about that era and location (Colorado just after the peak of the gold rush). Good subplots and characters as well. World the author creates feels "real," which few authors do these days. Definitely recommend this, especially while it's free :)

Very much enjoyed this book. It is a unique blend of history, romance, and "coming of age" story. If you like the Bible, that's an added bonus as the author weaves in passages with the narrative; if you don't, it doesn't ruin the story either because the author isn't beating readers over the head with verses, just sprinkling them throughout like a nice seasoning. It's enjoyable to watch the story come together, and the characters grow from what they've experienced. There are some unexpected twists which keeps one reading. Well written, flows easily, believable, and enjoyable. (I had to downgrade to 3 stars because the ending was not very good--the book had so much passion and drama for the first 3/4's, but then it just "neatly" wraps up at the end. Annoying)

This book is dreadful. There, I've said it. The only reason I gave it two stars is because it's "clean" and "sex-free."  Can't imagine who is giving it 4 and 5 stars unless the author has a network of friends and fellow writers who are propping her up. Don't take my word for it though, let me share with you a sample of said dredge:."Dr MacClueless was at the hospital doing a post-op clinic when I arrived. I kid you not, that was his name. I wasn't too happy about a doctor with that name operating on my eye....".Yikes! I'm not sure if the author thinks she's being clever by doing a "send up" of Dr. McDreamy from Grey's Anatomy, but there's nothing clever or tongue-in-cheek about the way she develops the Dr. MacClueless "joke." Once you have to explain a joke, you know it wasn't funny. Cut your losses and move on. Then, on the very same page, she continues with this twaddle:."I grabbed a coffee from the waiting room vending machine and sipped. Yuck. It tasted like it had been sitting there for about a hundred years. (Is this really the most clever analogy she could invent? Writers have been bemoaning bad coffee in detective novels ever since the genre was invented, surely, there is something better to be written. Perhaps, "if I had scooped a cupful of the nearest mud puddle it would have tasted better,"--just sayin')..She continues: Could you get Legionnaires' disease from stagnant coffee? I didn't fancy risking it, so since the brown sludge didn't pass the Amber Fox (why is she referring to herself in the third person?) taste test, I binned it and stared at the "healthy eating" poster on the wall instead. I knew all about the advantages of eating five portions of fruit and veg (sic) a day, but I had trouble with the actual eating part.".So, you've been warned. If you can in any way embrace that kind of abysmal dialogue, have at it. The protagonist is a poor man's Stephanie Plum, the writing is awful, and the plot is inane. Pardon my criticism, but the book has nothing to redeem it. Sorry.

Half way through and I will say this is a very good book, especially for a freebie. Quick Review? "Reads like a poor man's Agatha Christie," which is still high praise indeed. The detective (Henry Grave), if not quiet a three-dimensional character, has a unique m.o. and some moxie, which is essential in a detective. The writing is fairly clever, and there is a lot of self-deprecating humor in the book, which is funny when you realize that he's not really the old fart he claims to be (a la Columbo "crazy"). The supporting characters all have a purpose and are crisply and distinctly drawn (now that I'm finished, I take this back...supporting characters are barely 2-D, and add little to the story...predictable). The plot moves forward at an appropriate pace (until the middle of the book, when it just stalls. Book really tanks after that. Let these people off the damn boat for a minute. Boat docs in several ports, but Henry stays on board first because he gets stabbed, and then to continue the "investigation." I say: "Get off the ship and go have some fun, or an adventure. 2nd half of the book is monotonous). There are enough details of the people and places to keep all of the back stories interesting and relevant. So far, I really like this book. (Obviously I changed my mind on the last two statements. Very dull second half.)

As those of you who read my reviews know, I have been very hard on Stephanie Bond. Many of her books are so predictable I could fall asleep while Kindle was reading to me, wake up twenty minutes later, and the book would be exactly where I expected it to be. However, with each story her writing seems to get better and better. When I first started listening to this--partially based on the writing and partially based on the subject matter--I thought I was reading a new series by J.E. It was THAT good! Ms. Bond now uses supporting characters to the plot's advantage, instead of as "window dressing." The dynamic between the sisters is good and believable. She actually allows the reader to stay in the dark while she's weaving the plot instead of tipping her hand as she did in her earlier novels. There are little secrets that emerge about both of the sisters' husbands near the end of the book that keep the reader guessing. It is fun and a little frothy, and could certainly make for a good series (in fact, isn't this one of Sandra Bullock's favorite comedy themes--the "girl buddy" detective: Ms. Congeniality and "The Heat")..On the other hand, there is certainly still room for improvement. Bond could spend more time describing the scenery and surroundings for various scenes, which would make the story come to life and allow the reader to feel they are "inside" the story instead of clearly just reading a book. The male (future) love interests for the grieving widow is very thinly drawn, as is the old college flame of the other sister. The clothes, meals, hotel rooms, house decor, etc., is not fleshed out at all, other than one or two adjectives: messy and chaotic or plush and heavenly. I know Ms. Bond churns out a novel or two a year, but now that she is graduating to the big leagues, she should take time to describe what the reader should be seeing in their mind's eye like the "big girls" do..Would I rec it? YesWould I reread it in a year or two? YesWould I watch the series? Only if it had top shelf actorsWould I pay for it? Up to $4.99Hope this helps.

OK, so it's been over a decade (impossible to believe) since "Bridget Jones' Diary" heralded the news that big can be beautiful. At that time, it was a fresh breeze in the romcom world, and gave us less than perfect (or more than size 2) women some hope that we too might one day find our own "Mr. Darcy," (both, with a bit of irony, played by the yummy and multi-talented Colin Firth). But alas, in this brave, new, "super-sized" world in which we now live, the "solid" woman has gone from a size 8 or so to a stolid size 16! (And at 5' 5", that's clinically obese!) It is fine for all of the ladies of "The View" and other such estrogen-fests to proclaim that women have worth regardless of their size; I'll broach no argument here. However, irrespective of whatever fantasy world this author, her protagonist, and all other size 16+ women want to live in, there are a plethora of health issues that start to kick in once the BMI > 30: diabetes, stroke, heart disease, heart attack, etc., to name a few. So the fact that the author made her "heroine" an unabashedly proud size 16 is untenable. It's also troublesome that while the heroine is free to be 180 pounds, her male lead--OMG!--has washboard abs, broad shoulders, and a tiny waist. To this I cry "foul"! What's good for the gander is good for the goose!.Sadly, we are given no real reason why this gorgeous east Indian hunk falls for Ms. Chunkster, except that "Punjabi woman are curvy," so apparently that's what he's used to. Then there is the silly plot where said hunk, who is a fashion designer, is suppose to be gay. Obviously he's not, or there would be no book, but somehow the author, instead of having fun with this ruse, actually treats it as if we are gullible enough to believe it--as if?! It might be plausible if there were other men in the book vying for chubby's attentions, but since he's the only male lead, we know he can't be gay. So the reader is left to plow through the book knowing darn well that they're going to wind up together from the moment they meet. Lastly, there is this silly sub-plot where the heroine spent a year in India, and somehow (magically?) became fluent in Hindi--a very difficult language to learn in a year for an English speaker. Then, without showing us why, we are told that Delhi, "with all its bustle, is the only place this southern born, New York transplant, has ever felt at home." Now this could be endearing if we were ever SHOWN why, but the author is too lazy to write any flashbacks or scenes of the heroine in India; no, instead all we get is the fact that she "doesn't want to speak about it because she doesn't want to act like a 'know-it-all' in front of Daniel (the male lead)--yawn." If you are going to write about an American who considers India her home, you have to provide some rationale for it all else what's the point? Exactly..The book is readable, the ending is unbelievable, but the writing is cheerful and almost clever. There are some witty similes and analogies (not Oscar Wilde, mind you, but better than average) to keep the story (which is pretty thin) moving along. Sorry..Would I pay for it? NoWould I rec it? Only to die-hard "The Devil Wears Prada" fans who are looking for anything to read set in the fashion industry.

I understand that many good stories are reworkings of other great stories. How many times has the Cinderella story been told and retold? But there has to be a reason for retelling it with new twists or a modern spin or why retell it? So it is with "Legally Wed.".First of all, it latches on to the "marry me so I don't get deported" genre, which was already done to perfection in "The Proposal." If you're going to mess with perfection, you better expect tomatoes to fly!.Second, if you're going to do a "deportation" story line, at least mention the deportation throughout the book. Nowhere in the book are there any "funny scenes" with the deportation officer where they try to pretend they know things about each other that the other than has to pretend is true by doing something inane to "prove" the other spouse's lie..Third, if you're going to write a love story, give us a plausible reason why the two characters who are "thrown" together might possibly fall in love. The whole book is a very lame love story with Mia, the female lead, a 34/29 year old (the author can't decide which) who's not worried that she's not married even though she wants to start a family b/c she's a "career woman"; then there's Max (how cute, Mia and Max) who is (you won't believe this!) "the most gorgeous man she's ever laid eyes on"--how original! He's a confirmed bachelor with a gorgeous, 10 ft. ceiling apt. overlooking the Thames; he dates super-stick, leggy, blonde, super-models, but somehow, when he finds out he must marry Mia to prevent deportation, finds himself "lusting" after her and possibly "falling" for her. We are given NO plausible explanation why, after a life of easy debauchery, he would find size 12 Mia to be his "Snow White," other than she "had curves in all the right places," and "silky smooth skin.".Fourth, there is no real plot other than them moving in together as part of the ruse, them  planning their fake wedding, and them going to work to "fool" their co-workers after the wedding. Even the wedding itself, we are told that "they wrote their own vows" because they didn't want "any of those old cliches." Yet, the lazy author can't even bother inventing these amazing vows for her characters and putting them in the book..If you are dying for a "fall in love over work" romcom, either re-watch "The Proposal," or the all time classic, "His Girl Friday" with Rosalind Russel and Cary Grant. Leave this fodder alone, or glance at the cute cover...that's the beginning and ending of everything worthwhile in this book. Sorry.

Don't be fooled friends--this brutal series is nothing more than a cheap Liftime movie glossed up for Spike TV. It is full of amoral, poorly drawn characters whom we never care about. The closest thing Book One has to "protagonists" are two scions of rival rich families who learn nothing throughout the book, and grow organically not one iota (unless you count the woman bemoaning the fact that she never wrote checks to charities to help the homeless?!) Both of them have "Daddy" issues that help them "bond." The plot is implausible (the head of one of the rival families promotes the daughter of the other rival family as president of the world's largest hotel in Manhattan even though she has no work experience so he can "get even" with her father--"you can do this. I believe in you" is the "explanation"); the characters truly are one-dimensional and interchangeable; the writing is very average--no pithy lines or clever word choices to move the story along..I have no idea why there are so many amoral characters in the book, unless its to serve as fodder for brutal killings. Even the "good girl" sister to the female scion is sleeping with a new guy on the first date after she found her fiance' cheating on her: no grief, no anger, no "man hating phase," just "let's get back in the saddle"--total male fantasy, and unrealistic. The only char of any interest is the middle age lawyer who's a good family man and friend by day, and a kinky S&M freak by night; clearly, he's a tortured soul but we are never allowed to understand his motivations, except for a brief Psy 101 blurb before he kills himself by jumping in front of a speeding subway (Anna Karenina anyone?) and we are told that "judgmental society did this to him." Yawn. Imagine all of the shallowest char from any soap opera all stuffed together in one book, and you pretty much have 5th Ave. It's Dallas without Bobby or Ms. Ellie; it's the Kardashians without Rob or Bruce; it's the evil step-sisters with no Cinderella..Would I rec it? Only to NY's who might enjoy the "ambiance."Would I buy it? NO WAY!Would I reread it? No

The beautiful Jesus of "The Bible" series makes it worth watching, just as the real Jesus of the Bible makes it worth reading. What would the Bible be without Him? Yes, there are some wonderful accounts, parables, and verses in the OT, but would they still resonate as strongly as they do with us if it weren't for Christ coming and fulfilling those prophecies and leading an amazing, unimpeachable life? Of course, that's a topic for another discussion, but when we think of the importance of Jesus in history and spirituality, it's interesting to ponder what the world would be like if He had never made an appearance, or if we as a species had been allowed to develop further before He was sent to Earth. I often marvel at atheists who are so sure we should remove God and Christ from society and our belief systems, as if they know, a priori, that this would make the world a better place. How about we take them up on their offer and remove Christ from society, as a thought experiment, but at some date in the past. Should we remove Him before Handel wrote "The Messiah", or before DaVinci painted "The Last Supper," or Michelangelo "The Sistine Chapel"? Who knows how much their beliefs helped mold them as artists--perhaps if there were no Christ, there would be no DaVinci? It's absurd to think that all of the good things in society (art, literature, music) in the Western world would have developed without the West's single most overarching theme (Christianity), but I diverge..My point is that Christ is the highlight of the Bible just as Morgado is the pinnacle of "The Bible" series. (Plz don't think I'm being sacrilegious, b/c that is far from my meaning. It's just that Christ had to be cast perfectly, and they have done that here.) His love and compassion shines thru in every frame, and adds a tender dimension to Christ that isn't often shown on film. The series isn't perfect, but once it gets to the NT and starts telling the life of Jesus, with Diogo at the helm, it improves considerably. In fact, if they would edit the 10-hours down to 5, and sell just "The Christ" portion, I would buy it and we would watch it in our home every Easter. That portion of "The Bible" is truly a classic.

This book tries so hard to be "literature," but it just doesn't make the cut. Firstly, the heroine, Danielle, is just never fully developed as a three-dimensional character. She's suppose to be an artist and a "fabricant de parfum" as they might say in French, but we're never really taken to her inner place where an artist lives. The author rather drolly spells out that she would use "jasmine, rose, and sandalwood" for instance, for this or that effect. We are never treated to the moment of inspiration where D. comes across a scent while walking in the woods after the rain and catching just that first sniff of honeysuckle, or a budding rose, or breaking an herb or crushing a flower to release just the right smell at the right time and this, ah yes, this particular transient odor is the one she will capture--this one, and only this one, will do. Instead, the author acts as if all jasmine or rose or sandalwood smells exactly the same which is to miss the point of how a great "nose" captures just the right essence at a precise moment in time and bottles it. It's no different than knowing when a wine or cognac is ready to drink. So, the protagonist, who is in every scene of the book, is never fully fleshed out as an artist..Secondly, she's never developed as a mother. She's parted from her son at the very beginning of the book b/c of WW2, and his memory is 'sprinkled' thru the book, but never in an organic way, that shows the pathos and anguish and haunting loneliness and longing of a real mother who had lost a child and was never quite sure if he were dead. Instead, the author writes silly little sentences about D. seeing a child who looks like her son and feeling a "sudden pang of longing." It's all so superficial and unrealistic--where is the agony that she would undoubtedly feel about the loss of her 3 or 4 year old child? Who could bear it? Yet, it is almost never mentioned in the book, as D. is too busy raising her other two girls (who themselves are rarely mentioned, although they live with their mother), and moving to America to get far away from the German threat, and building her perfume business in America, and sorting out her love life. It's very superficial, and I'm not even sure why she's portrayed as a mother, except that the children are used as a plot device near the end of the book..If you can overlook the unfinished threads and gaping holes, the book is a decent story that shows how one woman came to America, rebuilt her life, and found true love after losing her first husband in the war, and making several poor choices after that as she struggles to survive. But to call it an historical novel is like calling "Real Housewives of Beverly Hills" an "in depth look at 21st century, upper crust America." The amount of "history" in the book is equivalent to what any of us (of a certain age anyway) would remember from junior high and high school (Nazis bad, Allies good). I would suggest that the author leverage some beta-readers who could help her find her missing pieces, and pull the stories together for a satisfying read, instead of a choppy one. Lot's of unfulfilled potential here..Would I rec it? Possibly, to the right readerWould I buy it? NoWould I reread it? No

When I first started reading this book, I though maybe the protagonist was supposed to have a learning disorder. The story was so disjointed and the grammar so hard to follow, that for a long stretch of the book I couldn't tell if the author was illiterate, or if she was trying to create a very special protagonist. By the time I finished the tome, I had decided it was a little bit of both, even if unintentional. The protagonist literally seems part Cher Horowitz, part Holden Caulfield. The strange language and bizarre interpretations of people's actions made me think that Kayla was going to be some kind of brilliant anti-heroine. The author leaves lots of lose threads throughout the book, interesting supporting characters (at least one), and as the book approaches the ending, it could still go in a dozen different directions. But then, sadly, she wraps up everything in a neat little fairy-tell ending. Huh? Imagine if Holden Caulfield finally met up with Jane, had sex, improved in school, and they went off to college together--what a totally unsatisfying "feel good" ending. Well, yeah, that's what happens in this book. For the first 300 pages the author captures this quirky, struggling, skewed heroine, only to turn her into a Hallmark character for the last 50 pages. Weird..Buy it? MaybeRec it? To the right readerRe-read it? Only if the ending changed

Katie and Scott are the ho-hum "protagonists" of this easily forgettable book. Katie, although beautiful, leads a very dull life. Uh-huh? Scott, despite being "the most beautiful man she had ever seen" (yawn...aren't they all anymore?) is single at 26 and looking for Ms. Right. The "cute meet" starts with him racing his truck/SUV passed her on a snowy road and drives her into a ditch. She later meets him somewhere and then recognizes the car, gets all "huffy," and that's suppose to be the spark/tension that makes Scott realize "this one's different than all the other girls." Bored yet? Exactly. The book is about as interesting as watching grass grow and horribly predictable. The only other thing that happens in the first half of the book is the two of them go on a sleigh-ride date (awwwww) and then Scottie taking her into the woods to cut down a "real xmas tree." (awwwww) Somehow, while setting up the tree everything gets hot and heavy and they have 30 pages of pornographic sex under the (blushing?) tree. Then an evil woman at work tries to break them up, and it works for about 30 pages, until Katie's BFF (who only appears to move the plot forward, and has no other purpose in the book nor dimensionality) tells her what the *itch did, and everything is resolved in short, predictable, (painfully obvious) order. This book is awful, except for the sex scenes if you like X-rated, which I don't. It can be read in 30 minutes by skimming one page, skipping three, skimming one, skipping three. You'll miss nada that you couldn't fill in yourself. Terrible.Rec it? Now wayBuy it? NeverReread it? Not if I were stranded on an island and this were the only book available.Sorry.

Hired by the Cowboy? More like "Written By a Formula." I cannot imagine how this book received an average of 4.5 starts from hundreds of readers; that's clearly too many to be in the author's circle of friends, so it can only be that women (of a certain age and fertility status) are suspending all possible belief to enjoy this book. Yes, there is a "cute meet"--Alexis (the female lead) literally 'falls at the feet of' Connor, the handsome cowboy. They both have no family, for various reasons, as is 'revealed' throughout the story, although it's pretty obvious from the start that neither of them has parents or siblings b/c she's a little waif on the lam, and the only person he has to introduce her to is his 'grannie.'.(Plot) The plot of him falling in love with her even though she's pregnant is laughable, and given no credulous reason for existing except for her 'glow' that he finds 'mesmerizing.' Really? Perhaps if his mother had been pregnant when she was killed in a car accident, there might be some Freudian issues that would make the plot plausible. Or if he had a 'handicap' himself, even a limp from a hunting accident. No, he has to be 'drop dead gorgeous, the most handsome man she has ever laid eyes on.'.(Reality Check) I have actually known a few pregnant women who started dating a man other than the baby's daddy; however, these 'fill in' men have always been 'fuddily,' and are leveraging their 'Mr. Nice Guy' persona by being in the 'right place at the right time.' I've even known some of these relationships to work, where the beautiful woman marries the 'plain, nice guy' and is genuinely happy to have a husband and dad. They might add a second child to the family and live happily ever after. However, NEVER in the handful of relationships that I've seen in real life did I ever see 'Mr. Drop Dead Gorgeous' ride in on his white horse and whisk the pregnant-by-another-man woman down the alter. So, the plot is far-fetched, the writing is very ordinary (no witty, pithy phrasing, metaphors, etc.), and the protagonists are kind of dull. But hey, I must be wrong, b/c everyone else seems to like it?

Secrets of 'Bethlehem' is a great title; I'll give it to the marketing department--it caught me attention. But the story has so little light or hope like other great stories that have come out of the other Beth-le-hem (Israel) that I'm not sure why they tried to be 'clever' by giving the book this title. The eponymous Bethlehem here is in Pennsylvania, and is a broken-down, old coal/steel mill town, that seems to churn out people who are as hard and cold as the product it used to make. The story is relentlessly icy and alienating. I guess if you 'hang in there' you will get some small reward but it was just to dark for my tastes. Sorry.

This tonic is terrific. I could NOT believe how well it worked, especially for a "feel good, all natural, go green" product. I thought it would probably be 'politically correct,' but would lack any real killing power. Wow, was I wrong. It has been said that all drugs are just natural remedies that have been purified, and to some extent, I'm sure that's true. So when you can go straight to the source, why bother with the man-made alternative?This product is nature's finest: it's a simple blend of peppermint oil, clove extract, and sodium laurel sulfate (a soap found in most shampoos). I rubbed it into my dog's hair and skin with a cotton ball (I did not spray it b/c I didn't want the fumes). Maybe working it into her skin really made the difference, I'm not sure since I never tried otherwise. I left it on her about 20 minutes, at which point she was sitting at me feet with her head cocked to one side and a "what did you just do to me" expression on her face. The smell is wonderful, but I could imagine it was over-powering for her, so I decided to rinse her off (even though the directions say nothing about rinsing). Since she's a little Yorkie (oh, yeah, super cutie), I decided to shower her in the upstairs tub that has a detachable shower-head so I could really put a lot of water pressure on the little suckers. I don't know if they were dead, in shock, or just too fumigated to hold on tight, but they rinsed right off and down the drain. She has a short 'puppy cut,' and I worked my fingers into her skin to dislodge any fleas that might still have a strangle hold. All totaled I rinsed about 15 of them down the drain with a scalding hot chaser. Sorry, I give to PETA but fried fleas are NOT animal cruelty :)She has been one happy puppy ever since, and is scratching just a few times a day, instead of every few minutes. I will repeat the treatment next week as well, just to finish them off, but all in all WE are D-E-L-I-G-H-T-E-D with the results. And for the price, and the environmental friendliness, you can't go wrong with this product!

I keep hoping to find a good murder mystery voice out there somewhere. Can it really be that hard to update and pay homage to Raymond Chandler? When you're reading his books, it seems that they are good, but that others somewhere could pick up where he left off and give us more riveting murder mysteries in his style. Apparently, I'm wrong; it's harder than it looks b/c no one seems to be doing it, especially this author..Plot is OK, and at least there are a few gentle, sloping twists and turns, although there are no "blow your socks off, I wasn't expecting that" ones--not by a long shot. However, the most annoying thing about the book is that the protagonist, a 45 y.o. former cop and detective turned writer, doesn't know exactly who he is. One page he's Bogey in "Key Largo," the next he's Adam Sandler in "Just Go With It"--I kid you not. There's a few pages half way thru the book where the prog explains "guy hugging" protocol. It's suppose to be funny and clever, but it's not, and its something I could NEVER imagine Sam Spade saying in any incarnation. Secondly, the prog speaking in the first person throughout the book is just lazy writing--it takes away all the 'suspense' to know what he's thinking and feeling at every moment, with very few 'false leads' scattered in along the way to make us think. Lastly, there's the ending--where both the hottest chicks in the book (one in her mid 20's the other in her late 30's) can't live without bopping the prog--which is just the author's male-fantasy wet dream. Unnecessary, and unbelievable. To make matters worse, they both want an 'open, modern' relationship with no strings attached. A book where there is no emotional attachment or commitment by anybody is just, in the final analysis, uninteresting. If they don't really care what happens to each other and they're just 'using' each other for sexual satisfaction, then why should we care what happens to them. Bogey NEVER played a role where he got TWO women at the end, unless it was to send one of them down the river, which would have been a much more satisfying ending.

OK, serves me right for not waiting for other people to review the book before I jumped in and started reading it. And it doesn't help that the cover looks like a good romcom movie with a red-haired Katherine Heigl and maybe John Cusack?.Sierra is a feisty (but predictable) matchmaker who lives in a small town, a few hours from LA. Marc is a big city corporate raider (a la Richard Gere in Pretty Woman?). He comes to Sierra's small town (cutely name "Love"), and slowly falls for Sierra over playful banter and many, many pages where they "moon" over each other. There's a decent sub-plot that has Marc's mom remarrying after divorcing his awful/misogynistic father. There are some "colorful" characters, such as "Flo," who acts suspiciously like a certain t.v. Flo, even though the former is suppose to be an Aussie. Same wisecracking, dime store perfume, know-it-all..75% of the book is frothy and runs smoothly along; it's not Dostoevsky, but it's competent. Sadly, the last 25% is mindbogglingly poor--predictable, trite, obvious, unbelievable. Marc goes back to L.A., and of course he can't sleep, can't eat, can't work, can't do anything but think of Sierra--really? He winds up back in Love for his mother's wedding, and what do you know, asks Sierra to take six months off and travel the world with him. Then he wants them to move in together when they get back, and if that works out, maybe down the aisle together. Really? I don't know of any man who would ask to "maybe" move in six months from now. Wouldn't that be something he would ask when they were say, sipping cappuccinos in Venice, or a Beaujolais on the Cte d'Azur? I was half expecting her to buy a lottery ticket on the way to the airport and win 100 mil or so, and then maybe as she was having one of her "nutty" intuitions, stumble on a cancer cure. The ending is that bad!

Really terrific read that makes you rethink what it means to be a follower/fan of Christ--the person, the enigma, the prophet, the freak! He was radical, and he wants nothing less than that from his fans. It's definitely now a "feel good," "God loves you," blah-blah tome. But don't we get enough of that from "spiritual" people who believe in G/god (I'm not even sure which one they call him now)? Fans of Jesus need to be intense, the way Packers fans are intense (not like Heat fans :).Lots of good stories/antidotes to keep it moving, and good references/re-interpretations about the Gospels. For example, every Christian knows the account of the fish and bread feeding a multitude. But author makes us rethink that by saying, "but guess what, most of those people hung around Jesus overnight, hoping to get breakfast the next day too. Christ said, 'Sorry, the buffet is over. I am the living bread. Everyone who hears my words and believes will never hunger or thirst again.'" Deep. Author points out that Christ didn't feed them a second time, but let many get confused and walk away. If you can't hang! Very intense and though-provoking. Yeah, few real Christ followers out there, right? How many would really 'pick up a cross and follow him.' You dig?

Full disclosure: I have to admit that for me, the Apostle Paul has always been very difficult to understand. Respect, appreciate, enjoy? Yes, but would I want to "hang out" with him? Probably not. He's almost the "bad cop" to Jesus' "good one." (No disrespect here, just as analogy). It is very difficult for anyone to find fault with Jesus' amazing life: his enlightening parables; his love of the sick, poor, and children; his grace, grace, dignity, passion, passion, fortitude, and love are legend. (Hope you get the double entendres). But Paul expands and clarifies the fledgling philosophy, and is fierce in his evangelism for "The Way." He always seemed to me part elitist, part spiritual warrior, and part unreachable scholar--very inaccessible. This book helped me understand the man behind the Epistles, which gave me a lot more empathy for Paul's rabid determination. Learning what life was like in Tarsus, how he was raised, what were standard living styles of Pharisees, really were eye-opening. I do agree with other reviewers that the author over-stepped a bit, and it's important to clearly separate the speculative from the factual when dealing with subject matter this important; yet, all-in-all the book is well-researched, extremely well-written (flows like a good novel), and does add to the dialogue about this quintessential disciple of Christ.

I am a fan of Horton's second book, "Reaching for the Stars." Just a quick note to all that this is definitely the "starter version."
