Why would anybody do that when you don't have to??!So, first let me tell you that the material is nice - light weight and easily wiped clean. The hardware is substantial and feels good in your hand - not flimsy and cheap. The zippers move nicely; and the shoulder strap is nice and thick to wear comfortably and not dig into your shoulders.The outside appearance appears 'small' to some. My hairdresser commented that she wouldn't be able to fit "anything" in that tiny purse but yet here's what I have in mine:1) In the front zipper, I have only my lip balm - though there's room for much more2) In the first zippered compartment, I have a 3 1/2" x 3 1/2" square compact mirror, business cards, an ID holder that carries two cards; coins in the zipper pouch, some dental floss (yeah, I know) and in the internal zipper, I have a travel sized thing for Advil/Aleve, and a pair of tweezers. The zipper zips completely all the way around to open up all the way.3) In the first large zippered section, I have a full size wallet with pictures; a pen in the pen loop and there is room for more as there is both a pocket and another internal zippered section. The zipper goes all the way to the bottom on one side so that once again, you have full view and accessibility to your items. Never is your hand being squished when you reach for anything.4) In the middle section that is open, I have my cell phone, my big key ring with plenty of keys on it; my work badge; and a 6" slim flashlight. That section is magnetized but even without it, the design as you wear it, seems to keep that area closed, so I don't worry about anything flying out of it. This was the one thing I loved about my favorite Travelon bag. I like to be able to have one section of my purse that is open or has a flap so I can easily grab keys, phone, or flashlight without having to unzip anything. This is perfect.5) In the last main zippered compartment, I have TWO eyeglasses cases - and they are full sized, AND they are the hard cases! I also have my pocket calendar/planner/phone book, and another pen.6) The very last area of the purse is an open, magnetized pocket, and I have dummy bank deposits and blank envelopes; store receipts and a shopping list.My purse doesn't look stuffed, and in fact, still looks flat; and you would never guess I have all that in it! But I wanted to show you how much it carries and that's largely due to the great design of this bag with it's all around zippering, light material, and open center. I am truly amazed and thrilled to see that essentially, my ol' favorite bag has been reincarnated in this Criss Cross Baggalini.Oh, be sure to check the prices on this style regularly as they change all the time. The price depends on the color you choose and there are plenty of colors to choose from! They all look great. The dimensions are posted, so I don't know how anyone can misinterpret the size. I think you will be surprised with this bag and love it more than you thought.

I thought this was very well written and organized in a way that flows as to how someone would approach their learning.I stay pretty well informed on health topics, so it wasn't that I was expecting to learn anything new but mostly wanted to see what Ann Malkmus had to say about it, being 'who' she is and appreciating all that she and her family does. I was excited to get her perspective and input.The surprise was that she mentioned some things I did not know; had not ever read before and I was very intrigued with that and it made perfect sense.This is a sensible approach that anyone can benefit from. Being informed is the key first and foremost in order to make changes and decisions. This book makes it easy to not become overwhelmed but rather to understand what's going IN you from what's AROUND you, so that you can make changes yourself that are easier and simpler than you might think.They say 80% of all cancer comes from the foods we eat - and is preventable - while the remaining percent is primarily environmental (some of which we still can prevent!).Ann Malkmus did a great job compiling the information in a coffee-table approach - making it an easy family topic of discussion to get on the road to positive change.

My hairdresser works out of her home and she swears by these FitFlops, as so many others do. She loves them and highly recommends them saying if it weren't for them, she could never stay on her feet for 12 hours a day, and she's getting close to 70, though you'd never guess..I've been on Amazon - and a reviewer - since the mid-90's. When I'm interested in something, I will read every single review and every single comment. I IMMERSE myself in what others have to say about something. So, I think it's safe to say that I get a good feel for what people like/don't like about something.I needed some flip-flops anyway and thought they'd make a good pre-birthday gift to myself and so I began reading all the reviews; checked out all the styles, etc, and couldn't wait to choose one and try them for myself. I mean the reviews are so glowing - ladies buying several different styles and different colors each in every style!You have people saying they do 5-K walks in them; prefer to wear them HIKING; climb over rocks; doing their workouts in them; and hating to take them off!Unfortunately..I'm not having any of those exclamations and I'm really bummed as to why not (??). Did I choose the wrong style? I normally wear a size 7.5 shoe and ordered these in a size 7 and the fit is perfect. Is it my feet?! My feet are neither wide nor narrow - they are a true medium. They are not UN-comfortable. Even the toe-piece is not rough or uncomfortable. But, they are not rocking the house down - OMG - they are amazingly wonderful - don't want to take them off - want to do my 5K walks in them, either!For one, they don't stay on my feet. I'm consciously aware of them the entire time they are on my feet. My feet have slipped out of them numerous times, so I'm aware of needing to grip them so they stay on. I think a better way to give visualization is, for example, when we ladies wear nylons with our shoes and we feel too much movement and slippage between our feet and the shoe - do you know what I mean?I wanted so much to love them - to really, really enjoy them! And especially those who mentioned they can WALK for hours in them, better than any walking shoe or running shoe - so much so that they prefer them for their 5K walks! But, after two weeks of wearing these, I can't say I want to wear them around the BLOCK! :(As for the '"FIT benefits" - I also feel nothing. Nothing in my calves, thighs, buns. Zip.So far, they have been a costly;  pretty; and reasonably comfortable flip-flop..and nothing more.

I ordered this for my grandson and had drop-shipped the order. I clicked the "gift" section and typed the "gift message". This is a MEN'S shirt, and as he's only 11 years old and not even 5', I ordered the size Small.My son-in-.law said there is "no way" that what they received was a MENS shirt. It looked like a young child's shirt. Needless to say, it was way too small.On top of that, they received no paperwork with it; no gift message - nothing whatsoever.Now they have to send it back..

Yes, I enjoy WRITING reviews, but what I really enjoy best is reading YOURS. I get so much out of the reviews and also the comments and it's all of your reviews that really save the day for me.For example, I wanted a travel bag but just wasn't satisfied with my search. Then I stumbled upon a comment and it made me realize that I hadn't thought "outside the box" and done a search on tote bags! But it was one review in particular that compared the expensive and heavy (travel) tote bags to the link for this bag that really sold me.I absolutely LOVE this bag! I used it as my carry-on bag on the plane. I had my cell phone in the little "secret" pocket; and my boarding pass and other papers in the front zippered pocket (which later I was able to fit a light sweater in). I also put a purse organizer (bought on Amazon also) inside to fit prescriptions, supplements; lip balm, Aleve, mirror, etc so as not to drop into a black hole. I also had pens and flashlight within easy grasp inside the organizer. In the pockets that are built into the tote bag, I had my camera; glasses; sunglasses; and two Kindles.I love the water bottle holder (I brought the Rubbermaid Chug bottles with me - also bought on Amazon and LOVE them!) on the side of the bag. There is so much room in this bag! And yet, it wasn't huge or silly looking when carried over the shoulder; and it fit comfortably. It also slid very well under the seat on the airplane.I had a regular sized wallet when using the whole bag - so that it was easy to grab when I opened the bag - but when I wanted to leave the bag at my sister's house, or in the trunk of the car, I just took a "satellite" purse with me. My satellite purse is just basically a wristlet that comes with a detachable cross-body shoulder strap and simply holds your cellphone, cards, and change but I can fit a lip balm in there, too and yet it's the size of your phone. It was perfect for taking walks on the beach or for day/night fun.I picked the Cosmic Girl print because I didn't want it to look like a computer bag (though it will be used for that, too); I didn't want it to look like a beach bag (though I did use it for that!); and I didn't want it to look like all my other purses or bags (a solid black or brown) - so the pattern worked really well for me.It absolutely solved all my anxiety of which bag to take and freed me up of lugging a purse and a carry-on, and having to transfer anything back and forth.The only "negative" comments I have are this: In my opinion, they should automatically make EVERY type of tote bag with a shoulder strap option (cross body preferred)! It's ridiculous not to! I don't care whether it is detachable or even as an additional purchase, but these days it is so much easier to wear things cross body and is also better on your back, neck and shoulders.The other comment I have is that although the water bottle section was big enough for two of my Chug bottles, I would've preferred to have a pocket on each end of the bag rather than only one end. It just made the bag heavy on one side and awkward, so if they did that it would distribute the weight. Small 'complaint', but I thought I would mention it.I will get so much use out of this bag, and know you will, too.

One day about ten years ago, it seemed I woke up and could no longer wear shoes - it seemed just like that. So, for the last ten years, it has been a real struggle to find shoes that are comfortable whatsover. I became desperate enough to not even care anymore what they look like.It's a sad day when that happens because if a woman can't wear shoes, then she can't wear clothes.So, for the last ten years, I wore fewer and fewer skirts or dresses. It really does change how you feel about yourself when you can no longer wear pretty; sexy; or flirty clothes and something as "simple" as shoes can really change a person's life.Then, I needed to absolutely find a pair of shoes for my daughter's wedding and I panicked. I didn't want to even GO because I would have no shoes to wear, and of course, then what clothes would I wear?! I felt sick and trapped that my own feet held me hostage!One day, I was watching a QVC episode online, and they were showing this shoe! The reviews were amazing! I went to Amazon.com and again, the reviews were the same! So, I ordered the shoes in the nude color and hoped for the best.I couldn't believe that right out of the box I could put these shoes on and walk all over the house! I was thrilled! But, I wondered - could they stand up to a wedding - on my feet for hours; and some dancing?These shoes not only stood up, but my feet never tired and I was able to wear a full length gown and feel like the pretty, feminine and sexy lady could finally be set free! I haven't felt that good in a long time and I thank you, thank you Clarks for making them and giving "me" back myself.*******Here's a side note: I had to travel to the wedding and checked two bags at the airport coming back home. I had 4 pair of shoes in the second bag, along with all my electronic chargers for everything. Two of the pairs were brand new and were this pair and another Clarks that I will do a review on also. When the airlines lost that bag, I was just sick. But, the good news is that I got the bag back today!! All is well. :)

I have long eyelashes, partly due to an eye medication, and partly due to the way I care for my eyelashes (which I've been wanting to write an e-book about).Anyway, I get compliments alot - "..are your eyelashes real?" is what someone asked me last night. Yes, they are. Funny how no one asks me what mascara I use, which is this one and the Max Factor 2000 Calorie.Goes on smoothly, doesn't clump for me, keeps them separated, and nice and long, and most importantly, doesn't seem to irritate my eyes.

I saw a video of the QVC show where this shoe was introduced as well as read the glowing reviews. It is such a hot, sexy, classy, cool-looking shoe and I can ONLY wear Clarks - so I was hopeful.Sadly, it barely made it ON the foot and it was a resounding NO, for me. My left foot has a small bunion - even though very small, and hardly noticeable to some, if a shoe rests on it, it is so painful, it stops me in my tracks. The design of this shoe not only touched it, it pressed right on it. Extreme discomfort right from the start.If you watch the video on QVC, and you read the reviews - perhaps this is a shoe that will work for you. It has such promise, and I know would look awesome with  slacks, skirts and even jeans.I can't tell you how sad I was that this didn't work for me, but I know it's not the shoe - it's MY foot. :(*************Stay tuned. In a few weeks, I will be reviewing two pair of Clarks shoes.***

I have always secretly lusted after this juicer, but had already purchased another juicer. Still, in the back of my mind, I knew someday I would get this juicer.There was one review in particular that had 'sold' me back then, and I exchanged comments back and forth with that reviewer a number of times over the few years, and he was always so very helpful. Darn, I wish I could find it.Anyway..there was also another review that was hilarious, and it was his "journey" of juicing that I wanted to compare with on my review here today, but I cannot find that one either. Ah well, whenever I do, I will modify this one.There's not a lot I can contribute here that hasn't been said already.I'm an experienced juicer and by that I mean that I not only have had a number of juicers, but I sometimes had them simultaneously - LOL! I've also been juicing for about 19 years, which is how long I've had my VitaMix and back then, it was my primary "juicer" - whether blending "whole juice"; or straining into a bowl and having "strained juice"; which nowdays, we don't refer to the former as juice at all, but a blended drink.Anyway, I digress..I've had both types of juicers - the centrifugal and the masticating - as well as a number of different brands/models of each one, and I'm back to the masticating, and gladly! Yes, there's more chopping involved, but it's been no big deal at all for me, and if it is, I can do beforehand and store in the fridge until ready.The cleanup is so delightful, I practically giggle  - but the JUICE! It's far better!I love the carry handle. I have to actually lift it and move it to a different area whenever I juice, and it's so easy to do. I love the design and how smooth and high quality it is. And you can't beat that 15 year warranty!Although this is one time that I did NOT purchase through Amazon; as I work retail on the weekends and purchased there using my discount. When working there I recommend this model all the time.I have not used the other features but when I do, I will be sure to comment on them. I'm anxious to make almond butter!It's so wonderfully quiet to operate and takes everything I've thrown at it so far.Be sure to understand what you should and shouldn't juice with juicers. I've read some reviews that comment about fruits. The saying goes "..EAT your fruits; JUICE your vegetables" and that is primarily true. So, to the reviewers who are looking to juice things like blueberries or raspberries, this is NOT how to go about it, and your quickest best route for things like that would be to blend (straining, optional). No, these types of juicers use fruit to augment the stronger flavors of vegetables and greens - using harder fruits such as apples; and ones that juice well, such as citrus, and pineapples.I don't regret my juicing journey or feel that I didn't like the other juicers I had, or that it has been a frustration or disappointment  with the "types" and styles of juicing. Not only do you somewhat have to have the experience in order to truly know what will suit you best; but also your needs change! Just like anything else in Life, right?For me, I can safely say that this is where I want to stay - with the Omega 8004 and my trusty Vitamix - I need nothing else. :)

Easy; inexpensive; works; lasts all day and night; color matches perfectly for me; lasts for-ev-er. What's not to like? Avon does a few products 'just right' and that's why I stick with those items.Thanks, Amazon, for carrying them.

Foolish and dumb as this may sound, I'd forgotten what impact caffeine has on various health issues - primarily raising my ocular pressure - and that can be serious for those with Glaucoma and other medical eye issues.New job; new pressures; stress; longer hours; inclement weather, and I was brewing more coffee and having more refills; taking bigger travel mugs and not thinking about it. I was using a higher quality of coffee and had read many articles about how organic; higher quality, etc really has more to do with how coffee affects/doesn't affect someone than the actual caffeine component, so I felt I was "okay" with drinking more of it. Wrong (at least for me).I had forgotten how I used to mix my coffee half and half with Teeccino and that cut down the caffeine. Teeccino's a great product, but it is not very cost effective for me, and I prefer something without the gluten.In the past, I tried the packets of Dandy Blend and it was ok. They quickly hardened and dried out so I threw away the unused packets.I had received some very bad news from my Ophthalmologist, so back to the drawing board and saw this 2# bag of Dandy Blend, with outstanding reviews and comments and thought I'd give it a go again. After all, it's a MUST!Not only is it gluten-free (and they explain on their site 'how' that is); but dandelions are great for the liver which is very closely related to eye issues - they go hand in hand. (I already take Milk Thistle every day for my liver, so this will be an added bonus!)Then I asked all of you a few questions on the Q/A area (great feature, and big help!). I wanted to be able to brew Dandy Blend along with a scoop of regular coffee grounds (as I did with Teeccino) and you all told me how I could. Score!So, right now I'm enjoying a delicious cup - or two, or three - of mixed brew and eventually will cut out the coffee altogether.I was too chicken to put the DB in the brew basket, so I used my normal amount of water for the pot; only put in one scoop of coffee, instead of two, and then when it was finished brewing, I added one rounded tablespoon to the pot and stirred it in.FABULOUS!The recipes and ideas on both the bag and the website are great - I would have never thought of doing that. Now I look forward to trying it. I'm getting ready to do some traveling, so will bring some with me.Folks - we can monitor our BLOOD pressure at home (which I occasionally do); but we cannot monitor our own ocular pressure. Hopefully, one day, it will be possible to do. Fortunately for me, I HAVE to go regularly to keep a close watch on it; but I was without insurance and took my chances and it was almost disastrous. Please be sure to get your eyes checked regularly, especially to check your pressures. It's still the leading cause of blindness.*****One week later****I only mixed with coffee for one week. I ended up loving it so much, I prefer it ALONE! It's delicious! And what's really awesome - no headaches; no fatigue; no withdrawals whatsoever being without coffee! AWESOME!

I'm sure that you, like me, have dozens of various shapes and sized water bottles filling up your cupboards and even at work. I have stainless ones, glass ones, ones with sleeves, ones with carrying straps; sippys, Nalgenes; wide mouth; exchangeable lids, and so on and so on.Then one day, I don't even remember what I was doing or looking at on Amazon, but I came across these. I would've blown over them but I noticed the reviews and had to stop and read.Well, I had been looking for just the right bottle to fit in the water bottle slot of my purse and various other bags; plus one that would almost replicate a store-bought bottle of water in size and feel; and one that would fit in my car holder.This one does it all!I love how easily I can slip it in on the side of my purse without struggle, yet it is secure; I love how lightweight it is; I love how there is no taste to it, and how easily they clean! I love the PRICE - and that you get TWO! I love that they have an option to buy EIGHT for families, or for those who are good 'planners' and freeze some to have later.I love that I have dropped them and nothing happened.I love that they snap closed tightly and when closed properly do not leak no matter how they are tossed around in my bag.And I love them so much I am taking them on the plane with me (empty of course) because I won't be without them.I would've never guessed that I would enjoy a water bottle so much so I guess another winning surprise!

It came quickly; it fits; the price was right and I love the color - woohoo!The only thing is, that material doesn't slide well when you put the phone in the pocket, but I figured as much already. But it sure makes gripping the phone a whole lot easier.

I have been wanting these forever. Finally, with the Holidays coming, I decided to splurge and get them, especially since it came as a two-pack.The reviews were awesome, and so is the price so I couldn't wait to get them and use them.Primarily what I wanted to use them for was for roasting vegetables. I used to use foil on a cookie sheet, drizzle olive oil and seasonings over them and roast them, but so many stuck to the foil that it was a waste of expensive organic produce plus I didn't want the aluminum from the foil getting in my food.I thought the silicone baking mats would be perfect and like the idea of using a reusable product rather than disposables. I could easily store them, and it would be so easy.Instead, I had such dreadful experiences with it, that I just gave up and tossed the one right into the trash!First of all, it would not wash clean. The oil, no matter what I washed it with, just seemed to "grow" worse and it was a huge mess trying to get it clean. It stained after one use, and it burned and burned right into the mat and it was worse trying to get the blackened bits out of the mat more than it ever was trying to clean a dirty pot! I got these to save me time and energy and cleanup - not create even more! Since I can't put them in the dishwasher, I had to clean by hand and they weren't cleaning! Even a de-greaser didn't get it done.Maybe they are fine for biscuits or cookies, and that's wonderful for all who have used it and loved it.As for me, this is the worst purchase I've made. Oh well, after all these years, I'm bound to have one flop.

To begin with, I think stevia tastes awful no matter how you mask it. I grow it outside and have picked the leaves off and chewed them just to see if maybe the 'freshest possible' might make a difference. It doesn't. Stevia is just bitter and nasty and leaves an aftertaste.There are a couple of brands that get all the accolades and all the advertising and this is one of them. Since most food things are a personal preference, one can not argue that it 'is' or 'isn't' tasty and good as you either like it or you don't.All I can say is I haven't necessarily found a stevia that doesn't taste like stevia - LOL! But, I have found an item that I DO like better than this one - is twice the amount in ounces and costs less, and with less of an aftertaste, but still has an aftertaste. I did not get it from Amazon, however (how rare!).There are better ones out there, and that give you more, for less money. Keep shopping.

Minus one point for the mesh zipper pocket inside the bag. The mesh does make it nice to be able to see what's inside the pocket and I agree that that can be nice, hoowever, it gets in the way constantly when you are pulling something out  either by coming out with it, or by pulling up. Also, the mesh material rubs my hand very roughly and it hurts! So, improving that part of the purse in the material and in keeping it better in place would be great.Everything else is really nice. I love having the open pocket in front - perfect for things I don't want to have to constantly zip and unzip but just grab such as my work badge and keys.The back zipper is big enough to hold my Kindle 3 or a paperback.I don't buy bottled water (bring your own and save on landfill debris!) but I have a container that fits in the water bottle holder and am happy about that because I avoid bottled water at all cost.I'm a true, diehard Travelon fan and all my bags are Travelon. This is another one to add to my collection that will be used until it's worn out.

Not much really to say about this. I wanted something I could have coins in  but not have to lay down on a surface to open and get them out; and to be able to do with one hand. I wanted something that might securely hold other things as well since other reviewers mentioned earphones, etc, and sometimes I am digging for safety pins or something small and this holds it securely.I wanted something I could grab and put in a pocket if I wanted to, in order to just dash out of the house without a purse. It has a key ring attached to the inside, so a perfect place for a spare key.I think it would be great to give to your house sitter/neighbor/dog sitter to have the house key, plus inside the pocket could be a list of phone numbers or feeding instructions, etc.I just got it so I don't have any issues with the hinges. It opens very easily, unlike what one reviewer said that it was very difficult and you needed to be strong. Not mine, at all. I would've preferred better quality, sure, but I guess that's what you get for about eight bucks. It isn't terrible quality, no, but it's not a $30 item, either.I'm very sensitive to smells and this is really stinking up my purse. I do expect that to go away however. Hopefully. Soon. :)All in all, I think it's a darn handy thing to have and at some point, I'll probably buy another one.

I love this stuff. So far I only use it when I brush my teeth and it's just marvelous. They glisten and gleem and feel so clean; and of course your breath is the freshest it can be.Haven't tried it for anything else yet.

This is a review for the entire Season 2 of Grimm. What began as just needing something to watch (and for free streaming) ended up as an absolute obsession.In the beginning of Season 1, it took a few episodes before deciding if it was worth my time. Was David Giuntoli just another pretty face or did this show have any possibility?First, let me tell you that as Season 1 wrapped up and I got wrapped up in Season 2, not only did the star, Nick, played by David Giuntoli prove to be a terrific actor - but the actors together do a superb job. I really like Hank, played by Russell Hornsby all the more once he was "in the loop" as to the real goings-on; and the development of the Captain's character was a nice turn of events. The character, Monroe, played by Silas W. Mitchell is the real maker of the show, because without him, it would be missing the element of humor and charm. And I love the addition of Rosalee! She's superb. The only character that's flawed is Juliette, who I found not only annoying, but her acting is sub-par and took away from the show. Everyone else made up for it though.The writing, storyline, acting, makeup, special effects and scenery make this Season 2 of Grimm the best. I stayed up late last night to watch three in a row if that tells you anything!(I do not recommend for children - let it be for adults only, in my opinion)

When I received this today, I was so thrilled and excited. It is so pretty - just a beautiful shade of pink that even I - the practical-and neutral-everything gal - immediately didn't care and would wear this with everything!It's so much prettier in person and made so nicely. But....unfortunately, I don't think it's quite going to work for me and I will have to send it back.Trust me, it actually is going to HURT to have to part with it and I keep trying to justify keeping it because it really is that neat. I envision people begging me to tell them where I got it so they could get one because it really is a head-turner.I'm disappointed for myself - but don't YOU be! If you think at all that this would work for you, definitely give it a go because it's a pretty cool bag!

I love all of the flavors but this one is one of my favorites since I love cranberries. I keep several boxes at work to eat for a bite for breakfast or a late afternoon snack at my desk.They are perfect to throw in my purse or pocket when I'm out and knowing that they are good for me and filling is all I really can ask for.They are a bit ooey and gooey, so keep some wet wipes in your car, purse or desk - LOL!

There's nothing wrong with the product and it certainly has many well deserved reviews by those who really seem to enjoy it.I am still in search of the 'perfect' sweetener, and quite frankly, that pursuit is a bit bittersweet. No wonder sweeteners are 'big money' and why there's Big Pharma involved; and GMO's involved as everyone wants to find the perfect sweetener, too.The short version is that I'm not happy with stevia (even those that say they don't have an aftertaste - they do); honey just doesn't do well in coffee; maple syrup is my favorite natural sweetener so far, but it's expensive and messy. I haven't tried agave yet but am looking for one that is not processed in the same way HFCS is; and just the name Xylitol is scary to me (although I like it the best overall). The latest reports on xylitol are not favorable either.So, I ordered this coconut palm sugar with high expectations. It looks good. It tastes okay too. There is no unfavorable smell. So, what don't I like? Well, for me anyway, I found I needed 2-4 times as many spoonfuls in my tea and coffee as I did with regular sugar. And although reported to be lower in calories and certainly lower glycemic levels, going through it fours times as fast just to get to the same sweetness level was just not going to be cost effective.Another reason I don't care much for it is because it reminds me of rapadura.Last year I had ordered five POUNDS of rapadura sugar from a local bulk co-op here. It had great recommendations and looked promising. However, number one, I can't stand the smell of it, and number two, I can't stand the taste of it, and number three, I had to double or triple the amount to get to my sugar equivalent sweetness. But, since I didn't like the taste or smell, I didn't get very far with it anyway.The coconut sugar reminds me of the rapadura experience in appearance and (lack of) sweetness. The only good thing is it doesn't taste or smell bad.I'm not saying you will feel this way. You probably won't and it could be just 'me'. But I am not likely to order again and will keep searching..

Who doesn't enjoy pasta in some form or another? With its many shapes and sizes and great in both hot and cold dishes and many different cuisines, pasta is just a staple in most peoples' homes.But, if starch, or wheat, or gluten is an issue, or grains in general are an "issue" with some people, you're bound to miss having your favorite dishes. I know I have. I have found various substitutes for noodles - and they are great in and amongst themselves - but I still longed for "regular" noodles.Spelt didn't do it. Rice noodles didn't either. But when I came across these by Andean dream, well, it was a "dream" come true! These noodles cook up nicely; they taste good (no dirt taste; or waterlogged mushy taste as with the rice noodles) and best of all - no tummy aches or bloat!! I loved them so much, I reordered - this time a whole case!That has been my experience, but even if you have no problems with pasta, I believe you will enjoy these simply because they are good!

Just as the subject line states, there is nothing wrong with it, but I underestimated its size and sent it back. I ordered the Proctor Silex 4 quart instead.This might be just perfect for you, however. It's cute as can be and love the little band to hold the lid on.

I've always owned Rival brand Crock Pots. Do you ever buy something and think it's because that's what you're "supposed to" buy? Maybe it's because that's what Mom always did, or some other reason?Well, the first crock pot I ever heard of was Rival and it's been Rival all through the years.When it came time for me to buy one again, I bought the larger, oval shaped Rival and have been using it for about 8 years but was never happy with it. For one, the Low setting cooked much too hot; and I thought I would like the oval shape but really didn't.I use a crock pot weekly, primarily to make healthy bone broth and if the temperature is too hot, it will not become gelatinous and it will also not taste right. Such has been the case now for months but I just couldn't justify buying another one when this one wasn't truly 'broken'.But my last batch of broth tasted 'burned' and I decided to throw in the towel and get a new crockpot and I wanted something smaller, as well as round.The first one I ordered was too small (what was I thinking!?) and I sent it back.Then I decided on this slow cooker, stepping outside my Rival zone - one for the three settings, and two for the great price and reviews.I used it yesterday and was tickled. I love being able to switch to the "keep warm" setting. I love the round shape.I will update if I feel or experience anything differently, but as for right now, I am glad I got it.Ha! And get this, the day this one arrived, the lid on my Rival broke! Good timing!

This was a free item, just so you know that I did not *purchase* this book.I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed it. I don't have kids at home anymore, so to be honest, I only had an interest because of listening to co-workers; reading FB posts, etc and seeing how poorly our children are eating and being concerned about it. I like to be able to make suggestions that are helpful with the idea of "what would I do if I still had kids at home to prepare lunches for??"I believe that part of the reason for kids not having good, nutritious meals is largely due to 1)Education - about healthy eating choices as well as learning about PREPARATION (SO many people these days don't know how to cook!); 2)Sheer laziness - grabbing a bag of chips; some Lunchables, and an apple is just "easy" to throw in a child's lunchbox; 3)Lack of imagination - however, the more you know, the more you will (should!) want to know; 4)Learning "workarounds" for inconveniences; 5) "Stigma"(I can comment more later on what I mean by "stigma" and how to get around that, if anyone cares)I thought this ebook had a lot of interesting, different recipes (imagination!) that were kid-friendly and nutritious and therefore, I am happy to share this book with FB friends who struggle with lunch ideas for the family.My only comment that I would have liked to see would be ways to show how these recipes get implemented into the typical busy family's work week and how kids can bring to school for lunch as a practical school-week lunch.I think the author did a good job!

I absolutely fell for "Jericho" with a passion and an addiction like I've never had before for any TV series. The acting, the characters, the writing all reeled me in hook-line-and sinker to a show that had me on the edge of my seat with my pulse racing the whole time.I never knew of its existence when it was a television show, and it was such a wonderful 'find' when exploring my Amazon Prime benefits and I latched on to Season 1 and 2 immediately.What a grave disappointment to learn that it ended there..with a makeshift compromise of a comic book version of continuation in what is known as Season 3, and holding out for something that will be Season 4.Nonetheless, in my excitement to at least keep the story going and not wanting to part with the characters (!), I ordered the Kindle version of Season 3. I have the 8.9 inch screen and STILL have to use a magnifying glass to see the print. So much of the adrenaline and the excitement is gone trying to suffer through it.For only the second time in 19 years of being an Amazoner, I'm considering a refund. It just doesn't do it for me. Perhaps you will feel differently, or maybe the book version is the better option.For those of you who haven't seen "Jericho" at all, start with the Pilot, and keep going. You won't stop..

..how fantastic this stuff is!I actually heard about it when on a blog with a link to another blog with a link to a website..you know how it goes.The website, like Amazon, has reviews and the people raved about this brand. I was placing an order anyway, so I ordered some.Truly, in my opinion, it's the best gluten free pasta I've ever eaten. In fact, in general, it's some of the best pasta I've ever eaten, regardless of the gluten free benefit.I'm so glad that I discovered this, simply reading a blog from a blog and will order this brand from now on. I had stopped eating pasta altogether because I was so dissatisfied with everything. I would end up occasionally just buying 'regular' old .99 cent - whatever's on sale at the grocery store stuff to eat since the "good stuff" didn't do me any good and cost a fortune so why not suffer through it to be able to eat certain recipes?! (Bad logic, I know, when it's your health you're dealing with.)But, now I feel that I can actually eat the recipes I want, not have to suffer with stomach issues or bloating, and be greatly pleased and satisfied with the taste and 'performance' of the pasta.Wow. What a find!I hope you find the same is true for you.

First, let me say that I am clinically hypersensitive. Even the smell of certain things can land me in the ER. Just being close to some things can be dangerous and threatening for me.So, when I say that I have used this now for a week and have no reactions whatsoever, thus far, I am ecstatic!It arrived perfectly and swiftly; and I put it on in the morning and it still looks good and fresh when I am finished with BOTH jobs (yes - a LONG day!) at night.The only time it smears would be the obvious - if I were to rub my eyes or something.And the price was fabulous! I'm happy to have found this! Now..if I can find a mascara...

I love ethnic foods and to cook them. Tonight I used the green for the first time and WOW! It made me look like a gourmet international chef - it is so incredibly good!It was definitely hot, though, which is fine with me but I was glad I had the coconut milk base. This is excellent and I will keep this on hand always.

I was delighted to find this on Amazon! I loved everything about it - taste, convenience, health benefits (I take primarily for my eyes), price (less than going through a Juice Plus Rep); and I don't have to sign up for four months but can order whenever I want to! What's not to love? :)

There's a Pinterest post that says "Everything you want lies on the other side of Fear" and so often fear keeps you from progressing or accomplishing something.That would be me in the case of doing anything technological - LOL.I was so sure I wouldn't know how to go wireless or even understand how to go about it that I postponed doing so until seeing these reviews. So, I ordered the router and got the email many of you have mentioned. Just as everyone says, they walked me through it over the phone and it works!I love it! In fact, the internet connection seems a bit quicker going through my router than it did before so I'm thrilled about that! My needs are simple: I just want to be able to go use my Kindles throughout the house and I love that it updates automatically when you turn them on.My customer service rep was wonderful - very helpful and patient and he had me up and running in about 8 minutes.Thank you Amazon and Medialink!

This appears to be specifically made for every skin type out there! It is a 1 fl oz bottle (30 ml) of a clear serum. A More Perfect Union key takeaways , analysis and review is based on the book written by Ben Carson, MD and his wife Candy Carson . The original book is a detailed overlay on the history of the make up of the constitution. How the constitution came to be and why the constitution exists When our founding fathers sat down to write the declaration of independence it was not written over night. Although it is over 200 years old only 16 amendments have been added since. The reasoning is because the founding fathers took their time to cover as many angles as they could. With the times changing however there has been some loop holes many have used to slip through and change / bend the rules. Knowing your own constitutional rights are essential. Which is why this book was written. Knowing your own rights can potentially prevent your rights from being violated. Easy to follow, kept the readers attention. I could not find any faults with the writing style. Although I received this item at a free and or a discounted rate in exchange for an honest review, it does not change my opinion on product.

I am sure the original story of Love Does is more interesting than this book portrayed. This author for the summary and analysis I would not recommend. The story line jumped drastically . First he was shot in the eye...but it never said what happened afterwards for recovery... He dropped a wedding cake in the parking lot in which had asphalt in it...but no explanation on relevance. His wife and him were having difficulties, next he sat down with his three children to discuss life views. Again I am sure the original story was more enlightening and had a story line. The most I could gain by this is although life happened as long as he stayed on the path of religion , he was in Gods hands. Again I am sure the original book was more detailed and interesting. This summary and analysis for me was not. Although I received this item at a free and or a discounted rate in exchange for an honest review, it does not change my opinion on product.

While I was studying criminology in college I took a few psychology classes that went into parenting. This instaread is very similar to what was covered in the courses. There are three different types of parenting 1. Authoritarian, 2. Permissive / Indulgent  and 3rd is Authoritative . The authoritarian is the parents know best and expect obedience . Permissive / Indulgent are the parents that give in afraid to upset and or anger their child offering very little guidelines. Authoritative - blends a caring tone , however sets structure and expectations . This istaread is based on the permissive / indulgent parent style in which has limited the now adult from being fully prepared entering college. The book goes into detail on how the authoritarian / authoritative parenting styles actually have better results in the child's own ability to function as an adult. Accepting responsibilities, the ability to follow rules and regulations and succeed at a much greater rate than those from permissive / indulgent homes.  Easy to read and follow. The analysis and summary seemed to glide effortlessly in keeping the readers attention. I could not find any faults with this instaread. Although I received this book at a free and or a discounted rate in exchange for an honest review, it does not change my opinion on product.

I have taken a few courses on nutrition over the years. I do not suffer from being over weight, I am one of those can't gain weight types. I also struggle with Crohn's disease therefore constantly trying to find a healthier new diet.  Many doctors , and nutritionist frown on carbohydrates.  They are harder for your body to break down. I can't believe all the positive reviews on this shoe --- did the others receive a different product than I?First thing I noticed was that the quality looks pretty bad overall.  The leather is hard, brittle, and scratchy on the inside (blister-making material for sure) and the staples in the shoe might be ok for saddles or something but on a shoe it really does look like a fifth grader made it.  I already anticipated this would need a Foot Petal or other insert since the wood surface would probably kill my feet after an hour or so and was as expected from pictures.  I went a full size up as others advised, which was correct, but still overall awkward.  I probably had a half inch of space in the back of the heel but the width of the front fit perfect (any smaller/narrower would be too tight) and the straps connected to the shoe base for the ankle strap were digging in under my foot (again with the hard, scratchy leather.)  Considering the price, I was overwhelmed with disappointment that such a cute shoe went so wrong.

At one point in the story there is a joke about watching teenwolf --- if you've ever seen the mtv tv series, you will recognize quite a few similarities in the threads of this story.  I liked the hero a lot, he made the story for me.  He was an extremely mature and responsible kid and did not do stupid.  Very refreshing.  As much as he longed for his happy childhood and mourned for his murdered father, he soldiered on and was there to support his mother.  Two major problems (besides the teenwolf similarities) that dropped the ratings for me was 1) there was no plausible explanation why he is an alpha freak of nature since he was only half-werewolf and 2) the romance with his major enemy's girlfriend was flat.  I had no idea why he liked her.  They felt like they could tell each other everything and she didn't feel like she could tell anyone else.  Hah?  What about her boyfriend, the a$$hole bullying teen alpha?  She and the hero are running around together at night bonding over illicit kid hockey games and falling asleep watching move marathons together but she had no intention the whole time of breaking up with her boyfriend.  Only after the boyfriend tries to kill her does she realize she likes the hero?  What?  As a romance it was lame and weak.  I would have preferred it be left out to being so tepid.

The characters in this story were all over the place.  So was the plot now that I think about it.  Hero didn't want to be alpha but became alpha and now wants to keep alpha status.  Isn't supposed to fall for anyone because he will be forced to hook up with whoever can snag the alpha female position but can't stay away from heroine.  Is major alpha to everyone except heroine who seems to be able to out-alpha even him.  Can even best another werewolf in a fight barehanded.  Not sure if there would be a reveal about her later but gave up halfway through.  Heroine is rebel without a cause since werewolves have somewhat first class citizen status in town.  Her cause is betrayed by best friend.  They do - do not - do - do not want to make up with each other to be bffs again.  Everyone in the story and the story itself seems to whip crazily back and forth like this.  I just felt annoyed and opted not to finish.

Bear shifting aside, these two were your average, everyday couple.  Very real romance, very real, likeable people but . . . kinda dull to read about.  Even with the suspense of the crazy brother and the dreamwalking, I don't know that I'll remember this a month from now. Not bad, not great.

This had a lot of good things going for it --- the hero and heroine had interesting back stories and had their good points.  The plot was not the most original but kept the story moving.  Unfortunately, I never really felt they really had chemistry!  Weird.  Hero is major player who falls into insta-love with heroine.  Could happen.  But I just didn't buy it.
Not quite as good as the first in this series but still liked it a lot.  The heroine is still someone you can really root for.  Looking forward to the next story.

Hero and heroine really were good for each other and had a healthy --- a$$ kicking, cause they were even more bada$$ as a team --- relationship.  First partners, then more, the romance was there but mostly simmering in the background so you could still call this more of a traditional sci fi story.  Seemed like the start of a series where a group of them try to take on the corrupt government organization controlling people with powers.

Really liked this one although I really wanted to give the hero a swift kick at quite a few points in the book.  The heroine saved it for me --- she was tough but relatable and I was rooting for her all the way.

Overall a very good story.  The romance was actually very sweet but somehow was expecting more sizzle with the whole dreams and destiny thing when they met.  Still a well written mystery and use of her power --- more traditional "everyday" powers and mysticism,  not like contemporary urban magic stories that seem to use their powers more dynamically.  Nice that the whole town accepted her instead of wanting to hang her as typical.

The story --- perhaps out of necessity to catch up readers --- seemed to rehash past events quite a bit and the main storyline just didn't grab me as much as the previous two did.  Still, it was nice to revisit this couple again.

If you enjoyed book 1 you won't be disappointed in this continuation.  The hero and heroine are trying to settle into their new married lives and their relationship with each other --- with interference still by past enemies.

Story started off strong with the hero already in a bind and being rescued by the heroine.  As it turns out, he ends up returning the favor.  Somehow lost steam towards the ending of the story and losing my attention a bit.  Although not a plot hole that the hero did not really know how he came to be or much of the world around him, it still made the world building somehow lacking and left me feeling a little distanced from it all since I felt like I didn't really know what was going on either.  May have had more of a connection if he learned about himself the same time we did.

A little strange to have the original animated series Batman and Waller voices in this very grown up story (serial killers, blood, sex, cursing, etc.) with anime style art.  Character dynamics of the team was interesting as were the story twists.

Lantern origin story. Always love the intergalactic space police aspect --- this is science fiction at its best, really.  We learn about the Corp through Hal Jordan's rookie training.  The one thing that always gets me is that the main Lantern (there have been so many) is never someone that really clicks for me.  Despite trying to redeem the character, Hal Jordan has always been kind of an a$$ and I can never really warm up to him.  Still, I tend to like the other Lanterns and it keeps me coming back for more.

Excellent re-imagining of the main 3 players in the justice league (superman, batman, wonder woman.)  This story covers their origins with familiar characters blended in a mad re-mix.  Batman is probably the most changed but he actually works better as a vampire.  The mystery was excellent and kept me guessing.  What stopped me from giving it 5 stars is that even though the characters showed flashes of friendship and --- basically humanity, I guess --- they were all essentially unlikable characters that were flawed, egomaniacal, and it was hard to feel sympathetic for them even when you saw they deserved it.

Second installment after Justice League War, Aquaman origin story.  Nowhere near as good as the first --- Arthur is a nice guy and not the angry man portrayed in other recent renditions.  Unfortunately, he also comes across as somewhat weak and lacking the charisma a king could probably use --- the romance with Meara is also weak.  Although I never cared much for Steve and not at all for Lois (who is a big B in every story rendition I've ever seen), can't say I'm a fan of the supes-ww romance here either --- this storyline seems to have cornered the market in awkward, stilted romances.  Strangely, the bats/supes pairing is still somehow a successful duo --- maybe to do with the normal/nice guy and tortured/jerk dynamic.  Cyborg, Lantern, and Flash have distinct personalities and add some humor to the story.  They make good additions to the cast unlike Shazam who is supposed to add humor but instead I find just as idiotic as ever .

These were a bit on the snug side so I was considering sending for a half size up.  Unfortunately, testing the fit by walking in place revealed that the outer edge is most definitely digging right in underneath my ankle bone which is a deal breaker for me.  Too bad, it looked cute and felt very stable like it would be comfortable to walk in otherwise.

These are amazingly uncomfortable  Offhand, the comparison I can think of is this shoe feels like it was made with credit card plastic it is so stiff and unyielding.  It also felt almost a full size to small it is so tight.  Too bad, looks so cute.

Tried this on my red, black, and brown boots.  There seems to be some very slight transfer of the color onto the cloth but nothing major.  The color of the boot leather looks fine after applying and seems to clean the leather, also.  Consistency and smell of pearlized liquid soap.

Actually, I am not entirely sure about the efficacy of this product.  I was overwhelmed with how awful the smell was --- reminded me of the cages at the zoo or something.  The smell from the bottle was not good but I hoped it would dissipate when applied.  After doing a spot test on the heel of each of a few boots, thereafter, I was hit with the awful smell every time I went near the boots.  After around four hours of this I had had enough so I went over the areas with the Wild Bill cleaner --- which smells like a pleasant soap -- and that seems to have helped get rid of the smell.

Material and make quality is very good.  Material is on the starchy-stiff side to help keep the brim shape and has a barely there sheen to it which I think gives it a hint of classy rather than cheap.  Fits my approx. 22.5" inch head just right.  Love the UPF and wider brim to keep the sun off my face but small enough to keep a lower profile in the urban jungle.  Wish they had more colors here.

Obviously when you buy this type of hat, fashion is not your first priority, it is utility.  It is almost impossible to make a wider brim look hip but if you are serious about keeping the sun off your face, coverage all around is key.  I thought this was a good effort at trying to make the wider coverage brim look sporty.  Unfortunately, for the price, I was rather disappointed.  The material feels very plastic tablecloth thin which is a good and bad thing.  It should be lighter/cooler and I could easily tuck in the back flap in as I planned but also felt a bit cheap and flimsy overall.  The brim was slightly dented in a couple spots and felt like lightweight cardboard similar to a 12 can coca cola box weight.  Likely it would not be able to keep its shape very well over time.  On the plus side, the fit for my approx. 22.5" head was loose but the sturdy cinch in the back worked really well to tighten it up.  I had also purchased the coolibar swim visor at the same time and found that to be so much sturdier so I ended up returning this one.

I would have to say that when you buy this kind of sporting type of hat, fashion is not your first priority, it is utility.  That said, the flat top crown helps the look a lot and I won't feel ashamed wearing it to the beach, archery range, or after-activity store or food stop.  I went with the fossil color which looks exactly as pictured live.  I actually like the array of colors --- even the crazy green-green one, why not--- being offered for outdoor wear.  Not like I'll be trying to match it with my office or dining out clothes, after all.  The material is similar to swim shorts and feels light, durable, and like it can handle water and sweat well.  The mesh inside helps keep your head cool.  The UPF and wider brim is the perfect width to keep the sun away but not get in your way.  Material and make quality is excellent.  Fits my approx 22.5" head just about right so I would probably only need the draw cord at the crown (or chin strap) if it was a really windy day.

Quality and materials are decent (did not try it in the rain, though.)  Fit my approx 22.5" head on the loose side but has the drawcord to fit as needed and did not look bunchy or anything.  I did not notice in the description that the brim style is longer in front and back and slightly thinner on the sides if you like that effect.  I prefer a wide brim all around so I returned the hat but did not dock any stars for it.  I forgot to measure the brim width but probably about 3" at widest points.
While not the best quality material/make, it is still good enough for everyday wear at a very cheap price.

After reading some of the mixed-bag reviews, I started this with some trepidation since I love PB and this series.  Perhaps because of my caution, I ended up enjoying this quite a bit.  As others noted, there was a lot of horse-related info and I sort of skim-read the pages relating to that since they were not relevant to the fae murder mystery being solved.  The murder mystery was creepy-fun to solve and Charles and Anna's relationship was in a good place in this one.  I still like some of the previous books in this series better but, overall, I enjoyed it.

These are obviously very slim inserts so those expecting instant nike walking on cloud action or birkenstock arch support are sure to be disappointed.  Also, I am pretty sure any super-cushion/arch support will require you buy your shoes a full size up --- I have some of those cushion/arch support types and they only fit in my running shoes because I can trade out the existing inserts.  Fashionable sandals or closed heels would be hopeless.So for those times when I've decided to sacrifice a little comfort for fashion, this is my answer.  These inserts have always fit in my regular sized sandals and fashionable heels without making them tighter yet adds enough padding to make that fashionable high heel that gets uncomfortable after 4 hours an 8 hour comfort shoe.  I have read that the foam is similar to custom orthotic type and will not get squished into flat paper or redistribute unevenly over time.Regarding difficulties putting in the insert --- I am willing to pay that price as long as the glue action is strong so it does not move around.  Having said that, I have never lost any inserts due to re-positioning mishaps.  After putting the first set I ever bought in place, I pretty much figured out how I could get it to work for me.  Here are some tips if useful for others:  The first time I insert the cushion, I guide it into the toe area on top of my hand and feel with my fingers where I want the main pad to sit under my foot.  I let the whole thing sort of sit "lightly" and re-position as needed (as long as you haven't pressed it on you can carefully pull it off and move it.)  Then I sit and with my foot up (no pressure on the insert) slide my foot in to the shoe as close to the top of the shoe to not press down and try to feel if it is where I want it or I need to try to re-position it.  Generally at that point, though, I'm good so I stand up in it to really let the glue stick in place.

Very nice quality, as pictured/described.  Keeps food cool on the way in to work.  The bag can be carried either flat or upright by handle, upright only using sling strap.  The one thing that would make this 5 star is two zippers on the main closure.  It just has one zipper so you have to go all the way from one end to the other to open/close.  Having two would make open/close much quicker.

Plastic is sturdy enough and the lid fits in a shallow groove snugly enough that it won't fall open with a casual nudge.  I bought two, One holds regular q-tip brand qtips laying flat with cotton facing side walls (not standing up, seems slightly cleaner to not grab them by the cotton tips.)  The other holds flat, circular cotton pads that are often used to remove cosmetics.  Easy to grab either out of their respective containers.  Very happy with these.

With no image to verify the book and very few images online, I really went on faith with this one and was disappointed.  I collect children's books and I really like this illustrator.  While there are a lot of beautiful illustrations on every one of the 32 pages, all are pencil type sketches and the result is very draft/blah.  I think this is the first time I was actually inspired to scan some images for upload on amazon.  Hopefully it may help the next person decide if this is for them.

I collect children's books for the illustrations mainly but it still has to have a good story.  Case in point:  I was really torn up about this one because the illustrations are so beautiful but the story is so awful.Perhaps it was supposed to be whimsical but the whole plot came across to me as totally random and, therefore, pointless.  There was no clever reason nor resolution to her no-kingdom situation and same goes for the romance with the hero.  Major events seem to happen without any real cause and effect.Another aspect where the whimsical theme did not work for me was the setting.  Sometimes anachronistic things can blend seamlessly --- as shown with the steampunk genre --- but this one was a mess.  There are pony carts, lords in white wigs, food fights, public libraries, and princesses with delivery careers who propose marriage to their hero.Lastly, I wondered what age this is supposed to be targeting, exactly?  I assume this book is meant for a child but how many children would enjoy or even understand about the hero's jester-contract running out and the couple's discussion about the work they will have to do --- he will tell jokes in pubs and she will continue to cart parcels ---  in order to "make a go of it"?  In a modern story that would not be out of place but in a princess story with such charming illustrations, those realities are just jarring and ugly.

I collect children's books.  This re-telling has a somewhat modern feel to it --- which I do not prefer so I knocked off a star subjectively --- but generally follows the traditional story.  It is suitable for kids since it glosses over the thorny defenestration (great shadow pictures, no major bloodletting or other details) and the ending is sans the twin babies.  Beautiful and charming illustrations throughout with vibrant color (lots of pink.)

I collect children's books and this is one of the illustrators I collect.  I bought a very nice quality used copy.  This tells the G-rated version of the story sans the twin babies at the end.  Unfortunately, the storytelling in this one did not grab me and neither did the illustrations.  I usually love golden book stories so I was rather disappointed.

I am an adult that collects children's books.  The cutouts in this are much more sophisticated than any I had as a child.  Having said that, after seeing images of the pages online, the real life version did not measure up.  Unlike the online images, the colors were not bright and vibrant.  Rather, the color scheme all looked somewhat brown and muddy and the whole effect was dull.

I am an adult that collects books by my favorite fairy tale illustrators and this has many charming pictures.  Cheerful color scheme throughout, similar to the cover.  The printing sometimes seemed a little blurry but considering the age and original price range/child paperback book level, it is acceptable.  Story is the traditional version suitable for kids.  I bought a relatively pricey used copy in very nice condition.  Glad it was worth it in the end.

I am an adult that collects books by my favorite fairy tale illustrators and this has many nice pictures.  The color scheme and print quality is rather muted, similar to what is on the cover.  Story is the traditional version suitable for kids.  I bought a used copy in very nice condition.

I am an adult female, shoe size 6.  Regular women's socks in the standard 6-9 size always end up with the heel somewhere behind my upper ankle because it is too big.  I find youth large fits me perfectly.  These are great.
Good for price.  As pictured, described.  Easy to assemble and plastic is sturdy enough to hold wig.

I first read this story ages ago in middle school and still enjoy it as an adult today thanks to a library book sale.  This story is a nostalgic romance --- somewhat reminiscent of Georgette Heyer --- set in Honolulu in the late 1800s with the completion of the Iolani Palace and Hawaiian coronation ball as the backdrop.  Orphaned Samantha Allen travels from New England to live with her uncle in Honolulu.  She is warmly welcomed by her part Hawaiian Aunt and family but troubled by her promise to her dying mother to return a stolen jeweled cross from Acapulco.  The original thieves are still after it and she knows she could be bringing danger to everyone if they catch up with her.  Worth reviving for some readers into historical romance today, I think.

Agreed with other reviewer, in retrospect, this book is actually rather ahead of its time and would fit in the now well-established YA fantasy-romance genre today.  I bought a hardcover of this book at a library book sale years and years ago and enjoyed it enough to keep it.  Had no idea the author wrote far and away (a movie I did not care for at all, actually, but maybe it was a better book.)
As pictured/described.  Works exactly as well as I had hoped.  Seems very sturdy.  Hope it will not warp or break and last a while.

Possibly the crappiest packing ever but a great fan.  Fan arrived in original box (not amazon brown box) completely open on the top.  The fan inside looked like it was a return that was repacked and taped together with clear packing tape.  Put it together to see if all the parts would be there and it seemed to be a complete set.  Fan itself is great.  As advertised, very quiet.  Wind action is very good, as expected --- to be as strong as a Vornado, it will also get as loud as a Vornado.  Tilts up and down --- unfortunately does not tilt up very far past being even/straight forward --- and you can turn the oscillation on and off.  However, the best feature of all is that opening the fan to clean the blades will not take an hour of cursing and trying to get multiple awkwardly placed screws on and off.  Has one screw that tightens the ring around the perimeter to hold the front and back grill together.Now, hopefully it will last a decent amount of time.
bought this to hold my embroidery hoop.  Very sturdy gooseneck and clip.  Works as hoped.

Very lightweight, all bendy plastic.  It is quiet and have no problem running at my desk at work.  Pushes decent amount of air for tiny lightweight plastic fan.  Exactly as I was expecting.  Hopefully it will last a while and not break.

The first keyboard worked ok for a few weeks, then the #5 on the keypad broke and would type a 5 continuously as long as my fingers were resting on it without pressing.Amazon service was amazing and allowed me to return it even though I had tossed the original box.  They immediately shipped out another to me and it arrived quickly.Unlike the first one, the second one 1) seemed to have sporadic connection for the charging app and it would only sometimes be able to update and tell me that it was nearly fully charged and 2) it kept indicating there was not enough light in the room to quickly charge.  I was able to type with the keyboard for about 15 minutes but then halfway through a sentence, it lost connection and would never reconnect.  I downloaded updated software for the charging app, the unifying receiver, and endpoint but still the keyboard could not be detected.I gave up, packed it back up, and requested a refund.Normally Logitech is my go-to for peripherals but this was all rather discouraging.
Very nice quality, looks cuter live than the picture, even.  Very fast ship.

_The Best of Amazing Stories: The 1926 Anthology_ (2014), ed. Steve Davidson and Jean Marie Stine. It is (as the title suggests) an anthology of eight short stories and novelettes from the first year of _Amazing_. The covers of the nine issues for that year (all by Frank R. Paul) are reproduced on the back for them that likes such stuff. Readers with a sentimental attachment to pulp fiction of the  silver Gernsbackian era may enjoy this volume. Most modern readers, I fear, will not.There are three stories in the anthology that may be fairly be called "classical _Amazing_" stories-- "In the Abyss" by H.G. Wells, "The Runaway Skyscraper" by Murray Leinster, and "The Man Who Saved the Earth" by Austin Hall. The Wells and the Leinster were reprints, from _Pearson's Magazine_ and _Argosy_, respectively. In fact, much of the material from the 1928 _Amazing_ was reprinted material from Jules Verne, Edgar Alan Poe, H.G. Wells, and Garrett P. Serviss. The Wells is the chiller about the explorer in the bathysphere who encounters deep-sea monsters in the Pacific. The Leinster is the sprightly comedy about the time-traveling skyscraper and what befell its inhabitants during their wild journey in the past. The Hall is a super-science tale about Earth versus Mars that is patently ridiculous from begining to end-- and yet is somehow great fun to read. I rarely say this of an Austin Hall story.Two stories-- Charles S. Wolfe's "Whispering Ether" and Samuel M. Sargent, Jr.'s "The Telepathic Pick-up" are two scientific wowsers about two mad scientists who are done in by their mind reading inventions. This is the first (and probably the last) publication of these tales.The remaining three stories have been reprinted a fair number of times and may be familiar to old timey readers of _Amazing_ like myself. But they are are really routine pulp stories at heart, with few virtues to recommend them. The stories are: G. Payton Wertenbaker's "The Man from the Atom," Curt Siodmak"s "The Eggs from Lake Tanganyika," and A. Hyatt Verrill's "Through the Crater's Rim". The Werttenbaker is about the man in the Colossal suit who views many galaxies before coming to a rest. The author wrote a sequel. The Siodmak is one of those mad-scientist-and the-monster-from-the-laboratory (this time giant fly) tales that Hugo Gernsback loved to print by the dozen in _Amazing_. The Verrill is a lost-race-in-the-Amazon-jungle story, complete with cannibal trees and bloodthirsty Aztec natives. The last two tales represent dead-end types of stories that have vanished from the field today, though you may still find them on the Late Nite Monster Shows from time to time.So, by my count there is one "A" story, two "B's,"  three "D's," and two "F's"-- not a very outstanding lineup. This seems to be the first of a year-by-year series of collections from _Amazing_-- the 1927 anthology is due out soon. This is an idea that seems to me to be a spectacularly bad one. _Amazing_ did have its string of good years, but it also had its decades of bad ones. For much better anthologies of _Amazing_, I recommend _Amazing Stories: 60 Years of the Best Science Fiction_ (1985) and _Amazing Stories: Visions of Other Worlds_ (1986), both edited by Martin H. Greenberg.

In 1963, Keith Laumer published a lively three-part serial in _Fantastic_ entitled "A Hoax in Time". The book version followed... sort of. It was entitled _The Great Time Machine Hoax_ (1964). But while it had essentially the same plot  as the original novel, it was very different in terms of details. Some scenes were cut from the original novel. Others were added. Dialogue was changed. Sequences of events were altered. This is the original serial version that appeared in _Fantastic_, and for my money it still  wears very well.It is a lighthearted fantasy adventure of the sort that L. Sprague de Camp and Fletcher Pratt used to do for _Unknown_, but it does have a kind of philosophy that might be described as a kind of amiable hedonism. The basic plot is this: Chester W. Chester has inherited a Victorian monstosity of a house, a supercomputer with his late grandfather's personality, and millions of dollars of back taxes in debt. He and his pal Case Mulvihill, a carny man, hatch a plan. With the aid of some special effects from the computer, perhaps they can con the Internal Revenue inspectors into thinking that they have a real, live time machine...And from there, absolutely _nothing_ goes as planned.

G. K. Chesterton's _The Ball and the Cross_ (1910) was his second novel. [His first was _The Napoleon of Notting Hill_ (1904)]. While it was not published in book form until after his masterpiece, _The Man Who Was Thursday_ (1908), the magazine serial preceeded _Thursday_ (_Commonwealth_ 1905-1906). So _The Ball and the Cross_ must be considered the earlier novel.In later years, Chesterton expressed a dissatisfaction with the novel. In the flyleaf of a copy owned by Father John O'Connor (the original of Father Brown), Chesterton inscribed a poem that read in part:This is a book I do not like,Take it away to Heckmondwike,...The speeches jerk, the chapters sprawlThe story makes no sense at all.Now, it is true that the novel is not without faults. But it is a novel written during Chesterton's most creative period. It is not without its virtues as well.There are two noteworthy faults of the novel. The first is Chesterton's satire of science-- in particular, his dismissal of evolution. Chesterton had little knowledge of either science in general or evolution in particular. We may take chesterton's scientific satire to be verbally witty but essentially nonsensical.The second fault is the final chapter of the novel, an apocalyptic ending in which everything goes up in flames, the atheist is converted to Christianity at the last moment,, and the City of God comes to Earth. Now this may have seemed to Chesterton (and a few conservative Catholics) like the Cat's Meow of a light comedy ending. But an ending in which all the characters ( and everybody else in the world) has been fried by eternal fire left me a bit less than cheery. And Chesterton's chipper assurance that it was all okie-dokie because God saved everybody's soul somehow failed to elicit the proper comic spirit in me.However, before this rather apalling ending, Chesterton actually presents a rather decent novel.

James Reynolds's _Ghosts in Irish Houses_ (1947) is a beautiful book, a real labor of love, ten years in the making. It is a blend of lovely art and folk tales. The cover is a striking wash of Rahee Castle, where the tale of "The Four Terrors" takes place-- a grim tale of brotherly double-cross and a bloody curse which followed a family for centuries thereafter..Other ghostly tales of a grim and bloody nature include "The Bridal Barge of Aran Roe," which the author claims to have seen near Slithey Rock; "Red Eva's Lepp," about a formidable female warrier who came back as a red cow; "The Bloody Stones of Kerrigan's Keep," a nasty tale of revenge and ghosts that drive men insane even today; and "The Black O'Flaherty of Castle Blake," about a _really_ nasty family: "From the shadow of O'Flaherty, God deliver me" (231).Not so bloody, perhaps, but a story of rather horrible revenge is "Shallardstown and the Orloff Whip". And for a similar tale of personal evil, there is "Mrs. O'Moyne and the Fatal Slap".Ghosts of a more whimsical or more sympathetic nature are "mickey Filler and the Tasey Wreath,"  the circus ghost at the "Place de la Reine Hippique," the incorrigible twins of "Badminton in Bloomers," the lovely governess of "The Phantom Portrait," and the wild girl who found true love in "The Spanish Fan".Rather bad but unusual haunts are the gluttonous Squire Bannot, "the filthiest ghost in all of Ireland" (10) and the headless Ormand Mallory of whom it was said "he invested wickedness with a brightness and a sparkle" (56). And Old Scratch himself makes one appearance as well.Two stories, "Duel with Song" and "The Shattered Mirror," come from Belvelly Castle, and were related to the author by a folklorist from the area. Stories about the Castle abound. These are different tales from different times, but they both have to do with the sin of pride and the horrors that can come of it."The Drums of Rathmoy" involves the resistence to Cromwell's invading fleet and why Rathmoy house survived the bombardment and shuns occupants to this day. "The ghostly Catch" is about a manifestation that arises out of the sea like a force of the gods even today. One tale is Irish patriotic, the other, Irish mythical. The second was told by a man who was injured by the Catch.The illustrations are partly of places--Sligo Rock, Slieve Donard, Kerrigan's Keep, and Rathmoy House. Some of the illustrations are of the historical people as they were when they were alive. The frontspiece is of Red Eva McMurrough in her battle curass. There is also her husband, Strongbow. The brothers of Rahee Castle, Princess Orloff, the O'Haggerty Twins... all are there. The circus ghost is not, but her much beloved toy horse is. Also present are portraits of native Irishmen: A White-Hooded Woman of Balinsoe, Kelp Gatherers of County Galway, a Listening Girl at Belvelly Castle. There is an illustrated map of Ireland with the Castles and Houses drawn in.In his introduction, Reynolds gives a thumbnail portrait of ghosts round the world. Italy and ireland, he says, have "more ghosts per square inch" (xiii) than any any other countries. Irish ghosts are no repectors of persons, but they do tend to be intensely personal.

If ever there was a science fiction author influenced by Charles Fort, it was Eric Frank Russell. His early novels, _Sinister Barrier_ (1939) and _Dreadful Sanctuary_ (1948), used very Fortean themes. Later in life, Russell was active in the British end of the Fortean society, clipping out unusual ("unexplainable") events from newspapers and playing host to Tiffany Thayer and other members of the Fortean society.Russell's _Great World Mysteries_ (1957) is a nonfictional, somewhat Fortean, book, though ultimately much more sane andsensible than the original books by Fort. It consists of eleven essays on some classic (and not-so-classic) mysteries. Two of the essays, "Satan's Footprints" and "The Creeping Coffins of Barbados," were reprinted in _Fantastic_ in 1958. The first deals with a line of mysterious footprints in the snow, while the second deals with some coffins that were moved around in a sealed family vault. Russell offers solutions to both mysteries.Other cases that Russell discusses are those of the _Mary Celeste_, that of  Kasper Hauser, that of Benjamin Bathurst (who walked around the horses), Easter Island, spontaneous combustion, and levitation. There is also a chapter on flying saucers which Anthony Boucher loved but which I did not.
