There is a good index.I would recommend this book for somebody who does not already have an encyclopedic collection of books on the mysterious. It is an excellent introduction. To somebody aleady well-read in lore about saucers or Easter Island or sea serpents or the Kasper Hauser affair, this book may be a case of coals to Newcastle.

Anthony Boucher would occasionally give brief reviews in his "Recommended Reading" column in _Fantasy and Science Fiction_ on the latest batch of flying saucer books. He confessed that he collected " the damned things" and "wouldn't miss a word of any one of them" (74). Boucher professed to be an agnostic on the topic-- neither a skeptic nor a believer. But I believe that he later came to find much of the behavior of some saucer believers to be on the on the bizarre and outrageous side. I am on the skeptical side of the fence myself. I avoid most flying saucer books like the plague-- I find them to be mostly unmitigated trash.But Edward J. Ruppelt's _The Report on  Unidentified Flying Objects_ (1956, 1960) is that rare thing, a _respectable_ account of the U.F.O. phenomena, and it remains something of a classic today. It will not please sensation-seeking flying saucer nuts-- it is much too rational and sober-- and it did not initially please Air Force officials who wanted all UFOs neatly explained away. but it does represent the results of solid, honest investigation.First, a bit of background. The Air Force had a series of projects supposed to be officially investigating UFOs: Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. Project Sign investigators were over ready to assign all UFO. reports to be extraterrestrial in origin. Early Project Grudge investigators bent over backwards to find non-saucer explanations-- some of them almost as bizarre as the saucer interpretations. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt was director of Projects Grudge and Bluebook from 1951 to 1953. Ruppelt was tempermentally skeptical, but he insisted on a thorough investigation of many of the reports and sightings._The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects_ is as close to an official, insider's view of the critical years of Project Blue Book that we are likely to have. But there are two different versions of the book. In the earlier, 1956 version, Ruppelt concludes that while _most_ UFOs can be accounted for in terms of named causes (such as airplanes, planets, lights, weather balloons, or hoaxes),  about 27% are still "of unknown origin". This leaves the door open for a few of them to be extraterrestrial. But in the 1960 edition, which adds three chapters, Ruppelt flatly concludes that the notion that UFOs are of extraterrestrial origin is a "myth". Saucer believers tend to ignore the 1960 version, but I really don't see how we can. Ruppelt swung to the skeptical side, not because he was "pressured" by Air Force Brass, but simply because there was _no positive evidence in four years to support flying saucers_.It must be said that Ruppelt was becoming increasingly disenchanted with various saucer writers as well. He criticized Donald Keyhoe, the author of several bestselling books on flying saucers:To say the book [_Flying Saucers from Outer Space_] is factual depends entirely on how one uses the word. The details of the specific UFO sightings that he credits to the Air Force are factual, but in his interpretation of the incidents he blasts way out into the wild blue yonder. (chapter 17)As time went on, so did the number of reports from flying saucer nuts:Many inquiries come from saucer screwballs and these people are like a hypochondriac at the doctor's, nothing will make them believe the diagnosis unless it is what they came to hear. And there are plenty of screwballs.One officer summed it up neatly when he told me, "It isn't the UFO's that give us trouble, it's the people." (chapter 16)But the bulk of the book is loaded with anecdotal case studies that make absolutely fascinating reading. Of course, Ruppelt starts with the case that started it all-- that of private pilot Kenneth Arnold, who spotted several "disc-shaped"craft flying over Mt. Ranier in 1947. Putting aside controversies about what Arnold actually said over the radio, Ruppelt is convinced that he did see actual aircraft (as opposed to sunspots or snow formations). Another early case was that of two Air Force colonels who spotted three objects in "V formation" while flying over the Carson Sink, Nevada area in 1952. They reported their findings in Colorado Springs, Nevada. (This one stuck in my mind because I have relatives in Colorado Springs.) And during 1946 and later in 1948, there were reports of "ghost rockets" of various shapes and colors appearing in many different countries around the world.In chapter two, Ruppelt spins out a story about crashed UFOs and two men known as "Jackson" and "Richards" and a Close Encounter on an island in 1947. Ruppelt piles on the details, and just when you think that you have encountered a real-life scenario out of _The X-Files_... Ruppelt jerks the rug out from under your feet. It was all a hoax cooked up by a couple of scoundrels who had just enough raw material to fake a UFO crash and some vivid imaginations. They were quickly exposed, and they faded off into the sunset.Ruppelt gives detailed attention to two "classic" UFO cases-- those of pilot Captain Mantrell of Kentucky, who was killed chasing down a UFO, and those of the famed "Lubbuck Lights" of Texas. Ruppelt does not interpret either case in the boogga-boogga manner that most saucer believers like. He believes that Mantell _could_ have been pursuing a skyhook balloon-- there was one just released from Tennessee at that time. But that we will never know for sure. Ruppelt rejects explanations involving extraterrestrial spacecraft or notions that Mantell was chasing down an image of Venus. As for the phenomenon of the Lubbock lights, well-witnessed over a long period of time by a lot of observant witnesses-- Ruppert does not give a solid conclusion to the mystery. but he rules out extraterrestrial space craft.In chapter four, Ruppelt gives attention to some spectacular bursts of light that appeared over parts of Mexico and the American southwest. They did not leave any trace of meteorite debris where they appeared. They always seemed to be the same shade of green. They were thoroughly investigated by some of the top scientists in America-- some of whom were eyewitnesses to the lights.But in the end, no solution to the mystery was found. One person suggested a "duck hunter" approach-- set up several observational "blinds" with permanent observers and cameras in places where the lights were likely to appear. This is sound in theory-- but awesomely expensive in practice.Other cases include the case of the Florida encounter with the scoutmaster that could be real... or a fraud, the case of the rise in radiation that coincided with a UFO sighting, and the massive numbers of UFOs that were sighted over Washington, DC and had President Truman calling him to ask what was going on. But Ruppelt says that there is always the persistent problem of perception. When one person says that they have seen a UFO, all critical thought goes out the window. Nobody asks if it could be anything elseIn one instance I traveled halfway across the United States to investigate a report made by a high ranking man in the State Department. An experienced observer. It was evening by the time I got to talk to him and he'd excitedly told me all the pertinent facts, how this bright light had "jumped across the sky," he said, "Want to see it? It's still there, but it's not jumping now."We went outside and there was Jupiter. (chapter twenty)In a review of _The Report..._,  Anthony Boucher praised the book but predicted: "Ruppelt is almost completely successful in maintaining a neutral attitude which will exasperate both 'pro' and 'anti-saucer' factions in and out of the USAF" (90). He was quite correct in this prediction. But I will tell you. There is something likeable about the voice of the author who speaks to us. It is sane, rational, humorous, clear-headed, and energetic. And he has a fascinating tale to tell. This is a book worth rereading today._References_: Boucher, Anthony. "Recommended Reading," _Fantasy and Science Fiction_, May, 1955, 74. For his review of Ruppelt, see "Recommended Reading," _F&SF_, May, 1956, 90-91.

Stanton Coblentz's _Under the Triple Suns_ (1954) is a novel from roughly the middle of his career. To be honest, it is a novel that has much the same strengths and weaknesses as his earlier and later novels. Stanton Coblentz (1896-1982) was a poet and satirist who was associated with the silver Gernsbackian era of the American science fiction pulps (from roughly 1926 through 1939), along with writers like David H. Keller, M.D., E.E. Smith, Ray Cummings, Miles J. Breuer, M.D., Capt. S.P. Meek, L.Taylor Hansen, Murray Leinster, and Edmond Hamilton.Coblentz's first novel, _The Sunken World_ (1928), was a straight utopian novel and proved to be passably good. But most of Coblentz's later novels were concerned with constructing silly, satiric dystopias. They were consequently marred by heavy-handed satire, cardboard characters, silly plots, and asinine dialogue. And yet, in a review of this very book, Damon Knight (1967) first pointed out an unexpected strength of Coblentz: His descriptive passages that evoke a sense of wonder-- in particular, an alien city on another world. He concluded that writers ought to study Coblentz's descriptive passages: "If your alien planet is just like Broadway, or even just like Uganda, what the devil is the use of leaving Earth at all?" (13)In evaluating _Triple Suns_, then, we must balance its weaknesses (its satire) with its strengths (its sense of wonder). Let us start  with the satire. Coblentz would usually have a main target for his satire in his novels. In _Hidden World_ (1935), it was perpetual warfare. In _Next Door to the Sun_ (1960), it was political electioneering. In _Lord of Tranerica_ (1966), it was automation. In _Under the Triple Suns_, the target is social classes and social repression of the "have nots" by the "haves" in society. This is done through some fairly obvious symbolic action.

Thomas M. Disch's _The Prisoner_ (1967) is a novelization that was a tie-in to the unusual television series starring Patrick McGoohan. It was written to make a quick buck, and I think that it would be grossly overstating the case to say that this novel is a classic like _The Genocides_ (1965), _Camp Concentration_ (1967), or _337_ (1971). But it is much better written than anybody had a right to expect it to be.The basic story line is this: The unnamed  hero hero is an ex Secret Service man who is promptly kidnapped and made prisoner in a strange, Orwellian Village, populated with automaton-like Villagers and guarded by giant spheres called Guardians. There authorities try to pick his mind while our hero hatches increasingly complicated plots to escape.The action of Disch's novel covers the early action of the series, from a scene with the hero's girl friend just before his kidnapping to a rather bizarre final scene that is something of a cliffhanger. It is true that some characters claim that the hero has "been to the village before". There is even some question as to whether the Village is really one Village or many. This is all part of the story's ambiguity, its playing with our sense of reality. But the action of the tale is meant to coincide with (roughly) the first three or four  episodes of the series. It does not take place after the action of the original series has ended.Unlike the series, Disch does not provide scenes that show his hero is a secret agent. He rather hints at it a few times, but his background is less clearly sketched out than in the television series.. He is a bit more of an enigma. We do not know his name. He gives different ages of himself to different people. But there is one thing he is certain about: "I am not Number 6. I am not a prisoner.I am a free man" (49). This comes from a realization a bit earlier on about the nature of the Village:The Village, this splendid room, the mirror in its frame of ormolu, and even the image in the mirror were not to be trusted. What, then, was?His body, the body beneath these wrinkled evening clothes, that could be trusted.And his mind.Because these things could not be tampered with.He could trust (as finally we all must) himself. (25)

Murray Leinster's _Planets of Adventure_ (2003), ed. Eric Flint is an omnibus of two novels and five short stories by the Dean of Science Fiction. The novels are _The Forgotten Planet_ (1954) and _The Planet Explorer_ (aka, _Colonial Survey_, 1956). They are not without their faults, but they are overall two of Leinster's very best science fiction novels. The short stories are lesser-known Leinster pieces, but they are mostly competent tales that deserve reprinting. Eric Flint has shown excellent taste in his selections.Due to a rather complex publishing history, _The Forgotten Planet_ is something of a curiosity-- a science fiction novel with 1950s science told with a 1920s style of writing. The ancestors of the survivors of a spaceship crash have had the misfortune to be on a partly terraformed planet where the dominant life forms are giant insects. The novel is a retelling of the Prometheus myth and has a curious power._The Planet Explorer_ is a novel in which four novelettes from _Astounding_ featuring different heroes from the Colonial Survey Team were rewritten so that they would all have the same hero-- a fellow named Bordman. One of these novelettes, "Combat Team," was based on Leinster's Hugo-winning story, "Exploration Team". Therein lies the problem. In the other three tales, Bordman is a young, bright, but somewhat insecure troubleshooter. In the fourth story, he is a pompous bureaucrat who spends most of the story threatening to toss the real troubleshooter in jail. The character is not consistent.Still, I would recommend that you read these tales. They are some of Leinsters most _thoughtful_ pieces of science fiction. They have a lot of sensible things to say about the limits of freedom and authority and about the different ways that different people will look at the same problem. They are also about teamwork and friendship-- among both humans and animals.The stories are: "Anthropological Note" (_Fantasy and Science Fiction_, 1957); "Scrimshaw," (_Astounding_, 1955); "Assignment on Pasik" (_Thrilling Wonder Stories_, 1949); "Regulations," (_TWS_, 1948); and ""The Skit-Tree Planet" (_TWS_, 1947). "Scrimshaw" has been fairly frequently reprinted. "Regulations" has never been reprinted before now. The other tales have been reprinted only once."Anthropological Note" is the tale about the female anthropologist, the male murderous scoundrel, the Venusian villagers with the mysterious customs, and an alien god who may or may not exist. "Scrimshaw" is about a grizzled old lunar prospector who manages to outsmart some ruthless outlaws. "Assignment on Paslik" opens with a spectacular spaceship crash and follows with non-stop action ever afterward. Pure corn. "Regulations" involves yet another scoundrel who comes to a bad end because he didn't pay attention to the rule book. And "The Skit-Tree Planet" involves the puzzle of an alien city that can appear or disappear at will. Nothing really classic here, but solid pieces of craftsmanship from the Golden Age that deserve another look.My ratings are: _The Forgotten Planet_ and The Planet Explorer_: four stars apiece. Collective rating for the Short Stories: three stars. Global score: four stars. Incidently, editor Flint deserves a few bonus points for his detailed and accurate bibliographical notes on the novels and the stories.

"Cyril Judd" was the pseudonym of C.M. Kornbluth and Judith Merril, which they used for two novels, _Gunner Cade_ and Outpost Mars_ (both 1952). _Outpost Mars_ was was originally a three-part serial in _Galaxy_ in 1951 under the title "Mars Child". It was later recycled under the horrendous title of _Sin in Space_ (1961), a version of the novel which is best forgotten.Let us start with the obvious problem of the novel: It hasn't aged very well. In the early fifties, _Outpost Mars_ must have seemed to be a fairly "realistic" and "scientific" picture of what colonial life on Mars would very likely be like-- the antithesis of the Romantic Mars of Edgar Rice Burroughs. Nowadays a colony existing outside of domes, with the colonists using nary a spacesuit, and the miracle pills that allow humans to breathe Martian atmosphere for a limited amount of time, and the archaic forms of radio communication seem to us less definitive than quaint.And yet, what remains is still a fairly well-told tale, with carefully drawn characters. It is a struggle between a utopia and a dystopia. The utopia is the Martian colony of Sun Lake, still desperately struggling for survival, but hoping against hope that they will be the foundation for a fine social civilization to follow. The dystopia is a large mining Combine that intends to take over Mars and rule it with an iron fist.The main leader of the colonists is the idealistic Dr. Tony Hellman. The leaders behind the Combine are the ruthless and greedy magnate Hugo Brenner and Hamilton Bell, Commissioner of Planetary Affairs. Bell is a corrupt politician who failed on Earth, was kicked out to Mars, and would now do anything to get back in with his party. He is in Brenner's pocket. Brenner accuses some member of Sun Lake of stealing a narcotic called marcaine from the Combine. (This is rich, since Brenner is a notorious drug dealer.) It has been tracked to the colony by a device called an electric Bloodhound. A search is started in the hopes that something will be found that will blacken the name of Sun Lake so that Brenner can shut it down.Various character caught up in the struggle of the drug search are Mimi Jonathon, the brave and competent leader of the colony; Anna, Tony's medical assistant and true love; Jim and Polly Kandro and their baby Sunny, the Mars Child of the story; Lieutenant Neely, the decent Army officer; Graham, the cynical reporter from Earth; Hank Radcliff, in love with Mars but blind to the fact that his wife Joan is going insane;  and Learoyd, the last of the old Mars pioneers. ("Call yourselves Marsmen? In six months half of you'll be dead. And the other half'll wish they was," 43.) And finally, almosty impossibly, there will be Martians.There is one thing that you will not find in great abundance in _Outpost Mars_, and that is vivid poetic description. There are a few spots where such things come to life, but not many. Here is one:[The rocket] looked like a bit of the sun at first; that was its braking blasts seen from under. The monster settled swiftly, roaring and flaring in a teasing mathematical progression of successively shorter blasts more closely spaced. When you could see its silvery bulk in profile it was going _pop-pop-pop-pop-pop_, like a machine gun. It settled with a dying sputter and stood on the field two hundred meters from the crowd like a remembered skyscraper. (89)But such scenes are extraordinarily rare. _Outpost Mars_ is an oddly _prosaic_ novel about Mars. There are no detailed descriptions of the Martian lanscape-- no descriptions of the desert, the Rimrock Mountains, or the Martian vegetation. And when the Martians themselves appear, they are sketchily described.. _Outpost_ relies on on character, dialogue, and action to tell its tale. And it is a tale worth telling. But I wish the camera had lingered just a little bit less on the colonists and a little bit more on the landscape.

"A man that studieth revenge keeps his own wounds green."-- Francis BaconThe above quotation is one of the themes of _Thankless in Death_ by J.D Robb (number 38 in her long-running series of futeristic detective stories featuring detectives Eve Dallas and the stalwart Peabody). Not surprisingly, the theme is revenge-- or, to be more precise, _imagined_ revenge for false wrongs.A related theme is _gratitude_. Much of the action of the story takes place round about Thanksgiving. And the murderer-- we know his identity from the get-go-- is an an ungrateful, psychotic, loser who believes that everybody owes him a favor. And that they should pay for it with their lives.The police know _who_ the killer is, and _why_ he murders, and _how_ he kills. But they don't know _where_ he is or who he will kill next. Smoothly told, with a villain whom I fear that police deal with all too often nowadays.

Agatha Christie's _The Big Four_ (1927) was her fifth Hercule Poirot novel. It was written during a slump following her classic _The Murder of Roger Ackroyd_ (1926). At the suggestion of her brother-in-law, Campbell Christie, Agatha reshaped eleven of her previously published stories into a thriller about a syndicate of criminal masterminds plotting to dominate the world. Mrs. Christie reports in her autobiography that _The Big Four_ sold well and was popular with readers. I have no reason to doubt her. But while it is mildly entertaining in spots-- especially where she parodies various detective stories-- it is on the balance awfully melodramatic and silly-- one of the weakest of all of her Poirot novels. It has not worn well over the years.There are some scattered mysteries solved solved in the course of the novel. But they are not Christie at her very cleverest, and they are all loosely reworked to serve the main plot of four criminal geniuses working behind the scenes in order to destroy the existing world order. Some of the crimes strike me as somewhat trivial affairs for taking over the world, and some of the motives for some of the crimes strike me as rather ridiculous. For example, the motive for murdering a chess master late in the novel was downright silly. There are, I think, three basic problems with with this novel. First, it is too loosely constructed. The plot depends too much on coincidence and happinstance. Secondly, the characters are heavily stereotypical-- cardboard Chinese, Russian, and millionaire heavies, seductive temptresses, pompous bureaucrats, and garden variety thugs. And third, the story is told mainly from the point of view of Hastings. Hastings has his virtues, but he is not the brightest crayon in the box. He is simply not the character to have in the center of a labyrinthine spy novel of this sort.A PBS film of _The Big Four_, starring David Suchet was made. Some elements  were retained from the original plot. Other elements were totally thrown out. Still others were drastically revised. Hastings was present (as he should have been), but he played a much smaller role. I do not usually say this, but the film was much superior to the original novel.

_Tom Swift and His Big Tunnel_ (1916) by "Victor Appleton" is the nineteenth edisonade in the long running series authored by Howard R. Garis (of _Uncle Wiggly_ fame). Tom's new invention isn't really anything very imaginative or colorful-- just a powerful explosive for blasting a wall of super hard minerals in a mine. But it sets the stage for a rather enjoyable jungle adventure in Peru.As usual, Mr. Swift warns Tom that his invention will fail and that he had better not continue his project. And there are a series of individuals problems which are all neatly solved by Tom in the Andes mountains through a series of incredible coincidences. Not very realistic, mind you. But rather fun to read about. There is a romantic misunderstanding that is eventually straightened out. And there are some villains who get their just desserts (though there are others who do not). This is certainly nothing classic, but it is passable fun. It is one of the more readable of the old Tom Swift adventures today.

The Great Marvel Adventure series (1906- 1935) was a syndicated Jules Vernelike series of stories authored by "Roy Rockwood" that eventually reached nine volumes. Most (but not all) of these Edisonades were written by the indefatigueable Howard R. Garis (of Uncle Wiggly fame), before he began to write the Tom SWift books. The Great Marvel Adventures were never quite as popular as Tom Swift. But they were a touch better written-- and much more imaginative and colorful.The series was filled with interesting inventions (which were always breaking down at inopportune times), and lots of action and hairbreath escapes. In forty adventures, Tom Swift never made it into outer space. But the heroes of the Great Marvel stories were soon zooming off to Mars, the Moon, and Venus. The series manages to avoid much of the "Empire politics" found in many Edisonades of the day that make them politically offensive by modern standards. There is a bit of racial stereotyping common for pulp writing at the turn of the century-- but then, you can't have everything._Through the Air to the North Pole; or, The Wonderful Cruise of the Electronic Monarch_ (1906) is the first volume in the Edward Stratemeyer syndicated series, and I must say that it is filled with thrill-a-minute, action-packed episodes, with lots of cliffhanging scenes at the end of chapters. Orphans Mark Darrow and Jack Samson take to the road as tramps and hop a freight train. The train goes "runaway" and wrecks. They are rescued from the wreckage by Professor Amos Henderso and his black servant Washington. In no time at all, they are hustled aboard a marvelous electric powered dirigible and are flying to the North Pole. Along the way, they have adventures with screaming eagles, fierce polar bears, walruses, hostile "Equimaux," and other perils. You can't take any of this too seriously, but it is easy to see why many affictionadoes rate the Great Marvel Adventures as worthy predecessors to Carl Claudy's science fiction juveniles of the thirties.

I have a personal favorite list of the five greatest philosophers to read from a strictly literary perspective. They are: Plato, Fredrick Neitzsche, Rene Descartes, John Stuart Mill, and Jean-Jacques Rousseau.* Thus, we may fairly expect _Rousseau's Political Writings_ (1988) to contain some lively writing, regardless of what you may think of the contents. And they do. They do.The book (edited by Alan Ritter and Julia Bondanella and translated by Julia Bondanella) is a Norton Critical Edition. It consists of three main parts: A. Original Political Writngs by Rousseau, B. Backgrounds (contemporary writings by and on Rousseau), and C. Commentaries (modern critiques of Rousseau). Ordinarily, the main value of a Norton Critical Edition is the third section. But in this book, it proves to be a mild disappointment.The Original Writings are: "The Discourse on the Origins and Foundations of Inequality Among Men" (1755), "Discourse on Political Economy" (1755), and _On Social Contract_ (1762). The two essays lay the groundwork for the longer work that followed, giving a detailed picture of Rousseau's theory of man's place in the original state of nature. He does not exactly portray such a man as a "noble savage," but his view of man in this state is more positive than that of many other philosophers. Some readers have assumed that Rousseau wants to recapture this state of nature. Not so. Rousseau is mildly nostalgic about it, but he says that it is a long time past. We can't go home again.In these essays, Rousseau develops a remarkable (some would say "preposterous") theme: that ever since the concept of property was invented, man has been headed downward on a slippery slope of enequality and corruption. Most developments in science, art, and music have added to this corruption and enslavement. Rousseau's ideal state for turning away from all this corruption is Sparta. (I am more of an Athens man myself.)There is, however, in the first essay a marvelous argument for the humane treatment of animals that Rousseau must have just tossed off. We should treat other people humanely, Rousseau argues, not because they are especially rational but because they are creatures of feeling and sensibility. If this is so, then we should treat animals in a similar manner. It could still be used by animal rights activists today._On Social Contract_ was written at the same time as Rousseau's novel _Emile_, and they were published the same year (1762). They were in many ways drastically different books. In _Emile_, Rousseau seemed to be saying, "Sentiment is everything! Feeling is everything! Away with reason!" Yet with _On Social Contract_, Rousseau was writing a tightly reasoned work of political philosophy. Both works managed to offend French Catholics, Genevan Protestants, and materialists all at once. His books were burned. Warrents were sworn out for his arrest in both Paris and Geneva. Rousseau had to seek sanctuary first from Frederick the Great of Prussia and later in England at the invitation of David Hume.The earlier essays were a kind of looking backward: How did we get the way we are? _On Social Contract_ is a kind of looking forward: What is the best form of government for mankind today? We should keep in mind that Rousseau's plan was for a fairly small government-- something akin to a Greek city-state or to his home city of Geneva. And while it was for a kind of democracy, it was not for a representative democracy. Rousseau believed that citizens in a representative democracy would surrender all of their rights and abdicate all of their responsibilities. (Looking at our democracy today, I'm inclined to think that Rousseau may have had a point.)_On Social Contract_ is divided into four main parts: Book One on the rights of man and an overview of government; Book Two on a discussion of Sovreignty; Book Three on the various forms of existing government; and Book Four on the General Will (which runs Rousseau's Contract form of government and which Rousseau considers almost inviolate).Readers taking a close look at Rousseau's democracy may be surprised. It is a democracy, sure enough. But it is a strangely _authoritarian_ democracy. Rousseau's famous words early in the work are: "Man is born free, and everywhere he is in chains" (85). One would expect Rousseau to be advocating a mellow, anarchistic, do-as-you-will sort of government. No such thing. In practice, Rousseau offers a government that offers more in the way of equality than freedom. Perhaps he felt that that was the best that we could do.The Backgrounds section contains a biography of Rousseau, excerpts from his _Confessions_, and comments (positive and negative) by Voltaire, David Hume, Samuel Johnson, Casanova, Adam Smith, Thomas Paine, Immanuel Kant, Joseph de Maistre, John Adams, Benjamin Constant, Pierre-Joseph Proudhon, and Leo Tolstoy. One senses that these men were some of Rousseau's sharpest observers.The modern commentaries are all well-written and thoughtful. But they are all much-of-a-much. They all tend to be democratic, generally positive toward Rousseau, and fairly narrow in their range of interpretations. We could have used an anti-democratic essay, or an anti-Rousseau essay, or an off-trail interpretive essay. We needed more _variety_ among the modern interpreters. Jean Starborinski has a good general study of Rousseau's politics, and Robert Wolff has an excellent critique of part four. Simone Weil's article is interesting, but her plea that we all need to get rid of political parties seems a bit impractical to me.On the balance, though, this remains an excellent introduction to the political writings of one of the major political thinkers of all time.* The absolute _worst_ philosopher from a literary perspective is G.W.F. Hegel. Hands down.

The Declaration of Independence was signed on July 4, 1776. On July 2, 1778, barely two years into the American Revolution, Jean-Jacques Rousseau died of a stroke while walking in the woods at Ermenonville, France. _Reveries of the Solitary Walker_ (1776- 1778) was Rousseau's last book, a work that was clearly not quite finished at the time of his death. It is a series of ten essays, loosely constructed around the theme of walking around Paris and other parts of the countryside. The essays are titled "First Walk," "Second Walk," "Third Walk," and so on.The reader might expect a somewhat Romantic view of Nature by this Romantic philosopher. And finally, in the middle of the book, in the Fifth Walk, there it is: a description of the Island of St. Pierre:The shores of the Lake of Bienn are wilder and more romantic than those of Lake Geneva, since the rocks and woods come closer to the water, but they are no less pleasing. There may be fewer ploughed fields and vineyards, fewer towns and houses, but there is more natural greenery and there are more meadows and secluded spots shaded by woodlands, more frequent and dramatic changes of scenery. (81)Rousseau and Therese Le Vasseur spent only two months on the island, "but I could have spent two years, two centuries and all eternity there without a moment's boredom" (82-83). There "the soul can find a resting-place secure enough to establish itself and concentrate its entire being there" (88). Rousseau underwent a genuine emotional bonding with Nature.In short, the island is a symbol of the thing in Nature that Rousseau would most like to grasp: a peaceful refuge. Unfortunately, by this time in his life, that aspect of Nature is usually beyond Rousseau's reach. For Rousseau is a troubled man:Happiness is a lasting state which does not seem to be made for man in this world. Everything here on earth is in a continual flux which allows nothing to assume any constant form. All things change round about us, we ourselves change, and no one can be sure of loving tomorrow what he loves today. All our plans of happiness in this life are therefore empty dreams. (137)The _Reveries_ contain a greater percentage of complaints than they do Naturalistic idlyls. Why is Rousseau so unhappy in his sixties? The reasons are complicated. For one thing, he has had enemies and has suffered persecution for his ideas from political and religious enemies over the years. That abuse takes its toll after a while. Rousseau also acknowledges that his own actions may have made him a lightning rod for trouble on many occasions:I lurched from fault to fault, error to error, and folly to folly, my imprudent behavior provided those who control my fate with weapons which they have most skilfully used to settle my destiny irrevocably. (28)There was a third source of Rousseau's unhappiness, however-- a psychological one. For Rousseau suffered from delusions of persecution throughout a large portion of his adult life. After David Hume had invited Rousseau to England to escape the wrath of French and Swiss authorities in the wake of the publication of his books _Emile_ and _On Social Contract_ (both 1762), Rousseau's increasing paranoia caused him to imagine that Hume (that most mild-mannered of all philosophers) was "plotting against him". He broke with Hume, and left England for continental Europe. For some time afterward, Rousseau feared that Hume would hunt him down.By 1776, while Rousseau had periods of rationality and lucidity, his mental illness was also very pronounced. His erratic behavior was noticed by many observers. He had withdrawn from contact with large groups of people. Throughout the _Reveries_, Rousseau consistently complains of people plotting against him. The reader must use a bit of judgement in evaluating such passages. When Rousseau recollects a mob stoning his house in Switzerland, he is talking about a real-life event when people _were_ plotting against him. When Rousseau says that doctors and members of the religious order of Oratorians are among his persecutors, I think that we can take this to be a notion purely in the imagination of Jean-Jacques Rousseau. In a similar vein, when Rousseau writes about spies following him about in the streets of Paris, we can probably take this with a grain of salt. By 1776, there were no active political enemies of Rousseau taking an interest in him.It seems pertinent to ask the question: Suppose Rousseau had lived a bit longer and written a few more essays. Would he have been more at peace? There are signs that he might have been. He had rediscovered the joys of studying botany (and he takes great pains to tell us why other scientific studies will not do for him). And while he professed to hold authors and literature in disdain, he admitted his great love of Plutarch. Who knows what other writers he might have embraced in future essays? And in the last essay, he recollected his great love for Madame de Warens. Yes, there were signs that Nature was providing him some comfort.The _Reveries_ is not really a great book. It doesn't have the stature of _Emile_, _On Social Contract_, or _The Confessions_ (completed 1770). But it is an oddly engaging little book that captures the portrait of a brilliant, greatly flawed, and-- in the end-- strangely sympathetic man. Like the character in the Bob Dylan song, he had been through some stormy times and now wanted "to go where it's quiet".

H.P. Lovecraft's _The Classic Horror Stories_ (2013), ed. Roger Luckhurst is an Oxford edition of nine Lovecraftian horror tales and the introduction to his famous essay, _Supernanural Horror in Literature_. It is handsomely packaged, with a good selection of tales, and excellent introductory material and notes. It's the sort of book that you might give as a present to a bright young person unfamiliar with the Old Master of Providence, RI. The sort of person who might relish learning new vocabulary words like "eldrich" and "batrachian". But Lovecraft affictionados will probably already have several collections that are more specialized.The most controversial aspect of this collection was the editorial decision to use the magazine or pulp versions of the stories, because they retain a kind of "pulp energy". (Translation: We didn't have access to the original manuscripts, so we did the next best thing.) The problem, of course, is that the magazine versions were frequently cut in ways that Lovecraft did not like. Purists who are looking for more carefully edited "authorial" texts should check out the collections edited by S.T. Joshi for Penguin.The stories are: "The Horror at Red Hook" (_Weird Tales_, 1927), "The Call of Cthulhu" (_Weird Tales_, 1928), "The Colour Out of Space" (_Amazing_, 1927), "The Dunwich Horror" (_Weird Tales_, 1929), "The Whisperer in the Darkness" (_Weird Tales_, 1931), "At the Mountains of Madness" (_Astounding_, 1936), "The Dreams of the Witch House" (_Weird Tales_, 1933), "The Shadow Over Innsmouth" (_Visionary Press_, 1936), and "The Shadow out of Time" (_Astounding_, 1936). "At the Mountains of Madness" (which was a three-part serial), "Shadow Over Innsmouth" (which was a pamphlet), and "The Shadow out of Time" all received covers. The cover for "The Shadow out of Time" was an excellent but somewhat whimsical one that failed to capture the horror conveyed by Lovecraft's story.Most of the stories in the collection are part of the "Cthulhu (pronounced "thulla") Cycle. But we should be a bit careful here. Lovecraft took a more loose and casual attitude toward stories in this cycle than many authors who worked after him (like August Derleth), who made it a systematic mythology. Some Cthulhu tales seem to be fantasies, while others seem to be science fictional.One of the tales ("The Horror at Red Hook") is early and decidedly minor Lovecraft. The other eight are much better fare, including four of Lovecraft's very best tales. "The Colour Out of Space" is the one about the meteorite with the Unhealthy Blight that spreads all about the New England farm. It has been made into several fairly wretched films over the years. "At the Mountains of Madness" is about the Antarctic expedition that encounters Horrors near the South Pole. "The Shadow Out of Time" involves a member of another expedition-- this one in Australia-- who stumbles into an alien library. I have found that when Lovecraft took the trouble to write stories that were more science fictional, his plots and description tended to be a touch more ingenious. "The Whisperer in the Darkness" is more of a _Weird Tale_ ish fantasy in which the hero makes a narrow escape from a horror in a lonely farmhouse.Lovecraft was an excellent critic of supernatural fiction, but readers may want to get the full-length essay published by Dover after reading the excerpt published in this collection. So. An excellent introduction to Lovecraft. But nothing that Lovecraft fans won't already have in a more definative text.

I first read Howard Phillips Lovecraft's _Supernatural Horror in Literature_ (1945) when I was in high school. But in truth, I was only familiar with a few of the authors that Lovecraft discussed. There was Poe, of course, to whom Lovecraft devotes an entire chapter. And I had read a few stories by Clark Ashton Smith, Lord Dunsany, William Hope Hodgson, and Nathaniel Hawthorne. But the majority of the names, novels, and stories were unfamiliar to me.On rereading the Dover reprint of Lovecraft's essay, now that I have read most of the stories and novels that he discusses, I am impressed with how sharp Lovecraft's critical judgement remains over time. He perhaps underestimates Henry James a bit, but his evaluation of James as a writer of ghost stories is sound. And he was probably one of the first critics to call attention to Charlotte Perkins Gilmans' "The Yellow Wallpaper" ( though, of course, he does not give it a feminist interpretation). Lovecraft interprets Guy de Maupassant's "The Horla" as a tale about a supernatural monster that could be "the vanguard of a horde of extra-terrestrial organisms" (49) ready to invade Earth. The story _could_ be read this way. Or it could be read as the story of a madman's delusions.There are three chapters on the development of the Gothic novel. Lovecraft's discussions of Horace Walpole, Ann Radcliff, Matthew Lewis, Charles Maturin, William Godwin, Mary Shelley, and William Ainsworth are all still dead on target and relevant today. He disapproves of Robert Louis Stevenson's "tendency toward jaunty mannerisms" (43), but he approves of "The Body Snatcher" and _Dr. Jeckyll and Mr. Hyde_.The chapter on Poe is very fine-- an excellent reminder (in spite of modern critical snobbery) why we should still value Poe and why supernatural literature owes a great debt to him. There is also  a discussion of the _Undine_ (1814) myth from continental Europe (in this case, Germany). I had once read the opening portions of a French play about this myth in high school. It was about the love between a water nymph and a young knight. We were told that the story ended tragically. But we were not told any details. It was not until I reread Lovecraft that I learned the full story.The final chapter, on Modern Masters, is also useful as long as you keep in mind that they are what we would now call Old Masters: Arthur Machen, Algernon Blackwood, Lord Dunsany, and M.R. James.Some readers have claimed to find evidences of Lovecraft's racism and anti-semitism in the text of this essay. Lovecraft was not without his prejudices, but I sometimes wonder if we don't read too much into the text. I can find little in this essay that smacks of offensive racial or ethnic bias or stereotyping. I _had_ expected to find Lovecraft's argument that materialists make better writers of the supernatural than True Believers. But that wasnt there, either._Supernatural Horror in Literature_ was first published in the 1927 issue of _The Recluse_, a fan magazine edited by Lovecraft's friend, W. Paul Cook. It went through several revisions in the 1930s, and was serialized in _The Fantasy Fan_ in the early 30s-- but the magazine folded before the serial was complete. The first full-length publication of the revised essay was in _The Outsider and Others_ in 1939-- two years after Lovecraft's death. The first separate book edition was in 1945. The Dover edition follows the 1945 version.

" I am therefore in this point a professed disciple of Apollonius, a scholar of Socrates, I neglect phrases, and labour wholly to inform my reader's understanding, not to please his ear; 'tis not my study or intent to compose neatly, which an orator requires, but to express myself readily and plainly as it happens. So that as a river runs sometimes precipitate and swift, then dull and slow; now direct, then _per ambages_ [winding]; now deep, then shallow; now muddy; then clear; now broad, then narrow; doth my style flow: now serious, then light; now comical, then satirical; now more elaborate, then remiss, as the present subject required, or as at the time I was affected. And if thou vouchsafe to read this treatise, it shall seem no otherwise than the way to an ordinary traveler, sometimes fair, sometimes foul; here champaign, there enclosed; barren in one place, better soil in another: by woods, groves, hills, dales, plains, etc.... I shall lead thee through a variety of objects, that which thou shalt like and surely dislike."-- Robert Burton, _The Anatomy of Melancholy_, 32Izaak Walton's _The Compleat Angler_ (1653) and Robert Burton's _The Anatomy of Melancholy_ (1621) are two classical Menippean satires from the seventeenth century. The Walton is a book about fishing. The Burton is a layman's book about medicine. Much of the advice that Walton gives about fishing is still useful today. The Burton, based heavily on the old Galen model of medicine, is almost totally useless as a medical guidebook today. No reputable doctor today would diagnose patients according to the amount of humours in their bodies, or would bleed them to relieve them of black bile in their blood, or would seriously assume that illnesses were caused by forces from stars or from witches or goblins, or would drill holes in patients' heads to relieve the pain of melancholy.I once visited a neurologist's office for a follow-up exam for something-or-other ( I have forgotten now exactly what it was for). I had a copy of Burton's _Melancholy_ in my hand. The doctor raised his eyebrows when he saw the book. I said: "A noble work of literature... but I sincerely hope that you weren't trained on this in medical school." He never cracked a smile. He said: "We weren't."Why, then, should you read a massive book that has prooved to be so spectacularly, medically _wrong_? Why, simply (as Roland Barthes would say), for "the pleasure of the text". First, there is Burton's near-inimitable baroque style of writing, with his labarinthine sentences, his torturous but oddly rhythmic lists and catalogues, his citations, and his Latin quotations. Next, there is Burton's originality of thought. (He might be frequently _wrong_, but he is never _dull_.) Third, it is a book that sooner or later touches on _everything_: witches and magicians, goblins, education, parts of the body, anger, greed, miseries of scholars, stars, the uses of exercise, the uses of music, lycanthropy, war, old age, fear, love, religion... Burton covers a huge range of topics. His knowledge is truly encyclopedic. And finally, there is Burton's sense of the comic. His _topic_ might be melancholy. But his _treatment_ is frequently witty and funny.Burton's _Anatomy_ provides a multitude of quotations for all kinds of topics. here he is on the upbringing of children. Children can be ruined by physical and verbal abuse. But:Too much indulgence causeth the like, _inepta patris lenitas et facilitas prava_ [the father's gentleness can be misplaced and his indulgence corrupting], whenas, Micio-like, with too much liberty and too great allowance, they feed their children's humours, let them revel, wench, riot, swagger, and do what they will themselves, and then punish them with the noise of musicians. (334)And Burton does seem to be ahead of his time in his denunciation of tobacco:Tobacco, divine, rare, superexcellent tobacco, which goes far beyond all the panaceas, potable gold, and philosophers' stones, a sovereign remedy for all diseases. A good vomit, I confess, a virtuous herb, if it be well qualified, opportunely taken, and medicinally used; but as it is commonly abused by most men, which take it as tinkers do ale, 'tis a plague, a mischief, a violent purger of goods, lands, healtth; hellish, devilish, and damned tobacco, the ruin and overthrow of body and soul. (229)One wonders what Burton would have written about various states today legalizing marijuana! Like his countrymen, Sir Thomas more and sir Francis Bacon, Burton toyed with the idea of a utopia, though perhaps not in quite so much detail:I will have convenient churches, and separate places to bury the dead in, not in churchyards; a _citella_ (in some, not all) to command it, prisons for offenders, opportune market-places of all sorts, for corn, meat cattle, fuel, fish; commodious courts of justice, public halls for all societies, bourses meeting-places, armouries, in which shall be kept engines for quenching fire, artillery gardens, public walks, theaters, and spacious fields alloted for gymnics, sports, and honest recreations, hospitals of all kinds, for children, orphans, old folks, sick men, madmen, soldiers, pest-houses, etc., not built _precario_ [as a favor], or by gouty benefactors... (99)

"We'l rejoice with my brother _Peter_ and his friend, tell tales, or sing Ballads, or make a Catch, or find some harmless sport to content us, and pass away a little time without offence to God or man."-- Izaak Walton, _The Compleat Angler_Izaak Walton (1593-1683), ironmonger, biographer, and fisherman may be said to have been a man who valued the contemplative over the active life. In today's world of hustle and bustle and time clocks, there is something to be said for a man like Walton, who knows how to take it slow and easy. His masterpiece, _The Compleat Angler_ (begun 1653), is in part a practical guide to fishing. For many years, it could be found in fishermen's creels. But it is also in part a praise of the pastoral life, which contributes to its charm:Look! under that broad _Beech-tree_, I sate down, when I was last this way a fishing, and the birds in the adjoyning Grove seemed to have a friendly contention with an Eccho, whose dead voice seemed to live in a hollow tree, near to the brow of that Primrose-hill; there I sate viewing the silver streams glide silently towards their center, the tempestuous Sea; yet, sometimes opposed by rugged roots, and pebble stones, which broke their waves, and turned them into foam: and sometimes I beguil'd time by viewing the harmless Lambs, some leaping securely in the cool shade, whilst others sported themselves in the chearful Sun; and saw others craving comfort from the swoln Udders of their bleating Dams. (79)Shortly after this scene, we hear a young milkmaid sing Christopher Marlow's "The Passionate Shepherd to His Love," which begins: "Come live with me and be my love/ And we will all the pleasures prove..." Her Mother sings Sir Walter Raleigh's "The Nymph's Reply to the Shepherd," which begins: "If all the world and Love were young/ And truth in every Shepherds tongue..." Yes, _The Compleat Angler_ is steeped in a vision of the pastoral. And this in turn is related to Walton's philosophy of the contemplative and fishing:And first, I shall tell you what some have observed (and I have found it to be a real truth) that the very sitting by a Rivers side is not only the quietest and fittest place for _contemplation_, but will invite an angler to it: and this seems to maintained by the learned _Pet. du Moulin_, who (in his discussion of the fulfilling of Prophesies) observes, that when God intended to reveal any future events or high notions to his Prophets, he then carried them either to the _Deserts_, or to the _Sea-shore_, that having so separated them from amidst the press of _people_ and _business_, and the cares of the world, he might settle their mind in a quiet repose, and there make them fit for Revelation. (40)For this reason, Walton says, ministers are forbidden to hunt but allowed to fish. Angling, it is recognized, can be a source of divine inspiration.Some modern readers may be enchanted by some of Walton's geography, especially when he relies heavily on Aristotle, Pliny, and Lucian:As namely of a River in _Epirus_, that puts out any lighted Torch, and kindles any Torch that was not lighted. Some Waters being drunk cause madness, some drunkenness, and some laughter to death. The River _Selarius_ in a few hours turns a rod or wand to stone: and our _Cambden_ mentions the like in _England_, and the like in _Lochmere_ in _Ireland_. There is also a river in _Arabia_, of which all the sheep that drink thereof have their wool turned into a Vermillion colour. And one of no less credit than _Aristotle_, tells us of a merry river, (the River _Elusina_) that it dances at the noise of musick... (41)When he relies on more modern sources, his accounts may have seemed equally fantastic to contemporary readers. But they were actually fairly scientifically accurate for their day. Here he draws from Montaigne's _Essays_:The _Cuttle-fish_ will cast a long gut out of her throat, which (like as an Angler doth his line) she sendeth forth and pulleth in again at her pleasure, according as she sees some little fish come near to her; and the _Cuttle-fish_ (being then hid in the gravel) lets the smaller fish nibble so near to her, that she may leap upon her, and then catches and devours her: and for this reason some have called this fish the _Sea-Angler_.The only correction I would make is that it is the Sea-Angler, not the Cuttle-fish, that angles for other fish. Even when Walton is engaged in straightforward description of angling, you can find a kind of baroque elegance to his prose:First, let your Rod be light, and very gentle, I take the best to be of two pieces, and let not your Line exceed (especially for three or four link next to the hook) I say, not exceed three or four hairs at the most, though you may fish a little stronger above in the upper part of your line: but if you can attain to angle with one hair, you shall have more rises, and catch more Fish. (105)Perhaps it would do well to back up a bit and give a bit of background about the book itself. The first edition (by Walton) was published in 1653. It went through three more editions by Walton in 1655, 1661, and 1668 respectively. In 1676, Walton approached his friend and fellow angler, Charles Cotton to write some material on trout and grayling fishing. The fifth edition of 1676 features Charles Cotton's "Part Two". Most modern versions of _The Compleat Angler_ are the Walton-Cotton fifth edition, the most complete version.The general format of the book is that of a dialogue. In Part I, it is between Piscator (the fisherman), his brother Peter, Venator (a hunter), Auceps (a Faulkner), and various shepherds, milkmaids, and hostesses (conveniently skilled in cleaning and dressing fish). They talk about the beauties of nature, the wonders of the elements, the virtues of their favorite sport, or the teachings of the Bible. And they frequently break out into rounds of song. Here is a verse of a song sung by Piscator:"_Of Recreation there is noneSo free as Fishing is alone;All other pastimes do no lesseThan mind and body both possesse:My hand alone my work can doe,So I can fish and study too._" (90)Pages 190 and 191 contain an angler's song set to music.Part II (the section by Cotton) is also in the form of a dialogue. This time, it is between Piscator, Junior (adopted son of Piscator) and Viator (the one-time hunter of the first dialogues). There are no songs or bursts of poetry, or stylized pastoral scenes with Lambs and Maidens and Shepherds. But there are some lovely descriptions of the English countryside and English rivers: "Why this Sir is called _Bently_ Brook, and is full of very good Trout and Grayling; but so encumbered with wood in many places, as is troublesome for an Angler" (250). Later, "the river _Wye_" consists of "a black water at the fountain" but "becomes a most delicate clear River, and breeds admirable Trout and Grayling" (252-253). But Piscator Junior's great love is the River _Dove_, "which divides the two Couties of _Derby_ and _Stafford_ for many Miles together" (250) and is known for "the swiftness of its current" (250).But the primary value of the section by Cotton is its practical value to serious fishermen: It's a wealth of information about how to tie flies, what flies to use during what months of the year, and angling strategies for outwitting the craftiest of trout and grayling._The Compleat Angler_ belongs to a very old form of writing called Menippean satire that includes works as varied as Francois Rabelais' _Gargantua and Pantagruel_, Robert Burton's _Anatomy of Melancholy_, Jonathon Swift's _Gulliver's Travels_, and Lewis Carroll's Alice books. Northrup Frye (1957) states that Menippean satire is characterized by its "ability to handle abstract ideas and theories" (309), its use of stylized characters who are "mouthpieces of the ideas they represent" (309), and a loose structure that loans itself to digressions and discussions.It has been said that next to the King James Bible and the Book of Common Prayer, _The Complete Angler_ is the most frequently reprinted seventeenth century English book. Well, perhaps. But how much is it actually _read_ today? That is much harder to ascertain. Do yourself a favor. Read this charming classic of Menippean satire. Let yourself be carried away to a world of ease and contemplation. You don't have to be a fisherman to enjoy the book. But it helps._Addendum_: I daresy that there are several excellent editions of this classic in print. But my favorite remains the Oxford World's Classics edition (1982), with the original introduction from 1935 by John Buchan and more up-to-date notes by editor John Buxton. From them, you may learn that Vergil wasn't really buried in Rome; that Charles Cotton had a cave on his property in which he hid from creditors; that according to Albertus Magnus (1193?- 1280), a certain type of frog did not eat at all in August; and many other vital pieces of information.

Roger Zelazny's _Jack of Shadows_ (1971) was originally a two-part serial in _Fantasy and Science Fiction_ that year. It was nominated for the Hugo in 1972, but lost to Philip Jose Farmer's _To Your Scattered Bodies Go_. _Jack_ remains  an interesting, quirky, and (ultimately) somewhat grim fantasy. It's not quite as entertaining as some of Zelazny's later novels like _Doorways in the Sand_ (1976) or _Roadmarks_ (1979). But I believe that it is a bit more substantial. I would place it alongside _The Dream Master_ (1966), _This Immortal_ (1966), and _Lord of Light_ (1967)-- Zelazny's best.The novel is set on a future Earth that no longer rotates and is watched over by the demonic Morningstar, who says that he is waiting for the sun to rise. The "brightside" of Earth is governed by the rules and laws of science, while the darkside is governed by the rules and laws of magic. Shadowjack the thief from the Dark Side is captured, beheaded, and resurrected. In short order, he breaks the Compact under which all Dark Side magicians abide, and now finds many hands against him.After engineering a near-impossible escape from his archenemy, the Lord of the Bats, Jack escapes to the Bright Side of Earth. Shadows are not so plentiful there, but the forces of magic are not so powerful, and he is able to lose them for a while. There he uses computers to aid him in his next steps toward widespread revenge.Jack is brave, and Jack is clever, and Jack is determined. But Jack has no soul. He will readily use people and toss them aside, and he thinks nothing of bringing the whole world to ruins simply to satisfy his own notions of revenge.I am reminded of an old folktale about Davy Crockett. It seems that during one bitter cold winter, the gears of machinery at the North Pole that made the world turn around iced solid and froze. Davy trudged up to the North Pole, gave the gears a solid kick, and started the Earth a-turnin' again. Jack is something like that. But he causes a _lot_ more chaos along the way.

I once talked a bit with the essayist Sam Pickering about how he came to be such an expert on flowers and plants. He said that when he vacationed on the family farm in Nova Scotia, there was often nothing to do except walk around and look at the plants. He has become a collector of nature books-- "the field guides, not the Annie Dillard kind". Some of them are new. Some of them, I know from his essays, are very old.I haven't got the slightest idea whether Sam Pickering has read _Wicked Plants: The Weed That Killed Lincoln's Mother & Other Botanocal Atrocities_ (2009) by Amy Stewart. But I do believe that it is the sort of book that he would enjoy. It is not overly mystical or transcendental, it is loaded with colorful facts, and it has realistic etchings of the plants which are labeled deadly, illegal, painful, intoxicating, destructive, or merely offensive. The etchings, by Briony Morrow-Cribbs, are in the style of old-fashioned nineteenth century nature books.The plants themselves are arranged alphabetically, from _Acondite_ (deadly) and Ayahuasca Vine_ (illegal) to _White Snakeroot_ and _Yew_ (both deadly). It is the White Snakeroot that is belived to have poisoned Nancy Hanks Lincoln via infected cow's milk. An Illinois doctor named Anna Bixby determined the cause of "milk sickness" as early as 1834, but few authorities listened to her (after all, only a _woman_ doctor). It was not until the 1920s that the plant was widely recognized as dangerous.The yew tree, with its roots "wrapt about the bones" of skeletons in European churhyards, has a wood that during the time of ancient Rome made drinking vessels intended for suicide-- or murder. Today, some chemicals from the yew are used in the treatment of cancer.A few states today (like Colorado) have made Marijuana legal since this book was written. I am not sure that all will be well as the result of this Great Social Experiment. The human capacity for folly is ever present in ventures of this kind. In any event, there is a section on Cannabis Sativia and its history, concluding "98 percent of the United States' eradication efforts are directed at weeds" (111).Anybody who has lived in the South any length of time knows about Kudzu, originally from Japan, which _seemed_ like a great idea for gardeners and farmers back in 1937. Nobody predicted how much the vine would run rampant. Stewart says that it now "covers seven million acres in the United States" (88). The city of Chattanooga once invested a small amount of money in some goats to crop hills of kudzu in the city limits. But now the politicians (always penny-wise and pound foolish) cut off the funding. The goats (popular with the public and with tourists) are gone. The kudzu is still there.Other plants of interest include arrow poisons, betel nut, castor bean (the source of a famous murder), mandrake, opium poppy, tobacco, and the suicide tree. There are sections on fatal fungus (such as death cap and false morel), the devil's bartender (plant sources for intoxicants), carnivorous plants, and the lawn of death (on destructive grasses). I had long known that Johnson grass was a formidable weed. To get rid of it, do not chop it. You must uproot it and lay it on a rock to bake in the sun. But I had not known before that it was poisonous.There are many more plants of interest. I promise that you will read this delightful book much more quickly than you expected. There is an excellent bibliography of plant-related books, all fairly up-to-date. And there is information on six famous Poison Gardens, for those that like such things.

Keith Laumer's _Retief: Ambassador to Space_ (1969) is the fifth Retief book and the third Retief collection. If you want to keep a rough chronology in mind (these things can probably never be _too_ exact with the retief tales), it was preceeded by the novels _Retief's War_ (1966) and _Retief and the Warlords_ (1968) and was followed by the collection,_Retief of the CDT_ (1971)._Ambassador to Space_ consists of seven adventures of Jaime Retief from _If_ between 1964 and 1967. Over the years, various artists had a go at illustrating Retief stories: Dick Francis, Virgil Finlay, Nodel... But the champion Retief illustrator was Jack Gaughan, whose pen-and-ink style was perfectly suited to the light, dashing stories. Only one of the stories in this collection was a cover story-- "Trick or Treaty," in the August, 1965 issue. But it was a spectacular, Halloweenish affair by Gaughan showing Retief and some centaurlike aliens dodging about some colorful off-world architecture.The stories are: "Giant Killer," "The Forbibben City," "Grime and Punishment," "Dam Nuisance," "Trick or Treaty," "Forest in the Sky," and "Truce or Consequences". The first story recounts how Ambassador Pinchbottle refused to listen to Retief and consequently contracted to fight a dinosaur by the next sundown. Need we say that the Ambassador was not quite up to the task? We need not. In the second tale, the Groaci and the Blugs are planning a planetary takeover during a peace conference. (Is nothing sacred?) Retief enlists the aid of some scrappy denizens from an underground city to spike the plot. In the third story, the decisive Mr. Raisinger orders some rats poisoned-- which breaks an ecological cycle and leads to an onslaught of mud. Lots of mud.The fourth tale involves some double crosses by the Groaci involving the uncalled-for present of a giant dam. In the fifth tale, it is some centaurs who are the bully-boys. They are delightfully put down by Retief and a family of carnies before they can start their invasion of the planet they had targeted for plunder. The penultimate tale is about a very strange gaseous planet with a most unusual ecosystem and an ambasadorial expedition that goes onward, upward... and out of control. The last story involves two sides in a Civil War enthusiastically fighting one another... until Retief reveals who their revered ancestors really were... and that unbeknownst to each other, the factions switched sides!Fans of the Bad Boy Diplomat of the _Corps Diplomatiques Terrestrienne_ will not need me to recommend these stories, but I do so anyway. They are first class entertainment; and as I have stated elsewhere, the novelette is the ideal length for a Retief tale. They are a perfect balance of action and wit.Perhaps it might be useful to close with a note about the spelling of Retief's first name. Early stories and books used the spelling "Jame". The Berkeley paperback that I used for this review uses this spelling as well. For a long time, that was the spelling that I used in my reviews. But later reprints, for reasons best known to God, jazzed up the spelling to "Jaime". This seems to be the more common spelling now, and so I have (somewhat reluctantly) modernized my spelling.

Fritz Leiber's _The Green Millenium_ (1953) was a satire on many of the darker sides of life in the early fifties. Leiber then fell silent for four years (largely, he has said, the result of his battle with alcoholism). But in the late fifties, he came back in force. One of his comeback works was the two-part _Galaxy_ serial, _The Big Time_, in 1958. The serial won the Hugo for best novel that year-- the fourth novel to do so.As numerous critics have pointed out, and as Leiber himself has confirmed in an introduction to the Collier Books edition to the novel, _The Big Time_ is in effect a kind of prose play, observing the unities of space and time. Thus, Leiber has characters from millions of years up and down the space-time continuum meeting in a single setting: the Place, a rest & recuperation center ordinarily removed from the fluctuations of time.The action of the plot covers only a few hours of time-- but a period of increasing suspense as elements of the Change War are brought into the Place, thus complicating the lives of all who live therein.The novel opens with a bang when three soldiers enter the Place from three different times-- a Nazi soldier from World War II, an English soldier (and poet) from World War I, and a Roman legionaire. In no time at all, insults are exchanged, there is a swordfight, and blood is shed. The verbal dueling does not stop.A second round of _very_ unusual soldiers comes a bit later with a tale of grim defeat before the Snake forces at Crete. Their not-so-bright commander rigidly follows orders and brings with them a tactical nuclear bomb. In the midst of the hysterics and dramatics that follow, the Major Maintainer-- the device that keeps the environment of the Place running-- vanishes. (The bomb is still very much there.) Where is it? Who took it? And Why?Leiber stated that he wanted his characters to be markedly individualistic, with recognizeable voices of their own. Here is Greta Forzane, party girl, formerly of Chicago, who narrates the novel:"The place outside the cosmos where I and my pals do our nursing job I simply call the Place. A lot of my nursing consists of amusing and humanising Soldiers fresh back from raids into time. In fact, my normal title is Entertainer, and I've got my silly side, as you'll find out." (7)The Place is run by Sidney Lessingham, originially an actor in Elizabethan London:"Look you, masters this is a Recuperation Station and I am running it as such. A plague on all operations! I care not if the frame of things disjoints and the whole Change War goes to ruin, but you, warrior maid, are going to rest and drink more wine, slowly, before you tell your tale and your colleagues are going to be properly companioned... Beau, and you love us, give us a lively tune." (42)Bruce Marchant, the English poet, is in love with words (especially his own) and old things slipping away. Here he is, inciting a revolt against the Spiders:"Perhaps there are some sentimentalists who would rather die than live in a world without the _Summa_, the Field Equations, _Process and Reality_, _Hamlet_, Matthew, Keats, and the _Odyssey_, but our masters are practical creatures, ministering to the needs of those rugged souls who want to go on living no matter what." (63)

Ah, yes. The bicentenntial was a pretty good year for science fiction novels. Roger Zelazny made a strong return with this three-part serial in _Analog_, along with some handsome John Schoenherr illustrations. And _Doorways in the Sand_ (1976) was nominated for the Hugo and the Nebula. But Joe Haldeman's _The Forever War_ was the impossible-to-beat juggernaut that year.Still, _Doorways_ is really a pretty good science fiction entertainment. I have read it at least half a dozen times over the the years without tiring of it, and I will read it again in the future. I grew up in the University of the South at Sewanee, famed for its Neo-gothic and Georgian architecture. A lot of the buildings that I grew up among are surely a lot like the university buildings of Zelazny's fictitious university that his hero, Fred Cassidy, loves to climb. Ah, well. Surely these fictitious buildings are taller. Steeper. More crooked. More numerous. And the buildings at Sewanee didn't house mysterious machines attended by not-too-efficient guards. But the basic architecture would be the same, with the spires and towers and turrets and battlements. And we did have our share of eccentric professors and unhelpful faculty advisors.Fred Cassidy is a perpetual undergraduate. Because of a peculiarity in his uncle's will, he will recieve money for his education _until he recieves a diploma_. He has managed to postpone that evil day for  thirteen years, outsmarting a series of faculty advisors determined to see him graduate. The one thing that gets Fred in trouble is his acrophilia-- his love of open places-- which takes the form of climbing university buildings.Fred's world might have remained fairly ordered and peaceful. But suddenly, everybody decides that Fred has acquired an alien artifact called the starstone, and everbody seems to be after it or after him-- a disreputable geology professor, a couple of gangsters, a government agent, several alien cops, some alien baddies, an AI "recorder" that pipes information to Fred, and a mysterious player in the background. Noboby seems to believe Fred when he says that he doesn't have the stone and doesn't know where it is. In order to survive one or more of these factions, Fred finds himself becoming involved in one madcap caper after another... and getting in another mess more complicated than the last one he was in.Readers may notice a certain "jerkiness" or "jumpiness" to the chapters. One chapter will end in what seems to be something of a cliffhanging scene. The next chapter will open with quite a different dramatic scene. Chapters often seem to begin _in medias res_-- in the middle of the chapter-- and sometimes there is nothing to do except to hang on and figure out by flashback how the hero got out of a cliffhanging situation. But eventually, it all does hang together.I believe that it was Ben Bova who first noted that _Doorways_ is the sort of novel that Raymond Chandler might have written had he lived to write science fiction. _Doorways_ is a touch more tightly written than your typical Chandler novel. But it has a Chandleresque hero and a Chandleresque plot. And there is a bit of poetry. But the poetry is all Zelazny, not imitation Chandler. That is all to the good.

I will admit it. Norman Spinrad's _The Iron Dream_ (1972) is a wicked and devastating satire that has affected how I read a lot of science fiction today. It is based on a very clever joke. Imagine an alternate world in which Adolph Hitler dropped out of politics when young, emigrated to the United States, and became a science fiction author. Here we have his 1954 Hugo-winning masterpiece, _Lord of the Swastika_, complete with rather pompous scholarly commentary.The hero is Feric Jagger, the blond-haired, blue-eyed "genotypically pure human" (13) who is concerned with keeping his home country of Helder free from "mongrelized mutations" like "Blueskins, Lizardmen, Harlequins" (14), "Toadmen" (14), "Eggheads" (15), "Parrotfaces" (15) and worse-- most of them slimy.In short order, Jagger has headed up a mob and killed a despised Dominator (something like a Jewish plotter). Then he takes charge of a gang of petrol-driven motorcycle thugs whom he renames Knights of the Swastika. From there on, we have a series of increasingly bloody victories as Feric leads his leather-garbed SS followers under the sign of the Swastika and using phallic weapons against the mutants. The last sentence of the novel is a masterpiece of triumphant awfulness.Spinrad's devastating point: There is not really a lot of difference between the tasteless, violent, and immoral novel written by "Adolf Hitler" and many "space operas" being written by modern writers today. Maybe there should be a time when in evaluating science fiction-- even space opera-- when our moral compass and sense of good taste should kick in. Several space operas that have struck me as offensively bad-- of the sort that Spinrad is satirizing in his novel-- are E.E. Smith's _Skylark DuQuesne_ (1966), L. Ron Hubbard's _Battlefield Earth_ (1982), and Colin Kapp's _Patterns of Chaos_ (1972).The novel does have a weakness. While it is an _effective_ joke, it is also a rather _tiresome_ one. It does go on and on to make its point. Yet at the same time, I don't see very well what else Spinrad could have done. Once he set up his satire, he pretty much had to ride it out to the end. _The Iron Dream_ should serve as a reminder that even space opera, even military science fiction, should have a moral content. Too many readers nowadays forget that basic truth.

The original notes for _The Demolished Man_ in Alfred Bester's Commonplace Book had something to do with police who could read the future with television screens. Horace L. Gold, the cantankerous but brilliant editor of _Galaxy_ magazine, suggested a telapathic police force in a telapathic society. Bester took the idea and ran with it.The result was a dazzling, three-part serial that ran in _Galaxy_ early in 1952 and was snapped up in book form the next year. It was the first novel to win the Hugo, and it is hard to imagine a better choice. The novel remains a real classic in the field, one of the all-time classics of science fiction.Bester plunges us into a world unlike any other that we have experienced before. A world where some characters have names like Samuel @kins, Duffy Wyg&, and Jo 1/4 maine. A world where time is told for all planets of the solar system on a watch at the same time. A world where a sizeable minority of the population is telepathic and can weave fantastic mental webs of conversation with one another, one-on-one or at parties. A world where most of the police are telepathic but are governed in their rules of evidence by a computer named Ol' Man Mose.In this world, we watch Ben Reich, a non-telepathic millionaire who swears: "I wouldn't change looks with the devil. I wouldn't change places with God" (12). Nevertheless, Reich is haunted by nightmares of a Man With No Face. Reich is convinced that the No Face means that it is the Face of Murder-- though his peeper psychiatrist says that it isn't so. Reich plots a murder against his business rival, D'Courtney. He carries out his plan, it goes somewhat askew, but the crime is committed. And, incredibly, Reich, a nontelepath, manages to stay a jump ahead of the telepathic police.Pitted against Reich is the determined ist-class telepath and cop, Lincoln Powell. Powell finds himself repeatedly frustrated from building a case against Reich. To Powell, this is more than just a murder case. Reich is a dangerous force who can play havoc with society if he is allowed to succeed-- if he escapes demolition.When I first read the novel, I thought that I had caught Bester in a small slip. I should have known better. It wasn't a slip at all. It was a clue to the solution to the novel. But I wasn't clever enough to figure out that solution the first time that I read _The Demolished Man_. Maybe you will. But my money is on Bester.When I reread the novel for review, I was not surprised at all to rediscover favorite sections. There were the opening paragraphs (which I had long ago memorized because of their operatic punch): "In the endless universe there is nothing new, nothing different. What may appear exceptional to the minute mind of man may be inevitable in the Infinite Eye of God" (10). There is the nonsense verse that Reich uses as an aid to murder that comes to haunt him:"Tenser, said the Tensor.Tenser, said the Tensor.Tension, aprehension,And dissention have begun.Tension, apprehension,And dissention have begun." (48)There is the telepathic party at Lincoln Powell's house that must be witnessed by the reader to be appreciated. There are the assassination attempts on Powell that go askew-- but not by much. And there is Reich's final, surrealistic showdown with the Man With No Face.What _did_ surprise me on rereading the novel were several sections that I had not really noticed before. There was the marvelously funny scene at Sam @kin's therapy clinic on Venus, where he is desperately trying to train nontelepaths into telepaths. And there is the manhunt on Spaceland, a kind of outer space theme park, where Reich is on the run and in danger of killing again.A terrific novel, full of dazzlement and style and suspense. And, as I found, something new on repeated rereadings.
