Robert A. Heinlein's _Double Star_ (1956) was initially a three-part serial in _Astounding_ in 1956, with some marvelous illustrations by Kelly Freas. It was the third novel to win the Hugo for best novel. And while some critics have grumped a bit that _Double Star_ is a touch "lightweight" for a proper Hugo winner, it is really rather hard to dislike the novel. It is first-class entertainment.The title refers, not to the double sun of an extra-solar planet-- all the action takes place within our own solar system-- but to the rather complicated relationship between acting and politics. Heinlein envisions a Solar System Government of the future that is a democratic government. But not a democracy modeled on 20th century America. It is a parliamentary system with an Emperor and Empire, much like 19th century Britain. Citizens in the Empire have some individual rights... But they are limited and by no means equal. Martians and Venusian natives have no rights.There are two political parties vying for power: A majority party called the Humanists, and a minority libertarian party led by a fellow named John Joseph Bonforte. The Humanists are Earth-firsters in their politics. The libertarians favor making Martians and Venusians citizens. Bonforte is about to undergo an important ceremony on Mars that could turn the tide in favor of his party. But before the ceremony can occur, an extreme wing of Humanists kidnaps him. Did I mention that politics in this future society is _very_ down and dirty?Enter Lorenzo Smythe, stage left. Into a bar. Lorenzo (Larry to his friends) is a moderately talented, out-of-work actor who looks just enough like Bonforte to impersonate him. Just for a little while. Until, hopefully, Bonforte can be rescued. Only, of course, bit by bit, things become more complicated. The impersonation has to be extended. And the role becomes more tricky.In lesser hands, we would have had a routine melodrama. But Heinlein understands that this is a story of character. Everything rests upon Lorenzo Smythe, the first-person narrator of the story. There is much to like about Lorenzo. He is charming, smart, talented at his trade, and full of a certain degree of worldly experience. He is full of anecdotes about the acting life. But he is also an alcoholic. And he is vain, selfish, egotistical, apolitical, and ignorant of a great many things outside of his profession: "The long-jump ships such as the _Tom Paine_, torchships that is, are (so they tell me) the real thing, making use of E equals MC squared, or is it M equals EC squared? You know-- the thing Einstein invented" (73-74). He has spent a great many years Looking Out For Number One. He finds it hard to understand others who do not live by that code.Here is Lorenzo Smythe (the self-styled "Great Lorenzo") fairly early in the novel:I had never meddled in politics. My father had warned against it. "Stay out of it, Larry," he had told me solemnly. "The publicity you get that way is bad publicity. The peasants don't like it." I had never voted-- not even after the amendment of '98 made it easy for the floating population... to exercise franchise. (54)We know people like Lorenzo. People who say that "all politicians are crooks". People who never vote. People who get the politicians that they deserve. People who loudly complain about the politicians whom they get. Yet when Lorenzo is told that he will probably be replaced by another actor-- is in effect given a chance to "get out of politics"-- he becomes furious and demands to know why. And a spaceman takes Lorenzo down a peg:"You asked for it, shipmate. See here, a man in my profession contracts to take a heap to Ganymede, that means he will pilot that pot to Ganymede or die trying. He doesn't get fainthearted and try to welsh while the ship is being loaded. You told me you would take this job-- no 'ifs' or 'ands' or 'buts'-- you took the job. A few minutes later, there is a fracas, you lose your nerve. Later on, you try and run out on me at the field. Only ten minutes ago you were screaming to be taken back dirtside. Maybe you are a better actor than Trowbridge. I wouldn't know. But I know we need a man who can be depended on not to lose his nerve when the time comes. I understand that Trowbridge is that sort of bloke." (45)Lorenzo is able to translate this into show business terms: "He was telling me that I was not a trouper" (46). And he knows that the criticism is just. He becomes determined to be a trouper. And slowly, as he learns to play the role of a lifetime, he learns how to become a greater man than he was. When I reread the novel, a lot of favorate scenes came back to me: The byplay between Lerenzo and Dak Broadbent in the bar, the takeoff from Earth under two gravities (not as tough as it could be, but tough enough), the therapy in which Lorenzo is cured of his prejudice against Martians, the Martian ceremony, the scene in which Lorenzo learns that winning an election isn't necessarily good, and the audience with the Emperor and the electric trains. Finally, there is the ending. This is what a politician should always remember (but which all too many of them forget).Yes, indeed. This is a novel worthy of its award.

There was serious science fiction that dealt with religion in mainstream science fiction back in the 1940s. But it was fiction that was always treating religion religion as a sociological movement: Robert A. Heinlein's "If This Goes On--" (1940) and Fritz Leiber's _Gather, Darkness!_ (1943). As James Blish (1964) noted in his classic essay on religion and science fiction, by the 1950s, we had the atomic bomb. Suddenly, we began to realize that Armageddon was not a distant prospect. It was something that we could bring upon ourselves today. Science fiction writers began exploring other aspects of religion, such as myth and theology.Blish's own novel, _A Case of Conscience_ (1958) was a serious attempt to explore Catholic theology against a science fictional background (though Blish himself was not Catholic). It won the Hugo for 1959, against some stiff competitors. It is not hard to see why. It was one of the greatest pieces of religious science fiction to emerge from the fifties, and the sophistication and subtlety of Blish's ideas are still challenging to the modern reader.Nevertheless, I am not completely satisfied with the novel. The problem is not with Blish's profoundity of thought but with the structure of the novel. It is composed of two parts. Part One is the title novella (originally published in a 1953 issue of _If_) set on an alien planet. Here, Father Ruiz-Sanchez, a Jesuit priest, is working as a biologist on a scientific team on the planet Lithia, populated by a strange, ethical, peaceful reptilian race of creatures. Their mission is to determine whether Earth and Lithia should maintain contact with one another. The physicist on the team favors contact, but not for a very good reason; he believes that the planet would make a good "weapons dump". Ruiz is against contact. But he admits that his reasons are rather nebulous. His religious training has started to trigger alarm bells. He becomes convinced that Lithia is in fact a vast, demonic trap.At the close of Part One, we know _why_ Ruiz-Sanchez thinks the planet is a trap. And because his reasoning is based upon a long discredited line of Catholic theology, he is at this point expecting to become excommunicated by the Church. We are left to wonder: is he right or wrong? Part Two centers around what happens when an alien egg is taken to Earth from Lithia. We see it hatch into an alien, who becomes a demonic, rabble-rousing alien. He causes no end of trouble on Earth. We see that Ruiz-Sanchez was right in every particular, we see all hell begining to break loose... and there is finally an ending that even the most charitable of critics must allow was pulled out of Blish's hat. It completely strains credulity.I have no way of knowing for sure, but I rather suspect that most readers who admire _A Case of Conscience_ tend to think in terms of the first half of the novel, when questions are being raised, rather than the second half of the novel, when all the questions are answered. It is certainly the better half of the novel by far._A Case of Conscience_ was the first of a "thematic trilogy" called After Such Knowledge. The trilogy title comes from a line from T.S. Eliot's "Gerontion": "After such knowledge, what forgiveness?" The later two novels in the trilogy are the historical novel, _Doctor Mirabilis_ (1968) and the fantasy, _Black Easter and The Day After Judgement_ (1980). All of these works deal with the issue of whether the pusuit of secular knowledge is a waste of the mind or even evil. Well, I suppose that it can be. But before we all start jumping up and waving our fists and ranting against Secular Humanism, perhaps we should remember another truth: The same could be said of religious knowledge as well._References_: Blish, James (1964)."Cathedrals in Space". In William Atheling, Jr. (ed.), _The Issue at Hand_. Chicago: Advent, 1973, 52-79.Leiber, Fritz (1964). "After Such Knowledge". In _The Book of Fritz Leiber_. New York: DAW, 1974, 115-117.

Mark Clifton and Frank Riley's _They'd Rather Be Right_ (1956) was the second novel to win the Hugo award. It is on many people's lists as the _worst_ novel ever to win a Hugo. There is perhaps some justification for this claim. Much of the science is dated by now. (The computer Bossy has vacuum tubes rather than transisters.) Much of the dialogue is in the form of rather long, didactic speeches. And there are times when the authors tell a bit more than they show.And yet... Is the novel really all that bad? I'll grant you that it isn't a deathless classic, but I don't see that it is an outright stinker, either. _They'd Rather Be Right_ (aka, _The Forever Machine_) is the third of a series of three stories. The first two are "Crazy Joey" (_Astounding_, 1953) and "Hide! Hide, Witch!" (_Astounding_, 1953).* The first tale introduces the telepath Joe Carter as a boy. The second tale introduces the supercomputer "Bossy" that must be hidden (along with two of her creators) from the mobs. The title refers to the verse:"Hide! Hide, Witch!The good folk come to burn thee,Their keen enjoyment hid beneathThe gothick mask of duty."The novel extends the story. It was first serialized in _Astounding_ in 1954, along with some lovely Kelly Freas illustrations. As the the novel opens, the scientist creators of "Bossy" are on the run from both the F.B.I. and mobs of common people. They are being aided by the telepath, Joe Carter, once a graduate student of theirs, to disappear into the underworld. Bossy has been disassembled but not destroyed, and the plan is to reassemble her.Bossy does get reassembled. She now has the power to answer virtually _any_ question given the adequate amount of data. This alone makes her valuable-- and dangerous. But Joe has discovered another power for Bossy as well. She can treat people in a kind of therapy that can "rejuvinate" that person and give them youth and virtual immortality. There is, however, a price. To undergo the therapy, one must "relax" and release one's basic prejudices-- admit that you could be wrong about your most basic beliefs. Most people, Joe says, would "rather be right-- and die" (53) than live forever.Bossy's first patient is the elderly prostitute Mabel, a woman who has comitted many sins but who has few illusions about herself. (Mabel is harboring Joe, the scientists, and Bossy in her establishment.) I found the episodes in which Mabel's friends engage in criminal activities to keep her alive during the rejuvination process to be fun. And the later scene in which the rejuvinated Mabel makes a monkey out of the pompous psychiatrist at the police station was hilarious.The authors envision a near-future society governed by a mob mentality and love of conformism that is accepted across the country (much like the McCarthyism and H.U.A.C. and witchhunting that were still fresh when the novel was written). One of the scientists, Hoskins, reflects on the disasterous effect that this has had on science alone:Now, for almost half a century, there had been nothing new. There was apparent progress, of course. The cookbook engineers were able to mix up new batches from old ingredients. There was still enough gadgetry invention to confound any criticism. But there was no exploration of new areas, hunting for new frontiers. (22)Clifton and Riley use images of blindness and visual impairment to dramatize man's lack of capacity for self-awareness. Early in the novel, the scientists are hiding out in a skid row flophouse and are discussing some of their theoretical ideas. Another bum even joins in the dialogue. But their conversation is hampered by the "chicken wire" (12) strung as a barrier between the bunks. Later, Joe tells Dr. Billings: "Every man surrounds his mind with a framework of screen mesh... composed of his own prejudgements, preconceptions of what is acceptable to him. Everything he receives must filter through it" (27). Later, Joe reflects that the human race "was like a universe of material bodies, each with its own eccentric orbit, blindly crashing into one another, carooming off" (55).But, like the blind man, the human race has learned how to do certain types of "cane tapping" (55) to help feel its way along. One type of cane tapping is science, with its "measurement of exteriors" (55). Two other potential canes for mankind are Bossy and psionics. But in order to use them, man must, bit by bit, abandon the mental mesh that blinds him.Joseph McCarthy is long dead. The House of UnAmerican Activities (HUAC) has long been disbanded. The McCarthy witch hunts are a thing of the past. But we have massive amounts of anti-intellectualism and ignorance in America today. There is still pressure to conform to this or that mass ideology. And much of the hypocrisy skewered by the authors is an ever-present evil. It really would not take much to bring about the world that Clifton and Riley satirize._They'd Rather Be Right_ has an undeserved bad reputation. It is well worth a look, and it still has something worthwhile to say to modern readers. Highly recommended. There have been several editions of _They'd Rather Be Right_ over the years, but my favorite is the Starblaze Edition. It is sturdily bound, with good print and good illustrations by M.W. Carroll.* The first two "Bossy" stories were written by Mark Clifton in collaboration with Alex Apostolides. They may be found in _The Science Fiction of Mark Clifton_ (1980), ed. Barry Malzberg.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.This is the absolutely best rose water and toner that I have tried so far. I am so happy with this. When I spritz it onto my face after a shower, my face just tightens up so beautifully. Love, love, love this. Sorry for getting giddy on a review, but it's almost essential in this case.Are there better toners? It depends on what you are looking for more. I am in my mid forties, and cannot use products that strip my skin, not even solutions as gentle as "witch hazel", which are actually not as gentle as we were once taught. So, for me, to find a toner that tightens, but does not harm, is pure magic.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.This is beautifully made. The design is like a fine tool. This is nothing like many of the chintzy wine openers that are out there in the retail world. The foil cutting blade is curved, with fine serrations, and is a real joy to use. The screw that goes into the cork has a groove all along its length so that it slides easier into the cork and the cork also unscrews easily. The artfully engraved jacking steps are spring loaded, so that when the first step is clear, it springs back so that you can use the second step pulling up the cork. All in all, a really elegant and satisfying tool to use.This is the one I will keep.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.This was the second such product that my husband recently tried. I didn't notice any effect that first day. Day 2, I dealt with the large pills again, but this time washed them down with a smoothie, which really helped. That night, I woke up with a big, hard, long lasting erectrion. That was definitely a noticeable effect. On Day 3, I woke up with a very pleasant, natural feeling hard and long lasting erection. It seemed like this supplement was really doing what it says it does 'promotes muscle growth...helps increase energy levels and endurance...helps increase sex drive.' Day 4 and 5, I had no noticeable effects to write of. But, I feel, that when needed, that this product will help me perform well."This is recommended. My husband felt that this product was a bit more potent then the previous product that he tried, which was also pretty good (see reviews). We would take off half a star, because of the size of the pills, but 4.5 still round up to 5 stars.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.I have been using this product on my Australian shepherd/wheaten terrier mix dog for the last week. My dog, Monkey, came to me with lots of allergies affecting his ears, nose, lungs, and paws. Most of his ailments are under control now, but his paws are still something he relentlessly chews on. I have to say that this spray seems to work pretty well. The chewing and whining is pretty much gone.The only thing I would like to see different with this product is to be able to administer it from a dropper bottle instead of a spray bottle. I may end up transferring the solution into one of my own dropper bottles. Monkey hates the spray, so applying this is a bit of a chore...and kind of messy. Monkey thinks I am assaulting him, but we get through it and he is feeling better these days.

This woman knows desserts. This book, along with a few others, has helped me turn my whole family vegan in less than a week -- even my 71 year old mom! Buy this book, if for nothing other than the Chocolate Truffle Tort and Shortbread Crust recipes. Devine!! They taste like over-the-top amazing gourmet food. And then when you tell people these are raw vegan desserts, just sit back and watch their jaws drop.

This thing is a beast. I have never owned a food processor as magical as this thing. If someone told me NASA built it, I would believe them. This handles everything that my Vitamix blender only wish it could. Of course, the blender makes sauces smoother and creamier in the end, but this food processor is being used more often than the blender at this point, and is helping me to get my raw food vegan game on.

SPINNER: Dries greens fast and easily. We pick greens for our garden, rinse in the sink, spin greens dry with this device, and in almost no time we are eating the freshest, cleanest salads possible. This device works very, very well for drying wet greens. Awesome purchase.PARTS: There are three main parts to this device, which include the outer bowl, the inner bowl, and the lid with handle.EASE OF USE: Crazy easy. Put one hand on the top of the spinner and use your other hand to turn the handle. Absolutely no problems so far. We now own two of these.CONCLUSION: I rate this salad spinner as a strong buy.

This is a great can opener. I am so glad I got it. It is perfect in every way. I agree with a previous reviewer who said that this would be very good for elderly people with arthritic hands. This can opener is very smooth and easy to work with.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.THE BELT: I absolutely love this belt. It is soooo comfortable. I am not a fan of purses, and women's clothes often lack practical features like pockets (don't get me started...), so this has been a godsend. I wear it around the house so that I don't have to carry my phone around with me in my hand and I wear it to the store sometimes, because this hot summer weather makes wearing a hoodie (which has pockets!) a rediculous sort of venture... but I still won't give in to lugging around a purse. I'm a minimalist, and so this is AWESOME for me!FEATURES:1.) Adjustable belt.2.) Large packet that is open both from the left and right sides, so that you can add or remove items quickly, without struggling with zippers or buttons. Think of this pocket as a very snug hoodie pocket that is on the inside of your clothes instead of on the outside. Smaller items fit in easier than larger items, but I had no problem fitting in either of my two phones, the largest being 5"x3".3.) Simple plastic hook, with closure for keys.CONCLUSION: Five stars, baby!

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.My mother was a nurse for some 30+ years, but took a break somewhere in there in order to try her hand at pet grooming. So she groomed animals professionally for two years before returning back to her nursing career. She was the obvious one for me to consult, regarding this tool.She loves it :)!My mom says that for a home-use tool, it works very well. She loves how easy it is to brush our sensitive dogs with this tool. She said that our dogs didn’t flinch and seemed to enjoy the process. She also remarked on how well this tool thins out the undercoat. She describes this tool as “easy to handle”, “effortlessly trims undercoat”, doesn’t pull or cause distress”, “combs don’t roll, but tool seems to work great.” She also noted the easy-to-clean detachable head.Along with her professional insight, I am adding my own images to help tell this product’s story.RECOMMENDATION: My mom gives this product 5 out of 5 stars and appears to be very happy with it!

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.This is my husband’s favorite product out of the three beard treatments that I bought for him recently (see previous reviews). He says that this conditioner is softer and easier to use than the Smooth Viking balm. He prefers to use this conditioner in conjunction with the Smooth Viking oil.He likes the smell, and describes it as “woodsy”, similar to how he describes the other Viking products.He rates this product 5 out of 5 stars for its ease of application and calls it his “go-to-goo”.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.This is one of three beard products that my husband recently tried, and here is his experience:My husband describes this balm as “very firm, waxy material.” He says it has the same smell as the beard oil that Smooth Viking also sells. This is a smell that he likes and describes as “like pine, kind of woodsy.”This balm must be warmed between your fingers before using, per instructions, otherwise the balm is too hard to work with. My husband says that it softens up nicely when warmed, and that it provides a firmer hold than oil or conditioner.He rates this product as 4 out of 5 stars and says that he would purchase it again.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.The only treatment my husband had been giving his beard prior to getting this was argon oil, purchased at a nearby drugstore. Thus, that will be our comparison for this review.My husband describes this oil as being thinner than argon oil, making it easier to spread throughout his beard strands. This is something he appreciates. He also says this oil has a “manly smell” that he describes as “like pine, kind of woodsy.” My husband is a master craftsman of wood (a luthier), so I am going to assume that he knows what he is talking about regarding the fragrance.He rates this oil as 4 out of 5 stars, says that he will buy it again.

I was sold this product at a deep discount in exchange for an honest review, and I can promise you that this will be an honest review.THE CASE: The outside of the case is made up of a man-made material that is meant to mimic a leather-type look. The black interior feels soft and a bit fuzzy, almost like velvet, though I would not call it velvet. The case holds the tweezer very nicely, but lacks the suppleness that real leather provides. This is appropriate at this price level and the pocket case adds significant value to the product, making the tweezer easier to find in a purse or drawer. The color is a dark purple, and is aesthetically pleasing enough for this price level. The tweezer fits very snuggly sideways. Ample room is given for the tip of the tweezer where the case folds over, and the case seals with a firmly adhered velcro closure.POSSIBLE ISSUE FOR THE CASE: Due to the lack of suppleness of the case material, the end of the flap closure lays FLAT instead of molding over the body of the case, increasing the likelihood of the corners catching on things in one’s purse. The issue is not severe, but I thought I would point it out since some individuals carry a plethora of items at the bottom of their purse. I would likely slip this tweezer case into a side/slender pocket of my purse to avoid any such issues. Aside from that possible small hitch, the benefit of the accessory case is a big plus at this price level, and so I won’t be deducting points for this maybe-it-is-maybe-it-isn’t-an-issue.THE TWEEZER: That’s what we’re here for, right? This tweezer performs very well. I had a mini-learning curve at first, thinking that the tweezer was not picking up the finest hairs around my brow. I was wrong. This is a precision tweezer, requiring precision handling as well. With less than a minute’s practice, I was able to pluck any size of hair, no matter how fine, with this tweezer. Afterwards, I slipped it sideways back into its snug little pocket case, and felt quite impressed.THE SPARKLES: Yes, this tweezer has them. Because of the darker purple color, the sparkles don’t appear overwhelming. If you have an aversion to looking overly Rainbows-CandyCanes-and-Unicorns, this should suit you well enough. Obviously, if you don’t like purple, you might be on the wrong product page.RATING: This tweezer performs very well, is a good purchase at this price, and is rated as a strong buy in this price category.

The liquid gel capsule was a brilliant idea. This small, easy-to-swallow pill works well and it works fast. The first time I used this product, I was on a business trip to China. The effects were subtle and natural, but I definitely felt myself falling asleep quickly.Before trying this product, both my husband and I separately used our own favorite melatonin brands. He liked to use a tablet form and I was using a sublingual form. After trying this product, we both agree that this melatonin works better than either of our other products, which we have been long-time users of (years). I would guess that the liquid solution is part of the reason for this product’s efficacy. The fact that this melatonin beats out two other top melatonin brands, as far as our family is concerned, is significant to us. We will be buying more supplements from this company.Recommendation: This melatonin is rated as a strong buy.

Review of smarter rest sleep sublime eye maskThe Sleep Sublime Eye Mask by Smarter Rest claims that I will get better, more restful sleep, and can maximize the healing effects of REM sleep. I rarely feel like I get enough rest, so I was eager to give this product a try.The eye mask comes in a nice drawstring pouch, and the strap is made with two little loops to hold a pair of earplugs; great for keeping everything together, especially when travelling. This one came with the earplugs, so I was all set.The easy to understand instructions tell how to adjust the strap for a comfortable fit; the strap is extra long to accommodate different head sizes, hairdoos, etc. I was a little concerned that the velcro on the strap might stick to my pillowcase, but it didn’t.In addition to the soft cotton material that touches your eyes, the mask has a flap that folds down to block more light from getting in around the sides of your nose; very effective.I put the earplugs in, pulled the mask over my eyes, adjusted the nose flap, and it was off to dreamland. The mask is very comfortable, I hardly noticed I was wearing it after a very short time. The earplugs are great at keeping out sound, and I was still able to hear my alarm go off when I did need to get up. The mask blocks pretty much all of the light, and I felt like my sleep was deeper and with more dreams.I’d recommend this product to anyone looking for a sleep aid that blocks light and sound and allows you to get a better nights rest.

NORI: These nori sheets have less added salt and are significantly firmer than expected. Hence, these sheets are a wonderful replacement for bread. They hold wet, soggy veggy mixtures better then pita bread!! For making sushi, I wet the inside side of the paper and lightly apply oil to the outside, rendering a far more plyable sheet for rolling and cutting. I will not be going back to standard nori sheets anymore. This is it for me.ADDITIONAL BONUS: The nutritional content for these sheets is higher than for standard nori sheets.RECOMMENDATION: I am rating this nori product as a strong buy and will continue to purchase this item myself.

Review for Attmu Brush, as used for dry brushing (not bath/shower use):BRISTLES: I am a little shocked by the usability of this brush. I have body brushes ranging in prices between $15-$40+ dollars, and this is hands-down the best body brush I have used yet. What sets this brush apart is the short, firm, equal-height consistency of almost every brush strand. The outcome of this design is that every stroke I make across my skin has the same amount of pressure under the full area of the brush, side-to-side and end-to-end. This made my jaw drop. The pressure is fully uniform: as long as the brush firmly touches my skin, my skin receives relatively the same level of treatment, whether or not my skin is massaged under the middle or the sides of the brush.MASSAGE NUBS: Again, very usable and effective. Gives the right amount of pressure without causing damage to skin.RECOMMENDATION: I am rating this brush as a “strong buy” for dry body brushing. I will absolutely be buying more of these brushes myself.

I am definitely blown away by the level of detail given to the design and packaging of this product. If you are looking for something in this price range, especially something worthy of giving as a gift, this may be it.SOUND QUALITY: Good. Nothing lacking, in my opinion, regarding the sound quality expected in this price range.MICROPHONE: Good. Simplistic on/off design.COMFORT: Good, but made for larger ears due to the size and weight of the ear buds. Consider this for the man or young adult/teen son in your life.AESTHETICS: At this price level, this is a bit of a show stopper. It is unexpectedly beautiful, and that's why I would heartily recommend this on your gift-giving list for work or as stocking-stuffers. I hope my photos give it justice.ISSUES: The extra ear bud covers are supposed to come in two sizes, but as shown in one of my pictures, I received one large pair (this is good) and one mismatched pair (one large and one small earbud cover -- this is not good). But, please note that this does not change the usability of the device: I do not believe that these earbuds are appropriate for smaller sized ears (see above), so the extra rubber for the smaller bud cover is a bit of a waste. Thus, only the original translucent ear bud covers in medium (beautiful) and the extra set in large standard black are what you want anyhow.RECOMMENDATION: For this price range, I rate this as a buy.

MOUSE BODY: This is a full sized, right-handed mouse and is one of the best in its price class. Materials look and feel good. Mouse rolls nicely. Right and left-click buttons, along with programmable buttons, click easily.DOUBLE-CLICK BUTTON: Yep. Although not likely used for gaming, it can be useful for office/graphic design type of work.DPI: 5 settings, easy reach.PRECISION: Standard precision (good), and is currently being used by my son in his gaming.CORD: The first thing I noticed when I pulled it out of its box was the quality of the cord. Unexpected for this price range. And although this doesn’t make or break anything regarding the overall function of a mouse, this is still noteworthy. My gaming son and my industrial designer husband both had the same initial response regarding the cord. The length is good, approximately 5 feet long.PRODUCT GUIDE: Not included.CONCLUSION: For the price, this is better than a standard mouse for gaming and for office work. This mouse is being given a strong buy recommendation.

Amazing. Clean and pure. Minimum ingredients: Cherry juice and cherry juice! I mix this with my teas and carbonated water. I get very nice compliments from my guests when I serve them this with sparkling water :)

I do not know how this brush does it, but it is the best detangler I have used in recent memory. The bristles have give, yet they succeed at separating hair strands. The body of the brush, though wide, is thin, has weight, and is elegant.This is a buy if you have long hair.
If you are aiming to impress, this is the one you want to get. BIG and thick. Lathers up very well. Nice thick cord for hanging.

For standardized testing, this is the go-to text that my youngest daughter uses. Currently, she is prepping for admissions testing for a medical program she wants to get into. We couldn't find this book anywhere at home (maybe we loaned it out?), so she asked me to buy another copy for her. She didn't want to prep without it. She raved about how it refreshed her memory for standardized testing in junior high and high school. I found her loyalty to this book enduring, and a testament to this grammar book's sheer magnetism. So, of course, my kid's orator skills earned her another copy from my wallet.
These will hold a lot and they are solidly built. Not much more to add.

Quality is more than adequate. I love the see-through design, which allows me to omit the labeling step if I choose to, since I can obviously see what is inside each envelope at a glance.With the advent of online coursework and loose-leaf textbooks, I find that dividing my documents (printed out from the internet or pulled from my loose-leaf stacks) amongst these envelopes, especially as strategically subdivided for each upcoming exam, allows me exceptional portability when I can't be at my computer, laptop, other digital device or desk. The Internet is an unparalleled study/information tool, but it can still slow the process of learning and memorizing efficiently when life gets hectic and one is on the go constantly.

Simple and pure. If you want a basic coffee scrub, this is it. Make sure you have your moisturizers and serums ready for afterwards, because your skin will be ready for it.I ordered four of these at once, because the price is incredibly low (less than $3 per unit right now) and the shipping costs per unit go down with each additonal unit that you order. Four of these for less than $20, including shipping? Unreal. I am very happy.

When I purchased the probiotics I ordered this probiotic exactly one month ago, when my dog "Monkey", who is still less than one year old, had an ear infection, was listless, was suffering from allergies, and was having diarrhea every 1-2 hours!! (especially throughout the night...it was like taking care of a sick newborn!!!). I purchased a well-regarded OTC ear medication (Zymox Plus), I bought these Pet Ultimate Probiotics, I bought a nutritional supplement, and I started making homemade food for Monkey.The ear infection was the first thing to clear, which I am certain can be credited to the Zymox. The ungodly cycle of diarrhea took about a week to clear, which I am fairly certain is credited, at least in part if not in whole, to these probiotics. The allergies have also been greatly reduced. And now, oh joy, Monkey has boundless energy, far more than he ever has. Instead of waking me to go potty, he wakes me to go play (after a long, restful night :). Changing Monkey's diet and having access to OTC products that actually work has completely turned my little guy around for the better.I am making sure to put these probiotics in one of his meals each day, which significantly helps to keep his diet plan complete, and I am sure aids in keeping his digestive system functional. I appreciate the quality of this product. I was not pleased with what I was finding online regarding probiotics until I came across this one. I feel very confident in giving it to my puppy.

This replaces almost every tracking journal I have, except my HealthMinder and BodyMinder journals. It is great for jotting down appointments and brilliant ideas throughout the day in the left-hand page (as well as reminders and trackers), while the right-hand side serves as a document page for more comprehensive notes. If my ideas run past the space allotted in the right-hand side, then I can easily just add some more college-ruled or graphing paper to continue my designs/thoughts/ideas, as it sensibly fits the pre-set format for this product. The monthly calendar pages allow me to visually track progress month to month, as well as allowing for summary and cross-referencing of more detailed notes written in the daily journal pages. The tabs for each month are helpful, but I will be adding magnetic bookmarks to the pages that I am working on each day.I have tried going digital for my documentation over the last few years, but honestly it hasn't worked out. Inevitably, an app becomes outdated, more difficult to use, I switch apps, or even worse, I somehow lose the data I have input (computer failure, phone upgrades, software upgrades, hacks, malware, etc.). Ya, I guess my house could burn down and then I could lose all my hard-copy journals, but that hasn't happened to me EVER, so my hand-written journals are still the safest most secure place for me yet. Not to mention that I find that I can access my hardcopy journals more quickly. I also write more in this format, verses when I am entering info via data entry style, as I don't have to wait for an app or program to open up for me or try to press tiny buttons. Finally, it hardly ever seems rude when I jot down notes in hardcopy when I am with people, but whipping my phone out constantly when I am brainstorming ideas can seem insensitive in some situations (such as during conversations, meetings, classes, etc.).Man, did I just go off on a tangent. Anyhow, if you like tracking things and you need a safe and efficient place to keep your ideas and goals/progress together, check this planner out.
This is professional looking and comfortable to carry around. I think it is well-made for the price. The color and the texture are both very pleasing. I will absolutely order more.

Devine. This is great to mix with other teas to jazz up the flavor and with my superfood powders as well (not to be confused with super powers!). This berry base helps me drink down my Miracle Reds and Rainbow Vibrance concoctions, as well as the other powders that I take regularly.

I love the sound quality (better than when I have my ear to my phone). The fit is good for me. The headset is well-made with sturdy materials, including lightweight metals. The mouthpiece is flexible, yet solidly built. This is absolutely the best quality headset I have owned so far.

This worked fairly quickly, within a few days, on an infection that seemed very painful for my dog. The ear was bright red and the dog was yelping when he touched it. My husband, who thought we could only clear the infection by taking our dog to the vet, was extremely and joyfully surprised at the success of this product :)!

Books by ER workers are plentiful, so there is no good reason to read this amateur-ish book instead of one of the better written others.  Most of the stories in this book are pretty common to this type of book--the woman who turns out to be male, the drunks, the liars seeking pills, etc.  There are no really unique stories that you can't miss.  Two things really bothered me about this author.  First, much of this book is really disrespectful of her patients.  She makes fun of peoples lack of medical knowledge, spelling mistakes, fears, etc.  I wouldn't want to be this woman's patient because of this attitude.  Second, she reports an incident where a police officer who brings an injured suspect to the ER tells her where he chased this suspect, and where he was throwing stolen jewelry out of his pockets to rid himself of the evidence.  The author and a friend go to this spot and find the stolen jewelry.  She thinks this is funny/cool.  I think this makes her almost as dishonest as the person who stole the jewelry in the first place.

While there were some interesting facts in this presentation, I felt it ultimately failed.  The pictures are cartoonish, and do not move.  It's like panning a picture book.  It would have been better if they had gone to Monticello and filmed it.  Sometimes what they were trying to get across was unclear.  For instance, with his bed that was between two rooms, I understood how the bed was set up because I've been to Monticello, but it wasn't clear on this DVD.  You almost had to know a lot about Jefferson in order to understand the video because so much was just mentioned in passing that needed more explanation.  This DVD also suffers from too much political correctness.  It dwells a bit too long on slavery.  Whether or not the Sally Hemmings story is or isn't true, I don't feel it's an appropriate topic for a video for young children.

We recently added this book to the children's collection at the public library that I manage.  It's perfect for the toddle/preschool set learning about dressing themselves.  I've read it to a couple of children.  They loved the boxers with hearts.  Little ones always think underwear is deliciously naughty.  When I'm reading it to a child, I change the word trousers to pants.  The ending of "I'm going to get you" can be as scary or as silly as you want it to be, depending on how you read it.  This one is a hit with our kids.

This review is for the DVD, not the book.  The book is good, but the DVD presentation of the book leaves much to be desired.  I guess the producers didn't want to spend much money on it.  The pictures are static.  The camera simply pans the pictures from the book--nothing moves.  It's a lot like watching a filmstrip, for those of us old enough to remember filmstrips in school.  My experience as a children's librarian is that 21st century children aren't satisfied by these DVDs with still pictures.  They are used to more pizzazz.  I bought this for the children's room of my library.  I'm disappointed because I expect this will be a shelf-sitter, and I've wasted the library's money.

Love Dasani water, but I wish Amazon would offer it in a larger size bottle for Prime pantry orders.  Half the time I'm almost finished with the bottle by the time I walk from the office fridge to my desk.

Since so many reviewers are saying that the Pringles come broken, I wanted to say that mine (in a pantry box order) were fine.  My pantry box was mostly bottled water, so it wasn't like the Pringles weren't in with heavy items.  So, evidently you take your chances when you order them in a pantry box.  To me the convenience of having them delivered to me at my office is worth the risk because I don't like dragging bulky bags on public transit.

Despite the title, this book has almost nothing to do with the Spencer estate Althorp.  This book is about the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.  English is not the author's first language, and it shows.  He should have had an English speaker edit the book.  However, that would still not have helped the lack of organization in the book.  But, the biggest problem is the number of mistakes.  For example, at one point the author notes that the British public would not have accepted Dodi Fayed, a Muslim, as the step father of the future king Harry.  Since there are lots of better books available that cover the death of Diana, there's no reason to read this.

Smells wonderful, cleans well, and the price is cheaper than buying it in the store.  I have only tried the lavender scent, so far.  It smells great, but the scent is very strong.  I love that, but some people might think it's too much.  A little goes a long way.  I squirt a little in the back of the toilet to make the bathroom smell nice.  A little in the garbage disposal refreshes your drain.

This cherry pie is really too sweet.  The crust has sort of a sugar coating.  I suspect that is on there to keep the pie from sticking to the box.  The crust is very thick.  There is not a lot of cherry filling compared to the amount of crust, and what filling there is has more the texture of thick jelly with only a few cherry pieces in it.  This is more like a cherry pastry than a cherry pie.

I'm not (unfortunately) a healthy eater, but when I saw how much salt was in this stuff it made me pause.  Sure enough, when I made it, there was way too much salt in it for my taste buds.  I toned down the salt by adding extra sour cream and by not salting the noodles I served it over.  I bought this to fill up my prime pantry box, but won't buy it again.  However, many people like a lot of salt.  This would definitely only be for salt lovers.

Jazz trumpeter Donald Byrd has been a pioneer in many ways, but his the body of his work shows that he is one that likes to challenge himself. During his hard bop period, he's had a massive body of work but it's his 70's period that's his most recognizable and most influential work. In the early 70's he decided to experiment with the jazz fusion movement. With the aid of The Mizell Brothers, he created some groundbreaking and innovative sounds- much to the chagrin of purists. It all started with 1973's "Black Byrd", where he landed the hit "Flight Time" (The song would later be the inspiration for the name behind Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis's production company, Flyte Tyme). He later followed it up with two albums in 1974: "Street Lady" and his best work "Stepping Into Tomorrow". In 1975, he issued his best known album "Places & Spaces" - which contained the heavily sampled tracks 'Wind Parade" and "(Fallin' Like) Dominoes". 1976's "Caricatures" was his final album for Blue Note and marked the end of his collaboration with The Mizell Brothers. As he wanted to make a change, he settled in at Elektra Records - a label that would later become known for jazz musicians such as Lee Ritenour, Patrice Rushen and Grover Washington, Jr. In 1978, he issued the album "Thank You For F.U.M.L. (Funking Up My Life)", while it was one of his rare self-produced projects, in the end he decided to let someone take the reins on the production side for his next album.In 1981, Byrd enlisted former in-house Stax producer/songwriter turned singer Isaac Hayes. Fresh off his Polydor stint, Hayes produced "Love Byrd" shortly before he decided to take a break from music to make a foray into acting. The album sounds noticeably different from Hayes' work at Polydor, which had taken a blatant slant towards disco. A couple of the songs on here try to stray from disco influences, but are very blatant in their dance music origins (See: The first single "Love Has Come Around"). "Love Byrd" also contains probably the first and only time a Cole Porter ballad has been covered as a funk record: The virtually unrecognizable "Love For Sale". The romantic ballad "I Feel Like Loving You Today" is best known as the sample behind Group Home's song "Baby Pa" from their 1995 debut "Livin' Proof". There are some great ballads on here, such as "I'll Always Love You" and the album closer "Falling". However, the best ballad comes in the form of the six minute "Butterfly", where a man pines for a lost love. Though "Love Byrd" is a decent offering from Donald Byrd, it wasn't without its flaws. The most obvious is that Donald seems to be a guest on his own album. Hayes' writing, production, arrangements and background vocals dominate the album to the point where Donald barely had any wiggle room to show off his playing skills. Despite that mishap, it's not as revered as his earlier work but still worth checking out.

After he split with his partner C.L. Smooth, Mount Vernon native Pete Rock decided to focus on putting out his artists InI and Deda. That plan would come to a screeching halt when Elektra decided to shelve their debuts after not seeing commercial potential in their releases. Pete then focused on releasing his solo debut "Soul Survivor" through Loud Records. While Loud meant well, they were nearing the end of their distribution deal with RCA Records and as such, they were gearing up for distribution with Columbia. Although he did respectable numbers, he ended up getting dropped from their roster by the time the Columbia distribution deal went through. A few years passed on by the time he released his next recording "PeteStrumentals". Ironically, the same fans who craved an instrumental album from Pete Rock unfairly trashed the album during its initial release. Since then, the public has reversed their opinion on the now hailed project. Shortly after that, he issued the long-shelved debuts from InI and Deda - "Center Of Attention" and "The Original Baby Pa", respectively - "Soul Survivor 2" and another instrumental piece, the outtakes album "The Surviving Elements". In between those projects, he continued to produce - including the Edo G. record "My Own Worst Enemy", while working with Redman, Method Man and Keith Murray and making random appearances on albums by Northern State and Keyshia Cole.In 2008, he released "NY's Finest" and did joint albums with Smif-N-Wessun and Camp Lo. Pete then signed with Arizona based hip hop label Mello Music Group to release yet another instrumental album "PeteStrumentals 2". While the sequel's title is a clear nod to the 2001 album, this one has very little in common with its predecessor. "PeteStrumentals" was basically a jazz fusion record with hip hop drums, while "PeteStrumentals 2" is less focused on melody and heavy on groove. The album starts off with the most mellow song on the album, the spiritual "Heaven & Earth". He does a dramatic reworking of the often sampled James Brown tune "Funky President" on "PR 4 Prez". He takes an ethereal approach on the first single "Cosmic Slop" while paying tribute to the B-Boy culture on "Clap Ya Hands (I Feel Good)". On "I Wish", he incorporates the hook of the 1976 Rose Royce classic "Wishing On A Star" as well as working in some Isaac Hayes on "One, Two, A Few More". He makes great use of Eddie Kendricks' song "Can I" on the retro "90's Class Act" and pays tribute to his biggest fan, the late J Dilla on "Dilla Bounce (R.I.P.)". He brings in a sinister sound for "Play Yo Horn", while delivering the dancehall sound on "Roots, Reggae, Kulcha" and afrobeat on the album closer "You Know Dat". Although "PeteStrumentals 2" is a great listen, there are a couple of songs that are filler. "My My Baby" seems to meander without really going anywhere and "Gonna Love You" just comes off as repetitive. Despite those shortcomings, Pete Rock shows that he's still got it after being in the music business after two and a half decades.

Although New Orleans is best known for the launch pad for the No Limit and Cash Money labels, the city has also spawned some notable talent in the R&B world. Names include the instrumental act The Meters, gospel trio Trin-I-Tee 5:7, Ledisi, early 80's funk group Windjammer and songstress Teedra Moses. Back in the late 90's, she was in a relationship with underground rapper Ras Kass (She was even thanked in the liner notes to his critically acclaimed debut "Soul On Ice"). However, they called it quits by the time the new millennium was approaching. Teedra then became a stylist to the stars while working on her music career. She was signed by an unlikely label - TVT  Records, a company more known for their hip hop and rock acts, and barely known for rhythm and blues. In 2004, she released her formal debut "Complex Simplicity", an album that was mostly produced by Paul Poli (Best known for the Black Eyed Peas single "Joints & Jam") with additional production by Raphael Saadiq and her then-labelmate Lil' Jon. The recording received generally positive reviews, but TVT's lack of history with R&B sunk the project before it got off the ground. While recording a follow-up, TVT Records folded due to a lawsuit over copyright issues and as such, Teedra went out to record a series of mixtapes and working behind the scenes as a background vocalist and songwriter.In 2011, she was thrown a lifeline by signing to Rick Ross' Maybach Music Group. It seemed like she was going to reach a mainstream audience, however label issues continued to put a halt to her career. After her appearance on the first "Self Made" compilation, she dealt with creative differences due to the label wanting her to sound and look a certain way. She left and then went to Shanachie Records for her release of her long awaited second album "Cognac & Conversation". This time around, she works with producers such as her longtime engineer Donnie "Cash" Whitmore, Charles "Uncle Chucc" Hamilton of the production collective 1500 Or Nothin', Trackademics, Thaddeus Dixon and Virginia based producer Bink. Musically, she takes an honest approach with her songwriting as she looks at love from the point of view from a woman nearing middle age. She issues come-ons on the opening track "R U Scared", while being unimpressed with material things on the Dynasty sampling "All I Ever Wanted". She addresses her current priorities in a relationship on "Get It Right", while duetting with Anthony Hamilton on "That One". There are a couple of songs that previously appeared on her mixtapes: "International Playboi" from 2010's "Royal Patience: A Love Journey" and the acapella "Wish You Were Here" from her lone release on Maybach Music Group "Luxurious Undergrind". She decides to be committed to someone on the ballad "Only U", while being frank and open about her personal life on the album's best track "Yesterday Ain't Tomorrow". "Cognac & Conversation" is a great album from Teedra Moses. She may not be as known as some of her female contemporaries, but her music holds up better than one would expect. Hopefully, she will get the recognition that she finally deserves.

Philadelphia singer Vivian Green got her start by helping write the song "Dear God"- the closing track on Boyz II Men's 1997 album "Evolution" while she was still in high school. She received an offer from a major label, but was rebuffed by her parents who insisted that she finished high school first. After graduation, she paid dues by touring as a background singer for Jill Scott. While in the neo-soul circuit, she ran into independent soul singer Eric Roberson, who mentored her when she wanted to give another shot at a singing career. She signed with Columbia Records to release her formal debut "A Love Story". The album yielded her first single- and signature song "Emotional Rollercoaster". Three years passed when she decided to follow it up with her sophomore effort "Vivian"-  a recording largely inspired by her recent divorce. She then went on a five year hiatus to change labels- which saw her move from Columbia to E1 Music for the release of 2010's "Beautiful" and 2012's "The Green Room". Despite her success and her personality, she was always perceived as being "the sad girl" due to her best known songs being about heartbreak. Although her later recordings showed her trying to distance herself from that, it was hard for her to shake that stigma. To that end, she decided to do a full on makeover- both in her music and her looks.Her first order of operations was to adopt a more sexier image- which she had been cultivating on her previous album "The Green Room". The second one was a label change, with her moving to Caroline Records. In her corner is the rapper turned producer Kwame (Raheem DeVaughn, Algebra Blessett, Tweet, Lloyd Banks), who insisted that she made music that reflected her true personality. The end result is her 2015 album- the aptly titled "Vivid". With Kwame producing the entire album, "Vivid" sounds like Vivian really wanted to be a dance diva. This is reflected in the first single- the Maze featuring Frankie Beverly sampling "Gotta Get Back To My Baby", the surprisingly sexual "Work", the Motownesque "123" and the closing track "Leave It All Behind". She duets with Raheem DeVaughn, who interrupts the mood with his slightly raunchy guest appearance on the ballad "All I Want Is You". She adopts a more positive outlook after a breakup on "Broken" and desires to live free without regard to rules on "Just Like Fools". After collaborating with her twice before, she connects with fellow singer Treena Ferebee on the introspective "Count Your Blessings". Vivian Green's "Vivid" is a decent offering from the veteran singer. Although the production could have been a little better, it's commendable that she decided to step out of her comfort zone and take risks in her career.

The original lineup of Dynasty consisted of singer and songwriters Nidra Beard and Linda Carreire with keyboardist Kevin Spencer being brought in at the last minute by Solar Records head Dick Griffey. In 1979, they released their formal debut as a trio "Your Piece Of The Rock", which yielded the hit "I Don't Want To Be A Freak". That same year, Spencer helped write the smash hit for his labelmates The Whispers "And The Beat Goes On". In 1980, they released the follow-up "Adventures In The Land Of Music" - which keyboardist William Shelby's appearance introduced the group as a quartet. That album contained their biggest hits "I've Just Begun To Love You" and "Groove Control" as well as the title track- which was best known as the sample behind Camp Lo's 1997 hit "Luchini AKA This Is It". Their longtime producer Leon Sylvers III became the fifth member of the group for their third effort "The Second Adventure". However, his profile in the group did little to to help with their fame. Also not helping matters was the issue surrounding all of the 1981 releases on Solar Records. Around that time, label founder Dick Griffey rush released recordings on Solar to get out of their distribution with RCA to enter into a partnership with Elektra, where he continued to rush release recordings. As a result, all of the albums by the acts on the roster suffered marketing and promotion problems.It's unfortunate that Dynasty was one of the acts caught up in the the label distribution mess, as "The Second Adventure" contained some of their best work. With Leon Sylvers III at the helm with co-production by Kevin Spencer and William Shelby, their album has songs that could have easily been a classic record. Starting off the album is the song "Here I Am"- a song about still wanting to be in love despite being hurt which was co-written by Midnight Star members Melvin Gentry and Belinda Lipscomb. A man that fancies himself a ladies' man gets his comeuppance on the funky "Pain, Got A Hold On Me", while "A Man In Love" shows someone who cannot hide their happiness and feelings over their significant other. A man pledges to give himself to someone on "Give Your Love To Me". Singer Nidra Beard takes the lead on the song "Love In The Fast Lane", where she takes a more careful approach to dating after being mistreated. Beard pens the Spencer led "Revenge", where a man finds out that his former love has moved on with someone else. Pleading with a lover to make a commitment is the theme of the ballad "Give It Up For Love", while a relationship comes to end due to excessive infidelity on "High Time I Left You Baby". Overall, "The Second Adventure" is a great yet overlooked album by Dynasty. Sadly, the group would never reach the level of success that their labelmates achieved- mostly because they gave away songs that became huge hits for their peers The Whispers and Shalamar. Despite not being recognized, "The Second Adventure" is a great album from beginning to end.

Philadelphia native Jill Scott originally got her start on film soundtracks, of all places. In 1999, she either appeared by herself (See: "Dreamer" from the LL Cool J and Omar Epps film "In Too Deep") or alongside someone else (See: Her duet with Common "8 Minutes To Sunrise" from "Wild Wild West" or Fredro Starr's rewrite of the 1986 Cyndi Lauper hit "True Colors"). When she did make an attempt to get noticed, she was sidetracked by a record company who wanted a more familiar name on a song she helped write- that said song being The Roots duet with Erykah Badu "You Got Me". By the turn of the millennium, Scott was lending her talents to other artists (Musiq Soulchild, Common) and was preparing for her chance in the limelight. She signed with the Michael Jordan owned smooth jazz label Hidden Beach Recordings, where she would release a trilogy of albums under the "Words And Sounds" set- 2000's "Who Is Jill Scott", 2004's "Beautifully Human" and her final recording for the label, "The Real Thing". When Scott made plans to leave Hidden Beach, it didn't go off without a hitch. The company still felt she owed them more albums despite the fact that she actually met her obligations. After the dust was settled, Scott moved to Warner Bros. Records for 2011's "The Light Of The Sun". Released shortly before Warner Bros. endured corporate shakeups, the album did fairly well- but wasn't as successful as her previous efforts. To give her a fresh start, Warner Bros. moved her to their sister label Atlantic Records to work out the kinks in their restructuring issues.Within that timeframe, she reunited with Andre Harris of the production duo Dre & Vidal, who produced the bulk of her debut. She envisioned an experimental double album, which became her fifth full length recording "Woman". While the subject matter was meant to show off the numerous sides of a woman, musically, the album plays out like a history lesson on R&B. The album goes from spoken word (like the Warryn Campbell produced intro "Wild Cookie"), to the 60's inspiration with the taking care of business themed "Run Run Run" and a cover of Carl Hall's 1967 hit "You Don't Know". Stax and Hi Records are the primary influence for the sensual ballad "Can't Wait". Scott also goes contemporary with the production team Oak & Pop (Ginuwine, Elle Varner, Mayer Hawthorne) on the SBTRKT sampling "Lighthouse" as well as on the mellow ballad "Cruisin'". She gets blindsided by a lover's deception on the uptempo single "Fool's Gold", while delivering the ultimate kiss off on the footstomper "Closure", which was surprisingly produced by David Banner. She channels Aretha Franklin during her Leiber-Stoller years on the heart mending "Back Together" as well as the big band sound of "Coming To You". Lastly, she works with hip hop producer 9th Wonder on the BJ The Chicago Kid duet "Beautiful Love". "Woman" is a great album from industry veteran Jill Scott. With nearly 20 years under her belt, she continues on the path to make music on her own terms without any hint of trying to compromise. It's always interesting to see where she's going to go next.

The indie rock band modest Mouse has come a long way since their humble beginnings in a small town in Washington. The band- fronted by the eccentric Isaac Brock- got their start by releasing an EP in 1994. After that, they issued their 1996 formal debut "This Is A Long Drive For Someone With Nothing To Think About". The following year saw the release of "The Lonesome Crowded West" which became their final recording on the Seattle based label Up Records. In 2000, they signed to major label Epic Records for the release of 'The Moon & Antarctica". Although the project was critically acclaimed, it wasn't successful- save for one of the songs being used in a commercial for a Nissan vehicle. After the issue of another EP "Everywhere And His Nasty Parlour Tricks", Modest Mouse saw their greatest success with their 2004 effort "Good News For people Who Love Bad News". The album contained the huge hit singles "Float On" (which would later be sampled by Lupe Fiasco for his record company bashing "The Show Goes On") and the harsh look at death "Ocean Breathes Salty". In 2007 came "We Were Dead Before The Ship Even Sank" which yielded the singles "Dashboard" and "Missed The Boat". However, by that time, original drummer Jeremiah Green returned to play on the album as well as getting help from former member of The Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr. Another EP "No One's First And You're Next" was released before the band went into seclusion by the turn of the 2010's.Modest Mouse spent the next few years doing live shows and constantly recording. Before they could release a new record, the group dealt with changes once again. The first of which was having to make a new album without their longtime bassist Eric Judy (who has since been replaced by Russell Higbee). The second change was more of a corporate nature: Pop music executive L.A. Reid had just become the CEO of their label Epic Records during the recording of their new album "Strangers To Ourselves". The recording was produced by Issac Brock with help from Tucker Martine (who also produced Tift Merritt's albums "See You On The Moon" and "Travelling Alone". Musically, it's a surprisingly upbeat effort, but its lyrical content have an edge of dark humor- look no further than the danceable "Pistol (A. Cunanan, Miami FL. 1996)", which retraced the beginnings of serial killer Andrew Cunanan- the shooter who ended up killing fashion designer Gianni Versace. The album starts off with the title track "Strangers To Ourselves", while they mock the current generation of millennials on the first single "Lampshades On Fire". He sings about going on a search party to find his lost brother who turned up missing on "Ansel" and relaying the message of the burial of a lost package on the ballad "S**t In Your Cut". They tell a dark story of ghosts and larceny on "The Tortoise And The Tourist" and close the recording with the ballad "Of Course We Know". Modest Mouse delivered a great album with "Strangers To Ourselves". It took them nearly a decade to make it, and let's hope that it will not take almost another decade for a proper follow up.

California native Tyrese Gibson made his debut on, of all places, a Coca-Cola commercial. Oddly enough, that advertisement was the same thing that got him a recording contract. He signed with RCA Records to release his 1998 self-titled debut "Tyrese". While sales were slow initially, by the beginning of 1999, he had two huge hits under his belt: "Sweet Lady" (which was composed by a then-unknown Johnta Austin) and "Lately", which has since been covered by Anita Baker. 2001 saw the release of his second effort "2000 Watts" as well as a starring role in John Singleton's film "Baby Boy". That role led to another starring role in the franchise "2 Fast 2 Furious", while he also released another recording "I Wanna Go There". Despite his singing chops, he became in demand as an actor- appearing in films such as the military drama "Annapolis", the remake of "Flight Of The Phoenix" and another John Singleton film "Four Brothers". By the time he released the 2006 double disc "Alter Ego", he lost his passion for music and swore that it would be his last album. However, that turned out to be untrue- as he was constantly bombarded with questions of recording another album. In 2011, he returned with the underrated "Open Invitation" followed by the long-talked about TGT album "Three Kings" with Tank and Ginuwine.Even though his comeback did respectable numbers, in the end Tyrese just lost the passion and desire to record. Taking a cue from Kanye West on the recording of "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy", he wanted to make a bold artistic statement. Ironically, his best album would also turn out to be his last album "Black Rose". He is joined with longtime producer Brandon "B.A.M." Alexander- who produced much of the album, as he previously did with "Open Invitation". Also along for the ride are Busta Rhymes protege Seige Monstracity (who produced the lamenting first single "Dumb S**t"), Tim & Bob, Rockwilder, Eric Hudson and Warryn Campbell, who produced the Jennifer Hudson backing "Shame". He sticks to being committed despite detractions from naysayers on "Picture Perfect" and duets with Chrisette Michele on "Don't Wanna Be Alone". Tank contributes background vocals on the ballad "Prior To You", while dealing with an abrupt breakup on "Without My Heart". He throws in a few sensual ballads for good measure (See: "When We Make Love", "Gonna Give You What You Need" and "Body Language")  before teaming up with Brandy on the song "The Rest Of Our Lives". Lastly, he closes the recording with the song about dealing with relationship troubles "I Still Do". "Black Rose" is a great album from Tyrese. It shows that he put his heart and soul into this album- sadly, we may never get another one like this from him.

Brooklyn rapper Skyzoo was once known as one of the emcees who lost to Jin on BET's 106 & Park segment "Freestyle Fridays". However, his loss turned out to be his gain, where he established a prolific recording career. After becoming an honorary member of the North Carolina collective the Justus League, he set out to record the 9th  Wonder duet album "Cloud 9: The Three Day High". That recording led to Skyzoo being signed to 9th's label Jamla via a joint venture with Buckshot's independent label Duck Down Music. 2009 saw the release of his formal debut "The Salvation". Despite the critical acclaim, Skyzoo felt that he wasn't becoming a priority at the fledgling Jamla Records. He sought out to rectify that situation by moving directly to Duck Down and establishing his own imprint The Faculty. In 2012, he issued his sophomore effort "A Dream Deferred", which was excutive produced by Illmind, with whom he previously collaborated with on 2010's "Live From The Tape Deck". After that recording, he issued two EP's "Theo Vs. JJ: Dreams Vs. Reality" and the Jay-Z tribute "An Ode To Reasonable Doubt". Skyzoo delivered yet another duet album: A collaboration with fellow Brooklyn rapper Torae as the duo Barrel Brothers. It became the formal debut from his Empire distributed label First Generation Rich.2015 saw the release of his new album "Music For My Friends", an album which Skyzoo calls his most personal to date. While most of his albums contained his usual lyrical based content, not much has been said about his upbringing or his inner circle, who introduced themselves during the interludes. The album is heavily littered with references to the HBO series "The Wire" (See: The struggling themed "Ask Bodie For A Package"), but the storyline also plays out like a couple of Spike Lee films- notably "Clockers" and "25th Hour". He starts the recording off with "All Day, Always", which leads into the first single "Suicide Doors". On "The Moments That Matter", he speaks of getting to lead a better life, while getting assistance from Westside Gunn on the wealth themed "Luxury". He dabbles in street narratives on "Everything's For Sale" as well as on the Jadakiss featured "See A Key". The Roots frontman Black Thought and singer Bilal appear on the pensive "Money Makes Us Happy". "Playing Favorites" shows Skyzoo having a romantic side, while he desires a beautiful woman with great culinary skills on "Women Who Can Cook". He looks back on his upbringing and his friendship on "The Experience" while honoring the fallen on "Things I Should've Told My Friends". Overall, "Music For My Friends" is a great recording from Skyzoo. Though the album is his most reflective, in the end he remains consistent with his approach to making music on his own terms.

Canadian singer Tamia got the public's attention by appearing on the first two singles from Quincy Jones' 1995 album, "Q's Juke Joint". Her formal debut came by way of a cover- the Rod Temperton penned "You Put A Move On My Heart", which was originally recorded two years prior by British singer Mica Paris on her third album "Whisper A Prayer". After appearing on a couple of songs from soundtracks, the released her 1998 self-titled debut, which yielded the hits "Imagination" and "So Into You". Despite having steady radio and video rotation, Tamia felt she wasn't given enough promotion by Quincy's label Qwest Records, so she moved over to Elektra for the release of her sophomore effort "A Nu Day". Things got off to a slow start with the release of the first single "Can't Go For That", but she more than made up for it with the release of her now-signature song "Stranger In My House". She then took an extended hiatus- and that's when things went haywire. She recorded an album's worth of material- only to have it shelved and start again. Not helping matters was her label was going through several internal changes. By the time she released her next album "More" in 2004, Elektra Entertainment was folded into Atlantic Records. Not one to let label issues stop her, she quickly rebounded with the independently released "Between Friends". A six year absence ensued prior to the release of 2012's "Beautiful Surprise".After 20 years in the music business, 40 year old Tamia is now back on a major label. This time, it's Def Jam Recordings- an unusual place for someone like Tamia- whose material tends to lean on the ballad heavy side of music. On her new effort, she works with a few familiar names form her past, a couple of newcomers and a few big names, but they don't stray too far from what she's known for. She gets production help form the likes of Warren "Oak" Felder and Andrew "Pop" Wansel (Ginuwine, Elle Varner, Mayer Hawthorne), Lil' Ronnie, Chuck Harmony, Tricky Stewart, Polow Da Don and her longtime producer Shep Crawford. On "Love Life", she sounds rejuvenated and inspired- and it's reflected in the overall mood of the recording. She starts the album off with the Minneapolis inspired ballad "Love Falls Over Me", while leading into another ballad- "Chaise Lounge", where she expresses her sensual side after missing someone. She goes for sultry on the funky first single "Sandwich And A Soda", while The Dream lends his pen to the uptempo "Nowhere" as well as the melodic "Special". Polow Da Don writes and produces the ballad "Stuck With Me", while Tamia aims for pop stardom with the piano driven "Day One". In the past, Tamia and Shep Crawford have tackled cover songs with great precision: DeBarge's "Love Me In A Special Way", The Winans' "Tomorrow" and Aretha Franklin's "Day Dreaming". This time around, they take on the 1983 Deniece Williams inspirational ballad "Black Butterfly". "Love Life" is a great recording from veteran singer Tamia. Though she's always had great material, this is the first album she's done where she sounds like she had a lot of fun doing it. Given Def Jam's long track record with their R&B acts, one has to wonder if she will get the recognition that she deserves. The only way is to wait and see.

Brooklyn, New York native Evelyn "Evie" Sands had one of the most heartbreaking stories in the music industry. As talented as she was with her voice and songwriting duties, she couldn't catch a break. When she was about to, other artists became famous from songs that originated with her. She was the protégé of Atlantic staff writers/producers Jerry Leiber & Mike Stoller. She recorded one of their songs "Take Me For A Little While", but her song made it into the offices of Chess Records- where singer Jackie Ross had a hit with the song. A couple of years later, another song she recorded "I Can't Let Go" became a hit for The Hollies. Shortly after, she recorded the song "Angel Of The Morning", but the label folded by the time the single was released (The song later became a signature song for country singer Juice Newton in 1981). In 1970, she moved to A&M Records for the release of the album "Any Way That You Want Me" and endured a shelved album for Buddah Records in 1971. She then decided to go on hiatus to focus on being a songwriter. She revived her career after a five year period of dormancy to record for Capitol subsidiary Haven Records.In 1975, she released her album "Estate Of Mind"- which was produced by Dennis Lambert & Brian Potter (The Four Tops, Tavares, Glen Campbell)- who also wrote a few tracks as well. Though her desire for success was dwarfed by label issues, Evie certainly didn't make it any easier with her music- which was, admittedly, difficult to categorize. She moved through rock and roll, jazz, rhythm and blues and pop as if it were second nature. She starts off the album with the hard rocker about  the woes of an ultra-busy girlfriend "A Woman's Work Is Never Done". She sings about midday sex on the ballad "Love In The Afternoon", while thanking a reformed bad boy on "You Brought The Woman Out Of Me". She desires romance on "One Thing On My Mind" (Which would later be covered by The Ebonys, Linda Clifford and Phyllis Hyman while also being sampled on "We Rollin'" from Tanya Morgan's 2011 album "You & What Army"). She thinks thoughts of inspiration on "Early Morning Sunshine" and wonders if there's second chance with an ex on the closer "(Am I) Crazy 'Cause I Believe". As great as "Estate Of Mind" is, the album barely gained any traction. She recorded one more album for RCA and decided to call it quits by the time "Suspended Animation" was released in 1979. Sands is an unsung hero of the 70's blue-eyed soul movement and her album deserves an honest listen.

West Coast rapper Xzibit made his initial debut on 1995 albums from King Tee and Tha Alkaholiks. He appeared on the former's lone album for MCA Records "King Tee IV Life" on the song "Free Style Ghetto" and the latter's sophomore effort "Coast II Coast"'s album track "Hit & Run". It was only a matter of time before the emcee released his formal debut and he did just that with 1996's critically acclaimed "At The Speed Of Life". He followed it up with the noticeably commercial "40 Dayz & 40 Nightz" with the creative music video for the first single "What U See Is What U Get". 1999 saw him make high profile appearances on Dr. Dre's "2001" as well as Snoop Dogg's comeback album "No Limit Top Dogg". As such, it led to Dr. Dre executive producing two of his albums- his multi-platinum "Restless" and 2002's "Man Vs. Machine". Despite the success, his career took a hit when Dr. Dre left and his longtime label Loud Records was folded into its parent company Columbia Records. The end result was the wonderful but poorly promoted "Weapons Of Mass Destruction". In the interim, he starred on the hit MTV series "Pimp My Ride" and done numerous acting gigs here and there.After releasing 2006's "Full Circle", Xzibit quietly disappeared from the music scene and made random appearances in films. It was thought among fans that he decided to leave music alone. However, in 2012, he released his album "Napalm" on his own label Open Bar Entertainment.
