"Napalm" contains production from the likes of M-Phazes, Illmind, Focus..., Rick Rock and even Dr. Dre. Some of the songs have a feel good vibe, such as "Everything", The Game and RBX assisted "Dos Equis" and "Enjoy The Night". However, the tracks that really stand out are the ones where Xzibit gets open and honest in details about his personal life. On "1983", he gets candid about his stint on MTV, his current relationship with his family and his fallout with Eminem and his manager Paul Rosenberg. He recalls his early life and career with Slim The Mobster on the inspirational "Stand Tall" and perseveres through struggle on "Spread It Out". On "Meaning Of Life", he celebrates living life with vocals from wounded Retired Staff Sergeant Shilo Harris. "Napalm" is a surprisingly great album form Xzibit. Though the album didn't recieve any promotion, the recording is well worth a listen.

Jazz and R&B have a long history of co-existing- much to the chagrin of music purists. Back in the 1970's, the jazz and R&B worlds would collide to form jazz fusion. Also, very notable jazz musicians became famous after their transitions into the R&B world. The list reads rather long, as the artists involved were Roy Ayers, Norman Connors, Ronnie Laws, Patrice Rushen, George Duke and George Benson, among others. By the turn of the 1980's, jazz and R&B would align again- this time under the subgenre smooth jazz. At times polarizing, it spawned the likes of Kenny G, Jeff Lorber and Pieces Of A Dream. At the turn of the century, there were blatant forays into R&B from jazz musicians Roy Hargrove and later, Robert Glasper. Joining this list is Lil' John Roberts- a drummer with 20 years of performing under his belt. Initially starting as a musician on Janet Jackson's "janet." tour, the Philadelphia native turned Atlanta transplant has been affiliated with some known and respected musicians in the music world. He later appeared as a musician on television shows such as "American Idol" and "Saturday Night Live". After going on tour with singer Ne-Yo, Roberts began recording his debut. He then signed to the neo-soul label Purpose Music Group- a record company best known for their signings of Bilal, Algebra Blessett and Anthony David.  A year's worth of work was created to form what became his debut album "The Heartbeat".The album is a star-studded affair, with some fellow musicians (Chris "Daddy" Dave, Pino Palladino, and James Poyser, among others). With the plethora of guests ranging from hip hop, rhythm and blues, rock and jazz, the records reads like a neo-soul version of Dr. Dre's "The Chronic". Starting off the album is the song "Space", which features vocals from Eric Roberson, Anthony David, Mint Condition's Stokley Williams and Musiq Soulchild. Musiq appears again- this time alongside singer Chantae Cann on the ballad "It's Your Time". Former Prince protege Ashley Tamar Davis appears on the Minneapolis influenced "Gimme Sumthin'". Byron Sowell appears on the rock infused "Grand Scheme", while George Duke makes one of his final appearances on "In A Duke Kinda Way", before his passing during the recording of the album. Rappers Kev Choice and Sa-Roc guest on two songs- the former on the inspirational "The Struggle" and the latter on "Get Right". Trumpeter Nicholas Payton on the funky instrumental "The Power", while smooth jazz saxophonist Walter Beasley shows up for "Forgiveness". Despite the abundance of original material, ironically the album's best track is a cover. In this case, it's the take on Leroy Hutson's 1978 song "Closer To The Source" with lead vocals from former Tease member and songwriter Kipper Jones. Lil' John Roberts' "The Heartbeat" is a great recording that plays to its strengths. Although the album is all over the place musically, it shows Roberts' extraordinary musicianship level and skill.

Maryland native Logic grew up in a turbulent household as a young child. Due to the nature of his upbringing, he sought solace in hip hop and formed a crew called the Ratt Pack. After initially going by the name Psychological, he soon shortened it to Logic before releasing his first mixtape "Young, Broke And Infamous". Shortly after the mixtape, he was sought after and signed by the independent label Visionary Music Group. After the succesful mixtape triolgy "Young Sinatra" ("Young Sinatra", "Undeniable" and "Welcome To Forever"), he recieved press from the likes of Billboard and XXL- with the latter putting him on the cover for their annual "Top Ten Freshemen List". A few months after the cover, he was signed to Def Jam Recordings by producer/A&R executive No I.D. (Best known for his work with Common, Jay-Z and Kanye West).  Since recording the album for nearly a year, Logic finally released his major label debut "Under Pressure" at the end of October 2014.What's noticeable about "Under Pressure" is the huge influence that rappers like Drake and Kendrick Lamar had over the album- despite Logic's allegiances to groups like OutKast and A Tribe Called Quest  (The skits between his songs are an obvious tribute to Tribe's 1993 album "Midnight Marauders"). The Drake and Kendrick Lamar comparisons are inevitable, but what sets Logic apart from them is the instrospection and candor in his songs- a theme that's fairly constant in the recording. Logic and his longtime producer 6ix handle the bulk of the album, with additional production from Strange Fruit Project's Symbolyc One, Austrailian beatmaker M-Phazes and DJ Khalil. He expresses thoughts on his career on "Intro", "Never Enough" and "Metropolis", while speaking on his difficult upbringing on "Soul Food". He celebrates his current position in life on "I'm Gone" and records the third installment of the maturity themed "Growing Pains". He has conflicting emotions toward smoking on "Nikki" and speaks from his own point of view as well as his parents on the nine minute title track "Under Pressure". Lastly, he traces his start from humble beginnings to getting a recording contract on "Till The End". "Under Pressure" is a great album from newcomer Logic. Despite the criticisms toward him, he crafted a well-produced and introspective freshman effort. The question that now remains is will Def Jam get behind him? There's only one way to find out.

The Oakland, California quartet Souls Of Mischief's origins started in elementary school. As two of the founding members entered into high school, they acquired two additional members and ran into Del Tha Funkee Homosapien. He founded the collective the Hierogylphics while still being under the guidance of his cousin Ice Cube. When Del decided to record his sophomore album "No Need For Alarm" with a different sound, the album introduced the group- as well as planting the seeds for the West Coast underground rap scene. The group obtained a deal with Jive Records to release their debut. While it started slow with the first single "That's When Ya Lost", it was the title track "'93 Til Infinity" that put the group on the map. As a result, it made their follow-up become highly anticipated. Unfortunately, a couple of setbacks threatened to derail their path to success. An on-air battle with Hobo Junction member Saafir proved embarrassing for them and sample clearances caused their second album to be pushed back repeatedly. In 1995, they finally released "No Man's Land" and due to the poor reception, they were dropped from Jive. In 1998, they went independent and recorded three albums as part of the Hieroglyphics. They recorded a couple more albums- including 2009's Prince Paul produced "Montezuma's Revenge"- before laying low for the remainder of the 2010's.In 2014, they got a call from producer Adrian Younge to record a new album. As such, they worked with him on the live instrument and sample-free concept album "There Is Only Now". Nararrated by their onetime labelmate Ali Shaheed Muhammad, the album is set in the past in 1994- several months after the release of "93 Til Infinity". The group deals with a kidnapping which later turns into a revenge tale. The album starts off with "Time Stopped", where they deal with the unexpected kidnapping. Busta Rhymes appears solo as the protagonist on the brief "Womack's Lament", while they search for member Tajai on "Panic Stuck". William Hart of The 70's group The Delfonics guest on "Another Part Of You" and Snoop Dogg makes an unlikely appearance on the title track "There Is Only Now".  On the song "All You Got Is Your Word", they take to task to other emcees who plagiarize their work. They detail an unfortunate encounter with a woman on "Miriam's Got A Mickey" and seek the need for a savior on "Ghetto Superhero". However, the album takes a rather dark turn with "Narrow Escape" and "Finally Back", where the members exact revenge on the kidnapper. Overall, "There Is Only Now" is a good album from the Souls Of Mischief. Adrian Younge's production may be an acquired taste, but works well with the film noir vibe of the recording. It's not as great as it should have been, but it's still a worthwhile effort from the West Coast underground hip hop veterans.

The R&B group Tease was a Los Angeles based band that contained some very notable members. The most memorable are the lead singer Kevin "Kipper" Jones and keyboard players Chuckii Booker and Rex Salas (The latter known for producing Vanessa Williams' hit single "The Right Stuff") and former bassist for Patrice Rushen Cornelius Mims. Originally signed to RCA Records, they released their first self-titled debut in 1983. Their debut had appearances from Ray Parker, Jr. and Gene Page and production from Ollie E. Brown (best known for his work with Parker's former group Raydio). Although the album tanked, they found a fan in former Capitol Records executive Larkin Arnold- who took the band over to Epic Records to record a follow up. In 1986, they recorded and released their sophomore effort (which was also self-titled) and featured production from Lakeside member Stephen Shockley. Musically and lyrically, their second recording is stronger than its predecessor.Even though they had been tagged as clones of The Time, a few songs on their second album don't exactly help their case. The most obvious examples are the songs "The Note", "Total Control" and "Better Wild (Than Mild)"- the latter Booker would reference on the title track to his sophomore album "Niice & Wiild". The best known song from the album- the single "Firestarter" could have easily been a Lakeside song, as it was penned by Shockley. They do a passable cover of James Brown's 1976 song "Body Heat". Aside from Shockley, another Solar Records connection comes by way of The Deele member Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds penning the ballad "Soft Music". Lastly, on "Baby Be Mine", the band interpolate the song "Nobody's Gonna Get This Lovin' But You" by their then-labelmates Krystol. The band would record one more album before calling it quits in 1989. Since then, Chuckii Booker released two albums on Atlantic Records, wrote and produced for the likes of Troop, Lalah Hathaway and Angela Winbush and became and in-demand musical director. Brothers Thomas and Derek Organ followed suit with Booker to assist with various projects. Finally, Kipper Jones released one album for Virgin Records and wrote songs for Vanessa Williams and Brandy- the latter of which he penned the hit songs, "Baby", "I Wanna Be Down" and "Brokenhearted". Despite being fairly derivative in their work, Tease's album is actually a good listen.

Singer Dave Hollister made his initial debut in 1991 as part of the Digital Underground spinoff group Force One Network. They recorded the song "Spirit (Does Anybody Care)" for the soundtrack of the John Singleton film "Boyz N The Hood". An album followed called "The MME Program 1", but Hollister's best known stuff came from his work outside of the group. He was featured on two songs by 2Pac- 1991's "Brenda's Got A Baby" and 1993's "Keep Ya Head Up". Although his previous group failed to gain any traction, he was summoned by Teddy Riley to join Blackstreet after the abrupt departure of original member Joseph Stonestreet. He appeared on their 1994 debut, while also writing and/or producing songs for the likes of Usher and Hi-Five member Tony Thompson and even contributing background vocals to Bruce Hornsby's album "Hot House". After leaving Blackstreet, Hollister linked up with Erick Sermon's Def Squad Records and "Ghetto Hymns" was originally slated for an early 1997 release. Plans were thwarted when Def Squad's distributor EMI Records was folded. He moved to DreamWorks for the formal release of "Ghetto Hymns" and his biggest album to date- "Chicago '85...The Movie". An ill-fated alliance with Motown came about for 2002's "Things In The Game Done Changed", while moving back to DreamWorks the following year for "Real Talk".A series of personal issues forced Hollister into finding solace with his Christian faith and he surprised everyone by recording two gospel albums for Verity Records. He also teamed up with neo-soul singer Eric Roberson and gospel singers Fred Hammond and Brian Courtney Wilson as part of the supergroup United Tenors. After appearing on the title track to Roberson's recent recording "The Box", Hollister announced his return to R&B with 2014's "Chicago Winds...The Saga Continues". A sequel of sorts to his classic sophomore effort, he decides to pick up where he left off and show off a personal and professional growth. Joining him for the album is producer Warryn Campbell (Mary Mary, Musiq Soulchild, Kelly Price, Dru Hill), who produces the entire record. Starting the album off is the commitment themed "Spend The Night", which also has a remix courtesy of Hollister's onetime mentor Teddy Riley. On the ballad "I'm Different", he serenades a woman with the premise of offering her something different from what she's experienced romantically. He gives his girlfriend some space on "I'm Waiting" and lacks the courage to end a relationship on the Tristan Wilds penned "Cold". Dave harbors no ill will toward an ex on "Wish You Well" and gets help from Jimmy Jam on piano and string arrangement on the ballad about balancing a music career with parenting "Chicago Winds". Two songs contain a direct influence from the Minneapolis sound: The ballad "Afraid To Lose" and the uptempo "Neverland". Overall, Dave Hollister's "Chicago Winds...The Saga Continues" is a good listen from the Illinois veteran. While it isn't as memorable as his earlier work, it's still a decent effort.

The Akron, Ohio duo The Black Keys had several albums under their belt by the time they broke through in 2010. The duo- comprised of drummer Patrick Carney and lead singer/guitarist Dan Auerbach first met and young children in the same neighborhood. Both would later grow up and attend the same college before dropping out to seriously pursue music. After several years of honing their craft, they recorded a demo which lead to recording their 2002 debut "The Big Come Up" for a small label. Though it was a modest seller, the band quickly attracted the attention of blues label Fat Possum Records. From that deal, they completed their sophomore effort "Thickfreakness". After releasing two EP's, they released two more albums: "Rubber Factory" and a Junior Kimbrough covers EP. They signed with Elektra subsidiary Nonesuch Records and issued 2006's "Magic Potion" and their first recording with producer Danger Mouse "Attack And Release". After a couple of side projects (Carney's band Danger and Auerbach's solo album "Keep It Hid"), they returned with the project "Blackroc"- a recording which had the duo record songs with their favorite hip hop artists.Later on, they released their breakthrough recording "Brothers"- followed up a year later by 2011's "El Camino". Auerbach then lent his production talents to other acts- notably dong three songs on Grace Potter & The Nocturnals 2011 album "The Lion, The Beast, The Beat" and Lana Del Rey's sophomore record "Ultraviolence". They returned in 2014 with "Turn Blue"- their fifth album with Nonesuch and their fourth recording with Danger Mouse. Musically, the band moves away from the blues-rock that everyone knows them for and attempts a more experimental sound in the vein of psychedelic rock. Lyrically, the album is a breakup album- spurned by Auerbach's divorce from his wife The album starts off with the nearly seven minute track "Weight Of Love", followed up with their trademark sound on "In Time". The first single "Fever" takes cues from 60's British Invasion, while "Year In Review" chronicles the demise of a relationship. Auerbach blames himself for the outcome on "Bullet In The Brain", while the ballad "Waiting On Words" works in the riff of Kool & The Gang's often-sampled album track "You Don't Have To Change". "10 Lovers" bears a noticeable commercial sound, and the album closes with the uptempo "Gotta Get Away". Overall, The Black Keys made a listenable effort with "Turn Blue". The change in sound may be an acquired taste for some, but no one could accuse them of staying inside their comfort zone. It's not for everyone, but it's an entertaining listen nonetheless.

Prince enjoyed a very successful run at Warner Bros. Records for the first fifteen years of his career. His contributions to the label hadn't went unnoticed and as such, they rewarded him a lucrative multi-million dollar contract. However, shortly after the deal, Prince's attitude towards the label shifted from enthusiastic to disdain as he felt they tried to stifle his creativity. To make matters worse, he also found out that he didn't own the rights to his name. He later changed his name to a symbol and released several albums within a short amount of time to get out of his contract with Warner Bros. In 1996, he was free from contractual obligation with Warner Bros. Records, but he was still bound to their publishing company. Still using the symbol moniker, he signed with EMI Records to release the three album set "Emancipation". His tenure with the label would be short-lived, as EMI folded a few months after the album's release. A few years later, he signed with Arista Records after meeting with its founder Clive Davis. His time there would be short as well, as Davis was replaced by L.A. Reid- who suggested that Prince outsource songwriting and production duties from other producers. By the 2000's, Prince decided to go independent.The independent phase didn't last long, as he found himself back on a major label- starting with Columbia (for 2004's "Musicology" and 2007's "Planet Earth") and later, Universal (for 2006's "3121"). After another independent release issued solely through Target (2009's "Lotusflower"), Prince surprised everyone with the news that he was going to sign with Warner Bros. again. In 2014, he released his newest recording- the funk based project "Art Official Age". The album has one foot in the present, while the other foot is mired in the past- recalling songs that wouldn't sound out of place on "Controversy", "Purple Rain", or even "Sign O' The Times". On the opening track "Art Official Cage", he expresses his attitude towards the future, and deals with heartbreak on the pensive ballad "Breakdown". He hands in a throwback track "The Gold Standard", while issuing sexual come-ons on "Breakfast Can Wait". On the ballad "This Could Be Us", he taunts a woman who's scared of commitment. He duets with his all-female band 3rd Eye Girl on "What It Feels Like" as well as the song "Funknroll". Lastly, he reflects on his life and looks toward the future on the poignant "Way Back Home". "Art Official Age" is a great album from Prince. After 35 years in the music business, he still makes great music without compromising his integrity.

Bronx rapper and producer Diamond D. originally got his start in the group Ultimate Force in the late 1980's. The group would disband after their debut album was shelved by MCA Records- which led him to start the role as a producer. He then started a collective- Diggin' In The Crates, or D.I.T.C.- which also included Showbiz & A.G., O.C., Buckwild, Big L and a pre-Terror Squad Fat Joe. In the Fall of 1992, released his classic debut "Stunts, Blunts & Hip Hop"- an album that was anchored by the singles "Best Kept Secret" and "Sally Got A One Track Mind". In between albums, he continued to produce songs for the likes of Illegal, Busta Rhymes, Tha Alkaholiks and the song from the "Panther" motion picture, "Freedom"- which he produced with Dallas Austin. By the time he issued his sophomore set "Hatred, Passions And Infidelity", he was five years removed from his debut. He had a very lengthy battle with his former label- the Stock Aitken Waterman owned Chemistry Records- which delayed the album. When it was released during hip hop's materialistic stage, it was barely noticed, and the Universal-PolyGram merger that was right around the corner didn't help matters either. In the 2000's, he released three albums independently- a mixtape and his long-shelved debut with his former group the Ultimate Force. In 2011, he surprised everyone by producing the song "Shine" on Pharoahe Monch's album "W.A.R. (We Are Renegades)". That gave Diamond D. the sign to proceed with a new album and he did just that by releasing "The Diam Piece" in late 2014.Unlike most of his recordings where he did the majority of the rapping, he decided to focus on production while letting the guests takeover and delivering the occasional verse and chorus here and there. He reunites with a couple of old friends (such as Fat Joe and A.G.), fellow producers (Pete Rock, Nottz) and works with newer artists that he admires. Starting off the album is the Pharoahe Monch featured "Rap Life" while Talib Kweli, Elzhi and Skyzoo question loyalty over a sample of Yes' song "Starship Trooper" on "Where's The Love". Fat Joe, Freddie Foxx and former child rapper Chi-Ali trades verses on the rock inspired "It's Nothin'", and Pete Rock lends his voice to the track "Only Way 2 Go". The Pharcyde guests on "Hard Days", as Black Rob delivers a club ready song in the form of "Take 'Em Off Da Map". Female rappers Rapsody, Boog Brown and Stacy Epps trade verses on "Pump Ya Brakes", as West Coast emcees Kurupt and The Alkaholiks team up for "We Are The People Of The World". Dilated Peoples member Evidence and producer The Alchemist appear on the brief "It's Magic", and the former Biz Markie protégé Grand Daddy I.U. shows that he still has it on "The Game". Diamond D. teams up with Masta Ace on "Ace Of Diamonds" and closes the album with the only song he didn't produce, the DJ Scratch helmed "Superman". "The Diam Piece" is a great album from Diamond D. He shows that he is still capable of doing what he does best and staying true to his art for almost 25 years- not many in the industry can lay claim to that.

Most artists who've had a bad experience with a record label would either quit or immerse themselves in working behind the scenes. The same cannot be said for New Jersey singer-songwriter and occasional producer Eric Roberson. When Warner Bros. Records shelved what would have been his debut album 20 years earlier, Eric became a man about town in the music industry. His songwriting work landed him on albums by 112, Musiq Soulchild and the soundtrack to the 1999 Will Smith film "Wild Wild West", where Roberson's songs dominated roughly half of the album. After finishing college with a degree in business management, Eric and his father established the independent label Blue Erro Soul. It would be there where he would release the bulk of his most of his studio albums. Despite being on an indie, Eric managed to build a cult following and have a few of his songs receive radio spins- with his biggest hit being the Lalah Hathaway duet about infidelity "Dealing". A decade after resuming his recording career, he entered into a distribution deal with E1 Music for the release of "Mister Nice Guy". While the company meant well, E1 Music released a summer single "Summertime Anthem" in the middle of fall and the should-have-been first single "Picture Perfect" was inexpliciably released as the second single.After that fiasco, Eric Roberson parted ways with E1 Music. In the interim, he teamed up with R&B singer Dave Hollister and gospel singers Fred Hammond and Brian Courtney Wilson for the one-off gospel supergroup United Tenors. Eric soon found distribution again- this time around with the Columbia, Maryland based label Liaison Records. In 2014, he celebrated his two decades in the music business with "The Box"- a new album that finds Eric focused mostly on live instrumentation. Production for most of the songs on "The Box" were handled by the team of Aaron Hardin & Slimkat 78 (The same producers behind the aforementioned song "Picture Perfect"). He also works with longtime producer Brett Baker on a few songs as well. Starting the album off is "Lust For Love" featuring a rare appearance from rapper turned entertainment attorney Tracey Lee. He works with Dave Hollister on the title track "The Box", while working with the indie soul trio KING on "Just Imagine". He tries to fall in love despite having reservations on the bayou blues feel of "Pill". Pharoahe Monch makes a rare guest appearance on an R&B album on "The Cycle", where Eric tales the story of a woman and her neverending series of bad relationships. Lastly, he duets with his father on the ballad about commitment "Do The Same For Me". "The Box" is yet another great album from Eric Roberson. It's pretty much what one would expect from him, while giving the fans something new as well.

Singer-songwriter Bill Champlin got his start with the band Sons Of Champlin. The band recorded three albums for Capitol Records- beginning with 1969's "Loosen Up Naturally", "The Sons" and "Follow Your Heart". The band broke up the first time and reformed in time for 1973's "Welcome To The Dance"- their lone recording for Columbia Records. Three more albums followed until they decided to call it quits for good in 1977. Now 30 years old, Champlin became the go-to guy for session work after moving to Los Angeles in that same year. He released his debut album "Single" in 1978 on Epic Records. While Epic meant well, they didn't know what to do with a musician who genre-hopped like it was second nature. He would experience the same obstacle at Elektra Records- where he would release his sophomore effort "Runaway". His second album- much like his debut- was produced by David Foster, who also worked with Champlin as a songwriter and would eventually include him in the band Chicago.Much like his previous efforts, Bill rolls through genres like it's nothing. He goes on to take on West Coast AOR, hard rock, pop ballads and also R&B. Even though R&B seems like an out of place genre for Champlin, consider that this is the same guy who co-wrote "After The Love Has Gone" for Earth, Wind & Fire, "Turn Your Love Around" for George Benson and "Stay With Me" for Cherrelle. He opens the album with the title track "Runaway", where he sings of a small town kid with big city dreams of being a musician. He focuses his attention elsewhere after being left behind on "One Way Ticket", while getting songwriting help from songwriter turned actor Alan Thicke on the ballad "Sara". He hopes for a second chance with someone on "Tonight Tonight" and collaborates with Kenny Loggins on the radio friendly "Take It Uptown". Bill gets annoyed by his new neighbors on the amusing "Stop Knocking On My Door" and pleads to fix things in the relationship on "Gotta Get Back To Love". Shortly after the release of "Runaway", Champlin was recruited for Chicago and sporadically resumed his recording career. Unfortunately, the Chicago affiliation didn't help his solo career much, but he became a popular act in Japan- mirroring the same fate that also happened to one of his peers around the same time, Texas native Eric Tagg. Even though "Runaway" is kind of hard to come by, it's not an album to pass up.

Los Angeles native Leela James first came to the public's attention by way of Pete Rock's third album "Soul Survivor II". On that recording, she sang the uplifting and powerful "No Tears". She worked on her debut album for nearly a year before the label she was signed to folded. As a result, her contract would be picked up by Warner Bros. Records- where she would release her debut "A Change Is Gonna Come". With production from high profile names such as Chucky Thompson, Wyclef Jean and Kanye West, her record was critically acclaimed, but didn't gain much traction due to Warner Bros.' very late arrival to the neo-soul movement. As such, she would leave the label and go independent by signing with Shanachie Records for her sophomore effort- the all covers project "Let's Do It Again". Leela would give the major labels one last try after releasing her third album "My Soul" on the newly reactivated legendary soul label Stax Records. That recording also stalled and Leela once again went independent for the tribute album "Loving You More... In The Spirit Of Etta James".One reason for her lack of success has a lot to do with her voice. Even though she was around the same age as her contemporaries at the time Beyonce and Keyshia Cole, she has a voice that made her sound much older than she really was. Not helping matters was her music being relegated to the neo-soul market- even as she tried to make inroads into urban contemporary R&B. She went to rectify that situation by taking her destiny in her own hands. The first of which was creating her own label J&T Records- the second thing was making a more accessible album. She did just that in 2014 with the release of her new album "Fall For You". Almost gone is her gravelly voiced growl replaced by a high pitched wail and sultry come-ons. She works with a variety of contemporary producers, such as Drew Ramsey & Shannon Sanders (Anthony David, Heather Headley) on the opening track "Who's Gonna Love You More" and Tim & Bob (Bobby Valentino, Donell Jones, Brian McKnight) on the Al Green sampling "Do Me Right". She collaborates with singer Anthony Hamilton on "Say That" and seduces a lover on the Mike City produced "Give It". She demands to be let go from a bad relationship on "Set Me Free" and closes the album with "Save Me" featuring an appearance from newcomer Joe Ryan. Though the change in sound is surprising, in the end "Fall For You" is a great album from Leela James. This time around, she may find that mainstream success that has forever eluded her.

By the time Durrell "Tank" Babbs signed to Atlantic Records in early 2010, he was a decade long veteran with a few albums under his belt. Formerly signed to Barry Hankerson's now-defunct Blackground Records, he released 2001's "Force Of Nature", followed up by 2002's "One Man" and almost quitting music before releasing 2007's "Sex, Love & Pain". While he has made strides in the recording industry, his name often went unmentioned with other R&B singer-songwriters- even while working behind the scenes. He addressed his frustration with the issue on the dark and moody mixtape "Diary Of A Mad Man"- specifically on the song "Underrated", where he bemoaned the fact that he wasn't being recognized the same way as his peers. Part of the problem was that people paid more attention to his looks and physique than they did to his songwriting and production skills- for which he would lend to the likes of Toni Estes, Dave Hollister and Chris Brown. Another part was his dramatic about face change to sing more about sex than love when he moved to Atlantic. After the release of "This Is How I Feel", he teamed up with Tyrese and Ginuwine for the much talked about TGT album "Three Kings" in 2013. Despite the success of that union, he felt a little uninspired- that was until he listened to Justin Timberlake's return to music "The 20/20 Experience". That record lit a fire under Tank and the end result is his new album "Stronger".He decided to make an album that paid tribute to the dance music and electro-funk of yesteryear- complete with live instrumentation, a horn section and an orchestra. He also shifted his focus back to singing from the heart and writing great songs. With that formula, he went in and recorded ten songs- all of which showcases how much work he put into this project and the risk paid off for him. The leading song is the first single "You're My Star", which features a sample of The Jacksons' "This Place Hotel" as well as background vocals from Kelly Rowland. Wyclef Jean's production partner Jerry "Wonda" Duplessis handles the lion's share of the album- with the highlight of one of his contributions being the Chic-esque track "Dance With Me". Tank also pays tribute to both Marvin Gaye and Prince- the former on "Missing You" and the latter on "Hope This Makes You Love Me". He delivers a power ballad in the form of the title track "Stronger", which was produced by Infinity (The same guy behind Mary J. Blige's Grammy Award winning "Take Me As I Am"). He closes the album with the torch song "If That's What It Takes"- a jazz ballad that was surprisingly produced by Da Internz (Best known for Big Sean's "Dance (A$$)" and Rihanna's "Birthday Cake"). "Stronger" is Tank's best album since "Sex, Love & Pain", and possibly his best album period. With him showing a lot of growth and maturity this time around, the question is will he stick to it? Only time will tell.

West Coast rapper Blu rode a wave of critical acclaim ever since he released "Below The Heavens" with producer Exile in 2007. After a few collaboration albums with the likes of Mainframe and Ta'Raach, Blu was offered a recording contract. The label that offered him a deal was Sire Records- one-time label home to Ice-T, whose last hip hop album that was released on the label was Donald D's underrated 1992 sophomore effort "Let The Horns Blow". With the go ahead to record his major label debut, the record company hoped he was recording something along the lines of "Below The Heavens". However, Blu clearly had other plans. He worked on the album that was called "No York"- an experimental and ambitious body of work. Though Blu loved the album, Sire and its parent company Warner Bros. Records was repeatedly going through internal changes- which resulted in numerous delays. As a result, Blu left the label and decided to release the album for free over the internet. In 2012, he reunited with Exile again for their second set together, "Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them". After releasing "No York" on physical product, he released his newest recording "Good To Be Home" at the end of spring in 2014.The recording was released as a double album produced solely by Bombay, whose lo-fi sound is noticeably similar to another West Coast producer, Madlib. Over the course of the 60 minute recording, Blu explores everyday life in Los Angeles, California, with guests who mostly hail from Cali- save for Mobb Deep member Prodigy on "Red & Gold". He opens the recording with the aptly-titled "Home" with vocals from independent soul singer Jimetta Rose. He details growing up in a gang infested neighborhood on "The Return" and collaborates with Fashawn and Pac Div on "Boyz N The Hood". Blu trades verses with Bombay on the song about having fun on "Summer Time". He gets help with MED and Oh No on "Brown Sugar" and duets with Thurz and Casey Veggies on their relationship troubles on "Well Fare". He has a seven minute posse cut "Can't Stop, Won't Stop" which features numerous people- including The Alchemist, Evidence, Planet Asia and Chace Infinte. Lastly, he closes the album with the instrumental "The West (Part Two)". "Good To Be Home" is a great album from Blu. Despite constant criticisms aimed toward his discography, he shows that he can make his best work when he's completely focused.

The California trio Dilated Peoples got off to a rocky start earlier in their career. Originally signed to Immortal/Epic Records, they were planning to release their debut in 1995- that is, until it got shelved by the label. They went to the indie label ABB Records and released a few 12 inch singles here and there, while group member Evidence produced one-third of Defari's 1998 debut "Focused Daily". They raised their profile by appearing on the Gold-selling Rawkus compilation "Soundbombing II". That appearance led to them being signed to Capitol Records where in 2000, they released their formal debut- the critically acclaimed "The Platform". 2001 saw the release of their sophomore effort "Expansion Team" and three years later, followed the somewhat commercial "Neighborhood Watch". In 2006, they released what became their final album for Capitol, "20/20". In 2007, Evidence released his solo debut "The Weatherman LP", while Rakaa released "Crown Of Thorns" a few years later. Within that time, the group's future was up in the air- even amongst the members themselves. Things started to change when Evidence signed with Rhymesayers to release "Cats & Dogs". Not only did the label sign him, but also the group- and so began the journey into their first album in nearly a decade, "Directors Of Photography".While most of Dilated Peoples' albums were helmed primarily by Evidence and The Alchemist, this time around their production contributions amount to very little. Evidence produces the title track, the Vince Staples assisted "The Dark Room" and two interludes, while The Alchemist oversees the Sick Jacken featured "L.A. River Drive" and the track recalling their formative years in their hometowns "Cut My Teeth". DJ Babu produces three songs: the bass heavy scratch track "Figure It Out (Melvin's Theme)", "The Reversal" and Opinions May Vary". On "Directors Of Photography", they reunite with DJ Premier on the first single "Good As Gone", while getting production help from D.I.T.C. member Diamond D. on the search for serenity "Let Your Thoughts Fly Away". Madlib's younger brother Oh No produces "Century Of The Self", with 9th Wonder overseeing the closing track "The Bigger Picture" featuring Strong Arm Steady member Krondon. Though most of the album is clearly geared towards the underground, the Aloe Blacc featured "Show Me The Way" sounds like it was meant to become a radio hit. "Directors Of Photography" is another great album from Dilated Peoples. They may been gone for eight years, but they haven't missed a step- and that's a good thing.

After spending a decade behind the scenes as a songwriter and producer, Robin Thicke decided to forge ahead with a career as a recording artist. In 2003, he released his debut "Cherry Blue Skies"- which was later retooled as "A Beautiful World". The album was critically acclaimed, but was way too eclectic for some people. He sought to change that with his sophomore effort "The Evolution Of Robin Thicke". His next album "Something Else" paid a clear tribute to 70's R&B and disco, while 2009's "Sex Therapy" had him testing the waters by working with hip hop artists and producers. 2011 saw the release of "Love After War", but the album didn't break any new ground for Robin. That would all change with 2013's "Blurred Lines"- which, to date, has given him the biggest pop hit of his career. However, in a move similar to the film "A Star Is Born"- albeit with gender roles reversed- his career was riding high while his marriage to actress Paula Patton was on the rocks. The couple eventually split- much to chagrin of Robin himself. Instead of following up with another pop driven album, he decided to pay tribute to his estranged wife- hence the title of his new album "Paula".While the theme of the album centers around lost love, sadness and regret, musically it sounds like a typical Robin Thicke album. In fact, one could say it's a continuation of "Love After War". Like most of his albums, Robin produced it with his longtime songwriting and production partner James "Pro-Jay" Gass. "Paula" is rife with genre hopping as it moves through bossa nova ("You're My Fantasy"), as well as adult contemporary ("Get Her Back" and "Still Madly Crazy"). On the songs "Lock The Door" and "Black Tar Cloud", his conscience eats at him for his past mistakes. He tries to find someone new on the James Brown inspired "Livin' In New York City" and realizes his estranged wife's personal freedom on "Whatever I Want". Robin remains optimistic on "Love Can Grow Back", while getting help from pop group Fifth Harmony on "The Opposite Of Me". While most of the album is great, there are a couple of songs that could have been left behind- specifically the jazz influenced songs. The tracks in question are "Tippy Toes", "Something Bad" and "Time Of Your Life". Though they aren't bad songs per se, they are better suited for pop-jazz crooners like Michael Buble. "Paula" is a good album from Robin Thicke. Though media hype and controversy put this album in a negative light for the pop fans, in the end this album was made strictly for the people who supported him for the duration of his career.

Canadian singer-songwriter Sarah McLachlan seemed to be destined to become a star. Barely one year into college, she signed a recording contract with the Vancouver based label Nettwerk with distribution from Arista Records in the United States. She released her formal debut "Touch" in 1989, which was propelled by the first single "Vox". She traded in producer Greg Reely for Pierre Marchand for her next album- 1991's "Solace"- and the pairing would prove to be a great move for her career. 1993 saw the release for her critically acclaimed album "Fumbling Towards Ecstasy"- which contained the first single "Possession", a song inspired by letters that a stalker wrote to McLachlan. In 1997, she broke through with her most successful recording to date- 1997's "Surfacing". The album yielded major pop hits such as "Building A Mystery", "Sweet Surrender" and "Adia" as well s the popular album track "Angel". After the success of that recording, she launched the all-female tour "Lilith Fair" and released the live album "Mirrorball". After laying low for several years, McLachlan returned in 2003 with "Afterglow" while Arista was going through corporate changes. She would disappear for several years until 2010, when she released what became her final record for Arista, "Laws Of Illusion".During her four year hiatus, she dealt with a few personal changes. The first of which was changing labels- she signed a contract with Verve Records after being with Arista for over 20 years. The second change was adjusting to life without her father, whom she lost last year. That loss became the inspiration behind her new album "Shine On". Most of her new recording was produced by her longtime producer Pierre Marchand- with the notable exception of a few songs. She works with producer Bob Rock (Bon Jovi, Metallica, Veruca Salt) on three songs- "Flesh And Blood", the pensive "Love Behind Me" and "Turn The Lights Down Low", which was co-written by former member of the Eagles Don Felder. Sarah teams up with Vincent Jones to produce the sensual ballad "The Sound That Love Makes", which was penned by Whitehorse member Luke Doucet. On the opening song "In Your Shoes", Sarah offers words of encouragement to a woman who cracks under the weight of negative criticism. "Monsters" shows Sarah taking an optimistic point of view on being in a bad relationship, while paying tribute to her dad on "Song For My Father". "Shine On" is a good album from Sarah McLachlan. While it's pretty much what one would expect from her, it seems as if she's in a better space despite the problems she's dealt with over the years.

Even though the music industry has been known as being youth oriented, there have been many who released their debut albums in their 30's. The long list of musicians include Roberta Flack, Sheryl Crow, Bill Withers, Macy Gray, Carrie Lucas and K.T. Oslin, to name a few. Joining that list is the Chester, Pennsylvania singer Denise White- known to many as Avery Sunshine. She spent her formative years in the background as a church musician, while performing on projects like the soundtrack to the Beyoncé Knowles and Cuba Gooding, Jr. film "The Fighting Temptations". She also lent her vocals to a house single that was only released in Japan, and was even hired as a musician for the stage plays "Meet The Browns" and "Dreamgirls". In 2010, she independently released her self-titled debut, which quickly made the rounds in the neo-soul circuit. The album was also a calling card for her to sign with a label, and she did just that by signing with Shanachie Records to release her sophomore effort "The SunRoom".Employing the tactic of "If it ain't broke, don't fix it", she produces most of the album with her longtime musical partner Dana Johnson with a little help from Incognito founder Jean-Paul "Bluey" Maunick. The 60's influenced "Time To Shine" was produced by Demien DeSandies, whose best known for his work with Carl Thomas. "The SunRoom" has a recurring theme of positivity and spirituality- as evidenced by the leading track, the Al Green influenced "Won't You Try". On the first single "Call My Name", she makes an effort to make things right in the relationship- as there is a lack of communication on both parties. She takes an optimistic approach to living life on "One Foot Ahead" as well as being in love on "Nothing To Something". On "I Do Love You (You Ain't Got To Lie)", Avery rides a bluesy rhythm while delivering a hilarious rant on an ill-behaved significant other. She stays true to her religious beliefs with the jazz influenced "Meditation #1 (Conversation With God)" as well as the album closer "Safe In His Arms". "The SunRoom" is a great album from Avery Sunshine. Despite being on an indie label, there's a good chance that you're going to hear a lot more from her- that is, if this project is any indication. Hopefully, that will be the case in the near future.

For about fifteen years, Coldplay has become the band that everyone either wants to love- or wants to hate. After releasing two EP's ("Safety" in 1998 and "The Blue Room" in 1999), they made their formal debut with 2000's "Parachutes". Just when one thought they couldn't outdo themselves, they released the now-classic follow-up "A Rush Of Blood To The Head". In 2005, the members  Chris Martin, Will Champion, Jonny Buckland and Guy Berryman went back in the studio for their next recording- "X & Y". However, the album was panned and didn't do as well as its predecessors. They sought to rectify that situation by enlisting the production talents of Brian Eno (best known for his work with U2, David Bowie and the Talking Heads). As a result, they released what's considered their best album to date- 2008's "Viva La Vida Or Death And All His Friends". 2011 saw the release of their fifth recording "Mylo Xyloto"- which became their final recording for Capitol Records. The reason being is by the following year, their parent company- The EMI Group- had been struggling for years after losing a few of their major acts (For example: Paul McCartney and Coldplay's primary influence, Radiohead). The recorded music division of EMI was sold to Universal Music Group, while EMI's British based Parlophone Records was sold to Warner Music Group. As a result of the corporate changes, Coldplay became the newest signees to Atlantic Records.Their first project under Atlantic is 2014's "Ghost Stories"- an album that was clearly inspired by Martin's separation from his wife, actress Gwenyth Paltrow earlier in the year. The two met when Coldplay were touring behind "A Rush Of Blood To The Head". When they separated in March, the status of their relationship became the concept behind "Ghost Stories". Coldplay produced the album with longtime collaborators Jon Hopkins and recording engineers/mixers Daniel Green and Rik Simpson. Also helping out on production is Paul Epworth- who is best known for his work with Adele, Foster The People, Cee-Lo Green and Florence And The Machine. "Ghost Stories" explores the various stages of feelings after a breakup- ranging from shock and surprise (As evidenced on the first track "Always In My Head") to acceptance (See: the closing track "O", which features additional vocals from Chris and Gwenyth's children Moses and Apple). Another theme running throughout the recording is the blatant influence of electronica on the material. Timbaland lends assistance on drums for the track "True Love", while onetime Rap-A-Lot staff producer turned Kanye West associate Mike Dean helps with the overall sound. On the single "Magic", Chris hopes for a possible reconciliation and insists he's interested in no one else. "Ghost Stories" is a good album from Coldplay. It's not as memorable or as moving as their earlier work, but it's an interesting listen from a band that continues to challenge themselves.

I read a lot of books, and I have started just reviewing books for new authors I found, or authors I don't feel like are getting the big amount readers they should be getting. It also has to be a book I loved.I'm breaking my own rule here with this book. Ms. Slaughter gets lots of readers, sells lots of books, and doesn't need me singing her praises.However, this book was edge of your seat, do not talk to me I'm reading book and I just wanted to give a shout out to Ms. Slaughter and say thanks for a really, really great read.The subject was not always easy, really kind of horrible at times, but I kept going, waded through the difficult parts, because I had to know the truth. I had to know what would happen to the characters, and what had happened to characters from the past. There were some surprises along the way that made me gasp out loud, and a few things I saw coming, but it did not take away from the overall suspense.I highly recommend this book.

Want to start off saying I am a huge fan of Mr. Maberry's. I read a lot of books, all genres, and the Joseph Ledger series by Mr. Maberry is an absolute favorite. I have the read the books more than once, and have them in audio as well.I decided to try his other series, and am making my way through them, but I just finished this trilogy and wanted to voice my opinion.I found the first book a little slow, but I realize now, it was only because the stories in the books take place over approximately a month, and I'm glad I was able to read one book after another. It was like reading one really long book, and each book built on the one before. By the third book, I was so invested in the characters and in the story, I could not put the book down. Mr. Maberry is a wonderful story teller.The setting of the town of course was another character, and if you like horror, or just plain creepiness, I think this trilogy is a must read.I did find a set of short stories on audible that also take place in Pine Deep, I am in the process of listening to them now. Kind of going slow, don't want them to end!If you have not read Mr. Maberry, do yourself a favor and read his books. This is the third trilogy of his I have read, cannot get enough. I'm not a fan of zombie stories but I even liked his Dead of Night series. Again....wonderful storyteller.....

This book was suggested by an author I follow on Facebook, or maybe a review page I follow. When I finished the book, I tried to go back to where I first saw it, so I could thank the person that suggested it to me. Couldn't find it, so I decided to post my own Amazon review instead and just thank the author.I read three to four books a week and only review new authors or books that I fall in love with, this falls into the latter category. The main character, a policeman, single father, and new dog owner, captivated me from the beginning. The story itself, had twists and turns along the way that were intriguing, a couple I did not see coming.On Mr. Parson's Amazon page, I saw there is a sequel to this book coming in a week or so, I'm so glad. I was not ready to let the character go at the end of the book, I have already ordered the new one.If you like mysteries, police procedurals and wonderful characters, this book is for you.

I knew before I even read this book, it would be great. I remember very fondly the first book in this series, and my passion for these books is still way up there.The author always uses the setting as another character, I think that is a big part of what first attracted me. The main character has grown so much through the books and it made for such a great read this time. I was really proud of him, which sounds kind of crazy, but with this series, you get to feel as if you know the character. Mike is a great character to know. It has been so much fun watching him come into his own.I have to admit, Mr. Dorion really got me this time. Twice I thought I had the mystery figured out, twice I was wrong.If you are not reading this series, I think it would fine to read this one now, however I know you will want to go back and start at the beginning. However, this book particularly reads as if it could be an enjoyable stand alone, there is enough background to build an interest, but the story really stands on it's own. You won't feel as if you are missing anything.It just so happens I had won an ARC of this book in a contest that Mr. Dorion had on his web page, but I had already ordered it, so I would have read it anyway. I have not missed one of these since the series started. Can I say I am already waiting impatiently for the next one?

I sat down to write this review, and I can honestly say, i have misgivings about this book. With that said, I can also honestly say, I really enjoyed it, read it quickly because I was caught up in it, and it really is a fun book.My main misgiving? I felt like the characters were a little shallow. I didn't feel as if I got to know them enough. I also felt like the author missed out on adding more humor to the book through the main character. Toward the end of the book, the humor was peeking through from inner dialogue that the main character was having, wish there was more of that.Still, I thought the premise of the story was great (I could see this being a great beginning to a TV show) and the action scenes were well written. Again,  I read it really fast because there was enough interest and excitement to keep me reading. Also loved the kids and the relationship the main character had with them, enjoyed the stay at home dad things. A couple of things happened that I could see coming, but also a couple of things that I didn't.If you like thrillers, I think you would enjoy this, and I would like to see the character again, if not a TV show in the book's future, a book series is another good possibility.***i just read on a review of this book at bookreporter.com that the rights to this book have been sold for a TV series. I was hoping for a sequel to the novel...not sure if that will happen or not, hoping the TV show will be good!

This is a great read, a beginning to what I hope will be a long series.First of all, I really liked the character. There are still a lot of unaswered questions about the character's history, but I look forward to getting to know him.  I liked the premise, a little like a Jack Reacher, a person going where needed, doing what needs to be done, and yet not infallible.The character is an expert at finding people, which is how he makes his living. This story has him working with the FBI, and all the characters were intriguing, especially the villain of the story.I can't wait for the next installment , already ordered! Again, if you like thrillers, or police procedurals, or just plain old good storytelling, this is a must read.

I have been a fan of Mr. Baldacci since his first book. I have enjoyed most of them,some more than others, but I have to say, this book is one of his best. Also I don't do reviews much for authors who will get lots of readers no matter what, and Mr. Baldacci is one of those authors. Still, I felt compelled to voice my opinion anyway.I loved this book. The premise struck me as so interesting! I put down what I was reading and started this yesterday. I could not put this book down. The character was an unusual hero, physically and other wise, which made the story so much more interesting. The murderer's motive was unusual to say the least, and although I guessed a couple of things, most of it I had to wait for things to unfold as I read the book.I highly recommend this book, just give yourself enough reading time after you start it, you won't be able to stop reading.

So I have given this book five stars but I did have one complaint. The good first....this series just gets better and better. I love these characters, and I really like how the writer has added character's personalities to the series. Even the newer character that has become part of the group adds so much to the stories. This particular book had me reading really fast, the action was pretty non stop and the reader was learning about the story along with the characters. The reader did not know why everyone wanted the "searched"  for person until the characters did.Which brings me to my one complaint. I hated parts of the ending. I am not one to complain normally about an author ends his or her book, but this ending fell kind of flat to me. So before I wrote the review, trying to decide if this was a four or five star book. I decided not to take any stars off for the ending, I could not put the book down, that is a five star! I also loved the kind of keystone cop kind of atmosphere, everyone chasing after the same person, everyone getting in each other's way. Very fun!

I have been a huge fan of Brian Haig since I was first introduced to his main character, Sean Drummond. Although I am one of those leftyLiberals that Sean seems to hate so much, I adore his character. Mr. Drummond always makes me laugh, the cases he works are always interesting, and in this book, I wasn't sure exactly who the murderer was. Which of course is the reason to read mysteries and books with lawyers.It has been a long time since the last Sean Drummond book, I thought the author had given up on the character. I was so glad to see him back. Don't make me wait so long for the next one please!

I have had this book on my Kindle for a while. Well, actually just the first couple of chapters that were downloaded as a sample. For some reason I decided to give it a try today, maybe to see if it would settle my excitement for the new Joe Pickett novel that is coming this month. Boy did it work.I started the book this morning, and I could not put it down. It was not a thriller that had me on the edge of my seat, rather a slow, character driven story, that enveloped me before I even realized it was happening. I got so involved with the Sheriff, his deputies, his family...I could not stop reading.I figured out who the bad guy was pretty quickly, but with more people involved that I didn't know, and the actual crime a question mark, I found the whole book a really satisfying read.There was one incident in the book that I am not sure why the author put it in, but to avoid spoilers, I won't mention it. Not sure if there is more to that incident or not for a later book. However, it did not take away my positive feeling for the book at all.I cannot recommend this book highly enough. Don't miss it.

I really do not like short stories or novellas. I prefer full length novels, and lately so many of my authors are publishing short stories and novellas for the characters in their series. I really wish though, if they want to do that, they would not make it a  must read for the character or story development. I kind of resent it actually...And to me, this book, if you like the series, is important to the character. If you pick up the next book in the series without reading this book, you have missed whole spot in this characters story.With that said, I did read it, loved the story, I love the main character, and I recommend this series to anyone a fan of urban fantasy or fantasy. It may appealing to even readers of police procedurals willing to involve themselves in an Atlanta, Ga after an event that changed everything we know...still learning about that world in this book and the next, which I have already started. If you have not read the first in this series, this book would be very confusing, but I would think would peak your interest enough to pick up the first in the series and then probably become hooked liked I am!***I know a writer has a right to write what he wants, I don't have to read it, but if I like a series and really don't want to read short stories with those same characters, I just wish the story was not important to the series, I don't want to miss anything****

I am a huge Andrew Gross fan so I was thrilled when I saw this book on Amazon Vine, it meant I wouldn't have to wait for the release date!! With that said...The book started out really slow for me. I was not connecting with the characters at all. There was one character I really liked and he was out of the picture early! The timelines were so confusing I was actually going back through the pages. I thought I had missed something. As I was reading, I was sad, I was afraid I was heading to a bad review.Then about halfway through the book, the timelines came together, the stores merged, and we finally had an Andrew Gross novel. Thrills, page tuner situations, and a character that came in late that I really liked. So at this point, the book went from a three star to a four. Still not my favorite Andrew Gross book, but a fun read.

I was so excited to start this book, I adore Rob Thurman, and I know I am always in for an entertaining read when I read one of her books. Although I read them again and again, I always look forward to a new one.This one does not disappoint.First of all, I love the different points of view, Niko and Cal sharing the narration. The first book she did that for, Deathwish, was always one of my favorites of this series, so I was thrilled to see it again. The story not only goes back and forth between the two narrators, it also goes back and forth between two time lines. I really like the stories of the past, all the books have a couple of snippets or stories about the past, but this one really delves into a past timeline, and it adds so much to the history of the characters. So great.....I don't want to say too much, no spoilers, but there are a couple of twists and turns that are surprising. And if you read the Trickster novels, it goes full circle in one part of the book. By the way, if you have not read the Trickster novels, you must. They are fun as well.So I will read this one again, like I do all the others, but I must say, this is one of the best.

I absolutely love Mr. Rosenfelt. I have read all of his books, and although I am partial to his Andy Carpenter books, I read everything he writes.This book was two stories in one. The main character had to solve a murder to free his kidnapped brother, and also try to find this kidnapped brother, in case he could not solve the murder! I really liked the characters, and was so glad even with the seriousness of the situations, Mr. Rosenfelt let his sense of humor come through, and help the reader move through the seriousness of the story. It seemed to be a little open ended, so I am hoping to see these characters again.

I was not sure how to rate this book. I found myself unable to stop reading, I wanted to know how it was all going to end. Yet, as I was reading, I found myself confused, and wondering where it was all going. Not in the what is going to happen mystery way, but more...what can happen next to confuse the issue.I really liked the narrator, maybe that is what kept me reading, yet at times, I felt like he was spinning his wheels, and doing things that did not make sense. In trying to solve his brother's shooting, every one he came across was a suspect, and he was floundering so much, I felt like how did he ever pass his bar exams. Then I would forgive him because he was young, with so many issues, it didn't surprise me he was floundering. Everyone lied, and I mean everyone. It was....sad?There were no secondary characters I liked, except maybe his brother who was on machines in the hospital, and the reader was learning about him through the narrators eyes...yet even then there were so many questions about his brothers integrity, I wasn't sure if I should like him or not. I did though.So the story was convoluted, the ending seemed open ended, and I hope there will be another book with this character. I want to know what happens to him. Which explains the four stars. The author did his job, kept me reading, left me wanting me more. I will definitely read a second book from this author, hope Monkey boy is back.

I was first attracted to this book because a reviewer compared it to a Jack Reacher book, so I was surprised when I started reading it....this character is no Jack Reacher. Jack Reacher is a hero....the Ghostman is not, really, really, not. However, I found myself enthralled with his story , his character and well, his life. I found myself rooting for him to succeed and face it, he is not even really an anti-hero. That kind of character who lives on the edge, not quite a white hat doing wrong things sometimes for the right reasons. This character is a bank robber, a criminal, and one of the most interesting characters I have come across in a long time.The character is a "ghost" in his life, and he is a ghost to the reader too, but I really hope he will be back. I look forward to reading more about him, learning about him, what makes him tick, and finding out where the author is going to take him. This is a read well worth your time, I highly recommend it.

This is a great thriller that I could not put down.  The author was a suggestion from Amazon because of some other recent purchases, and I am so glad I checked it out. I started reading it, and found myself skipping sleep to finish it.I liked the author calling the main character the Gray man, an assassin, is he a good guy?  Even though he is particular about the cases he takes, still, being an assassin opens up the readers to that place the character lives, between black and white, good and bad. That grey area....Anyway I have not been this involved in a thriller book in ages. I loved the character, loved the story, even if some may consider it a little over the top....I was enthralled. On to the next one!

This book is a really interesting read about Thomas Jefferson.It starts out a little jumpy,the time period would jump a year, without any explanations, sometimes hard to connect things at the beginning. That is why the four stars rather than five. It actually deserves a four and a half.However with that said, it was overall a really in depth and non-judgmental book about Mr. Jefferson. If you have not read any other biographies about Mr. Jefferson, this is a good one to read first. The information about Sally Hemmings was again, written without any judgments, just the facts, and that made it more interesting to read.Well worth the read

I am actually writing this review for the first three books in this series, I am on my way to start the fourth but I wanted to take time out to review the books so far.As you can see from my five stars, I really like these books. Some other reviewers have said the main character is a little over the top but that is what I like in my thrillers and mysteries. If the characters weren't extra special, the books would not be interesting! I love the main character and apparently in future books, the reader will told more about his background and how he got to where he was. Through the stories so far, there have been interactions with people that make you wonder and think about their previous relationships with the main character. Just enough to get you wondering.There is a "sidekick" to the main character, Boxer, and I love every scene he is in. I look forward to more about him as well.These books are edge of your seat thrillers, lots of action, fast paced books that once I start I cannot put down. Highly recommended!

Mr. Atkins' name came to my attention when I read he was chosen to continue Robert Parker's Spencer series.I read about this series and it sounded like something I may be interested in. I am so glad I picked it up, it is a great book, I will move on to the next one right away, I have already preordered the third one.Mr. Atkins is really good with mood and description, and I was pulled into the story from the very beginning. I loved the main character, a US Ranger, on leave for a funeral, finding himself pulled into the politics and the criminal mess going on in his hometown. Not everyone was all bad or all good, although there is a core group around him I look forward to seeing in the next book.I really recommend this book. It grabbed me and I could not put it down until I had finished.

Well,I just finished reading this latest book in this series and thought I would put in a review. It is such an underrated series that I thought I would give it a boost, Well, joke is on me. I just read this is the last in the series, that the publisher did not pick it up. What a shame.The characters have grown with each book, the stories have gotten better and better. These books are better than so many books out there that seem to be pushing along. Again what a disappointment, I will really miss Ray Lily.However, if you have not read these books, even knowing they are going to stop, I would suggest reading them. The world that Mr. Connolly built is very different, magic is not the benign thing that is going on in so many current urban fantasy books. This world makes magic scary and strange, and Mr. Lily, with the Twenty Palaces organization is all that stands between evil magic and humanity.I have liked this series from the beginning and if you have not read the previous books, I feel like it is a must to read them in order. Wow, still bummed no more Twenty Palaces books. Still, great reads and worth your time. Maybe the publisher will change their minds down the road. There is always hope!

I like this fry pan, but I have a small complaint. The instructions that come with this pan, tell you not to use non-stick spray. Well, that was a mistake. This was tried twice, both times the food stuck and left small food burns on the pan. Therefore there was a small burn taste one of the times. However the clean up was great, but it just is not the non-stick miracle they say it is.I do like the way the pan fits the stove top. It seems to be perfect for the ceramic stove top. I do not love this stove top, but it is what I have right now, and this pan seems to balance and sit perfectly on the stove top. Which of course means even heat.

I was a little surprised to see another Flavia de Luce novel this year, since the third in the series had already been released earlier in the year. Also, I have to admit, I did not love the last entry as much as the first ones. I was anxious, however, to give this one a try since Flavia was going to finally determine whether or not Santa was real.Of course, she was going to do this in the way only Flavia could. With total scientific experimental clarity.I love this series so much, and this book does not disappoint. I am still waiting however, for the reason Flavia's older sisters seem to have so much acrimony with Flavia, I keep thinking there is more to the story about their Mother's death than we know so far.If you have not read any of these books, you should. Although they are billed as mysteries, it is really the characters that drive the stories. So far, I have pretty much figured out "who did it" even if not necessarily why, but that does not take away the enjoyment of the stories. I sit down with one of these, and find myself caught up in a world that it seems only Mr. Bradley can portray so well.This series is so much fun, I would recommend these books to everyone that loves a good story.

I am a huge Rob Thurman fan and could not wait for this sequel. Although I discovered her through the urban fantasy genre, this book, which is a sequel to the book Chimera, is not in the urban fantasy category. It is just an old fashioned thriller, one that has a little science fiction element, but actually reminds me of Michael Chricton. Thriller books with a twist to give it a kick.The relationship between these two brothers is at the heart of the story but it was great reading how they have each grown, together and on their own. I also love the character of Saul, and was really glad to see him back in such a major way.I don't want to say to much, I don't want to give the story away, but as usual, Ms. Thurman throws in twists and turns that turn the story on it's head more than once. (See her trickster books, The Trick of the Light, and Grimrose Path, such fun) Anyway, the action was non-stop and it is a great book for anyone who likes a thriller book with more than non-stop action, but great characters that you fall in love with as well.By the way if you read this book on Kindle, they put the line about checking out the other author's books in the wrong place, it is before the epilogue. So when you get there, keep going, and read the epilogue. Amazon goofed!

I downloaded this book earlier and had not read it yet, mainly on the five star reviews. I was looking for something to occupy my time until Basilisk by Rob Thurman came out on Tuesday, and I decided to start this book. Well, surprise, surprise, I could not put it down. What a great book. A totally different world built around demons, magicians, and humans. So much fun. I loved the characters, I was surprised the way the book unfolded, and so enjoyed something different. This is a great beginning to a new series and I can't wait until the next book, unbelievable this is a debut book. I love the characters, I loved the story and I so look forward to what is coming next.

When I first started reading this book, I had a really hard time getting into it. I am not sure why, I knew why Harry had been shot, but could not figure out where the whole thing was going. I had guessed from something Mr. Butcher said in the book before this one, and again, I just wasn't bonding with the story. Then about 38% read( I read it on Kindle) something turned and I started reading and could not put it down. It just took off, and I could not read this fast enough. I laughed out loud, we all know Harry, and I cried a whole bunch. I don't want to say to much, I don't want to give anything away, no spoilers, and of course the plot of the book has been outlined elsewhere. I will just say, if you are a Harry Dresden fan, do not miss this book. If you have not ever read any of this series, go back, start at the beginning and enjoy the ride.

First let me start by saying I did not buy this product on Amazon, but now that I know they have them, the next time I purchase one, I know I will come here. This product is great. We have been having a terrible time with ants this year on our hummingbird feeder, more than any other year. Not sure why, however, we picked one of these up not expecting much, IT WORKS! It is great, I was surprised,  no ants from the first time I used it. Still no ants. The package said it will last one whole hummingbird season so we will see, but even it doesn't, I would put a new one right away. Great simple product and solution for a not so great problem.

I really enjoyed this book, it is a great beginning to a new Urban Fantasy series. It is kind of dark, with flawed, complex characters, and the framework for a really strange world. The fairies in this book are not the sweet fun loving fairies that normally live in the urban fantasy genre, and there are things going on that have no explanation yet. The end really leaves you hanging. However, it also leaves you waiting impatiently for the next installment, I can't wait to see what is going to happen, what or who the mysterious characters are. What is really going on in the new world that is being built. The mystery was good, I had figured out who, but now why, and it was really a shocking conclusion to the mystery, so I really liked that too.I understand this author normally writes young adult novels, but this is really not for that audience at all. So if you normally read this writer, and are a young adult, maybe look elsewhere!Anyway, give this a try if you like urban fantasy and are looking for something a little different, something new. It is well worth your time.

I could not put this book down. I am a huge fan of Mr. Hurwitz and this book is now at the to pof the list of my favorites of his books. I could not stop reading until I finished it. From the very beginning, I was hooked and at first my heart was breaking for the main character, and I could not guess where the story was going. And then, as the book took off, it just did not stop. What a page turner.I really liked the main characters, not sure if it would make sense to see them again in another book, but I would love too. I am curious, with the ending the way it is, how things in their lives turn out. Anyway, this is a great book, a great thriller.A must read....

I totally love this series. I just finished this book, the second in the series, however I really feel like to enjoy this, you need to read the first one.I read a lot of urban fantasy books and this series stands out as among the best. The series is different than most, the main character is a husband and father who is also a demon hunter. He is loving, sarcastic and really good at his job. He has good friends, a brother he helped and is now trying to rebuild his relationship with, and a demon that hangs around, not really a friend, but so far, not an enemy. It is an interesting twist in the story.This latest installment kept me on the edge of my seat, I could not put it down. I am really looking forward to the next book.

The cover sucked me in on this story, seeing that cute little frog sitting there and then the title, "Sharing a Pond."The blurb pretty well covers the basics.  Corey and Shane have been together for ten years and are middle aged.  They're established in their careers, home, and community.  Yes, they are frog shifters - Both green (forgot the specifics on species)  -- Despite that their human forms are different in skin coloring.  What interesting concepts.Sharing a Pond is about Corey and Shane accepting their third in their triad:  Brent.  He is a lot younger at twenty, hasn't been to college, and comes with a lot of baggage.  Not possessions but his past which influences him.  He is handsome to Corey and Shane and they feel the mate pull as Brent does to them.  While it's understandable the three need to cement their relationship, I was amazed at how much page space was for smex.  Some of it was justified in claiming each other and developing trust without jealousy.  Personally I would have liked more communication between them because it's always a lack of talking that causes problems.  And that includes covering the whole issue and bring up that rat stink John and sticking his nose in something that was none of his business.  *sigh*  No, Brent didn't tell his mates about John.As their relationship deepens, Brent grows and matures.  He put his mates first even when he was hurting.  And it takes a lot of courage to stand up and speak of past hurts, not knowing how they'll treat you when they learn the truth.  Of course it's easier to blossom when there is love and support and Brent has that.I loved the 'frog' water scenes and wish there were more.  There were a lot of things I enjoyed about this story, but not so much the smex, which I ended up skipping.  I'd love to see another story of this threesome. . . .
