With Cory's job, a move or not, Brent more confident and frog stuff.  - Dan's Wife

A warlock, a prophecy, a demanding father, and antiques.Conner is a talented wizard with fire talent.  He does as his father commands.  I don't know how old Conner is, but he's now at the point where he wants a relationship.  In this case a guy at work is spiking his interest, Scott.Scott has no magical ability but does have an affinity for antiques.  And it's thru his job of cataloguing and verifying antiques where he gets to know Conner.  Their relationship is slow building.  Conner has to keep his magical abilities hidden and his status as a warlock.  Scott is openly gay yet is shy, too afraid that Conner is straight, and doesn't act on his feelings.  So they hold back from each other, keeping secrets, and until courage takes over.Now.  The story interested me but the execution was glaringly bad.  There are punctuation mistakes, fragmented sentences, wrong word placement, and repeated misspelled words.  Examples are:Instead of couch it was coach.Beginning chapter:  Prophecy is wrongly spelled. Instead  it is prophesy and that misspelling is repeated throughout the story.Yeah the ears tearing up happened when Scott was confiding in Jade that Conner must be gay -- He bit my bagel!Chapter 4 opens:  "The tram doors swung wide open.  I shuffled through a crowd of college students, finally freeing myself from metal box."  That followed with a sentence with misplaced commas.Is hell capitalized?  It is here.  As are Warlocks, Witches, and Demons, but not mortals.  A hair style is capitalized:  ". . . black Mohawk style hair. . . "  There are a few others but you get the idea.Fragmented sentences.  Case in point the fire flower Conner makes for Scott:  "Or better yet." "A green stem, white petals, a yellow center."It's like part of the story was passed off to someone else, someone that didn't take the time to edit.  I agree with what another reviewer wrote - It's like the work was started by one person and someone else contributed.  Someone that doesn't know English grammar.  This is a low point in Wolf Specter's work.  Very disappointing.  - Dan's Wife

Having read the first book, Prickly Business, I was excited to see another out.  This is a continuation of Avery and Dylan.Avery is a Louisiana bred, a well dressed and cute looking hedgehog shifter.  He is mated to his wolf partner Dylan.  Avery is now learning to live within his means, still values his friends, and is heavily invested in being a PI.  A lot of this story is about Avery and his PI gigs.  So Avery is putting in the hours, talks about his boredom on stakeouts, and is working all hours of the day and night.  He's pushing himself and losing weight as well as sleep.Of course Dylan is worried about Avery.  He has the wolf vibe going on, wanting to help, to protect, and be front and center for Avery.  Unfortunately Avery's schedule puts a damper on most of that.  Yes, most of the time the two guys are apart.  Dylan is understanding but over time he's more unhappy.  While Dylan and Avery aren't whiney, there is immaturity on Avery's part and a lot of the story has unresolved wallowing, in spite of Avery's epiphany.I appreciate a deeper look at a mated shifter couple and how they work on their relationship.  But.  Whenever they were together it was sex and sleep.  Or sex, food, and sleep.  Or sex.  Avery and Dylan come into this mating with expectations yet have cultural and species differences.  They should be solving and discussing things instead of all this wallowing.  Little insecurities became big and some of the angst was over stupid stuff.  Like Dylan trying to figure out when to say 'I love you.'  It kept coming up again and again in Dylan's thoughts and by the time it was settled it wasn't a big deal.This story introduces two more matings in the works and no conclusion on them.  I hate it when sideline matings are more interesting than the main couple.  I'm still wondering who Luc met in New Orleans.  And Jaden.  You know it shouldn't take a tragedy to make a mated couple communicate.  Especially a shifter couple.  I felt the angst was more human directed and not what instinct driven shifters would do.  Because a mate is everything and their shifter half should have been pressing them.  But these two rarely shift.  So then there's that.  - Dan's Wife

Ricky was raised by an abusive father and has a low sense of self worth.  When this story opens Ricky is running from five years of more abuse, torture, and slavery.  Despite all this he has a core of steel to be able to survive.  Ricky has had a rough life, he's human and only 23 years old.  The story mainly focuses on him, his lack of choices, the few he can make, and how he struggles to overcome.Sandy is Ricky's six year old shifter brother.  Sandy is special and Ricky is tasked to protect him.  There are a lot of details to this sibling bond that I could go into but the short of it is they're both at risk, the last of their kind.  They are hunted, in danger, and until Sandy grows up, they're always at risk.As the story opens, Sandy and Ricky seek asylum at the Windy River Pack and meet up with Alpha Grant.  So a new chapter begins.  Alpha Grant is a fierce protector and is in charge of an extremely large pack.  He is a more settled alpha that is patient but has limits.  He's never had a boyfriend and is new to a relationship but at least he listens to advice and learns from his mistakes.  Unfortunately some of those lessons come a bit late.The world building was interesting and just enough to get a feel for the time period and setting.  The main characters are well drawn and interesting.  The many back up characters bring a depth to the pack and the story.  If this is a first story by this author, I can say I'm impressed.  There was a good flow, lots of consequences for your actions, believable dialogue and situations.  My two nit picks would be a six year old talking like an adult, complete sentences and grammar.  Even if Sandy is special and a shifter he is still only six years old.  Another is I wished the pack had a psychiatrist.  Ricky needs to talk to someone besides is six year old brother and busy mate.  He can't overcome his past without addressing it and hearing it from a trained professional.  I will note that the abuse mentioned in this story is not front and center.  There's a distance from all of that and it was well done being presented that way.I overlooked the editing and grammar - if there were problems -  because the story just dragged me in.  I can recommend this for KU customers that want a decent shifter m/m read that is longer, interesting, and well done for this first book.  - Dan's Wife

It's been ten months since I read the last Renounced, Southwestern Shifters Book 10.  So I downloaded the last one to prepared for this -- Then I saw my review on Renounced and I remembered the storyline and what to expect.  So.  Retrograde is another look at Nathan and Marcus's relationship.  We've met them before, we've watched them experience their bond, their sex lives, and how they are growing into their roles.  Now they are established in their positions are together, but want to be closer to each other and to their wolf side.Because they were an established couple and their story is already written, I wasn't as invested in this story.  Sure every relationship has change and decisions have to be made.  So there is talk between Nathan and Marcus. . . . Visions of a bright future, 'down to nature' and running thru the forest.  But it's just talk!My main gripe with the story is what I griped about in my review on Renounced.  Marcus and Nathan keep getting it on and while it is nice to see an established couple and leaders of their people be so into each other, to have their sex take up 65% of the book is a bit much.  Just a bit.  So I was skipping pages because while it was hot and steamy and Bailey Bradford does deliver for her readers. .. . I wanted to get to the plot.  To the story line.  Pages of sex isn't a storyline and in this series it's already established that Nathan and Marcus have outstanding sex.  There was nothing new here.I was bored with Retrograde.  There were ideas and talk and plans but nothing was implemented.  I was disappointed.  SPOILER:  Going to be interesting to move with six babies.  Just saying.  The cover is also odd.  Is that Asher?  Malnourished Asher?  Nathan has knee length hair so it can't be him.  Odd hair there.  - Dan's WifePost note / Spoiler:  What wasn't addressed is how a foreign visitor (won't get too much spoiler details) could contact a US hunter and get the hunter to cooperate with their plans.  What did the 'spy' find in Marcus's office?  Did he call anyone?  Was he looking for pack details in the US so he or his organization could wipe them out?  There was NO conclusion on this.

Having read two other stories by Noah Harris, I tried this one on the KU program.  Unfortunately I couldn't get past the first page.  I understand the concepts and comparisons but the phrasing is odd.  I'm not sure if it's the tenses (past vs future) or if it's the first person narrative.  Let me see if I can make myself clearer.  Standing in a childhood bedroom the mc is at a cross roads.  He is thinking of his past in that he is one personality at home and another at school.  Re-reading it I'm stumbling across the odd descriptions which now that I look at them are overly wordy.  Think 'wet water'.  (Water doesn't need to be called wet, it already is)"It was meant to be a celebration.  For me, the moment my eyes welcomed the small world that was my childhood bedroom, I was filled with both resentment and remorse.""At home, I was expected to be reserved, and mannerly.  While at school I was expected to be flamboyant and exaggerated.  Neither of these personalities had been who I truly was at heart."No commas in the first sentence:  At home I was expected to be reserved and mannerly.I don't know.  I've never had anyone refer to someone as being mannerly.  I think 'well behaved' is a better term.Same thing with exaggerated.  Stop being so exaggerated!  You're too flamboyant!  Flamboyant works, exaggerated doesn't.So if he wasn't flamboyant or reserved what exactly was he?  What defines him?  And what in the heck is he celebrating?"I found that the boy I was at home had been oppressed."  Found seems wrong here.  He's talking about himself.  He knows what his last years are like, he didn't just realize it.  When you find something it's a new discovery.  I can't begin to figure out correcting it.  The sentence is past tense.  Maybe:  I grew up in an oppressed home.When "and" links two words there isn't a comma.  When three words are linked the commas are:  Apples, oranges, and peaches.  Apples and oranges.  Not apples, and oranges.  Yes there are punctuation mistakes errors in the sentences I quoted.So this was the opening and I'm sorry but I was so bogged down in details, I focused on those instead of the story.  I returned it after stumbling on the first page.  I'd like to not rate it and just put some comments but the Amazon powers that be ask for a rating. I was generous with three stars.  - Dan's Wife

How to Walk Like a Man was pre-ordered.  I don't often do that but this time it was worth every penny.  For those that love dogs, love their little quirks, is willing to watch a guy find himself and his humanity. .. . All I can say is this one delivers.  It is wonderful.  It hit all my happy buttons and I was either snickering or smiling.  The story reminds me of a dog compared to a cat.  While the cat is secretive and sly and wanting to take over the world, a dog is happy!  Fun loving!  Loves egg sandwiches!  The outdoors!  The indoors!  And everything!  Then there's the various breeds and how well Eli Easton describes them in human form.  The breezy friendly golden retriever that runs the diner.  The English bulldog and jowels.  The border collie and the protective intensity.  Knowing these breeds I could relate.  Even if you don't, you'll enjoy them.Yes the story focuses on Roman.  His picture is on the cover - The German Shepherd.  Yup, he does go dog in the story so the cover ruined the 'coming out to Matt' for me.  Other than that, no complaints.  The town is spot on, the townies, great follow up on Tim and Lance, and an even more detailed look at how 'quickened'' happens and how it impacted Roman.  And it's a continuing process, not something that is achieved overnight.Roman is a human but also a German Shepherd.  I loved how his mannerisms reflected on his alter half, the curiosity, the obedience, the waiting for orders, the wanting reassurance and praise.  Wonderful.  Matt is just as good but again this is Roman's story.  I loved it and it's staying on my re-read list.  This one's a keeper.  The world would be a better place if our beloved pets lived longer lives.  - Dan's Wife

The last few books I've read by Wolf Specter I've enjoyed.  They keep improving!  So this one, Dragon Fire, is about a dragon shifter Liam.  He is an arson investigator for the fire department and at this point in his long life, his inner dragon is fighting for control.  It wants what it wants and is forcing Liam towards losing his humanity.  Yet.  There is a 'cure'.I love the way Wolf Specter writes about shifters.  Liam's dragon doesn't talk to him but reacts and influences him without words.  He's one author that does it so flawlessly and makes it believable and interesting.  No, not humans that are shifters that never shift but a shifter that has an alter ego that wakes up and takes center stage.Shane is a police detective and sent to investigate various arsons, documenting the loss of property.  He meets Liam on the job and they both compare notes.  From there we get a rich look at both men.  Their relationship is based on family, the past, and variables like Liam's dragon.  Yes, this is fiction and involves shifters and the ability of a dragon shifter impregnating a human male.  I especially loved the epilogue which took the pair a few years down the road, really nicely done and gave the book a satisfying ending.  I wouldn't mind seeing a continuation.  - Dan's WifeFootnote:  We never did learn if it was Liam's dragon behind the arsons.  My assumption is he was behind the first two (his memories and the timeline with when he forgot) but not the third although the timing was questionable.  How could his enemy know when to strike?  And why are bad dragons black?  ??

I was looking forward to this story, bought it on the day it came out on Amazon, then never reviewed it.  Now that it's gelled a bit, I'll take the time to give a few thoughts.Of course everyone wants to find their fated mate or beloved.  In this story  Gypsum, a vampire, is assisting in relocating some angus cattle shifters to New Mexico.  He's tasked with assisting and transporting since he helped rescue them.  This is a nice follow up to Not a Line of Bull (A Loving Nip Book 6).  Gypsum is the second of his coven, a strong older vampire, but patient and fair minded.  The angus shifters are pretty well dropped as Gypsum smells his mate.Lucius is a dingo shifter, one of the rehabilitated shifters from the situation in Rehabilitating His Dingo (Wolves of Stone Ridge Book 23).  He and his half brothers have been with the condor shifter alpha for a few years.  He's not fully recovered but feeling safe.  The outdoor scene of him playing with his brothers and beta was wonderful.Lucius isn't ready for a mate.  His past defines him and he's led a really troubled one.  Gypsum doesn't have hang ups and pursues with determination.  Unfortunately the story is short and there's just a few moments that define their relationship.  Just as it begins the book was over.  One area that wasn't put into a lot of detail are the characters of Lucius's pack.  Well the world building is mentioned enough but the inner circle of this pack is just touched on.  Even in that earlier story,  Rehabilitating His Dingo (Wolves of Stone Ridge Book 23, this pack was just getting started.  And the angus cattle shifters are there but now in the background.  One stands out.  Maybe we'll hear more from him.  *Note* wish all that kidnapping / fight situation / scene could have been left out and the guys getting better acquainted.  *sigh*Now a friend on a forum pointed out that it looks like the otter shifter was tossed into the fire (cover).  Nope, not true.  No otters here.  That was a hot dog and marshmallow moment!  Yes I was disappointed with this one.  To this point I've enjoyed the Loving Nip Series.  This one doesn't compare to the others even if it does advance earlier books. - Dan's Wife

I bought this flexi leash on Amazon over a year ago. .. . Or longer.  I'd have to go through all my reviews to figure that out.  This leash listed is for the LARGE size, for Large dogs, 16 feet length.  The tape lead is NOT reflective.  Not in this size.  It is bright yellow and easy to spot in the daytime.  The casing does have a reflective quality but I don't know how well that holds up at night.What I love about this leash is the casing is lighter weight than other large models.  Also the bright color which is easy to spot in the house when I'm searching for the leash.  Because it's lighter in weight It's easier to hang on to when out walking.  Walking with this flexi is an enjoyable experience.The negative is that there isn't much room for your hand when grasping the handle.  The handle area is smaller than my old flexi.  When I wear gloves it's difficult to grasp cause my fingers are so cramped.  If I don't have a good grasp, I can't handle my dog.  So during the winter I usually switch out to another flexi simply because I can't worry about losing my dog or dealing with cramped / cold fingers.  I'll include a picture of my old flexi - If Amazon will print share it to compare.  It isn't until you see the two leashes side by side that you notice the differences in the finger / gripping space.  (New model vs my older one)Flexi really is the way to go.  The tape doesn't get dog hair caught up in it like the cord type.  And if you get tangled or grasp it when the dog is pulling, the tape doesn't hurt your fingers or hand like a cord does.  I have had the cord type slide through my fingers and left a rope burn -- Well, almost a rope burn.  I've had fingers twisted due to a pulling dog and hauling back on the cord and grabbing it wrong while grabbing the dog.  It's those quick not thinking responses when your dog jumps or pulls or tries to get away / to another dog.  So my experience is a tape is better and the flexi retractable is wonderful.  Note that this model retracts until it stops when the metal attachment hit it.  So there is always pressure on the leash to let your dog know you are there on the other end -- No slack.  - Dan's Wife

This is the story of Isaiah, a bat eared fox shifter . .. . and . . . .Tech guru for Dominic's pride.  He's the guy that sits looking at computer monitors, is a loner, and takes care of all the security computer stuff.  As he is so self contained, I couldn't place him from the other books.  He's probably in the background, doing his job, and not making an impact.Isaiah is the son of an alpha and raised to take over his skulk.  But due to Isaiah being gay, he was kicked out and resettled with Dominic's pride.  The years have passed and now there are family issues and Isaiah is called back home.The other half of this story is a human, John.  There is some back story on why he's been imprisoned for a year in a cabin on Whitedell Pride property.  Not remembering much on him . . . He was hired to kidnap Jamie for the Glass Pharmaceutical company.  I don't think he was experimented on and has no enhanced abilities.  He never offers to help Isaiah with computer stuff so I assume he isn't tech savvy.  He was asked to train with the enforcers but there is very little page space on that.The road to this relationship is problematic. Isaiah had to figure out his priorities and unfortunately he goes through a indecisive stage that was really off putting.  I expected better from a shifter!  John is the rock in this one even though he has to remodel his life and live with shifters.  He knows he's at a disadvantage and isn't sure where he stands.There were spots of humor that lightened up the story.  Keenan and Nysys are now best buds and their curiosity leads them into . . . new adventures.  A few old faces pop up and some new ones are introduced.  There is no conclusion on the Glass Company situation from the last book.  The focus is on Isaiah and John and how another mating comes about.  4.5 stars simply because Isaiah's reasoning was beyond my tolerance.  Especially if he was trained to be an alpha - You'd think he'd go thru decision making and problem solving!  And there isn't a set HEA.  *sigh*  -- Dan's Wife

Jason is 22, has left home, and decides to reconnect with his Uncle Raul.  He is unsure of his welcome, unsure if he can stay.  Since we've met Raul in another story, I thought it'd be an interesting time to reconnect.  But no, Raul makes very few appearances.  He doesn't even take the time to sit down with his nephew and have a heart to heart.Sorry, this one didn't do it for me.  Jason is part way through college.  No idea what he was majoring in, just that his mom and step-dad cut off his funds.  Of course he takes up his schooling once he's in Stone Ridge but again, who knows what field.  And while I'm on the subject, who knows what Michel does for a living.  What rank his wolf is in the pack.  There are so many blanks when characterizing these two.The kicker for me was when Jason was told Michel would never hurt him.  Yet Michel, under the influence of drugs, attacks Jason and goes for his throat.  Kill shot and Michel barely pulls back in time.  Now I know things were intense and Michel was in wolf form and couldn't talk but once they were in the hospital together, they didn't discuss this.  This involved trust and Michel should have talked about what the drugs did to his wolf.  Did that happen?  Of course not!I'm to believe Michel, a 370 some odd year old wolf shifter, a guy that has been married, raised 3 kids, and a grandson. . . A guy with this much experience and knowledge would mess up with his mate.  Miscommunication.  Assumptions.  It was all just really off.This is the first time I've heard of a wolf from this pack 'hiding' while reinventing his image.  All the other mates are living their lives and they're not getting a new image.  Carson is still the enforcer and I bet he's been Declan's enforcer for decades.  And I know Carson leaves pack lands to do his job.  Then there's Declan.  He's just as old as Michel yet I've never heard one word about him reinventing himself.So Jason agrees to live with Michel, off the grid, out in the woods.  They still have differences to overcome.  They declared their love to each other rather quickly and when the story ends they are happy for now but not a HEA.  Sad.  - Dan's Wife

Milo is the small town sheriff and a werewolf.  Well, he's part human and wolf but can shift.  He is a dedicated lawman, working overtime, and has the town's best interests at heart.  While he does so much for everyone else, he is still lonely and apart due to his shifter half but also because he's a closet gay.Eli is the boss of a security firm called Calvary.  I have no idea what Eli looks like besides his 'being as hairy as a wolf' and that he likes to man handle Milo.  Eli is dedicated to his job and his people.I didn't read the first book in this series but didn't feel lost.  This one focuses on Eli and Milo and the situations around their growing relationship.  Of course there's drama and self doubt, at least on Milo's part.  Part of that is because Eli is human and won't feel the mate pull . . . The back and forth between the two men making it work was good but not over done.  It was nice to see these two work their jobs and communicate to make their relationship work.Unfortunately the story ended with a lot of lose ends.  I realize this is a series but as it is Milo's job situation is up in the air, the hunters are still out there, and Joe's dad is still dying.  Peter isn't contacted although I thought that might have been him on that run Cal and Milo took.  Then there was that boy in the hospital.  I mean heck.  There are so many little storylines left hanging and the main reason I gave it 4 stars is because this story was about Eli and Milo.  They aren't settled yet.  They're not living together or 'had that talk' about where they'll settle.  Everything is up in the air.  I guess it's a HFN but with the threats who knows how long that will last.  This story was written in May and here it is the beginning of November and no continuing book planned or out.  (Yes I did check the author's site).  *sigh*  - Dan's Wife

Callum of Drakkar Coven takes a step back and shows vampires for what they really are -- Blood thirsty, violent, and cruel.  If you like your vamps of this caliber, then you will enjoy this story.Laramie is a simple young man, ready to be wed to Sara and lives in his village with his father.  He grew up with tales of  the Lord and his brothers living nearby and how humans from their village disappear within their castle and never return.  Rumors of vampires float around yet Laramie is in his own world dreaming of his girl, soon to be wife.  So innocent. . .Lord Callum is the other half of this story, the vampire, the one that captures and holds humans for his own needs.  They are like cattle -- His to use, abuse, feed from, or play with.  And he prefers men, especially for sex.  Thankfully Callum isn't a cruel master, he sees his decisions as merciful.  Culling the herd, so to speak.  After all his food source can't starve during a brutal winter.-- That impacts him.A bit of caution here.  This book is intense, morbid, sadistic, and gruesome.  And that's just the physical stuff.  Then there's the about face where  Laramie changes from this bespotted love struck youth of 18 to turn into a guy consumed with his own sexual needs.  His attraction to Lord Callum consumes him and Laramie thinks less about the other captives.  It's not quite Stockholm syndrome, but there is a change there. . . And it's a downward spiral.  He's losing his humanity. . .The writing is amazing, the characters are convincing and deep, and the situation is intense.  For all of that, I give this story five stars. It is an amazing story.  Unfortunately it wasn't my type of book.  I don't like to see main characters go through what Laramie did or the heartache he had to deal with.  But I can't drag the rating down because of my own view - Even if I did have to set it down and not finish -  That shows a great author and how deep she can write.  My loss but someone else's gain.  - Dan's Wife

Once again I'm amazed at Wolf Specter's writing. The curse with that is I'm now actively looking for more from him.  *grin*Becoming Omega goes way beyond the normal omega alpha meet, greet, and 'mine'.  Issac Ward is convinced by his old army friend Carter to 'compete' in the trials.  It's a chance to prove your physical, mental, and emotional ability.  At the end of being tested, the remaining few will be turned.  Werewolf turned and brought into the pack.Ward meets Alpha Ryan early on and knows they are mates but their situation is strained.  Ward is committed to the trials and frankly, he isn't gay.  Never been with a guy, not ever interested.  So this was a gay for you (GFY) story along with a competition and interesting pack situations.  Through it all, Ward acts like himself and Ryan is one to let him.  None of the strong arm alpha tactics.  While the story is told from Ward's point of view, I did wonder what Ryan was doing, off on those sidelines.  He's a strong alpha and that mating call had to wear on him.The term 'omega' is rarely used in referring to Ward.  Ryan never calls him that and neither does anyone that matters.  He's a strong, military trained special ops guy with a conditioned body and mindset.  He is able to stare at more dominate people / wolves and doesn't act submissive at all.  And how he was able to go thru the trials under the physical condition he was in . . .  Borderline unreal.  I'll rate this story a 4.5 stars and hope that Wolf Specter writes a follow up story.  I enjoyed these characters.  - Dan's Wife

Charlie Richard's stories are either a hit or miss with me.  I enjoyed this one.Hess is a Kodiak bear shifter and the story is mainly told from his point of view.  He stands 6' at the shoulder -- No, not when standing on his hind feet but when he's on all fours.  That's huge.  Hess is military trained, smart, and plans out his visit like a military campaign.  With his data all done he strolls into pack territory, scratching his back, ambling along, and thinking of ways to have fun.  I loved his easy going character. That was well done.Gilbert is one of a few rescued bird shifters from a lab in Russia.  He and his friends live in a converted barn in pack territory.  While Gilbert is the main squeeze in this tale, I never got a feel for his raven.  Gilbert never has any 'attracted to shiney' moments, hording his 'pretties' or any of that stuff that are associated with ravens.  Yes, I did check Wiki --  Ravens are ground horders, playful, and love aerial aerobatics. No, none of that from Gilbert and I doubt being stubborn is a raven traint. Now I realize Gilbert is busy with his flock and still recovering from decades of being in that lab. . . But still. I wanted a bit more from him, to be worthy / a good match / fun / for Hess.Anyway, the story is cute, the relationship has a few hiccups and of course things are happening in pack territory.  I'd have liked some feedback on the skirmish.  I had a few questions tied up there and if page space was the problem with explaining everything, then I'd have liked less details on the flock.  You know, all of their birds, personalities, and what they do in their spare time.  Yeah, I felt like feathers were flying in that barn and while I appreciated the background and an idea of where the series is going, I know all those names and attributes will be given all over again in Hector and Rock's story.  Just saying.Four stars for the humor, the loveable bear in Hess and his settling down in a barn with the flock. Not quite a fox among chickens analogy, but close.  By the way, I'm sure Gilbert and Hess will learn to deal with thin walls . . .  - Dan's Wife

Shortly into the story I'm greeted with this paragraph:"Jack sighed at the German grandfather clock coming across the room and flipped the key in his register to pull a cash report.  He liked to take one every hour, on the hour, for his records.  Last year, he had ended this business day with ten dollars and forty-five cents."As that first sentence is written, the clock is moving across the room.  Instead it should be something like Jack LOOKED at the German grandfather clock while crossing the room.  Then the next sentence is vague and I assume it links to the cash report and not the register.  Now while I get the atmosphere of his work and duties are important, this is a twenty odd something page extremely short story.  So every single word needs to be right as the plot builds.Ethan is this cute skinny blue eyed blonde that visits Jack's store.  For Jack it's instinct, the smell, that sets off his hormones and he's primed to rut.  And that's about what it is for Ethan and Jack.  They come together because of their wolf nature,  they can't fight their urges.  What bothered me is we don't have much background on Ethan and why he was out on his own camping in the dead of winter.  Was it a dare?  A request from his family?  Was he put up to it by his pack?  Did scenting Jack trigger Ethan's mating heat?  And while I'm on that topic, an omega's mating heat wasn't explained at all.  And my thought.  That homeless guy also had a key to the shop.  Right?  I expected him to barge in on Jack and Ethan. . .The premise is good, Jack is well drawn.  Ethan is lacking substance.  We don't know his reasoning or his background.  But again this is only twenty some odd pages.  I'd be curious to see if the mating takes or if this is just a passing scene to help Ethan get through his heat. This is not a HEA or even a HFN story - More of a hook-up between two men.  Of course the story ends at an abrupt halt and there's no follow up to see if Jack and Ethan can make a relationship work or not.  After all it's more than physical chemistry and that's all these two have.  Three stars.  It was okay. - Dan's Wife

Omega New Moon is a 50 page segment of a larger work.  As this stands it's an introduction to Nikhil, a Russian wolf immigrant.  He is a math wiz, teaches at a local university, and of all things he's an omega wolf.  He has been with his current pack for years yet somehow this situation with Mathias is just starting.Mathias is the alpha for Nikhil's pack, a strong leader.  He was brought up by his father to do the right thing and one of those is to never give in to being with a male.  Any male.  No, that's wrong.  So this attraction Mathias has for Nikhil is forbidden.  There's a lot of inner conflict and I never did get the reasoning behind Mathias changing his mind.  Was it his wolf?  Instinct?  Fate?  In protecting Nikhil did those feelings prompt the mating or was it by accident and he had to follow through?  While I wasn't sure about the WHY, at least Mathias recognizes his mate in front of the pack.In this wolf mating there is no romance.  No kind words.  A few actions but I could tell Mathias's heart wasn't in it.  It was sad because Nikhil deserved more.  The story was left on a cliffhanger with unresolved issues.  There's unrest in the pack and while it used to be only directed to Nikhil, now it is targeting Alpha Mathias.  On one front things are good but there's a lot of work to do to make the pack a safe and happy environment for Nikhil.  I'd also like to see the two grow into their mating -- More than the protection / safety aspect and more into loving and caring.  - Dan's Wife

So this is one of three quick KU short reads that I picked up and read together.  While I enjoy having a bit of selection in the paranormal m/m genre, I get tired of these segments that are longer than chapters but not a complete book.  Let me also say that I was disappointed.  No story should end on a cliffhanger.  It takes away from the story.  It's not a sneak peak into the next segment but a disregard for readers and fans.  Because a tease is just that -- a tease, and some authors take months if not years to put out the next story.  So again I tend to forget storylines and continuations when they're not available . . . and yes I did check to see if the next on in this series is out and no it is not.So on to this story.  Dylan is an omega wolf that is of age to mate.  He's currently working and going to college.  He lives with his dad and is in a stable pack.  The twist in this story is that the wolf population is declining and omegas are to be bred with or without consent.  So when the dreaded letter comes, Dylan is required to participate in a run with the 'benefit' of attracting an alpha, whether Dylan wants one or not.The situation was interesting, the writing creative.  Dylan's solution, along with a lot of magic, shows that Jamie is his true mate.  But there's a catch.SPOILERS:Like another reader, I agree that the epilogue jumped too far into the future with no explanation.  Did they adopt?  No?  Was Dylan already pregnant?  Was Jamie able to get a surrogate?  How is a strong alpha wolf able to cope in an established pack?  Do Dylan and Jamie leave the pack and start their own?  It was too confusing.  All that after a fairly decent read that showed a lot of promise and creativity.  - Dan's Wife

For what's written, the story is sweet, sassy, and fun.  It's a surface feel for a mating between Katie, a hedgehog and Joey, a dragon shifter.  The reason the two meet is due to Joey's grandfather dying and the inheritance of his house and land.This story needs more depth.  I even looked for a continuing story, maybe about another dragon council member and. . . Nothing is out there.SPOILERS:This whole story evolved around Joey's inheritance.  Yes, he sells it to Katie but. . .The pair is now living in Miami.  So.  What happened to the house?  What about a talk about the grandfather, how much he meant to both of them, clear the air about that issue, and talk of a few treasured items Joey inherited that should be  in their new place?  As I expected the grandfather to have some sort of dragon horde, it fits with the dragon image.  After all, that frying pan is still with Katie.  I'm surprised she didn't tell Honey that it's a family heirloom now, something to 'tell the kids' when meeting Joey.  . . .  It adds weight to the story. . .I must say Joey has great self control.  Never once does he give in when she gets hers. .. No pant adjusting.  No bursting.  No nothing.  And Katie doesn't mention his needs when hers are met.  That was an eyebrow moment.  Really?I honestly wanted to see more of the wolf and cat alphas. . . .The story was fine until the ending.  I never understood how far Honey was in her pregnancy.  Was she going to deliver during the house party?  And if humans aren't supposed to know about paranormals, then why are the dragons flying where Honey and Katie can see them?  Yeah, that last scene.  I wanted to see some snark between the women and a pricky hedgehog alpha dealing with the dragons.Anyone wonder if Katie can be  a part of the 'prickle'?  Her alpha is not in Miami. . .  Yeah, too many questions with that ending and a continuing book is not available.  I guess I am done.  - Dan's Wife

Exodus is the second story in the Valen's Pack Series following Run With The Moon.  This story could be read as a stand alone or if you've read the first story as I have, you can pick this one up without being lost. The story starts with Valen as Alpha and dealing with humans and shifters interacting in his pack, their pack, rebuilding lives and the pack grounds.  As this is happening Rivvie, the Beta and brother to Valen is starting a job with Matt, Aaron's brother.  (Valen and Aaron are mates, the alpha pair).  This story focuses on their brothers.We get a lot of background on Matt but not as much on Rivvie.  Of course their relationship takes time.  The world they live in isn't stable.  Who knows why natural disasters happen but what the title states does happen.  The pack needs to relocate and amidst all the changes and confusion Rivvie and Matt become closer.There's a really interesting storyline.  Valen and Aaron are new at leading.  There is still dissent from both the humans and the shifters.  Outside forces are battering the pack so there's a lot going on.  There's struggles both physical and emotional.  It's a time of testing.SPOILERSWe never learn what it is that causes the shifter virus to change another.  I thought it was a bite done in wolf form.  But no, that didn't happen with Rivvie and Matt.  So is it blood drinking and violence and not a fever?  Is it accepting the love of your mate?  So how will this impact their new shaman when we know he is infected and no one is stepping up in his 'cure'.  If he doesn't get changed he'll die.And that shaman -- Not much is said about him.  Is he accepting of shifters?  Is he of the right mindset to handle shifter ceremonies and recognizing a higher power?  He'd been through horror and dealt out death to family and friends.  He's tormented and at a state where he wishes death before he gets any worse.  Yet he's the pack shaman.So the story ended rather abruptly.  Not a cliffhanger but with questions running through my mind.  Not just the shaman issue although that was one.  Another is how Matt's turning was vastly different from Aaron's.  What did the pack learn from that?  We don't know!  Are the humans getting sicker?  We don't know!  Just that their moral is down.  Is anyone experimenting on them?  What about those new shifters that joined?  They just show up and are forgotten.  We don't even know if Matt got sick, just Rivvie wanting to turn him.  Too many inconclusive threads made this an incomplete story of Rivvie and Matt.  - Dan's Wife

I was dragged into getting this story, A New Dream, because the blurb grabbed me.  A middle aged man is seeking a new life.  He lost his wife and almost lost his own life, lived with despair and is now moving on.  Of all things he wins this green card lottery so he's flying out to the states and is lined up with a job.  On the plane he meets James.  Both are in the dark about how their lives will intertwine and that they'll be working together, living in the same building, and becoming something more.From reading a few reviews I realized this story was written in French than translated to English.  I'm glad I saw that because otherwise I'd mark the story down for odd sentence structure and this wordy verbose explanations.  The French outlook and expressions were fun and while my my high school French is rusty, I wasn't left guessing what was said.  It was well explained.  Some of the situations were odd at times.  Like having a conversation about systems of measure like miles and kilometers.  Weird.  I've been around foreigners that speak English well and that's the last thing to discuss.  Who cares?  Unless your on the road?  Now the units of measure in a bar is another matter but again odd.  That discussion wasn't presented as a discussion over work training.  And there were a few other instances were I had to wonder about the translation.While the French part was well done I didn't feel the author knew America and Boston as well.  I couldn't picture a knifing and hate crime like that in a bar, not even if the guys causing the damage were drunk.  And a wound to the gut takes a long time to recover from - But with Christmas around the corner, even a few months away, I couldn't picture anyone being able to lift that tree and help set it up.  (I deleted just who is gutted so this review isn't spoilerish)The main gripe I had was the way the story was told and not experienced.  David was explaining about his life going on and on and on and I kept waiting for a break but that didn't happen for pages.  Then he finally gets on the plane and I assume is sitting in his seat --  I did wonder how he had his face at James' waist and see his shirt ride up yet he could tell James was 3 inches taller than his own 6'2".  How could he tell how tall James was just by eyeing him?  Oh yes, the unit measures with height were a bit off in translation too.  But whatever.  It made the story more authentic if you can get over how off it reads.  Almost forgot!  Green Card Lotteries do exist.  I had to look that one up, never heard of it before.  How weird to 'win' your chance to live in the states.As a side note I would have loved to see David give James that drawing from the plane -- Even as a Christmas gift.  And why in the heck wasn't David drawing in his spare time?  I expected him to visit the cathedral and have that inspire him. I'd say  - Dan's WifeEDIT:  After thinking about it I lowered the review a star.  When a book is translated to English the editors should step up and do their job.  They didn't for this one.

After all the five star reviews and because I tend to read shifter stories, I decided to try this one.  Nothing to lose, it's on the KU program.  So my expectations were high even if this was a 34 page story.The top review goes into this wonderful imagination of Kit.  Is that because the story is told from Kit's viewpoint and he's bored on a road trip and is fantasizing about his step-brother Cole?  Because he can feel an evil vibe of their new town?  Eyes staring?  Well guess what, Cole felt the same way.  As the title is "My Werewolf Stepbrother"  I realized one of the brothers was a werewolf.  I was thinking Cole had some hidden depths, maybe he was the were.  He already has the build and 'fur'.So in this short entry to the series we learn about Kit, he's younger than Cole,  I assume he's out of school since it didn't look like there was a school there in that ghost town and no talk of school.  The reason I mention that because we aren't quite given Kit's age.  I assume under 20 and over 16.  Was he driving or a passenger on that drive?Cole is big, brash, the leader, older than Kit, yet he's Kit's best buddy as the two had grown up together and bonded together.  Yes they are step brothers.  Cole has this bad boy image where Kit is the voice of reason.This extremely short story ends on a cliff hanger.  I detest cliffhangers and it's an instant reaction to lower ratings when a story ends with one.  A good writer won't do that to his audience.  My other thought is. . . .Running for your lives and there's time for smex?  The very first time together?  We're talking young adults and they have no time to process things or talk it out.  No, they're on the run and fearing for their lives.  And what was up with their mom ignoring them when they needed her?  So tired they can't talk, bloody, clothes torn, shock must be setting in and she turns away?  No, sorry.  The guys should at least have cleaned up, talked, and fallen asleep.This one may have been well written and edited but the situations to push the plot were overdone.  I couldn't suspend my disbelief  - It dropped and with the cliffhanger it died.  - Dan's Wife

I realize I'm the first to review this book.  I also realize I haven't finished this book.  What I did do was read the sample here on Amazon and it's set up completely different than the kindle download.I'm one to ignore grammatical mistakes, sentence structure and the like.  What made me stop reading this story is the set up.  I even changed the page spacing to see if another variation would improve anything.  It didn't.Opening chapter:"  Anything to drink, sir? " The waitress smiled at me."  Oh no thank you.  I ' m waiting until my boyfriend arrives.  "IE:  Every contraction has space around it.  Instead of don't it's  don ' t.The floating quotes bothered me, too.There isn't double spacing between paragraphs.  Or conversations.  It just rambles on and on.  The logistics of all that took me away from the story and I couldn't get interested.  It was too distracting.  The odd thing is the sample here on Amazon isn't like that.  So maybe the formatting needs a look at or something.  I feel bad I can't give it a better review. - Dan's Wife

Lion's Claim is the first book I've read by Briar Omance.  If this is the first published story by this author, it has a lot going for it.  The story flowed and wasn't always told from one viewpoint.  The characters were interesting and believable.  The situation between the two wasn't original because there are so many shifter stories out there but it was well thought out.So Josh's friend entices him to go out clubbing but not just to any club.  This is a shifter owned one. Josh wasn't really interested, had just about decided to give up on relationships but decided to tag along.  From the moment they're in line, Josh knew the club catered to a different type and he felt out of place, under dressed and the odd man out.Mercer is a pride leader, a lion shifter, on the lookout for his fated mate.  He has a deadline and like Josh, has just about given up.  But he is here at the same club as the last resort.  Once Mercer's gaze lands on Josh, all bets are off.Like I said I enjoyed this story.  Yes it is a common theme of shifters and finding your fated mate.  But if this is a first book as I think it is, it's written a lot tighter and seamlessly then some authors that have zillions of stories out.  There's enough background to know the plot, the characters are well defined, and the story ends when you know things will work out.  Once I was done I had to check and see if another book was out by this author and was disappointed when I didn't see anything.  I wlll be checking back to see if Briar Omance writes more, especially about Mercer's Pride and how things go.  - Dan's Wife

While I enjoyed Dane's Syn and it had a lot of elements going on. . . . This is more of a overarching story with the big picture and less focus on Syn and Dane.  Even though this is their story, too.  The series expanded so much, really taking on a life of it's own.First off this series is about Leopard Shifters.  Syn and Dane are Leopard Shifters, Syn is a dominate being the brother of Alpha Talyn.  Dane is of a submissive class called the Prim.There is more action, more conclusion on what is going on with Talyn's Coalition and conclusion on the Council problem until one of the Council Enforcers wants revenge.  So the fallout happens and more is added on.  Stick in a mission for Dane and Syn and things get hopping.I'll say that Syn and Dane may be bonded now but their story isn't finished.  Dane had a complete character change from how he acted all his life.  There's going to be adjustment to that yet Syn loves Dane, regardless.SPOILERS and THOUGHTS:Dane drank vampire blood and there's no idea what this will do to him or the baby he's carrying.  The doctor was to examine Dane but that never happened.  So we're left guessing about Dane, the changes, if they're going to get worse in time, or if the baby is affected. Then there's the threat of the vampire returing to taunt Dane and get Dane to drink more vampire blood.  What a situation to have with a budding relationship!No, I didn't feel Dane's story is finished.So there's issues with the wolves on the west coast.  Issues with Salvador, Talyn's father.  Salvador's agenda.  The Council's agenda or at least two of the councilmen and their plans for Stillwater, the area where Talyn's Coalition  lives.  Then there is the threat from the Council Enforcers and wanting answers to the missing Hans.  There's the alliance with the vampires that happened without Syn saying a word about the message he was supposed to present.  And who knows just what that tow truck driver was doing.  Added to all that is a missing wolf and vampire.  How do they tie into this mess other than the vampire betrayed his brother and coven leader?  Oh yes and the wolf was the brother of the wolf alpha.  Two prominent guys that are missing.  Oh let's see. . . . Yeah.  There's more.What about what Talyn will do about his father trying to take over his territory, come back out of retirement to reclaim his coalition?  What about the Prim and their group, leader, and issues?  That was a big deal to Dane, a big part of his life and as this is Dane's story why wasn't that resolved?  Instead it's left up in the air and Dane left wondering how he'll be treated as he lives around them, still has to put up with them, even if he isn't housed with them.  As Dane is more aggressive then he used to be of course this is important.Like I said this story was enjoyable but there are so many inconclusive parts.  If it's a lead in for more answers I'm all for it.  I just hesitate because Lynn Hagen doesn't always conclude plots - I know cause I've read so many of hers and offered more than my share of reviews.  So I'm just on the fence here to see what will happen and of course if Dane and Syn's story will be concluded.  This book didn't do it. - Dan's Wife

Rocket Man is a story set on a space station.  It's about Max, a war hero, an elite soldier that left the war without an occupation.  With time he's settled into owning his own scrapyard on this space station.  He's barely making a living, starving half the time, but unwilling to give up.  He's fiercely competitive, full of street smarts, and into this life steps his old military buddy Kyle.Kyle is with the Special Forces and they have a job for Max.  They need his expertise to capture someone in the government there on the space station.  Does Max have a choice?  No.  It's either doing the job or being arrested.  Great choice.Now Max always had an interest in Kyle and Kyle felt the same way.  But the war interfered.  Now they're back together, working as a team, not under the best conditions or circumstances but at least they can now act on that attraction.  Under the never ending heat they worked a dangerous job.  They knew they have a good thing. ..  Yet part of Max's problem is with Kyle taking away his life, his job, his reputation, his sense of security.  How would anyone feel when the person you want to build your life with is destroying the one you have?The characters were real, the world interesting, the situations believable, and the outcome wonderful.  Some of the inner thoughts shifting through Max's brain got a bit old at times but overall a really great story.  My only thought is why didn't Kyle and his boss get to Max sooner.  But I guess Max had to become his own man before this segment of his life.  - Dan's Wife

The magician in this story is 'John', a short man with a big presence.  He doesn't look like much but he gets things done.  In his odd way he came to the town of Dustville to escape his past.  He inherited land there -- Who knows how much land or  why it's so run down or who he inherited it from. . .But that's John's reason for coming and living in Dustville.Henry is the town sheriff..  He's not trained for the job but can hit things he aims at.  Like John he also has a past, one he's running from.  This is the story of John and Henry getting to know each other, acceptance for who they are.  Add in a bit of magic, two men together, and a frontier town, set about 150 years ago.As for the writing -- Sentence phrasing was odd.  I don't know if  it was because Henry was trying to impress John or if it was the author trying for a historical feel.  As the story was told from Henry's point of view it'd make sense if he could pull it off.  But no, Henry was from a poor background in the South, I felt he didn't have the background to think or converse in those odd sentences.  The effect didn't translate well.The Magician of Dustville  is set in a frontier town after the Civil War.  Actually it was called the War Between the States back then and if Henry was fighting for the South, he would have called it that.  (Because once more this is Henry's viewpoint and he specifically said Civil War).  It isn't until our day that we call it a Civil War.  Another problem I had was that magic school back east.  Education was a lot different back then.  I bet Henry wasn't very educated.  And if there was a magic school, how did that impact the war?  Were mages used?  ??  !!I know people struggled hard back then and church attending and morals were in high regard.  It all went with modest clothing and the horror of 'girls of ill repute'.  So for a small town like Dustville to  accept John and Henry's relationship . . .  It was just a bit too pat.  The rivalries that divided the country were still going strong, even when the war was over.  So if people were upset over the outcome of the war and knew someone was in your town and fought for the other side, of course they're be problems.  That was a reality.  It was probably why Henry didn't want his desertion from the South to be known.  So yes, I had a hard time believing in this world.  There wasn't any background on why magicians are accepted, trained, and schooled or why a school is even there for them.  And yet even Henry knew of this magician school and he's been in the army or in a frontier town -- Another fact is that it's difficult traveling across country and news isn't up to date or reliable.  So I have to wonder about Henry knowing of this mage school.We don't learn why that dying magician decided to make his last stand where John would be involved.  I had a hard time justifying situations and events in that type of world it just went beyond my ability to grasp.  - Dan's Wife

I've enjoyed these bear shifter books, the various series that play off each other in TS Joyce's world.  This story, Bear the Heat does it all.  It gets down to the nitty gritty of a bear shifter's life and what's important.  No, not material posessions but respect, safety, family, and love.So the saga continues after the bear shifters 'came out' to the humans.  It's a time of turmoil, insecurity, and fear --  Both on the part of the bear shifters but also the human population.  Bear the Heat is just that - The focus on their town, their bear family, and putting up with it all with the added benefit of watching Boone's mating.Cora is a reporter from a local news station.  She was mentioned in previous books.  She's always supported the shifters and of all things. . . .She's Boone's mate.  Yet due to the uncertainty going on Boone doesn't want to put her career or life at risk or 'become a monster like him'.  Such a wonderful loving bear, a firefighter, a close sibling and loyal son.  I enjoyed the back and forth with Boone and Cora yet the story is greater than those two.  It talks about preconceived ideas and how hatred exists.  It's about standing up for others and being there for them despite the odds.  It's about taking the happiness you have now and valuing it above all else.  It's about changing people's minds a bit at a time and hoping for a better tomorrow.My only little nit pick is that dream of Boone's.  It was of his family being hunted down, shot and killed.  It was intense and the way it occurred I wasn't sure if it would come true or not.  Since it happened early in the story, I saw it as an attention grabber, something for the free sample to give a 'cliff hanger' feel.  It wasn't explained if this was prophecy.  It was barely referred to when Boone talked to Cora.  It was just an odd dream of killing off all the series main characters - Something no reader ever wants to happen.  - Dan's Wife

Having enjoyed the first book in the Coyote's Call series, I was excited about this one.  The opening with Gael being homeless. .. The despair, dealing with hunger, being cold, alone, and trying to survive. . . . In his case for 20 years.  I could picture exactly how the public ignores the homeless, even when they're right there in your space.  I don't know if it's embarrassment or pity that turns help away.  It is an issue to be aware of, to do what we can in our own way to help those that are less fortunate.  Gael's plight was so well done and I appreciate an author that takes the time to talk about social issues.Then there's Iker, a detective in Del Rey, a wolf shifter that is a part of a Coyote. .. band.  Yes a group of coyotes is a band.  The relationship with Iker and Gael was fast but heartfelt.  Again, like the first book I was a bit tired of all the pages of sex.  I would have liked more plot and research into what went on behind the scenes, solving the crime, a bit more with Gael's homeless pal, and what in the heck was the relationship with Roman and the Ranger.  There's just enough hints to make me wonder about each and then . . . nothing.  Was the ranger a shifter and what in the heck was he injected with?  What about that relationship with Roman?  Then there was the shoot out and there wasn't any conclusion about those mountain lion shifters.  How come no detective work is shown when Iker is a detective?  No, the case is just dropped in favor of sex in the apartment and thoughts of buying their own place.  *sigh*A big part of this story is about the crimes done to Gael and his family -- It was the set up for the plot, the basis for this story.  So when those crimes weren't solved, the plot falls apart.  At least it did for me.  I was left with too many questions in this conclusion.  In From The Cold doesn't solve the 'cold case' at all.  Nope.  - Dan's Wife

Thick and warm. Buttons are large enough and spaced enough that in the dark, you'll be able to adjust them. Cozy and comfy. I also tested the less expensive version of this (the mircofleece). This does live up to the PLUSH factor. Side by side in the packaging, the Plush was much fatter/thicker (yet not heavy).For me, there was slightly noticeable texture difference...the plush was a bit softer, spongier.Heating wise, they are identical - and have two cords, one for the right/left side so it's going to mean you'll need two free outlets. I'm not plugging in my husbands side, however, as he's always too warm anyway.If you can afford to splurge, this is a nice model and slightly more luxurious.But if you are watching your pennies (I guess more like dollars these days!) - go with the microfleece. Not too much difference and still high quality.

I stand for about 4 hours in one spot at a part-time job I work at. This is killer on my back/knees even though I'm petite. I have wide feet and high arches. I had a pair of knock of Skechers like these though not as cushiony. I wore them all summer. Walked my dog almost every day for at least 40 minutes. They were great.I hesitated to buy these as winter is coming up. However, I took a chance and have to say I'm glad I did.For 30 extra dollars than the knock off brand - these are even way more cushiony. I feel they do provide arch support without weighing down my foot. They look great with black pants and jeans.They stretch without losing shape.So comfy I wear them around the house when I'm home too!Worth the price.(and I'm a cheap skate!)

This is even smaller than it seems to be in photos. About the same width as my iPhone 5s. I did have to take my cover off in order to use the charger, but luckily I have an easy on/off cover so it's not a pain.Love the color. So far it works great. I'll update if there are any problems.

Update: 10/29/15I had given this 2 stars for frustrating set up. Then 3 stars when it seemed to work (though I had no idea how I got it to work). I'm bumping it up to 4 stars because customer service contacted me right away after seeing this review and explained that there wasn't an online manual yet because it is so new and they also walked me through the set-up problems I was having. These are the directions CS gave me which were much easier to understand. I hope this helps anyone who may be having problems setting it up.From Customer Service email:"We are working on updating the manual and posting it online. Let me assist you in setting this up –First, When you turn it on it should search for WWWB time signal, (the icon should be flashing) if doesn’t get the signal after those 7 minutes.Then  you can press the wave button so force a search.  Don’t press anything while its searching in those first 7 minutes.The RF button is  for the outdoor sensor if outside temperature is lost (RF – radio frequency)The units default time zone is Pacific – To set the time, in this case to Eastern hold the set buttonUntil you see  04  blinking on the display, then release and press  and release the down arrow until you see 01. (that is the time zone for Eastern) and your all set. 02 for Central, 03 for Mountain, 04 for Pacific."My problem setting it up had been do I wait for the signal to search for seven minutes or do I press the Wave button while it is searching. This makes is much more clear.It is working great now. I'd give 5 stars for customer service but 2 stars for the directions included with it when first sent out. I hope they can rework directions because it's an awesome little device once it's working.Here is my original review published on 10/28/15Very confusing directions. Went to the website for help...couldn't find the model. This is my first time using a weather forecast/monitor. But the directions should make it easy for someone who has no idea how to set it up.I honestly have no idea if this is actually working or not because of the confusing directions.I have no idea what the RF button is used for (other than as an UP function).I received this for free for testing purposes. Spent over an hour trying to determine if it was actually working - and searching for help on the website listed - had I spent the almost 60 bucks this is selling for at the time of this review, I'd be way more frustrated.Horrible directions and virtually no explanation of unit.UPDATE: 10/29/15 -I appreciate that a representative commented on my review and I will be contacting them via the email they gave. The unit seems to be working  though I have no idea how I set up it. I finally gave up and it seems to be reading the outside temp/inside temp correctly and forecast matches weather outside. However, the time keep reverting to three hours prior (ie: I'd set it for 2pm, it would be set and matching my time zone, then a few hour later, it would go back to 2pm.).
So far, so good. They are marked on the bottom so you can trim them to fit your shoe/boot. First few days wearing them. Will update if there is any problem or wears out quickly.

I love the the marking measurement on the side (2-4-6 cups). The lid is very tight, and I could see how someone with arthritis might find opening the container challenging.I also love that the terra cotta disk can be attached to the lid and the directions (to soak for 15 minutes then dry with paper towel, place in sugar in container) is etched on the lid so if you ever forget - it's there to remind you.I have a similar brown sugar container that seemed to stop working - but realized when I read the directions on this container that you should resoak the terra cotta every 2-3 months!Very sturdy and strong.Love it!

Great! This has no frills, but the cover is sturdy and the pages are strong. There is a pocket in the back (wish there was one in the front also). Plenty of space for writing, both on the monthly view and the weekly view.The photo of it doesn't do it justice. It's a heavy textured charcoal colored cover/back.

Didn't last long - under 10 minutes. And the round bone part separated quickly on one of the them and I took it away as I was worried our dog would swallow it whole. He is right at the top of 50 pounds so perhaps he was just a bit too big for this.

I like this a-lot. Not as much as Cards Against Humanity, but it's fun.It can be difficult though, if a player finds it difficult to use different dialects. Some younger players had no idea what a Canadian sounds like!If you go with it, and don't worry about trying to be perfect, you'll have fun. Some players get frustrated when they can't master the accent - make sure you play with laid back people and you'll have a great time!

There are complete pages that are so faded I can't read them. There were at least 50 plus pages which made this book useless. I'd caution that the buyer make sure all the pages are printed well as soon as this book arrives if you buy it online (and make sure you go thoroughly through it if buying at store) so if there is a problem,  you can send it back before the return date.
Soft and snug. Very very cozy. Love! I'm 5'4" and and wear 4-6 and these are roomy without looking baggy.

I own the audio-tech ATR2100-USB microphone. I can't use this because it requires a cable (I don't have, and it doesn't come with) and a sound system. There are many people getting into podcasting who might think this is similar to the ATR2100 (plug n play) and it isn't. You must have the total setup in order for it to work.I wish it was noted somewhere in the description that this compliments a sound system and is not compatible/nor plugs into computer.I would have never chosen to review a piece of equipment that I was unable to use. Really wish the description had made it perfectly clear what sort of equipment is needed in order to use this mircrophone.

A Newbie Review Focused Only on HDMI experience.I know nothing about setting up a projector and this was super easy. I didn't even have to open the directions. I already use an HDMI cable to stream my computer to my TV (this comes with no cables other than the electric plug). So this was as simple as turning the projector on, connecting my computer to the projecter via HDMI cable and the projector recognized it. I used the levers on the front to put it into focus, and TADA, we were watching a movie on the wall.The sound is not too great. It's doable, and if you're in a small space, it's okay, but it won't blow you away.Love it!
Works great, I've had a similar one for years. You can fit 6 cords IF you don't use need a three prong cord or if you're not using boxy plugs.Excellent Value.

I thought this was a plug-n-play (my mistake) though I didn't see anywhere that the consumer must download drivers (if using Windows) to use this product. Also, it doesn't come with outsource power supply - so if you want to use with with a TV, you'll have to make sure you have a 12 VDC, 1 A, center positive)

Very interesting. This is a bit on the creative side with some poems (only a few). I was most interested in how he got his start and he does go in detail about how he got his information about Clinton/Lewinsky. It's fascinating to read this book (written in 2000) knowing the continued success he has had.It's truly an inspirational story - from nothing to something - simply for doing what he loves and doing it because he wants to be helpful - not with some end goal of having tons of money in the bank at the expense of misleading/taking advantage of people.We need more Drudges in the world - though it's becoming increasingly more difficult with the political regulations created to stifle the Matt Drudges of the world.The last quarter of the book was mostly about the media corporations merging - and they have morphed and merged so much more in the last 15 years, yet the bottom line remains true: It's a monopoly - with a few pulling many strings and it's about power and control, not about enlightening and empowering people.

Wow. This should have been titled, "The Real Ego of Steve Tobak."Look, I'm all for self-promotion, but it has to be done with some sort of finesse, and Tobak is ME ME ME and really does nothing to offer any inspiration for going your own way.I'm going to have to go back to Napoleon Hill's Think and Grow Rich. An old book, but it has character, humility, and is still one of the most inspirational books in print.Don't just skip this - if you see it in a bookstore, hide it! (just kidding).

There are a few good nuggets of info in this book, but my word, Michael Port is a bit pompous and though he speaks about being humble, really does not practice it.The only valuable part of the book (for me) were in the back half of the book that talked about how to divide a speech/focus points.Everything else was just Port tooting his own horn about how wonderful he is.After reading this, I heard him on an EOF podcast and my personal observation that he is a bit of peacock was verified.He admonished the host of the podcast and said that speaking off the cuff was frowned upon - yet, I've heard many speakers who are great on the fly (and perhaps, that's what makes them great).It's as if he was saying people can't possibly be successful unless they do it Port's way.I disliked him immensely after hearing the podcast - he was way too practiced and rehearsed and it felt like he was 'phoning' it in.I probably would have given this 3 stars had I never heard the interview. But after the interview, I thought if you end up sounding like Port, better to skip this book and just watch youtube videos of Ted Talks, Brian Tracy, Jim Rohn or (my favorite) Zig Zigler. Emulate. And be authentic, not authoritative.

This was sent to me in exchange for an honest review.The moving rollers massager is ok- but the static massager is really awakard, no matter how much lotion I use.It's very cheap feeling/looking BUT, the roller one is nice/easy to use and does the job is was meant to do.

I put this on the top of an old desk that I use often. It works GREAT. I had no problems peeling and sticking it to the desk top. No bubbles. Probably much easier to do when it's going on a flat horizontal surface.The cloth that came with it is fabulous! It erases without using any spray (even erased old writing I had on different dry erase board).Love it!

I think the problem I had with this calendar is the way it was shipped - causing the calendar to have rolls in it at both ends and also dents in the middle. Hanging it up (and it is very large) helped ease the curled ends, however, the dents in the middle will always remain. It comes with a dry erase marker, but the squares are quite small. You can't fit a-lot of writing in the boxes.

I have an old pair of Tweezers I bought ages ago. They are just a cheap pair, nothing elaborate, but I've become very accustomed to them, which is probably why I did not fall in love with these, I'm just not as comfortable with them.I did like the color. I love anything with color.However, they aren't as easy to close as my other tweezers. The tweeze part is slightly gritty - they make an odd noise and it's almost like sand particles rubbing against each.I would think these might be excellent for splinters (though I'm not going to impale myself with shards of wood in order to test this thought!).I really think it's just a personal preference. If you have a pair of tweezers you LOVE, I doubt these will make you abandon your favorite tweezers. Nice to have as a backup though.

Truly amazing.It was hard to put this book down, and to be honest, after the first 5 chapters, I skipped to the back to find out what happens. I had no idea who Mengers was, and this book is a testament to the fact you don't have to know of her to love the book.I then went back and read the middle of the book.It is a fascinating, fascinating look at power, old (and somewhat new) Hollywood (and New York entertainment).I don't think I would have liked Mengers - though I do admire her moxie.The author did such a great job with this story. This would make a great Mad Men type of show centered around Sue as the female Don Draper type character.I'm a bit stingy with giving a book 5 stars, but this one...I'd give 10 stars.

I had never heard of this tape, but after using it on my ankles, I am a huge believer.I'm generally a very skeptical person, and decided to try this because my husband runs/worksout and thought it might be good for him.I was having ankle pain the day it arrived. I didn't watch any videos on how to use the tape. I simply put a few strips around my ankles and went out the door. I was amazed that almost immediately, my aching ankles felt great!After I returned home, when I was finally able to visit the website (kttape) and it gives demonstrations on how to use the tape for all sorts of aches/pains.I wrapped my knee the next day - not following their guidelines- just using a simple wrap around with the tape, and it works. Pain, gone.After about 6 hours, my skin does start to itch a bit. I listen to my body and take it off.I think this is amazing. And I'm not easily influenced these days.Highly recommend.

It's a fun game...much like cards against humanity but using slang words instead. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because CAH kind of broke the barrier and nothing (including the expansion packs of CAH) beats the shock/orginality of CAH, however, this is probably a 5 star game for those who think CAH is too bold. The charade aspect is fun.

So far, works great. It's a bit cheap feeling - however, at the price it's selling for, I think it's a good value.  Also, the shape is great; I can use this in our old kitchen which doesn't have enough outlets. It's handy for areas you need extra outlets but don't want to place a an outlet strip on the counter.

These are great. Adorable. I made chocolate chip cupcakes and they did not fade. I used a muffin pan for one dozen and used the cups as stand alone by themselves (on a cookie sheet). They do stand up on their own, it's just difficult to pour (for me) without making a mess when not using muffin pan.My biggest compliant with muffin/cupcake cups is always the fading - these do not fade!
For Auburn fans everywhere! Great cups that hold up. Sturdy & strong and don't sweat.

As a lifelong student of the behavioral sciences and advertising, combined with my travels and experiences of living in the real world vs academic world, I was eager to read this book but found it quickly dissolved into PT Barnum dissertation that will take advantage of easily influenced people.To his credit, Holmes did point out that the study of psychology is fragmented. Too often, researches focus on their status - their goal is to "discover" something new and collect the accolades that follow, elevating their status within the community. Holmes points this out in a story about the discovery of ancient species that different researches claimed as their own discovery and therefore,  one species was "discovered" over 20 different times by 20 different researchers. One researcher pointed out that this is like 20 different researchers claiming and renaming Newton's Law of Gravity as their own discovery.The ironic thing is that Holmes cites different researchers throughout the book, and a resourceful reader who has been exposed to the irony in the world of behavioral studies, will be acutely aware of these inconsistencies and examples.I was quite disappointed in the underlining antisemitism coursing through the book. I thought the story about Hand and Hand in Israel started off great, but then quickly dissolved into a veiled attack on Jews. There are many many instances of Jews being attacked, not just in Israel but all over the world, especially in Europe where they are fleeing in rapid numbers. A non-biased book would have included a story about Jews being taunted and discriminated against - but Holmes does not include any, which confirms his bias.If you can get your hands on a copy of any of Albert Hobbs books (check the library), you will learn something valuable about the industry of behavioral sciences and experiments and how behavioral science is not really a science as there are too many un-measurable and subjective variables.And if you want to read a great book about how marketing is disguised in medicine and science (including the marketing of researchers), read "The Father Of Spin" by Larry Tye; it's about the father of public relations and how he manipulated the medical and scientific community to make money or a name for his clients.

I'm really only giving this three stars for the holiday atmosphere/mood it brought to me. I'm not a Fern Michaels reader normally, so I wasn't familiar with these characters.There is nothing truly compelling about any of the stories or characters, but I didn't mind because the book itself was a nice, sweet,  distraction from the crazy world.It was a cozy read. Short stories that somewhat tie in together.

In the future, the Blood Plague has crippled society and the Doctors now rule.  Ren Grant’s parents were killed by the Doctors and she has been on the run since as a Carrier of the Plague.  When Ren is finally found, it is not by the Doctors, but by Rian Sloan and his group who are looking for a Keeper’s Watch.  Ren happens to have her mother’s Watch.  Rian needs her Watch to board a ship and escape Earth.  Ren travels with Rian and his group to Myrreka.  Ren goes through an adventure that will take her through danger, friendship and new trials.Ren really captured me from the beginning of this story.  Her situation and mode of survival made Ren interesting and easy to care about.  I was intrigued by her backstory, her mother’s secret and the mystery of the Watch.  It was fascinating to see what had happened to other cities after the Blood Plague as the group travelled.
