This is the tool to get old gasket goo off and prep your mating surfaces. A couple of different grits included in the kit so you can start by taking off the heavy stuff and work your way back to a good smooth surface. Used mine in a simple electric drill and it did the job in nothing flat.

Star 12-point end did not fit hinge pin properly. Other end is a hex and takes a 1/2 inch socket. The tool actually works better backward with the hex end in the hinge pin and 12 point end in a 12 point socket. Once I got it to fit it sheared off with only moderately-strong force on an 18 inch breaker bar.  Like 80 lbs pull so 120 ft-lbs.Thats not that much! Used a vice grips and a tie rod "pickle fork" to get broken end out of hinge because it had deformed. Thankfully the tool was so weak it didn't mess up the hinge pin.Merc puts these hinge pins in with generous red Loctite. You gotta "gorilla" them off! Why Merc assembles them  with red Loctite no one can say, just generally bad engineering typical of Mercury Marine....like the same way they make it so you need a special tool to remove 'em.....but tight they are, and anyone who has done the job will tell you the same.Here is a link regarding red Loctite and how to diassemble red Loctite-ed parts.http://www.us.henkel-adhesives-blog.com/post/All-About-Threadlockers/How-to-Remove-Red-Threadlocker/Bottom line heat to 500 F, which is hot but no where near glowing. Most kitchen ovens go up to 500 F.  Red Loctite is supposed to be permanent and intended to be used for non-servicable parts, ONLY heat re-liquifies it. Blue Loctite is what is intended for servicable parts..... like these hinge pins. This Sierra tool is NOT up to the job. Look around Amazon for other suppliers that have reviews of being up to the task. Heartland Products and Tungsten marine being a couple I found. FYI  a half inch hex (Allen) wrench socket fits the 12 point hinge pin and you can get one of those in a half inch drive impact socket, but you DON'T want to use an impact gun to remove the hinge pin. Too easy to bugger the 12-point head.BTW if you are about to begin this job you also need to remove the trim sender pucks, also screwed on with red Loctite. You need a hand-held impact screw driver ( the sort you whack with a hammer, not the version that looks like a power drill..... If the power tool version driver-bit slips or cams out you will destroy the screw head faster than you can let go of the trigger! ) to start those puck screws b/c heat will cook the pucks.  Buy a decent one 'cause it is a tool you will use a LOT on your Mercruser products. Something like this one:http://www.amazon.com/Lisle-30750-Hand-Impact-Tool/dp/B004I9UOAA/ref=pd_sbs_263_17?ie=UTF8&refRID=130AJ6B5BTSYRY11YMSQ

Very little restriction, no leaks whatsoever, and easy to use.  I especially like that it is easy to set an intermediate flow with this valve. Not really what it is designed for, but it works so smoothly it is a cinch to regulate from a trickle to full flow. At this price it is all I could ask for.

I have used many a Purdy brush while painting but I generally pick up less expensive brushes for less demanding work or general priming where the brushes tend to not get carefully cleaned daily; or for work where I know I won't be able to clean the brush properly so I'll probably wind up throwing it out after the job. (That happens to me a lot as I often do very small repair jobs for customers from carpentry to finish, including putting the few strokes paint onto my repairs at the end of the job. ) and  I had done just that with these 1 1/2 inch Wooster Golden Glo sash brush.Now paint brushes are deceptively complex tools. They need "pick up" or "load" the generous amount of paint without causing it to drip all over; they need to lay that paint down on the surface you are painting; then they need to spread it around. Finally they need to tip the paint film off so that you don't get brush marks. Not surprisingly there are many brushes that excel at one of these tasks but not at the others. There are trade off's in the bristle stiffness, the way the bristles are formed at their tips (good ones look a little like hairs with split ends, not just simple straight bristles.)  and then there is the thing about the bristles not falling out or going off in odd directions as the brush gets older so that they cause unwanted paint streaks outside of the lines you are cutting. Finally  the spreading around part wants slightly stiffer bristles particularly with heavy "low VOC" paints,  but the tipping off part generally wants softer bristles.  A brush that has soft bristle tips, but stiffer bristle shafts further up would be ideal.Next up is the over all shape of the tip of the brush. If it isn't formed in a neat straight line you can't possibly get neat straight lines out of it no matter how hard you try. So really cheap brushes (think disposable "chip" brushes here) have ragged ends, but really good brushes are made with precisely formed, neat, straight line across the bristle tips. And now that you know a little about bristles you can appreciate that this isn't as easy as just cutting them off to length after the brush is made.Last up is the hozzle. Ther are different shapes of hozzles for different tasks. For finish work you don't want too much paint in each brush load. So you want a hozzle that is relatively thin and rectangular. But if  you need the brush to hold a lot of paint, you want a hozzle that is fatter, even possibly rounded or oval. The fat oval hozzle has a lot of bristles in  the middle of the brush, so it holds a lot more paint. Good for getting a lot of paint to a big bit of work, but that much paint on a finish brush would be hard to control.Some of the best painters in the world brush paint hulls of mega-yachts to mirror finishes. Yep.. they BRUSH paint them, they don't spray them!  They have a three part crew. The first part is a man ( or men) with an oval brush and all he does is get the paint on the hull and move along. Right behind him is a guy(s) with a medium brush and he spreads the paint out into an even coat, first brushing one way, then another, criss-crossing. Then the last guy(s) comes behind him and tips everything off.  Three parts to painting, three guys, three different brushes... and a team effort that must take years of practice working together so as to get it just right and no one takes too long or goes too fast.However, for us mortals working alone we need a good compromise brush for the job at hand. Painting a fence? Maybe you want an oval brush to really get the paint on and you are not to worried about a mirror like finish.... but painting window or door trim you need a finish brush that can pick up the right amount of paint, get it to the work, spread it evenly, then tip it off, and it should also cut a clean line.This Wooster Golden GLO brush does all that, and it is deceptively inexpensive!It is also compatible with the new water borne finishes, something the natural bristle  (china Bristle) brushes, previously the most highly prized, simply can't handle. If  you use a natural bristle brush in a water born finish you will ruin both the brush and the finish. And those brushes are NOT cheap. A little tip: to get your water based paint to lay down like glass add about 1/2 ounce of household ammonia (non-foaming)  to a pint of paint. Your brush will glide the paint on the way the old oil based paints used to. It doesn't look so great immediately after you tip it off, but in 24 hours it will lay down and look like glass, provided you had good prep work under it.ALWAYS prime with oil based primers outdoors. Water based primers allow the wood to "breath" which means it will move, which opens up the joints and that lets moisture in and rot will begin. You can apply a top coat water based finish over a good oil primer coat. Use 20% - 30 % Penetrol in your "high solids low VOC" oil primer.This brush works extremely well; much better than any Purdy brush I have ever tried most at more than 2X the price. I was pleasantly surprised since frankly I had not expected this sort of performance at this price point. I just ordered a bunch more for my paint locker.

Works in a pinch, but clarity is of course limited by the quality of your camera, which is to say a lot of fine print probably will not be crystal clear. All-in-all it could get you out of a jamb. Definitely a keeper. If you scan and convert to .PDF you may also need to download a free Adobe PDF viewer. I had to for my Kindle FIre, but it was easy and free.

Nice fit and finish on this item. If you need a bar adapter this is a good one. 25.4 mm is 1 inch; common on many handlebars.  31.8 is a common larger standard for may stems.  So if you get a stem that is set up for 31.8 and want to put your 1 inch (25.4 mm) bars on your bike, this is the unit!
These are  nice Presta adapters. Note they have the little O-ring in there to help seal, a feature not seen on many competeing products.
A hard-to-find stem by angle and length, but this one is a good one. High quality, nice finish and puts my handlebars where I need them.

I got this belt for work trousers around the home. It is nice that it stretches so that you can have it tight enough to keep your trousers up when standing, but it doesn't constrict when you crouch or stoop or bend over.  It is attractively finished.The quality is good for the price, but I don't expect it to last a lifetime.

I needed a belt for working outdoors and around the house. This one is a good choice. It is well made and attractive. It has enough give to be comfortable when climbing ladders, bending over, stooping, what have you, and yet still hold my trousers up to avoid plumber's crack.Shipped fast and the price is great.

I have been riding bicycles for a very long time. As a teen and a  young man I rode to get places, not in competition or for exercise or for personal amusement.  I never needed  a mirror because the traffic was lighter, I usually rode faster than most of the traffic, I never rode in groups to speak of, I had plenty of flexibility in my neck and shoulders to twist to see behind me, and most of all since I was young I was certain I was invincible.I'm getting back into cycling now for exercise and fun. But with more traffic, riding with friends, going at a slower pace so that the traffic is often overtaking me from behind,  and mostly now with the wisdom that only comes with age that I will certainly not come out well in an altercation with a cell-phone distracted idiot-automobile operator. I decided reluctantly that it was time to try a bike mirror.Here is the problem: You are a pretty compact package on a road bike. You neither have nor want things sticking way out to the sides, but if you keep the mirror in tight how do you see past yourself on the bike?  You block your own view! And you don't want an over sized wind-dragging mirror, so small and light is good, but where do you put it so you can see behind you when you need to?  I experimented with a few of the more popular concepts and concluded that a flat (non-wide angle) mirror on your eyeglasses or helmet is best.You want a small mirror because you don't want the windage or the sticking out factor. But if the mirror is already small, you really don't want to make the view even smaller by using a wide-angle mirror. So forget about the supposed benefits of a wide angle (convex) mirrors unless it is going to be on your beach cruiser and as big as the side mirror on your SUV...BUT if it is a small mirror how much can you see? Can you see enough? Well, if it is on your head like this "Take a Look Mirror" it turns out you quickly adapt to tilting or turning your head ever so slightly this way and that as necessary to peer anywhere you please around the vicinity of your 6 o'clock.If you try this mirror walking around the shop or home, you will not appreciate how intuitive that head tilting is, and how quickly you learn to adjust the mirror so that you can glimpse it in your peripheral vision. Or if you are deliberately looking into it, how you still have your peripheral vision engaged on the road ahead. It is a lot like using  your automobile side mirrors: You don't feel as if you have to look entirely away from where you are going, and if you move your head slightly to change your mirror-view a little, it's no big deal. I walked around the house with mine and was totally skeptical that it was going to work for me. Once on the bike it was entierly natural and intuitive.OK so this is the right design: A small helmet or eyeglass mounted mirror, flat, not convex.  But what about the quality? adjust-ability? value? and so on? Well I was absolutely floored that the quality was so good at this price point.  It is a simple thing, but it is also well made from good materials. Perfect! And it comes with a lifetime guarantee from a company that has been around long enough that you know they must mean it. There is a reason this has been such a popular product for so long.  As for adjusting it? You can move it very easily to whatever orientation you like. In my experience so far it stays put where you adjust it. It is also easy to adjust with one hand while riding for fine tuning if you need it. Size? I got the "original" and I think it is about right, though I suppose some may prefer the newer compact version. It is important to set the mirror up so that it doesn't interfere annoyingly with your forward vision, but isn't too far over so that you can't just glimpse it.  With so much adjust-ability in the mounting there are several options. You will have to experiment and decide what works for you. For me the "original" size works great. Not too big to block my forward vision, not too small to see behind. Just right.I have mine on a pair of aviator style sunglasses that have lightweight thin bows. Not quite wire bows as on RayBans, but nearly so. This is no problem for the mounting. It would also clip easily onto wide bows on wraparound style glasses. And you snap the mirror on and off easily enough to move it to other specs or to your helmet, or if you just want to use you glasses without the mirror while you are having lunch or something. I think there is an "optional extra" to mount it to a helmet, but I also think that for many helmets you might not need it. Just clip it to the shell which might require removing a little foam.And how do I like it? I LOVE it! I never thought I'd be the sort to say that. I'm not the spandex type, but I'm not into looking like a fool either... and I never thought that these mirrors were "cool." However this mirror gives me a good view astern which has added unanticipated confidence and opportunity when I'm riding. I can speed up or slow down to time my left turns when there isn't an idiot behind me trying to run me off the road; I can cross busy intersections when I know there isn't some soccer mom on her cell phone about to cut me off;  if I have to swing wide around a pothole or sewer grate I can look behind in an instant to check for an oncoming dump truck....and best of all I can look back there to see if my mates are still keeping up with me ('cause I'm still way faster than most of them *wink*)Fist off if you are on the fence about getting a mirror, just get one. Any one. You won't regret it. You will like it.Next: The "Take a Look Mirror"  beats out the bar end mirrors, the frame mounted mirrors, and all the other wide angle helmet or eyeglass mounted mirrors hands down. Don't waste  your time with the others. Try this one first and you won't have to try anything else. There is a reason they have been around so long and why they keep getting repeat customers.Peter

This extension cord is at the short end of the spectrum for work site or shop use.  On a job site you would typically run a heavy duty main cord with an  AWG 12 or 10 gauge wire, put a 3-way on the end, and then run this  light duty 16AWG cord from that to your hand-held power tool, work light, shop vac, whatever. Because it is not terribly long and you are not trying to hang 6 or 8 tools off the end of it,  it doesn't need to be a monster gauge wire to combat undue voltage drop. The lighter weight makes it easier to store, lighter weight on the back of your power tool when you are using it, and inexpensive enough that you can afford a couple of them so that each tool you are currently using can have its own cord. That saves time and aggravation of having to constantly keep changing the cord to the current tool. EXAMPLE: I set one up on my mini shop vac and another on my DA sander. Then when I am sanding and prepping both tools are ready to go all the time.Also perfect for just running across the shop or workspace if you have a nearby outlet where once again the runs are not long and you aren't trying to run a whole job site off the cord.It is more than capable of conducting enough power to run just about any tool or device that you could run by plugging directly into the wall socket with the possible exception of an air compressor. Circular saws, sawsalls, drills, drill press, sanders, vacs, work lights.... all OK. So go ahead and buy yourself that AWG 10 or 12 gauge wire for the main power feed cord at 75 feet, but from the end of that to your tool use these.Don't waste your money paying for copper in heavy wire gauges that you don't need in a short cord.Well insulated and suitable for outdoor use;  I doubt a little rain or snow would harm it.

Chambray is a cotton that is light weight. It is supposed to be lighter than denim, and as such I hoped to use these shirts in warm weather. They are very nice, sturdy, great quality construction. They fit well and so on,.... but typical Carhartt they are rather "heavy duty." I would put the material weight as "lightweight denim"... a good late fall and early spring shirt. Too heavy for really warm conditions, not really heavy enough for real winter wear, though they could be nice over a Tee for that time of year, or if  you worked mostly indoors in cool but  not cold conditions.I'm happy keeping mine because I know I'll get plenty of use out of them, even though they were not precisely what I was expecting.Peter

****EDIT:After receiving a great batch of cups lightening quick from "WelDun Solutions" I wrote the following positive review and re-ordered some more of them.*BUT*The first batch came from  "WelDun Solutions" the second batch came from "VetMed USA" a distinction that didn't even cross my mind until I opened my second shipment.The second batch from "VetMed USA" are slightly different cups. They are still pretty good, were shipped promptly and so on, but not the same as the first batch, and significantly, not the same as the one in the listing photo. The photo shows a sharp upper lip to the cup, which is what I got in my first order. The second batch has a rolled-over upper lip.VetMed shipped via US Postal Service via DHL which added two additional days onto the "free 2 day delivery" to my area and does not offer any en-route shipment tracking; The shipping delay is not VetMed's problem, it is a problem with my local post office, but a recurring one. The cups are not as flexible; and the graduations are not as sharp and clear. They are made from a different material. I did not tear open the sealed plastic bags they came in so I can't determine if they are as solvent-resistant as the first batch or if they have the same handy supplemental markings on them because I may return them. I haven't made up my mind if it is worth the effort to ship them back since we aren't talking about much money here. I'm sure this second batch would be fine for dispensing meds, but since I'm using mine for mixing glues and paints I am not nearly as enamored of them. I'm being nit-picky, to be sure, but I found the first batch to be absolutely perfectly suited to my needs, which is why I ordered more immediately. The second batch is OK, but not as perfect for my particular use.****ORIGINAL REVIEW: (NOTE: This order shipped from from WelDun Solutions)Just right for mixing of paint or epoxy etc. in small batches. Shipping was lightning quick.Cups have graduations in these increments: 5 ml  (same as 5 cc;) 1/8  fluid ounces; 1 tsp; or 1 dram. (8 drams to 1 oz.)They have extra markings at: 2.5,  7.5  and  12. 5  ml (cc's);and at: 1/2 tsp, and 1 dssp1 dssp is a "dessert spoon" and is standardized at 10 ml which is about 2/3 tablespoon. That is also 2 tsp. (3 tsp per tbs in the kitchen!) A Brit tbs is 15 ml, a US tbs is 14.79 ml. so there is a very small difference between Brit measure and US measure, but that difference shouldn't matter for recipes, or for mixing paint or glue...... If that 0.21 ml is critical to you, you had better find a more precise means of measuring than markings on a little cup.The graduations are small but easy to read as they are sharp, crisp, clear, molded in markings. I appreciate that they are crisp and clear since many molded-in markings can be rather indefinite.  I like the multiple scales because I am usually interested in ratios, not absolute numbers, and with all the choices you can nearly always find some combination that works.The cups are flexible so you can kind of squeeze the top to make a spout to pour stuff out of them into other containers (such as loading epoxy into hobby syringes) or if you need to smush a wider brush into the tops of them you can get that done too. Top lip is about 1 3/4 inches in diameter, but by squeezing the top to elongate the lip I was able to coax a 2 inch disposable paint brush into one well enough to load the brush with paint for touch up work. It wasn't pretty, but it was the brush I had at the time and it got the job done.1 3/4" diameter across the top, 1 3/8" inch high,  1 1/8" inch diameter across the bottom.I have not tried them with the more aggressive solvents like acetone or lacquer thinners, but the mini plastic "water cooler" cups I was using previously dissolved in the solvents of my alkyd paint ("oil" based house paint) in about 30 minutes, and the paper version just turned to mush in about 10 minutes. Alkyd paint solvents are mostly mineral spirits and/or naphtha.  These cups do not suffer that fate.  ** update: I have since tried both acetone and lacquer thinner in them with no problem. Overnight might be an issue, but for the 1/2 hour or so I'm working with them they are fine with these solvents showing no sign of degradation. **Now that I have tried these I'll be sure to keep plenty in my shop. I can't tell you how many times I've mixed way, way, WAY more epoxy or paint than I needed just because I couldn't get convenient accurate measure in small batches, yet the ratios are critical.... so I'd mix up a big batch just to be sure to get the ratios right and then throw away about five times more than what I'd actually use.

Like the rest of the Campy Veloce equipment this chain works flawlessly. The 10 sp cassette that is currently offered is called "Ultra Drive" I believe, which is a geometry meant to work specifically with the campy 10 sp UD chain.Circa 2014 the end link for joining is not like the previous style: It uses a pin system somewhat similar to Shimano's to connect the two end links. If you get a chain that has the older system of a master link it may not be an Ultra Drive or "UD" chain.  I'm not sure precisely when the changeover was made, but in the past I've had Campy 10sp chains that use a master link so both systems are out there. Check and ask to be sure you get the version you want. The Campy UD chain MUST be shortened ONLY from one particular end, there is a tag on the opposite end that warns you of this. Leave that tag in place to remind you until you are ready to join the ends. Then the end links are joined with a two part pin set. You insert a little guide (supplied with the chain) from the  outer side of the chain(away from the bike frame) and press in the joining pin (also supplied and a use-once-only item)from the bike-frame side. Once the pin is in place the guide part is removed using just your fingers and either tossed out, or if you are like me, carefully set aside (squirreled away?) with the removed links. Like Shimano you are not supposed to re-use the same link or pin to remove and replace the chain. Campy sells a special little three link service kit for this. I'm not convinced this use-once-only system is a true improvement, but it is what it is and it does work perfectly well. Campy says its stronger, but I've never had an issue with a master link failure.The system claims it requires a special Campagnolo chain tool to accomplish properly, but I got by just fine with my standard one. The Campy chain tool has a system that centers the tool's drive pin onto the chain's joint pin quite precisely, I used common sense and great care to accomplish the same.

What can one say about a front derailleur? Its a pretty simple device. This one, like all Campy stuff is beautiful and works flawlessly. I upgraded a sport/exercise road bike for my wife using the entire Veloce groupset to replace some low end Shim..no junk that came with the bike. I know Shim..no's low end stuff is much cheaper (in the USA) than this Campy entry level Veloce groupset, so you might think that direct comparisons may not be entirely fair, but the Campy Veloce stuff works flawlessly whereas the Shim..no stuff often simply didn't work,... period... Lots of clatter, dropped chains and missed shifts. It is a shame Campagnolo is so dear in the USA but Merlin shipped UPS International for free and there was zero hassle. The shipment arrived in a matter of days, sooner than some local suppliers got other parts which I ordered at the same time into the US mail. And it was cheaper doing it this way than the price of Shim..no's entry level Sora group. Now when I ask my wife how she likes the way her bike shifts she says "I don't really think about it. I just DO it." ....Perfect!If you opt for the braze on version reviewed here and you don't have a braze on lug on your seat post to mount it be sure to get the correct size Campy adapter clamp. I like this system because I can then swap this derailleur to another bike with a different size seat post someday by simply buying the correct clamp.

"Power Torque" is Campy's solid axle setup. The old cartridge or spindle in your bottom bracket is removed. The Veloce Power Torque drive side crank has a solid axle attached with a bearing pressed onto it; the non-drive side crank is just a crank. There are two cups that replace your bottom bracket. The one on the drive side receives the bearing pressed onto the aforementioned axle, and the one on the non-drive side has a bearing that stays put in the cup. This system is not the same as "ultra torque" which has a two piece axle with a joint in the middle inside of  the bottom bracket housing.This system must be specified at purchase to fit your bottom bracket threads and housing size. There are a bunch of different choices here so if you aren't sure what you have you had better give it a good look before you purchase this crankset. Still not sure? Ask your local bike shop to help.I like this system and IMHO it is a natural improvement over BB cartridges or cup-and-ball bottom brackets. The only down side I can see is that it requires some extra tools to disassemble and  service it down to the individual bearing point because they are pressed in and on, but this sort of cervice is something most of us will never have to do. Of course they sell Campy specific tools for pulling the bearings but it boils down to a two-jaw puller which is available just about anywhere cheaply. Complaining that this is a drawback is about like complaining that you need both a torx and a regular screwdriver to work on your car.The finish is very nice and the shifting on the chain rings is crisp and sure.  Too bad Campy is so dear in the USA, but Merlin shipped mine for free via UPS International with no hassle whatsoever. The stuff came faster than parts I ordered domestically, and I had UPS tracking the whole way.

Absolutely fabulous value in wheels. If I could give them ten stars I would. Maybe not as slick as some wheels costing thousands, but heck, for the price you simply cannot beat these wheels. They arrived promptly and were 100% true right out of the box. I used these with a Campy conversion on a sport/exercise road bike for my wife and I could not be more pleased.The description says "Brake compatibility: V" which is a brake often found on cyclocross or MTB's. Don't be put off. I used them with Campy Veloce brakes no problem.

It's handlebar tape, so what can you really say about it? Well it is a very complete package including bar end caps, some nice electrical-like tape to finish the wrap that doesn't have logos all over it, and some short pieces for the back of the shifters/brake levers.The tape itself is quite cushion-y which suits some people. I prefer cotton, but I'm old-school and don't change my habits easily. My wife loves this version

I used these to make a mountain bike into a more upright beach cruiser for my wife. The straight-across MTB bars caused her to lean on her wrists uncomfortably. These are more swept back and also come up a little higher to solve that problem. They are well made and installed easily even with her GripShifts indexed shifters. They also  look great on her bike.

If you need to occasionally touch up the tune on your piano, or if you are just beginning to dabble in piano work for a hobby this is a fine place to start. I suppose there are more expensive kits out there, and ones with fancier hammers, but this one is pretty complete and will work just fine. the carry case makes it easy to keep everything together.I only took off one star because it does not appear that you can easily interchange the tuning hammer heads. Most people won't need to, but it seems like it would be a cinch to make it possible to do so. Perhaps if I looked further into it maybe it is possible to work around this somehow. I'm just not that familiar with the various standards for these tools.

Nice dual purpose tool for your bike kit. I used this to remove a cup that must have been put in place by King Kong himself. Bike in the stand, giant over-sized wrench on the tool, one foot on the frame, two hands on the wrench.... but it got it done! What more can a fella ask for from a tool?
Just the right tool for the job. I like that it is dual purpose. Nothing fancy, but why not get two tools for the price of one? It fit my bottom bracket perfectly.

You won't get your cranks off without doing damage unless you have a puller like this one. This is the right tool in a neat package shipped promptly and a nearly universal fit. I found that I had to substitute a washer under the tip of it to spare my spindle threads when pulling a Shimano crank. The little included disk was too thick in this particular application and the puller's threads wouldn't engage the crank-bore sufficiently. No big deal.
Nicely machined, includes a little rubber o-ring on the Presta side that others don't have which would seal around the Presta stem. Comes five to a pack and shipped quickly. Very happy!

This is a great cover at the price point. Mine is out in all sorts of tough New England weather all four seasons and has survived for more than a full year. Lately I noticed a few small tears starting to appear in the tricky spots where my grill is particularly sharp cornered, probably occurred  from me taking the cover on and off, not from cold/heat/sun/wind damage. No biggie because a new one is inexpensive and ships quick from Amazon!

This does the job of the more expensive ones for a fraction of the price. No instructions come with this tool, so check out  you-tube for guidance.The internal brushes and gears all drop right out for easy clean up, so take a picture of how they all go together before that happens to you by accident! You will also want to have a  parts cleaning bucket handy to clean this tool up after you use it.Does not include cleaning solvent.It will splash some greasy spots around so don't clean your bike chain in the living room!  Take it outside and put down newspaper or a scrap of cardboard. No other chain cleaners are any better in this regard.Can't be beat for the price!

This is a pretty nice tool but it is big, awkward, and heavy for a palm sander. OK for shop or workbench use, but not so great for one hand at the top of a ladder, or over your head like on a boat topside or bottom. It really requires two hands to handle properly. Also since it is over sized for one-hand operation the switch and speed control dial are not as conveniently located as it might appear in the picture. You're going to wind up holding it low down where it says "Bosh" on the side opposite the dust collector. There is not enough room above the dust collector and the top "handle"overhang where the cord comes out to get your hands in that side.... and the top "handle" is too wide to hold comfortably in one hand. It is about 3 inches wide and 51/2 inches long. So from the low grip position your thumb is now around the side of the sander and nowhere near the switch. "So what?" you ask.... Well these type of RO sanders like to be used by turning them on and off AFTER it is in contact with the workpiece, not before. So you press the tool to the work (gently) THEN you turn it on..... if you do it the other way around,( turn it on and then press it to the workpiece,)  you will most likely leave swirl marks and can easily gouge the workpiece. So a convenient location of the on/off switch is not trivial.  I also hoped to be able to exchange pads with my other Bosch 3107 DVS  (a larger random orbit sander with a handle) that I have had for years and love, but that was not to be. A new pad design for this sander precludes that. I also hoped this would be a nice complement to that older sander as one that was a bit more handy. As it turns out this would make a decent replacement for that bigger handled sander, but it is not a great complement to that tool.  The kit includes a carry bag (not a hard case), a vacuum adapter and the dust collector  I have a LOT of tools, many of them Bosch and I have always really liked every one of those Bosch tools until this one. There is really nothing wrong with this tool but the ergonomics of some of the other brands would be preferred, and they all seem to have a bit more power to boot.Peter

The renovated tool looks like new. It came with a carry bag, the dust collector, and an adapter for a shop vac hose. Sadly the "Kit" does not mean a hard box like it used to, at least not for this item. Its a bag now.... but a nice one, kind of like a mini tool bag with nice handles and a couple of little side pockets and enough room inside for a spare pad or two and a some spare sanding disks.Seller shipped promptly, item delivered quickly, all good... etc.Why the 4 stars? Because this is a BIG tool for a hand sander. Fine for shop work on a bench, but NOT a one-hander atop a ladder unit. I have the older rear grip BOSCH random orbit 5" sander and I love it, which is partly why I sprang for this one. I sort of hoped this would be a bit more compact, but not so much.I also hoped I'd be able to swap pads between the two since I have soft, medium and hard pads for the old one. No go on that either. The older one has a single allen head machine screw in the center of the pad, this one has four torx screws.Last, both sanders come with a "damper" that stops the pad from spooling up if you are not in contact with the work piece when you first turn it on. If you do that you will cause gouge marks on your workpiece.... BUT if you get used to the way these things work you can use that to your advantage. Lift up, let the pad spool up, then gently use it to cut down high spots sort of like a disk sander.... then press down firmly for orbital action to smooth the surface. Dual Action! Very handy if you have the touch, so I remove the dampers from mine.... This one removing the damper is a bit more of a project requiring that you unscrew the case a little. Those case screws are torx too, but in very deep holes so you need long, skinny torx driver to get at 'em. The sort of driver where you exchange bits won't go down into the deep holes.All in all this is a nice tool, but best suited for shop and bench work, not ladder work. Fair enough, but I had high hopes for something more compact since it said "Palm Sander.".... No way is it a "Palm Sander" unless  you are King Kong......and more interchangeable with my older Bosch sander would have been nice. This one would be a great choice to replace my old big Bosh, which are now very expensive, but to compliment it as a lighter smaller tool, not so much.Peter

This is what you need to change out the high side valve core and cap on some newer vehicles. I bought this one for an '09 Chevy Suburban 1500 LT V8 but it looks identical in dimensions/threads/ etc. to the one  I just changed in my '01 Dodge Dakota 4X4 sport with the 4.3L V8. As far as I can tell the only difference is the color of the o-ring seal just above the threaded part. Maybe one is Buna and the other Viton? It hardly matters. This one came with a new dust cap included and the threads already treated with a thread-locking compound. The inner valve core is integral to this piece and can't be changed out separately.Go to your high side valve and take the plastic cap off. Look down into the valve: If there is a stem sticking up in the middle like a tire fill valve you don't use this part. If you see a little rubber diaphragm instead, this is your guy. The listing picture is upside down. The threaded part goes into the aluminum tube on the high side. There is a hex on the aluminum tube with a circumferential notch that makes it appear as if that is where things come apart; ......but BEWARE!!!!...... That is NOT where to twist your wrench! Instead this valve body has a hex machined into (onto?) what the top quick-connect collar. (The first big ring above the very bottom in this listing photo.) This hex is not obvious at first but that is where you put your wrench to unscrew it while firmly holding the hex on the aluminum tube so as to prevent damage to that super-light aluminum part.The hex on the valve body is an odd-ball size. You can either use a pair of channel locks or, or grind your own special open-ended wrench, or get yourself the special socket. Amazon sells the socket. Search for the following:Mastercool (MSC98234) R134A HIGH SIDE HEX SOCETThings do not have to be gorilla-tight. The seal is made at the green O-ring in the photo, the threads more or less just hold things in place, so don't wind up the aluminum tube getting all macho torque-y with it! Snugging it up nicely is enough maybe with a teeny drop of loctite if yours didn't come with it.I do not see any way of changing this without emptying the system. If you do that you will need to recover the refrigerant that is left in the system, not just vent it to atmosphere. Also you will need to pull a vacuum on the system before you can recharge it. Recharge the system with the proper amount of refrigerant, usually a critical amount for most cars. If the system has been 100% depressurized for any time you should also replace the drier which means then you also must add oil of the right sort and amount when re-charging. If this sounds like Greek to you, take it to the shop, just don't get sucked into paying thousands for a new evaporator when all you need is a new service valve for less than 10 bucks. If the shop balks simply say "Please start by replacing the service valves and then leak check things before you dig into the evaporator." If the shop balks at that request, you need to find a new shop because that guy is a crook!The evaporator is just a length of tube with fins on it. Nothing would make it leak unless you stuck a screwdriver into it by accident or it was very, very old. Usually the evaporator connections and their seals are even in the engine box, not under the dash. On the other hand the service valves are notorious for going bad.Peter

Bought this for my wife's cruiser. It has a very concave shape from nose to back. I don't know why.Here is the thing: a good performance bike *saddle* is something you sort of lean back against, the long nose of the saddle hardly contacts you at all. Your butt cheeks kind of press back against the back of the saddle (like leaning against a kitchen counter) and the nose is mostly there to stabilize you side to side. This arrangement works well for hard performance riding. That is why it is exactly what you see on all performance bikes. A bike *seat* is another story. It is a place to actually rest your weight and sit, which is why it is a style popular on beach cruisers and kid's bikes. A quality womans bike seat tends to be wider in the back than a man's for obvious reasons. For women the nose is wide and short. Men need a different fit,  generally longer and skinny-er in the front and narrower in the back with the front tilted down more. Back in the '60's and '70's the differences between mens and womens were blatant, now in our politically correct gender neutral times, not so much.This is a seat. It is wide in the back and short in the front. But it isn't' flat like a proper bike seat. It is scooped out.... if you looked from the side it would be very concave  in profile along the top line drawn from the middle of the front to the middle of the back. This means that if you tilt the nose down enough so that you are not getting excess pressure on your perineum you are now forced to be leaning against the back like a saddle, and not a great one because the scoop is too extreme and the back tilts up too much. If you don't continually press backward you slide forward...very annoying. If you tilt the nose of the seat up enough to support your bum without sliding off forward, you will be getting badly poked in the perineum by the nose. NOTE: With a properly adjusted performance bike and saddle this isn't an issue. Your saddle is higher and bike frame bigger than on a cruiser bike and you generally want to pedal harder.... so it is more akin the aforementioned leaning against the kitchen counter, which is good for performance pedaling.... but on a cruiser you want to *sit* not lean.I can only assume the design was inspired by the scoop look of a motorcycle saddle or seat, particularly of the HD variety... but motorcycles saddles are different. They are very wide in the perineum area so there are no annoying pressure points. Generally they have a flat-ish zone in the mid length where your bum goes, and the flip up in the back, if they have one, cradles your behind, but isn't where you sit your weight. They are more like riding a horse than sitting astride a fence rail, and since you don't generally have to pedal your Harley (or your horse)this is OK. But not OK on a bicycle where your thighs are close together and in continual motion.I like that it is not gel, as the gel will feel nice for a few miles, but after a long ride it all smushes away from the points where you need it most. This seat has some springs beneath which are too stiff to be of much use other than to give it a retro-look. Other reviewers mentioned adjusting the springs, but the seat I got was at the limits of adjustment. Any looser and the adjusting nuts would just fall of. So no help there.Because of the overall shape and the springs the height is greater than most stock seats/saddles. You will need a couple of inches down-travel adjustment available in your seat post to be assured you can get a comfy height after you swap out this saddle with stock saddle. The actual amount will depend on your present seat of course, but if you are nearly all the way down now you may not be able to get low enough with this seat.The quilted stitch pattern on the seat looks great but is most definitely NOT waterproof.The quality is good, but personally I dislike this seat for both comfort or performance, but my wife likes the way it looks on her bike. Who am I to argue?  If she rides less than a few miles at a time it will be fine.Peter

If you are replacing an older Rule switch with the mercury inside be aware that his one is slightly longer and the mounting holes do not line up precisely. IT might be a little taller too, it looks it, but I have not measured. They are not way off, just enough to be a real PITA because you will have to fill the old mounting holes or the new screws will try to "find" them and mess you up. Also it seems that the turn on is at a higher water level as is the shut off. Not a lot, just a little.I can't imagine why they didn't make it an exact drop -in replacement, but that's Rule for ya!

This watch with its stainless steel band and multiple Iron Man features is a perfect work and sport watch.Rugged and good looking with all the features you might ever need.It is truly waterproof with an easy to read display, but without being too big on your wristFace is about 1 1/2 inches to the outside of the bezel; about 1" wide across display. Band is about 3/4 inch wide.Count down timers can be set to stop when done or reset continuously from any value (Best watch EVER for timing sailing starts!)Chrono has lots of split lap times; cycling enthusiasts, workout routines, runners, motorsports, should love it.Three time zones! Great for pilots and navigation where you want quick reference to Zulu time.Several alarms which can be set for once only, daily, weekend etc.Back light for night useBattery lasts a very long time ( 2+ years)Setting the watch and accessing the features is consistent and quickly becomes intuitive. No nested menus.You DO have to adjust the bracelet to fit to your wrist without a lot of slop. If you do not you will catch it on something and the band will break. Adjusting the bracelet is fairly easy if you are a handy person, if not find a jeweler who will help. You must push out a pin to separate the links. I use a straightened safety pin with the point filed off and a block of wood underneath with a small hole to make room for the pin to come out. You will need a small pair of needle nose pliers to hold the safety pin and to push the link pin back into place.The good news is that after you beat the heck out of this watch and finally something gives up, it isn't expensive to replace!I'm on my forth one of these over many years, I wear mine daily for work (I work outdoors) and for play. Salt water, sand, surf, swimming, shop dust, paint, oil, solvents, or in the shower, its always on my wrist. No worries! My wife is on her second, she only wears hers when she is running or swimming.Peter

Pros : Holds Like Crazy Once Hooked UpCons : Reliability Issues In UseBest Uses : Small BoatsI have a small "Commando" G-5 and a larger one for my other boat, a 26 foot power boat which is notably  heavy for her size.The flukes assemble to the stock, crown and shank with a slip together setup. Everything is held in place with machine screws through the flukes squeezing clamps around the stock. (The stock is the horizontal bar across the bottom of the flukes)If the clamps are not extremely tight that stock can slide sideways out of the clamps and ultimately spontainious disassembly could occur! I was shocked after sitting on the g-5 for an afternoon to pull it up and find I was only inches from this occurance! The stock had already slid most of the way out! A few more hours and my boat definately would have been on the beach. It was only a small Boston Whaler and I was only  a few feet away up on the beach so that wouldn't have been a tragedy, but if the wind were offshore and had carried the boat away it really could have su*ked!  I intend to modify mine by drilling two holes through the stock that will attach to some tabs I'll have welded to the flukes where the old clamps went....  This should be a design change made at the factory! They wouldn't have to weld the tabs, ( They brag that they don't weaken the structure with welds) but could incorporate them into the fluke design.** An anchor that can fall apart unexpectedly while in use and on the bottom is a pretty scary proposition!**NEXT, although the anchor holds like crazy once it sets, the close fit between the crown and the shank means it often gets clogged with coarse sand or mud. This jambs the crown from moving which prevents the flukes from falling (pivoting) properly into position to hook up. I've experienced this a bunch of times now. That is OK under normal circumstances where you can make two or three trys to hook up,... just haul up the anchor, (its nice and light) clear the jamb, and try again... but it's not cool if you are in a situation where  you need an anchor that works RIGHT NOW the first time! This jamming has happened with both the little G5 and the bigger anchor repeatedly. Maybe 25% of the time for each.This anchor is convenient, light weight, and it does hold very, very well once hooked up, so I like it a lot, but in view of the above shortcomings I wouldn't trust it as my primary anchor. I would also be very wary of using [this type or brand of anchor] for larger boats where these sorts of failures are a bigger problem. Even simply failing to hook on the first try because the flukes are jammed is a bigger PITA if you have a big boat, a large anchor, and a lot of rode.P.S. If I lost you with anchor nomenclature just google "Parts of an anchor" for a good diagram of a Danforth-style anchor.BTW: the kit bag is nice and the setup comes with 100 feet of line, some chain, and a shackle.Since this is a small boat anchor you probably won't want or need 100 feet of line most of the time you use it, so cut that line into convenient lengths. Coiling 50 feet of line is somehow 10 times easier than coiling 100 feet of line, and if you need all 100 feet you can always bend the two pieces back together with a good knot. The chain is too light to be of any use for weight, only to prevent chafe if you anchor in rocky spots. I don't so I set mine aside. You will want to add a stainless swivel to help prevent the rode from making hockels (those tight twisted loops) when you deploy or recover it. Don't forget to safety wire your shackles!Peter

To begin with let me say I am very picky about my audio components.  I will not abide inferior sound reproduction or distortion. Weak highs that are not crisp and muddy bass reproduction are my two most common complaints with inexpensive audio components. These speakers perform OK in that regard.I just installed a pair of these in my boat.  There is no point in going crazy on speakers for a boat cockpit: They simply don't last in the harsh marine environment, but I do value good sound quality.  I did not expect these to be the absolute tops in sound reproduction, but I was pleasantly surprised at how adequately they perform.  As you might expect they are mid-range biased if the equalizer is neutral. Pushing up the bass and treble a bit results in perfectly acceptable sound quality for listening to typical radio music programs like Country , Rock, etc. At moderate volume the highs are crisp and decently bright. Bass is clear and not muddy, but it won't rattle your windows. If you are after street-thumping bass these won't do it, but neither will most 5" speakers. However, if you are listening to most broadcast music the way the artists intended you to hear it they are fine. The audio stage is remarkably good for such inexpensive speakers! The speakers come with the mounting hardware you need and they look nice installed. You get a plain looking round black grille and bezel with a small plastic "PYLE" logo on it, which isn't intrusive by way of size or bright color. You will see a bit of the silver colored triax speaker layout through the grille, and perhaps a peek of the blue  bass speaker cone (Is it mylar? It's some sort of plastic, not paper...); a classy look that will work fit into almost any situation.I'm going to buy another pair for inventory so that I have them when the set I just installed need to be replaced,Overall I'm plenty pleased.

Right kit for '01 Dodge Dakota. The kit has three "standard" Schrader cores, plus one 8mm core, one 10mm core and an entire high-side port quick disconnect assembly with the valve already inside it. So that is six pieces in all.The last one is what you need if you look down into your Dodge high side service port and do not see a little valve stem but rather a rubber diaphragm.You unscrew the entire quick-disconnect collar and replace it with the new one. The quick disconnect has some odd size wrench, but I got mine off and on just fine with a big pair of channel locks. Be sure to hold the hex on the high side line firmly with a flare-nut wrench as you do this. the lines are only light aluminum. The separation point is not where it first appears. Take a good look at the replacement part before you wrench in the wrong place. Also you will need refrigeration gauges and a vacuum pump since there is no way to change the entire quick connect with the system still charged as is the case with some of these valve cores IF you have the right tools.If you have the gauges and vacuum pump this is the kit to get the job done on your Dakota or Durango.EDIT: Search Amazon for the following and read my review there for tips:Four Seasons 59946 High Side Service Port AdapterPeter

This is a nice kit, very complete but not the correct kit for some cars. If you take the dust cap off the high side port and look into it you will either see a valve stem sticking up like a tire valve, in which case this is probably your kit, or you will see what looks like a little rubber diaphragm. In that case this is not your kit. You probably need the:Four Seasons 26782 kitorFour Seasons 59946 High Side Service Port AdapterBoth of which are also sold by Amazon. The 26782 kit includes a few valve stems and caps plus the high side port adapter. You use one of the "regular" valve stems on the low side. If all you need is the high side part you can buy that separately. See my Amazon review on that separate part for more tips.I used the above high side port adapter on an '09 Suburban1500 V8, but it looks identical to the one in the 26782 kit which I used on my '01 Dodge Dakota 4X4  4.3L. Double check for compatibility to your application.Peter

A fascinating first hand account of the life of a slave in the waning days of plantation economy. Written by a slave at the time it offers insights often distorted by other narratives written after the fact. As much a interesting peek into the economics of plantation life as it is into the life of bondage and allure of freedom. If this sort of thing interests you in the least you need to pick up this book.
Supposed to clean out the memory cache, but only seems to work when you are on-line and getting ads. Try Clean Master instead for a better product and experience.

Should be instantly installed on every Kindle Fire. The Android OS buffers lots of the stuff you used recently and pretty soon it takes up most of  your useful memory. This cleans it all out without any drama or special knowledge.  I've tried others, but this one is the best.

I'm just starting to learn about repair and tuning of pianos.  This all time industry standard book not only offers theory but also practical advice that is very useful and straight forward. Well written and a joy to read and own. Buy the hardcover because it will be in your reference library for years to come!
Make sure this is the size liner you really want! It didn't fit any of my paint trays I had on hand, but other than that it was fine.

Simply didn't Work... the back check valve did not function, so the bulb won't pump fuel. Sometimes you have to hold these sots of bulbs in a particular orientation to get things started,a little ball has to fall into place by gravity until it is filled with fuel.... that didn't fix the problem with this one. I couldn't get the fuel pressure up enough to even start the engine. Swapped the bulb back to the original one (which is not low permeation and that is the reason it was getting replaced) and it started right up.

Bought these for orthotic support. Style and size were spot on, just as described, but for my foot the arch support was uncomfortably high. Running in shoes with too high an arch is what got me to have to wear something orthotic in the first place. I can't use these and had to return them.  If you are looking for good support with an exceptionally high arch these will work well for you.(Peter's wife)

Unfortunately this deodorant did not work well for me. It was applied after a shower when my underarms were dry. I did not exert myself or work up a sweat. Within a few hours after application I could smell slight b.o. As the day progressed, the odor became worse. I've used it multiple times with identical results.This deodorant has an odd smell (wet cardboard & mint) and a weird texture (damp sand). The application site is a little sore as this product is pretty abrasive. It's awfully expensive, but I was willing to try it because of the natural ingredients.I will not purchase again.

I can't believe no one has mentioned this soap smells like Moroccan Orange Blossom Water...which smells refreshing to me. If it is actually in this soap, Orange Blossom Water is great at hydrating, purifying and toning your skin. I cut a small piece and put it in my shaving bowl. It lathers quickly and allows my razor to glide over my skin. The shave I got was much more comfortable and close compared to other soaps, creams and gels I've used in the past. I did feel a slight burning sensation on my cheeks when I had to apply more for an additional pass with the razor, but it went away within minutes after I was done and didn't turn my cheeks red.

PROS- Made from durable 1000D nylon, very rigid, the last case you'll ever need for your iPad- iPad fits very well and is easy to insert/remove- Wake/sleep functions perfectly- Cutout around camera does not interfere with camera- Material on inside of cover is suede-like and soft- Film and glass screen protector compatible- Plenty of room around charging port for larger third party lightning cables- Material on outside of case provides great tactile feel- Elastic strap that secures cover is wide (16mm) and tight- The speaker cutouts are large and shouldn't hamper sound output- Reasonable price- Register online within 30 days of purchase for free warranty extensionMINOR ANNOYANCES (does not affect rating)- Cutout around camera not positioned perfectly- Side switch, volume and sleep/wake buttons slightly difficult to access- Interior of case looks slightly purplish in certain lighting environmentsOBSERVATIONS (does not affect rating)- Faint odor, think new pair of athletic shoes- Case is 21mm thick, by comparison the ESR Intelligent Series case is only 14mm and the Apple Smart Case is just over 8mm- Unlike the product photos, the camera cutout is round and the cutouts for the speakers are much larger- Velcro on flap that secures iPad is very strong- The elastic strap is probably the only part of this case that may fail (stretch out) after repeated use- Minimal protection on top and bottom right corners of iPad- iPad may suffer some damage if case falls/drops and elastic strap is NOT securing the cover- Toffee logo badge on front of case is large (24mm x 43mm)CONS- None

PROS- Lightweight, thin, rigid, minimalist design (only 14mm thick)- Leather deco adds a touch of class- iPad fits securely in plastic tray, but is easy to remove if necessary- No chemical odor- Wake/sleep functions perfectly- Cutout around camera does not interfere with camera- Material on inside of cover is very soft- Film or glass screen protectors should not be affected by the case- Plenty of room around charging port for larger third party lightning cables- Reasonable priceNEUTRAL- I imagine this case can provide basic protection only...don't expect your tablet to be unscathed if it sustains a fall from a few feet or higher on concrete, tile or other hard surface- Elastic strap that secures cover is narrow (5mm) and will probably fail (stretch out) after repeated use- It would be nice if there was some soft material in the plastic tray to ensure your iPad would never get scratched from the plastic...I'd even pay another $5 for this case if it had soft material in the plastic tray- Cover does not lay perfectly flat due to the crease in the front cover- Available colors are good, but I'd like to see moreCONS- Anti-slip clip is practically useless in keeping iPad from slipping...I prefer cases that have grooves to hold your tablet in landscape mode- Magnets built into cover are not strong enough to hold the cover closed, you must use the elastic strap- Polycarbonate shell is NOT rubberized like the description statesWorthy of a solid 3.5 star rating.

I thought this would be the perfect case for my iPad mini 2, but when it arrived there was a chunk missing from the front of the cover and a tear on the back of the cover between the camera and mic cut-outs. It wasn't damaged during shipping because the envelope and packaging were near perfect, so it was either previously used and sold as new or this one slipped past quality control.PROS- Plastic snap/clip to keep cover secured (it's easier to use the snap/clip than a strap that needs to be pulled/stretched over the entire side of the case)- Acceptable colors- Plastic tray that holds your iPad is lined with soft material to prevent scratching- Cut-outs practically perfectCONS- Case I received was not in perfect condition- Should cost no more than $20- Chemical odor (not super strong, but definitely noticeable)- Cover does not lay flat unless snapped shut- Surprisingly heavyAt any rate, I ended up returning the case because it should be perfect considering the price.

I've used Tech Armor screen protectors on various smartphones and tablets. Their products are sized just about perfect for the specific application and are durable. I've never had to remove/replace a Tech Armor screen protector due to scratches, bubbles or any other issues. Sure, the price may be a few dollars more than other brands, but I tend to be a brand loyalist (only if their products are good).Application of this screen protector on my iPad mini 2 was typical and took only a few minutes. The protector was applied in the bathroom after a steamy shower to keep unwanted dust at bay. I find this to be a very successful method.Unfortunately, I wiped my iPad with the included microfiber cloth and it left many small particles behind. Of course these small particles could only be seen after the protector was applied. I had to lift each corner of the protector and use the dust removal tape to catch those pesky particles. Usually I use a brand new MagicFiber cloth because the included microfiber cloths are junk. This time I forgot...oops, my bad.Now that the particles are gone, the protector looks great and should last a long time.Note that the issue with cheap microfiber cloths are not isolated to this brand.

I purchased three of these shirts when Amazon had them as a Lightning Deal. The deal price was about $5 more than what I paid in the past at my local department store. Unfortunately, my local department store has a very limited selection and none were in my size or preferred color.Compared to the same shirts I purchased in the past, these are a bit thinner and lighter. The quality of the stitching is good on the three I received. The fit is a bit relaxed, but not baggy.Overall, I am happy with these shirts, but would have liked to see the price about $5 less. These deserve 3.5 to 4 stars.

I've used many products and lotions that did one of two things...they either moisturized my skin and gave me breakouts or dried out my skin and kept the acne at bay. I've even used 100% Argan Oil and products that contained Argan Oil and none work as well as this brand.The oil absorbs quickly and easily if you don't use too much. It has cleared up my acne and dry skin issues. It doesn't smell bad (assuming its fresh). Another reviewer mentioned it has a rubberband-like smell...I can see what they are talking about, but to me it smells a bit more like a Band-Aid. It's not strong, distracting or even that noticeable after applying. Family members have not mentioned that I smell any worse than normal. lolSure it's a bit expensive, but the quality of this product is definitely worth it. I will NEVER buy any other brand of Argan Oil (unless of course the product changes in some way).For great looking skin, I trade off between this and the Shea Terra Nilotic Shea Butter. I always apply after shaving my face, showering or before bed.

I love fresh apricots. I love dried apricots. I love those German cookies with the apricot filling. I thought I would have loved this tea more.The Sri Lankan black tea in this product is good, but it's bitter (typical for black tea). A pinch of baking soda, honey and/or making sure the tea does not steep too long will help.If you are looking for a black tea that has a hint of apricot, then this is for you. If you like apricots like me and want a tea that is overpowered with apricot flavor, then this tea is not for you.The bag of tea I received wouldn't reseal so I had to empty the contents into two quart-sized mason jars.

Ever since I finished my last container of Alterra Blueberry Rooibos tea, I've been looking for a solid replacement. Many teas I tried were underwhelming with blueberry flavor, but not this one. This tea is very fragrant, flavorful and delicious. It doesn't really need all the other ingredients (apples, currants, raisins, hibiscus, elderberries, and cornflower petals) but they all seem to work well together.Nowhere does it mention if this tea is organic, which leads me to believe it is not. I wish it was organic.

I replaced both CV axles and control arms on my Caravan and thought this tool would be perfect for removing the tie rod end from the steering knuckle.This tool was way too small to even come close to working (needed at least another inch of spread). Plus the swivel tip was missing from the box upon opening. Maybe I received a used one or maybe someone at the factory forgot to include the swivel tip...it happens.I'm not sure if this tool is large enough to work on anything other than a small car. It did seem to be built well.As always, Amazon was great about the return process and issuing a refund.

I've been using FRAM air filters on my vehicles since I started driving. At every oil change, I blow any dirt and debris out of the filters and replace them at least once per year (sooner if they appear extremely dirty).The price of these filters is easy on my wallet and usually FRAM is offering some sort of rebate.

I have a very friendly hummingbird that frequents my feeders, hovers above my head and even eats out of my hand from a small test tube feeder. He is attracted to this color (as opposed to a basic red or pink) and always buzzes by me when I wear this shirt.The shirt is made well, but the material is thin compared to older shirts I've owned from FOTL and Hanes. Not really a big deal to me because I only wear this when I am "playing" with the hummingbird.I purchased in XL and it fit snug. With most tees I am too big for a large and too small for an XL.1/2 star taken away for the snug fit and 1/2 star taken away for the thin material.I wish it had a pocket. I would purchase again.

I purchased this cable to use with an external hard drive enclosure for my home entertainment system. The original cable that came with the enclosure was way to short. With almost an additional 5' of cable, I can place the hard drive in a convenient location.

I purchased these for my grandmother who uses incontinence products on a daily basis. She has tried off-brand products and complains they do not absorb as well.I ended up ordering these through Amazon because when she needed more, I was out of town and unable to take her to the store. The bulk package was a few cents cheaper per item than purchasing locally and she has been satisfied with the quality of the product.Some reviewers mentioned these were not as soft as the ones they were getting locally, but my grandmother noticed no difference. Around the house she uses Poise brand products (for light bladder leakage) and the Depend underwear for when she goes out (for maximum absorbency).

Before I knew about these Sewell banana plugs, I purchased about $150 worth of the Monster banana plugs that I am using with my sound system. I purchased these Sewell plugs for my parents sound system.Essentially, they are almost identical to the Monster plugs except that the Sewell plugs are a bit longer. I used 16ga wire with them and installation was a breeze. I am using 12ga with my Monster plugs.Not really much else to say except a set of these (enough plugs for a 5.1 ch system + right and left zone b) is a fraction of the price compared to the Monster plugs.

UPDATE:I just saw 1lb bags of this taffy at my local grocery store. $2.99 per bag. I can tell the difference between flavors, but wish they were stronger.Most of the pieces I've tried were fresh and soft, but a few were old and so hard it hurt to chew. Freshness aside, all the pieces were buttery smooth.One star was taken away for the freshness issue. I would purchase again to satisfy another taffy craving.Product was ordered from Casey Ann's.Here's a flavor guide for most of the ones that came in my 5 lb. bag...not sure how they can get away with stating "80 flavors of Gourmet Salt Water Taffy".Banana - Yellow with orange stripesLicorice - Black with white swirlWatermelon - Green with pink centerCough Medicine Cherry - Pink with pink stripesNeapolitan - Brown, white and pink stripedOrange Creme - Orange with white swirlRoot Beer - Brown with white centerRaspberry - Blue with blue stripesPeppermint - White with pink stripesGreen Apple - Green with green stripesCinnamon - Pink with white swirlCaramel - Brown with white swirlVanilla - WhiteGrape - Purple with purple stripesChocolate - Brown
This extractor works fine for taking out your typical sized screw, but don't bother using this on anything larger. I ended up breaking one of the extractors.

I purchased this for an elderly family member who wanted a TV in her bedroom. She isn't interested in HD cable, so the only programming this TV has seen is SD. The SD picture is pretty poor and text can be difficult to read. I did test this TV with my HD cable and the picture was about average compared to other TVs I've seen at BB & Wally-World.

About 2 years ago I visited a local office supply store and was shocked at how expensive the house brand scissors were, but I needed a pair and paid about $15. We have bought quite a few of these over the years. Some of which gave up the ghost because of quality reasons. This one feels like better quality in my hand. The grip has a large grip my big hand fits in and has a rubber like coating layer.Although it feels solid it is light for its size and balanced in my hand for ergonomic comfort. The next quality feature i notice is the 9.84 foot flat strap in stead of it being a round cord. This recoils better and is more reactive as a leash. The weight limit is for smaller and medium sized dogs under 44 lbs. The chrome plated swivel snap is a medium size and is easy to operate better than the dinky ones but is just the right size for the size dog it is recommended for.The push button lock feature allows for easy length adjustment, with one key button to relax, tighten the tether strap. This is an awesome Quad copter! I have several quad copters from nano to highly advanced. I have built a few as well. I say this because I want you to know my experience level. Our 10 year old grandson can fly this copter almost better than me. I know this has a 14 year old rating. But because it has 6-Axis Gyro Stabilization System it is a lot easier to manage than any other copter in this price range that I have seen.The 2.4GHz 4 channel technology allows good performance of about 30-50 yards with decent power for wind-resistant control.The copter comes with one battery, but you can purchase more. But actually you should allow the copter to cool between flights. The controller requires 6 "AA" which are not included. So remember those if giving as a gift because the person your giving it to will want to go out and fly it right away.The controller has all 6 axis controls as well as trim adjustments. The props are 2 1/4" long. The copter footprint including the blade guards is about 5 1/2" square.No camera means this is for the pure joy of flying and because of its light weight to power ratio you get that.Model Number: HS170Package Includes:1 x Quad Copter1 x 2.4G Remote Controller (1.5v AA batteries not included)1 x 3.7V 350mAh Li-Ion Battery4 x Aditional Rotating blade1 x USB charging cable1 x Screwdriver1 x User Manual I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true assessment.

In kinda a jewel design this light has a few features that are nice. First it is LED which conserves the included "AA" batteries. The warning lamp has a separate button to scroll through various modes such as solid red and many flashing sequences to your liking to make you visible.Its mount is adjustable for various sized post and is easily removed if needed. The light removes with out removing the mount so you can change batteries and remove it for security.The second button sprays a dot pattern by laser on the ground to mark your space. This feature of the tail light should be brighter. See my photo taken in a dark room on a dark floor. I don't think even on a dark night a auto would see it. But they certainly should see the rear tail light however.I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true assessment.

To me a 4th generation architectural wood worker and plant engineer, it amuses me to see the strides in technology to all the trades. This level is no exception. I really like this level. The maker knows my background and asked me to rate this level with no expectations, and provided me a sample. This baby is so sweet, they had to feel no fear I would like it as much as I do. If your in the trades let me appeal to your experience, and prove it to yourself.This digital torpedo level is very well suited to the machine work, steel fabrication industry, auto alignment, satellite dish,electricians, plumbers and any other precision trades. Very precise digital measurements + - five hundredths degrees (0.05).The magnetic base is strong, and linear V groove for pipe. The read out is very bright auto rotating display, as the digits are lit and not just a LCD back light, the large numbers jump out at you, even in daylight. Two arrows indicate if you are high or low on the angle - level, plumb, or alternate.  The display can be set to read in metric, feet / inches, degrees, or percent slope. All this can be read in absolute real earth level, or angles can be also set to find relative angles by taking any angle and setting a new alt zero angle to compare the difference. It has standard level and plumb bubbles as well.The display allows you to select an audible tone for level and plumb. There is also an audible tone conformation in the calibration process.Now I have to tell on my self..... I thought the audible level feature was defective on the level they gave me. I called the manufacture and they explained to me it is so accurate the device need to be absolutely level or plumb to sound. We confirmed the device was 100% by resetting the relative alt. angle on my desk top to zero and it fired on the tone! I think that speaks for its sensitivity and precision,...... and my duh!I can see the solid build the maker claims. Their claim is backed by a one year warranty and they brag a certified water and dust proof and operating range of -4F - 140F degrees. Power source is two "AA" batteries (included). It has a auto off and the display is LED, for battery conservation. The body is extruded aluminum with rugged bumpers to take the test of the tool bag and time.Once I had it in my hands and understood its features I could find no faults in the device, which coincidentally is also true about my dog and grandchildren......

In an effort to clean up and organize I have tried everything. If you have ever packed a cord organizer loom with several wires then need to remove one, only to have to repack whats left you will appreciate this set up. The insertion tool is what makes the process easy.Its still visible but much better than looking at all those cords in disarray. I like this because if you need to pull a cord, or two out or add one, along the way you can.Be sure to gather all you cords up straight in one line. Open the clam shell on the insertion tool and insert the wires and allow it to close. Load the pointed lead in the tube, as the photos show in the description. Push it in from the up from the direction you are going. As you go continue pushing and try to resist pulling the down side because you will squeeze the tube and tighten the against the cord. If you can avoid squeezing its ok to pull but pushing does me better. Another tip is keep the cords straight and in line, no twists. The hardest part is getting it started but once you get the feeder all the way inside its smooth sailing.This tube is 60" long & just over an inch diameter.I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true assessment.
