For my kit copter This is a layer of shock protection for the smaller control moduals. I think it could be used for a FPV camera as well. The top plate is 2" X 3". You would attach this to your Copter body with bolts, zip ties.ect. Included are two 3M double sided  sticker rounds to attach the control modual.The plates are a fiber glass / carbon fiber type material with various mounting options It is suited for different open source CC3D flight controller, Naze32, Mini APM or other mini flight control.From OpenPilot:OpenPilot is an Open Source project aimed at providing the community with low-cost but powerful stabilization and autopilot platforms. OpenPilot’s strength is in the community that has developed, where individuals contribute their time, effort and skills so all can benefit. As a non-profit open source program, OpenPilot aims to bring this technology down in price to make it more affordable to deploy.Target applications of OpenPilot developments include civil and humanitarian uses where search and rescue capabilities afforded by guided aerial platforms can be of immense value; academic uses for research; stabilized platforms for aerial photography; as well as DIY hobbyists looking to do a little flying and have some fun. The OpenPilot platform includes support for multirotors, helicopters and fixed wing aircraft. However, the OpenPilot platform is flexible and can be adapted to diverse needs such as unique aircraft, marine, and ground vehicles. Being an Open Source project, the code is freely available for modification to suit unique needs.OpenPilot is an ideal platform for researchers and hobbyists working on aerial robotics or other mobile vehicular platforms where stabilization and guidance are required. OpenPilot brings the cost down to reasonable prices so people can focus on developing and refining applications rather than paying the extremely high prices of most commercial offerings, or having to do ‘from the ground up’ hardware development.I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true opinion. But a interesting project. I have a, Nano copter, a Syma 9 and a DJI P 3 pro as well a quad & hex DIY copter, as work in progress.

This is a viewing monitor mirror that attaches with a couple spring clamps shown in my photos, onto and over your existing rear view mirror. The instructions (see my photo) are very poor and basically leave you to figure it out on your own. When the monitor goes on approximately 1/3 of your rear view mirror is replaced by what the camera view is. Both sides are still viewable. I would prefer a separate monitor that didn't share the mirror.It has a pig tail that have three different colored connections coming from it. Red is 12 volt DC 2.1 x 5.5mm DC Power Pigtail Female that is connected to a an included 2.1 x 5.5mm DC Power Pigtail male plug. That has two wires red for a 12 volt DC power source & black for a ground source. The idea is because it has an auto on feature that is activated by sensing power on, that you locate your back up light circuit and connect to that hot lead. The black can go to any ground source. There is no on/off control accessible. It would be possible to install a switch in the 12 volt constant power connection so you can choose to use it at your preference.The other two plugs one white, & one yellow are RCA AV plugs for cameras or DVD connection in two channels. In the case of two inputs you would need a AV selector switch.The monitors Resolution is a fair 480W * RGB * 272H and pulls, 3W of power consumption.The weight is 13.7 ounces and may be to much weight to keep held up by your existing mirror unless you can adjust the tension on it. The grip range for the mirror is 2 1/8" x 3" and both clips are spaced 4" apart. The menu buttons, control the brightness/contrast/hue/language, and are only accessible by removing the mirror. The monitor mirror is 11 3/8" x 3", the actual viewing area is a 4.3 inch diagonally TFT 16:9 screen.I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true assessment.

It is a prudent practice to be very protective of your blades. They are the first lifeline to the aerodynamics of your copter. they are the control surfaces as well as propulsion inherent in copters. If you lose a prop in a fixed wing aircraft they control surfaces will likely still work and you can glide it down in a somewhat controlled manner. The are the wings as in rotor wing. So why take chances dropping a expensive copter because one of the rotor wings failed? This is not only a damage control issue but a safety concern. When this happens the copter cannot be controlled and it will most probably damage your equipment, and your pride it can fly way out of control and cause injury or property damage. It would be wise to inspect your blades prior to every flight closely. Never fly with a blade that had any damage what so ever, even a small chip can run under the stress of flight. DJI blades are less prone to that because of the engineered material used to manufacture them.The problem is with carbon fiber is it is great for some purposes. But I do not like them for props because they are stiff and un forgiving. They have glass like properties and when stressed to a point they just break causing a complete failure. I have had it happen. My original thought was these are stronger, but was a misconception. Carbon fiber is very strong but it needs to maintain its rigid shape. If not extreme failure occurs. Under the stress of blades I have found it to much. the stock props that come with your P3 spring better and are much more forgiving to sudden acceleration. Strong doesn't always mean unbreakable.An estimated $1.7 trillion worth of knockoffs, counterfeit and imitation products are sold to consumers every year. While it can be difficult to spot the fakes, many counterfeiters are selling products the manufacturers never made in the first place. You can see them on sale at Amazon, Taobao, a China-based website that's one of the biggest online marketplaces in the world, and on eBay. Knock offs are often made and sold before DJI can identify them.While identifying a fake product can be difficult, to counter the counterfeiters, there are several steps shoppers should take before buying online:Step 1:Buy directly from the manufacturer or an authorized dealer to make sure you're getting the real thing. I can only assume Amazon has a way to verify this, but sometimes and especially in our modern day hacker environment things can slip between the cracks before they are found.Step 2:If you look at your original DJI props you will see the DJI logo. I have seen knockoffs with this logo however. DJI props are packaged and labeled.Step 3:Two more markings are the 2 prop directions and the part number with the black saying 9450cw and the silver tip saying 9450. these are oriented with the top of the numbers on the top of the blade.Step 4:DJI blades come fairly well balanced. if yours are obviously not you probably have a knock off.Step 5:DJI props do not have metal thread inserts. If there are present they are defiantly knock offs and can cause damage to your copter. Two issues can occur. If the inserts are cheap and the threads are not precisely cut or if a thin layer of plastic is coated in them (a practice to cover up the metal to deceive you. They can lock so tight you will break the motor shaft or like in my case the balancing rod off in the attempt to remove them. The next issue is the metal inserts by some manufactures can be so loose they can un spin themselves while air braking. DJI blades are engineered to stay in place. That is why I am skepticalStep 6:DJI blades are ever so slightly flexible. If yours are rigid they are knock offs. They can be so stiff they are brittle and break in flight as well. This can be an issue with carbon fiber props as well.Step 7:If the price is too good the prop is probably not. Beware of blades that are priced below way below the manufactures suggested retail price are often knock offs.Step 8;Buy trusted blades by buying those proven by other sources. If a reviewer has spotted a knock off beware! Again I can only assume Amazon has a way to verify the authenticity, but sometimes and especially in our modern day hacker environment things can slip between the cracks before they are found. I gave this set a 2 star until I can tell otherwise, but one reviewer claims to has spotted them as fakes. That isn't totally reliable however because they could be wrong, or a unethical plant from another seller trying to degrade the credibility of this one to steer you towards their knock off or site. As a top reviewer I just can't say at this point its even OK. As a top reviewer I have seen all the nasty tricks and I checked up on the profile of the one negative review of a blade. All the other reviews were very positive but hers was bringing notice by saying some of the identifiable markings were inconsistent with a OEM product. But the reviewers profile shows only one review, 6 activities and Reviewer ranking: #32,829,985. The advantage with Amazon is if you receive a product with a suspicious blade you can return it in a timely manner. But do us all a favor and make Amazon aware of the fake so they can look into the sellers credibility.Step 9:Recently DJI has been surrounding the center of the blade with shrink wrap covering the threads. This is new so older versions may not have this.Step 10:Check against original blades for any detection such as size difference, material color, anything different.Step 11:Check the manufactures web site to confirm they make that model in construction and cosmetics. If they don't it is obviously a knock off.These blades offered seem to pass the test until seen otherwise. I have only seen three reviews so far and they point the right direction for OEM. I also am skeptical about aftermarket manufactures that offer aftermarket "compatible or comparable" blades. I am unaware of any endorsed products by DJI. But if one is out there how do you confirm a true endorsement? I had a qualified dealer suggest a blade design that has a through hole (required a bushing and a pointed nut holds it in place). I'm just not willing to bite on that at this point. On the Phantom Pilot forum I haven't read any OEM failures outside of blade strikes but have from non DJI and knock offs. The steps are guidelines and I hope they are helpful to your buying decision.

This bit has three cutting surfaces and solid backing. This improves the efficiency  of standard 2-flute bits by 50% because the third flute increases the cut rate allowing more cuts per inch, reducing the work load on each flute. This results in longer bit life, smoother cuts, less if any burning. An other thing I like is the face and side pitch making this a spiral up cut bit for smoother cuts & sawdust & heat ejecting.The half inch shank is much more solid that a 1/4" shank. The bearing is quality and should give reasonable service The company whom manufactures is a world leader in the commercial blade & bit tooling industry.The cutter head is set by the bearing to cut a square 3/8" wide x just under 1/2" deep rabbit.I am an consultant to wood products factories, but using this bit at my home shop, on some oak screen doors. I will not have to worry about the side cut because it is already set by the bearing used at the factory. But I will need to adjust my depth to 3/8" + 20 + - mill (my screen thickness). This way I can mill out some 3/8" x 3/8" screen molding and by having a proper adjusted depth i can get the screen molding flush to the frame with the 20 mil. screen panel.

This is a simple replacement because i altered the original one on my Bosch Pr20 laminate router. My alternation was to get a deeper cut in the corners of  a 3/8" rabbit with a half inch mortise bit. That way I can use a square corner chisel to clean the corners for a set of oak screen doors I am building.This one comes in just like the original factory guide in every aspect.

Buying these as a value purchase. I recently went through a labeling phase at the shop for labeling all our drawers so we could see at a glance what was in them but also so the items get replaced in the proper order. Really that is what labels are all about (Organization). I seem to use the 1/2" white background most, so buying two it is a lower unit cost. These have always printed well, clear and take reasonable ware. I'm printing on a Brother PT-2730.

I am a mark for a pocket picker. This bag will hide these valuables in a non conventional place secured by zippered pockets. You can wear the bag out of sight under your shirt, or over your shirt. Now I have one place that is secure to put the items I need quick access to.To be honest when the folks at Zero Grid sent me a sample for an un biased review, I had concerns of comfort, practicability, Security, and quality. Those concerns are proven positive in my mind. I don't expect you to take it at that so I will point out the features this bag has.The strap is soft and adjustable in length, and weight is very light. The buckle is hidden in side a side pocket to prevent tampering. The back side (I have pictured) is made of a very comfortable ultra-soft breathable mesh. I put it on my bare belly & the mesh that holds the bag slightly out from is soft and allows ventilation between it and your body. The rest of it is made with quality anti-tearing, durable, waterproof, lightweight, nylon. An embedded RFID barrier material in the nylon shell protects your personal information of electronic identity on the passport and credit cards, protecting them from a cyber pickpocket.Also made with water-resistant, 210D Rip-stop Nylon with double stitched reinforced seams. Moisture-wicking back panel with breathable poly cotton mesh to eliminate moisture and uncomfortable heat. Fully adjustable, One Size Fits All. Suitable for Men and Women waste size 44" and under.The wallet can hold your passport, cash, credit cards, money, jewelry, cell phone and other valuables. Confirming the 2 pockets (three zipper pockets; a pocket located between the back breathable mesh and nylon. Inside the rear main pocket are two open top organiser pockets, and a loop with a small carabiner clip, to secure keys.If your reading this you must be aware of the way hackers can get into your information that is contained on your cards and Passport from feet away. These packets have a proven protective coating that blocks the hackers signal.I tested it with my TV remote in side which is RF as well. My TV wold not turn on when the button was pressed. I went to Home depot and asked the manager to allow me to test it on their security devices. He gave me a active strip and we tested with ans without using the sleeve. Now he is concerned....The sleeve blocked the signal! This device or my demonstration is not meant to advert shoplifting and the manager told me the sensors are just one of many levels of security.The protective coating scrambles the frequency and foils hackers attempts to get your ID. They will just move on to some easier target.I received only a free sample for evaluation and unbiased review - It’s just my true opinion.

I needed a few sets because I need to replace my wicks, and it was just about the same price for this combo as for 1 wick. These are factory parts and the only ones I will use. I removed the cotton packing with some rheostats.  This exposes the inner lighter and the old wick is still in place and wrapped around the flint chamber. I have often taken a good wick and just reversed it after cutting off the old burned end. If your lighter has sat for a long period it may be caramelized. If thats the case your best to replace. I clean the hole out with a toothpick. You need to make a clean pass and remove ant obstructions that would inhibit you from passing the wick through the hole because the hole is so deep. The wick has some wire that helps keep it stiff but sometimes thats not much rigid-ability. You can try from either end of the lighter, but I prefer the upper end because the fluid chamber is so deep. In that event I still trim the end with a point and get it started then reach in the other side to pull it through. Wrap it around the flint chamber an bring it up the side. Repack in reverse order. I like to replace the flint at this point Fill with fluid and let set for several minutes to allow for absorption. You don't want to burn a dry wick because it will just burn up.My dad told me if you send your Zippo lighter back to the factory they will rebuild it free.From Zippo:All you need to do is provide your Zippo pocket lighter toour distributor. You will bear the cost of any expensesincurred in making a claim under this Guarantee, includingthe cost of shipping the lighter to our distributor. Thelighter will be repaired and returned to you, free of furthercharges.

Wow!  Get ready for a great new perspective to WWII and D Day specifically. This is a series of interviews of various German soldiers on the Atlantic front. The first stunning fact is they could not believe the British and Americans wanted to attack them when the real war was with the Russians. Additionally they felt like the French people supported them and didn't want the destruction. They were DEFENDING the French and the United Europe!  There was acknowledgement that not all were in favor but a specific number were. What a statement here about the Nazi propaganda and there is discussion of this.  When soldiers are encountered they are completely surprised by their resolve and anger. It is truly a fascinating read. It's also interesting to hear of their defenses: how in some cases it was very good and some, not good at all.The most SHOCKING statement was their amazement at the Ally weapons. Due to limited resources, German troops always traveled with horses to transport equipment and save fuel. The fact that the Allies had no horses at all bewildered them.The fighting here is intense and tales of the embardment from the other side shows that our weaponry and air superiority completely overwhelmed the Germans.  But listening to some of these men describe the horrific discussion of death and body destruction by flame throwers and incendiary bombs is just tragic.Like WWII literature?  Ready for a new/different perspective?  Read this very enlightening book!

Having read the first book which I STRONGLY RECOMMEND, I bought this as a companion And was not disappointed!  More stories of surprise at the ferocity of the Allied soldiers, Allied weaponry superiority and aircraft. This book touches on other individual stories of interest. For example, where was the The famous Luftwaffe and superior technology of weapons?  Well that's discussed here. A pilot describes his flight but on orders not to engage, but reconnaissance only. He also discusses their lack of spare parts and how the constant bombardment had severely limited their airports and flying capabilities.Another fascinating story is a tale of a superior weapon, not an atomic, but a very destructive kerosine-like bomb that completely destroyed a wide range of land. Unfortunately, weather conditions had to be ideal and even then the soldiers using it would probably be killed. So what happens when they attempted to use it which they felt could have turned the initial tide of the D Day incursion? Well, it's here in this book and is absolutely fascinating. Additionally it is fascinating why the soldier never spoke of this after the war.Another theme of this book is the Russian deserters who were now fighting for the Germans to protect France against the Allies. What happened to them and why is nothing really written of this?Continually mentioned by the soldiers is the previous Dieppe Attack which evidently was an incursion two years earlier that was turned back. The Germans felt this was another bluff, particularly since it wasn't at a port where they felt the Allies needed to bring in all the equipment necessary for the war. There has always been much talk of the enormity of the invasion. This book articulates this better and to a higher degree than any I have read.A final theme of this book is the German/French relationships and the many romances and babies that were born. Great historical exploration from a first hand account which I found fascinating!Like WWII literature?  Ready for a new/different perspective?  Read this very enlightening book!

Beautiful, handy, and professional. As a restaurant owner I gave this to one of our leading servers as a gift knowing it would be used constantly and projects a very professional appearance. Some might look at this like a basic item. But use it constantly in your job and the nuance of a good tool will be shown. This passes the test with flying colors and I strongly recommend.

Yes I loved it!  I'm a regional investment banker but my product does not involve collaboration with other firms which this book seems to highlight many questionable acts when working WITH other firms. What this book does is show what happens when YOUNG men are given power and money and the play field to enjoy.Yes, there is debauchery, some funny, some disgusting. Yes, he talks about the business in quite some detail. This is a fast and enjoyable read. Now, will it be a bookend to Liars Poker?  ABSOLUTELY NOT!Buy and enjoy, or don't enjoy. But don't fall for the trap of throwing him under the bus without sampling the product.

An American Sex columnist living in London writes of her aggressive male inspired sex life with humor but also a good amount of romantic tales as she falls from bed to bed. I loved it: witty, funny, topical. But then something happens. The book goes on and on with much repetition and nothing really to add as the book slowly lumbers to a finish. I LOVED 2/3 of this book and rate it fairly highly. Still, at a certain point, enough is enough. Don't write to have a certain page length. Write for quality. Still, I wouldn't pass as some parts are very good.
Really disappointed. Don't fit well. Too loose and don't stay up while walking which all other types do. Also, really not that cold. I would pass.

I'm trying to read shorts as I love to read but have limited time. A successful businessman billionaire meets a cut but not stunning girl and is instantly infatuated and treats her like a queen. Sound like something a romantic girl might write?  Exactly, well it's short and to the point but nothing of substance. I'd take a pass.

Short but convoluted as a long lost brother who had a moment as a Hollywood player disappears to Mexico with no interest in family connecting to him. They find him. But was it worth it?  The good news: it's short. Otherwise, I can't say I connected with this tale and cannot recommend.

Written in sections of interest with comments by virtually all of the players in the movie, this is a great summation of creating magic on film. It's always intended but rarely happens and in this case, it definitely did. Alicia Silverstone was so cute and perfect for this part. I remain amazed that she wasn't a star of Julia Roberts' level of fame.  And of course my personal favorite Stacey Dash to this day remains absolutely stunning should also have had much greater fame.But lightening struck here by a great director and a wide eyed cast most getting their first taste of fame and no idea how this would make them famous for life. If you like/loved the movie, READ THIS BOOK!  It's a great revisit and will have you smiling for days till you finish.

A very good short story of a sibling who wonders about the picture of her brother she never met and his prom date who she has no idea who she is or how to connect with. But in the age of the Internet it's not as hard as you think. So this book is the research of her brother's history (not overly lengthened) and her research to find his date and receive personal information to better know her brother. An incredibly well told tale with a great story. Looking for a fast but satisfying read?  This is it.

I'm a basketball fanatic and Iverson is an iconic performer.  Additionally, I live in Memphis and we signed him late in his career and he lasted only two months and tore the team and coach apart.  Not to mention the stories I heard about problems at his hotel with SERIOUS marijuana smoking.  NOTHING IN THIS BOOK WILL CHANGE YOUR MIND!  It's a sad story.  His early incarceration (not warranted IMO), his Georgetown career, his pro career, and his drinking and bad habits that traumatizes his family.  This is very sad and frankly, entirely too long.  I cannot rate this book highly as there are no new stories here and it is told slowly and not worth the time.  I would pass.  You know the story already.

I want a fairly short, fast and exciting read in the few fiction books I read.  this book was offered to review and based upon my reviews of Hollywood stories I thought I would give it a try.  I was not disappointed.  a very fast read but great action throughout:  beautiful women, a smart aleck Private detective and some bad guys easy to hate.  buy this book for entertainment and you will be pleased.
I have cooks in Mexico that prepare the oranges and limes the old fashion way.  This saves time, better yield per lime, and is much easier to use.  Glad I added this.
Love this!  Bigger dial, easy to track right on.  Very pleased.

I'm throwing away my "neck hanging" guitar stands.  I like this one very much HOWEVER, I have another one that has a slightly better device to fold up when not in use.  This one has a hinge that is a little sticky and not as professional that I did not like as much.  Still, performs its primary job very well.

Why have I never seen this before.  It has the quick turner to speed up changing strings but I always use pliers to clip the strings and frankly, a lot of times I just don't.  Now with this device always right by my guitars, I've not got clean, professional looking guitars.  And as bad as I play, anything that makes me look better is good.
Good short story.  Sometimes you just don't want a book and since I read only nonfiction, this was a good break.  Not serious stuff here but mildly entertaining.

Well, the reviews were correct:  this is the best device on the market.  I'm an active tennis player squeaking out the last years on my knees with doctor advice to ice consistently and I do.  I keep ice knee devices and I also keep the cold pack that does not require ice depending if I am at home or away.  Normally I play tennis very early, change to work clothes at a club and can't take the cold pack devices.  this is what I use as I can fill with ice at the club and I couldn't be more pleased.A couple of things to discuss:  the ice bag is rubber but very thin.  I previously had an ice bag with a lining.  I worry about this bag sweating on my clothes.  Not a problem yet but I am watching for this.  My previous ice bag wore out and started leaking on my clothes.  Second, the connection of the rubber to the mouth of the device makes me worry if the very thin rubber will eventually tear.  If it does, I'll change my review.Another statement:  I am normal size that used a medium Moji knee icer.  this device has only one size and it is actually a little small for me.  I need to adjust my ice in the bag down which I think will help this problem.  I will add again my previous device, while not anywhere as professional as this, had a better ice bag with double lining.  Still, I can't complain thus far and am very pleased.  I use four times a week and one week in, it's better than before.

My new go to device.  This is my first Bluetooth headset and that change alone was worth it.  Second, the fit to your ears is the best I've EVER had.  I currently have three other sets and I only want to use these as the fit is perfect and for ear plugs vs. the large devices, the noise filter is exceptional!  also, note the color.  I have so many black devices.  this is easy to see in the bag, and easy to see if you are about to leave in the rental car.  Big positive for me.What are the potential negatives?  I had a bad connection one time knocking me off.  If this comes up again I'll change my review. Second, remember, since it is Bluetooth, it works off a battery so be prepared to keep these powered up for the long trips.  No problem noted but I take long trips to the West Coast and then need to make sure it works for phone calls.I couldn't be more pleased.  Buy this device and I think you will also.

As an Owner of three restaurants I'm always looking for good advice. This is a fine book with 20 owners telling their story. While there are good tidbits, I would have preferred more nuts and bolts by one writer. Some of the stories are good, some not applicable. Overall not a bad read but not great either.
Love this new Tuner. Bigger face and more accurate. Excellent price but don't be fooled: a quality device that does its job.
Well, when you don't change your 12 string guitar strings for 10 years everything sounds better. These did the job and sound great.

This novella starts very slow. It seems to want to demonstrate the tedious nature of Vietnam fighting: boredom followed by MASSIVE Adrenaline rush. But the payoff of the novella is very worth the read. You will finish this in one plane ride. Stick with it as the second half of the book is exceptional!Allen Tiffany attempts to quickly describe his Vietnam experience through the most seminal occurrence: his training of a new "cherry" who looks at the war from a different perspective and the massive war event that occurs. Reading the "action event" I was so astounded I had to challenge whether it was real or fiction, particularly as it describes future reunions.Unfortunately the buildup is too slow for me to rate a 5 but I do strongly recommend this short book.

I read to be entertained. But sometimes you need to read to learn. This book details the date/acquaintance rapes happening on the U of Montana campus, many involving football players. What separates this book from this exceptional author is the great research and storytelling of various incidences and their entirely different outcomes which allows the reader to have a greater knowledge of this subject. And more of us should read both sides of an issue to understand. This book details the hard job of law enforcement and prosecutors, the damage to the victims, the misunderstanding of the men who commit these crimes and infractions and sadly, the fans who want to ignore that their football players may be bad people.One of the top books of the year where you will learn and be entertained while learning. But I caution that some parts will bring you to tears and anger at what happens to some of these women that did not deserve these violent acts.

As a restaurant owner I'm reading more books about the business but still trying to be entertained and this book clearly did that. You will get great setup information of the roles of the different players in the restaurant industry and great descriptions of how this service can make a difference. This is what I came for.But what makes this book entertaining is this "almost rock star" who enjoys his high paying bartender job which turns in to a top waiter job at the Polo Lounge in Beverly Hills. Or at least that's my guess. I've made stops there but always for drinks, never for dinner which I will definitely do soon due to this great description. Ok, if you want to hear about stars, who is good to wait on, who is not, this is the book for you. He has personal favorites and does a good job in great detail showing how so many stars are really good people and, some who are not.  And I must admit, some of the bills for dinner absolutely astounded me. I've paid $4,000 dinner bills for business. But I cannot imagine taking a family of four to dinner and a bill of $8,000!  I think I'll pass on the expensive $4,000 bottles of wineBut what is very compelling is the pride in this distinguished restaurant which eventually turns in to disdain as he views their foreign corporate owner as destroying  their previously great culture. How this plays out and how well he conveys this in words is exceptional and I thoroughly enjoyed and recommend. Favorite part?  The author looks up to one professional waiter who after hours turns in to a sexual/drug enduced deviant. Well, at least in a good way and these stories are very entertaining.I strongly recommend this book.

An interesting, fast read of dating women on vacation from China. As Anglo men, knowledge of Chinese and a love for women, these guys attract women and describe in detail all of their movements thru late night disco, food and all activities. And that was some of the problems of the book. It becomes very mundane as he tries to weave their special talents for meeting women but do I need to now every minute of your day?It has many enjoyable parts and probably will be more appealing to others younger than me or with particular interest in China and Thailand. But part of writing is presenting a compelling story concisely with great character build. This didn't build the characters as well as I would like and was too detailed. Still, it was enjoyable and I wouldn't discourage anyone from reading, just not one of my favorites. I really would prefer to give this a 3 1/2.

Great story that many will think is similar to the Wolf of Wall Street, a book I did not like due to the author's writing ego. Mark Yagalla does not have that ego and recognizes his crimes and feels very badly as he effectively stole money from his investors to fund a lavish lifestyle.Some highlights in this very interesting and very fast read:His business start - the book does a great job of showing a young bright guy who also fortunately met influences that allowed him to expand his contacts and business. Many of these were conservative people like the Fulton Bank Director, a bank I have worked with, have great respect for and am a shareholder. Just another investor duped although he did remove his money. But in addition to the business start he also met a person who fed his insatiable appetite for high end call girls.His Ponzi Scheme and business practices - the interesting part here is his establishing relationships to become an early investor for the penny stock companies and how he was making money getting out before the losers. This is simply and quickly laid out and is interesting.His Love of Beautiful Women even if they were all generally Call Girls -  starting small and getting big the amount of money he was paying was unbelievable and he was clearly addicted to this and could not stop. Some of the names are familiar like his relationship with Michelle Braun, the madam who later supplied Tiger Woods. This addiction eventually feeds his lavish lifestyle to impress the women including Gulfstream planes and helicopters.  But read these chapters and look up the girls in Google. Very, very beautiful women that he idolized or disclosed their money grabbing weaknesses.Overall I could not recommend this book higher if you have interest in Wall Street business and the love of beautiful, but greedy women.

The autobiographical story of the fatherly college professor who thinks he is going to Argentina to meet the famous model when in fact he is being duped in to carrying drugs. And was he ever duped and fell for it at every turn. This is a short read of the story from his side and is not worth your time. Yes, it's short. And that's about the only positive to this clinically written tale: the Internet courtship, the arrest, the trial, the illness and finally he's released. But it ends so quickly with no conclusions that it is totally unsatisfying. I would pass this read.

Engaging historical perspective that while dragging and repetitive at times, has so much information that frames our world now, and generally NOT in a positive way, that it should be required reading. Yes, I was aware of the name as a 61 yr old. But I was not aware of their roles. Not aware of brothers. Not aware of Allen's involvement in the CIA. Nor aware of their careers at the massive law firm of Cromwell and Sullivan.But reading this was stunning and made me angry. George Dulles was more responsible for the Cold War than anyone. And documents after the war shows the Soviets were not near as devious as we give them credit for. But our fear painted a view of a hidden enemy bent on our destruction. We missed opportunities with Khrushchev. More importantly and totally unaware to me, these guys we responsible for government overthrows and were actively involved in the 1950s with alienating Vietnam leading eventually to a horrible loss of civilian lives and more importantly to me, American soldiers who were led in to the wrong war at the wrong time.But let us not forget the documented CIA overthrows of Congo, Guatemala,Indonesia and Iran. Is this America? Well, in the post WWII world, we lost our values and stooped to such tactics.There are stories here America doesn't study and they should. How the interface of commerce, politics and war can lead to disastrous results that haunt us today.Read this book to learn. Not all of it will make you proud. Yes, I learned. And yes, I'm angry and ashamed.

Elvis' last girlfriend tells her story. And it's a very brief story since they dated under one year with Elvis proposing. Her honesty comes through loud and clear so if you want to know a lot about Elvis, read this book!!  And he's better and more normal than more people will imagine. And she doesn't cut corners. Yes, he shot out a TV. Yes, he gets irritated and has fits. But generally he is an incredibly nice guy seeking spiritual awareness.Probably the most interesting part of the book to me is her relationship with Lisa Marie and how normal Lisa seems. In the back of the book is a fabulous picture of her as a kid with full smile. It was great to get an inside look at her early life. Priscilla is also positively mentioned.This is not a long book. It is not here to settle any scores. It is here to tell what her life was like with Elvis and paints a great picture of him. I encourage this book for any Elvis fan or just those who are curious.
I can't tell you how it tastes. I can only tell you that my dog loved it.  Kept her occupied and she loved the test as she asked for more. Good product.
I don't like antiperspirant. I like a nice smell in a stick deodorant. This hits the spot!  It's perfect. It has a pleasant smell and not overpowering. My new deodorant!

I never use a phone case. I want a phone to be as small as possible to fit in my pocket. But what if I could do away with a billfold? I already carry just a clip with money and credit cards and drivers license but it is not really efficient.This device works!  Yes, the phone case with slot for 3 credit cards makes it bigger. But not so much that you can't still carry it in your pocket. But now I can have my Drivers License more available for use at the airport since I I travel a lot, and still two more credit cards. For now I am just carrying my money in my pocket. Basically I've removed a device and I love it. This is one of the most functional devices I have ever used!  Now, there is a downside. I cannot ever lose my phone since it has really important things attached to it. But for now, this has not been a problem. If you like a phone case, why not kill two birds with one stone. Make traveling lighter and more convenient.

This roller works very well. It is smaller in diameter than what I normally use and I think I prefer the larger rollers. HOWEVER, this is absolute GREAT for taking on huge road with you in a small suitcase. I was amazed how well it fit in my suitcase. A good product and worth the money.

I recently had the Jawbone block which I lost. This is a great replacement: good pricing, good sound, easy pairing. Small and light enough to pack in the suitcase if you want good sound. I don't use it that way. I use it in my house and can take it from room to room. I also take it to my massage therapist to have my own music without being forced to wear headsets or have their inferior speakers. I did do a listening test to a friend's Jawbone. While I thought the sounds were very similar, my friend felt the Jawbone had a better bass sound. Overall, I am very pleased with this device.

I have an older IPad and an IPhone5, both have different hookups. So now going to a hotel room you are not as likely to have a stereo system as the common device fits only IPhone4. This device is so small that I easily put it in my suitcase and have good music in my room. Now, it has it's limitation: being so small means it can't be a high powered speaker, but still adequate. Overall, I am very pleased fort what I use this for.

Sounds simple, 15 short stories in Spanish challenging your vocabulary and forcing you to exit your Grammer books and read what is actually the language. The story is followed by a Q&A of the story to challenge your reading comprehension but more importantly, a section for highlighted language lessons. This part is the best. For years I've been trying to literally translate sentences that don't literally translate. This gives great lessons to clarify these sentences.I can't overstate how good this exercise is in learning to be more fluent in another language. I only hope they have more books like this as it really helped my comprehension.

Fast, furious, one day read on playing at the bottom end of the NFL food chain. If you like pro football, BUY THIS BOOK AND READ IT!  It's that good. I don't even remember what made me purchase this and I didn't read it immediately but it was a great find. This is of a D III player who with some assistance from Bill Walsh manages to find his way into the league. BARELY. A short stint with the 49ers leads to a career at Denver under Mike Shanahan. The strength of this book is the DETAILED description of the life, injuries and feelings of a lower level NFL pro including a stint in NFL Europe.I'll skip much of the story for you to enjoy yourself. But let me reiterate that in addition to being very impressed with his descriptive writing and detailed account of pro football this is a fast and fun read!

This is a solid book. Leigh Steinberg revolutionized the sports agency business. From the mid 70s with his first client UCal QB Steve Bartkowski who was only slightly younger than Steinberg to the 2000s, Leigh Steinberg was the Go To Guy. Agent who controlled the QB position. This book is very interesting in providing the backstory to his rise to fame, his philosophy on running the agency, his many relationships with athletes and specific stories of player negotiations. He eventually transcended player representation bridging into multimedia and ownership.But this book is at it's best just recounting how he got in the business, how he grew it and how he negotiated it. I had some dealings with his agency. As a CPA I interviewed to handle the finances for Walter Lewis, an AL QB who signed a million dollar contract with the USFL in 1983. We were selected by Steinberg's partner, Mike Sullivan. I specifically remember a year later when Mike called announcing he was leaving. That period is covered well in this book and needless to say, Steinberg felt mistreated by his former partner. Mike was a real pro I enjoyed meeting but I had no involvement with Leigh.If you are interested in pro football and the agency business, grab this book and read it!  But there is another part of Leigh's story and there have been newspaper articles that go into further detail of his alcoholism which broke Steinberg completely and ruined his reputation with many clients. But as you would expect of a marketing person, that is somewhat glossed over. Yes, it's covered. But relatively quickly and always with an angle to make him the hero. That's my only complaint with this book. Steinberg is a shell of his former self in the agency business but you would never know it form reading this. In some respects I wonder if he wrote this because he needs any money he can get.Irrespective to my ramblings and guesses, I thoroughly enjoyed this read and with the caveats mentioned can definitely recommend it.

I love the Axe sprays even though I don't like using sprays. Their's are the best smelling however when you move to sticks, their products have only very faint smells when I prefer more.  Additionally this product is the typical white antiperspirant which goes on dry and I don't prefer that feeling. I have no problems with the faint smell and I will use all of this but I wish I had received the Non antiperspirant as I enjoy it more.  Overall a good product that keeps you dry with a faint clean smell.

Minecraft, to anyone not familiar with the franchise, is a simple yet increasingly sophisticated building game that has been equated to Legos for adults.  Players of all ages can learn and hone several skills including architecture, engineering, resource management, and broaden their overall creativity.  However, while the game is easy to pick up, it can be difficult to master, especially the red stone mechanics that gives Minecraft more challenge.There are a LOT of guides out there that claim to help assist the reader with learning the ins and outs of Minecraft.  I was particularly impressed with the Minecraft Guide for Dummies as it not only broke down the game perfectly for anyone to understand but also had a "For Parents" section that explained how Minecraft can be a great learning tool (albeit much more articulate than I).  The Ultimate Player's Guide to Minecraft is a great reference guide as it breaks down everything into comprehensive chapters for anyone above a 3rd grade level to read including red stone mechanics.  The chapters are organized and the language easy to understand.However, I felt as though the Dummies version gives a more conversational, yet informative, approach that everyone, including parents, can appreciate.  This isn't to say The Ultimate version is no good, far from it as it sits quite proudly next to my Dummies version on my shelf, but I would rather recommend the For Dummies version instead.Still a great read, but I'd recommend Minecraft For Dummies first.

An an audiophile I'm very particular about my sound systems as I have a Klipsch Icon surround sound and computer speaker system and a Harmon Kardon Onyx 2 speaker for my office.  The wife wanted something for the bedroom that produced good sound balance for when she's reading or primping in the adjacent bathroom.  The Panasonic SC-PMX9 is an excellent addition to our sound systems and has satisfied our prerequisites flawlessly.The SC-PMX9 supports several different input modes including Bluetooth, Apple Airplay, red-white stereo, FM radio, and CDs, giving it a wide variety of streaming options with the exception of 3.5mm Auxiliary input, but that can be supplemented with a cheap Y-Splitter cable.  I was able to sync my Samsung Note up to the Panasonic simply by setting the stereo to Bluetooth and it popped right up on my phone's BT menu.  Simple as that.The sound quality is just amazing.  I decided to christen it's first song with Kenny Loggin's Danger Zone and that perked everything up almost immediately.  The stereo has a near flawless balance between bass and clarity, allowing the listening to hear every song as it was meant to be.My only real beefs with the SC-PMX9 is I'm not certain if it's worth the hefty price tag and I wish it had a direct 3.5mm AUX input but you do get what you pay for and the latter can be resolved with a cheap cable purchase.All in all, an amazing device!

The Viking Oval Roaster is an excellent addition in any modern kitchen with it's beautiful, modern, stainless steel look and it's practical usage as a metal oval roaster and Dutch oven.  My wife and I have used the Viking Oval Roaster on several occasions, most recently with a pot roast today, and have been very satisfied with the results.The materials are beautiful, making a family pot roast or turkey dinner for Thanksgiving a more aesthetically pleasing experience.  The Viking is also very efficient at roasting and as a Dutch oven.  My wife and I will definitely get a lot of use out of this!

Sturdiness in a case is a must but with a phone like the Samsung Note 5, which is known for being a slippery phone, having a case with good grips is a must.  Truth be told, the entire new line of Samsung are super slippery as the stage 4 gorilla glass on the back has no traction to speak of, whose responsibility falls on the case.  I usually recommend Speck gripped cases as they can maintain position even on a vehicle's dashboard, but I wanted to try the new Verus and, I gotta say, it's very durable but super slippery to the point where it's useless as a case.The Note 5, with it's aforementioned stage 4 gorilla glass, is a tank to begin with so the only reason for a case is added protection and to provide traction.  Without traction, the Note 5 can easily slip out of a person's pocket, especially if they're wearing tight jeans or yoga pants, and fall to the ground increasing the risk of a break.  The Verus case is just as slippery as my Note 5 kept slipping out of my pocket with little trouble.  It took all of one shift at work for me to retire the Verus for good and go back to my Urban Armor Gear.Again, the Verus provides excellent protection but it's too slippery to be considered since the Note 5 is a tank to begin with.

My wife and I recently adopted a rescue from the local shelter named Dax, she is around one year old and requires a LOT of stimulation and attention especially now that she's bonded with us.  The Iris CLF-5 didn't really do it for us as it was annoying to build and too small for any cat other than a kitten, but the CL-021 was actually what Dax needed as it provides a good amount of scratch material and wasn't too small to use... and I didn't contemplate seppuku while assembling it.Assembling the CL-021 took roughly 15 minutes, a third of the time it took to build the CLF-5 and it wasn't that much of a chore... except for getting the ball danglers in the right post as the instructions weren't all that clear on what angle they had to be put in.  Truth be told, I broke one of them trying to figure it out but, oh well, still have the other 3.Once I had it assembled, I put it in our bedroom near the window that Dax likes to perch on and watched her react to this new marvel that came in a box.  She was hesitant at first but eventually started scratching it once I rubbed a cloth on it that I just recently scratched her head with (amazing how effective it is to distinguish their belongings with this technique).  This method marks their territory and gives them a sense of familiarity in the same way they mark people to designate family.Dax didn't use the upper tier so much as it was a stepping block to the window, which was my intention as I'd rather she takes steps up there rather than leap and knock over whatever is up there.All in all, the CL-021 is nice albeit the instructions need to be clearer on a few things.

Meet Dax, our 13-month old rescue and one very bored kitty that tends to get into trouble.  We usually keep her entertained with a laser pointer but both my wife and I work so we needed something keep her busy while we're away.  We tried both the IRIS CLF-5 and CLF-021 and, while the CLF-021 was very nice and Dax loves it, the CLF-5 was a pain to assemble and it's so scaled down that even out skinny Dax cannot use it effectively.Assembly was not fun as the instructions have you start from the top down and the cloth wrappings on the vertical connections do not want to cooperate.  It took me about 45 minutes to get it right as I ended up removing all wrappings from the connectors to get the bolts to line up properly.As for the product as a whole, it's not, at all, a scratching post, nor does it provide any real use as the platforms and tree house are so small that my tiny Dax cannot use it.  Dax isn't a big cat as she's still growing and when I placed her on the saucer on the right she looked cramped and quickly jumped down.  Truth be told, she only uses the bottom rung to sleep on and that's about it.This is more for kittens due to it's size and that doesn't do much for owners since you can't keep them kittens forever.  I cannot recommend this product for normal users.

Many crosses I've seen have a gaudy appearance to them with too much gold, glitz, and glitter, kind ruining the message behind the image that the cross evokes.  As such, the Rose Gold and Amethyst cross is a nice blend of color with my favorite metal, sterling silver, that is big enough to be noticed but not screaming "LOOK AT ME" on a megaphone.  It's weight is well balanced so the cross doesn't find itself twirling or twisting on a person's neck, a common problem among poorly made jewelry.All in all, this is a nice item to show off your beliefs without looking like a money collector at the temple.

Wasn't very satisfied with the mat I had in my bathroom so I decided to give the DII a chance and we've been pretty satisfied so far.The cotton material feels great beneath my toes after a nice shower and seems to soak up enough runoff to prevent the any water from seeping onto the floor.  It's been two weeks and we've been very happy with it.A definite must have for any bathroom.

I have an immense collection of fragrances, with a particular interest in sporty scents such as Lacoste Essential and Nautica Voyage, and I've been very pleased with Burberry Brit Splash for the past week or so.  It's a nice, watery, summer, fresh smell that doesn't scream frat boy or Axe cheap.  It's a fine blend of scents that also doesn't overpower anyone within nasal range as many fragrances, such as anything by Ed Hardy or Axe, wreak of cheap ingredients and overpowering musk that can only be described as machismo.I am very satisfied with how Burberry Brit Splash smelled on me and the pleasant reactions of those around me and will continue to wear it on the appropriate occasions.

The Korean War is often overlooked as the "Forgotten War" despite how horrific many of the battles were.  Amidst the many battles, missions, and operations of the Korean War are numerous stories that cannot be forgotten and, from the author of Higher Call, comes another story that lives up to its namesake that evokes similar emotions as did Unbreakable and Into the Mouth of the Cat (Excellent read).Adam Makos tells the story of two naval aviators who couldn't be more different and the most amazing one-man rescue ever.  Truth be told the story seems far fetched and, while I won't give away the specifics of the rescue, it seems almost mission impossible but Makos delivers it genuinely and faithfully to where the audience believes what it is reading and roots for the characters no matter what the peril.All in all, the best book I've read all summer and I hope they adapt this one to screenplay.

There are many great stories of ordinary individuals standing up to the Nazi war machine and achieving great success and, no matter how many there are, they are all worth preserving and Avenue of Spies is an excellent drop in the bucket of anecdotes worthy of praise.Author Alex Kershaw takes the reader on a journey of bravery where none seemed to exist.  I've read some of Kershaw's work before and his level of simplicity carries over into Avenue of Spies, a good thing to say the least as it makes the book easy to read for all audience and not just academics.All in all, a great fall read.

While not quite a scientific study and analysis on dolphins, author Susan Casey takes the reader on a personal journey on her love of dolphins inspired by a trip to Maui.  Her prose is deeply personal and genuine while her "science" seems to just be there, a sideshow if you will, but I still found the book somewhat intriguing albeit with quite a bit of fluff.All in all, a nice rose garden style of prose on the author's personal connection but the rest just falls by the wayside and, by that, I mean her "research" and "science."

Regardless of your position on the political implications of the Enabling Acts, this book provides a solid historical narrative involving the formation of said acts via an excellent array of primary and secondary sources and presents them in an eloquent manner.While little more than a bedside reader, I found this book to be quite informative and without any real political bias.All in all, a good read!

My wife and I have been contemplating the paleo diet for quite some time since the Atkin's diet was horrific to say the least.  However, we wanted to be able to indulge a certain degree of desserts as well and Paleo Desserts for Dummies allows us to have our cake and eat it too with over 100 simple, yet diet-conforming, recipes to choose from.In typical "For Dummies" fashion, this book has everything in a very easy-to-read and understand format that is critical to any cookbook.  The recipes don't call for ridiculous ingredients that require a trip to a foreign country so that's also a plus, and the prose is anything if not entertaining.If you're on the Paleo diet or thinking of going on it, THIS is the book for you.

There have been a lot of books on military leadership and warrior skills translating into the business world from Richard Marcinko, Brian Hiner, etc. so what SEALs Willink and Basin offer is not entirely new as they cover the same principles such as teamwork, keep your ego in check, and don't panic under stress.  However, this isn't to diminish what the authors say as their message of SEAL dedication and poise under stress is a definite plus in any leadership.All in all, this is a good book that is well written and grounded in reality... just nothing the "Rogue Warrior" (Richard Marcinko) hasn't covered already.

With national tension with law enforcement at an all-time high and the Black Lives Matter Movement, it's no surprise that stories of alleged police brutality have become all the more poignant albeit it is putting some stories into the category of hysteria.  Don't get me wrong, stories of brutality, abuse, and fraud MUST be brought to light for justice to be served, and this motivates me greatly to read about them to form my own opinions.With this in mind, I found Ronnie Greene's story of several NOPD officers response to an officer under fire, their response, and the cover-up that followed to be very rioting, shocking, and disturbing.  Tales such as these need the light of day to bring about a better discourse on law enforcement policy and Greene does a great job investigating the incident... if only his writing skills matched his research methods.Truth be told, Shots on the Bridge has a great story behind it but it marred by poor writing and editing to the point where one has to re-read sentences and paragraphs once more to understand what Greene is trying to say.  I was able to finish the books but I can see others experiencing the same difficulties as I did and that can potentially turn people off.Still a good book but further editing is required.

We always hear about the rulings on Supreme Court decisions, what the majority of judges voted on, but we don't hear about the dissenting opinions too often as they become secondary to the overall narrative of American judicial history.  However, an examination of dissenting opinion is critical to the public discourse or dialog on the issues and author Melvin Urofsky provides a good insight on how dissent in the Supreme Court helps shape policy.Urofsky doesn't provide any new insights on dissent that we don't already know or have not studied in depth, but he does provide an excellent narrative for those new to the subject as he eloquently weaves his thesis on dissent well in a way that any non-academic can understand.All in all, this book is a great resource and starting point for those not familiar with the topic but nothing new or exciting for those of us who are.  Still well written, though.

As an ardent fan of Legos and K'Nex, I was very curious to see what it would be like to construct a K'Nex Nerf-esque rifle and how well it would hold up.  While the construction of the K-Force rifle was mostly fun with some difficulty, the rifle didn't hold up well under even non-tactical bench shooting and is little more than a show-off piece than a Nerf rifle.Construction of the K-Force was entertaining to say the least as I had a good time seeing the mechanics come together as I would with any other K'Nex or Lego project.  The instructions did present a small issue of assuming the reader would see symmetry in the pictures as they were slanted/tilted, meaning that one had to guess the other side was the same and build accordingly.  There were a few times I had to disassemble the rifle and start a process over.  An issue, but a small one.Once I completed the rifle I tested it out on my unsuspecting wife, who immediately commented on how much force and impact it caused on her posterior, to which I was then sentenced to clean the bathroom.  Truth be told, the K-Force rifle has quite a bit of velocity on it, giving the rifle a lot of power behind it so I don't recommend shooting at people in vulnerable spots like the face or groin... unless you really, REALLY want to and have a decent enough head start.However, it didn't take all but two minutes for the trigger mechanism to require adjustment as it relies on a very primitive setup to fire.  I had to make frequent adjustments to allow the rifle to fire again, making it impossible to rely on in an actual Nerf war.  Parts of the frame also seemed to warp or twist a little despite my thorough construction indicating that it is more fragile than it looks.  Needless to say, this is a show piece and little more.I wouldn't take the K-Force to a Nerf fight but I would, and have, ambushed my wife and her cats with it but it doesn't work well under anything but controlled settings so this is a show piece that is more fun to construct than use.All in all, an OK toy.

I have several Seagate portable hard drives at my disposal including a few 2TB travel drives that work great and, to be honest, I didn't think it would get any more portable this quickly.With the new Seagate Seven ultra-portable hard drive, one is able to appreciate an even more compact storage drive that is the size of a wallet and super thin but still give the same performance and speed as a regular drive.  I first tested mine out while editing a video promo I was working on in Final Cut Pro X on my Macbook.  I was able to work efficiently and effectively without any real delay from the hard drive.  The sheer compact nature of the hard drive also allowed me to keep the drive tucked away and out of the way so my hands could work freely and take with if necessary.While somewhat pricey, the Seagate Seven is an excellent portable hard drive for filmmakers needing a readily available and reliable backup storage as well as something fast to work on.  With this in mind, the Seagate Seven is also an excellent choice for anyone working on the go despite it's steeper price.

My wife and I have tried several noise canceling headphones from the Monster Octagons to Bose and generally enjoyed both of them.  We figured the Panasonic HC800, being lower priced than the others, would reflect the quality of the sound and noise canceling effects but, after a few months of use, my wife has adopted the set as her own personal "husband tuner-outer."Requiring very little battery use, the HC800 provides excellent sound quality and drowns out most ambient noises while providing a nice, comfortable experience for the user.  My wife was able to tune me out along with most other ambient noise in our apartment while listening to her music and not feel like the headphones were squeezing her head likes others do.For the price, the HC800s provide an excellent experience that doesn't quite rival Bose or Klipsch but still gives the user something to listen to while tuning out the rest of the world.

Similar to the AR-15 rifle platform, the Nerf N-Strike ECS-10 sports a modular design that can be outfitted with a wide variety of attachments from scopes, forward grips, butt stocks, etc., allowing the user to adapt the rifle to any situation... in theory.In practice, the ECS-10 is a creative design marred by a flimsy design that seems to want to break apart, and attachments that are anything but practical.  The rear butt stocks are barely held together on the frame by two plastic leads that feel wobbly when pressed firmly against the shoulder while the scopes don't really do what they're supposed to do.However, despite the shortcomings from the attachments, the ECS-10 is still a solid semi-automatic nerf rifle platform that competes decently with other similar rifles on the market.  The ECS-10 provides a decent and consistent rate of fire that grants the user a good tactical advantage over the competition.All in all the ECS-10 is a solid platform that should be perfected with decent attachments and not gimmicky accessories that serve little purpose beyond aesthetics.

Had my wife try this cream out as she is always striving to have good skin and she was quite pleased with the Proactive +.She commented on how easy it was to apply, how quickly results came in (just over one week), and how long the 3oz supply lasts (been over a month and still going strong).  All one has to do is take a small dab on your finger and carefully rub it on your face, leave it there, and enjoy the results around a week or so.All in all, my lady is very satisfied with the Proactive+ and will be requesting a refill when her current supply runs out.

Just moved into a new place and it's a bit of a fixer-upper so we needed new tools to be able update and modernize our home.  We had to cut into the walls, make cuts on plywood, tiles, etc. and that requires a tool that can make consistent cuts without bringing over a band-saw or a table-saw.  We used the RotoZip SS560 and were very pleased with the results.  The RotoZip was able to consistently make clean cuts and the "dust vault" was able to trap all the dust, which is nice for clean-up and the operator doesn't have to wear a face-mask.The RotoZip was very easy to setup and use as the controls are very basic and the attachments come on and off super easily.  This is a definite plus for anyone with limited DiY experience.  The motor is surprisingly heavy and strong for it's size so it's powerful enough for most small tasks but I would strongly urge operators to use both hands while utilizing it for safety.My only complaints were the overall cost of additional bits as they seem to cost almost double of what one would normally cost.  Small downside but they can run a person a lot of $$ in the long run.Overall, the RotoZip is an excellent tool for most DiY projects that will make a nice addition to my tool shed.

Never was a firm believer in many forms of holistic medicine/living but I always try to keep an open mind on new ideas and perspectives.  However, while I found the dietary advice and recipes genuinely intriguing, there are several scientific elements the author seemed to have missed, glossed over, or oversimplified.The first thing I noticed in chapter 1 was how the author talked a lot about stress affecting conception, and we all know stress is public enemy no. 1, and a few stress-related factors such as increased cortisol but fails to address the condition by name; Cushing's Syndrome or Cushing's Disease (two separate, but similar conditions).  I found that odd since the authors were describing it but not address it by name.  While not a true demerit on the book itself, it made me read on with a more attentive eye and I soon found other bizarre notions.In chapter 2, the author suggests that anyone having trouble smoking should "consult an acupuncturist ASAP."  I have read one or two studies on how acupuncture was supposed to make the taste of cigarettes unpalatable (most notably a 2001 study of 47 subjects), those studies were considered inconclusive as they failed to meet the required minimum assurances of a bias-free methodology.  For instance, in the aforementioned 2001 study, the researchers relied heavily on questionnaires and the honesty of the subjects thereof rather than any form of reliable observation thus raising the margin of error too high to be considered accurate.  While prominent personalities such as Dr. Oz, whom I do respect and agree on some issues, endorse acupuncture as a method of quitting smoking, it is not a proven science.Truth be told, the remainder of the book is filled with seemingly unsubstantiated or pseudo-science facts that stems from traditional Chinese medicine.  While the author cites studies, they cannot be found on search engines, only on the author's website or on highly-bias websites which further questions their validity.  I do agree that we put too much crap in our food and it can lead to horrific side effects in pregnancy, but there is plenty of good science behind an educated and accredited MD and OBGYN as well.Overall, I found the recipes intriguing enough to keep in my cookbook cabinet but I wouldn't take any of the pregnancy advice too seriously.

I usually keep a small fixed blade in the driver's side door of my vehicle in the event of an emergency and am somewhat particular about my blades.  I had a cheap United Cutlery Combat Toothpick there for about two years until I had the opportunity to review the SOG SEAL Strike knife, which is now my personal defense blade in my vehicle due to its superior design and durability.After testing the SOG SEAL Strike for about two weeks my buddies and I noted the knife is extremely sturdy, sharp, has excellent balance, and the sheath sports several utilitarian features albeit with one moderate flaw that prevents a perfect score.The blade is just under 5 inches making it ideal for concealment even with the sheath.  The tang is perfectly forged into the handle allowing for fantastic balance and durability since most "survival knifes" have very short tangs and can snap easily.  One simply needs to hold the blade to feel the heavy weight behind it but it's light enough to carry around.As for how sharp the blade is, we tested it on the usual suspects of cutting targets from twine, paper (trying to slice through a piece of paper without sawing shows true sharpness), plastic ties, summer sausage, kindling, etc. and the SOG SEAL Strike passed beautifully.  For most non-hardened objects little to no sawing was required while the serrated edge provided superior sawing for stronger surfaces with little effort.  In other words, it comes sharp, VERY sharp, and can be kept sharp with the sharpener on the sheath towards the front tip.One more great feature I liked on the blade itself was, at the bottom of the handle, the knife sports a rugged 'bashing' edge for applying a little brute force trauma to your intended target, giving the user more than one way to enforce order.The sheath, I found, was a source of great utilitarian features but also of the blade's largest flaw.1:  The sheath has a sharpener that works.2:  The sheath also sports a line cutter for twine, nylon cords, cables, etc. and it works great.3:  A frustrater that I cannot seem to figure out (never could) but I handed it to a hunter friend of mine and he nodded in approval.However, the sheath does have one design flaw regarding how it is carried and the knife removed from it.  The upper portion of the sheath that supports the handle of the knife is wider than the width of the knife's handle.  The width is due to the belt clip being located at the top of the sheath whereas most other sheaths have them located towards the middle such as my USMC Kabar.  This doesn't sound like an issue until you try an unsheathe the knife and realize that you have to use your fingers to do so less you grab the whole thing and yank the sheath off your belt.  The sheath is also hard polymer so one has to either grip the whole thing or use their fingers with relative delicacy.  Also, the sheath is very bottom heavy which means that the knife, when clipped to one's belt, will flop around and that is quite a nuisance when out and about.  Even if you had the knife attached to your suspenders facing downwards, one would have to exert some delicacy with the fingers to remove the knife from the sheath.This may not seem like an issue and it isn't in a casual sense.  However, in the field it prevents rapid deployment from the sheath to an open hand and that can be a problem with soldiers, Marines, law enforcement, etc.  This makes the SOG SEAL Strike more of a casual knife and not something for the field but IT IS STILL AN EXCELLENT BLADE.Despite the flaw with the sheath, the SOG SEAL Strike blade is still an amazing blade that I will keep on me while driving.  I'd recommend it to hunters and enthusiasts but not anyone serving in the field.

For over 100 years mankind has perfected the art of flying (not air travel) and the romantic appeal of taking the skies is still as striking as it was during the Pan Am years of aviation.  Author and 747 pilot Mark Vanhoenacker masterfully talks about the romance of flight by talking about himself, a former academician turned pilot, his journey to become an aviator, and the science and joys of flying without too much technobabble to confuse the general audience.Indeed, at times, Vanhoenacker discusses the science behind flight but does so in a way that does not baffle the general audience.  While I consider myself an aviation fanatic since my days working the public affairs office as a civilian intern for the USAF, I'm no astrophysicist, so reading about complex terms broken down for us dummies in the audience really made my experience with Skyfaring a good one.I really enjoyed reading this one as it excites the imagination with it's romanization of flying and it's articulate, yet simple, prose that makes Skyfaring a read for everyone.

I've heard of KIVA and have nothing but admiration for their work with micro loans.  There is no doubt in my mind that the author, Jessica Jacklay, is a true believer in what she does and I commend that, however, Clay Water Brick is marred with disjointed narratives and poor prose that makes the book difficult to read at times.  I had to put the book down once or twice as I had to gather my thoughts on where Jacklay was going, which always ended up with me forcing myself to continue and I didn't care for the payout.Jacklay has a knack of jumping from topic to topic with no real sense of direction and, if there is one, it isn't adequately explained and it doesn't start to come together at the end like a Quentin Tarantino film, either.  On top of that, Jacklay also exhibits poor prose in her writing with poor sentence structure and a LOT of redundancy that seems to ramble on a lot.Either way, while Jacklay's story is interesting and, indeed, heartwarming, the poor organization and prose makes the book nearly unreadable and requires serious revisions before being a 4-5 star.

Having grown up in a suburban area north of Seattle I find myself loving to read any local or regional history regarding the small area I call home that doesn't have to deal with Twilight, Grey's Anatomy, or a nameless romantic flick with Tom Hanks.  However, after reading the collection of stories from Jack Nisbet, I find myself wondering what I just read beyond a bunch of seemingly loose narratives, whose only commonality is the region they resided in.Nisbet treats the audience to a series of stories involving various people living across the Pacific NW from Oregon to Idaho but, beyond that, there's no real connecting factors and, if there are any, Nisbet makes no effort to link them.  This leaves the reader wondering what it is they're reading beyond a bunch of narratives so the book lacks cohesion and that's not a good thing.If anything, if Nisbet made an effort to weave a narrative or focal point into the stories than Ancient Places would be a much better read but, for now, it's merely a table-top reader.

Alzheimers is one disease that should scare the living hell out of anyone not because there is no cure but the notion of losing your mind bit by bit and being cognizant of it as it happens would be enough to drive me mad.  Alzheimers literally is the theft of memory as author Jonathan Kozol so eloquently puts it in his book regarding his father, a renowned psychiatrist, and his eventual downfall caused by the horrific disease.Kozol spares no description as he and his family struggled to understand and live with his father's ailments despite having comfortable financial status.  It reminds us that life with coherence is precious and that we REALLY need to appreciate what we have while we have.I experienced some difficulty reading Theft of Memory given Alzheimers runs in my family and I am one that is considered "at risk" of catching it but, we all face reality at some point and fight to keep our whits and health in the meantime.  An excellent read.

Needless to say that I, a male, did not take this test.  My fiancé took the tests as her period is late and tensions are high so the Clearblue tests were more of a Godsend than I care to admit as the results from taking two tests over the course of a few days (just to be sure) put us, particularly me, at ease (see title).My lady, after using both tests, was happy to report that the Clearblue are easy to use as the grip provides decent... distance between the hand and the... um... stream, allowing her to use the test in a clean manner with spillage.  The instructions were simple enough, consisting of a PG version of a dog's solution to anything (urinate on it), and wait up to three minutes for results.After carefully examining the test after the allotted time elapsed we're proud to announce that she's not pregnant (again, see title) so our parents will refrain from being basket cases on the matter till AFTER we get married (Friday).  The pluses mean you are pregnant and the minus means no so there's little room to speculate, a definite plus.Overall, we're very pleased with Clearblue and SHE will continue to use them while I sit in the other room saying we won't be in THAT situation again but, then again, who am I kidding?

My lady loves to experiment with different nail colors and polishes and had an absolute ball trying out the Essie Nail Colo as the silver glittery look just shined in just about any light.  The color allowed her to experiment with different kinds of applications for different effects.  Again, she really enjoyed it.However, one small issue was that the polish kept clumping in globs preventing an even coat.  This is due to the thickness and multiple glitters inside each application creating a nice big glop, which makes it tricky, but not intolerable, to apply.I would recommend this to anyone wanting to experiment with different nail colors and polishes but issue care when applying.

I have used UAG products before and have always been very satisfied with them for their rugged designs and stylist looks without sacrificing function or utility like most cheap "ruggedized" cases.The USAG S6 case fits on very tightly, as one would expect, and the acrylic materials provide excellent flexibility to get the device in but still exert excellent protection.
