The clear coating with black trimming looks really good with the white S6 so I wouldn't recommend it for the black sapphire.Also, unlike most cases, the UAG does not interfere with the buttons so, while it may seem stiff at first, one can still operate the buttons with ease and not worry about any "runoff" and, by that, I mean having your fingers accidentally hit other buttons while touching the home button.  One of my biggest gripes on open-faced cases is that the case overlaps onto the screen too much so when you hit the home button you repeatedly hit another button cause you have to hover half your thumb over the case.All in all, the UAG is an excellent case and the clear is perfect for the white S6.  A must recommend as well as Speck and Tech21.

Most ruggedized cellphone cases are either too bulky (Otterbox Defender, Lifeproof, etc.) or provide the worst possible traction possible (Otterbox Symmetry) as they can easily slip out of your hands or pocket.Having worked with a LOT of cellphone cases, one of my favorite brands are Speck as they are military-grade, drop-tested, have excellent anti-heat and impact insulation, and sport some of the best rubber grips for the price.  The S6 case is no different as the grips provide fantastic traction on any surface including a vehicle dashboard, is easy to put on, is super tight with the S6 inside it (which you want), and the buttons are not restricted by the case itself.The dragon green color is an interesting choice, one that only seems to work well with the black sapphire S6 cool and not so much with the white or gold colors.I recommend Speck cases to anyone seeking a nice budgetary case that provides excellent protection.  Heck, I purchased one for my fiancé and she loves it.

If you know how to work with fondants than the Via Roma is a good choice but, for my fiancé and I who are more hobbyists than experts, we had some difficulty working with the fondant as it was sticky, dries quickly once dye is applied and then becomes too hard to work with.However, all that aside and compared to other fondants, the Via Roma tasted good, it worked well with our cake and cupcake projects and... yeah, it's good.  Just be sure to know what you're doing with it as we sure learned a lot working with this one!

I have always come to depend on UAG for their extremely simple, yet rugged cases and their clear-case for the Samsung S6 Edge is just another example of UAG living up to their reputation.The case fits on very tightly, as one would expect, and the acrylic materials provide excellent flexibility to get the device in but still exert excellent protection.  The clear coating with black trimming looks really good with the white S6 so I wouldn't recommend it for the black sapphire.Also, unlike most cases, the UAG does not interfere with the buttons so, while it may seem stiff at first, one can still operate the buttons with ease and not worry about any "runoff" and, by that, I mean having your fingers accidentally hit other buttons while touching the home button.  One of my biggest gripes on open-faced cases is that the case overlaps onto the screen too much so when you hit the home button you repeatedly hit another button cause you have to hover half your thumb over the case.All in all, the UAG is an excellent case and the clear is perfect for the white S6.

Gretchen Carlson is an interesting woman in that, I believe, she sincerely is more than just a pretty face on a controversial news station.  She documents her rise from Miss America to her beginnings in small time news to her eventual ascension to FoxNews.  Carlson is a true success story and she does a good job conveying her personal beliefs of going all out to achieve one's goals.As for the obvious political elephant in the room, I didn't find much cause for concern as she tends to keep to her "success story" narrative rather than what others would expect; an anti-leftists essay.  I simply did not see it.All in all, Getting Real is a good read about a woman who wouldn't quit and utilized her talents to their fullest.  I enjoyed it and would recommend it as a women's study on success.

Very rarely does a book so such a great job at reminding us about how awesome the author is that one forgets that they are supposed to be reading about something and the meaning is lost and the book gets shelved faster than Gwyneth Paltrow cookbook.Author Jon fine masterfully reminds us of what he's done in his life and how everyone else "sucks" compared to him... oh, and something, something, indie band.In all seriousness, Fine took a very provocative approach with his title and it got my attention as I thought it would be a riveting analysis of how while indie bands are generally subpar they hold great cultural significance.  Instead, Fine distracts the reader with snobbery and self-indulging anecdotes to the point where it makes the book unreadable.  I, sincerely, could not finish this one.Can not recommend to anyone.

I have tested out the Vysk and Mophie cases before and, while the Incipio holds up very well, it is not as high quality as the Vysk.The Incipit is, essentially, a battery backup case that provides up to 120% additional charge for the iPhone 6 and charges via a mini USB cable when in need or a recharge.  The Incipio sports a good battery, easy to set in frame that is one piece as opposed to the usual two pieces (Such as the Vysk and Mophie), and the frame provides good protection from drops or impact.However, there are two things to note about the frame.First off, the outer shell is smooth and rubbery suggesting that it may wear out after prolonged use.  One of my biggest complaints against case manufactures such as Otterbox (the Defender in particular) is that consistent removing of the case can wear out the rubber and it looses it's grip.  This can lead to poor protecting and a bad grip on the phone.My next issue is the texture/traction as it's too smooth to remain in one place.  Slippery cases can slip out of a person's hand, pocket, or off the dashboard of a vehicle and go where ever gravity takes it.  Rubber grip marks, such as those found on certain Speck cases, make cases a LOT harder to slip up with and they, typically, don't fall out of a person's pocket or slip out of their hands.All in all, the Incipio is good, but there are better ones out there.  I prefer Vysk, myself.

SpongeBob Operation works exactly like the original operation save for the obvious change in themes and, most interestingly, the removal of the specialist and doctor cards, which takes away any sense of randomization.  Instead, the players choose which ailment to remove until all are gone and whoever successfully removed the most wins (aka Free Mode in original Operation).  This doesn't exactly give the game any real challenge beyond what other Operation games do so it'll only hold it's replay value with fans and small children.The set seems well put together and survived several sessions with me and my buds but we had to make up several curveball rules to make it more interesting.

Does not work.  Tried it with both my fiancé, who has long thick hair, and her BFF, a stylist that has short and thin hair, and we couldn't get the InStyler to work at a..  It lacks the power to properly pull and curl hair and it takes forever to warm up.We had the same experience with two other InStyler products and will not recommend them to anyone.

I honestly expected this to be cheaply made like a lot of branded fashion jewelry for kids. Happy to say I was surprised by the quality. This bracelet is adorable and the perfect gift for a Frozen fan. Comes in a lovely gift box.Parents should note that this bracelet is for SMALL children. It is only about two inches wide, which means it simply won't fit around the wrist of a girl older than maybe seven or eight, Which also means she will outgrow the bracelet sooner than later. Because of the price, consider the maturity level of the recipient before buying. You don't want to drop $30 on a piece of jewelry for a five-year-old only to have her lose it at school the first day.

This is really less a bubble bath than a shower gel. Doesn't really foam up or lather well at all. The point of a bubble bath is BUBBLES. The decadence of lounging in the tub surrounded by thick bubbly lather while reading a book or just relaxing. But this doesn't really provide that sort of experience.It does serve as a decent shower gel, however. Again, it doesn't lather real well but it rinses clean and didn't leave my skin feeling sticky and like there was a residue left over. The smell is wonderful; each bottle has a distinctive but not overwhelming scent that smells natural. The scent doesn't last very long, however. Pretty much lost the scent fifteen minutes out of the tub. Which is fine for me as I don't really like lingering fragrances unless it is a perfume I am wearing.

Swingline has a wide range of staplers, some not so dependable, so I wasn't sure what the overall quality would be. Thankfully, these branded staplers are made with their better-quality units. This is a heavyweight, sturdy stapler that can actually take a little abuse. No jamming or broken staples. Branding elements aren't just cheap stickers but well-designed decals that feel like vinyl. They can be scratched off, but I don't suspect they will just start randomly peeling off on their own like cheaper quality stickers would. The red color is muted, not shiny.I'm annoyed that for the price this stapler doesn't even come with a complimentary strip of staples. Seriously, this thing retails for $40 and you don't even provide a strip of staples? The price is also outrageous. I'm glad I got this for free through Vine as my boyfriend is a big 49ers fan. But if I am going to spend $40 on branded merchandise it is going to be a jersey or something. Just seems excessive.

The Jarrow supplements have been hit-or-miss with me. So I didn't have high expectations here but I wanted to give them a fair shot.Since March, I have been using the MyFitnessPal app to help monitor my calorie intake. I have also been using an exercise bike three times a week. Between these two activities, I have been consistently losing one to one and a half pounds a week. Nothing exceptional, but it has been consistent and I have not been hungry at all. This supplement is the only change I have made to my routine. I've stuck to my same diet and exercise regimen.If you have trouble swallowing pills, this product is not for you. Each pill is slightly less than an inch in length. And you need to take three of them, twice a day. You are supposed to take three a half hour to an hour before either breakfast or lunch, and three a half hour to an hour before dinner. That is a LOT of pills to have to take each day if you have issues swallowing pills to begin with. I usually struggle with taking supplements or medication on an empty stomach as it sometimes makes me nauseous. Fortunately, I had no such issue with this supplement so I would say it should be safe for those with sensitive stomachs to use.The bottom line is whether or not it does anything. After ten days, I lost 2 lbs. A week later, I had lost slightly more than 1 and a half pounds. So this reflects a small increase in weight loss over what I was losing before taking the supplement. My appetite hasn't really changed at all, but I haven't been starving myself anyway on my existing diet plan so I didn't expect that to change.For me personally, the impact of the supplement is too minor for me to add this to my regular regimen. Is it worth $30-$40 a month to lose an additional one or two pounds a month? For some people, it may me. For me, I'm in no hurry to reach my goal weight. I'm more interested in being able to maintain my goal weight once I reach it than rushing to hit the goal. If you are struggling with your diet because you always feel hungry, this nay prove useful. It does seem to work, but for me the results are too minor to get overly excited. But if you are fighting for every pound, it may be worth it to you to at least try this for a month or two to help your body adjust to a lower calorie intake.

The Star Wars: The Force Awakens X-Wing Miniatures Game Core Set is a complete game that can be enjoyed without having to buy additional expansions. This is never a forgone conclusion in the miniature games hobby, so it is a big deal. Everything you need to play is in the box. You can, of course, buy expansions if you wish, but they are not needed to enjoy the game. The pre-painted ships are gorgeous and have exceptional detail. Rules are clearly written and easy to follow. This would make a great gift for a Star Wars fan.

Grabbed this for the nieces, as they love DIY projects. The set comes with six spools of thread, which is plenty to keep the kids busy for several hours wrapping anything and everything. The spools are about the same size as a standard spool of thread that you would buy at a craft store, which means you could expand your color repertoire with pretty much any thread you wanted. Which is a bonus, since the official refills for this thing are $12-$13 for 3 spools!  Much cheaper to buy a few dozen different spools of thread at a craft shop for your kids.As some others have noted, getting parts on and off can be a bit problematic. From my perspective, the primary fear was that, because the unit is comprised of cheap plastic, too much force would break it. Once everything is hooked up, however, it is very easy to use and you can use it to decorate all sorts of small items: pens, eyeglass frames, watches, lipstick cases, hair accessories, the dog's collar...whatever they can get their hands on.

Teen Titans Vol. 1: Blinded by the Light is another reboot of the popular Teen Titans team.  Apparently nobody ever explained the concept of “If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” to D.C. This new incarnation of the team isn’t bad. In fact, if this was an all-new team formed for some specific purpose, it would feel more interesting.  But the problem is that this isn’t an all-new team. It is still supposedly the Teen Titans but with a fresh coat of paint and a few parts moved around.  The entire reboot feels like change just for the point of change, with no real direction. Sort of like when a cereal company promotes “ALL NEW PACKAGING” but the actual product ingredients don’t change all that much.There isn’t a lot of character build-up in volume one. The story jumps right into the action. But the action is fairly standard and feels phoned in. It is action for the sake of action and to show off some of the new characters’ powers, but doesn’t really do much for moving the story along.  The team dynamic never really fleshes out in this volume. Hopefully. we’ll get more of that in future volumes.Note: I was given a copy of this through NetGalley for review.

This multi-cooker has been a wonderful addition to my kitchen. It would be easy to dismiss this device as a glorified rice cooker, but it is a versatile and highly useful appliance. Takes the place of multiple appliances.Included: Detachable electrical cord, poacher/steamer basket, measuring cup, ladle, and spatula/scraper, and cookbookOverall design: Sleek and sturdy design. Quality construction across the board. Carry handle and cool-to-the-touch exterior allow you to use this to carry meals with you for potluck dinners and office parties. The non-stick interior unit is ridiculously easy to clean. Plenty of products claim to be non-stick, but you still end up with difficulty safely cleaning them without damaging the non-stick surface. After two dozen uses, the interior unit cleans up in two minutes tops with regular dish soap and water and no scrubbing.Ease of use: The appliance comes programmed with ten preset temperatures and cooking times to let you easily prepare rice, stews, sauces, steam vegetables, even saute and roast. We have a gas stove top and normally I have to constantly adjust the flame and continuously stir or monitor pots and pans to prevent foods from boiling over or sticking. With this multi-cooker, you set it and walk away until it is done, freeing you up to do other things while dinners cooks.Quality of results: Even cooking temperatures make recipes come out perfect. So far, I've used this to make beef stew, pineapple chicken with rice, chicken and quinoa with cashew nuts, scrambled eggs, chicken alfredo, ziti with meat sauce, and a bunch of other recipes. With pasta dishes, you don't even need to boil the pasta first. You can prepare the sauce and pasta all at once with the simple instructions provided in the included cookbook. The only things I haven't attempted yet are baking or making yogurt. Every meal I've created in this, from my own recipes from scratch to recipes from their cookbook to pre-packaged foods like Hamburger Helper, has come out perfectly.I confess that I am one of those people who never would have spent this kind of money on a multi-cooker and would have just dismissed it as a fancy, overpriced rice cooker. But I just love this appliance. If you enjoy cooking but want to make your life easier in the kitchen, this appliance will become your favorite.

Since we have been giving this to Chewy, our 13 year old Doberman/German Shepard mix, we have seen a noticeable improvement in his mobility. He's able to get up and dow the basement stairs on his own again and once more wants to play instead of just sitting around all day. He's still slower than he once was, but he's 13.Pills are very tiny. For Chewy's weight, we have to give him 3 a day. So a bottle is a 20 day supply. This makes the product exoensive at the list price of over $25. But it is an acceptable value at the Amazon sale price of $11. If the price started to go up, I would probably start looking into other brands. But at the current price it is a good deal.
Purchased as replacement bulbs for office lighting. Bulbs arrived without damage and were as described. Fit into existing ballasts with no issues.

We ordered two of these dressers and they arrived today. I am pleased with the delivery speed, as we weren't expecting them for another week.Like another reviewer noted, the color of the dressers in person does not match the photo. The photo indicates a vibrant blue. The actual color is a black-blue. It looks black to my boyfriend, but I have better color definition than he does and can see the slight blue hue. It is definitely NOT the vibrant blue in the image.There was also a faint turpentine smell when we uncrated the dressers, but it went away after a few hours and as of this evening I no longer smell it. I'm going to chalk that up to the dressers being made recently, perhaps, and not having time to completely air out before being shipped.The overall construction of the dressers is adequate in relation to the price we paid ($137 each). The dressers have heft to them. They aren't going to get knocked over easily. They sit flat on the floor with no wobbling. The drawers open and close easily and are fairly roomy. You could sit a small TV or other device on the top of one of these units and not worry about the top buckling.But while the overall construction is sufficient, the company drops the ball on the little things. The company that manufactures these dressers needs to get their QA dept in line. One of the dressers arrived short screws to attach a handle.They are standard screws so we'll find some to add the last handle. Two of the drawers have scuff marks on the interior edges. They are only visible when the drawer is open. I'm not necessarily mad about either issue as they are minor, but it does reflect poorly on their QA that we ordered two dressers and both had problems.Overall, these dressers will serve our needs. Not particularly impressed but not upset either.

After using this product with Chewy for 20 days, I have to say the jury is still out on whether or not it actually does anything. Based on Chewy's weight (70 lbs), we have been giving him two per day. He likes them and responds to them like treats. The list of ingredients doesn't include anything that would set off alarms. It is a relatively straightforward list. But truth be told, there has been no real change in his behavior. He's never been an aggressive dog (unless he thought I was in danger) but he barks at the drop of a hat and gets worked up over random noises. We had hoped this might tone him down a little. He still barks his brains out at the neighborhood cat whenever it walks across the lawn. He still goes nuts at random sounds. He's not begging and mooching as much anymore, but I associate that with the recent changes in his dog food (we switched him to grain-free food). It is possible that he is just too old and set in his ways (he's 13) for this to really do much to him.

Varney the Vampire is a Victorian-era gothic serial that was first published from 1845-1847 in what was known as the “penny dreadful” format. Authorship of the original work is still a matter of some debate; though most acknowledge James Malcolm Rymer or Thomas Peckett Prest (or possibly both) as the actual author(s). Varney is considered by many the original vampire story on which all others are built. Varney didn’t play to the vampire horror tropes. It created them. By modern standards, the narrative is woefully inconsistent, poorly edited, and occasionally (all right, more than occasionally) downright soap opera. But it is important to appreciate Varney in relation to the time it was written. It was a surprisingly revolutionary work.These Dover Publications editions are not a retelling or a revision. These are reproductions of the original text with all the warts. While this edition does reproduce some of the original art, not all of the art is included. It is important to note that the actual penny dreadful serial ran well over two hundred chapters. I can understand why the publishers made the decision to limit the number of images included. Even breaking the serial into Parts One and Two, as Dover has done here, still results in two huge books without all the images. It is important for readers to understand what they are getting. This is not a modernized retelling of the original story. It is the original text, in Victorian English, with all the grammar and spelling errors and plot holes included.My review copy was a PDF of the print book. While the pages are high resolution, because they are reproductions of the original work the text itself is at times hard to read due to inconsistencies in the original source material. I cannot speak for mobi or epub versions of this book; though I have to image formatting them was a nightmare!I’m glad Dover Publications took the time to restore Varney the Vampire for its historic and literary value. Those of us that are book buffs appreciate the care required to restore a classic like this. But casual readers are going to struggle with trying to actually read the text and may not really appreciate the story because of it.Reviewer Note: I obtained a copy of this book through Netgalley

A is for Arsenic: The Poisons of Agatha Christie by Kathryn Harkup is a delightful, entertaining, and thoughtful look at how one of literature’s greatest mystery writers used poisons. Some might consider the topic a bit morbid, but Harkup’s approach to the material is actually educational and fun.For mystery and suspense writers, this book should be required reading for both the historical perspective it offers and as a matter of craft. For fans of the genres, the book provides a unique insight into Agatha Christie’s body of work.This isn’t just a list of which poisons are used in which stories. Harkup presents the science behind the poisons as Christie would have understood it. Christie was well versed in the science behind her preferred method of murder, having worked extensively in pharmacies during both world wars. She also understood the logistics of poison: how easy or difficult they were to obtain, how easily they could or could not be traced, and how investigators would go about identifying them.Instead of taking a dry, academic approach, Harkup adopts a more conversational tone that will make the book more accessible to casual readers. The approach, however, may put off those expecting a straightforward scientific discussion. This isn’t a science book and it certainly won’t tell you how to poison anyone today. But it does offer an extensive historic look at the use of poisons throughout history and how that knowledge was used by Christie.A is for Arsenic is a wonderful look into the mind of Agatha Christie and would be a welcome addition to the library of any fan.Reviewer Note: I was given a copy of this book via NetGalley in exchange for a review.

It is possible that if you have really damaged hair, that this shampoo may actually do something. But for me, there has been no positive change to my hair condition from using this product. I don't use curling irons or hairspray or even conditioner. I do use an anti-frizz product. So my hair is pretty healthy to begin with. I haven't been using my normal anti-frizz product while using this shampoo so I could accurately assess if it was accomplishing anything.First, this shampoo has a weird smell. I can't quite put my finger on it. It smells a little like vegetable oil but there is something else there as well. Thankfully the smell doesn't linger long after rinsing, but it is noticeable. Second, it doesn't lather very well. You actually need to use quite a bit of it to get any sort of real lather going. I needed almost twice as much product as I do with other brands to get the same level of lather. Third, after a few uses I started to notice waxy residue building up in my hair brush. As I've never had that happen before, I have to assume it is residue being left behind from the shampoo itself. And this doesn't really seem to be all that effective with frizz. Maybe after a few months of use I wouldn't need to use a separate anti-frizz product. But seriously after a few weeks if a shampoo is going to deliver on the hype you should see a significant improvement.My hair feels clean after use. So it is a functional enough shampoo. But I don't feel that, for people with normal hair anyway, this is of much value.

It looks like a toy. Yeah yeah I know. It IS a toy. But no, the Easy-Bake Oven is still supposed to be functional oven. I had one as a child (amazingly avoided burning myself or the house down in the process). The "fresh, modern look" looks like a generic toy. I have concerns about the overall construction of the item. Outside the box, it doesn't look like it can withstand a lot of use. Also, for the size of this thing, the actual tray that is used to bake is ridiculously tiny. What am I doing, baking for elves?I'm trying to put my own nostalgic disappointment aside because I understand nothing is made like it was "in the old days." The included recipes are simple enough to follow. The finished baked goods were okay (and if I'm honest, that was also true with the old EBO lol). But there are a lot of missed opportunities here.Like why isn't there a real timer/clock on this item? At first I thought maybe I had gotten a demo model or something (wouldn't be the first time, Vine!) but another reviewer noted the same issue. Baking is all about timing. WHT IS THERE NO TIMER? Also, with the conversion to electric from the notorious light bulb, why doesn't it have multiple settings. The included spatula doesn't give me the warm fuzzies. Seems to be cheap plastic that probably should not be exposed to heat.But then the nieces saw this and freaked out wanting to use it. THEY seem to love it, but alas they have no memories of the original EBO. They enjoy it, so that may be more important than my own nostalgia.

We have been working on switching our 13 yr old dog to grain free food. He's taken well to this brand, though he isn't "excited" about it like he was with the Rachael Ray(TM) Nutrish Zero Grain(TM) Natural Dry Dog Food, Salmon & Sweet Potato Recipe, 4 lbs. I'm pleased with the wholesome list of ingredients. Chewy's experienced no digestive issues at all. This is a good, cost-effective choice if you want to transition your dog to grain-free.Since we have moved Chewy to grain free dog food, I've noticed he is trying to "mooch" food from us a lot less. I think this may be because he is actually feeling full from eating non-filler dog food. So it has had the side effect of improving his temperament and behavior (though all bets are off if he sees a pizza crust!)

Was so excited to learn the boys were back together and releasing a new album. The only song I'm not fond of is Fire It Up because the lyrics are just trite. But that isn't enough for me to subtract a star for. People complaining about the album are just those people that never want bands to evolve and instead rehash the same sound each album.

The LeapFrog Word Whammer is an engaging, interactive device that encouraged developing motor skills as well as language skills. I much prefer toys like this than apps that just have you push a button. The child twists and bumps the handles to cycle through answers and find the correct one. Intuitive design makes the toy easy for children to master, and while it isn't completely quiet it isn't annoyingly loud. Good value for the price and solid construction that can stand up to lots of playtime.

Pluses:Extremely slim and lightweight, so it doesn't take up a lot of space.Stand attaches quickly with no need for tools.Plug-and-play: just plug it in and go. Didn't require any special drivers or cumbersome setup.Negatives:Poor speakers. Really bad sound quality. Don't rely on the built in speakers for your primary sound needs. Sound was so bad I don't even know why they bothered.Takes a lot of adjustments to get image picture quality right: Had to keep fiddling with the settings to get the correct brightness and color output. Once it was set, the image is acceptable but nothing great.Overall, this would be a good choice for a secondary monitor, but as a primary monitor it is a bit lacking. If you are a casual computer user, the monitor is perfectly functional. But if you watch movies or play games from your computer, you will want a higher end monitor.

Massimo Montanari’s Medieval Tastes is a detailed, well-researched, and insightful look into the evolution of the culinary arts and how our modern concepts of “Medieval” food are, frankly, hilariously wrong. This is not a cookbook, but rather a historical account of the development of cuisine during the medieval period. Montanari discusses not only how our modern ideas of what foods were eaten during the Medieval era is flawed, but also how the foods items themselves were fundamentally different centuries ago.Much of our modern thought on medieval cuisine is rooted in entertainment media and the romanticizing of the time period courtesy of medieval festivals and events. Montanari digs deep into the actual historical records to reveal how complex and at times controversial certain culinary movements were during the time period. It is an intriguing look into the day-to-day lives of both commoners and nobles and how food played a role beyond mere sustenance. The book is weighed down, however, by the academic tendency to over-explain and use cumbersome language and sentence structures to make a point. Casual readers interested in the topic will not find the text easily accessible. Part of this may be the fault of the translator, as sections of the book do in fact read like literal translations instead of conversational ones. Perhaps a more careful attempt to make the work readable for English speakers would have made the text easier to follow. I should also note that my review copy was an unedited proof, and some of this awkwardness may have been rectified in the final, edited version.Reviewer note: I was given an advance copy of this work for review.

A Force For Good is a nuanced and insightful call-to-action. The Dalai Lama offers a holistic approach to overcoming the many issues we currently face. For me, the most important part of the book is the discussion regarding the "us versus them" mentality that has put a stranglehold on modern society. In truth, most people know what needs to be done to achieve greater balance and equity in the world, but we are bogged down by worries of the other side "winning" at our expense. His Holiness points out that it is not a matter of winning or losing, of us versus them. It is a matter of putting out into the world what we want to see in return. It is a call to finally move beyond the primitive, tribal mentality that rears its ugly head in times of crisis and prevents us from examining the root causes of problems.

Sound quality is excellent and I have no issues with that. The primary issue was getting the correct size pads on the buds. The pads simply did...not...want...to...attach. I was afraid the entire time I was going to damage the pads from trying to force them onto the buds, as they did not pop on and off easily. It took a good ten minutes of carefully trying to coax the pad onto the bud to finally get them on. Once I got the pads on, they item works great.

Easy Caulk "Press in Place" is a quick fix for cosmetic issues in dry locations like cabinets or counters, but not ideal for areas subjected to moisture such as sinks and windows. The caulk is attached to a piece of vinyl so that when you press it into place you have the vinyl surface that looks nice but is not waterproof. If used around a sink or other area that is subject to a lot of potential moisture, you run the risk of mold getting behind the vinyl. Ended up using this in the kitchen in the cabinets and it looks lovely. But I wouldn't use around sinks or places that are likely to get wet often.

These nutritional shakes have a similar taste and texture to SlimFast. Not bad, but nothing to croon over. Taste better when cold, but is drinkable without refrigeration. I've found them useful as a meal replacement at breakfast if I am running behind schedule or if I get hunger pangs mid afternoon and want to avoid unhealthy snaking. With only 70 calories but 12 g of protein, it is surprisingly filling and keeps me from being tempted to indulge in the break room snack machine.The product is soy based, and as such people with soy allergies should avoid. One bottle covers 10%-30% the RDA of most vitamins and minerals, so assuming you eat an otherwise balanced diet the rest of the day this will help you meet your nutritional goals.Sodium content is higher than I would like (300 mg) but it has 0 sugar. So it is a fair trade-off so long as you are monitoring your sodium consumption the rest of the day.

Okay so I grabbed this to give the nieces something to do when they come over to visit. Then the item arrived and I decided to keep it for myself. The two figures are absolutely so adorable. The pictures don't do them justice. These are really less toy that cool artsy items. I ended up putting them together myself (don't judge me...) and now they sit on my desk to keep me company.

Very soft and absorbent kitchen towel with a cute coffee design that blends well with almost any decor. After washing, there was no degradation in the color or pilling of the fabric, which are the most common problems I've seen with cheaper kitchen towels. No noticeable fraying of the edges after washing, either.

I have used regular Febreze (both the fabric freshener and air freshener) before and always been pleased with it. I'm actually a little disappointed with this "Unstopable" formula. While it has a pleasant scent, it didn't last nearly as long as the regular Febreze air fresheners I have used. The traditional brand usually keeps the room smelling fresh for hours. This only lasted about an hour. In addition, the traditional Febreze never left a noticeable residue behind on furniture. This formula seems to leave a slight but noticeable residue. I feel this formula is actually a downgrade from the original.

I've used other variants of Natural Instincts before. This was my first time using the new Crema Keratina formula. Most hair coloring has that weird chemical smell. This particular formula actually had a pleasant scent. I have very long hair (goes all the way down my back) so I often worry if one bottle will provide enough coverage. Had no issues at all with this formula. I only have a few gray hairs, and the color blended in perfectly. Not sure if the coverage would be sufficient if you were trying to cover a lot of gray. But if you just have a little gray showing or if you are just looking for a new color, this hair coloring is wonderful.I wish the conditioner that came with the hair coloring was sold separately. My hair felt so soft after it was dry.Usually when I color my hair, I ruin a t-shirt because I'll get some of the hair color on it. This time was no exception as I ended up with some color on the back and shoulders of the t-shirt I was wearing. Was surprised when I pulled the t-shirt out of the washer and it wasn't stained. Not sure if I just got lucky this time of if it is the new formulation.Only downside is that, like most of these color-at-home kits, the gloves they give you are woefully insufficient. I don't even have long nails, and my fingers pinched through during the coloring. Use your own gloves instead.Otherwise, would definitely use this color again.

Nail color only required one coat and dried in five minutes. Appears to be silver sparkle in the bottle, however once it dries it is actually gold sparkles with larger silver flecks. Has the effect of looking either silver or gold depending on the lighting. After two days, no chipping with normal activities (typing, opening mail, opening cans, breaking down boxes, etc). I'm wearing it by itself but could be used as a topcoat to add sparkle to a darker undercoat.

Chewy seemed indifferent to this brand. He would sniff the bowl and then sort of pick at it but not really eat until he was really hungry, which of course meant instead of eating his food he would beg at the table for what we were eating instead. Nothing inherently wrong with the dog food insofar as ingredients. I like the fact that it is grain free and the rest of the ingredients are for the most part "normal" food items and not just strings of chemical compounds. He just didn't seem to be real interested in eating it. Maybe it just didn't smell tasty to him.

UPDATE:This is an update to my original review. I am changing my score to reflect recent updates to the app.1. Rebates now rely less on video, making it easier to claim rebates on items,2. Most rebates now can be activated on the site instead of through the app. Some rebates still require app to be used for activation, but the majority can now be activated from the website. This makes it much less cumbersome to select and activate rebates.3. App is more responsive and not as laggy. You still have to take a photo of the entire receipt, which is still a pain when you have a long receipt, but the app seems to process the receipt faster now.The above updates make the app easier to use and less time consuming. I feel much better about this program than I initially did. I'm glad I stuck with it long enough for the app to be updated.PREVIOUS:I downloaded the app directly from their site. The app is cumbersome, buggy, and HIGHLY INVASIVE.To get deals, you go through the app and find the items that you are interested in. The one saving grace is that they have a huge selection of products, including many products that are good for any brand. Unlike similar apps, it actually provides discounts on lots of household staples like milk, eggs, and bread. So that is the one good thing.But, the app is time consuming and requires too much work for too little gain.For example, to earn a 30 cent discount on milk, I had to complete two tasks. Both tasks included watching a 15 second ad on my phone. Many of the tasks can ONLY be performed from your phone and require watching some sort of video. This means you will be draining your battery and, if you aren't using wi-fi, draining your data plan, for 10-15 cent discounts. Not all tasks require a video. Some require a one question survey or answering a trivia question. But most of the bonuses are tied to using your phone to watch ads.Once you purchase a qualified item, you have to complete two additional steps to claim your redemption. The first thing you have to do is scan the barcode. Again, battery drain and possibly data drain. But then you have to take a photo of your receipt, the ENTIRE receipt, and send it to them from your phone. My first time doing this, it look me almost 20 minutes to scan the products and then get a complete photo of the receipt because you have to take multiple images of long receipts to get the entire thing.If the app doesn't recognize a barcode, you have to take a photo of the front of the product and send to them. I had an issue where the app didn't recognize any of the cases of soda I purchased, despite them being Pepsi products and not off-brands. And then when I took the obligatory photo of the front, the app wouldn't connect to actually send the photo. Lost out on that 20 cents, I guess.So I spend 30 minutes on the app completing tasks, and another 20 minutes scanning barcodes and copying my receipt all to earn...wait for it...$2.10!In addition, if you don't manually go in and change the defaults, the app constantly spams you with messages about everything. Every time a new item is added, or it wants to "remind" you of something you already completed a task for, or anything. The app sent me six alerts within a span of a few hours before I realized the default was set to SPAM-CRITICAL.You could easily, if you aren't careful, even up spending more on your phone's data plan overages than you would ever possibly earn.A better suggestion for deal seeking shoppers is Savingstar. I linked my grocery store loyalty card to the savingstar account and it automatically deposits my credits to my account without me having to watch videos, answer trivia, or fill out surveys. I've redeemed over $20 from them so far and money is transferred in only a couple of days to your Paypal account. It is a much easier, faster, and less invasive alternative to Ibotta.
Purchased these for the emergency lights in our facility. High quality battery that installed easily. No complaints.

This "rotary" organizer does not rotate. We purchased two for the office. Neither spins at all. Defeats the purpose of using a rotary organizer if the organizer doesn't actually rotate.The blade for the tape dispenser doesn't work well at all. It is impossible to dispense a piece of tape with one hand, and even if you hold the roll in place and use both hands it is a struggle.The design of the actual compartments is nice and it holds a lot of stuff in a small space, but all those compartments are useless if the item doesn't spin to access them.We'll be returning these items for a refund.

Very happy with the quality of this product. Unlike similar tablecloths, this one doesn't feel too thin or stiff. Drapes nicely around the corners of the table and doesn't slide like some polyester tablecloths.  Stood up to washing with no fuzzing around the hem or color fading.
Replacement thermostats for our office. Our maintenance guy was able to install them in about ten minutes and they work exactly as promised.

Purchased these to replace batteries in our AED device. The batteries did not come in Duracell packaging, but a small white box with a white label and barcode. But they are genuine Duracell batteries.with an expiration date of March 2023.

A heavy duty tool that is easy to use and easy to load. Hammer tacker cleanly releases staples with no jamming, and staples are flush to surface and don't require additional hammering or effort. Nice no-slip grip and solid construction.

For an inexpensive shelving solution, this does the trick. We picked up one of these for the office to use to store paper and shipping labels in the reception area. Assembly took all of five minutes. The tubes simply screw together and, amazingly, all of the shelf holes lined up correctly (this is NOT a foregone conclusion with cheap shelves!) Neutral colors blend in to your typical office environment. I wouldn't count on the shelves holding anything too heavy, but for light use such as files, books, and general office supplies this unit works nicely.

I actually acquired two different models of the door handle, the 23025-119 and the 23021-119.Both are sturdy, all-metal products with precision construction and an attractive satin finish. I was very impressed with the design of both models. Both are designed for interior doors. The Push, Pull, Rotate lock (23035) was installed on a bathroom door and the 23021-119 on the interior door leading to the basement.Despite the instructions claiming you only need a Phillips screwdriver, the installation was problematic because we were replacing the knobs on older wooden doors. The items did not fit properly in the existing holes after the original knobs were removed. A door hole saw was required to adjust the hole size in order to get the items to fit correctly. This may not be an issue with newer doors, but it is something to keep in mind if you are replacing knobs on older doors. Once the holes were adjusted, the installation took about fifteen minutes each.

I actually acquired two different models of the door handle, the 23025-119 and the 23021-119.Both are sturdy, all-metal products with precision construction and an attractive satin finish. I was very impressed with the design of both models. Both are designed for interior doors. The Push, Pull, Rotate lock (23035) was installed on a bathroom door and the 23021-119 on the interior door leading to the basement.Despite the instructions claiming you only need a Phillips screwdriver, the installation was problematic because we were replacing the knobs on older wooden doors. The items did not fit properly in the existing holes after the original knobs were removed. A door hole saw was required to adjust the hole size in order to get the items to fit correctly. This may not be an issue with newer doors, but it is something to keep in mind if you are replacing knobs on older doors. Once the holes were adjusted, the installation took about fifteen minutes each.

In the interest of disclosure, there is no way I would ever spend $200 of my own money on a keyboard. I didn't even realize how pricey this was when I saw the keyboard available through Vine. But IF I was going to throw down that kind of money on a keyboard, it would be this one. It is a thing of beauty. When it arrived, I thought there was a brick or something in the package because of the weight. I'm accustomed to keyboards that weigh about as much as a stapler. This thing has serious heft to it. The steel casing is streamline and sturdy.I confess to being a little confused at first because the wrapped cord included two USB cables and two audio plugs., which all need to be plugged into your computer.  One USB powers the keyboard, while the other is for the two USB ports on the keyboard itself. This is very convenient for charging devices or if you are using multiple thumb drives (like I often do when I am working on non-gaming projects). The audio plugs allow you to quickly switch between your speakers or a headset directly from the keyboard. Though the design threw me off at first, I quickly appreciated the ease with which I could switch between speakers and a headset.The keyboard also includes a set of extra keys and a tool to easily remove and replace keys. Besides the utility of customizing your keyboard, the tool will make cleaning the keyboard easy. (Admit it...I am NOT the only person who eats at the computer and sometimes gets crumbs on the keyboard!). The key design is highly responsive. There is a noticeable difference in performance.I didn't think I would like the backlighting, as I have sensitive eyes and I was worried the red backlight would be irritating. Instead, I find it a nice touch. You can set the backlight bright or dim or turn it off completely, based on your own preferences. There are also different settings that will only backlight certain gamer-centric sets of keys (like WASD and Function keys).I take back my initial statement. Before actually playing with this keyboard, I would never have thought to spend this much money on a keyboard. But if you consider how often the average hardcore gamer has to replace a keyboard and the exceptional performance of this unit, it is actually a good buy.
Purchased this item for the Whirlpool refrigerator at the office. Replacement part installed quickly and easily with no issues.

Note, Vine requires reviewers to review items within 30 days. This is not always enough time to really discover problems with a product. While I used the pruners for some light use before writing the review below, I didn't have a chance to really put them to the test until this weekend.Original review:I started gardening seriously last year and was thrilled to see this available in Vine. This is a well-constructed pruner with an easy to use safety lock and powerful, non-sticking blades. The handle design offers incredible comfort without losing pruning power...if you are right handed. The lower portion of the handle is set on a gear that partially rotates to alleviate stress on the hand. The problem is that the handle's movement is specific to the right hand. When trying to use the pruner in the left hand, the movement is awkward. Most of us lefties are accustomed to having to adapt to right-handed tools. But the unique design of the handle just doesn't work for lefties.Revised review:This weekend, I spent several hours using the pruners. Unfortunately, they do not hold up to sustained, heavy use. I was using these to prune back blueberry bushes that I had just planted and cut back some thin branches (1/4" diameter) on a flowering tree and bushes in the front yard. By the end of use, the sheers would not close properly to cut without wiggling the handle.Revised decision: pruners are fine for occasional light pruning, but serious gardeners that need a trustworthy pruner for more intensive work may be disappointed.

This was purchased as a gift item. Solid construction and good value. My mother wanted a travel blanket for when she and my dad travel for vacation and she said this works perfectly for her. Plugs in to the cigarette lighter for continuous heat. So long as momma is happy, I'm happy.

This is a revision of my review previous review.I took the original pod and planted it in a biodegradable container to start it in my windowsill. It did sprout and I thought it would grow. I went to the store and bought three more (one cherry tomato and two peppers) and put them in containers to start in my windowsill. The original pod later withered, and the three additional ones that I bought never grew.So people don't think it is just me killing plants: at the same time I put these in the windowsill, I also started snap beans and broccoli from seed. Both of those prospered and I just planted them in my garden. Only the groables failed to grow. I've been starting plants from seed for several years now in my windowsill and never had issue. Very disappointed.

When this item appeared on Vine, it did not specify it was for a specific camera system only. I was under the impression that it was a generic carry case for electronics. But the case is specifically designed for the GoPro camera. I just want to make that clear in case someone else stumbles across this and thinks they can use it for their own camera and such.That said, I've found use for the case anyway. The removable insert (which is cut specifically to hold and cushion the GoPro brand camera and accessories) pops out easily and you can use this as a general accessory case. The case is very sturdy and will hold up to being dropped, stepped on, or falling down a flight of steps (it was an accident. I swear). Interior zippered pouch adds to storage convenience. You can use this to create an "emergency" kit of first aid supplies, batteries, and other misc items to keep in your car, for example. Or use it to store cosmetics and other personal items that you don't want to get crushed when traveling. And of course, you CAN use it to store electronics even without the insert. Just wrap them in something with a little cushion and the case will do the rest.

While I like the smell of the shampoo, I can't say that it is anything exceptional to justify switching from less expensive brands. There is no noticeable difference in my hair for good or ill after using it for a few weeks. If I catch it on a good sale I might pick it up, but otherwise I would probably continue to use the less expensive brands I normally buy.

Had to stop taking it after a few days because I was getting nauseous. The nausea went away when I stopped taking. Last week I tried to start up the supplement again and again got nauseous. I'm obviously having a negative reaction to the supplement.

Emissary is a poignant and artfully crafted science fiction story that examines what it means to be human and the nature of free will. Author Chris Rogers paints a vibrant tale of loss, hope, struggle, and finding redemption where you least expect it.Ruell is an emissary, trained to merge his consciousness with a human host in the hopes of convincing humanity to offer his people sanctuary after their own planet was destroyed. He first merges with the president of the United States. But when that situation takes a turn for the worst he finds himself merged with an alcoholic cop named Kirk Longshadow. This is where the plot really takes off as the developing relationship between Ruell and Kirk is the best part of the story.Reviewer Note: I was given a comp copy of this book for review.

The fit could be a bit tighter around the sides, and the bottom edge had a slight bulge, and there's a small bit of mold flashing on one edge. Texture is a nice grippy matte that doesn't show fingerprints. Overall I'm happier with the similar LK case, it fits a little tighter and seems slightly higher quality.

I just needed something to protect a little against scuffs, and this is perfect. It fits nice and tight, looks good, and has a grippy texture on the edges and back. Unfortunately the "x" pattern on the back is shiny and smooth and shows fingerprints.The lip around the edge is helpful for using this with the type of Bluetooth keyboard that's got a slot to hold your device; the S2 is really thin so it tends to angle back pretty far - but with this case added the angle is more vertical and just right.

For phones, I prefer Android to iPhone, but until the S2, the iPad Air 2 was the best tablet I could find. But now I've replaced my iPad with this tablet and I'm totally happy that I did.Compared to the iPad Air 2, the Samsung is a hair smaller and thinner and lighter, but the screen looks to be the same size and resolution. Performance seems equally good. Although the base memory is limited to 32GB, you can add an SD card to get more memory.Battery life seems a little shorter than the iPad Air 2, but there are a few settings you can change that will improve it; you can enable power saving mode (it dims the screen a little and slows the processor down a bit), you can make Wi-Fi turn off when the tablet is sleeping, and you can also use the built in Smart Manager app to "optimize" apps that you don't use often so that they don't run at all  in the background until you need them again.There are a bunch of built-in Samsung apps that I didn't want but couldn't uninstall, although you can disable some of them. None of them seem to really be useful except for the aforementioned Smart Manager app.Samsung's TouchWiz skin on top of Android is not as ugly or clunky as on earlier products, but by default the first page on your home screen is the Flipboard "briefing" news page, which luckily you can turn off. Of course you can also replace TouchWiz launcher entirely if you want to; I installed Google Now Launcher because it puts all the contextual cards from Google Now on the first home screen page where you can get to them with just a swipte.Sound quality is good, the fingerprint reader works well, the screen is sharp and bright, and it runs every app I've tried just fine. It'll even let you run two apps side by side, similar to what you can do on newer iPads - but also similar to iPads, that feature only works with certain apps.Overall I'm very satisfied.P. S. If you do add an SD card, just plugging it in isn't enough; you then need to do two things make the system use it: First, for any apps that use a lot of storage - mainly ones that do a lot with photos, music, or video - open the app, go into its settings, and if there's a choice to use SD, make sure it's on. Second, go into system settings for apps and make sure that you've moved as many apps as possible to SD (this is only available for some apps and only lasts until the next time the app is updated).Also P. S. I ran into several apps which insist on running in portrait orientation instead of being able to handle both portrait and landscape. Luckily there's an app called Rotation Manager by Meerkat which will let you force any particular app to work in either or both orientations (there are actually several similar apps, but this was the only one I found that was both easy to use and which worked).

I used this with my Android tablet. I loved the full-width keyboard and the fact that it's substantial and sturdy. It's ideal for use in a lap or on a desk (it's heavy enough that it won't tip, but not uncomfortably so), but I think it's too bulky and heavy for something you would want to travel with. The only other downside I found, and it's minor, is that if you use it with a thinner-than-average device, the angle may tilt back further than optimal.I only used it with one device so I didn't' test the rotating selector switch although I think it's a nice simple and obvious way to switch. But there's also a pair of buttons on the other side of the keyboard that lets you select the device type; the problem is that if you accidentally tap the wrong button after setting up your device (which did happen a few times - they're near the backspace/delete keys), you might find that some keys act differently. The fix is easy however - just tap the other button.P.S. It came with batteries (two AAA) but they were dead.

I've never tried this type of case before, so maybe some of the things I didn't like about it are just "the way it is". First of all, the case itself is a bit heavy, I think because it's got magnets or metal in it so that the keyboard (which just sits on it when it's open) can "stick" to it. The next problem is that if you set up the keyboard and case for typing, you have to lift the keyboard off the case, move it, and set it back down before you close the case, so it's not a one-step process to close or open the case. Finally, the last thing I didn't like is that the keyboard layout puts the "Open Browser" button exactly where I expected to find the delete key. After opening the browser about 7 times instead of deleting, I had had enough. To be fair, on the plus side, the material looked and felt good inside and out, so if you don't mind the above issues you'll probably be happy.

This battery includes a built-in Motorola Keylink accessory, which is also available as a standalone smaller gadget. I purchased a Keylink a few months ago and it was a big disappointment. Its key- and phone-finding abilities only work over a short range (claimed to be 100 feet but actually less), it frequently disconnected from my phone even when they were close together, and the coin battery only lasted about a month instead of the year advertised.

Even when it's working perfectly, the Keylink really can only do two useful things in a limited way. First, if your phone and keys are within range of eachother, you can make the Keylink beep. Second (also if they're in range), you can skip needing to use a PIN to unlock your phone. According to Motorola the range is 100 feet, but I found it to be a lot less when indoors through walls and floors etc.There's a third thing you can do too, which is to use the Keylink to make your phone ring if you've misplaced it - but you don't need a Keylink to do that; just call your phone or use the Android Device Manager app/site to find it on a map - and that will work even if your phone is miles away.I already knew that the locating features were very limited, but I didn't mind since I really only was looking for the convenience of not needing to enter a PIN whenever I wanted to unlock my phone. At first that worked well with my Droid Turbo phone, but after a month, the feature became unreliable and I found I was often entering my unlock PIN, even though I had the Keylink in my pocket less than two feet away. If after PIN unlocking my phone I opened the Moto Connect app, the Keylink would show as disconnected, but then it would reconnect within a few seconds.Aside from the unreliable connection, another letdown was that I experienced nothing like the  one year advertised battery life. After a month of use, the battery level reported by the Moto Connect app was 8% - despite the fact that I kept the Keylink's "find my phone" setting turned off because that's supposed to save power. Maybe the connection started to degrade once the battery got too low, but if that's true, then I would have expected the Moto Connect app to warn me about the battery level, which it's supposed to do but didn't.I purchased from Motorola's website; all of these problems started just a few days after the 30 day return period, so I had to do a warranty replacement instead. Dealing with Motorola support to request a replacement was tedious. It took two email exchanges (containing some incorrect/vague info) and two phone calls (both involving being on hold and being transferred) over 4 days - and as far as I can tell this is their normal process!When I got the replacement unit, the first thing I did was discard the pre-installed generic battery and install a new name-brand one - to see if battery life will improve. I'll update this review when there's new info to report.

I've used this for a week and I haven't noticed any difference in what comes out or how long it takes. I think keeping up with your fiber intake will do more good than using this thing (which is also kind of bulky and medical-looking).

Our unit only measured 24x24 but this 28x28 cover fits fine. It looks sturdy and well made and should work to keep leaves out of our AC unit (I didn't want a full cover because I was worried that it would collect moisture).P.S. The cover comes with bungee cords to attach it. Pay attention to the warnings about wearing eye protection when attaching the bungee cords! I ended up using zip ties instead since trying to get the bungee cords hooked on the lower edge of my AC unit was a pain.

It looks good and is well put together. But the padding in the back is thin and stiff. The seat cushion is thick but not particularly soft, and it's also shallow front to back. Hopefully with use the padding will soften.

I expected this to be basically shaped and sewn up like a cube with no bottom, but one vertical seam on a corner is left open with rows of grommets that you can lace up with the included tie-cords. That was more of a hassle than I expected. Otherwise the material seems tough and looks fine.P.S. Anyone considering this kind of cover needs to keep in mind that it can trap moisture and provide a dry home for critters; I looked online and talked to my system installer and it seems like nobody thinks these are really necessary unless you live someplace where snow might pile up on and around the unit for weeks/months; outdoor AC units are made to face the elements. If you just want to prevent leaves from getting in through the top grating, you can buy a mesh cover for the top only.

We got this thermostat as part of an all-new furnace and AC install - all I had asked the installer company for was a "wireless thermostat". I'm glad and lucky I got this one!My favorite part is the optional assistant for programming the schedule; it asks a few easy questions (like "Is someone home all day", "When does the last person go to bed", etc.) and sets up your schedule that way - but you can also do it the old-fashioned way which isn't that much more difficult.The screen is large and clear and touch-sensitive all over. Information is easy to see and navigation is simple. Even though there are a lot more options, it's a lot easier to use than my old programmable thermostat. Clearly a lot of consideration and thought went into the design of this product.For convenience you can temporarily snap it off of its wall mount and use it in your lap, or at your desk, etc.Other things I like are the option for "circulate" on the fan, which will not only run it when heating/cooling, but also just at random times to keep the air from getting stale. And I also really like the compatibility with optional wireless REDLink accessories - I've added the Internet gateway so I can control the thermostat from anywhere from my smartphone, and I've also added an indoor remote temperature sensor (which I've put upstairs - the thermostat averages the temp from both locations to determine the "current" temp).P.S. Some advanced users will want to mess with the installer options - if you do, you'll need the password - it's a 4 digit number and the default password is printed on the model number sticker inside the battery compartment.

It's small and unobtrusive, about the size of a travel computer mouse. It uses 2 AAA batteries that are included. Connecting it to the thermostat was easy, there's a connect button inside the battery compartment (no other controls other than a LED light that I've never seen turn on). It seems like once it's connected, the thermostat uses the average of the temp at the sensor and the temp at the thermostat to figure out the "current" temp.P. S. Some reviews have said that this will "even out" heating/cooling in your home, but it doesn't work that way; if your HVAC system has problems getting heat or cold to some parts of your home, that will not change. By adding this gadget all you are doing is making your thermostat get a more accurate - but still AVERAGE - reading of your home's temperature. So for instance if you install this someplace that's always too cool in winter, that area will get warmer in winter, but so will every other part of your house; similarly if you put it someplace that's always too hot in summer, that area will get cooler in summer, but so will the rest of your house.

Super painless setup. The instructions are clear and easy. You plug it into your router, enter info from its label onto the honeywell website, set your thermostat to connect mode and press the connect button.

It works well for me as a booster during peak pollen periods, on top of my usual Zyrtec or Allegra. And unlike some similar steroid sprays I've never had problems with nosebleeds.But there's a downside too. After 2-3 months of daily use (only one spray per nostril per day) I ended up with nearly nonstop headaches, which went away a day after I stopped using Nasacort.From now on I'll only use it if the misery of peak allergy season outweighs the misery of headaches!

I recently had a small inguinal hernia (eventually got it fixed with surgery). Before that I did a lot of research and learned that hernias do not heal on their own, and therefore can only either stay the same or get worse. If your hernia isn't very bothersome then I guess this book can't hurt (neither would wearing a truss), but even if you think your hernia has healed, it probably hasn't. Some hernias can play hide & seek and don't always bulge out.P. S. Another reviewer said that surgery stitches the hole closed. As far as I'm aware, most hernia repair surgery these days in fact does not do that, but instead staples or stitches in a mesh patch to cover the hole. Scar tissue eventually forms around the mesh, strengthening the area even more.

It's amazing what you get for $50, but I still wouldn’t recommend this as anyone’s only tablet - mainly because of the screen’s low resolution, the so-so battery life, the lack of voice input (except inside apps that offer it), and the mediocre cameras.Another downside is that the Amazon app store feels like a time warp compared to Android's Google Play store: Amazon has fewer apps and games, and sometimes only older versions (but on the plus side, more of them are free).Still, there are unexpected benefits considering the price, including decently snappy performance, bluetooth, SD card slot, and parental controls. Although it looks simple and chunky, it doesn't look cheap and it feels sturdy and well put together.The operating system and user interface is based on Android, so another benefit is that it's simple to use, and if you have used Android on other devices it'll feel familiar.The main differences compared to Android are 1) there are no official Google apps - but there are mostly decent substitutes preinstalled and available in Amazon's app store, and 2) once you flip past the first home screen with the usual grid of app icons and folders (but no widgets or shortcuts), the remaining screens are storefronts for Amazon products and services (such as music, books, etc.).Overall this is a great tablet for what it costs, but it shouldn’t be your only tablet unless you're on a severe budget. However for the kids, or for grandma, or as something cheap to travel with, you can't really go wrong.P.S. I bought one mainly out of curiosity and ended up returning it. I was thinking it could be handy for travel compared to my more valuable and bulky iPad, but I decided that a basic unlocked Android phone is even better as a travel device: it's smaller, has a better selection of apps, and it can work as an affordable phone if you put a local SIM card in it. Yes it costs more than $50, but it's still cheaper than an iPad and many tablets (for instance as of late 2015 the basic Moto E is under $100 and the nicer Moto G is about $150).
Works great with all of my fake sticker appliances and fake sticker phone chargers.

For the price they can't be beat. They are a bit softer than the original Philips brush heads (which I don't mind), otherwise the only practical difference is that the blue bristles - which should fade to tell you when to replace the brush - never do fade. Not a big deal for me; I just replace them every couple of months regardless.The only other differences, which I don't care about, is that they don't come with the little transparent plastic covers, and there are no extra colored rings (but each head does come with a colored ring attached).

Our old furnace finally died, so I got this DeLonghi to heat our bedroom while we wait for the furnace to be replaced. On the plus side, it's small, it puts out a lot of heat, and it's odorless and noiseless (no ticks or pings).But there are a few minor things I don't like about it... first, instead of a simple dial to control the power, it has two power switches which you can use individually or in different combinations together (for low, medium, high), and there's only a 100 watt difference between the low and medium settings.Second, it's got a thermostat dial, but there's also a "comfortemp" button that the instructions say will "...reach and keep the suggested ideal temperature". There's no explanation of how this button works together with the dial, so I ignored the button and just used the dial since it works as I expect - plus the "comfortemp" button turns on a bright green light that I don't want at night in the bedroom.P.S. To people who are confused about this being an oil heater - this heater is electric and has to be plugged in. The oil is not burned - it's just there to help spread the heat around evenly inside the heater, and it increases the amount of heat given off while the heater isn't actively running. The oil is sealed inside; you can't see it or smell it and there is no way to get at it.

I'm not using this for the fast charging, but rather for security when charging in sketchy situations like from USB at a charger kiosk or in an airplane.It's also the only way I can charge my Kindle Paperwhite from USB on a plane and also still use the Kindle. That's because the airplane USB apparently makes the Kindle think a computer is connected, so the Kindle goes into a mode where it won't do anything and wrongly assumes you are using your PC to access its memory.

So far it's keeping the rugs in place, despite our crazy cats tearing around at night - the old thin pads didn't work at all, even though the floor was sticky under them when I threw them out.It has good grip without feeling sticky, and it's thick enough that it adds a just-noticeable amount of cushion.It's too early to know if these pads will also end up sticking to the floor or leaving a residue; I'll update this review later on.

I got this for the rare occasions when I'm in a hotel that has ethernet but no WiFi (or bad WiFi). I haven't tried it in that situation yet, but it was cheap enough and small enough that I figured it was worth grabbing one and keeping it in my travel bag.I did successfully hook it up to my home router via ethernet just to make sure it worked, and yes I got it to create a WiFi network that my iPad could connect to and get online.The instructions are a bit vague, and the device's setup web page - although attractive and simple looking - is also a bit unclear about some settings - but it wasn't that hard to figure it out eventually.To get it to work as a basic wireless access point i.e. plug it into ethernet and use its WiFi (which is what most people will use it for), you have to move the switch on the side to the "wired" position (it shipped with it in the other position).I haven't tried the mobile app or the USB storage options and I probably won't.

Regarding other reviews for this item, I find it very suspicious that most of the people who got it for free liked it, but most of the people who paid their own money think it's junk. Draw your own conclusions about what that really means. ;-)Anyway... I bought this (despite the sketchy reviews) because I needed a big, realistic looking model of a plane for a stage production, and I didn't want to pay an outrageous amount of money (seriously, a good quality real model this size will cost something like $200 if you can even find it).Pros: it's big and it looks realistic (except for the lump under the wings with the motor and wheels).Cons are pretty much everything else:- The electronics were dead. I tried two different sets of batteries but couldn't get any lights, sounds, or motor operation.- Fit and finish is poor. Parts don't line up perfectly, some surfaces look grungy or scuffed.- One wing is more curved/bent than the other.- The motor under the wings is mounted slightly off center so the whole thing sits slightly tilted to one side (and the bent wing doesn't help).- Each wing has a big sticker on it that says "AIRPLANE", which looks very dumb (the other stickers look OK).- The stand is thin plastic (not metal as some other reviewers have stated), and it's kind of teetery.

This is a shoddy no-name toy of the type sold in dollar stores, worth maybe 2 or 3 dollars at most. It even comes in a plastic bag labeled "TOYS".It's made of regular plastic, not fiberglass. It comes with garish stickers already applied; the wings and tail need to be snapped on. It's got lumpy chromed wheels, the two halves of the body don't fit together perfectly, the wings are loose in their sockets and droop, and one had an engine already broken off.It looks like the rest of it would break or fall apart the first time a kid played with it - and that's all it's good for; it's certainly not a model/replica that you would want to preserve or proudly display.The only good things I can say are that the proportions look like a real airliner (except for the friction motor and wheels) and it has molded-in details that add some realism, like the windows, doors, wing flaps, etc.P.S. You can see most of the problems mentioned above if you zoom the product photos and look carefully.

These put out a very warm light, so they're most suitable for "relaxing" type areas like bedrooms or living rooms, but less so for kitchens, bath, etc.Unlike previous dimmable LED bulbs I've used, the light color also gets warmer as you dim them more, the way an old-school incandescent bulb does. The previous LED bulbs I used just got less bright but kept their cool color, which looked weird although it made sense.But unlike incandescent bulbs they don't dim down as far; at a certain point where I wish they would get a bit dimmer, they just turn off. But it's a low enough level of light that I'm OK with it.Another minor issue is that I have two of them in one fixture, and when I dim them all the way down, one will shut off before the other. I think this is pretty common with LEDs since I had the same thing happen with the previous LED bulbs I was using in the same lamp.

I didn't buy this set, but they are available separately and I did buy one. Here's my review of it:...This is a shoddy no-name toy of the type sold in dollar stores. It's worth maybe $2 or $3 at most; it even comes in a plastic bag labeled "TOYS".It's made of regular plastic, not fiberglass. It comes with garish stickers already applied; the wings and tail need to be snapped on. It's got lumpy chromed wheels, the two halves of the body don't fit together perfectly, the wings are loose in their sockets and droop, and one had an engine already broken off.It looks like the rest of it would break or fall apart the first time a kid played with it - and that's all it's good for; it's certainly not a model/replica that you would want to preserve or proudly display.The only good things I can say are that the proportions look like a real airliner (except for the friction motor and wheels) and it has molded-in details that add some realism, like the windows, doors, wing flaps, etc.P.S. You can see most of the problems mentioned above if you zoom the product photos and look carefully.

This is a shoddy no-name toy of the type sold in dollar stores. It's worth maybe $2 or $3 at most; it even comes in a plastic bag labeled "TOYS".It's made of regular plastic, not fiberglass. It comes with garish stickers already applied; the wings and tail need to be snapped on. It's got lumpy chromed wheels, the two halves of the body don't fit together perfectly, the wings are loose in their sockets and droop, and one had an engine already broken off.It looks like the rest of it would break or fall apart the first time a kid played with it - and that's all it's good for; it's certainly not a model/replica that you would want to preserve or proudly display.The only good things I can say are that the proportions look like a real airliner (except for the friction motor and wheels) and it has molded-in details that add some realism, like the windows, doors, wing flaps, etc.P.S. You can see most of the problems mentioned above if you zoom the product photos and look carefully.

This is really handy for use on airplanes with USB plugs.
