Last time I flew I wanted to juice up my Kindle reader, but as soon as I plugged it in, the Kindle went into USB connection mode and there was no way to exit and keep reading!I haven't yet tried this on a plane, but I did just try it to plug my Kindle into my PC, and my Kindle is happily charging and it is NOT in USB mode.I'm going to make sure I keep this cable in my travel kit.

I had a small hernia that only bothered me sometimes. I was going to be waiting a month until I could get surgery, so I got this to tide me over.At least for me, I found that whether I was happier with or without it on was unpredictable and depended on whether I was active or not, whether I was doing a lot of standing and moving or lying around and relaxing, etc.I still would recommend it since it did help me sometimes, and when it did cause discomfort, it was easy to remove.It's got a pocket with a removable rounded dense foam insert that presses on the hernia bulge area. For my small hernia I was happier without the insert.P.S. I wear 32 or 33 waist pants, so I ordered the medium size, but it's almost too small. If your waist is closer to 34 or 35 you would be better off with a large.Also P.S. If you are planning to use the belt before and after surgery, there is another sizing consideration: It's not uncommon to experience abdominal swelling after hernia surgery that can add an inch or two to your waist, and which can take months to fully resolve. That happened to me - nearly a month later and I'm still swollen although it's getting better slowly.

These are well made, very handy in the kitchen for keeping bags of chips, coffee, cookies, rice, etc. etc. etc. securely shut.They clip together to save space when you're storing them before use, and have strong magnets in case you want to use them to hang up notes etc.And the colors are fun!

It's totally quiet (no buzzing even when first turned on), there is no odor even on first use, and it puts out a lot of heat.I did check that it shuts off if tipped over, so that's a plus!Of course for the cheap price (I paid less than $20) it's to be expected that it's lightweight, mostly plastic, and wobbles a tiny bit even on a flat surface.Also the controls could have been easier to use - you have to pay attention to see what you're setting it to. It's got a knob that just turns endlessly, and every setting (off, 400W, 800W) is duplicated twice, and it's difficult to see the molded in arrow that points to the setting you want (you can see what I'm talking about if you zoom in on the photo and look at the knob on the top).

(Note: This is a review of the ProFusion H-5511 heater which seems to be identical except for the color)It's totally quiet (no buzzing even when first turned on), there is no odor even on first use, and it puts out a lot of heat.I did check that it shuts off if tipped over, so that's a plus!Of course for the cheap price (I paid less than $20) it's to be expected that it's lightweight, mostly plastic, and wobbles a tiny bit even on a flat surface.Also the controls could have been easier to use - you have to pay attention to see what you're setting it to. It's got a knob that just turns endlessly, and every setting (off, 400W, 800W) is duplicated twice, and it's difficult to see the molded in arrow that points to the setting you want (you can see what I'm talking about if you zoom in on the photo and look at the knob on the top).

I'm only using one ring and it seems to do the job.So far I've been using the same ring for 2 months, pulling and stretching it every time I put on or take off my Charge (at least 2x/day), and it hasn't broken or loosened and shows no signs of wear. At this rate I'm sure my Charge will die before I go through all of these rings.The only thing I don't like is that the rings are just a tad smaller than they need to be, and fit REALLY tight.

I ordered two and both have the same problem - the latch is very weak; only the slightest pressure or bump and the box can open.As a test I dropped each one three times (empty and closed) onto a tile floor from kitchen countertop height. They opened every time.So if you do want to travel with this, I highly recommend putting a rubber band around it just in case - or just use it to hold small items at home where it can sit on a shelf.Other info: the plastic seems tough and slightly flexible; the white color is fine, and the size is 3 1/2" wide, 2 1/4" deep, and 3/4" high. Each of the 6 compartments is 1"x1"x3/4" (a bit less than a cubic inch).

This is my 4th case for this phone and definitely my favorite.Compared to the Diztronic it's a hair thicker and the edges are rounder, making it more comfortable to hold; I think it also looks a little better because the shiny accents near the top and bottom on the back add some visual interest to the otherwise smooth matte back.I also tried the VSTN case which was pretty similar to the Diztronic in thickness and appearance, although the VSTN had little dimples across the entire back which made it look a bit more interesting (unfortunately the VSTN case didn't properly fit my phone - that was before they figured out that it wouldn't fit the nylon version of the phone).And the first case I had was a no-name, ugly (hex patterned), but very thick case I bought at the Verizon store when I got the phone. It definitely was tough but I didn't like the look at all.

This diztronic case is a bit thinner than other cases I've had on this and previous phones, but that's OK since I'm mainly looking for something that just keeps the phone from getting scuffed up.It's got simple and unassuming looks, with a matte finish that's semi-grippy. Cut-outs line up fine with various openings, and the power and volume bumped-out buttons are easy to feel and operate.But there are several minor issues (see photo):1. The case is a little uneven around the micro USB connector2. A fair bit of the phone's "chin" at the front bottom isn't covered by the case, although it still looks protected.3. The edges of the case around the screen are semi-sharp corners instead of being rounded, so it gets a little uncomfortable to hold for a long time.4. There's a mold blemish near the bottom.

This certainly is the highest quality heater fan I've owned so far (I think this is my 4th or 5th).But it's also got the lowest heat output of all of them. The fan has only one quiet low speed, and air comes out warm not hot, so it takes longer to warm up even a small room - even though it does move a large volume of air.The controls are simple - power switch, thermostat dial, and switch for selecting 3 different levels of heat. They're physical switches, so it can be powered on/off from a timer or a wall switch (unlike products that have electronic touchpad controls).Note: The 2-prong cord is black, which doesn't look that great except in a utility room. It would be better if it was beige or white.

UPDATE: After 3 months I decided this wasn't the right tracker for me and I replaced it with the smaller and simpler Fitbit Zip. Here are the reasons I switched:- It needed to be recharged every 3 or 4 days, using a proprietary cable that I always worried I would lose (the Zip's battery lasts 6 months).- The clasp to close the strap was always a hassle - difficult to close, and it occasionally unexpectedly opened (the Zip just clips on).- I didn't end up using any of the extra features like caller ID or sleep tracking or silent alarms anyway (the Zip doesn't have those - that's probably why its battery can last for months).- I just wasn't crazy about how it looked on my wrist (the Zip is more unobtrusive).---------------------Here's my original review:I got this as a Christmas present in 2014. I started with the small size and exchanged for the large after a week. Here are my impressions after about 3 weeks:Pro tips:- If your wrist size is exactly in between needing a small vs a large (as indicated by the size guide on the box), go with the large; otherwise the fit will be very snug and it'll be difficult to close the strap.- Make sure you set your "dominant wrist" in app settings, otherwise your step count will be less accurate.- Similarly, it's a good idea to measure your stride length and update that too (on the fitbit website), because until I did that it underestimated my walking mileage by about 10%.Pros:- It's light and has a comfortable fit; I usually don't even notice I'm wearing it.- The display is bright and easy to read.- The app is attractive and easy to use, and even if you have your fitbit synced to your phone, you can still install the app on a 2nd device (iPad for instance) and manage your fitbit from there too.- The sleep tracking is cool and it starts and stops automatically (although it's not perfect, see below).- The stair-climbing detection seems to work most of the time, and it's eye-opening to see how many times I'm actually going up and down the stairs at home (more than I thought).- Battery life is good and as advertised; I wear it all the time and have to charge roughly every 5 days.Cons (experienced with both units):- The clasp is difficult to close (unless you want a very loose fit) and comes too easily undone (today I thought I'd lost the fitbit but found it in the sleeve of my jacket).- The double-tapping gesture is unreliable, but it seems to have the best chance of working if I double-tap above the display window.- Caller ID is slow.- If you lie in bed a while before you fall asleep, it can still count that as "sleeping". Similarly, if you don't get out of bed right after waking up, it can count that as "restless" sleeping.- After a workout there's sweat inside the charging connector which is a small recessed hole with corners that are hard to reach to wipe it out - I'm wondering if long term that's a spot where crud will build up.- The latest updates to the android app have lost a few minor useful features like adding foods to your favorites (or if the feature is there, I can't find it).- Fitbit support is friendly and responsive, but fairly clueless. I asked for help with the Android app and they responded as if I had asked about the website, then when I clarified they referred to features that were only in an older version of the app.
I was tired of my dried, dull, cracked ant eggs. I started applying this and now I have shiny, healthy moisturized ant eggs!

The one I got simply didn't work; powered it on, adjusted the frequency to minimum and maximum, but no flashing at all.Lens diameter is about 6 or 7 inches.The housing and bracket are plastic but seem sturdy, and the grounded power cord is decently long (maybe 4-5 feet).'This is going back and I probably won't try another one since I also ordered a Chauvet strobe light which is working fine.
After 3 years of light use, the left side Ctrl key has become harder to press and often doesn't register unless pressed really hard. Time to replace it I guess.

I got this for my cat; she likes it a little too much! For some reason she chews the inner lining to rip holes in it and pull out the stuffing. This is the only thing in my house (so far, knock on wood) that she does this to, so there must be something particularly appealing to her about the mouth feel or the flavor?Anyway, aside from my cat loving to chew it up, it's a good size, looks nice (before it got chewed), and is fluffy and soft and comfy.

Most T-shirts are made with fabric that's too thin and lightweight for my taste; this one is definitely on the heavier side, although it's still light enough for warm weather. The stitching seems to be good quality, and overall it seems like a shirt that's going to last and look and feel good. Fit is good (I'm an M) though I think it's a little long, but I would prefer that to having the whole thing being baggy (and anyway, if you tuck it in, having a longer shirt helps avoid the dreaded "plumber's butt").

The idea is good, since you can hang it almost anyplace and it's the right hight for most cats, but my cats totally ignored it - even though they love scratching their (also vertical) sisal scratching posts. I think maybe the problem is that the surface just doesn't look "scratchy". It feels somewhat like papier-mache and it looks like solid lumpy concrete, rather than something with fibers that they can get their claws into.Of course as with all offerings made to cats by their human slaves, your mileage may vary depending upon the whims of your cat.

The only thing that was a little disappointing is that the dangling cat toys shown in the photo, though included, are listed in the instructions as "for display only" and there isn't even a way to attach them (I guess I could staple them, but that would last ten seconds with my cats). However, that's not a big deal and I think they'll make decent little toys for the cats to just bat around on the floor.Otherwise I'm very happy with this. It's sturdy, easy and quick to assemble (only one tool needed and it's included), and the cats love it. I could have gotten an even more robust tree from a local maker but it would have one heavy piece that would have been tough to haul up the stairs!

This is the third - and so far best - indoor antenna I've tried. Before this one I had tried two other similar flat & amplified (but not flexible) antennas - a Terk FDTV1A and an RCA ANT1650R (the Terk was a little better).My house is on a hill about 50 miles from most of the local transmitters, and the TV is on the 2nd floor. All three antennas pulled in the same number of stations (roughly 20), but the Mohu is the only one that's able to usually (but not always) get every channel with no glitches - with the others, there were always 2 or 3 channels that almost always had glitches, if they would come in at all.The Mohu came with a longer cable than the other antennas, and I think that helped a lot with the reception; it allowed me to locate the antenna higher up on the wall - but even so, I did need to reposition it several times before I found a satisfactory location.Besides the longer cable, the Mohu's got several other benefits compared to the other antennas I tried:- The amplifier is USB powered, so if your TV has a USB port in the back (mine does) you don't need to use up an extra outlet for yet another USB power adapter (but one is included if you need it).- The antenna is very flat (no thicker than maybe 3-4 sheets of paper), so you could stick it to a wall. They include sticky velcro mounts and pushpins; I tried sticking it with carpet tape but it didn't hold.- It's white on one side and black on the other, so if you mount it white side out it's not that much of an eyesore (I'm not sure why they didn't just make it all white - how many people have a black wall?)------6 MONTH UPDATE: There were always a couple of channels that never came in clearly, especially during bad weather. So I finally bit the bullet and installed a GE attic antenna. Even though it's only about 3 feet higher up, it's about 4 times larger in "intercept" area, and the fringe stations are now rock solid. Moral of the story: unless you're already getting perfect reception, a higher/bigger antenna will always be better.

I had been using this with a small hot tub. It was in an outdoor location (on the outer wall of my house), inside an outdoor receptacle cover to keep it dry.  It died after 4 months (from June to September), although there was no sign of moisture or corrosion inside the cover which was always closed. The previous plug from the same manufacturer died after about a year of use in the same location. This time I've replaced it with a more well known brand (Leviton); hopefully it'll be higher quality.

Not much to say about these - they were exactly as they appeared in the photo although I got more of the blah colors (red, white, black) compared to the more "fun" colors. Nothing is printed or embossed on them.

I put this on my desk to try to keep the kittens off. I guess it's functioning because the LED blinks, but they happily keep walking around, just inches from the front of the unit. These kittens react to all sorts of other sounds, so I don't think there's anything wrong with their hearing.Note: Someone commented that this product is often not effective on cats younger than a year old because they can't hear frequencies that high. So I'm going to keep it and see if it works later. If things improve, I'll update the review.

This pattern/flush trim bit has a lot going for it.  To start with, it has a 1/2" shank and the cutting diameter is 3/4", which is much more useful for pattern work than the typical flush trim bit with a 1/4" shank.  The cutting length is 1 31/32" and it has bearings on both the top and bottom.  This is great because sometimes it's you can have the pattern on either the top or bottom, depending on the design and fixture you're using.Yes, it's expensive, but the carbide cutting knives are replaceable.  Strangely, the replacement cutting inserts (P/N 790.500.00) are not available in Amazon, but you can get them, along with bearings (P/N 791.007.00 and 791.011.00) and other replacement parts, from Router Bit World.Each carbide insert has 2 cutting edges and they cost less than $4.00 each.  So, first of all, you get the equivalent of 2 first class pattern bits with the initial purchase and then you can renew the edges for about $4.00 a pop.  If you do a lot of pattern work, this bit will quickly pay for itself.I'm using this bit with a PORTER-CABLE 75182 Variable Speed Router Motor in a router table with an INCRA Mast-R-Lift-II Router Lift.  The bit is smooth and stable.  I've used it for about 8 hours, cutting hundreds of 3/4" thick pieces to a pattern.  The cut surface is extremely smooth; completely free of chatter.  The inserts are still new, but I've had zero trouble cutting with or against the grain.  No chip out climbing out of a dip against the grain.  This may change as the inserts dull, but so far so good.

I bought the Porter-Cable 7518 for use in a custom router table that I had built, equipped with an INCRA Mast-R-Lift-II Router Liftand an iGaging DigiMAG 6" Magnetic Remote Digital Readout.  I wanted a powerful, precise motor capable of driving both large diameter panel raising bits and very small precision bits.The first thing I did after I unpacked the 7518 was to set it up to measure the Total Indicated Runout (TIR) of both the spindle and the collets.  I was surprised to find a runout of 0.0015" on the spindle, which IMO, is not acceptable.  I was even more shocked when I measured the runout of bit shanks held by the collets.  Bits held in the 1/2" collet had TIR ranging from 0.006" to 0.012".  Bits held in the 1/4" collet had TIR ranging from 0.002" to 0.005".  Again, this is not acceptable IMO.  The problem with excessive runout is that at the speeds these motors turn, it produces vibrations that can make the router difficult to control, noisy and cause the bearings to fail prematurely.  It can also cause bit breakage if the TIR is 10% or more of the bit diameter.I consulted with someone in the industry who has a great deal of experience with PC (and other) motors and collets.  He had never seen a 7518 with a TIR as high as I had measured.  So, I guess it was either an anomaly or my measurement was off.  He did agree that the TIR I had measured for the PC collets was typical of what he has seen.  I decided to return the 7518 for a replacement.The replacement arrived a few days later. Thank you Amazon for shipping the replacement before receiving my return.  This time, my measurement of the spindle TIR was less than 0.0005", so I figured the first one was just a bad apple.  The 1/2" collet that came with the router was no better than the first one, with TIR's measuring up to 0.012".There is another problem with the PC collets.  I had a great deal of difficulty getting bits in and out of the 3 examples I received (two 1/2" and one 1/4", which I ordered separately).  The final straw came with the last bit I tested on the second 7518 I received.  It was a brand new, 1/2" shank Whiteside bit, with the protective coating still in place, covering the cutting edges.  I struggled to get it into the collet and when I tried to remove it, I had to use so much force that the protective coating came off the bit and my thumb slid along the cutting edge, cutting it very deeply.  After dealing with the medical emergency, I looked closely at the interior bore of the collet with a loupe.  I was surprised to see a significant number of burrs attached to the slots in the bore.  I went to work on the collet with needle files and some 1000 grit wet/dry paper and eventually got it to the point where I could get bits in and out without too much trouble.I was so disappointed with the PC collets that I replaced them with after market collets made by precisebits.com.  I won't go into detail here, but these collets have about one tenth the TIR of the PC collets and are truly precision parts.  Check them out if, like me, you find the PC collets lacking.My experience so far with the 7518 motor couldn't be more different than my experience with the PC collets.  It has the power to do anything I've asked of it.  With the new collets, it runs very smoothly.  When I run large diameter bits, it's also noticeably quieter than with the PC collets, although it's still a pretty noisy machine.  Hearing protection required.Since I immediately installed the 7518 in the router table I haven't used the base that comes with it, so I can't comment on it.I was in a quandary about the number of stars to award the 7518.  I decided not to penalize it for the lousy collets, since I'm not going to use them.  I do like the motor and decided to give a split rating in the title.  I only have a couple of weeks experience with the 7518, but I will update the review in a year or so.

I bought these because they were inexpensive, and cheap they are, but not a good value.  The viewing area is small, the frames are fragile and uncomfortable.  I have little doubt that they will break quickly.A much better value, even though they are more expensive, is the Spring Hinge Plastic Reading Glasses (5 Pairs), Includes Sunglass Readers.

I bought the Bradshaw International 19880 3 piece measuring cup set to use in my hobbies, and gardening.  It's a set that I use when mixing paint, mortar, fertilizers and so on.  There marks are easy-to-read and are in both OZ and ML.  Unfortunately, those easy-to-read markings are not terribly accurate.  I checked the 1  QT/1 L cup by filling it to the top line and weighing the contents.  The amount of water poured to the 1 Liter line was 2.4% higher than it should have been.  The results on the 1 quart line were worse: 7.8% high.Another negative for these cups is the way the handle is molded into the body, there is a dip in the edge of the body that follows the contour of the handle.  That means that you can't fill the cups anywhere near to the top without liquid spilling out along the top of the handle.  Take the example of the 1 Liter cup.  When you fill it to the 1 Liter line, the lip of the cup is about 1 1/16" (27mm) above the liquid.  However, the outlet at the top of the handle is only 3/16" (4.8mm) above the liquid.  This means you have to be very careful moving the cup or the liquid will run out over the top of the handle.I would not choose these cups to use in my kitchen because of the inaccurate measurements. I also prefer to use glass measuring cups in the kitchen because I trust that glass is less likely to add unwanted substances to my food.

The MSI-PRO 225-D 51120 toggle clamps, are sturdy and well made.  There are no sharp edges and the action is smooth.  The rubber foot has an adjustment range perpendicular to the clamp of about 1 1/8".  The slot in the clamp allows an adjustment of about 1 1/8" parallel to the clamp.  The base has holes for four 1/4" attachment bolts.  I drilled mine out to fit the 5/16" bolts I had on hand and didn't run into any problems.  The clamps will exert a lot of force which can be increased or decreased by raising and lowering the rubber foot.I'm using a pair of the MSI-PRO  clamps to attach a sacrificial fence to the Biesemeyer fence on my Delta Unisaw.  I recently added a router table to this saw, so I'm using the fence for the router as well, and router fences often need to be milled or split, something that's not recommended for the Biesemeyer.If I needed a tall or sacrificial fence in the past, I would attach it to the Biesemeyer with some bar clamps.  This works, but it's slow to set up and the clamps are often in the way.I made a fence with a piece of MDF and made some 3 3/4" x 1 1/2" x 3" blocks to attach the toggle clamps to the MDF with bolts (the bolt holes in the MDF are counterbored for the bolt heads).  It's pretty slick: I can attach the auxiliary fence in a few seconds and remove it just as quickly.Bottom line: the MSI-PRO toggle clamps are well made and useful around the shop.

I exaggerate only slightly.  I recently converted my carport to a garage with an overhead door.  There were a couple of issues with this.  First, the carport slab had no little step down at the overhead door line, as most slabs poured for a garage would have.  Second, the slab had a slope built into it from side to side, so it was 1 1/2" higher on the left side of the door than on the right.I talked to the manufacturer of the door about the slope issue.  They said that the door had to be installed level, not parallel to the slab. To fill the gap on the right side of the door, they advised me to stuff the right end of the U shaped gasket on the bottom of the door something like a slice of a pool noodle to compensate for the slope.  I did my best to a cut a tapered wedge out of the noodle about 6 feet long and pushed it into the gasket.  It did look pretty good.  I could see just a sliver of light under the far right end of the door, but other than that, it seemed to fill the gap.The next day, we had 2" of rain and water flowed under the door along almost the entire length and there was a torrent on the right side, between the door and wall.  I looked outside to see what was going on and saw that the rain pouring off the roof and falling in front of the door was ponding almost an inch deep along the whole length of the door.  Part of the trouble was the slab itself.  Because it was not exactly as smooth as glass, the seal really couldn't do its job.  I live in South Florida and torrential rainfall is a common occurrence in the summer months.  I had visions of my newly created garage workshop flooding several times a week.In a panic, I did a search and found the Storm Shield Garage Door Threshold.  It looked like it might help, so I ordered it immediately.  My door is 12' - 2" wide and the 16' threshold I ordered measured just over 17'.  I cut it to length and installed it according to the instructions.  The 2 tubes of liquid nails that came with it were just enough to make the beads described in the instructions.  If you have a 16' door, I recommend that you pick up an extra tube of liquid nails, just to be sure you don't run out.  In addition to the liquid nails, I ran a bead of silicone caulk along the edge of the threshold to seal it.  I also cut up some pieces of leftover threshold and made a dam at each end of the threshold, blocking the space between the threshold and the wall, and caulking the spaces as needed.Since I installed it, there have been a number of downpours, but not a drop has entered the garage.  I am so happy!

Our delightful kitty 'Skittles' will not be contained by ordinary window screens.  She's shredded 4 of them that blocked her favorite escape routes.  In about a minute, she can make a cat-sized hole and she's outta here.  It's been a nightmare here in South Florida.  We can't open our windows on hot nights because every flying and crawling critter comes right in through the giant holes in the screens.In desperation, I bought the NY Wire Pet D-Fence Screening to see if it would help.  Installation was pretty easy, but you really do need a screen roller tool.  I got mine from a big box store, but you can also get them on Amazon: New York Wire 90611 2-Wheel Wood Handle Screen Tool.  For the first 2 screens I reused the old retainer spline, but that was very tough because the Pet D-Fence Screening is thicker than normal screen material and it required a LOT of force to push it in place.  For the second 2 screens, I bought a length of 1/8" (0.125") screen spline from a big box store  (you can also get it on Amazon: New York Wire 1/8-in x 300-in Black Screen Spline- 98015 ).  This made the installation process a lot easier.To do the installation, first pull out the old spline and remove the old, shredded screen.  Set the empty frame on a surface large enough to support the whole frame.  Next, unroll the Pet D-Fence screen, lay it on the aluminum frame and trim it to overhang 1" - 2" on all 4 sides.Place the spline on top of the screen, over the groove in the frame and begin pushing the spline into the groove at one corner.  It will help the installation and the final appearance if you carefully line up the strands of screen wire (not the cut edge of the screen) parallel to the groove.  Work your way around the frame, lightly pulling the screen taut with one hand while pushing the spline into the groove with the tool in the other hand.  Make sure the hand you are using to pull the screen is in the same line as the tool and do not pull hard.  You only need a light touch to keep the screening straight.  Depending on the design of the frame, you may be able to go completely around the frame with a single piece of spline, meeting up at the original corner.  Once the spline is installed, carefully trim the excess screen with a sharp box cutter.If any leg of the aluminum frame is bent and kinked, just throw the whole thing away.  For $10 you can get a frame kit at one of the big box stores or Amazon and make a completely new screen.  I had to do this with 2 of my screens and it was no problem.I installed the Pet D-Fence screening about a month ago.  Little Skittles has made a couple of runs at it, but so far, it's completely unscathed.  I have a good feeling about this.  The Pet D-Fence screening is slightly more opaque than regular screening, but that means nothing to me because regular screening won't survive one night.  So far, I'm very happy!

I will qualify this review by saying that I've only had the Freud SD508 Dado stack for a few weeks.  In that time, I've used it to make dado cuts in Baltic birch plywood, HD 'sand ply' plywood, hard maple, yellow birch, poplar, MDF and MDF with laminate.  In all of these materials, I was impressed with the flatness of the bottom of the dado and the clean edges at the top of the cut.  The outside blades do leave a light scoring mark in the bottom of the cut, but that's about it to my eye.I made some dados that were wider than the maximum stack, requiring multiple passes to get the width.  Even with these dados, the only visible-to-the-naked-eye marks were the light scoring of the outside blades.I am very happy that this set includes a 3/32" chipper.  Cutting dados to fit 'standard' plywood thicknesses is much easier.  I also like having perfectly sized steel spacers in increments of 0.004".  Much better than using paper or plastic shims.  The first thing I did was to mark the thickness on each shim and chipper with a sharpie. I can be a bit dyslexic at times, so I also marked the 2 outside blades with an L and R.  Makes it much quicker to set up a stack.I was particularly impressed when I cut a 1 1/4" wide X 1/2" deep dado for an INCRA Miter Channel - 32" in a 27" x 36" router table top.  I made the top from a double thickness of 3/4" MDF edged with 3/4" poplar and with 1/16" laminate glued to it.  I checked the surface flatness of the  laminate with a straightedge and feeler gauges before I made the cut and it was flat within 0.010".  The cut with the Freud dado stack produced no chipping of the laminate at all; the edges were sharp and clean.  I want to qualify that a bit because I did take some precautions with these cuts.  I used a zero clearance insert on my table saw, and cut the exact slot width with the cutters I was using.  I also used a sacrificial board clamped against the exit side of the dado to prevent any blow out of the poplar or laminate.  And of course the dado stack was quite sharp, being relatively new.  I also took the precaution of running the first 3/4" wide cut down the center of the slot, checking the edges, and then enlarging the slot in both directions.  After that first cut, I ran a piece of blue tape across the corner of the exit end, for extra insurance.  It all worked and the bottom of the dado was very smooth, with 2 light score marks.  From end to end, the width of the slot varied by 0.004".Other reviewers have dinged this set because of the low quality of the box it comes in.  I agree that it is poor quality, particularly the red, blow molded insert, which arrived cracked and a bit shredded, but still useable.  Personally, I would prefer to have Freud put their money into the dado stack, not the box.  These things are expensive enough; I don't really want to pay even more for a better box.  If it really bothers me in the future, I might make my own *really beautiful* box, but I probably won't.

I wasn't expecting too much from the Hyundai HPA-TIG tire inflator, given it's relatively low cost.  When it arrived, I was impressed with the fit, finish and heft of it.  It just feels well built and solid in my hand.I used it to inflate the tires in my Savana van, which calls for 80 PSI in the rear and 50 PSI in the front.  The attachment clip did an excellent job of holding on to the tire valve while I was inflating the tires, so it's an easy one-handed operation.  The action of the trigger and valve was smooth and positive.Other reviewers have complained about the 0 - 180 PSI range of the included gauge, but I didn't find it to be a deal killer.  I checked the 8 - 10  pressures I read against my digital gauge and found that the HPA-TIG gauge read consistently 2 - 3 PSI low.  I don't really know if my digital gauge is any more accurate than the HPA-TIG's  analog gauge, but at least there was a consistent difference between them.  I suppose that I could replace the gauge with a better one, but I doubt I will, unless it breaks at some point in the future.This is only day 1 with this inflator and I have no way to know how it will stand up over time, but right out of the package, I'm very happy with it.  I gave it 5 stars not because I think it's the best tire inflator out there, but because it's great value for the money spent.

I like to have a box fan in my bedroom window when the weather is right for it.  Set on low speed, the white noise of the fan masks distracting sounds and the air movement is helpful for sleeping.  When my ancient box fan developed an alloying ticking sound on low speed, I knew it had to go.I got the Lasko 3720 because of the good reviews, low sound rating and weather resistant construction.  I've had it for a week now, and I like it quite a lot.  The one thing that bothered me at first was that, when set to low, the fan turns faster than my old box fan.  I think this may be due to the size and shape of the fan blades.  The blades on my old fan were larger and rounder, so I imagine it could move more air at a lower speed.  The higher speed of the Lasko means that the woosh of air movement is a bit louder than I would like.  I'm getting used to it, and have no intention of looking for a fan with a slower turning low speed.

I bought this adapter to use with the 2 1/2" x 10' Clear Flex Hose sold by Peachtree.  This hose is not as described, and you can look at my review to see the details.The OD of the large end of this adapter measures 2.480", and the OD of the small end measures 2.244".  Both ends are tapered, so the measurements are only approximate.The large end can be forced into the ID of the Peachtree hose and the small end will fit in a typical 2 1/4" shop vac port or into a 2 1/2" x 4" adapter.  If you buy the Peachtree hose, you will probably want 2 of these Woodstock W2046 adapters.

UPDATE 05/15/2014:  The jury has returned and the verdict is: I hate this hose.  I gave it 3 stars in my original review and now I'm reducing it to 1 star.  The 2 1/2" adapters I mentioned in my initial review only barely fit.  It takes way too much force to insert them and with almost no effort, they pop right off.  The snap-out/snap-in nature of the hose it just annoying.  It just won't go where I want it and stay put.  When the hose coils snap shut, a flap of clear plastic protrudes into the ID, making it impossible to insert a fitting and inhibiting air flow.  I was so put out that I bought a 15' length of 'normal' 2 1/2" clear flex hose and I an much happier with it.ORIGINAL REVIEW: I ordered this hose to use with my shop dust collection system, thinking I would be receiving the item shown in the Amazon photo: a clear, flexible plastic hose about 10' long.  What I got was something very different.The hose that Peachtree is now selling is what I would call a 'snap open', 'snap closed' hose.  It it's collapsed state it is about 32" long.  When you pull on it, the coils snap open, one by one.  You can open as many as you want, at any place along the length of the hose.  Fully extended, my hose measured just over 11 feet long.The ID of the hose is difficult to measure.  When collapsed, I measured approximately 2.4".  I was not able to  get the hose ID over the OD of my 2 1/2" X 4" adapters, which measure 2.535".  I was able to use a Woodstock W2046 2-1/2-Inch Hose Adapter for W2049 Cyclone Separator from Amazon that measures 2.480" OD on one end and 2.244" on the other.  The large end of this adapter can be pushed into the ID of the hose and the small end will fit in a typical 2 1/4" shop vac port or in the ID of a 2 1/2" x 4" adapters.  If you buy this hose, I suggest you get 2 of these adapters, one for each end.I gave the hose only 3 stars because it isn't the product depicted in the photos and it's a bit difficult to use.  I do like the fact that it is sort of self-storing.  If the hose were fully 10' long all the time, in some situations I would either have to cut it or deal with the excess hose.  With the 'snap out' design, I can pull out only the amount of hose I need for a given situation.  I have no idea whether the hose will lose this ability over time.For me, the jury is still out on this hose.  I would have preferred a more typical hose, but I am willing to give this one a try and see how it goes.  I will update the review then I have more experience with it.

I bought the Oneida Molded DIY Dust Deputy Cyclone to collect the sawdust and shavings in my garage workshop and needed a drum to go with it.  The Eagle 1610MB was the right size, capacity and price.  It's pretty heavy duty and has no trouble coping with the vacuum produced by my shop vac.The top is sturdy and has a tapered edge shape that forms an excellent seal with the drum.  The steel band will keep the top firmly in place, but for my use, I really don't need it because the negative pressure generated by my shop vac holds the top firmly in place.  I did reinforce the underside of the top with a piece of 1/2" plywood, but that was more to stabilize the Dust Deputy than to add strength to the top.I used an old dolly and some scrap wood to build a frame-on-wheels to hold my shop vac and the drum and posted some photos of the results.  The system works well and 95+% of the sawdust and shavings end up in the drum.

I have a small garage woodworking shop.  With only about 250 square feet to work with, space is at a premium.  I need dust collection, and for a for a few years I've been using a 6 gallon Rigid shop vac to collect the sawdust and shavings from my table saw, planer, jointer, band saw, and various hand tools.  There are a couple of problems with this solution.  The small capacity of the shop vac means that I have to empty it frequently, especially when using it with the planer.  Because it is a single stage, the filter becomes clogged quickly.  I've had larger shops in the past, with central dust collection, so I know how effective cyclone separators are at reducing the load on filters.After a bit of research, I settled on the Oneida Dust Deputy.  It seemed a good match for my Rigid shop vac, but I didn't like any of the Oneida options for collection buckets.  The 5 gallon plastic bucket seemed too small.  The 10 gallon steel drum seemed like a better size, but both seemed way over priced.  I decided to go with the DIY option and find a suitable drum.The drum I chose is the Eagle 1610MB Blue High Density Polyethylene Lab Pack Drum with Metal Lever-lock Lid, 14 gallon Capacity, 26.5" Height, 15" Diameter.  I like the 14 gallon capacity and the relatively small 15" diameter.  Because of my limited floor space, I chose to locate the drum above my shop vac, rather than beside it.  I built a frame to support the drum (which has a convenient step in the OD about 2/3 of the way up the side) and attached it to the an old 18" x 22"  dolly that I wasn't using.  The vac rides on the dolly and the drum is suspended 1" above it, with the Dust Deputy on top.  The whole thing is about 19" x 24" x 66" high (75" with a loop of hose into the top of the Dust Deputy) and fits easily in a footprint not much larger than the shop vac alone.  I'll post some photos.My results with the Dust Deputy and 14 gallon drum are very good.  The system seems to be very tight (no leaks).  I tested the system by using it to clean out the base of my Delta cabinet saw, which hadn't been cleaned completely in quite a while.  I vacuumed using a Bosch VAC005 5-Meter Vacuum Hose 35mm, sucking the sawdust as fast as the system would take it.  There was enough sawdust to fill the drum nearly to the top.  I estimate that it contained 12-13 gallons when I was done.  I then opened the shop vac and found about 1/2 gallon of sawdust in it, so the Dust Deputy separated about 95% of the material and left it in the drum.I've noticed that some very light shavings, like the ones from my jointer, have a tendency to become suspended at the top of the cyclone, spinning and spinning.  They don't go into the shop vac, but they don't go into the drum until I shut the shop vac off.  I haven't made enough of these light shavings to know if this will overload the cyclone eventually.The Dust Deputy is simple and well made.  It is made from 2 pieces of a thermoplastic material that appear to be welded ultrasonically.  It does flex a bit at the flange when attached to the drum top.  It probably will survive well in my shop, but I doubt that it would take a lot of abuse.  I knocked off one star because, IMO, the selling price is too high for this item.  That said, I didn't find anything else in the market that would do the same job at a lower cost.
I bought some 304 Stainless Steel piano hinge and needed some screws for it.  These to the trick and are quite a bargain.

I've seen plenty of piano hinges that were too flimsy for nearly any purpose.  I needed some hinge for a chop saw stand in my workshop and liked that this is stainless steel, so I tried it.  I used it in 3 places on my stand and so far, it's working well.  Since it's stainless, I know that it won't rust in the places I cut it.If you buy this hinge, you may also be interested in Stainless Steel Sheet Metal Screw, Plain Finish, Flat Head, Phillips Drive, Self-Drilling Point, Right Hand Threads, Inch.  The table listing the screw sizes for the hinge say to use #4 screws, but you should ignore that because the #6-20 screws work perfectly with the hinge.  I used the 3/4" length, but they are also available in a 1 1/4" length.  They are called sheet metal screws, but they worked well in plywood.  They have a self drilling point, but I pre-drilled the holes.

I needed a 24" high stool for occasional use in my workshop.  I have little space to spare, so I wanted something compact and foldable.  The TG82-0827 does the trick for me.  Note that the 24" seat height is right for a 36" high table or bench, but too high for a 29" - 30" high dining table and too low for a 40" - 42" high bar.When I opened the box, I noticed right away that the cardboard label was sandwiched between the seat and the frame.  In order to remove it completely, I turned the seat upside down and removed 2 of the seat screws and slipped the label out.  Then I replaced the screws and all was good.I can't say what the weight limit is for this stool, but it is sturdy enough for my 175 pounds.  Anything over 200 pounds might be risky.  I like that there is a spring loaded pin that snaps into place when you unfold the stool.  It will prevent an accidental collapse.There isn't much padding on the seat, so it isn't too comfortable for long periods of use.  If I needed to use it for hours at a time, I would probably either use a cushion on top or remove the seat and add some padding to it.It's a decent, no frills stool that's great for occasional extra seating.

I bought this ground bar kit to use with Siemens S2024B1100 100 Amp, 20 Space, 24 Circuit, Indoor Main Breaker Load Center, with Copper Bus Bars that I had purchased previously.  When I received the panel, I discovered that it contained no ground bar.  I need a ground bar because I was using the load center as a sub-panel, which requires separate bars for neutral and ground.  So, I lost a few more days while I waited for the ground bar to arrive.The EC2GB152 ground bar kit works perfectly with the S20224B1100 panel.  The mounting holes are already in the panel, so no drilling or tapping is needed.

I really have no business owning a conduit bender, but I needed to add some surface mounted outlet boxes in my shop and decided to do it myself, using 1/2" and 3/4" EMT.  I used a piece of 3/4", schedule 40 threaded pipe, about 60" long, for the handle.  This worked, but I bent it a bit before I was finished with the project.It took me a while to learn how to use the bender and get the conduit bends in the right place.  If you're new to conduit bending, I suggest watching a couple of the many Youtube videos on the subject before you start.  I thought that using the bender seemed pretty easy, so I didn't bother watching any of  the videos until I was ready to give up in frustration.  Also, buy a couple of extra lengths of conduit, because you're bound to mess up a few times.

I bought 4 sets of these slides to use in a rolling cabinet in my workshop.  They work smoothly and support all the weight I could put in a 30" W x 23" D x 8" H drawer with ease.  To remove the drawers from the slides, there is a lever that must be depressed.  The levers are very effective in preventing the drawers from coming off the rails unless you want to remove them.I wanted to make the drawers as deep as possible.  My cabinet is 23 and 3/4" deep, so I made the drawers 23".  Since the only slides I could get were 22", I wanted over-travel slides.  The over-travel on these slides is about 1", so every bit of the drawer is visible when fully open.My one quibble with these slides is that the "positive stop" that is supposed to prevent accidental roll out is very weak.  It doesn't take much for the drawers to overpower this stop.  In my application, a rolling cabinet, these stops are completely inadequate to prevent drawer rollout when I move the cabinet.  I made a more effective drawer lock by making an L shaped piece and attaching it to the side of the cabinet with a piece of piano hinge.  To lock the drawers closed, I swing this piece so that the L shape rests against the front and side of the drawers.  I swing it out of the way when I want to open the drawers.

I use a lot of very loud woodworking and construction tools and equipment.  I also suffer from hearing loss that happened with I was younger and wasn't very careful about using ear protection.  That damage isn't going to heal, but I want to do everything I can to prevent further noise-related hearing loss.I've used many different types of earmuff and ear plug protectors.  I've mostly bought less expensive earmuffs and never thought that they worked as well as the plugs, so I've tended to use the plugs.  Although they're effective, I find wearing ear plugs uncomfortable.  I also tend to lose them when I remove them periodically when I'm working.I recently bought the 3M Peltor X-Series Over-the-Head earmuffs, hoping that, with a NRR of 31, it would be more effective than the muffs I've used in the past.  I've been using it for a couple of days and I'm very happy with it.  The Peltor is very light weight and comfortable.  It seals extremely well around my ears, even while wearing Dewalt DPG59-115C Reinforcer Rx-Bifocal 1.5 Clear Lens High Performance Protective Safety Glasses with Rubber Temples and Protective Eyeglass Sleeve, which I also recommend highly if you use reading glasses.  The noise reduction is extremely effective; subjectively, I would say that it is as good as with the ear plugs I've been using.  The 3M Peltor is bulky, but not heavy.  I've worn it for several hours at a stretch without tiring.Bottom line is that I probably won't be using ear plugs very often any more.

I needed to drill a lot of bolt holes in 6 x 6 and 8 x 8 pressure treated timbers. I bought this bit expecting that the job would be slow and difficult.  Much to my amazement,  the bit went through the timbers like a hot knife through butter.  There was almost no need to woodpecker it to clear the chips.  I am extremely happy with this product.

I replaced a Creative Home Satin Splendor Metallic 2.8 Quart Whistling Tea Kettle, Cranberry with the Chef's Secret.  After 3 years, the old tea pot looked terrible, with heat marks and chips in the finish.The Chef's Secret Stainless Kettle looks amazing.  The shape is beautiful, the handle is comfortable and for the most part remains cool enough to handle without a pot holder.  The kettle seems well designed and constructed and it heats water to a boil on the large burner of my gas stove very quickly.  The spring on the pour spout closure is quite firm, but it snaps open easily when I pull the handle.  My one concern when I first got the kettle was that there is no way to leave the spout closure open, but this hasn't been a problem for me.I've had the kettle for about 6 months and it's still just as beautiful and functional as it was on the first day.  Due to the materials and build quality, I'm pretty confident this kettle is going to last a long time.The fill top fits well and requires a little push to get it all the way on.  If I don't push it all the way, sometimes enough steam will escape from the gap to prevent the whistle from sounding.  Since you can't leave the spout closure open, leaving the fill top slightly ajar will kill the whistle, if it annoys you.A few months after I bought the kettle, I accidentally let the water boil away completely.  When I came back to the kitchen, the kettle was extremely hot and there were heat stains on the stainless surface.  Fortunately, the stains cleaned up very nicely with some Bar Keepers Friend® Cleanser & Polish: 12 OZ and elbow grease.

I replaced an older head light with the Energizer Pro 3 LED Headlamp.  The old one used 3 AA batteries, was very bulky, weighed a ton, was uncomfortable and ate batteries like crazy.The energizer pro is everything that my old one was not.  First off, it uses AAA batteries, not AA's, which reduced the weight considerably.  The lamp head is light, compact and very comfortable.  The light and switch housing pivot so that you can put the light exactly where you want it.  Light itself is quite bright and the built-in lens does a good job focusing the beam.  At a distance of 6 feet, the spot diameter is about 34", and it plenty bright for walking at night.  The L:ED bulbs mean that battery life will be improved.  I've used it about 20 hours and I'm still on the first set of batteries.The switch on the Energizer Pro has 3 positions.  Center = off; right = white light; left = red light.  The red light is useful indoors if you want to see where you're going, but don't want to kill your night vision when you turn the light off.

I'm using the Dell AX510 sound bar on a Dell UltraSharp U2413 24" LED LCD Monitor - 16:10 - 6 ms , replacing a pair of speakers that I've had sitting on my desk.Installation is very quick and easy: just snap it in place, plug the power cord into the back of the monitor and plug the signal cable into your sound card.  Note that the power cable is for 12V.  There is no line voltage cord.On the right side of the bar is a combo on/off/volume knob.  In the center of the bar is a discrete white LED indicator that is lit when the bar is powered.The sound quality isn't going to blow you away, but It's at least as good as the desk top speakers I replaced and fine if you keep the volume down.  I really like not having the speakers on my desk.I'm giving it 5 stars not because it's the best speaker I've ever heard, but because it's very well designed and for $20, I don't think you can beat it.

I used the Dico 120 grit brush to clean the tile grout and fixtures in my bathtub/shower surround.  There was plenty of mold on the tiles and grout and the handles and spouts had mineral deposits.  The brush was effective in removing the mold.  The polished fixtures came out looking like new.I also wanted to remove and replace the existing caulk at the tub/tile joint.  Removing the caulk was a lot more work than I would have thought.  I cut it with a box cutter and used a scraper to remove the bulk of it.  The Dico Nyalox brush was almost useless when it came to removing the last stuck on bits of caulk.  I ended up using a wire brush for that, and even then it took a lot of pressure and time.The Dico Nyalox Cup Brush 120 grit is great when you want to scrub and polish gently, without scratching.  It isn't aggressive enough to remove really stuck on material.

The knives are very sharp, well machined and do what they're supposed to do.I have 2 quibbles with these Delta replacement parts.  First is that the price is pretty high for the product, but I guess that's what you're going to find with an OEM replacement part.  Second thing is that they could supply these with a sharpened edge on both sides so that you could just flip them over when they need replacement.I recommend using a Rockler Magnetic Jointer Jig (or equal) to set these knives. The jig makes the process go much more quickly.

I'm using these receptacles in wooden lamp bases, to provide power for a laptop or cell phone charger.  I chose the single receptacle because they can be mounted through a 1 3/8" diameter round hole, which is a lot easier to make than the hole shape for a duplex receptacle.  They are well made and work well, but it does take quite a bit of force to insert and remove the plug.  Maybe they will loosen up over time.

UPDATE: I can confirm that I went through the initialization process described in the dimmer instructions and that the tiny slide switch on the dimmer was in the "CFL" position during my test.The first CFL bulb I tested was a 13W "Bright Effects" brand.  I also tried a 14W CFL bulb with the "Revision" brand, with similar results.  I purchased both of these bulbs several years ago, and I saw in the dimmer instructions that "dimmable CFL bulbs" are recommended/required.  I went to my local big box store to buy a CFL bulb specifically identified as dimmable, but of the dozens they had, none claimed to be dimmable.  I don't know what to make of that.I also tried the dimmer with a Phillips LED bulb and it worked well with that; similar to its performance with an incandescent bulb.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I bought this dimmer because it said that it would work with incandescent, CFL and LED lights.With incandescent bulbs, the light is dimly visible at the minimum setting and smoothly transitions to full brightness in proportion to the position of the slider.With CFL bulbs, I had 2 different results.  With only a CFL in the fixture, the bulb flashes on and off when the slider goes from 0% to 50%.  From 50% - 100%, it was fully on, no dimming.  With a combination of one incandescent bulb and one CFL bulb in the fixture, the CFL bulb stayed very dim from 0% to 50% and then was fully on from 50% to 100%, while the incandescent bulb behaved normally.I bought 2 of these and one of them had a defective slider, which did not move smoothly, but stuck at several points.  I returned that one and received a replacement with a working slider.  It still will not work with a CFL though.I will keep the dimmer because I do have a use for incandescent dimming, but I am disappointed that it will not work with CFL.

A couple of words of caution.  A jointer is inherently dangerous.  BE SURE TO UNPLUG IT BEFORE DOING ANYTHING WITH THE KNIVES!  The knives are very sharp; don't touch the cutting edge with your bare hands.  Be sure to double check the locking bolts on all the knives before starting it up.  After replacing the knives, make sure to replace the guard before starting the machine.  Stand behind the machine fence when starting it for the first time after changing knives.The following is not a complete description of every aspect of replacing and setting jointer knives. Read the owner's manual for your jointer and the instructions that come with the Rockler jig.  I have a Delta 6 inch jointer and use the Rockler jig to set the knives.Setting the knives on a jointer has some aspects that are not precise.  One of the first things you do, whether using the Rockler jig not, is locate the 'top dead center' of the knives.  That is, the point at which the cutting edge of the knife reaches its highest point while the head rotates.  The usual way to do it is to place a straightedge on the outfeed table, projecting out over the cutter head and rotate the cutter head by hand until the knife edge just touches the straightedge.  With the Rockler jig, the straightedge is replaced by the magnetic bars, but the principle is the same.Finding TDC sounds pretty straightforward when you read about it, but the reality is a bit different.  First, the outfeed table has to be exactly level with the knife when it's at TDC, something that's inherently not exact.  Second, the knife is going to be approaching the straightedge tangentially, which means it's difficult to say precisely when it touches the straightedge.  Third, it's difficult to see the spot where the knife touches the straightedge, no matter how much light you use and how you position it.  Once you think you know where TDC is, you scribe a mark on the fence to locate it.  The fence itself is not a precision device.  The next time you want to use that TDC mark, the fence will probably not be in the exact same position that it was when you made the mark.In a word, mushy.Once you locate TDC, the Rockler jig does make the inexact process of setting the individual knives much faster.The process is fairly simple. Loosen and remove the knives and locking bars.  Thoroughly clean the cutterhead slots and locking bars.  At this time I also spray Boeshield T-9 Lubricant on all the parts to prevent rust and to ensure that the new knives will slide freely in the slots during the setting process.  Loosely place a new knife and locking bar in a slot, making sure that it's centered from side to side.  The locking bolts need to be in very light contact with the cutterhead slot, just to keep the knife in the correct position.  The knife must be free to slide up and down, and if it doesn't, that means the locking bolts are too tight.Tip: With the Rockler jig, you don't need to use the jacking screws under the knives as you do in conventional knife setting.  Back them off a bit so that they won't inadvertently limit the travel of the knife in the slot.Place the Rockler jig in position, with the scribe line on the bar aligned with the TDC line you made on the fence.  Rotate the cutterhead until the cutting edge of the knife is right at the TDC line on the jig.  If all is right, the knife will snap up to the magnet on the bar and stay there.  I suggest using a small piece of wood to push down on the knife edge, letting the magnet pull it back into position a couple of times to make sure that it moves freely and that it's exactly where it should be.  You can't do this unless you've backed off the jacking screws.  Lightly snug the 2 locking bolts closest to the center of the knife.  Rotate the cutterhead back and forth and observe the knife when it reaches TDC.  It should just barely touch the Rockler jig bar, but not move it.  If the jig bar moves, the knife is too high; loosen the locking bolts and reset the knife.  Once the knife is in the correct position, snug all of the locking bolts and then tighten them with force.  Double check the knife position with the Rockler jig.Go through the same procedure with the remaining knives.  Double check every locking bolt on every knife to make sure they are tight before plugging in the machine and turning it on.Once you get the hang of using the Rockler jig, the process is fairly fast, compared to setting the knives with only a straightedge. The end result may be no more precise, but you will get there faster.  I'm happy to have the jig and there is no doubt I will use it because it is faster.

I have the Bosch ROS65VC-6 6-Inch Pad Rear-Handle Random Orbit Sander with Vibration Control sander. It comes with this medium-soft backing pad, part number RS6045, which is fine for general purpose sanding.When I need to sand a contoured surface, I switch to the New Bosch 6-hole Hook & Loop Backing Pad RS6044 Tool because it's softer and conforms to the contours without gouging.When I need to sand a flat surface and want to minimize edge rounding over, I switch to the hard backing pad Bosch RS6046 6" Hard Backing Pad.The pads are quick and ease to change with an allen wrench.

I have the Bosch ROS65VC-6 6-Inch Pad Rear-Handle Random Orbit Sander with Vibration Control sander.  It comes with the medium-soft backing pad (Brand New Bosch RS6045 6-Hole Hook & Loop Backing Pad), which is fine for general purpose sanding.  When I need to sand a contoured surface, I switch to the RS6044 because it's softer and conforms to the contours without gouging.When I need to sand a flat surface and want to minimize edge rounding over, I switch to the Bosch RS6046 6" Hard Backing Pad.The pads are quick and easy to change with an allen wrench.

I have the Bosch ROS65VC-6 6-Inch Pad Rear-Handle Random Orbit Sander with Vibration Control sander, which comes with a medium-soft backing pad ( Brand New Bosch RS6045 6-Hole Hook & Loop Backing Pad).  This is a fine general purpose pad, but it does tend to round over the edges when I sand flat pieces.  The RS6046 hard backing pad minimizes edge rounding.For sanding contoured surfaces, I use the extra soft New Bosch 6-hole Hook & Loop Backing Pad RS6044 Tool because it conforms to the surface and minimizes gouging.The pads are quick and easy to change with an allen wrench.

I have a lot of woodworking machinery and tools and use Boesheld T-9 along with wax to keep the rust off my steel and cast iron parts.  Here in SO FL, the heat, humidity and salt air are a lethal combination for ferrous metals.  I have to reapply T-9 and wax monthly to keep the oxides of iron at bay, but it's worth the trouble.  Since T-9 is wax based, it's compatible with woodworking activities.Bottom line: it just works.

UPDATE 30 March 2014:I bought a second iGaging DigiMAG 6" DRO to use with my INCRA Mast-R-Lift-II Router Lift. The installation was pretty easy, but you will need a 3mm tap to do it.  I bought the Irwin Tools 2712- 3 Piece Set - 3.0 mm - 0.50 mm because the holes drilled in the top plate should not go all the way through so at least 2 taps are required, one tapered and a bottoming.  I drilled and tapped 2 holes in the router clamping piece and did the same for 2 holes in the backside of the main plate and used the 3mm screws that come with the DigiMAG to attach the scale to the plate and the slider to the clamping piece.  Be very careful not to over torque the tap when you tap the holes in the plate.  It's very easy to strip a thread in aluminum when tapping a blind hole.The advantage of using a DRO in a router table is that you can zero the readout at any point and then make your cutter bit height adjustments from there.  You also have the option to use decimal inches, mm or fractional inches with the push of a button.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I've had a Jet 15" planer (similar to JET 708538 JWP-15DX: 15 CS Planer with Quick Change Knives, but without the quick change knives) for about 14 years and recently I installed new knives and adjusted the cutter head, feed rolls and chip breaker.  After the adjustments, the thickness across a 12" board is within 0.001" from edge to edge and the planed surface is like glass.I've been thinking about putting a DRO on the planer for a long time, and once I had it running well, it seemed like a good time to do it. I didn't do a ton of research, but the iGaging DigiMAG seemed to be just what I wanted, at a very reasonable price.  I particularly liked the remote readout and preferred it to the DRO designs that have the display on the sliding unit.  It's just much easier to read the display when you can put it anywhere you want.Installing the sensing unit on the Jet planer was relatively simple because I was able to use existing tapped holes in the base, movable platen and top unit to attach brackets.  I used a piece of 1 1/2" x 1 1/2" x 12 1/2" long aluminum angle to span between the top and base and attached one of the Z brackets supplied with the DigiMAG to the platen. I mounted the measuring scale and attached the sliding unit to the bracket.  The readout display has magnets on the back, so it will stick securely to almost any part of the planer.  I have mine stuck to the top, where it's easy to read.Another reviewer pointed out that for a planer, the product you want is 35-706P, not 35-706 because of the 'preset' function (thank you Ronald Haefner "Haefdog").  IMO, this feature is essential for getting the best use out of the DRO.  In practice, it works like this: plane a board to any thickness; measure the thickness with a digital or dial caliper to the nearest 0.001" (average of the readings for both edges); enter this into the display with the 'preset' function (explained in the instructions); press 0/Set and that calibrates the entire system to the cut you just made.  After that, you can choose to have the display show MM, fractional inches or decimal inches.I installed the unit with the cable attached to the sliding section facing toward the planer, to keep it out of the way.  When I did this, the display reads the movement of the platen as negative, so a 3/4" thickness will show up as - 3/4" or -0.750.  No problem with this, but it meant that I have to enter the 'preset' thickness as a negative number, not positive.After going through the preset procedure, which takes just a couple of minutes, I am easily able to have my planed boards come out with in +/- 0.002" of the DRO setting.  I am so happy!I've only been using the DRO for a couple of days, so I can't speak to the durability in my shop, but I will update the review in the future, when I have more experience with it.I'll post a photo of the installation when I figure out how to do it.UPDATE 28 SEPTEMBER 2014:I've been using the iGaging DRO on my planer for about 9 months and it continues to be the best thing ever.  In the 9 months I've been using it, I've calibrated it just one time.  Ever since then, I just turn on the display before I use the planer, crank the thickness to where I want it and run the boards through.This week, I planed a bunch of 2" Western Red Cedar to a thickness of 1 9/16" (1.562") in several stages, removing about 1/32" with each pass.  After the final pass, I checked several boards with a digital caliper and found them all to be within +/- 0.002" of my target.Having the iGaging DRO on the planer has changed the way I use it.  Before I had it, setting the thickness was a hit-or-miss (mostly miss) proposition.  It usually took so long to get it just right that I did everything I could to minimize the number of times I had to change the setting.  I have a small shop and if I had to plane long, wide, thick boards, I sometimes ran into real problems trying to move and stack the boards as I worked them down to the final thickness.  With the DRO, changing the setting is so quick and easy, that it's no problem to work a single board through several thicknesses and then go on to another one, which makes material handling much easier.Another thing that's very nice is that I no longer have to think about backlash in the adjusting gears as I change thicknesses.  Without the DRO, I would have to be careful to move the platen in the same direction every time because of the backlash.  With the DRO, the measurement on the display is always accurate, whether I'm moving the platen up or down.  So slick!
I've used it in hard wood, aluminum, cast iron and steel without any problems with chatter.  Good for both countersinking and deburring.  Reasonably priced, good quality.

Pros:Easy to installCan be easily removed without tools for cleaningCloses slowly without noiseFun to watch for the first 100 times, or soLooks greatCons:If you buy only one of these and place it on the toilet you use most often, it's a pretty good bet that eventually you will use another toilet and forget that it doesn't slow-close and you'll wake up every person and beast in the house when it bangs down.

Pros:Light weightSmall physical sizeBright, with a variable spot sizeDoesn't need a cordHas a strong magnetic base that will stick to any tool with steel or cast iron partsYou can point the light where you want it and it stays put, even with vibrationLED, so batteries will last a long timeInexpensive compared to the corded alternativesCan easily be removed from the arm and used as a flashlightCons:None I've found so farI've used it on my drill press, hollow chisel mortiser, band saw and table saw.  Even though my chop saw has an aluminum body, I may be able to stick it to a steel clamp attached to the fence.My first impulse was to buy one for every tool, but it's so easy to move that I will probably just get 1 or 2 more.

I bought the Kreg bench dogs to use with an Eclipse 10" Quick Release Vise.  Let's face it, bench dogs do a fairly pedestrian job and these dogs to it well.  They're light weight and hold a wood piece without marking it.  The bench brakes are a bonus. Why pay 3 - 4 times as much?  A dog's a dog and that's all.

I've wanted a Record 52 1/2 vise for years, but never could justify the cost.  I finally decided to get one, only to discover that they're no longer made.  No problem I thought, I'll find one on Ebay.  Unfortunately, the Record vise now seems to be a collector's item and a decent used one commands a higher price than they were when sold new.  After some more research, I discovered that the Record tooling for the vise had been sold to an Indian company, and the Indian product was being distributed in the US by Woodcraft at a very reasonable price.I ordered one and waited, hoping that the product would be well made and fully functional.  The package arrived a bit beat up, which is what you might expect when you put a 35 pound, cast iron and steel vise in a cardboard box.  The vise itself was undamaged and looked good, if a bit oily.If you do a search for 'installing an eclipse vise', you will find a great article on how to install this vise on a bench.  The author suggested disassembling the vise to clean and install it and I highly recommend doing it this way because of the weight and size.  I used the flush-mount method and am very happy with the results.At one point during my installation, the rear jaw of the vise (which probably weighs 7-8 pounds) fell off the bench and hit the concrete floor with a loud bang.  I winced and wondered if I had broken it.  Not to worry; there was a little chip in the paint, but the only damage was a chunk taken out of the floor.  Solid!The Eclipse vise works very well and seems to be a worthy successor to Record.  The fast action is smooth and sure and the screw does what it's supposed to do.  It's huge! Even with 3/4" thick wood jaws added, the opening is 14".  One nice feature of this vise is that the jaws are not parallel from top to bottom when they are not squeezing something.  As you apply pressure, the support rods bend slightly as they are loaded.  When this happens, the jaws deflect slightly and become parallel.  Genius!I'm using the Eclipse at then end of my bench and so I drilled a series of 3/4" holes for bench dogs, in line with the retractable dog in the movable jaw of the vise.  I used Kreg Tool Company KKS1070 Kreg Bench Dogs and am very happy with them.
